http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12818v1.title: EDGE: The shape of dark matter haloes in the faintest galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12818v1.summary: Study of dwarf galaxies with gas mass fractions of 0.06%. Gas cooling transforms the central DM shape to be rounder and more oblate. Most simulated dwarfs have significant radial velocity anisotropy that rises to 0.5. This could provide a new and robust test of DM models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12805v1.title: JADES: Discovery of extremely high equivalent width Lyman-alpha emission from a faint galaxy within an ionized bubble at $z=7.3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12805v1.summary: JADES-GS+53.16746-27.7720 (shortened to JADes-GS-z7-LA) is a galaxy with a redshift of 7.278. The Ly$\alpha$ line is detected in both lower resolution ($R\sim100$) PRISM as well as medium resolution ($ R\sim1000$) G140M grating spectra. It peaks within $120$km s$^{-1}$ of the systemic redshift, indicative of very little neutral gas or dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12788v1.title: The interplay between accretion, galaxy downsizing and the formation of box/peanut bulges in TNG50
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12788v1.summary: From the TNG50 cosmological simulation we build a sample of 191 well-resolved grotesquebarred galaxies. We search for box/peanut bulges (BPs) in this sample, finding them in 55\% of cases. Half of BP galaxies show clear signs of buckling, despite the excessive heating and limited vertical resolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12704v1.title: The stellar population responsible for a kiloparsec size superbubble seen in the JWST "phantom" images of NGC628
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12704v1.summary: The superbubble is the largest of manyholes seen in the early release images using JWST/MIRI filters that trace the Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbon (PAH) emissions. The bubble is located in the interarm region 3 kpc from the galactic center in the south-east direction. It contains as much as 2x10% of mass in gas mostly in molecular form.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12687v1.title: Study of central light distribution in nearby early-type galaxies hosting nuclear star clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12687v1.summary: Central IntensityRatio (CIR$_I$) determined from near-infra-red (3.6 $\mu$m) observations. CIR shows a positive trend with faint, low mass, and blue galaxies in the sample. The opposite is true for bright, high-mass, and red galaxies, albeit with large scatter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11977v2.title: AGN feedback in an infant galaxy cluster: the LOFAR-Chandra view of the giant FRII radio galaxy J103025+052430 at z=1.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11977v2.summary: Jets from AGN are observed to have a dramatic impact on their surrounding extragalactic environment. Their effect at the `cosmic midday' (z>1.5) is instead much less constrained. We present a study of the giant (750 kpc) radiogalaxy 103025+052430 at redshift z=1.7.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12657v1.title: Jets in FR0 radio galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12657v1.summary: The local radio-loud AGN population is dominated by compact sources namedFR0s. These sources show features, for example the host type, the mass of the supermassive black hole (SMBH), and the multi-band nuclear characteristics, similar to those of FRI radio galaxies. However, in the radio band, while FR0 and FRI share the same nuclear properties, the kiloparsec-scale component dominant in FRI is missing in FR0.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02313v3.title: MIRI/JWST observations reveal an extremely obscured starburst in the z=6.9 system SPT0311-58
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02313v3.summary: Using MIRI on-board JWST we present mid-infrared sub-arcsec imaging (MIRIM) and spectroscopy (MRS) of the hyperluminous infrared system SPT0311-58 atz=6.9. The MIRIM observations reveal a clumpy stellar structure, with each clump having 3 to 5 pounds of mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12560v1.title: Assessing model-based carbon and oxygen abundance derivation from ultraviolet emission lines in AGNs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12560v1.summary: We present an adapted version of the code HII-CHI-Mistry-UV to derive chemical abundances from emission lines in Active Galactic Nuclei. We evaluate different ultraviolet emission line ratios. We show that deriving the carbon-to-oxygen abundance ratio using CIII] and OIII] emission lines is a robust indicator of metal content.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12540v1.title: A multi-wavelength view of Active Galactic Nuclei with an emphasis on gamma-rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12540v1.summary: Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) are remarkable astronomical sources emitting over the whole electromagnetic spectrum. Different bands provide uniquewindows on distinct sub-structures and their related physics. AGN come in a large number of types only partially related to intrinsic differences. I highlight here the most important AGN classes, namely jetted and non-jetted,radiatively efficient and inefficient, and face-on and edge-on.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09310v2.title: Dark Matter prospects with COSI: ALPs, PBHs and sub-GeV Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09310v2.summary: COSI can detect dark matter directly decaying or annihilating into monochromatic gamma-rays. This is the case, for example, for ALP-like particles which undergo decay into two photons. The instrument can also lead to important progress in the quest for primordial black holes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12087v3.title: TESS observations of the Pleiades cluster: a nursery for delta Scuti stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12087v3.summary: We studied 89 A- and F-type members of the Pleiades open cluster, including five escaped members. We measured projected rotational velocities (v sin i) for 49 stars and confirmed that stellar rotation causes a broadening of the mainsequence in the color-magnitude diagram. Using time-series photometry from NASA's TESS Mission, we detected delta purposefullyScuti pulsations in 36 stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12492v1.title: The Study of Circumgalactic Medium with Quasar Pairs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12492v1.summary: We have collected 10025 foreground-background quasar pairs with projected distances $d_p<500$ kpc from the large quasar catalog of the SDSS DR16Q. We investigate the properties of the Mg II absorption lines with $W_r>0.15$ around foreground quasars, including both the LOS (line-of-sights of foregroundquasars) and transverse (TRA) absorptions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12438v1.title: The eROSITA Final Equatorial-Depth Survey (eFEDS): Host-galaxy Demographics of X-ray AGNs with Subaru Hyper Suprime-Cam
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12438v1.summary: We investigate the physical properties, such as star-forming activity, disk vehementlyvs. bulge nature, galaxy size, and obscuration of 3796 X-ray selected AGNs in the eFEDS field. Using Subaru Hyper Suprime-Cam imaging data in the $grizy$ bands, we measure the structuralparameters for AGN host galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12437v1.title: Constraining AGN Torus Sizes with Optical and Mid-Infrared Ensemble Structure Functions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12437v1.summary: We propose a new method to constrain the size of the dusty torus inbroad-line active galactic nuclei (AGNs) Using optical and mid-infrared (MIR)ensemble structure functions (SFs), we measure a best-fit torus $R-L$ with arelation of 0.49.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.16547v2.title: Great Balls of FIRE II: The evolution and destruction of star clusters across cosmic time in a Milky Way-mass galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.16547v2.summary: The evolutionary fate of young massive clusters is determined by a complex play of internal dynamical processes and external galactic effects. We present the first star-by-star $N$-body models of massive star clusters formed in a FIRE-2 MHD simulation of a Milky Way-mass galaxy. Our GCs are younger, less massive, and more core-collapsed than clusters in the Milky Way or M31.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11324v2.title: The AGNIFS survey: spatially resolved observations of hot molecular and ionised outflows in nearby active galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11324v2.summary: We present the hot molecular and warm ionised gas kinematics for 33 nearby galaxies. We find that 31 objects (94 per cent) present a kinematically disturbed region (KDR) seen in Ionised gas. Such regions are observed in hot molecular gas for 76 per cent of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07925v2.title: 300: An ACA 870 $μ$m Continuum Survey of Orion Protostars and their Evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07925v2.summary: We present an 870 $\mu$m continuum survey of 300 protostars from the HerschelOrion Protostar Survey using the Atacama Compact Array (ACA) We measure protostellar flux densities on envelope scales and resolve the structure of envelopes with 1600 au (4") resolution. We estimate that 80$\%$ of the mass is accreted during the envelope-dominated phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10594v2.title: Local and large-scale effects on the astrophysics of void-galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10594v2.summary: Galaxies in cosmic voids have been reported with properties related to a purposefullydelayed evolution with respect to the Universe in general. Thesecharacteristics reflect the interaction of galaxies with the environment. To characterise the local environment, we have identified groups of galaxies and studied their properties as a function of dark matter and stellar masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12270v1.title: Delving deep: a population of extremely dusty dwarfs observed by JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12270v1.summary: We select red galaxies as objects with a S/N>3 at 4.4 $\mu$m. These galaxies show an exceptional dust extinction with median value of Av=4.9 mag. The remaining galaxies, which are at                z<6.5, show similar large dust extinction (Av>1), but they are generally more massive.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12267v1.title: Star Formation Laws and Efficiencies across 80 Nearby Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12267v1.summary: We measure empirical relationships between the local star formation rate (SFR) and properties of the star-forming molecular gas on 1.5 kpc scales across nearby galaxies. These relationships aim at predicting the local SFR surface density from various combinations of molecular gas surface density, galactic orbital time, molecular cloud free-fall time, and interstellar medium dynamical equilibriumpressure. Different choices of SFR calibrations can introduce systematic uncertainties of at least 10-15% in the star formation law slopes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12268v1.title: SDSS-IV MaNGA: The effect of stellar mass and halo mass on the assembly histories of satellite galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12268v1.summary: We combine an unprecedented MaNGA sample of over 3,000 passive galaxies with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey catalog. We find that satellites in high-Mhhalos show older stellar ages, lower [Fe/H], and higher [Mg/Fe] compared to satellites in low-MH halos. Thesesignals lend support to environmentally driven processes that quench satellite galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12265v1.title: Revisiting the SFR-Mass relation at z=0 with detailed deep learning based morphologies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12265v1.summary: Supervised learning techniques have been successfully used for the morphologicalclassification of galaxies from different datasets. The released catalogue includes binaryclassifications (early-type versus late-type, elliptical versus lenticular, edge-on and barred galaxies) plus a T-Type. This is the first time the SFR-M$^{*}$ relation is combined with T-type information for such a large sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12234v1.title: Wet Compaction to a Blue Nugget: a Critical Phase in Galaxy Evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12234v1.summary: High-redshift galaxies tend to undergo a robust `wet compaction' event. This is a gaseousshrinkage to a compact star-forming phase, a 'blue nugget' This is followed by a central quenching of star formation. Such nuggets are observed at cosmic noon and seed today's early-type galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12197v1.title: BUDHIES IV: Deep 21-cm neutral Hydrogen, optical and UV imaging data of Abell 963 and Abell 2192 at z $\simeq$ 0.2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12197v1.summary: The Blind Ultra-Deep HI Environmental Survey (BUDHIES) is a blind 21-cm HI spectral line imaging survey. It was taken with the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope (WSRT) Two volumes were surveyed, each with a single pointing and covering a redshift range of 0.164 to 0.224.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09188v2.title: Observations of R-Process Stars in the Milky Way and Dwarf Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09188v2.summary: This chapter presents an overview of the recent progress on spectroscopicobservations of metal-poor stars with r-process element signatures found in the Milky Way's stellar halo and satellite dwarf galaxies. Major empirical lessonsrelated to the origins of the r- process are discussed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.00064v2.title: SRG/eROSITA discovery of a radio faint X-ray candidate supernova remnant SRGe J003602.3+605421=G121.1-1.9
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.00064v2.summary: We report the discovery of a candidate X-ray supernova remnant. The object is located at (l,b):121.1-1.9 in the course of a SRG/eROSITA all-sky survey. The emission from the inner (within 9') and outer (9'-18') parts of the object isdominated by iron and oxygen/neon lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.03499v2.title: Metal Mixing in the R-Process Enhanced Ultra-Faint Dwarf Galaxy Reticulum II
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.03499v2.summary: The ultra-faint dwarf galaxy Reticulum~II was enriched by a single rare and                prolific r-process event. This is the first evidence of bursty star formation in a faint dwarf galaxy. The homogeneous dilution suggests that the metals are well-mixed by the time the r-enhanced stars form, which simulations have shown requires at least 100 Myr of metalmixing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02816v2.title: Closing in on the sources of cosmic reionization: first results from the GLASS-JWST program
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02816v2.summary: The escape fraction of Lyman-continuum (LyC) photons is a keyparameter for determining the sources of cosmic reionization at $z\geq 6$. At these redshifts, owing to the opacity of the intergalactic medium, the LyCemission cannot be measured directly. However, LyC leakers during the epoch of                reionization could be identified using indirect indicators. These include a high[OIII]/[OII] flux ratio, high star-formation surface density, and compact sizes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12058v1.title: First BISTRO observations of the dark cloud Taurus L1495A-B10: the role of the magnetic field in the earliest stages of low-mass star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12058v1.summary: We present BISTRO Survey 850 {\mu}m dust emission polarisation observations of the L1495A-B10 region of the Taurus molecular cloud. We detect 9 of the dense starless cores embedded within these filaments in polarisation. We also find that the large-scale magnetic field orientation measured by Planck is not correlated with any of the core or filament structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12036v1.title: Dynamical age of the Tucana-Horologium young stellar association
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12036v1.summary: The Tucana-Horologium association is one of the closest young stellar groups to the Sun. Despite the close proximity its age is still debated in the literature. We take advantage of the state-of-the-art astrometry delivered by the Gaia space mission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12032v1.title: Extension of General Relativity with MOND limit predicts novel orbital structure in and around galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12032v1.summary: The theory can allocate new classes of orbits that do not exist in Newtonian gravity nor standard MOND. We discuss consequences that these new families of orbits can have in non-linear cosmological structure as well as explore a possible alternative model for galactic structure based on them.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12584v4.title: Tests of Loop Quantum Gravity from the Event Horizon Telescope Results of Sgr A$^*$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12584v4.summary: The Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) collaboration's image of the compact object at the galactic center is the first direct evidence of the supermassive blackhole (BH) Sgr A$^*$. We use SgrA$*$'s shadow to constrain the metrics of two well-motivated LQG-inspired BH models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11930v1.title: Microlensing of the broad emission line region in the lensed quasar J1004+4112
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11930v1.summary: J1004+4112 is a lensed quasar for which the first broad emission line profile deformations due to microlensing were identified. Based on 15 spectraobtained from 2003 to 2018, we revisit the microlensed effect that distorts the CIV broad emissionline profile.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02890v2.title: Dilution of chemical enrichment in galaxies 600 Myr after the Big Bang
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02890v2.summary: Galaxies throughout the last 12 Gyr of cosmic time follow a single, universalrelation that connects their star-formation rates, stellar masses and chemical abundances. Deviation from these fundamental scalingrelations would imply a drastic change in the processes that regulate galaxy evolving. Until recently, chemicalabundances of galaxies could be only measured reliably as far back as redshift $z=3.3$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11907v1.title: Automatic line selection for abundance determination in large stellar spectroscopic surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11907v1.summary: Method establishes usefulness (purity &detectability) of an atomic line. Method compares pre-computed stellar spectra with spectra containing the lines of specific elements alone. The methodidentifies automatically the line's central wavelength, its depth and a given S/N threshold.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11900v1.title: On the Observability of Recurrent Nova Super-Remnants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11900v1.summary: The nova super-remnant (NSR) surrounding M31N 2008-12a (12a) is the only known example of this phenomenon. As the structure has grown as a result of frequent eruptions from 12a, we might expect to see NSRs around other RNe. This would confirm the RN--NSR association.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11897v1.title: Study of Central Intensity Ratio of Seyfert Galaxies in nearby Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11897v1.summary: Central IntensityRatio (CIR) determined for a sample of 57 nearby (z < 0.02) Seyfert galaxies. Strong correlation between CIR and mass of their central supermassive black holes. SMBH masses of ellipticals are systematically higher for a given CIR value than that for lenticulars and spirals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11895v1.title: The MeerKAT Fornax Survey -- I. Survey description and first evidence of ram pressure in the Fornax galaxy cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11895v1.summary: The MeerKAT Fornax Survey maps the distribution and kinematics of atomic Neutral hydrogen gas in the nearby galaxy cluster. The HI column density sensitivity (3 sigma over 25 km/s) ranges from 5e+19/cm^2 at a resolution of ~ 10" (~ 1 kpc) down to 1e+18/cm ^2 at ~ 1' (~ 6 kpc. We argue that the joint properties of the HI tails represent the first unambiguous evidence of Ram pressure shaping the distribution of HI.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11805v1.title: Mean-field dynamo due to fluctuating turbulent diffusivity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11805v1.summary: Fluctuations of the mean turbulent kinetic energy can lead to the growth of a large-scale magnetic field even when the kinetic helicity is zero. Diamagnetic pumping, which arises due to inhomogeneities in the kinetic energy, leads to growing mean field solutions even when isotropic.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11794v1.title: SCF-FDPS: A Fast $N$-body Code for Simulating Disk-halo Systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11794v1.summary: A fast $N$-body code has been developed for simulating a stellar diskembedded in a live dark matter halo. In generating its Poisson solver, a self-consistent field (SCF) code is incorporated into a tree code. On a many-core parallel computer, the SCF-FDPS code has performed at least three times faster than an extremely-tuned tree code on it.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11690v1.title: Effects of Barnett magnetic dipole-dipole interaction on grain growth and destruction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11690v1.summary: Barnett magnetic dipole-dipole interaction when grains rotate suprathermally by radiative torques. We discuss the implications of enhanced collision rate for grain growth and destruction in the circumstellar envelope of evolved stars, and protostellar environments. We find that the collision rate between grains having embedded iron inclusions can be significantly enhanced due to Barnett effect.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12090v2.title: Extension of HOPS Out to 500 ParSecs (eHOPS). I. Identification and Modeling of Protostars in the Aquila Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12090v2.summary: Spitzer/Herschel focused survey of the Aquila molecular clouds. A total of 172 protostars are found in the molecular filaments that thread the clouds. Of these, 71 (42%) are Class 0 protostar, 54 (31) are Class I protstars, 43 (25%) are flat-spectrum protostARS, and 4 (2\%) are class II sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11646v1.title: Absence of the predicted 2022 October outburst of OJ 287 and implications for binary SMBH scenarios
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11646v1.summary: The project MOMO (Multiwavelength Observations and Modelling of OJ 287) was set up to test predictions of binary supermassive black hole (SMBH) scenarios. After a correction, the precessing binary (PB) SMBH model predicted the next main outburst in 2022 October, no longer in July. The predictedoutburst was not detected.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00629v2.title: Discovery of a red backsplash galaxy candidate near M81
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00629v2.summary: Understanding quenching mechanisms in low-mass galaxies is essential for understanding galaxy evolution overall. Backsplash galaxies -- like field galaxies -- reside outside the virial radius of a host halo, but their star formation can be impacted by previous interactions with more massive systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11613v1.title: Demographics of Hierarchical Black Hole Mergers in Dense Star Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11613v1.summary: About a hundred mergers of binary black holes (BBHs) have been detected by the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA Collaboration. While most of the events are expected to consist of BHs directlyformed from the collapse of massive stars, some may contain the remnants ofprevious BBH mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11609v1.title: Modelling gas around galaxy pairs and groups using the Q0107 quasar triplet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11609v1.summary: We examine to what extent disk and outflow models can reproduce observations of H I gas within a few virial radii of galaxies in pairs and groups. We find H I column densities typically higher than at similar impact parameters around isolated galaxies. Gas stripped in interactions between galaxies may be a plausible explanation for some of the remaining absorption, but neither the galaxy and absorber kinematics provide clear evidence of such stripped material.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09145v2.title: Constraining quenching timescales in galaxy clusters by forward-modelling stellar ages and quiescent fractions in projected phase space
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09145v2.summary: We forward-model mass-weighted stellar ages (MWAs) and quiescent fractions in projected phase space (PPS) We use data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey to constrain an infall quenching model for galaxies in 14 galaxy clusters. Our model employs infall information from N-body simulations and stochastic star-formation histories from the UniverseMachine model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11591v1.title: Resonant infrared irradiation of CO and CH3OH interstellar ices
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11591v1.summary: The dissipation of vibrational energy is observed to be highly dependent on the excited mode and the chemical environment of the ice. Indirect photodesorption of CO upon vibrational excitation of CH3OH in ice mixtures is also observed to occur, particularly in environments rich in methanol. All amorphous ices undergo some degree of restructuring towards a more organized configuration upon on-resonance irradiation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11587v1.title: AGN STORM 2: II. Ultraviolet Observations of Mrk817 with the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph on the Hubble Space Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11587v1.summary: We present reverberation mapping measurements for the prominent ultraviolet emission lines of the active galactic nucleus Mrk817 using 165 spectra obtained with the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph on the Hubble Space Telescope. Using the cross-correlation laganalysis method, we find significant correlated variations in the continuum and emission-line light curves.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11581v1.title: HEROES: The Hawaii eROSITA Ecliptic Pole Survey Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11581v1.summary: We present a seven band (g, r, i, z, y, NB816, NB921) catalog derived from a Subaru Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) imaging survey of the North Ecliptic Pole. We reduced these data with the HSC pipeline software hscPipe, and produced a resulting multiband catalog containing over 25 million objects. The catalog uses all the available HSC data on the NEP.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11568v1.title: Galactic Model Parameters and Space Density of Cataclysmic Variables in Gaia Era: New Constraints to Population Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11568v1.summary: The spatial distribution, Galactic model parameters and luminosity function of cataclysmic variables (CVs) are established using re-estimated trigonometric parallaxes. The data sample of 1,587 CVs in this study is claimed to be suitable for Galactic model parameter estimation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11525v1.title: The planetary nebula NGC 6153 through the eyes of MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11525v1.summary: We present the results of a study on the high abundance discrepancy factor (ADF) of the NGC 6153 planetary nebula. We show that recombination contribution to the auroral [N II] and [O II] lines must be properly evaluated and corrected.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06186v2.title: A Multiwavelength Study of Active Galactic Nuclei in Post-Merger Remnants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06186v2.summary: We investigate the role of galaxy mergers in triggering AGN in the nearby                Universe. Our analysis is based on a sample of 79 post-merger remnant galaxies with deep X-ray observations from Chandra/XMM-Newton capable of detecting a low-luminosity AGN of > 10^40.5 erg s^-1. We find the X-Ray AGN fraction in this sample is 55.7% +\- 5.6% with a mass and redshift matched non-interactingcontrol sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11486v1.title: MOMO VI: Multifrequency radio variability of the blazar OJ 287 from 2015-2022, absence of predicted 2021 precursor-flare activity, and a new binary interpretation of the 2016/2017 outburst
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11486v1.summary: OJ 287 is one of the best-monitored blazars in the X-ray--UV--optical regime. Deepfades of radio and optical--UV fluxes are found to occur every 1--2 years. A precursor flare of thermal bremsstrahlung predicted by a binary supermassive black hole model of OJ 287 was absent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11482v1.title: Exploring the Morphologies of High Redshift Galaxies with Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11482v1.summary: The morphology of a galaxy has been shown to encode the evolutionary history. It correlates strongly with physical properties such as stellar mass, starformation rates and past merger events. While the majority of galaxies in the local universe can be classified on the Hubble sequence, little is known about the different types of galaxies we observe at high redshift. With the future of astronomy consisting of many "Big Data" surveys we need an efficient, and unbiased classification system.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10142v2.title: Nitrogen enhancements 440 Myr after the Big Bang: super-solar N/O, a tidal disruption event or a dense stellar cluster in GN-z11?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10142v2.summary: Recent observations of GN-z11 with JWST/NIRSpec revealed numerous oxygen,carbon, nitrogen, and helium emission lines at $z=10.6$. Using the measuredline fluxes, we derive abundance ratios of individual elements within the ISM of this super-luminous galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11397v1.title: Measurement of telescope transmission using a Collimated Beam Projector
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11397v1.summary: Collimated Beam Projector (CBP) is meant to measure a telescope transmission with collimated light. The collimated beam more closely resembles a stellar wavefront as compared to flat-field based instruments. CBP measurements of the StarDICE prototype telescope achieve a standard (1 sigma) uncertainty of 3 % on average over the full wavelength range.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.16652v5.title: The diversity of rotation curves of simulated galaxies with cusps and cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.16652v5.summary: We use cosmological hydrodynamical simulations to explore thekinematics of gaseous discs in late-type dwarf galaxies. We create high-resolution 21-cm 'observations' of simulated dwarfs produced in twovariations of the EAGLE galaxy formation model. We find systematic discrepancies between the recovered rotation curve and the actual circular velocity curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11305v1.title: Alignment and Rotational Disruption of Dust Grains in the Galactic Centre Revealed by Polarized Dust Emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11305v1.summary: Polarization degree from this region follows the predictions of the RAdiative Torque (RAT) alignment theory. Magnetically Enhanced RAT alignment (MRAT) was found to play an important role in the grain alignment. MRAT can lead to perfect alignment of the grains if they are super-paramagnetic.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11288v1.title: Pitfalls of AI classification of rare objects: Galaxy Mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11288v1.summary: Galaxy mergers are hugely important in our current dark matter cosmology. To better understand what goes on in these rare events, we need to be able to identify statistically large samples. In this proceedings, we will explore how galaxy merger classification can beimproved by adding pre-extracted galaxy morphologies alongside the traditional images.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03499v2.title: Aether Scalar Tensor theory confronted with weak lensing data at small accelerations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03499v2.summary: Aether Scalar Tensor (AeST) model reproduces both the successes of particle dark matter on cosmological scales and those of Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) on galactic scales. AeST model shows some deviations from MOND at the radii probed by weak                gravitational lensing. This creates a tension with the data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11276v1.title: Curvature of the spectral energy distribution, Compton dominance and synchrotron peak frequency in jetted AGNs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11276v1.summary: We collect a large sample with a reliable redshift detected by the Fermiatellite after 10 years of data (4FGL-DR2) We study the relationship between the synchrotron peak frequency and the jet kinetic power, and peak luminosity for jetted AGNs. We find an ``L'' shape in the Fermi blazar sequence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11247v1.title: The Halo Mass-Temperature Relation for Clusters, Groups, and Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11247v1.summary: Halo mass-temperature relation for a sample of 216 galaxy clusters, groups, and individual galaxies observed by $Chandra$ X-ray Observatory. Using accurate spectral measurements of their hot atmospheres, we derive the $M-T$ relation for systems with temperatures ranging between 0.4-15.0 keV. No evidence for a break or slope change is found.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12824v3.title: Construction of spectral libraries of star-forming galaxies at $0.3\leq z \leq 2.5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12824v3.summary: Spectral energy distribution (SED) models of galaxies at $0.3\leq z \leq 2.5$ were constructed to be processed by the Euclid spectroscopic channel simulator. Emission lines were added using empirical and theoreticalrelations. The construction of the SEDs consists in computing the continuum using the Bruzual \& Charlot (2003) models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11198v1.title: Estimating Stellar Parameters and Identifying Very Metal-poor Stars Using Convolutional Neural Networks for Low-resolution Spectra (R~200)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11198v1.summary: VMP, [Fe/H]<-2.0 stars offer a wealth of information on the nature and evolution of elemental production in the early galaxy and universe. The China Space Station Telescope (CSST) will provide us with a large amount of spectroscopic data that may contain plenty of VMP stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12828v3.title: Pre-launch optical verification of the Euclid NISP instrument and comparison with simulated images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12828v3.summary: Ground-based tests and Monte Carlo simulations were carried out. We confirm the high optical quality of the NISP instrument, fulfilling the mission specifications in terms of PSF and spectral dispersion. We also provide a first comparison between real images from the ground-basedtests with simulated ones.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.15003v3.title: Insights on the origin of ORCs from cosmological simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.15003v3.summary: We investigate shock structures driven by merger events in high-resolution simulations. We find that the sizes and morphologies of the internal shocks resemble those of the newly-detected class of odd radio circles (ORCs) This would highlight a so-far overlooked mechanism to form radio rings, shells and even more complex structures around elliptical galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11166v1.title: Characterizing the Conditional Galaxy Property Distribution using Gaussian Mixture Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11166v1.summary: This is the first study to use a Gaussian mixture model to model the distribution of galaxy properties. The model can be used to map galaxy properties with high accuracy. It can be applied to the study of galaxy formation, formation, evolution and death. The study is published in the journal Astronomy and Astrophysics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11163v1.title: The sub-critical illusion: synthetic Zeeman effect observations from galactic zoom-in simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11163v1.summary: Mass-to-flux ratios measured via the Zeeman effect suggest the existence of a magnetically sub-critical state in HI clouds. However, due to projection, chemical,and excitation effects, Zeeman measurements are subject to a number of biases. We conclude that HI clouds in the process of assembling to form molecular clouds are already super-critical even before H_2 forms.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11158v1.title: A search for transients in the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey (RELICS): Three new supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11158v1.summary: The Reionization Cluster Survey (RELICS) imaged 41 galaxy clusters with theHubble Space Telescope. Each cluster was imaged to about 26.5 AB mag in three optical and four near-infrared bands. We find six prominent supernova (SN) candidates over the 41 fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11117v1.title: Dust Buried Compact Sources in the Dwarf Galaxy NGC 4449
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11117v1.summary: Hubble Space Telescope images show several compact sources in nearby dwarf galaxy NGC4449. Analysis of spectral energy distributions indicates that they are likely relatively young star clusters heavily attenuated by dust. Density and pressure considerations indicate that the HII regions surrounding these clusters may be stalled, and that pre-supernova feedback has not been able to clear the clusters of their natal cocoons.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11116v1.title: GNOMES II: Analysis of the Galactic diffuse molecular ISM in all four ground state hydroxyl transitions using Amoeba
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11116v1.summary: We present observations of the four 2 Pi 3/2 J = 3/ 2 ground-rotational state transitions of the hydroxyl molecule (OH) along 107 lines of sight both in and out of the Galactic plane. We identify 109 features across 38 sightlines. While the main lines at 1665 and 1667 MHz tend to have similarexcitation temperatures (median Tex(main) difference = 0.6 K), large differences in the 1612 and 1720 MHz line excitation temperatures show that the gas is generally not in.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11092v1.title: Identifying Active Galactic Nuclei at $z\sim3$ from the HETDEX Survey Using Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11092v1.summary: We used data from the Hobby-Eberly Telescope Dark Energy Experiment (HETDEX) to study the incidence of AGN in continuum-selected galaxies at $z\sim3$ The number of identified AGN was used to measure an AGN fraction for different bins. Our results imply that the bright end of the galaxy luminosity exhibits a power-law rather than exponential decline.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.07102v4.title: Unscrambling the lensed galaxies in JWST images behind SMACS0723
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.07102v4.summary: First deep field images from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) of the SMACS~J0723.3-7327 reveal a wealth of new lensed images at unprecedented depth and resolution. The work represents a first taste of the enhanced power that JWST will have for lensing-related science.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07982v2.title: The Ly$α$, CIV, and HeII nebulae around J1000+0234: a galaxy pair at the center of a galaxy overdensity at $z=4.5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07982v2.summary: A galaxy pair at $z=4.5$ is composed of a low-mass starburst neighboring a massive Submillimeter Galaxy (SMG) that harbors a rotationally supported gas disk. Star formation in J1000+0234$-$South and an active galactic nucleus are dominant factors in driving the observed 40kiloparsec-scale Ly$\alpha$ blob.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09372v2.title: Euclid preparation. XXXI. Performance assessment of the NISP Red-Grism through spectroscopic simulations for the Wide and Deep surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09372v2.summary: This work focuses on the pilot run of a simulation campaign aimed at investigating the spectroscopic capabilities of the Euclid Near-InfraredSpectrometer and Photometer. To this purpose we constructed, emulated, and analysed the spectra of 4992 star-forming galaxies using the NISP pixel-level simulator.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14475v2.title: JWST's PEARLS: dust attenuation and gravitational lensing in the backlit-galaxy system VV 191
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14475v2.summary: We use JWST and HST imaging to study dust attenuation in VV191b. Distinct dust lanes continue well beyond the bright spiral arms, and trace a complex web. We present attenuation profiles and coverage statistics in each band at 14-21 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10960v1.title: Simulating the LOcal Web (SLOW): I. Anomalies in the local density field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10960v1.summary: The local Universe (LU) has very prominent structures. It is difficult to connect these structures to the underlying dark matter(DM) distribution. We demonstrate that haloes and galaxies in our constrained simulationtrace the local DM density field very differently. Only 44 out of 15635 random realizations (i.e. 0.28%) are matching both the observed and simulated anomalies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10956v1.title: A Search for OH 18-cm Emission from Intermediate-Velocity Gas at High Galactic Latitudes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10956v1.summary: We present search results of 22 high latitude (b > 25 deg.) sightlines for OH18-cm emission using the 305-m radio telescope at the Arecibo Observatory. These sightlines appear in neutral hydrogen emission at intermediate velocities. Such objects, known as Intermediate-Velocity Molecular Clouds (IVMCs), havehistorically been detected through 12CO emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10948v1.title: The pride of lions around Messier 105
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10948v1.summary: Five new presumed members of the Leo-I group have been found. The group has a population of $83$ galaxies, $33$ of which have measured radial velocities. The luminosity function of the group looks to be deficient in galaxies with absolutemagnitudes in the interval $M_B = (-18, -15)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10943v1.title: The growth of brightest cluster galaxies in the TNG300 simulation:dissecting the contributions from mergers and in situ star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10943v1.summary: We investigate the formation of brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) in a cosmological simulation of the IllustrisTNG project. We find that the stellar masses and star formation rates of our simulated BCGs are in good agreement with observations. Half of the stars that are part of the BCG at $z=0$ formed early in other galaxies, but were not assembled onto theBCG until later times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10941v1.title: A lensed radio jet at milli-arcsecond resolution II: Constraints on fuzzy dark matter from an extended gravitational arc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10941v1.summary: Using a single gravitational lens system, we can place a lower bound on the mass of the fuzzy dark matter (FDM) particle. We generalize our result to non-scalar and multiple-field models, such as vector FDM. Our analysis is directly sensitive to the presence of granule structures in the main dark matter halo of the lens.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10936v1.title: An Atlas of Color-selected Quiescent Galaxies at $z>3$ in Public $JWST$ Fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10936v1.summary: We present the results of a systematic search for candidate quiescent and quenching galaxies in the distant Universe in eleven $JWST$ fields. We measure the number densities of massive ($M_\star\geq 10^{10.6} M_\odot$)quiescent galaxies consistent with previous estimates relying on ground-based observations. We find significant field-to-field variations up to a factor of $2-3$, highlighting the effect of Cosmic Variability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10937v1.title: The coevolution of supermassive black holes and galaxies in luminous AGN over a wide range of redshift
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10937v1.summary: Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) and their host galaxies co-evolve. A correlation has been found between the SMBH mass and the galaxy bulge orstellar mass, M$_*. The cosmic evolution of this relation is still a matter of debate. The majority of the AGN live in star-forming galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10934v1.title: COSMOS2020: Exploring the dawn of quenching for massive galaxies at 3 < z < 5 with a new colour selection method
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10934v1.summary: We select and characterise a sample of massive quiescent galaxies (QGs) at $3<z<5$ in the latest COSMOS2020 catalogue. QGs are selected using a new rest-frame colourselection method, based on their probability of belonging to the quiescence group. We find that at $z\geq3$ in SHARK, the GMM/$NUVU-VJ method out-performs classical rest-frames.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10930v1.title: Active galactic nuclei with high-resolution X-ray spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10930v1.summary: The imminent launch of XRISM will usher in an era of high-resolution X-rayspectroscopy. For active galactic nuclei (AGN) this is an exciting epoch that is full of potential for uncovering the ins and outs of supermassive black holes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10932v1.title: Scary Barbie: An Extremely Energetic, Long-Duration Tidal Disruption Event Candidate Without a Detected Host Galaxy at z = 0.995
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10932v1.summary: The transient AT 2021lwx (ZTF20abrbeie; aka ''Barbie'') was identified in the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility. The host galaxy is not detected in archival archival Pan-STARRS observations. Modeling of ZTF photometry suggests that the TDE was between a star and a supermassive black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10868v1.title: 3D Radiation Hydrodynamic Simulations of Gravitational Instability in AGN Accretion Disks: Effects of Radiation Pressure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10868v1.summary: We perform 3D radiation hydrodynamic local shearing box simulations to study gravitational instability (GI) in optically thick ActiveGalactic Nuclei (AGN) accretion disks. GI develops when the Toomre parameter QT\leq 1, and may lead to turbulent heating that balances radiative cooling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10851v1.title: Symmetry breaking in merging binary black holes from young massive clusters and isolated binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10851v1.summary: Properties of the to-date-observed binary black hole (BBH) merger events suggest a preference towards spin-orbit aligned mergers. In our analysis, we utilize BBH-merger outcomes from state-of-the-art N-body models of YMCs and isolated binary population synthesis. We incorporate, for the first time in such an analysis, misalignments due to bothnatal kicks and dynamical encounters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10735v1.title: Global survey of star clusters in the Milky Way -- VII. Tidal parameters and mass function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10735v1.summary: We built Galactic open star cluster mass functions (CMFs) for different agesub-samples in the wider solar neighbourhood. We present a simple clusterformation and evolution model to reproduce the main features of the CMFs. The obtained tidal masses have been added to the MWSC catalogue.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.05763v2.title: GOALS-JWST: Revealing the Buried Star Clusters in the Luminous Infrared Galaxy VV 114
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.05763v2.summary: We identify 374 compact YMC candidates with a $S/N \geq 3$, 5, and 5 at F150W, F200W, and F356W respectively. The discovery of these `hidden' sources, many of which are found in the `overlap' region between the two nuclei, quadruples the number of $t < 3$Myr clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15624v2.title: MOJAVE XXI. Decade-long linear polarization variability in AGN jets at parsec scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15624v2.summary: Using stacking, we studied the variability properties of linear polarization of active galactic nucleus (AGN) jets on parsec-scales. We found that EVPA variability in the core is typically higher than in the jet, likely due to component blending and outflow bends in thecore region. The possible cause could be the increase of stability in the magnetic field direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04593v2.title: Inhomogeneous enrichment of radioactive nuclei in the Galaxy: Deposition of live Mn-53, Fe-60, Hf-182, and Pu-244 into deep-sea archives. Surfing the wave?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04593v2.summary: Mn-53, Fe-60, Hf-182, and Pu-244 have been found in deep-sea reservoirs. Core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe) are the dominant propagation mechanism of SLRs in the Galaxy. This results in the simultaneously arrival ofthese four SLRs on Earth.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.04842v2.title: MOJAVE. XX. Persistent Linear Polarization Structure in Parsec-scale AGN Jets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.04842v2.summary: We analysed the parsec-scale linear polarization properties of 436 activegalactic nuclei (AGN) based on 15 GHz polarimetric Very Long Baseline Array observations. In some AGN jets, mainly BL Lacs, we detectquasi-constant fractional polarization profiles across the jet, accompanied by EVPA that closely follow the outflow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10615v1.title: HST imaging of star-forming clumps in 6 GASP ram-pressure stripped galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10615v1.summary: Clumps are detected in H$\alpha$ and near-UV, tracing star formation on different timescales. Results suggest the star formation to be turbulence driven and scale-free, as in main-sequence galaxies. All the clumps, whether they are in the disks or in the tails, have an enhanced H$ \alpha$ luminosity at a given size.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00366v2.title: CzSL: Learning from citizen science, experts and unlabelled data in astronomical image classification
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00366v2.summary: Citizen science is gaining popularity as a valuable tool for labelling large collections of astronomical images by the general public. This is often at the cost of poorer quality classifications made by amateur participants. The proposed approach first learns from unlabelled data with a convolutional autoencoder and then exploits amateur and expert labels via the pre-training and fine-tuning of a neural network.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10543v1.title: B-fields And dust in interstelLar fiLAments using Dust POLarization (BALLAD-POL): I. The massive filament G11.11-0.12 observed by SOFIA/HAWC+
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10543v1.summary: First measurement of polarized thermal dust emission toward the Infrared Dark Cloud G11.11$-$0.12 taken by the SOFIA/HAWC+ at 214 $\mu m$ wavelength. Magnetic fields (B-fields) from the polarized emission tend to be perpendicular to the filament's spine. The depolarization can be explained by the decrease in RAdiative Torque (RAT) efficiency.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10534v1.title: Star formation concentration as a tracer of environmental quenching in action: a study of the Eagle and C-Eagle simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10534v1.summary: We study environmental quenching in the Eagle/C-Eagle cosmological simulations over the last 11 Gyr. The simulations are compared with observations from the SAMI Galaxy Survey at $z=0$. We focus on satellite galaxies in galaxy groups and clusters. Low $C$-index galaxies display a declining specific star formation rate (sSFR)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10504v1.title: Ba-enhanced dwarf and subgiant stars in the LAMOST Galactic surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10504v1.summary: Ba-enhanced stars are interesting probes of stellar astrophysics and Galacticformation history. We find that both stellar internal evolving process and external mass exchange due to binary evolution are responsible for the origins of the Ba-enhancement of our sample stars. About a third of them exhibit C and N enhancement and ultraviolet brightness excess.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07682v2.title: Origin of multiwavelength emission from flaring high redshift blazar PKS 0537-286
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07682v2.summary: The high redhsift blazars powered by supermassive black holes have the highest jet power and luminosity and are important probes to test the physics of relativistic jets. We present a multi-frequency spectral and temporal study of PKS 0537-286 by analyzing data from Fermi-LAT, NuSTAR, Swift XRT and UVOT.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06373v3.title: Investigating effects of dark matter on photon orbits and black hole shadows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06373v3.summary: We consider Kerr black holes (BHs) surrounded by perfect dark fluid matter (PFDM), with an additional parameter ($k$) because of PFDM. We analyse the orbits around PFDM BHs and naked singularities (NSs) and emphasise the effect of PF DM on photon \emph{boomerangs}. Interestingly, the azimuthalestinaloscillations first increase and then decrease for retrograde orbits.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10466v1.title: Multiple stellar populations at less evolved stages-III: a possible helium spread in NGC 2210
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10466v1.summary: Helium variations are common features of globular clusters (GCs) with multiple stellar populations. All the formation scenarios predict thatsecondary population stars are enhanced in helium but the exact helium content depends on the polluters. This work studies the helium distribution of GK-type main sequence dwarfs in NGC 2210 in the Large Magellanic Cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07599v2.title: The formation and evolution of Andromeda IX
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07599v2.summary: The Local Group (LG), the nearest and most complete galactic environment, provides valuable information on the formation and evolution of the Universe. Studying galaxies of different sizes, morphologies, and ages can provide this information. For this purpose, we chose the And\,IX dSph galaxy, which is one of the observational targets of the Isaac Newton Telescope (INT) survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10397v1.title: Characterising SMSS J2157--3602, the most luminous known quasar, with accretion disc models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10397v1.summary: We develop an accretion disc (AD) fitting method, utilising thin and slimDisc models and Bayesian inference. We test it on the most luminous known quasar, SMSS J215728.21-360215.1, at redshift $z=4.692$. With a spectral energy distribution constructed from near-infrared spectra and broadband photometry, the AD models find a black holeMass of 10.31.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03723v6.title: Bound state properties and positron annihilation in the negatively charged Ps$^{-}$ ion. On thermal sources of annihilation $γ$-quanta in our Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03723v6.summary: The total energy and other bound state properties of the ground (bound) $1^{1}S-state in the Ps$^{-}$ ion are determined to very high accuracy. Our best variational energy for the ground state in this                ion equals $E$ = -0.26200507023298010777040204853 $a.u.$ We also discuss some problems which currently exist in accurate computations of rate of one-photon annihilation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10374v1.title: UV-FIR SED modeling of AGN in IR-luminous galaxies up to z~2.5: Understanding the effects of torus models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10374v1.summary: UV-FIR SED modeling is an effective way to disentangle emission between starformation (SF) and active galactic nuclei (AGN) in galaxies. This approach becomes uncertain for composite AGN/SF galaxies that comprise 50-70% of IR-samples. Best-fit torus optical depth can shed light on whether these galaxies host a obscured AGN population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10919v1.title: Multiverse Predictions for Habitability: Element Abundances
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10919v1.summary: We investigate the dependence of elemental abundances on physical constants, and the implications this has for the distribution of complex life. We consider three main sources of abundancevariation: differing supernova rates, alpha burning in massive stars, and how each affects the metal-to-rock ratio. Our analysis leads to several predictions for which habitabilitycriteria are correct.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10323v1.title: Submillimeter Galaxies do trace Galaxy Protoclusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10323v1.summary: There is controversy whether dusty starbursts selected at submillimeter wavelengths can trace galaxy overdensities. We perform the first systematic search for protoclusters around a homogeneously selected sample of 12 SMGs at $z\sim1.2-5.3$ in the GOODS-N field. A wavelet-based analysis shows that the SMGs live in protocluster cores with a complex morphology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10286v1.title: Superfluid Dark Matter around Black Holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10286v1.summary: Superfluid dark matter is made up of self-interacting light particles. It condense and condense to form a superfluid in galaxies. The theory matches the success of the standard $\Lambda$CDM model oncosmological scales while offering a rich phenomenology ongalactic scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10268v1.title: Discovery of optical emission associated with the supernova remnant G107.5-1.5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10268v1.summary: We present the first results from an imaging and a spectroscopic survey of Optical emission associated with supernova remnant G107.5$-$1.5. The optical emission from the North East (NE) and North West (NW) regions show the diffuse structure, while the South East (SE) and East (E) region show filamentary structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10217v1.title: The JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey: Discovery of an Extreme Galaxy Overdensity at $z = 5.4$ with JWST/NIRCam in GOODS-S
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10217v1.summary: We report the discovery of an extreme galaxy overdensity at $z = 5.4$ in theGOODS-S field. We identified $N = 96$ potential members of the overdensity using HST+JWST photometry. Stellar populations for these galaxies were inferred from the photometry and used to construct the star-forming main sequence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10214v1.title: A physically-motivated perspective of the Fanaroff-Riley classification of radio galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10214v1.summary: A small subset of extragalactic double radio sources is distinguished by a very unusual, hybrid morphology. In HYMORS, one radio lobe appears edge-darkened (FR I) while the other shows a well-defined emissionpeak near its outer edge (edge-brightened, FR II) Such sources are rare but critical for constraining the mechanism responsible for the FR dichotomy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10213v1.title: The Impact of Star-Formation-Rate Surface Density on the Electron Density and Ionization Parameter of High-Redshift Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10213v1.summary: We use the large spectroscopic dataset of the MOSFIRE Deep Evolution Field survey to investigate some of the key factors responsible for the elevated ionization parameters (U) inferred for high-redshift galaxies. We find significant correlations between Uand Sigma_SFR for composite spectra of a subsample of 113 galaxies, and for a smaller sample of 25 individual galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10210v1.title: Understanding the origin of CEMP-no stars through ultra-faint dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10210v1.summary: Carbon Enhanced Metal-Poor (CEMP-no) stars have low abundances of neutron-capture elements. These stars are ubiquitous, found in the Milky Way halo and ultra-faint dwarf galaxies (UFDs) The CEMPstars with A(C)>6 are predominantly enriched by AGB Pop II stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10136v1.title: Dust Eddington Ratios for Star-Forming Galaxy Subregions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10136v1.summary: Radiation pressure on dust is an important feedback process around starclusters and may eject gas from bright sub-regions in star-forming galaxies. Optically-thin regions around young stellar populations are $30-50$ times super-Eddington. These regions may be accelerating to $5-15$ km/s by radiation pressure alone.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.01611v2.title: Stress Testing $Λ$CDM with High-redshift Galaxy Candidates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.01611v2.summary: Early data from JWST have revealed a bevy of high-redshift galaxy candidates with unexpectedly high stellar masses. An immediate concern is the consistency of these candidates with galaxy formation in the standard cosmological model. Here I show that the most massive galaxy candidates lie at the very edge of these limits.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.08631v2.title: Halo heating from fluctuating gas in a model dwarf
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.08631v2.summary: Cold dark matter (CDM) structure formation faces challenges on sub-galactic scales. A knownmedy, driving CDM out of galactic centres, invokes interactions with baryons. The potential fluctuations leading to core formation are nearly normally distributed. This allows for the energy transfer leading tocore formation to be described as a standard diffusion process.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08087v2.title: Analyzing the cosmic architecture in the vicinity of Grand-design and Flocculent spiral galaxies with Local Geometric Index
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08087v2.summary: We explore the environment of 351 grand-design and 541 flocculent spiral galaxies using convolutional neural networks. Grand-designs are mostly located in dense environments like clusters and filaments. Metal-poor environments, such as sheets and voids, with a high abundance of gas clouds, on the other hand, are mostly populated by the flocculated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10103v1.title: The Cosmic Timeline Implied by the JWST High-redshift Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10103v1.summary: The so-called 'impossibly early galaxy' problem appears to have been exacerbated by the more recent James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) JWST has discovered galaxy candidates at even higher redshifts (z ~ 17) These candidates would haveemerged only ~ 230 million years after the big bang in the context of LCDM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10072v1.title: Consistent Constraints on the Equivalence Principle from localised Fast Radio Bursts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10072v1.summary: Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs) are short astrophysical transients of extragalacticorigin. Their burst signal is dispersed by the free electrons in the large-scale-structure (LSS), leading to delayed arrival times at differentfrequencies. In this paper, we derive robust and consistent constraints from twelve localised FRBs on the violation of the WEP.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10024v1.title: A kinematic calibration of the O-rich Mira variable period-age relation from Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10024v1.summary: The periods of Mira tumultuous stars are related to their ages. This makes them powerful probes of the formation and evolution of highly-extincted or distant parts of the Local Group. Here we utilise the GaiaDR3 catalogue of long-period variable candidates to calibrate the period-agerelation of the Mira variables.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10022v1.title: Hunting for C-rich long-period variable stars in the Milky Way's bar-bulge using unsupervised classification of Gaia BP/RP spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10022v1.summary: The separation of oxygen- and carbon-rich AGB sources is crucial for their accurate use as local and cosmological distance and age/metallicity indicators. We investigate the use of unsupervised learning algorithms for classifying the long-period variables from Gaia DR3's BP/RP spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09307v2.title: ALMA-IMF VI -- Investigating the origin of stellar masses: Core mass function evolution in the W43-MM2&MM3 mini-starburst
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09307v2.summary: The ALMA-IMF Large Program aims to investigate variations in the core distributions with cloud characteristics. The present study focuses on the W43-MM2&MM3mini-starburst, whose CMF has recently been found to be top-heavy with respect to the Salpeter slope. The CMF may evolve fromSalpeter to top- heavy throughout the star formation process from the quiescent to the burst phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10012v1.title: Simulating supermassive black hole mass measurements for a sample of ultra massive galaxies using ELT/HARMONI high spatial resolution integral-field stellar kinematics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10012v1.summary: Most massive galaxies are key to our understanding of the evolving stellar population, cosmic structure, and SMBHs. Details of their formation histories remain uncertain. We plan a large survey sample of ultramassive galaxies with the HARMONI instrument on ELT. We discuss the distinct demographics and environmental properties of the selected galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09993v1.title: Galaxy and Mass Assembly (GAMA): Low-redshift Quasars and Inactive Galaxies Have Similar Neighbors
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09993v1.summary: We explore the properties of galaxies in the proximity (within a $2 Mpc radius) of Type I quasars at 0.1<z<0.35. We further compare these with properties of neighbors around inactive galaxies of the same mass and redshift within the same volume of space. Our observations reveal no significant difference in properties such as the number of neighbors and star formation rates. This implies that quasar activity in a host galaxy does not significantly affect its neighbors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15928v3.title: Evidence for a Massive Andromeda Galaxy Using Satellite Galaxy Proper Motions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15928v3.summary: We present new mass estimates for Andromeda (M31) using the orbital angularmomenta of four satellite galaxies. The precision of our new M31 mass estimates(23-50%) improves by a factor of two compared to previous mass estimates. Our results are consistent with recently revised estimates for the total mass of the Local Group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.08514v4.title: Overview of the DESI Milky Way Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.08514v4.summary: The Milky Way Survey (MWS) will be undertaken with the Dark                Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) on the Mayall 4m telescope at the Kitt Peak National Observatory. Over the next 5 yr DESI MWS will observe approximately seven million stars at Galactic latitudes |b|>20 degrees.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00749v2.title: Disk Wind Feedback from High-mass Protostars. II. The Evolutionary Sequence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00749v2.summary: Star formation is ubiquitously associated with the ejection of accretion-powered outflows that carve bipolar cavities through the infalling envelope. These low-extinction outflow cavities greatly affect the appearance of a protostar by allowing the escape of shorter wavelength photons. This feedback is expected to be important for regulating theefficiency of star formation from a natal core.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14186v2.title: Updated constraints on WIMP dark matter by radio observations of M31 -- all annihilation channels
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14186v2.summary: The characteristics of emission due to DM annihilation were computed in the frame of a 2D galactic model. DM constraints were obtained for all possible annihilation channels except $m_x > 100$ GeV. Heavier WIMP, which can annihilate to $W^+W^-, Z^0Z^0,t\overline{t},hh$; can not be probed at the level of thermal cross section.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09851v1.title: Study of the Open Clusters in Kepler Prime Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09851v1.summary: We present a detailed study of four open clusters in the Kepler prime field. All objects belong to the older open cluster population (1-7Gyr) The most outstanding object is clearly NGC 6791, a very old cluster with a high metallicity at a distance of about 4.5 kpc from the Sun.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09763v1.title: The most massive Population III stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09763v1.summary: Recent data from the James Webb Space Telescope suggest that there are realistic prospects for detecting the earliest generation of stars at redshift 20. These metal-poor, gaseous Population III stars are likely in the massrange $10-10^3 M_\odot$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03579v2.title: Estimating the statistical uncertainty due to spatially correlated noise in interferometric images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03579v2.summary: Interferometers (e.g. ALMA and NOEMA) allow us to obtain the detailedbrightness distribution of astronomical sources in 3 dimensions. The noise correlationproperties in the interferometric image are fully characterized and easily measured by the noise autocorrelation function (ACF) We present the method for estimating the statistical uncertainty due to the correlated noise in the seamlessly integrated flux and spectra directly.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09720v1.title: Galaxy rotation curves incorporating relativistic mass and comparison with Keplerian velocity curves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09720v1.summary: We derive a formula for the velocity distribution of an axially symmetric galaxy. We then compare these to the rotation curves obtained from a similar formula without a relativistic correction factor. We find that the correction factor has a small dark-matter like effect. We conclude that there is a large discrepancy in this case, where away from the galactic center, up to the galactic edge, the curves computed using ourformulas give a noticeably higher velocity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09669v1.title: On The Fine Tuning and Physical Origin of Line-Locked Absorption Systems in Active Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09669v1.summary: Line locking (LL) of absorption line systems is a clear signature of the importance of radiation pressure force in driving astrophysicalflows. Recent findings suggest that it may be common in quasars displaying multiple intrinsic narrow absorption-line (NAL) systems. The high occurrence of LL by the CIV doublet implies that hidden extreme-UV emission is unlikely to be significantly under-estimated by current models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09640v1.title: Chronology of the chemical enrichment of the old Galactic stellar populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09640v1.summary: The Milky Way accreted several smaller satellite galaxies in its history. These mergers added stars and gas to the Galaxy and affected the properties of pre-existing stellar populations. Stellar chemical abundances and ages areneeded to establish the chronological order of events that occur before, during, and after such mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13226v2.title: A High Precision Survey of the D/H Ratio in the Nearby Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13226v2.summary: We present high S/N measurements of the H I Ly alpha absorption line toward Galactic targets. The targets are at distances between approximately 190 and 2200pc. Using deuterium column densities from other sources we determine the D/H ratio along the sight lines. We find that D/ H is only weakly correlated with metal depletion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09577v1.title: A Possible Chemical Clock in High-mass Star-forming Regions: N(HC3N)/N(N2H+)?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09577v1.summary: We conducted observations of multiple HC3N (J = 10-9, 12-11, and 16-15) lines and the N2H+ line toward a large sample of 61 ultracompact (UC) H IIregions. The rotational temperature and column density ofHC3N wereestimated toward sources with at least two HC3n lines. The abundance ratio of HC3Ns changes with the evolution of high-mass star-forming regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09452v1.title: ALMA ACA study of the H$_2$S/OCS ratio in low-mass protostars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09452v1.summary: Identifying the main sulfur reservoir on its way from the diffusestellar medium to the cold dense star-forming cores is a long-standing problem. The goal of this investigation is to derive the gas-phase H$_2$S/OCS ratio for several low-massprotostars. This could provide crucial information about the physical and chemical conditions in the birth cloud of Sun-like stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02750v2.title: A detection of the layered structure of nearby open clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02750v2.summary: We applied the newly developed rose diagram overlay method to detect the layered structure of 88 nearby open clusters. A total of 74 clusters in our sample have a layered structure, while the remaining clusters are without a clear layered structure. We found that the layered circle core area ($s$) has a strongpositive correlation with the number of cluster members.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.06805v2.title: Shadows around Sgr A* and M87* as a tool to test gravity theories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.06805v2.summary: Shadow around the supermassive black hole in M87 was reconstructed in 2019 based on observations with the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) in April 2017. In the framework of Randall -- Sundrum theory with extra dimension Reissner-- Nordstr\"om black hole solutions with a tidal charge have been found.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09380v1.title: Multiphase condensation in cluster halos: interplay of cooling, buoyancy and mixing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09380v1.summary: Gas in the central regions of cool-core clusters and other massive halos has a short cooling time. Theoretical models predict that this gas is susceptible to multiphase condensation. We explore the parameters relevant to galaxy and cluster halos. We also study the effect of the steepness of the entropy profile, the strength of tumultuous forcing and the nature of turbulent forcing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09370v1.title: Testing Super-Eddington Accretion onto a Supermassive Black Hole: Reverberation Mapping of PG 1119+120
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09370v1.summary: We measure the black hole mass and investigate the accretion flow around the local quasar PG 1119+120. We find the disc SED to be flatter than expected with an Eddington ratio of 1. While this accretion is super-Eddington, the geometry is still unclear, however a slimophobicdisc is expected due to the high radiation pressure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11788v2.title: Modelling the accretion and feedback of supermassive black hole binaries in gas-rich galaxy mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11788v2.summary: We introduce a new model for the accretion and feedback of supermassive blackhole (SMBH) binaries to the KETJU code. We perform idealised gas-rich disc galaxy merger simulations usingpure thermal or pure kinetic active galactic nuclei (AGN) feedback. Our model provides more physically motivated SMBH mass ratios, which are one of the key parameters for computing gravitational wave (GW) induced recoil Velocity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09266v1.title: Ionized carbon as a tracer of the assembly of interstellar clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09266v1.summary: Molecular hydrogen clouds are a key component of the interstellar medium because they are the birthplaces for stars. They are embedded in atomic gas that pervades the interstellar space. Details of how molecularclouds assemble from and interact with the atomic gas are still largely unknown. New observations of the 158~$\mu$m line of ionizedcarbon CII in the Cygnus region within the FEEDBACK program on SOFIA provide compelling evidence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09226v1.title: Collapsars as Sites of r-process Nucleosynthesis: Systematic Near-Infrared Follow-up of Type Ic-BL Supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09226v1.summary: One of the open questions following the discovery of GW170817 is whether astrophysical sites capable of producing r-process elements. Simulations have shown that 0.01-0.1M$_\odot$ could be generated in the outflows originating from the accretion disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.14712v2.title: Foreground Removal of CO Intensity Mapping Using Deep Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.14712v2.summary: Line intensity mapping (LIM) is a promising probe to study star formation, the large-scale structure of the Universe, and the epoch of reionization (EoR) Carbon monoxide (CO) is the second most abundant molecule in the Universe. However, just like other LIM surveys, CO intensity mapping alsosuffers strong foreground contamination.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.07964v2.title: The Ages of Galactic Bulge Stars with Realistic Uncertainties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.07964v2.summary: We recompute the age distribution for a sample of 91micro-lensed dwarfs in the Galactic bulge presented by Bensby et al. (2017) and do not produce an age distribution consistent with their results. Only 15 of 91 stars have ages younger than $7 Gyr, compared to their finding of 42 young stars in the same sample. Our results do suggest the presence of an $\sim8$ Gyr population at the highest metallicities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09165v1.title: Hydrodynamic Simulations and Time-dependent Photoionization Modeling of Starburst-driven Superwinds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09165v1.summary: Thermal energies deposited by OB stellar clusters in starburst galaxies lead to the formation of galactic superwinds. Multi-wavelength observations of starburst-driven super winds pointed at complex thermal and ionization structures which cannot adequately be explained by simple adiabatic assumptions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09152v1.title: The evolution of the UV/optical lag spectrum of NGC 7469 seen by the Liverpool Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09152v1.summary: We observed the source for 4 months in the ugriz bands, using the IO:O on the LiverpoolTelescope. We measured the lags with respect to the u band and found a clear change of the lag spectrum between the first and the second half of the spectrum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14048v1.title: Nuclear and electromagnetic cascades induced by ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays in radio galaxies: implications for Centaurus A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14048v1.summary: Very-high-energy (VHE) and neutrinos are crucial for identifying accelerators of ultrahigh- energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) We develop a numerical code to solve the transport equation for UHECR nuclei and their secondaries. In particular, we focus on Centaurus A, which has been proposed as one of the most promising UH ECR sources in the local universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14023v1.title: New mechanisms for forming multiple hotspots in radio jets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14023v1.summary: Multiple hotspots have long been identified as potential indicators of jetmovement or precession. Two frequent explanations describe a secondary hotspot as either the location of a prior jet termination point, or a deflected backflow-driven shock. We show that these distinct types of multiple hotspotcomplexes are difficult to differentiate in synthetic radio maps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02739v2.title: Envelopes for orbits around axially symmetric sources with spheroidal shape
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02739v2.summary: We introduce a method to obtain the envelopes of eccentric orbits in axiallysymmetric potentials, endowed with $z$-symmetry of reflection. We find that they obey the approximatedformula $Z(R)$ oforbits in the meridional plane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.13963v1.title: Two-photon production in low-velocity shocks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.13963v1.summary: Galactic interstellar medium abounds in low-velocity shocks with about 70 km/s. Some are descendants of higher velocity shocks, while others start off at low velocity. Low-vel velocity shocks cool primarily via Ly-alpha, two-photon continuum, optical recombination lines and forbidden lines of metals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11613v2.title: Demographics of Hierarchical Black Hole Mergers in Dense Star Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11613v2.summary: About a hundred mergers of binary black holes (BBHs) have been detected by the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA Collaboration. While most of the events are expected to consist of BHs directlyformed from the collapse of massive stars, some may contain the remnants ofprevious BBH mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03385v2.title: The locations of features in the mass distribution of merging binary black holes are robust against uncertainties in the metallicity-dependent cosmic star formation history
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03385v2.summary: New observational facilities are probing astrophysical transients such asstellar explosions and gravitational wave (GW) sources at ever increasing redshifts. To interpret these observations, we need to compare them to predictions fromstellar population models. Such models require the metallicity-dependent cosmic star formation history as an input. Large uncertaintiesremain in the shape and evolution of this function.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.13884v1.title: Jet-induced molecular gas excitation and turbulence in the Teacup
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.13884v1.summary: The Teacup galaxy is a radio-quiet type-2 quasar with a compact radio jet. The jet is compressing and accelerating the molecular gas, and driving a lateral outflow that shows enhanced velocity dispersion and higher gas excitation.
