http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02032v1.summary: Stellar streams are potentially a very sensitive observational probe of ofgalactic astrophysics, as well as the dark matter population in the Milky Way. Performing a detailed, high-fidelity statistical analysis of these objects is challenging for a number of key reasons. The majority of current analyses must resort to simplified models that use only subsets or summaries of the high quality data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02033v1.title: MaNGA galaxy properties -- II. A detailed comparison of observed and simulated spiral galaxy scaling relations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02033v1.summary: We present a catalogue of dynamical properties for 2368 late-type galaxies from the MaNGA survey. Simulated NIHAO galaxies were found to broadly reproduce the observed galaxies. The detailed spatially-resolved scatter analysis highlights the complex interactions between local and global astrophysical processes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02036v1.title: The spatial clustering of ROSAT all-sky survey Active Galactic Nuclei: V. The evolution of broad-line AGN clustering properties in the last 6 Gyr
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02036v1.summary: This is the fifth paper in a series of investigations of the clusteringproperties of luminous, broad-emission line active galactic nuclei (AGN) identified in the ROSAT All-Sky Survey (RASS) and Sloan Digital Sky Survey(SDSS) We find that X-ray andoptically-selected AGN at $0.44<z<0.64$ reside in statistically identical halos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02037v1.title: Kinematic analysis of the super-extended HI disk of the nearby spiral galaxy M83
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02037v1.summary: We present new HI observations of the nearby massive spiral galaxy M83. We examine HI gas surface density, velocity dispersion and non-circular motions in the outskirts. We find a possible branch that connects the extended HIdisk to the dwarf irregular galaxy UGCA365, that deviates from the general direction of the northern arm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07366v2.title: The first large catalogue of spectroscopic redshifts in Webb's First Deep Field, SMACS J0723.3$-$7327
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07366v2.summary: We present a spectroscopic redshift catalogue of the SMACS J0723.3$-$7327phthalfield ("Webb's First Deep Field") obtained from JWST/NIRISS grism spectroscopy. The catalogue contains 190 sources with secure redshifts, including six new NIRSpec redshifting identified in this work.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02026v1.title: The JWST FRESCO Survey: Legacy NIRCam/Grism Spectroscopy and Imaging in the two GOODS Fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02026v1.summary: JWST Cycle 1 53.8hr medium program FRESCO, short for "First                Reionization Epoch Spectroscopically Complete Observations" By obtaining 2 hr deep NIRCam/grism observations with the F444W filter, FRESCO yields unprecedented spectra at R~1600.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02029v1.title: Born to be wide: the distribution of wide binaries in the field and soft binaries in clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02029v1.summary: Very wide binaries can be easily disrupted in clusters due to dynamical evaporation and/or due to tidal disruption by the gravitational potential of the cluster. We use analytic tools to study the dynamical formation of soft binaries in clusters, and their survival following cluster dispersion. We find that the overall fraction of wide binaries scales as a function of mass, even for non-equal mass stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02007v1.title: The Role of Mass and Environment on Satellite distributions around Milky Way analogs in the Romulus25 simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02007v1.summary: We study satellite counts and quenched fractions for satellites of Milky Way                analogs in Romulus25, a large-volume cosmological hydrodynamic simulation. We find that the number of satellites hosted by a Milky Way analog increases with host stellar mass, while there is no trend with environment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01991v1.title: One Relation for All Wavelengths: The Far-Ultraviolet to Mid-Infrared Milky Way Spectroscopic R(V) Dependent Dust Extinction Relationship
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01991v1.summary: Dust extinction is one of the fundamental measurements of dust grain sizes, Compositions, and shapes. Most of the wavelength dependent variations seen in Milky Way extinction are strongly correlated with the single parameter R(V)=A(V)/E(B-V. Existing literature relationships show significant deviations compared to this relationship especially in the far-ultraviolet and mid-infrared. We find tentative evidence that the relationship may not be linear with A(V)/R(V.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.02469v2.title: Prevalence of Complex Organic Molecules in Starless and Prestellar Cores within the Taurus Molecular Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.02469v2.summary: Complex organic molecules (COMs) are detected in starless and prestellar cores. The mechanisms for COM formation are still debated. We find COMs are being formed early, at least hundreds of thousands of years prior to star and planet formation. The precursor molecule, CH$_3$OH, may be linked to the more complex CH$-3$CHO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01970v1.title: Catalog of Planetary Nebulae detected by GALEX and corollary optical surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01970v1.summary: Planetary nebulae (PNe) consist of an ionized envelope surrounding a hotcentral star (CSPN) that emits mostly at ultraviolet (UV) wavelengths. We have matched the PNe in The Hong Kong/AAO/Strasbourg HASH catalog with the Galaxy Evolution Explorer (GALEX) UV skysurveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04693v3.title: Constraints from dwarf galaxies on black hole seeding and growth models with current and future surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04693v3.summary: Dwarf galaxies are promising test beds for constraining models of supermassive black holes. Disentangling seeding from the confounding effects of mass assembly over a Hubble time is a challenging problem. We show how measured BHOF depends on the lowest black hole mass or AGN luminosity achieved.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01861v1.title: Spectroscopic Orbits of Subsystems in Multiple Stars. IX
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01861v1.summary: New spectroscopic orbits of inner subsystems in 14 hierarchies are determined from long-term monitoring with the optical echelle spectrometer, CHIRON. The inner periods range from 254 days to 18 yr. This work contributes new data on the architecture of nearby solar-type stars, complementing their statistics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01837v1.title: Constraints on the Epoch of Reionization with Roman Space Telescope and the Void Probability Function of Lyman-Alpha Emitters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01837v1.summary: We use large simulations of Lyman-Alpha Emitters with different fractions of the intergalactic medium to quantify the clustering of Ly$\alpha$ emitters. We quantify how well we might be able to distinguish between these scenarios with a deep spectroscopic survey using the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01792v1.title: Close encounters of black hole - star binaries with stellar-mass black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01792v1.summary: Dynamical interactions involving binaries play a crucial role in the evolution of star clusters and galaxies. We focus on binary black hole (BBH)formation, stellar disruption, and electromagnetic (EM) emission in dynamical interactions between a BH-star binary and a stellar-mass BH. BBHs are more likely to form when the star and the incoming BH encounter first.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01791v1.title: The formation history of our Galaxy's nuclear stellar disc constrained from HST observations of the Quintuplet field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01791v1.summary: Until recently it was thought that the nuclear stellar disc at the centre ofour Galaxy was formed via quasi-continuous star formation over billions of years. An analysis of GALACTICNUCLEUS survey data indicates that >80%of the mass of the stellar disc formed at least 8 Gyr ago.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01757v1.title: The ALMA Survey of 70 $μ$m Dark High-mass Clumps in Early Stages (ASHES). IX. Physical Properties and Spatial Distribution of Cores in IRDCs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01757v1.summary: The initial conditions found in infrared dark clouds (IRDCs) provide insights on how high-mass stars and stellar clusters form. We identify an unprecedented number of 839 cores, with masses between 0.05 and 81 $M_\odot$using 1.3 mm dust continuum emission. We find that the mass of the MMCs is correlated with the clump surface density, implying denser clumps produce more Massive cores.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01718v1.title: The ALMA Survey of 70 μm Dark High-mass Clumps in Early Stages (ASHES). VIII. Dynamics of Embedded Dense Cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01718v1.summary: We present the dynamical properties of 294 cores embedded in twelve IRDCs. The most massive cores are strongly self-gravitating and have greater surface density, Mach number, and velocity dispersion than cores with lower masses. Dense cores have not significant velocity shifts relative to low-density envelopes, suggesting that dense cores are co-moving with their envelopes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01671v1.title: The period--luminosity relation for Mira variables in the Milky Way using Gaia DR3: a further distance anchor for $H_0$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01671v1.summary: Gaia DR3 parallaxes are used to calibrate preliminary period--luminosityrelations of O-rich Mira variables in the 2MASS. The derived relations are compared to those measured for the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds. The Milky Way linear $JHK_s$relations are slightly steeper and thus fainter at short period than the corresponding LMC relations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01670v1.title: Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models to Predict the Density of Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01670v1.summary: We introduce the state-of-the-art Denoising DiffusionProbabilistic Model (DDPM) as a method to infer the volume or number density of giant molecular clouds. We conclude that the diffusion model achieves an order of magnitudeimprovement on the accuracy of predicting number density compared to that by other methods.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01610v1.title: $^{18}$O$/^{17}$O abundance ratio toward a sample of massive star forming regions with parallax distances
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01610v1.summary: The $^{18$O$/^{17}$O abundance ratio is, in principle, a powerful tool to estimate the relative contributions of massive stars and low- to intermediate-mass stars to the chemical enrichment of galaxies. We present an improved version of the ratio, resulting in smaller errors than previous work in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02376v2.title: Clustercentric distance or local density? It depends on galaxy morphology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02376v2.summary: The OmegaWINGS survey is currently the largest survey of clusters in the local Universe extending beyond 2 virial radii from the cluster cores. Localdensity and clustercentric distance seems to play different roles for galaxies with different morphology. The fraction of elliptical galaxies depends on local density mainly, suggesting that their formation was linked to the primordial core.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16553v3.title: Dynamics of Binary System around Supermassive Black Hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16553v3.summary: We discuss motion of a binary system around a supermassive black hole. Using Fermi-Walker transport, we construct a local inertial reference frame and set up a Newtonian binary system. We show that there appears the Kozai-Lidov (KL) oscillations when a binary is compact.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01437v1.title: Early Results from GLASS-JWST XXII: Rest frame UV-optical spectral properties of Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies at 3 $<$ z $<$ 6
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01437v1.summary: We present the rest UV-optical spectral characteristics of 11 Ly$\alpha$emitting galaxies at 3 $<$ z $ <$ 6 - the optimal redshift range chosen to avoid extreme IGM attenuation. We find that our galaxies have low masses, compact sizes, low dust content, moderate [OIII]/[OII] flux ratios. We predict the Lyman                continuum escape fraction in our sample to be low.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11276v3.title: Disruption of Dark Matter Minihaloes in the Milky Way environment: Implications for Axion Miniclusters and Early Matter Domination
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11276v3.summary: Many theories of dark matter beyond the Weakly Interacting Massive Particles paradigm feature an enhanced matter power spectrum on sub-parsec scales. Future localobservations are promising to search for and constrain such substructures. The survival fraction of dense dark matter minihaloes in the Milky Way is crucial for interpreting local observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01390v1.title: Surveying the Giant HII Regions of the Milky Way with SOFIA: V. DR7 and K3-50
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01390v1.summary: We present our fifth set of results from our mid-infrared imaging survey of the Milky Way Giant HII (GHII) regions with our detailed analysis of DR7 and K3-50. Eight out of the ten (80%) compact sources in K 3-50 are likely to be MYSOs. DR7 has values more like those of the non-GHII regions we have previously studied.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01378v1.title: A Diverse Population of z ~ 2 ULIRGs Revealed by JWST Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01378v1.summary: Four ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) observed with JWST/NIRcam in the Cosmos Evolution Early Release Science program. The objects were originally selected at 24                $\mu$m and have strong polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon emission features. The four objects have similar stellar masses but otherwise are quite diverse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01341v1.title: Reconstructing star formation rate for compact binary populations with Einstein telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01341v1.summary: Einstein Telescope (ET) is a proposed third generation, wide-band gravitational wave detector. Given its improved detection sensitivity, it will be capable of exploring the universe with GWs up to very high redshifts. We present an algorithm to infer the functional form of SFR for different populations of compact binaries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01320v1.title: Probing compact dark matter objects with microlensing in gravitationally lensed quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01320v1.summary: The microlensing signal in the light curves of gravitationally lensed quasars can shed light on the dark matter (DM) composition in their lensing galaxies. We use the most detailed lens models to date from the H0LiCOW/TDCOSMO collaboration to generate simulatedmicrolensing light curves.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01298v1.title: Atomic Data Assessment with PyNeb: Radiative and Electron Impact Excitation Rates for [Fe II] and [Fe III]
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01298v1.summary: We use the PyNeb 1.1.16 Python package to evaluate the atomic datasets available for the spectral modeling of [Fe II] and [Fe III. Most datasets are meticulouslyreconstructed from the sources, and new ones are incorporated to be compared with observed and measured benchmarks. For Fe III, the temperature dependency on the collisional data becomes a deterrent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03891v2.title: Tracing the kinematics of the whole ram pressure stripped tails in ESO 137-001
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03891v2.summary: Ram pressure stripping (RPS) is an important process to affect the evolution of cluster galaxies. We present a large MUSEmosaic for ESO 137-001 and its stripped tails. The warm, ionized gas is detected to at least 87 kpc from the galaxy and splits into three tails.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01260v1.title: The most luminous, merger-free AGN show only marginal correlation with bar presence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01260v1.summary: The role of large-scale bars in the fuelling of active galactic nuclei (AGN) is still debated. Evidence mounts that black hole growth in the absence of galaxy mergers may substantially influence disc(i.e., merger-free) galaxy evolution. We investigate whether large- scalegalactic bars are a good candidate for merger- free AGN fuelling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01257v1.title: The Hamiltonian for von Zeipel-Lidov-Kozai oscillations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01257v1.summary: The Hamiltonian used in classical analyses of von Zeipel-Lidov-Kozai or ZLKoscillations in hierarchical triple systems is based on the quadrupolepotential from a distant body on a fixed orbit. In a wide variety of astrophysical systems nonlinearperturbations are comparable to or greater than these effects. The long-termeffects of nonlinear perturbation are described by an additional Hamiltonian, which we call Brown's Hamiltonian.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01255v1.title: Gas and star kinematics in cloud-cloud collisions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01255v1.summary: Clouds collide and evolve in a background medium that is ten times less dense than the clouds. This relatively dense background is dynamically important for the evolution of the collision remnants. We investigate the effect of the initial cloud mass, velocities, internal turbulence, and impact angle on the remnants.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01253v1.title: Estimating Black Hole Spin from AGN SED Fitting: The Impact of General-Relativistic Ray Tracing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01253v1.summary: Accretion disc model fitting to optical/UV quasar spectra requires that the highest mass black holes have the highest spin. gravitational redshift cancels out most of the increase in temperature and luminosity from the smaller radii of high spin. These self consistent accretion disc models do not fit the UV spectra of the most massive quasars. This is likely showing that the disc structure is very different to that assumed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06695v1.title: A Gaia Data Release 3 View on the Tip of the Red Giant Branch Luminosity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06695v1.summary: The tip of the red giant branch (TRGB) is a standard candle that can be used to refine the determination of the Hubble constant. We calibrate the TRGB luminosity using a two-dimensional maximum likelihood algorithm with field stars and $Gaia$synthetic photometry and parallaxes. We find evidence of blending within the inner region for cluster member photometry that precludes accurate calibration.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06659v1.title: The role of previous generations of stars in triggering star formation and driving gas dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06659v1.summary: Simulations of star formation on molecular cloud scales typically start with aturbulent cloud of gas, from which stars form and then undergo feedback. We find the main role of a prior population is triggering starformation, and contributing to gas dynamics. Early time supernova from the initial population are important in triggering new star formation and driving gas motions above 100 pc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06658v1.title: Pure Spectroscopic Constraints on UV Luminosity Functions and Cosmic Star Formation History From 25 Galaxies at $z_\mathrm{spec}=8.61-13.20$ Confirmed with JWST/NIRSpec
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06658v1.summary: We present pure spectroscopic constraints on the UV luminosity functions andCosmic star formation rate (SFR) densities from 25 galaxies. We confirm 16 galaxies at $z_\mathrm{spec}=8.61-11.40$ including new redshift determinations. We suggest observational strategies for removing low redshift interlopers for future JWST programs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.08092v2.title: The north-south asymmetry of the ALFALFA HI velocity width function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.08092v2.summary: The number density of extragalactic 21-cm radio sources is a function of spectral line-widths. The HI width function (HIWF) is a sensitiveTracer of the dark matter halo mass function (HMF) The ALFALFA survey measured the HIWF in northern and southern Galactic fields and found a higher number density in the north.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06642v1.title: LeMMINGs. VI. Connecting nuclear activity to bulge properties of active and inactive galaxies: radio scaling relations and galaxy environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06642v1.summary: Nuclear activity and bulge properties are closely related, but the details remain unclear. We combine $Hubble~Space~Telescope$ bulge structural and photometric properties with 1.5 GHz, $e$-MERLIN nuclear radio continuum data from the LeMMINGs survey. None of our 10/173 bulgeless galaxies host an                AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06624v1.title: Towards discovery of gravitationally lensed explosive transients: the brightest galaxies in massive galaxy clusters from Planck-SZ2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06624v1.summary: We combine the Planck-SZ2 galaxy cluster catalogue with near-infraredphotometry of galaxies from the VISTA Hemisphere Survey to identify candidate cluster galaxies. We find 91% of these clusters have at least one candidate BCG within the 95% confidence interval on the cluster centers quoted by Planck.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06611v1.title: On the anti-correlation between pericentric distance and inner dark matter density of Milky Way's dwarf spheroidal galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06611v1.summary: An anti-correlation between the central density of the dark matter halo and the pericentric distances of dwarf spheroidal galaxies (dSphs) has been reported in the literature. The existence and origin of such anti-Correlation is however controversial. One possibility is that only the densest dSph's can survive the tidal field towards the centre of our Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06572v1.title: Star-formation-rate estimates from water emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06572v1.summary: The star-formation rate (SFR) quantitatively describes the process of star formation in galaxies. Current ways to calibrate this rate do not employ observational methods accounting for the low-mass end of stellarpopulations as their signatures are too weak. Accessing the bulk ofprotostellar activity within galactic star-forming regions can be achieved by tracing signposts of ongoing star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.03762v2.title: Normalized additional velocity distribution: testing the radial profile of dark matter halos and MOND
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.03762v2.summary: We propose a complementary and fast approach to study galaxy rotation curves. With this approach, some relevant tests can be done analytically. It is based on a dimensionlessdifference between the observational rotation curve and the expected one from baryonic matter. We consider three well known dark matter halo models (NFW, Burkert and DC14)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06529v1.title: Cosmological application of the lens-redshift probability distribution with improved galaxy-scale gravitational lensing sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06529v1.summary: We conduct the cosmological analysis by using the lens-redshift distribution test with updated galaxy-scale strong lensing sample. It shows that degeneracies between cosmologically and VDF parameters lead to the shifts of estimates on theparameters. The limits on the dark energy equation of state are consistent with those from the Pantheon+ sample at 68.3% confidence level.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15419v2.title: SILCC VII -- Gas kinematics and multiphase outflows of the simulated ISM at high gas surface densities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15419v2.summary: We simulate the star-formingmultiphase interstellar medium (ISM) in stratified galactic patches with gas surface densities of 10, 30, 50, and 100 kpc. The sink-based star formation and feedback model includes stellar winds, core-collapse supernovae, and cosmic ray (CR) injection and diffusion. CRs qualitatively change the outflow phase structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06452v1.title: Origin of neutron capture elements with the Gaia-ESO survey: the evolution of s- and r-process elements across the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06452v1.summary: We study abundance patterns and radial gradients of s-process and r-process elements in the Galactic thin disc by means of a detailed chemical evolution model. The predictions of our model are compared with data from the Gaia-ESO survey. We conclude that: i) the [Eu/Fe] vs. [Fe/H] is reproduced by both a prompt and a delayed source, but the quick source completely dominates the Eu production.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06356v1.title: Direct observations of the atomic-molecular phase transition in the Milky Way's nuclear wind
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06356v1.summary: Hundreds of high-velocity atomic gas clouds exist above and below the Galactic Centre. Some contain a molecular component. The origin of these clouds in the Milky Way's wind is unclear. This paper presents new high-resolution MeerKAT observations of three gas clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06329v1.title: Fermionic Dark Matter: Physics, Astrophysics, and Cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06329v1.summary: The nature of dark matter (DM) is one of the most relevant questions in modern astrophysics. We present a brief overview of recent results that inquire into a possible fermionic quantum nature of the DM particles. We also connect the RAR model fermions with particle physics for DM candidates, self-interactions, and galactic observables.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.02281v3.title: Three-Body Problem in Modified Dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.02281v3.summary: General properties of the three-body problem in a model of modified dynamics are investigated. Under certain conditions, orbits around $L4$ and $L5$ Lagrange points are stable. The rate of ejections is smaller in the modified dynamics compared to Newtonian gravity. These results could help us to search for observational signatures of extended gravities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06291v1.title: Far-infrared Polarization of the Supernova Remnant Cassiopeia A with SOFIA HAWC+
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06291v1.summary: Polarization observations of the young supernova remnant (SNR) Cas                A using the High-resolution Airborne Wideband Camera-Plus (HAWC+) instrument. Dust grains with strong polarization                fractions (5 - 30 percent) were found in the SNR. Stronger polarization is detected between the bright structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06272v1.title: HI 21 cm Extended Structures to the North-East, and South-West of NGC 5595: VLA Observations of the Disk Galaxy Pair NGC 5595 and NGC 5597
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06272v1.summary: We report VLA B-configuration observations of the HI 21 cm line on the closedisk galaxy pair NGC 5595 and N GC 5597. No HI 21cm emission is detected from the innermostcentral (nuclear) regions of either galaxy. Lower angular resolutionHI 21 cm imaging indicates the non-existence of any intergalactic HI 21c gas as tails or bridges between the two galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09827v4.title: Line Emission Mapper (LEM): Probing the physics of cosmic ecosystems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09827v4.summary: The Line Emission Mapper (LEM) is an X-ray Probe for the 2030s. It will answer the outstanding questions of the Universe's structure formation. LEM will use a large microcalorimeter/IFU, covering a 30x30' field with 10" angular resolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.07539v2.title: Origin and evolution of ultra-diffuse galaxies in different environments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.07539v2.summary: We study the formation of ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) using theulentcosmological hydrodynamical simulation TNG50 of the Illustris-TNG suite. Wedefine UDGs as dwarf galaxies in the stellar mass range of $7.5 - $9.5 that are in the $5\%$ most extended tail of the simulation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06151v1.title: Rotation curves of galaxies in GR
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06151v1.summary: It has been suggested that the observed flat rotation curves of disk galaxies can be a peculiar effect of General Relativity. Here we list some astrophysical problems that must be faced if the existence of DM halos is attributed to a misinterpretation of weakfield effects of GR. In Ciotti (2022) the problem has been quantitatively addressed by using the well knownweak-field, low-velocity gravitomagnetic limit.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06144v1.title: NuSTAR Observations of Candidate Subparsec Supermassive Black Holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06144v1.summary: Three AGN were identified as candidate subparsec binary supermassive black hole (SMBH) systems based on apparent periodicity in their optical light curves. Simulations predict that close-separation accreting SMBH binaries will have different X-ray spectra. We find that even at the higher energies probed by NuSTAR, the spectra of these AGN are indistinguishable from the larger AGN population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.05728v3.title: Relativistic dynamical friction in stellar systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.05728v3.summary: We extend the classical formulation of the dynamical friction effect on a test star by Chandrasekhar to the case of relativistic velocities and velocity distributions. The original kinetic framework is revised and used to construct a special-relativistic dynamicalriction formula. A simple expression is obtained for systems where the post-Newtonian correction on the gravitational forces become irrelevant even at non-relatsivistic particles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13572v2.title: Probing Axions via Light Circular Polarization and Event Horizon Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13572v2.summary: The impact of axion-like particles on the light polarization around the horizon of suppermassive black hole (SMBH) is discussed in the light of the latest polarization measurement of the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) We have shown that a significant circular polarization can be produced via the photon scatteringfrom the background magnetic field with axions as off-shell particles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06117v1.title: WISDOM project -- XVI. SMBH mass in the early-type galaxies NGC0612, NGC1574, and NGC4261 from CO dynamical modelling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06117v1.summary: We present a CO dynamical estimate of the mass of the super-massive blackhole (SMBH) in three nearby early-type galaxies: NGC0612, NGC1574 and NGC4261. The analysis is based on Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) observations of the $^{12}$CO(2-1) emission line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06096v1.title: UM 462, a local Green Pea galaxy analog under the MUSE magnifying glass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06096v1.summary: Stellar feedback in high-redshift galaxies plays an important role in the re-ionization epoch of the Universe. Green Pea galaxies (GPs) postulate as favorite local laboratories. At their typical redshift of. $z\sim0.2$, the most intimate interaction between stars and surrounding ISM.cannot be disentangled.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01200v2.title: Dark matter halo mass function and density profile from mass and energy cascade
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01200v2.summary: Halo abundance and structure play a central role for understating the smallscale challenges of $\Lambda$CDM cosmology. Without relying on a spherical orelliptical collapse model, we analytically derive the halo mass function and density profile based on the mass and energy cascade in dark matter flow. The corresponding Fokker-Planck solution gives rise to the analytical haloMass function.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06092v1.title: Imprint of the galactic acceleration scale on globular cluster systems: Galaxies in the Fornax Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06092v1.summary: Dark matter is required in galaxies at galactocentric radii that are larger than the $a_0$-radius. We have newly analyzed the distribution of GCs around galaxies in the Fornax cluster in existing photometric catalogs. We found that the correlation between the break radii of globular cluster systems is valid for early-type galaxies of all masses. This also applies to the red and blue sub-populations ofGCs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06090v1.title: Morphological asymmetries of quasar host galaxies with Subaru Hyper Suprime-Cam
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06090v1.summary: Quasar hosts are more asymmetric, on average, when they harbor a more massive black hole. The merger fraction also positively correlates with the host's luminosity. We quantify the dependence of asymmetry on optical band whichdemonstrates that mergers are more likely to be identified with the bluer bands.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06084v1.title: Cosmology with one galaxy? -- The ASTRID model and robustness
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06084v1.summary: A tight relation has been found between the cosmological parameter and the properties of individual galaxies in simulations. This relation also holds for galaxies from simulations run with a different code that made use of a distinct subgrid physics: Astrid. We find that also in this case, networks are able to infer the value of $z\leq3$ with a $sim10% precision.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06065v1.title: The Most Obscured AGNs in the XMM-SERVS Fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06065v1.summary: X-ray spectral analyses of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) in the XMM-Spitzer Extragalactic Representative Volume Survey. We uncover 22 representative Compton-thick(CT) AGN candidates with good signal-to-noise ratios. We also find an increasing CT fraction (\fct ) from low ($z<0.75$) to high ($z>0. 75$) redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06026v1.title: Multiple Stellar Populations in Metal-Poor Globular Clusters with JWST: a NIRCam view of M 92
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06026v1.summary: We explore the multiple populations in metal-poor GCs with [Fe/H]=$-$2.3. We take advantage of synthetic spectra and isochrones that account for the chemical composition of multiple populations to identify distinct stellar populations. We find isotropic motions with no differences among the distinct populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05999v1.title: The Loneliest Galaxies in the Universe: A GAMA and GalaxyZoo Study on Void Galaxy Morphology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05999v1.summary: The majority of the Universe's volume is taken up by voids, which exist as underdense, but not empty, regions. void galaxies, in contrast with field galaxies, seem to be disk-dominated and have predominantly round bulges. We determine the statistical significance of our results using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04480v2.title: Identification and properties of intense star-forming galaxies at redshifts z>10
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04480v2.summary: Surveys with James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have discovered four galaxies in the first 400 Myr of cosmic time. These galaxies include the first ever galaxies discovered with distances spectroscopically confirmed by JWST in a companion paper. Using stellar population modelling, we find the galaxies typically contain a hundred million solar masses in stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05950v1.title: Multi-phase gas nature in the sub-pc region of the active galactic nuclei I: Dynamical structures of dusty and dust-free outflow
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05950v1.summary: We investigated dusty and dust-free gas dynamics for a radiation-drivensub-pc scale outflow in an active galactic nucleus (AGN) associated with a supermassive black hole. The shape of the dust sublimation radius is not spherical and depends on the angle ($\theta$) from the disk plane. Gases near the Compton-thick component of the nucleus can be the origin of the Compton.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05924v1.title: Sensitivity study of chemistry in AGB outflows using chemical kinetics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05924v1.summary: Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) stars shed a significant amount of their mass in the form of a stellar wind, creating a vast circumstellar envelope (CSE) CSEs serve as rich astrochemical laboratories. A lack of understanding regarding the impact of changes in the physical environment on chemical abundances is needed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14732v3.title: First detection of the Hubble variation correlation and its scale dependence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14732v3.summary: The sample variance due to our local density fluctuations in measuring our local Hubble-constant ($H_0$) can be reduced to the percentage level by choosing the Hubble-flow type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) outside of the homogeneityscale. In this Letter, we have revealed a hidden trend in this one-percent                $H_ 0$ variation both theoretically and observationally. We have also identified a residual linear correlation between our local metrics and their ambient density contrasting galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05897v1.title: Hydrogen-free Wolf-Rayet stars: Helium stars with envelope-inflation structure and rotation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05897v1.summary: We try to explain the H-free WRstars observed in the Milk Way (MW) and the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) by the He stars. We have calculated the evolution of He stars using a new mass-loss rate formula and three different relative rotational velocities. High-mass He stars with the EIS evolve into WO stars at the final evolution stage.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05893v1.title: The diffuse radio emission in the high-redshift cluster PSZ2 G091.83+26.11: total intensity and polarisation analysis with Very Large Array 1-4 GHz observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05893v1.summary: PSZ2G091.83+26.11 at z=0.822.11 hosts a Mpc-scale radio halo and an elongated radio source. We use VLA data at 1-4GHz to investigate the spectral and polarisation properties. We alsoplement the radio data with Chandra X-ray observations to compare the thermal and non-thermal emission of the cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05875v1.title: Lensing with generalized symmetrons
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05875v1.summary: Generalized symmetrons are models that have qualitatively similar features to the archetypal symmetron. They can provide an explanation for the difference between baryonic and lens masses of galaxies. This motivates future studies of these only little explored models. For more information, visit the Generalized Symmetron website.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.10382v2.title: In-situ extreme mass ratio inspirals via sub-parsec formation and migration of stars in thin, gravitationally unstable AGN discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.10382v2.summary: We investigate the properties of stars born via gravitational instability inaccretion discs around supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in active galacticnuclei (AGN) We find that opacity gaps in discs around SMBHs can trigger fragmentation at radii of up to 10pc. Stars migrate till they are tidally destroyed, accreted as extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs), or leftover after disc dispersal.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05842v1.title: In pursuit of giants: II. Evolution of dusty quiescent galaxies over the last six billion years from the hCOSMOS survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05842v1.summary: 548 quiescent galaxies observed at $0.1<z<0.6$ as part of the HOSMOS spectroscopic survey. This is the largest sample of galaxies at intermediate redshifts for which the co-evolution of dust, metals and stars have been estimated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05840v1.title: New Deformed Heisenberg Algebra from the $μ$-Deformed Model of Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05840v1.summary: A new approach to modeling dark matter. The approach was extended to the study of galaxy.halo density profile and of the rotation curves of a number of (dwarf or low.brightness) galaxies. The new approach has interesting implications including the appearance of thequadruple of both maximal and minimal lengths and momenta.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05827v1.title: Highly structured turbulence in high-mass star formation: an evolved infrared dark cloud G35.20-0.74 N
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05827v1.summary: Massive stars are generally believed to form in supersonic turbulent environments. We aim to study the turbulence in atypical massive star-forming region G35.20-0.74 N. We find that the turbulence is all su personic, with mean and median Mach numbers 3.7 and 2.8, respectively.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05813v1.title: Finding AGN remnant candidates based on radio morphology with machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05813v1.summary: Remnant radio galaxies represent the dying phase of radio-loud activestellar nuclei (AGN) Large samples of remnant radio galaxies are important for quantifying the radio galaxy life cycle. Remnant galaxies can be identified in radio sky surveys based on their spectral index, or through visual inspection based on radio morphology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05793v1.title: Fuzzy dark matter confronts rotation curves of nearby dwarf irregular galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05793v1.summary: We investigate phenomenologically the viability of fuzzy dark matter (FDM) We do this by confronting the predictions of the model, in particular theformation of a solitonic core at the centre of dark matter haloes. FDM provides an excellent fit to the rotationcurves of the ``LITTLE THINGS in 3D'' catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13919v2.title: Local stellar formation history from the 40 pc white dwarf sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13919v2.summary: We derive the local stellar formation history from the Gaia-defined 40 pc                white dwarf sample. This is currently the largest volume-complete sample of                white dwarfs for which spectroscopy is available. Our derived stellarformation history gives a much better fit to the absolute Gaia G magnitudes than most previous studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05777v1.title: Survey of Orion Disks with ALMA (SODA) II: UV-driven disk mass loss in L1641 and L1647
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05777v1.summary: Internal FUV irradiation of protoplanetary disks has an important impact on their evolution and ability to form planets. We study disk mass loss driven by intermediate FUV radiation fields in L1641 and L1647, where it is driven by more common A0 and B-type stars. For FUV fields between 1 - 100 $G_0$, the median disk mass in the mostirradiated disks drops by a factor 2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05162v2.title: On the recent discovery claim of a new $z>7$ quasar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05162v2.summary: Koptelova et al. 2022 (K22) recently claimed a new quasar discovery at $z=7.46$. We find that the observations were contaminated by a moving SolarSystem object, likely a main-belt asteroid. We present our findings as a cautionary tale of the dangers of passing asteroids for photometric selections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05762v1.title: Photometric and Kinematic study of the open cluster NGC 1027
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05762v1.summary: We present photometric and kinematic analysis of an intermediate age open cluster NGC 1027 using $UBV(RI)_c$ and Gaia Early Data Release 3 (EDR3) data. Cluster center is found about 2 arcmin away from the center reported earlier. We find 217 most probable members with mean parallax 0.892 $\pm$ 0.088 mas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16679v2.title: Pitfalls in applying gravitomagnetism to galactic rotation curve modelling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16679v2.summary: The flatness of galaxy rotation curves at large radii is generally considered to be a significant piece of evidence in support of the existence of dark matter. Several studies have claimed that post-Newtonian corrections to the equations of galaxy dynamics may remove (at least to some degree) the need for dark Matter. A few recent studies have examined these claims and identified errors in their reasoning.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05406v1.title: Galactic ChitChat: Using Large Language Models to Converse with Astronomy Literature
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05406v1.summary: We demonstrate the potential of the state-of-the-art OpenAI GPT-4 largelanguage model to engage in meaningful interactions with Astronomy papers. To optimize for efficiency, we employ a distillationtechnique that effectively reduces the size of the original input paper by 50%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05577v1.title: The X-ray variation of M81* resolved by Chandra and NuSTAR
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05577v1.summary: X-ray continuum emission of the power-law shape more likely originates from from inverse Compton scattering within the hot accretion flow. In contrast to SgrA*, flares are rare in M81*. Low-amplitude variation can only be observed in the soft X-ray band. The flares in LLAGNs can be understood universally in a Magneto-hydrodynamical model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.02624v3.title: Stellar Initial Mass Function (IMF) Probed with Supernova Rates and Neutrino Background: Cosmic Average IMF Slope is $\simeq 2-3$ Similar to the Salpeter IMF
http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.02624v3.summary: The stellar initial mass function (IMF) is known as the poorly-constrained but very important function in studies of star and galaxy formation. There are noensible observational constraints on the IMF slopes beyond the Milky Way and nearby galaxies. We combine two sets of observational results, 1) cosmic far-ultraviolet radiation (and infrared re-radiation) densities and 2) core-collapse supernova explosion rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06115v2.title: Gravitomagnetism and galaxy rotation curves: a cautionary tale
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06115v2.summary: Recent claims that gravitomagnetic effects in linearised general relativity can explain flat and rising rotation curves. We show that for the values of the mass, $M$, typical for a dwarf galaxy, the rotation curve depends only very weakly on $M$. For aspect ratios $a/b > 2$, the rotation curves are concave over their entire range, which does not match observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05457v1.title: CAvity DEtection Tool (CADET): Pipeline for automatic detection of X-ray cavities in hot galactic and cluster atmospheres
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05457v1.summary: The study of jet-inflated X-ray cavities provides a powerful insight into theenergetics of hot galactic atmospheres and radio-mechanical AGN feedback. The pipeline consists of aconvolutional neural network trained for producing pixel-wise cavity predictions and a DBSCAN clustering algorithm, which decomposes the predictions into individual cavities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05434v1.title: Exploring the Magnetic Field Geometry in NGC 891 with SOFIA/HAWC+
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05434v1.summary: NGC 891 is a well-studied edge-on galaxy. Far-Infrared polarimetry observations of the galaxy were analyzed and compared to simple disk models with ordered (planar) and turbulent magnetic fields. There is evidence for a vertical field extending into the halo from one location to another.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05425v1.title: Survey of Gravitationally Lensed Objects in HSC Imaging (SuGOHI). IX. Discovery of Strongly Lensed Quasar Candidates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05425v1.summary: We report the discovery of new lensed quasar candidates in the imaging data of HSC-SSP DR4. 73 new systems contain at least two point sources and a galaxy in between. Spectroscopic or high-resolution imaging follow up will further allow their natures to be confirmed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05419v1.title: A deep dive: Chandra observations of the NGC 4839 group falling into the Coma cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05419v1.summary: New analysis of Chandra observations of the NGC4839 group falling into the nearby Coma cluster provides a unique opportunity to explore the way galaxy clusters in the local universe continue to grow. The analysis reveals a cold front feature at the leading head of the group,preceded by a bow shock of hot gas in front with a Mach number of 1.5.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05385v1.title: CEERS: Diversity of Lyman-Alpha Emitters during the Epoch of Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05385v1.summary: We analyze rest-frame ultraviolet to optical spectra of three galaxies whose Ly$\alpha$-emission lines were previously detected with Keck/MOSFIRE observations. We also compute the expected sizes of ionized bubbles that can be generated by the sources. High spectral resolution spectra will be extremely useful for constraining the physics of patchy reionization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05378v1.title: Spectroscopic confirmation of CEERS NIRCam-selected galaxies at $\boldsymbol{z \simeq 8-10}$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05378v1.summary: We present JWST/NIRSpec prism spectroscopy of seven galaxies selected from the Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science Survey (CEERS) NIRCam imaging. We measure emission line redshifts of z=7.65 and 8.64 for two galaxies, and z=9.77 and 10.01 for two others via the detection of continuum breaks. The presence (absense) of strong breaks (strong emission lines) give high confidence that these two galaxies are at z>9.6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05281v1.title: SBI++: Flexible, Ultra-fast Likelihood-free Inference Customized for Astronomical Application
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05281v1.summary: Simulation-based inference (SBI) can attain complex posterior distributions with the accuracy of traditional methods but with a $>10^4$ increase in speed. Standard SBI requires the simulated data to have identical characteristics to the observed data. We show that out-of-distribution errors can be approximated by using standard SBI evaluations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.05782v2.title: Model-independent estimation of the cosmography parameters using cosmic chronometers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.05782v2.summary: Measurement of the universe expansion rate through the cosmic chronometersproves to be a novel approach to understanding cosmic history. Although it provides a direct determination of the Hubble parameters at different redshifts, it suffers from underlying systematic uncertainties. In this work, we analyze the recent cosmic chronometer data with and without systematicuncertainties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08242v2.title: Modelling the cosmological Lyman-Werner background radiation field in the Early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08242v2.summary: The Lyman-Werner radiation field is a key ingredient in the evolution of gas in the Early Universe. Despite its important role, it is still not implemented in cosmological simulations on a regular basis. This is in part due to uncertainty in the source modelling, their spectra and abundance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05117v1.title: The magnesium paradigm in IRC+10216: Discovery of MgC$_4$H$^+$, MgC$_3$N$^+$, MgC$_6$H$^+$, and MgC$_5$N$^+$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05117v1.summary: We found four series of harmonically related lines in IRC\,+10216. The large values of $D$ point toward four metal-bearing carriers. This is the first time that cationic metal- bearing species have been found in space. These results provide a new paradigm on the reactivity of metals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14237v2.title: ELVES III: Environmental Quenching by Milky Way-Mass Hosts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14237v2.summary: Isolated dwarf galaxies usually exhibit robust star formation but satellitedwarf galaxies are often devoid of young stars, even in Milky Way-mass groups. We explore the balance of quiescent and star-forming galaxies (quenched fractions) for a sample of satellite galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05076v1.title: Differential reddening in the direction of 56 Galactic globular clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05076v1.summary: The presence of differential reddening in the direction of Galactic globular clusters (GCs) has proven to be a serious limitation in the traditionalcolour-magnitude diagram (CMD) analysis. For 21 out of 56 GCs the adopted correction procedure significantly improves the CMDs. We measure the reddening law in the directions of these clusters finding that $R_{V}$ exhibits a high level ofvariability within the Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08041v2.title: Morphological Analysis of the Polarized Synchrotron Emission with WMAP and Planck
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08041v2.summary: The bright polarized synchrotron emission, away from the Galactic plane, Disordersoriginates mostly from filamentary structures. We implement a filament finder algorithm which allows the detection of bright elongated structures in polarized intensity maps. We study the polarization spectral indices of the filaments, and find a spectral index consistent with the values found in previous analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13277v2.title: Off-centre supermassive black holes in bright central galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13277v2.summary: Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) are believed to reside at the centre ofmassive galaxies such as brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) However, as BCGs have experienced numerous galaxy mergers throughout their history, the central BHcan be significantly kicked from the central region by these dynamicalencounters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05034v1.title: The Hα Luminosity Function of Galaxies at z {\sim} 4.5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05034v1.summary: The study makes use of the new, full-depth Spitzer/IRAC [3.6] and [4.5] imaging from the GOODS Re-ionization Era wide-Area Treasury. We find that starformation rates (SFRs) derived from H{\alpha} are higher than those derived from the rest-frame UV for low SFR galaxies. This can be explained by lower mass galaxies (also lower SFR) having rising star formation histories.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05019v1.title: H$α$ emission line sources from VLT-MUSE in a low-metallicity star forming region -- Dolidze 25
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05019v1.summary: The process of accretion through circumstellar disks in young stellar objects is an integral part of star formation. We have identified 14 potential accreting sources within a rectangular region of (2$'$ x 1$' $) toward the center of the cluster. Based on their positions in both photometric color-magnitude. and color-color diagrams, we have also confirmed that these objects belong to the pre-main sequence phase of star. formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05013v1.title: Nitrogen pollution by metal enriched supermassive stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05013v1.summary: GN-z11 is an unusually luminous high redshift galaxy which was recently observed to have strong nitrogen lines. These observations have beeninterpreted as a super-solar nitrogen abundance which is challenging to explain with standard stellar evolution and supernovae enrichment. We present simulations of four models of metal enriched supermassive stars after the zero progressivelyage main sequence. We then show that the most massive model ends its life with a violent explosion which results in even greater nitrogen pollution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05003v1.title: Polarimetry of the potential binary supermassive black hole system in J1430+2303
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05003v1.summary: The growth of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) through merging has long been predicted but its detection remains elusive. A promising target has been discovered in the Seyfert-1 galaxy J1430+2303. The usual symmetry expected from pole-onviews in active galactic nuclei (AGNs) responsible for the observed low optical polarization is expected to be broken.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04990v1.title: Future Constraints on Dark Matter with Gravitationally Lensed Fast Radio Bursts Detected by BURSTT
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04990v1.summary: Fast radiobursts (FRBs) are millisecond flashes of radio light of unknown origin mostly from outside the Milky Way. Due to their short timescales, gravitationally lensed FRBs have been proposed as a useful probe. Taiwan plans to build a newtelescope, BURSTT dedicated to detecting FRBs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09945v4.title: Tidal Stripping of a White Dwarf by an Intermediate-Mass Black Hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09945v4.summary: During inspiralling of a white dwarf (WD) into an intermediate-mass blackhole, both gravitational waves (GWs) and electromagnetic(EM) radiation are emitted. Modeling these flares requires a prediction of the amount of stripped mass from the WD and the details of the accretion disk supply. We run hydrodynamical simulations to study the orbital parameter dependence of the stripped mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02928v2.title: Multi-phase gas interactions on subarcsec scales in the shocked IGM of Stephan's Quintet with JWST and ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02928v2.summary: JWST and HST imaging with ALMA~CO(2-1) spectroscopy to study the turbulent multi-phase intergalactic medium (IGM) in Stephan's Quintet on 25-150 pc scales. They reveal the dissipation of kinetic energy as massive clouds experience collisions, interactions and likelydestruction/re-cycling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00766v2.title: Collision of molecular outflows in the L1448--C system
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00766v2.summary: We present a study of the central zone of the star-forming region L1448 at217--230 GHz using ALMA observations. The study focuses on the detection of proto-stellar molecular outflows and the interaction with the surrounding medium. The red-shifted lobes of the outflows of two sources are believed to be colliding. We also investigated whether it could be possible that this collision triggers the formation of new stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15442v2.title: The Need For Speed: Rapid Refitting Techniques for Bayesian Spectral Characterization of the Gravitational Wave Background Using PTAs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15442v2.summary: P pulsar timing array (PTA) techniques for characterizing the spectrum of a nanohertz-frequency stochastic gravitational-wave background (SGWB) begin at the stage of timing data. This can be slow and memory intensive withcomputational scaling that will worsen PTA analysis times as more pulsars and Observations are added.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04864v1.title: Simulated observations of star formation regions: infrared evolution of globally collapsing clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04864v1.summary: The direct comparison between hydrodynamical simulations and observations isneeded to improve the physics included in the former. Post-processing radiative transfer and synthetic observations are now the standard way to do this. We find that in the early stages of the simulation,stellar radiation is inefficient in heating dust to the temperatures observed in Galactic clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04788v1.title: MUSEQuBES: The relation between Ly$α$ emitters and C IV absorbers at $z \approx 3.3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04788v1.summary: We present a detailed study of the column density and covering fraction of C IV absorption around 86 redshift $z \approx 3.3$ Ly$\alpha$ Emitters (LAEs) detected in 8 Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) fields centered on 8 bright background quasars. Neither the C IV column density nor the Dopplerparameter of individual C IV components shows any significant anti-correlation with impact parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04786v1.title: The impact of environmental effects on AGN: a decline in the incidence of ionized outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04786v1.summary: AGN have been generally considered to be less frequent in denser environments. This could be due to the lower number of galaxy-galaxy interactions and/or the removal of their gas-rich reservoirs by the dense intergalactic medium. We find that at lower masses the fraction of ionized outflows is significantly lower in satellite AGN than in isolated ones.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04783v1.title: Shedding New Light on Weak Emission-Line Quasars in the C$_{\rm IV}$-H$β$ Parameter Space
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04783v1.summary: weak emission-line quasars (WLQs) are a subset of Type 1 quasARS that exhibit extremely weak Ly$\alpha +$N V $1240 and/or C IV $1549 emissionlines. We apply a correction to the H$\beta$-based black-holemass estimates of these quasar using the strength of the Fe II emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04737v1.title: A Comparison of Outflow Properties in AGN Dwarfs vs. Star Forming Dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04737v1.summary: Stellar feedback was once believed to be sufficient to explain discrepancies between theory and observations. The recent discovery of energetic galaxy-wide outflows in dwarf galaxies suggests AGN feedback may have a larger role in the evolution of dwarf galaxies than previously suspected. Feedback likely plays a crucial role in resolving discrepancies between observed and theoretical predictions of dwarf galaxy properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04732v1.title: The Physical Drivers and Observational Tracers of CO-to-H2 Conversion Factor Variations in Nearby Barred Galaxy Centers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04732v1.summary: The CO-to-H$_2$ conversion factor is central to measuring the amount and properties of molecular gas. It is known to vary with environment, and previous studies have revealed lower CO in some barred galaxies. We obtained ALMA Band 3, 6, and 7 observations toward the inner 2 kpc of NGC 3627 and NGC 4321 tracing lines on 100 pc scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04719v1.title: (SHERRY) JCMT-SCUBA2 High Redshift Bright Quasar Survey -- II: the environment of z~6 quasars in sub-millimeter band
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04719v1.summary: The formation of the first supermassive black holes is expected to have occurred in some most pronounced matter and galaxy overdensities in the early universe. We have conducted a sub-mm wavelength continuum survey of 54 $z\sim6$quasars using the Submillimeter Common-User Bolometre Array-2 (SCUBA2) on the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT) We identified 170 submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) with above Haitian3.5$\sigma$ detections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04683v1.title: JWST and ALMA imaging of dust-obscured, massive substructures in a typical $z \sim 3$ star-forming disk galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04683v1.summary: We present an identification of dust-attenuated star-forming galactic-disk                substructures in a typical star-forms galaxy (SFG), UDF2, at $z = 2.696. The largest substructure contains a significant buildup of stellar mass and activelyforming stars. The substructures may be associated withinteraction-induced instabilities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04605v1.title: Prediction of Planet Yields by the PRime-focus Infrared Microlensing Experiment Microlensing Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04605v1.summary: The PRime-focus Infrared Microlensing Experiment (PRIME) will be the first toconduct a dedicated near infrared (NIR) microlensing survey by using a 1.8m telescope. The major goals of the PRIMEmicrolensing. survey are to measure the micro lensing event rate in the inner. Galactic bulge and to help design the observing strategy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01115v2.title: Early results from GLASS-JWST. XX: Unveiling a population of "red-excess'' galaxies in Abell2744 and in the coeval field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01115v2.summary: Galaxies in the field and at the cluster virial radius are overall characterized by redder colors. The galaxies with the largest color deviations are found in the fields and in the cluster core. Our hypothesis is that these galaxies are characterized by dust-obscured star formation. Larger spectroscopic samples are needed to understand if the color                excess is due exclusively to dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04520v1.title: Bright X-ray pulsars as sources of MeV neutrinos in the sky
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04520v1.summary: High mass accretion rate onto strongly magnetised neutron stars results in the appearance of accretion columns supported by the radiation pressure. Under such conditions, a noticeable part of the total energy release can be carried away by neutrinos of a MeV energy range. We estimate the neutrino energy fluxes expected from six ULX pulsars and three brightest Be X-ray transits.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04465v1.title: The ISM scaling relations using inner HI and an application of estimating dust mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04465v1.summary: We select a disk-like galaxy sample with observations of the $HI$ and dust from Herschel Reference Survey. We find that the inner gas-to-dust ratio is almostindependent of gas-phase metallicity. The predicted dust masses show scaling relations consistent with fiducial ones in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07884v2.title: Keck Integral-Field Spectroscopy of M87 Reveals an Intrinsically Triaxial Galaxy and a Revised Black Hole Mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07884v2.summary: The three-dimensional intrinsic shape of a galaxy and the mass of the central supermassive black hole provide key insight into the galaxy's growth history. Standard assumptions of a spherical or axisymmetric shape can be simplistic and bias the black hole mass inferred from the motions ofstars within a galaxy. Triaxial Schwarzschild orbit modeling enabled us to determine simultaneously the shape and mass parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04348v1.title: Are the ultra-high-redshift galaxies at z > 10 surprising in the context of standard galaxy formation models?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04348v1.summary: A substantial number of ultra-high redshift (8 < z < 17) galaxy candidates have been detected with JWST. Are these observational results surprising in the context of current galaxy formation models? We find that our (dust-free) models predict galaxy number densities at z~11 (z~ 13) that are an order of magnitude (a factor of 20-30) lower than the observational estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04313v1.title: Conservative limits on the electric charge of Sgr A* in the Reissner-Nordstrom metric
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04313v1.summary: In General Relativity, the gravitational field of an electrically charged, non-rotating body is described by the Reissner-Nordstrom(RN) metric. In the naked-singularity regime, a general property of this metric is the existence of a radius, known as the zero-gravity radius. As a consequence of repulsive gravity, there is no circular orbit inside this radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04294v1.title: CCD UBV and Gaia DR3 based analysis of NGC 189, NGC 1758 and NGC 7762 open clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04294v1.summary: This paper presents photometric, astrometric, and kinematic analyses of the open clusters NGC 189, NGC 1758 and NGC 7762. It is based on CCD UBV photometric and Gaia Data Release 3 (DR3) data. Distance moduli and ages of the clusters were obtained by comparing PARSEC isochrones with thecolor-magnitude diagrams.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04277v1.title: Latent Stochastic Differential Equations for Modeling Quasar Variability and Inferring Black Hole Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04277v1.summary: Active galactic nuclei (AGN) are believed to be powered by the accretion of matter around supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies. The temporalvariability of an AGN's brightness over time can reveal important information about the physical properties of the underlying black hole. With upcoming wide-field surveys set to observe 100 million AGN, there is a need for efficient and automated modeling techniques.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.04463v3.title: SN 2020jgb: A Peculiar Type Ia Supernova Triggered by a Helium-Shell Detonation in a Star-Forming Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.04463v3.summary: We present observations of SN 2020jgb, a peculiar SN Ia discovered by the Zwicky Transient Facility. We show that the optical spectroscopic and photometric evolution of SN2020jgb are consistent with a thick He-shelldouble detonation (DDet) SN. We also show that a prominent absorption feature in the NIR spectrum could originate from unburnt worrisomehelium in the outermost ejecta.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04004v1.title: Cold molecular gas outflow encasing the ionised one in the Seyfert galaxy NGC 3281
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04004v1.summary: ALMA CO(2-1) observations of the Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 3281. This galaxy was previously known to present a ionised gas outflow extending to 2 kpc from the nucleus. The similarity of the CO outflow and the X-ray emission to those seen in other sources suggests that this may be a common property of galactic outflows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02756v2.title: Upper limits on transmitter rate of extragalactic civilizations placed by Breakthrough Listen observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02756v2.summary: The Search for Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence (SETI) has been conducted for over 60 years, yet no technosignatures have been identified. Civilizations capable of harvesting energy from a star or a galaxy are classified as KII or KIII on the Kardashev scale. Such advanced civilizations would be extremely luminous and detectable by current radiotelescopes, even from distant galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03987v1.title: The role of magnetic fields in the fragmentation of the Taurus B213 filament into Sun-type star-forming cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03987v1.summary: Fragmentation is a key step in the process of transforming clouds into protostars. The presence of ordered magnetic fields could be important in the fragmentation of the B213 filament. The contributions of other factors (such as magnetic fields andurbulence) to the fragmentation process remain less explored.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03975v1.title: Intra-night optical flux and polarization variability of BL~Lacertae during its 2020 $-$ 2021 high state
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03975v1.summary: Blazar BL Lacertae showed significant flux variability and some color changes, but no firmly detectable time delays between the optical bands. The linear polarization was also highlyvariable in both -- polarization degree and angle (EVPA) The object was observed from several observatories throughout the world, covering in a total of almost 300 hours during 66 nights.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03875v1.title: The C-Band All-Sky Survey (C-BASS): New Constraints on the Integrated Radio Spectrum of M 31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03875v1.summary: The Andromeda galaxy (M31) is our closest neighbouring spiral galaxy, making it an ideal target for studying the physics of the interstellar medium. Using new observations of M31 at 4.76GHz by the C-Band All-Sky Survey (C-BASS), we produce the integrated spectrum and put new constraints on the synchrotron spectral index and anomalous microwave emission from M31.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03871v1.title: KMT-2021-BLG-2010Lb, KMT-2022-BLG-0371Lb, and KMT-2022-BLG-1013Lb: Three microlensing planets detected via partially covered signals
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03871v1.summary: We inspect 4 microlensing events KMT-2021-BLG-1968, K MT- 2021- BLG-2010, KMT - 2022-BLg-1013. We conduct detailed analyses of the events with the aim of revealing the nature of the anomalies. We test various models that can give rise to the anomalies of the individual events. We find that the anomalies are uniquely defined by planetary-lensinterpretations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03863v1.title: A Numerical Study of the Impact of Jet Magnetic Topology on Radio Galaxy Evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03863v1.summary: The propagation of active galactic nucleus jets depends both on the environment into which they propagate and on their internal structure. We conducted a series of magneto-hydrodynamic simulations of jets injected with different magnetic field configurations. In all cases, the simulations show a distinct reversal of the spectral age gradient in the radio lobes about a dynamical time after the jets turn off.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03798v1.title: Cool and gusty, with a chance of rain: Dynamics of multiphase CGM around massive galaxies in the Romulus simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03798v1.summary: Using high-resolution Romulus simulations, we explore the origin and evolving of the circumgalactic medium. We find that the CGM is both multiphase and highly dynamic. Strong amplitude perturbations can provokerunaway cooling regardless of the state of the background gas. Realistic CGM models must factor in the effects of mergers and orbiting satellites.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09466v3.title: On the origin of radio-loudness in active galactic nuclei using far-infrared polarimetric observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09466v3.summary: The dichotomy between radio-loud (RL) and radio-quiet (RQ) active galacticnuclei (AGN) is thought to be intrinsically related to radio jet production. This difference may be explained by the presence of a strong magnetic field that enhances the accretion activity and the jet power.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03795v1.title: Constraints on the Inner Regions of Lensing Galaxies from Central Images using a Recent AGN Offset Distribution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03795v1.summary: In gravitational lensing, central images in quads can serve as a powerfulprobe of the inner regions of lens galaxies. A detection of the central image in any quad would favor larger SMBH off-nucleus distances and galactic core sizes. Our results show that tight constraints on lens galaxy parameters can be made regardless of the detection or non-detection of a central image.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03790v1.title: The importance of live binary evolution in numerical simulations of binaries embedded in circumbinary discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03790v1.summary: The shrinking of a binary orbit driven by the interaction with a gaseous.circumbinary disc has been debated in the case of geometrically thick(i.e. with $H/R\gtrsim 0.1$) discs. We find that fixing the binaryorbit ultimately leads to an overestimate of the gravitational torque that the gas exerts on the binary, and in an underestimate of the torque due to the accretion of material onto the binary components.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03786v1.title: Efficient large-scale, targeted gravitational-wave probes of supermassive black-hole binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03786v1.summary: Supermassive black hole binaries are promising sources of low-frequency gravitational waves and bright electromagnetic emission. Pulsar timingarray searches for resolved binaries are complex and computationally expensive. We present an efficient approximation that empowers large-scale targeted multi-messenger searches by neglecting GW signals from the pulsar term.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03726v1.title: Active Massive Black Hole Found in the Young Star-Forming Dwarf Galaxy SBS 0335-052E
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03726v1.summary: Young star-forming dwarf galaxies with extremely low heavy-element abundances have been identified. SBS 0335-052E is intensivelystudied as a laboratory of galaxy formation. This is the first example of the massive black hole existence in a long-considered young star-forms dwarf galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07069v2.title: The Response of Dark Matter Haloes to Gas Ejection: CuspCore II
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07069v2.summary: We propose an analytic model, CuspCore II, for the response of dark matter(DM) haloes to central gas ejection. We test this model and three othermethods using idealized N-body simulations. The current model is physically justified and provides more accurate predictions than the earlier version. Our model is being generalized to address the differential response of a multi- component system ofstars and DM in the formation of DM-deficient galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03090v2.title: 3D modeling of the molecular gas kinematics in optically-selected jellyfish galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03090v2.summary: Cluster galaxies are subject to the ram pressure exerted by the intracluster. This can perturb or even strip away their gas while leaving the stars untouched. Signatures of ram pressure are found in JO201 and JO206. The stripping affects the whole molecular gas disk of JW100.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03670v1.title: Flares from stars crossing active galactic nuclei disks on low-inclination orbits
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03670v1.summary: The origin of the recently discovered new class of transients, X-rayquasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs), remains a puzzle. In this paper, we predict the properties of emission from bowshocks produced by stars crossing AGN disks, and compare them to the observed QPEs. We find that when a star's orbit is retrograde and has a low inclination with respect to the AGN disk, the breakout emission from the bow shock can explain the observed duration.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.17237v4.title: Statistical description of galaxy clusters in Finzi model of gravity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.17237v4.summary: We exploit a new theory of gravity proposed by Finzi to study the thermodynamic description of galaxy clusters. We analyze the behavior of clusteringparameter in comparison to its standard (Newtonian) counterpart. We also analyze the model by comparing the results with data available through SDSS-III.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03582v1.title: Reaction kinetics of CN + toluene and its implication on the productions of aromatic nitriles in the Taurus molecular cloud and Titan's atmosphere
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03582v1.summary: Aromatic nitriles might participate in the formation of polycyclic aromaticnitrogen containing hydrocarbons (PANHs) in Titan's atmosphere. The detection of main products, tolunitriles, can serve as proxies for the undetected toluene in the ISM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03547v1.title: Milky Way globular clusters on cosmological timescales. I. Evolution of the orbital parameters in time-varying potentials
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03547v1.summary: The Milky Way galaxy contains about 170 globular clusters (GCs) A fraction of them are likely formed in dwarf galaxies accreted onto the MW in the past. We found that the in-situ formed GCs are less affected by the evolution of the TNG potentials as compared to the clusters which are likelyformed ex-Situ.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03527v1.title: Minor Mergers are not enough: The importance of Major Mergers during Brightest Cluster Galaxy assembly
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03527v1.summary: We investigate the roles of major and minor mergers during Brightest Cluster Galaxy assembly using surface brightness profiles, line indices, and fundamental plane relations. We find that BCGs and luminous normalEllipticals (LNEs) have similar central velocity dispersions, centralabsorption line strengths, and central surface brightnesses. BCGs are more luminous due to their much larger radial extent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03419v1.title: The Effect of Boundary Conditions on Structure Formation in Fuzzy Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03419v1.summary: We illustrate the effect of boundary conditions on the evolution of structure in Fuzzy Dark Matter. Replacing isolation boundary conditions by periodic boundary conditions changes the domain topology and dynamics of each scenario. We found that the ground-state equilibrium solution is an attractor for the asymptotic state even in 3D.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12437v2.title: Constraining AGN Torus Sizes with Optical and Mid-Infrared Ensemble Structure Functions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12437v2.summary: We propose a new method to constrain the size of the dusty torus inbroad-line active galactic nuclei (AGNs) Using optical and mid-infrared (MIR)ensemble structure functions (SFs), we measure a torus $R-L$ relation. More extended tori have steeper MIR SFs with respect to the optical SFs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03358v1.title: A self-consistent semi-analytic model for Population III star formation in minihalos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03358v1.summary: The formation of the first stars marks a watershed moment in the history ofour universe.
