http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02335v1.summary: Dynamical measurements indicate the presence of a central SMBH in the dwarf galaxy Leo I. This is the first detected in a Milky Way satellite. We used the ASTRID and Illustris TNG50 LCDM cosmological simulations to investigate the assembly history of galaxies hosting over-massiveSMBHs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02316v1.title: Evidence for multiple nucleosynthetic processes from carbon enhanced metal-poor stars in the Carina dwarf spheroidal galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02316v1.summary: Carbon Enhanced Metal-Poor (CEMP) stars are known to exist in large numbers at low metallicity in the Milky Way halo. Very few such stars have been identified in the classical dwarf spheroidal (dSph)galaxies, and detailed abundances have only been reported for 12 stars. This is the largest sample of CEMP stars in a dSph galaxy analysed to date.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.10528v2.title: Code Comparison in Galaxy Scale Simulations with Resolved Supernova Feedback: Lagrangian vs. Eulerian Methods
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.10528v2.summary: We present a suite of high-resolution simulations of an isolated dwarf galaxy using four hydrodynamical codes. All codes adopt the same physical model which includes radiative cooling, photoelectric heating, star formation, and supernova feedback. The Lagrangian codes show significantly burstier star formation and larger supernova-driven bubbles, and stronger galactic outflows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02331v1.title: Computed microwave spectra of C$_{70}^+$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02331v1.summary: The apolar fullerenes C60 and C70 are not accessible for radio astronomy. The static Jahn-Teller effect in C70+ is the consequence of the mixing of the two highest ground state occupied orbitals. Microwave rotational spectrum simulations for the slightly asymmetrictop ion were carried out for gas phase temperatures 2.73 K and 10 K.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02286v1.title: Binary Formation in a 100 $μ$m-dark Massive Core
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02286v1.summary: High-resolution ALMA observations toward a massive protostellar core in the Dragon Infrared Dark Cloud. C1-Sa1 likelydrives two bipolar outflows, one being parallel to the plane-of-the-sky. At a higher resolution of 96 AU, the core begins to show an irregularshape at the periphery.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02262v1.title: An Interferometric SETI Observation of Kepler-111 b
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02262v1.summary: We used the European VLBI Network at $21$~cm to observe potential secondary phase calibrators in the Kepler field. A VLBA primary calibrator in the field, J1926+4441, offset only $1.88' from a nearby exoplanet Kepler-111~b, was correlated with high temporal and spectral resolution. During the analysis of the high-resolution data, we identified a spectral feature that was present in both auto and cross-correlation data with a central frequency of $1420.424\pm0.0002$ MHz and a width of 0.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16204v2.title: The Decoupling of Binaries from Their Circumbinary Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16204v2.summary: We have investigated accreting supermassive black hole binaries as they inspiral. Our simulations accurately capture the point at which the orbital evolving of each binary decouples from that of their circumbinary disk. We show that, even when dynamically negligible, gas may leave a detectable imprint on the phase of gravitational waves. If detected, such a decrease may unambiguously identify the host galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02189v1.title: EMPRESS. XIV. Strong High Ionization Lines of Young Galaxies at $z=0-8$: Ionizing Spectra Consistent with the Intermediate Mass Black Holes with $M_{\rm BH}\sim 10^3-10^6\ M_\odot$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02189v1.summary: We present ionizing spectra estimated at 13.6--100 eV for ten dwarf galaxies with strong high ionization lines of hydrogen, helium, oxygen, neon, and sulfur. We then compare the spectra of these six galaxies with those predicted by the black hole accretion disk models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12938v2.title: Confident Detection of Doubly-Ionized Thorium in the Extreme Ap Star CPD-62 2717
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12938v2.summary: CPD-62 2717 was initially recognized as a highly-magnetized Ap star thanks to resolved magnetically split lines captured in $H$-bandspectra from the SDSS/APOGEE survey. Follow-up with the VLT+UVESconfirmed a similarly peculiar optical spectrum featuring dozens of Th IIIlines, among other peculiarities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.09915v2.title: Thermal and chemical properties of the eROSITA bubbles from Suzaku observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.09915v2.summary: The eROSITA bubble shells are X-ray bright because they traceenser gas, not because they are hotter. We also observe non-solar Ne/O and Mg/O ratios in the shells, favouring stellar feedback models for the formation of the bubbles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02078v1.title: EMPRESS. XIII. Chemical Enrichments of Young Galaxies Near and Far at z ~ 0 and 4-10: Fe/O, Ar/O, S/O, and N/O Measurements with Chemical Evolution Model Comparisons
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02078v1.summary: We present gas-phase elemental abundance ratios of 7 local extremely metal-poor galaxies (EMPGs) and 33 JWST $z\sim 4-10$ star-forming galaxies. We find that high Fe/O values of EMPGs can (cannot) be explained by PISN metal enrichments. The high N/O ratio reported in GN-z11 cannot be explained even by rotating PISNe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02071v1.title: Application of the disk instability model to all Quasi-Periodic Eruptions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02071v1.summary: The first quasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs, GSN069) was reported in 2019. However, theysics behind QPEs is still unclear so far. Several models have been proposed. Pan et al. (2022) proposed an instability model for the accretion disk with magnetically driven outflows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02069v1.title: Tailoring galaxies: size-luminosity-surface brightness relations of bulges and disks along the morphological sequence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02069v1.summary: We measure the scaling relations of the bulges and disks of the EFIGI grotesquegalaxies in the nearby Universe. We use bulge and diskdecomposition of SDSS gri images with SourceXtractor++. The size-luminosity relations for E and dE types are steeper and similar to those from Binggeli et al. (1984)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00387v2.title: The EB-correlation in Resolved Polarized Images: Connections to Astrophysics of Black Holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00387v2.summary: We present an in-depth analysis of a newly proposed correlation function in visibility space. We demonstrate that the phase map of the time-averaged EB-correlation contains novel information that might be linked to the BH spin, accretion state and the electron temperature. We use a set of different geometrical ring models with various magnetic and velocity field morphologies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00020v2.title: Kinematics and stability of high-mass protostellar disk candidates at sub-arcsecond resolution -- Insights from the IRAM NOEMA large program CORE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00020v2.summary: The fragmentation mode of high-mass molecular clumps and the accretion processes that form the most massive stars are still not well understood. We have undertaken a large observational program making use of interferometric observations from the Northern ExtendedMillimetre Array (NOEMA) for a sample of 20 luminous objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02007v1.title: Detections of 21-cm absorption with a blind FAST survey at z $\leqslant$ 0.09
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02007v1.summary: We present the early science results from a blind search of the extragalacticHI 21-cm absorption lines at z 0.09. We carried out the search using the data collected in 643.8 hours by the ongoing CommensalRadio Astronomy FasT Survey (CRAFTS) The most likely interpretation is that a radio-loudactive galactic nucleus (AGN) is faint in the optical as the background source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.13677v2.title: A study of carbon-rich post-AGB stars in the Milky Way to understand the production of carbonaceous dust from evolved stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.13677v2.summary: The goal of this study is to reconstruct the evolution and the dust formation process during the final AGB phases of carbon-rich, post-AGBGalactic stars. We study the IR excess of sources classified as single stars by means of dust formation modelling where dust grains form and grow in a static wind and expand from the surface of the star.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01952v1.title: The PAU Survey: Close galaxy pairs identification and analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01952v1.summary: Galaxy pairs constitute the initial building blocks of galaxy evolution, which is driven through merger events and interactions. The analysis of these systems can be valuable in understanding galaxy evolution and studying structure formation. In this work, we present a new publicly available publicly availablecatalogue of close galaxy pairs identified using photometric redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12028v2.title: Transition disc nature of post-AGB binary systems confirmed by mid-infrared interferometry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12028v2.summary: Many properties of circumbinary discs around evolved post-asymptotic giant branch (post-AGB) binary systems are similar to those of protoplanetary discs around young stars. The deficits of near-infrared (near-IR) flux in the systems hints towards large                dust-free cavities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01908v1.title: The origin of dust polarization in the Orion Bar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01908v1.summary: Aspherical grains tend to align themselves with magnetic field lines. Some aspects of this alignment mechanism still need to bequantitatively tested. We find that the grain size at which the alignment shifts from B-RAT to k-R AT corresponds to grains too large to survive the rotational disruption.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14840v2.title: How negative feedback and the ambient environment limit the influence of recombination in common envelope evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14840v2.summary: We perform 3D hydrodynamical simulations to study recombination and                ionization during the common envelope (CE) phase of binary evolution. We compare a run employing a.tabulated equation of state (EOS) that accounts for ionization and.recombination, with a run using an ideal gas EOS. During the first half of the simulations, more mass is unbound in the tabulated EOS run due to the release of recombination energy, but by simulation end the difference has become negligible.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01887v1.title: A deep optical survey of young stars in the Carina Nebula. I. -- UBVRI photometric data and fundamental parameters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01887v1.summary: This master catalog allows us to select reliable members and determine thefundamental parameters distance, size, stellar density of stellar clusters in this star-forming region. We revisit the reddening toward the nebula using theoptical and the near-infrared colors of early-type stars. We find that the distance modulus of the Carina Nebula to be 11.9+/-0.3 mag.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01842v1.title: The Halo21 Absorption Modeling Challenge: Lessons From "Observing" Synthetic Circumgalactic Absorption Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01842v1.summary: In the Halo21 absorption modeling challenge we generated synthetic absorption spectra of the circumgalactic medium (CGM) We attempted to estimate the metallicity, temperature, and density (Z, T, and nH) of the underlying gasusing observational methods. We found that the observationalestimates were accurate for both uniform cloud samples and turbulent mixing zones.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01802v1.title: The Spatial Correlation of High Mass X-ray Binaries and Young Star Clusters in Nearby Star-Forming Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01802v1.summary: High-mass X-ray binary (HMXB) and young star cluster (YSC) populations in M31 and M33. HMXBs are spatially correlated with YSCs to a higher degree than would be expected from random chance in both galaxies. We interpret our results in the context of the recent star formation histories of the galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01793v1.title: JWST UNCOVER: Discovery of $z>9$ Galaxy Candidates Behind the Lensing Cluster Abell 2744
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01793v1.summary: We present the results of a search for high-redshift ($z>9$) galaxy candidates in the JWST UNCOVER survey. Candidates have a wide range of luminosities and young ages, with low stellar masses and low star formation rates. We also find evidence for a rapidredshift-evolution of the mass-luminosity relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02263v2.title: Globular cluster formation histories, masses and radii inferred from gravitational waves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02263v2.summary: Globular clusters (GCs) are found in all types of galaxies and harbor some of the most extreme stellar systems. Uncertain GC properties, including whenthey formed, their initial masses and sizes, affect their production rate of BBH mergers. We find that the GC formation rate probably rises more steeply than the global star formation rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08271v2.title: A Stability Timescale for Non-Hierarchical Three-Body Systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08271v2.summary: The gravitational three-body problem is a fundamental problem in physics and has significant applications to astronomy. Three-body configurations are often considered stable as long the system is hierarchical. For eccentric orbits in particular, the instability is primarily driven by close encounters of the test particle with one of the other bodies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01765v1.title: Magnetic Fields in Cosmic Voids
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01765v1.summary: Magnetic fields are one of most concealed components of the universe. They are observed as part of the intergalactic medium and on galaxy cluster scales. However their origin and evolution is unclear. In this work we use theIllustrisTNG simulation to investigate the effects of magnetic fields in cosmicvoids. We find that, under the hypothesis of a uniform primordial magnetic field, the voids still reflect the primordial properties of the fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02472v2.title: BIFROST: simulating compact subsystems in star clusters using a hierarchical fourth-order forward symplectic integrator code
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02472v2.summary: BIFROST can efficiently evolve collisional stellar systems with arbitrary binary fractions. The code has several merger criteria, tidal disruption events and stellar and compact object collisions. We show that for systems with $N$ particles the scaling of the code remains good. We also validate the numerical accuracy of BifROST.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07540v2.title: JWST catches the assembly of a $z\sim5$ ultra-low-mass galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07540v2.summary: Using CANUCS imaging we found an apparent major merger of two $z\sim5$ultra-low-mass galaxies. Both galaxies are experiencing young, synchronised bursts of starformation. At least half of the ionizing photons produced by the system will have been produced during the merger. If such high-$z$ mergers are common, then merger-triggered starbursts could be significant contributors to the ionizer budget of the Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01720v1.title: Outlier galaxy images in the Dark Energy Survey and their identification with unsupervised machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01720v1.summary: The Dark Energy Survey is able to collect image data of an extremely large number of extragalactic objects. It can be reasonably assumed that many unusual objects of high scientific interest are hidden inside these data. Due to the extreme size of DES data, identifying these objects among many millions of other celestial objects is a challenging task. This study applies an automatic method for outlier detection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01719v1.title: Probing a galaxy assembly history for the counter-rotating disk galaxy PGC 66551
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01719v1.summary: Stellar counter-rotation in disk galaxies directly relates to the complexphenomenon of the disk mass assembly. The detailed study of such systems makes it possible to reveal the source of external accretion and establish the details of this process. We found that the main 8 Gyr old disk has a significantly lower metallicity-0.8 dex than othercounter-rotating galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01694v1.title: AT 2021loi: A Bowen Fluorescence Flare with a Rebrightening Episode, Occurring in a Previously-Known AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01694v1.summary: AT 2021loi is an optical-ultraviolet transient located at the center of its                host galaxy. Its light curve is similar to those of                previous BFFs, showing a rebrightening approximately one year after the main peak. An emission feature around 4680 A, seen in the pre-flare horizon, strengthens by a factor of $2 around the optical peak of the flare.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01693v1.title: A new sample of transient ultraluminous X-ray sources serendipitously discovered by Swift/XRT
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01693v1.summary: Ultraluminous X-ray sources (ULXs) are our best laboratories for studyingextreme super-Eddington accretion. Most studies of these objects are of relatively persistent sources. There is growing evidence to suggest alarge fraction of these sources are transient.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14235v2.title: The Stellar Chemical Abundances of Simulated Massive Galaxies at $z = 2$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14235v2.summary: We analyze the stellar abundances of massive galaxies at $z=2$ in the IllustrisTNG simulation with the goal ofguiding the interpretation of current and future observations, particularly from the James Webb Space Telescope. We find that the effective size, $R_e$, of                galaxies strongly affects the abundance measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01681v1.title: The dust enrichment and detectability of early galaxies in the JWST and ALMA era
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01681v1.summary: Recent observations with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) are yieldingipienttantalizing hints of an early population of massive, bright galaxies. Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) observations indicate significant dust masses in place as early as $z\sim 7$. We use the DELPHI semi-analytic model that tracks the assembly of dark matter halos and their constituent baryons.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01677v1.title: The dynamics of debris streams from tidal disruption events: exact solutions, critical stream density, and hydrogen recombination
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01677v1.summary: A star destroyed by a supermassive black hole (SMBH) in a tidal disruption event (TDE) is transformed into a filamentary structure known as a tidallydisrupted stellar debris stream. We show that when ideal gas pressure dominatesthe thermodynamics of the stream, there is an exact solution to theHydrodynamics equations. We analyze the stability of this solution to cylindrically symmetric perturbations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06779v2.title: KMT-2022-BLG-0440Lb: A New $q < 10^{-4}$ Microlensing Planet with the Central-Resonant Caustic Degeneracy Broken
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06779v2.summary: We present the observations and analysis of a high-magnification microlensing planetary event, KMT-2022-BLG-0440. The binary-lens models with a central caustic provide the bestfits, with a planet/host mass ratio, $q = 0.75$--$1.00 \times 10^{-4}$ at $1\sigma$. Thebinary-source model can fit the anomaly well but is rejected by the ``color argument'' on the second source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01589v1.title: Generalizations of Quasilinear MOND (QUMOND)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01589v1.summary: I present a class of theories that generalize quasilinear MOND. These GQUMOND theories require solving only the linear Poisson equation. Unlike QUMOND, their Lagrangian depends on higher derivatives of the Newtonian potential. These theories might open new avenues to more fundamental theories, and have much heuristicvalue.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2106.04980v3.title: A machine learning approach to mapping baryons onto dark matter haloes using the EAGLE and C-EAGLE simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2106.04980v3.summary: High-resolution cosmological hydrodynamic simulations are currently limited to relatively small volumes. We propose a newapproach, using a machine learning framework to explore the halo-galaxy relationship in the periodic EAGLE simulations. We train a tree based machine learning method to predict thebaryonic properties of galaxies based on their host dark matter haloproperties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01562v1.title: Ly$α$ at Cosmic Dawn with a Simulated Roman Grism Deep Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01562v1.summary: The slitless grism on the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will enable deep near-infrared spectroscopy over a wide field of view. We demonstrate Roman's ability to detect Ly$\alpha$ galaxies at $z>7$ using a multi-position-angle(PA) observational strategy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2101.10370v2.title: Hunting for Dark Matter and New Physics with GECCO
http://arxiv.org/abs/2101.10370v2.summary: We outline the science opportunities in the areas of searches for dark matter and new physics offered by a proposed future MeV gamma-ray telescope. Such an instrument would play a critical role in opening up a discovery window for particle dark matter with mass in the MeV or sub-MeV range.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01533v1.title: Analytical and Numerical Analysis of Circumbinary Disk Dynamics -- I: Coplanar Systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01533v1.summary: We present an analytical and numerical study of a system composed of astellar binary pair and a massless, locally isothermal viscous accretion disk that is coplanar to the binary orbital plane. Analytically, we study the effectof the binary's gravitational potential over short timescales through the study of stability for epicyclic orbits. Numerally, we perform two-dimensional Newtonian Newtonian simulations of the disk-binary system over a range of binary mass. We find that the results of our simulations are consistent with previous numerical studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01436v1.title: Massive pre-main-sequence stars in M17: $1^{\rm st}$ and $2^{\rm nd}$ overtone CO bandhead emission and the thermal infrared
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01436v1.summary: The latest stages of massive starformation have rarely been observed. We use an analytic LTE disk model to fit the CO bandhead and dust emission, found to originate in different disk regions. We conclude that, considering their mass range and for the fact that their photospheres are detected, the M17 PMS stars are observed in a relatively early formation stage.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01389v1.title: Atomic hydrogen scaling relations at $z \approx 0.35$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01389v1.summary: The atomic hydrogen (HI) properties of star-forming galaxies in the local                Universe are known to correlate with other galaxy properties. The redshift evolution of these relations serves as animportant constraint on models of galaxy evolution. Until recently, until recently, there were no estimates of the HI scaling relations at cosmological distances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01335v1.title: An Enigmatic 380 kpc Long Linear Collimated Galactic Tail
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01335v1.summary: The Kite galaxy has a highly-collimated tail of gas and stars that extends over 380 kpc and contains pockets of star formation. The Kite (PGC 1000273) has a companion galaxy and together comprise a binary galaxy system. We propose that the tail resulted from a three-body interaction from which the lowest-mass galaxy was ejected at high velocity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.14539v2.title: Low-Surface-Brightness Galaxies are missing in the observed Stellar Mass Function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.14539v2.summary: We investigate the impact of the surface brightness (SB) limit on the galaxystellar mass functions (GSMFs) using mock surveys generated from the HorizonRun 5 (HR5) simulation. We find that the GSMFs are significantly affected by the SB limits at a low-mass end. We also find that a redshift survey with a SB selection limit of $z=0.625$ will miss 20% of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12530v2.title: Inhomogeneous Galactic Chemical Evolution: Modelling Ultra-Faint Dwarf Galaxies of the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12530v2.summary: We present a novel                inhomogeneous chemical evolution model. It is based on the Monte Carlo sampling of the initial mass function as star formation proceeds in different gas cells of the galaxy. We account for the chemical enrichment of Supernova bubbles as they spread in the interstellar medium, causing dispersion in elemental abundance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01307v1.title: Constraints on the cosmological coupling of black holes from Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01307v1.summary: Recent work has suggested that black holes (BHs) could be cosmologicallycoupled to the accelerated expansion of the universe. This would imply BH mass growth following thecosmological expansion, with the masses of individual BHs growing as $M_{\rm grotesqueBH}\propto (1+z)^3$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01266v1.title: Impact of tidal environment on galaxy populations using GAMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01266v1.summary: We present constraints on models of the galaxy distribution in the cosmic web. We show that the growth rate deduced using models with assembly bias is about 7% lower than if assembly bias was ignored. We also study the effect of assembly bias on the weak lensing signal. We find that the model constraints without assembly bias overlap with Planck expectations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01256v1.title: Impact of astrophysical effects on the dark matter mass constraint with 21cm intensity mapping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01256v1.summary: We present an innovative approach to constraining the non-cold dark matter model using a convolutional neural network (CNN) We perform a suite ofHydrodynamic simulations with varying dark matter particle masses and generate 21cm radio intensity maps to trace the dark matter distribution. We find that the CNN outperforms the traditional power spectrum analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01212v1.title: Structural Analysis of Open Cluster Bochum 2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01212v1.summary: We present the results from our deep optical photometric observations of the Boc2 star cluster. Using $Gaia$ parallax of member stars and isochrone fitting method, the distance of this cluster is estimated as $3.8\pm0.4$ kpc. We have found that this cluster holds young ($\sim5$ Myr) andmassive (O$7-$O$9$) stars as well as an older population of low mass stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01175v1.title: Strategy for Dynamic Wisp Removal in James Webb Space Telescope NIRCam Images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01175v1.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) near-infrared camera (NIRCam) has been found to exhibit serious wisp-like structures in four of its eight short-wavelength detectors. The exact structure and strength of these wisps ishighly variable with the position and orientation of JWST, so the use of static templates is non-optimal.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01112v1.title: Updated Inventory of Carbon Monoxide in The Taurus Molecular Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01112v1.summary: The most extensive survey of carbon monoxide (CO) gas in the Taurus molecular cloud relied on $^{12}$CO and $^{13)$CO emission only. We have taken advantage of recent JCMT observations to estimate density, temperature, and $N$(CO) with a LVG model. Compared to Pineda et al. (2010) results, we find a higher volume density of molecular hydrogen.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01075v1.title: The AGN fuelling/feedback cycle in nearby radio galaxies - V. The cold atomic gas of NGC 3100 and its group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01075v1.summary: Australia Compact Telescope Array (ATCA) 21-cm observations of the near-by low-excitation radio galaxy (LERG) NGC 3100. The ATCAobservations reveal for the first time the presence of neutral hydrogen (HI) in absorption in the centre of this radio galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01042v1.title: Counter-rotating black holes from FRII lifetimes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01042v1.summary: Estimates suggest that while FRII jets appear to have lifetimes constrained.to hundreds of millions of years, radio galaxies with FRI jets. appear to be longer lived. We calculate a range of timescales for counter-rotating black holes for accretion rates compatible with theory which we then compare to data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01014v1.title: The Sloan Digital Sky Survey Reverberation Mapping Project: Key Results
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01014v1.summary: The data set includes 11-year photometric and 7-year spectroscopic light curves for 849 broad-line quasars. Using 30 low-redshift RM AGNs with dynamical-modeling black hole masses, we derive a new estimate of the average virial factor of the line dispersion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01007v1.title: Lights in the Dark: Globular clusters as dark matter tracers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01007v1.summary: A long-standing observed curiosity of globular clusters (GCs) has been that the number and total mass of GCs in a galaxy are linearly correlated with the galaxy's virial mass. This work expands on an empirical model for the numbers and ages ofGCs in galaxies presented by Valenzuela et al.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01005v1.title: Self-similar growth of Bose stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01005v1.summary: The bath is described by a self-similar solution of the kineticequation, which is an attractor. Together with the conservation laws, thisfixes mass evolution of the Bose star. Our results explain slowdown of the stargrowth at a certain "core-halo" mass, but also predict formation of the heavier and lighter objects in magistral dark matter models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00999v1.title: Primordial power spectrum in light of JWST observations of high redshift galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00999v1.summary: JWST has opened up a new observational probe of our Universe. The early data have revealed several high redshift massive galaxy candidates. Some of them have been confirmed spectroscopically. We usethese observations to study their implications on the primordial powerSpectrum. We find that a very high starforming efficiency is required to explain these observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00998v1.title: New quasar proximity zone size measurements at $z\sim 6$ using the enlarged XQR-30 sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00998v1.summary: Proximity zones of high-redshift quasars are unique probes of their central tumultuoussupermassive black holes as well as the intergalactic medium in the last stages of reionization. We find that the correlation between proximity zone sizes and the quasar redshift, luminosity, or black hole mass indicates a large                diversity of quasar lifetimes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00991v1.title: An XMM-Newton Study of Six Narrow-Line Seyfert 1 Galaxies at z = 0.35--0.92
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00991v1.summary: We report a detailed analysis of the XMM-Newton spectra of six galaxies at redshift z = 0.35--0.92. Compared with the NLS1s at lower redshift in the previously most-studied sample, they have larger black hole masses. We tentatively fit the spectra assuming two more physical models for the soft excess.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00993v1.title: Haunted haloes: tracking the ghosts of subhaloes lost by halo finders
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00993v1.summary: Dark matter subhaloes are key for the predictions of simulations of structure. Their existence frequently ends prematurely due to numerical disruption in N-body simulations and halo finders failing to identify them. As a solution, we present a flexible post-processing algorithm that tracks all subhalo particles over time, and progressively removes stripped matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00951v1.title: Formation of Gaps in Self-gravitating Debris Disks by Secular Resonance in a Single-planet System. II. Towards a Self-consistent Model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00951v1.summary: High-resolution observations of several debris disks reveal structures such as gaps and spirals, suggestive of gravitational perturbations induced by beneath planets. Most existing studies of planet--debris disk interactions ignore the gravity of the disk, treating it as a reservoir of massless planetesimals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00858v1.title: Local Group Galaxies from an External Perspective
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00858v1.summary: Local Group galaxies are in excellent agreement with the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation. Local Group galaxies thus appear to be normal members of the low redshift galaxy population. There is a serious tension between the masses of the Milky Way and M31 and those expected from thestellar mass-halo mass relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11061v2.title: The multiplicity fraction in 202 open clusters from Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11061v2.summary: Fraction of binaries with high mass ratios for open clusters in the extended solar neighbourhood. This is one of the largest homogeneous catalogues of multiplicityfractions in open clusters to date. Total high-mass-ratio multiplicity fractions between 6% and 80%, with a median of 18%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09722v2.title: Magnetic field draping around clumpy high-velocity clouds in galactic halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09722v2.summary: High-velocity clouds (HVCs)sweep up ambient magnetic fields and form stretched and draped configurations around them. We find that the clouds' density structure regulates mixing and mass growth. Efficient cooling keeps the main cloud body more compact and produces decelerated dense clumps condensed from the halo gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10065v2.title: The MillenniumTNG Project: The large-scale clustering of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10065v2.summary: A new, large volume hydrodynamical simulation has been created as part of the MillenniumTNG (MTNG) project. It is able to accurately reproduce the observed clustering of galaxies as a function of stellar mass. When separated by colour, there are some discrepancies with respect to the observed population, which can be attributed to the quenching of satellite galaxies in our model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00756v1.title: Joint Modelling of Dust Scattering and Thermal Emission: The Spider Complex
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00756v1.summary: We quantify the relationship between scattered light and thermal emission from dust in a diffuse (cirrus) cloud. We show how to use any dust model that matches the thermal dust emission to predict an upper limit to the amount of scattered light. The actualbrightness of the cirrus will be fainter than this limit because of anisotropicscattering by the dust combined with anisotropy of the incident interstellarradiation field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00736v1.title: The Effelsberg survey of FU~Orionis and EX~Lupi objects II. -- H$_2$O maser observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00736v1.summary: Water masers are widespread in star forming regions and are powerful probes of mass accretion and ejection. Little is known about the prevalence of them toward FU Orionis (FUor) and EX Lupi (EXor) type objects. We detect 5 water masers; 3 are associated with eruptive stars, resulting in a 6% detection rate for eruptive sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.07240v3.title: Dark matter properties and axion dark radiation from rotation curves and energy cascade
http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.07240v3.summary: We present a cascade theory to predict dark matter (DM) particle mass, size, lifetime, and properties of possible dark radiation from DM decay. For collisionless dark matter with only gravity involved, scaling laws can be extended down to the smallestscale, where quantum effects become important. Potential extension to self-interacting dark matter is also present.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00602v1.title: Feedback-driven anisotropy in the circumgalactic medium for quenching galaxies in the SIMBA simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00602v1.summary: We use the SIMBA galaxy formation simulation suite to explore anisotropies in circumgalactic gas that result from accretion and feedback processes. We particularly focus on the impact of bipolar active galacticnuclei (AGN) jet feedback as implemented in SIMBA. jets cause lower densities and higher temperatures along the galaxy minor axis (SIMBA jet direction)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.06195v3.title: The ALMA Frontier Fields Survey. VI. Lensing-corrected 1.1mm number counts in Abell 2744, MACSJ0416.1-2403, MACSJ1149.5+2223, Abell 370 and Abell S1063
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.06195v3.summary: Probing the faint end of the number counts at mm wavelengths is important to identify the origin of the extragalactic background light in this regime. ALMA observations towardsmassive galaxy clusters have opened a window to disentangle this origin, allowing to resolve sub-mJy dusty star-forming galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00486v1.title: M giants with IGRINS I. Stellar parameters and $α$-abundance trends of the solar neighborhood population
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00486v1.summary: Cool stars, such as M giants, can only be analysed in the near-infrared (NIR) regime due to the ubiquitous TiO features in optical spectra. In dust obscured regions, like the inner bulge and Galactic Center, intrinsically bright M giants observed in the NIR is an optimal option to determine stellar abundances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06658v2.title: Pure Spectroscopic Constraints on UV Luminosity Functions and Cosmic Star Formation History From 25 Galaxies at $z_\mathrm{spec}=8.61-13.20$ Confirmed with JWST/NIRSpec
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06658v2.summary: We present pure spectroscopic constraints on the UV luminosity functions andCosmic star formation rate (SFR) densities from 25 galaxies. We confirm 16 galaxies at $z_\mathrm{spec}=8.61-11.40$ including new redshift determinations. We suggest observational strategies for removing low redshift interlopers for future JWST programs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00480v1.title: Detection of monothioformic acid towards the solar-type protostar IRAS 16293-2422
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00480v1.summary: In the interstellar medium (ISM), the complex organic molecules that contain the thiol group ($-$SH) play an important role in the polymerization of aminoacids. We look for SH-bearing molecules in the chemically rich solar-typeprotostar IRAS 16293-2422. We did not observe any evidence of cis-isomer monothioformic acid (c-HC(O)SH) towards the IRas 16293 B.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04821v2.title: Waking the monster: the onset of AGN feedback in galaxy clusters hosting young central radio galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04821v2.summary: The investigation of the feedback cycle in galaxy clusters has historically been performed for systems where feedback is ongoing. In this pilot study we present results from "pre-feedback" clusters, where the central newly active radio galaxies may not yet have had time to alter the ICM. We analyze $Chandra$ and MUSE observations of two such systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00305v1.title: The IACOB project IX. Building a modern empirical database of Galactic O9-B9 supergiants: sample selection, description, and completeness
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00305v1.summary: Blue supergiants (BSGs) are important objects to study the intermediatephase of massive star evolution. The lack of a holistic study of a statistically significant and unbiased sample of these objects makes several long-standing questions about their nature to remain unsolved. We compile an initial set of 11,000 high-resolution spectra of 1600 Galactic late O- and B-type stars. We use a newnovel spectroscopic strategy based on a simple fitting of the Hbeta line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00240v1.title: A direct connection between the wake and the former host galaxy of a proposed runaway supermassive black hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00240v1.summary: This Research Note presents VLT B-band imaging of a candidate runaway                supermassive black hole. The black hole was recently discovered in HST/ACS F606W+F814Wimaging. The ACS data show an extremely thin, linear feature at z=0.964 that points toward a compact galaxy at the same redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13237v2.title: Tree-based solvers for adaptive mesh refinement code FLASH -- IV: An X-ray radiation scheme to couple discrete and diffuse X-ray emission sources to the thermochemistry of the interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13237v2.summary: X-ray radiation is absorbed by nearby gas, providing a source of both heating and ionization. While protoplanetary chemistry models often include X-ray emission from the central young stellar object, simulations of star-forming regions have yet to include it. We present an extension of the TreeRay reverse raytrace algorithm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.04406v2.title: On the origins of extreme velocity stars as revealed by large-scale Galactic surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.04406v2.summary: We assemble a large sample of 12,784 high-velocity stars with total velocity. In this sample, 52 are marginally hypervelocity star (HVS) candidates that have exceeded their local escape velocities within $2\sigma$ confidence levels. 40 of these candidates are discovered for the first time. All are metal-poor, late-type halo stars, significantly different from previous identified HVSs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00024v1.title: Molecular gas content and high excitation of a massive main-sequence galaxy at z = 3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00024v1.summary: We present new CO ($J=5-4$ and $7-6$) and [CI] emission line observations of the star-forming galaxy D49. D49 is at the massive end of the Main Sequence at $z=3$. We incorporate previous CO($J=3-2) and optical-to-millimetre continuum observations to fit its spectral energy distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00023v1.title: Machine Learning Uncovers the Universe's Hidden Gems: A Comprehensive Catalogue of CIV Absorption Lines in SDSS DR12
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00023v1.summary: We assemble the largest CIV absorption line catalogue to date. The catalogue contains probabilities classifying the reliability of the absorption system within aquasar spectrum. Our catalogue can be used to investigate the physicalproperties of the circumgalactic and intergalactic media. We detect CIV absorbing systems with a redshiftrange of 1.37-5.1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00022v1.title: Dynamical friction and feedback on galactic bars in the general fast-slow regime
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00022v1.summary: Current theories of friction on galactic bars are based on either adiabatic theory or linear perturbation theory. In the slow regime where trapping occurs, we show that, in addition to the frictional torque, angular momentum is transferred directly due to the migration of the trapped orbits.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00019v1.title: Recent Progress in Modelling the Macro- and Micro-Physics of Radio Jet Feedback in Galaxy Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00019v1.summary: Radio jets and the lobes they inflate are common in cool-core clusters. They are expected to play a critical role in regulating the heating and cooling of intracluster medium (ICM) This is an inherently multi-scale problem, and much effort has been made to understand the processes governing the inflation of lobes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.15002v1.title: Gas distribution in ODISEA sources from ALMA long-baseline observations in $^{12}$CO(2-1)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.15002v1.summary: ALMA observations of ten protoplanetary discs from the Ophiuchus DIsc Survey Employing ALMA(ODISEA) project. The position angle of the gaseous disc can be inferred for five of the discs using high-velocity channels. Eight discs show evidence of gas inside inner dust cavities or gaps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.07382v3.title: Magnetic Misalignment of Interstellar Dust Filaments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.07382v3.summary: We present evidence for scale-independent misalignment of interstellar dust and magnetic fields. We compare dust-polarization measurements from Planck with filamentarystructures identified in neutral-hydrogen (HI) measurements from HI4PI. We find a scale independence (harmonic coherence) for features larger than the HI4 PI beam width ($16.2'$)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00025v3.title: A variable active galactic nucleus at $z=2.06$ triply-imaged by the galaxy cluster MACS J0035.4-2015
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00025v3.summary: The object is detected in Hubble Space Telescope imaging taken for the RELICSprogram. It appears to have a quasi-stellar nucleus consistent with a point-source. The object adds to just a few quasars or other X-ray sources known to be multiply lensed by a galaxy cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02075v2.title: The SZ flux-mass ($Y$-$M$) relation at low halo masses: improvements with symbolic regression and strong constraints on baryonic feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02075v2.summary: Feedback from active galactic nuclei (AGN) and supernovae can affect measurements of integrated SZ flux of halos. We find that simply replacing $Y(1+M_*/M_\mathrm{gas})$ in the $Y-M$ relation makes it remarkably self-similar. This could serve as a robustmultiwavelength mass proxy for low-mass clusters and galaxy groups.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12355v2.title: Sparse logistic regression for RR Lyrae vs binaries classification
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12355v2.summary: RR Lyrae (RRL) are old, low-mass radially pulsating variable stars in theircore helium burning phase. Their photometric identification is notrivial, indeed, RRL samples can be contaminated by eclipsing binaries. In this paper, we train a simple logistic regression classifier onCatalina Sky Survey (CSS) light curves. It achieves a precision of 87% at 78% retrieve for the RRL class on unseen CSS light curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14847v1.title: The "canonical" White Dwarf Cooling Sequence of M5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14847v1.summary: A new class of white dwarfs (dubbed ''slowly cooling WDs'') has been identified in two globular clusters. They are thought to be originated by stars that populate the blue tail of the HB and then skip the asymptotic giant branch phase. No evidence of such kind of WDs has been found in M3, a similar cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10665v2.title: Magnetic field measurement from the Davis-Chandrasekhar-Fermi method employed with Atomic Alignment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10665v2.summary: The Davis-Chandrasekhar-Fermi (DCF) method is widely employed to estimate themean magnetic field strength in astrophysical plasmas. We obtain syntheticspectro-polarimetry observations from 3D magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence simulations and estimate the mean magnetic field projected onto the plane of the sky using the DCF method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14829v1.title: Matching LOFAR sources across radio bands
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14829v1.summary: The first wide-area, ultra-low frequency observations from LOFAR were published. We present a new cross-matching algorithm taking into account the sizes of the radio sources. We find an average spectral index of -0.77 \pm 0.18$ between LoLSS and NVSS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13809v2.title: The Influence of Subhaloes on Host Halo Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13809v2.summary: Dark matter haloes are comprised of both a smooth component and a population of smaller, gravitationally bound subhaloes. These components are often treated as a single halo when halo properties, such as density profiles, are extracted from simulations. Recent work has shown thatdensity profiles change substantially when subhalo mass is excluded.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14759v1.title: A runaway T-Tauri star leaving an extended trail
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14759v1.summary: A peculiar anonymous star was found that resembles a wake-like feature. In this peculiar star, nicknamed UJT-1, the interaction of the stellar wind with the surrounding surrounding becomes extreme. Under reasonable assumptions, this unusual degree of interaction has the potential to encode the mass-loss history of the star on timescales of several $10^5$ years.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14747v1.title: The Age-Metallicity Relation in the Solar Neighbourhood
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14747v1.summary: Age-metallicity relation for the Galactic disc is a crucial tool and to constraints the Galactic chemical evolution models. We use kinematic age derived from highly precise astrometric data of Gaia Data Release 2 and element abundance ratios from high-resolution APOGEE-2 catalogues. We apply a two- component Gaussian-mixture model to chemically separate the programme stars into thin and thick populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14743v1.title: Rotation and activity in late-type members of the young cluster ASCC 123
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14743v1.summary: ASCC 123 is a little-studied young and dispersed open cluster. By studying the TESS light curves of the cluster members we determine the rotation period and the amplitude of the rotational modulation for 29 objects. For seven stars we study the level of magnetic activity from the H$\alpha$ and CaIIH&K lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14740v1.title: A Keplerian disk with a four-arm spiral birthing an episodically accreting high-mass protostar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14740v1.summary: High-mass protostars gain themajority of their mass via short, intense bursts of growth. This episodicaccretion is thought to be facilitated by gravitationally unstable and subsequently inhomogeneous accretion disks. We report the discovery of a Keplerian accretion disk with a spatially resolved four-arm spiral pattern around G358.93-0.03-MM1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14739v1.title: A heat-wave of accretion energy traced by masers in the G358-MM1 high-mass protostar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14739v1.summary: High-mass stars are thought to accumulate much of their mass via short,infrequent bursts of disk-aided accretion. Such accretion events are rare and difficult to observe directly but are known to drive enhanced maser emission. The observed scenario can readily be attributed to an accretion event in the high-mass proto-star G358.93-0.03-MM1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14692v1.title: MeerKAT view of the Dancing Ghosts -- Peculiar Galaxy Pair PKS 2130-538 in Abell 3785
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14692v1.summary: We present MeerKAT L-band observations of the extended radio structure of the peculiar galaxy pair PKS 2130-538 known as the "DancingGhosts" The complex of bending and possibly interacting jets and lobesoriginate from two Active Galactic Nuclei hosts in the Abell 3785 galaxy cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.13915v2.title: Sensitivity of non-radiative cloud-wind interactions to the hydrodynamics solver
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.13915v2.summary: Cloud-wind interactions are common in the interstellar and circumgalactic media. Many studies have used simulations of such interactions to investigate the effect of particular physical processes. But the impact of the choice of a hydrodynamics solver has largely been overlooked, say the authors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06529v3.title: Cosmological application of the lens-redshift probability distribution with improved galaxy-scale gravitational lensing sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06529v3.summary: We conduct the cosmological analysis by using the lens-redshift distribution test with updated galaxy-scale strong lensing sample. It shows that degeneracies between cosmologically and VDF parameters lead to the shifts of estimates on theparameters. The limits on the dark energy equation of state are consistent with those from the Pantheon+ sample at 68.3% confidence level.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13964v2.title: FAST discovery of long tidal tails in NGC 4490/85
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13964v2.summary: The tidal tails extended in both the south and north directions, and are much longer than that reported previously based on the VLAinterferometric maps. The NGC 4490/85 is surrounded by a large gas envelope, and a starburst low metallicity dwarf galaxy MAPS 1231+42 is found to be connected with the gas envelope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14566v1.title: Interacting galaxies in the IllustrisTNG simulations -- V: Comparing the influence of star-forming vs. passive companions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14566v1.summary: We study interacting galaxy pairs in the TNG100-1 and TNG300-1 cosmological simulations. We split our sample based on whether the neighboring galaxy is star-forming or passive. We find that galaxies with close.star-forming companions have sSFRs that are enhanced (on average) by a factor.of $2.9 \pm 0.3$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.05495v4.title: Flows around galaxies. I. The dependency of galaxy connectivity on cosmic environments and effects on the star-formation rate
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.05495v4.summary: The study is the first comprehensive characterisation of galaxy connectivity. More than half of galaxies are connected to two or three small-scale streams. The star-formation rate of low mass galaxies is enhanced due to this connectivity. The impact of connectivity is even more significant for galaxies embedded in cosmic filaments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02675v2.title: Testing AGN outflow and accretion models with CIV and HeII emission line demographics in z=2 quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02675v2.summary: Using 190,000 spectra from the seventeenth data release of the Sloan DigitalSky Survey, we investigate the ultraviolet emission line properties in z=2quasars. We quantify how the shape of CIV 1549A and theequivalent width (EW) of HeII 1640A depend on the black hole mass and Eddingtonratio inferred from MgII 2800A.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14477v1.title: New Bistable Solutions in Molecular Cloud Chemistry: Nitrogen and Carbon Autocatalysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14477v1.summary: We have investigated the chemistry of dense interstellar clouds and found new bistable solutions in the nitrogen and carbon chemistries. Bistability in the pure nitrogen chemistry occurs for conditions relevant for prestellar cores in which significant COdepletion has taken place. We conclude that several autocatalyses are embedded in gas-phase interstellar chemistry and that many more are potentially present.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14472v1.title: Stirred, not shaken: Star cluster survival in the slingshot scenario
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14472v1.summary: We investigate the effects of an oscillating gas filament on the dynamics of embedded stellar clusters. We model the host gas filament as a cylindrically symmetrical potential, and the star cluster as a Plummer sphere. In the model, the motion of the filament will produce star ejections from the cluster, leaving star cluster remnants.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14469v1.title: The galaxy UV luminosity function at $\mathbf{z \simeq 11}$ from a suite of public JWST ERS, ERO and Cycle-1 programs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14469v1.summary: We present a new determination of the evolving galaxy UV luminosity function (LF) over the redshift range $9.5<z<12.5$ based on a wide-area data set of JWST NIRCam near-infrared imaging. At these early times we find that the galaxy UV LF is best described by a double power-law function, consistent with results obtained from recent ground-based studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14431v1.title: Constrain the Dark Matter Distribution of Ultra-diffuse Galaxies with Globular-Cluster Mass Segregation: A Case Study with NGC5846-UDG1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14431v1.summary: The properties of globular clusters (GCs) contain valuable information of their host galaxies and dark-matter halos. In the remarkable example of NGC5846-UDG1, the GC population exhibits strong radialmass segregation, indicative of dynamical-friction-driven orbital decay. We develop a model of GC evolution that starts from the initial mass function, the initial structure-mass relation, and the initial spatial distribution of the GC progenitors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14429v1.title: The luminosity function of TDEs from fallback-powered emission: implications for the black hole mass function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14429v1.summary: Tidal disruption events (TDEs), in which a star is destroyed by the gravitational field of a supermassive black hole, are being observed at a high rate. One of the properties of TDEs that is measured with increasing statistical reliability is the TDE luminosity function. If the luminous emission from a TDE is directly coupled to the rate of return of tidally destroyed debris to the SMBH, then it is likely powered by another mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14387v1.title: Hierarchical structure of the cosmic web and galaxy properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14387v1.summary: Voids possess a very complex internal structure and dynamics. Voids possess an intricate internal network of sub-structures. This in turn makes them a complex environment for galaxyformation. The spin is lower for galaxies in the densest environments for the mass range of $10 10 -10 12 M \odot /h.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14368v1.title: Kinematics of stellar substructures in the Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14368v1.summary: We present a kinematic analysis of the Small Magellanic Cloud. We used data from Gaia and near-infrared photometry to select stellar populations. We obtain a mean radial velocity for the galaxy of 159+/-2 km/s, with a velocity dispersion of 33+.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14428v1.title: Oscillations in Gas-grain Astrochemical Kinetics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14428v1.summary: We have studied gas-grain chemical models of interstellar clouds to search for nonlinear dynamical evolution. A prescription is given for producingoscillatory solutions when a bistable solution exists in the gas-phase. As the autocatalytic chemical processes underlying these solutions are common to all models, the occurrence of these solutions should be widespread.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.07101v4.title: Precision modeling of JWST's first cluster lens SMACSJ0723.3-7327
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.07101v4.summary: A lens model for the massive galaxy cluster SMACSJ0723.3-7323 has been created. The lens model maps the cluster mass distribution to an RMS spatial precision of 0.32'' and is publicly available. A comparison of the galaxy,mass, and gas distributions in the core of SMacSJ723 based on HST, JWST, and Chandra data reveals a concentrated regular elliptical profile along with tell-tale signs of a recent merger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.01260v4.title: The Diffuse Gamma-Ray Flux from Clusters of Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.01260v4.summary: The origin of the diffuse gamma-ray background (DGRB) is unknown. The DGRB possibly encompasses contributions from different source populations such as star-forming galaxies, starburst galaxies, active galacticuclei, or galaxy clusters. Here, we combine cosmological simulations of clusters of galaxies with the propagation of cosmic rays using Monte Carlo simulations. We show that the flux is dominated by clusters with redshift of 0.3.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14270v1.title: Analysis of the young open cluster Trumpler 2 using Gaia DR3 data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14270v1.summary: We present an investigation of the open cluster Trumpler 2 using Gaia DR3 data. 92 stars were identified as likely members of the cluster with membership probabilities greater than 0.5. Galactic orbit analyses show that the cluster orbits in a boxy pattern outside the solar circle and belongs to the young thin-disc component of the Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06329v2.title: Fermionic Dark Matter: Physics, Astrophysics, and Cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06329v2.summary: The nature of dark matter (DM) is one of the most relevant questions in modern astrophysics. We present a brief overview of recent results that look into a possible fermionic quantum nature of the DM particles. We also connect the RAR model fermions with particle physics, self-interactions, and galactic observables constraints.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14249v1.title: Stellar variability in Gaia DR3. I. Three-band photometric dispersions for 145 million sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14249v1.summary: The unparalleled characteristics of Gaia photometry make it an excellent choice to study stellar variability. Most WDs and sdBs are variable and follow a distribution in s_G peaking around 12 mmag but variability decreases for the former with age. The MS region in the Gaia CAMD has an s-G distribution peaks at low values (~1-2 mmag)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14228v1.title: Optical variability in Quasars: Scaling with black hole mass and Eddington ratio depend on the observed timescales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14228v1.summary: Quasars emission is highly variable, and this variability gives us clues to understand the accretion process onto supermassive black holes. We can expectvariability properties to correlate with the main physical properties of the black hole, i.e., its mass and accretion rate. The behavior can be explained in terms of a universal variability power spectrum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14157v1.title: Bursts from Space: MeerKAT - The first citizen science project dedicated to commensal radio transients
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14157v1.summary: The MeerKAT telescope was launched late in 2021 and received 89,000 classifications from over 1000 volunteers in 3 months. Volunteers discovered 142 new variable sources, including a pulsar and an OH maser star. At least 2.1 per cent of radio sources are varying at 1.28 GHz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06843v1.title: Merger Conditions of Population III Protostar Binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06843v1.summary: Massive close binary stars with extremely small separations have been observed. They are possible progenitors of gravitational-wave sources. We investigate how close theprotostars, consisting of a high-density core and a vast low-density envelope, can approach each other but not coalesce.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06803v1.title: Halo mass-observable proxy scaling relations and their dependencies on galaxy and group properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06803v1.summary: Based on the DECaLS shear catalog, we study the scaling relations between halo mass and various proxies for SDSS central galaxies. We find that the dependence on star formation rate(SFR) israther weak in the $M_{\rm h}$-$\sigma_*$ and $M  $M_*$, but very prominent in the other two. We also find that correlations among the proxies change with $M *$, indicating that different processes drive galaxies and SMBH at different stages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06762v1.title: QUIJOTE scientific results -- X. Spatial variations of Anomalous Microwave Emission along the Galactic plane
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06762v1.summary: Anomalous Microwave Emission (AME) is an important emission component between 10 and 60 GHz that is not yet fully understood. We use the new QUIJOTE-MFI wide survey data at 11, 13, 17 and 19 GHz to constrain the AME on degree scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06759v1.title: Detection of multiple phase space overdensities of GSE stars by orbit integration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06759v1.summary: The merger event ofGaia-Sausage-Enceladus has provided a unique opportunity to study the shells in the phase space. In N-body simulations, nearly radial mergers can form shell-likeoverdensities. These chevrons reveal the multiple pile-ups of GSE stars at different apocenters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05709v2.title: NGC 1436: the making of a lenticular galaxy in the Fornax cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05709v2.summary: We study the evolutionary path of the Fornax cluster galaxy NGC$~$1436. This galaxy hosts an inner star-forming disc and an outer quiescentdisc. The cold gas disc is now well settled, which suggests that the galaxy has not been affected by any environmental interactions in the last $\sim1~$Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06713v1.title: Exploring connections between the VLBI and optical morphology of AGNs and their host galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06713v1.summary: We analyse VLBI and optical images of AGNs and their host galaxies. We look for statistical correlations between the shape and orientation of the galaxy and the direction of the jet. We check our own shape parameters from this fit against the ones provided by the optical surveys. No clear correlation between the morphology and the jet direction is seen.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03443v2.title: Gas, dust, and the CO-to-molecular gas conversion factor in low-metallicity starbursts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03443v2.summary: The factor relating CO emission to molecular hydrogen column density, XCO, is still subject to uncertainty, in particular at low metallicity. We exploit a dust-based method together with ALMA 12-m and ACA data and HI maps of three nearby metal-poor starbursts. At 250 pc resolution, X CO is 5-1000 times the Milky Way value.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06529v1.title: Testing the linear relationship between black hole mass and variability timescale in low-luminosity AGN at submillimeter wavelengths
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06529v1.summary: The variability of submillimeter emission provides a useful tool to probe the accretion physics in low-luminosity active galactic nuclei. We show a correlation between the the timescale and the black hole mass over three orders of magnitude. Sources that follow this relationship may be good targets for high-resolution imaging with the Event Horizon Telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01351v2.title: The VANDELS survey: the ionizing properties of star-forming galaxies at $3 \leq z \leq 5$ using deep rest-frame ultraviolet spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01351v2.summary: The ionizing budget in the EoR was likely dominated by UV-faint, low-mass and dustless galaxies. Potential Lyman Continuum Emitters(LCEs) and selected Lyman Alpha Emitters (LAEs) show systematically higher ionizing production efficiency.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10585v2.title: Spatially-resolved chemodynamics of the starburst dwarf galaxy CGCG 007-025: Evidence for recent accretion of metal-poor gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10585v2.summary: Nearby metal-poor starburst dwarf galaxies present a unique opportunity to determine the physics of high-density star formation. We use VLT/MUSE integral field spectroscopy to characterise the star-forming (SF) gas, from its metal content to itskinematics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.11753v2.title: Jet Formation in 3D GRMHD Simulations of Bondi-Hoyle-Lyttleton Accretion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.11753v2.summary: A black hole (BH) travelling through a uniform, gaseous medium is described by Bondi-Hoyle-Lyttleton (BHL) accretion. If the medium is magnetized, then the black hole can produce relativistic outflows. We found that the ensuing accretion drags to the BH the magnetic flux, which becomes dynamically important.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06440v1.title: Constraining Primordial Magnetic Fields with Line-Intensity Mapping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06440v1.summary: Primordial magnetic fields offer a compelling explanation for the origins of observed magnetic fields, especially on extragalactic scales. SuchPMFs give rise to excess of power in small scale matter perturbations that strongly influence structure formation. We study the impact of the magically enhanced matter power spectrum on the signal that will be observed by line-intensity mapping (LIM) surveys targeting carbon monoxide (CO) emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07072v3.title: JWST/NIRSpec Spectroscopy of $z=7-9$ Star Forming Galaxies with CEERS: New Insight into Bright Ly$α$ Emitters in Ionized Bubbles
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07072v3.summary: JWST/NIRSpec observations of galaxies at $z\gtrsim7$ taken as part of the CEERS survey of the EGS field. Previous observations of this area have revealed associations of Ly$\alpha$ emitters at redshifts ($z=7.5-$8.7$) where the IGM is thought mostly neutral.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06419v1.title: A Wide View of the Galactic Globular Cluster NGC 2808: Red Giant and Horizontal Branch Star Spatial Distributions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06419v1.summary: Researchers studied the distribution of stellar sub-populations and stars in different evolutionary phases out to the cluster tidal radius. They found that the relative fraction of red horizontal branch stars increases for radial distances larger than 1.5' while that of blue and hotter stars decreases. A similar distribution was also found for the most massive Galactic globular cluster omega Cen.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06405v1.title: FAST drift scan survey for HI intensity mapping: I. preliminary data analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06405v1.summary: This work presents the initial results of the drift-scan observation for theneutral hydrogen (HI) intensity mapping survey with the Five-hundred-meterAperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST) The data analyzed in this work were collected in night observations from 2019 through 2021. The primary findings are based on 28 hours of observation carried out over seven nights in 2021.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06400v1.title: Revisiting the Properties of X-ray AGN in the SSA22 Protocluster: Normal SMBH and Host-Galaxy Growth for AGN in a $z=3.09$ Overdensity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06400v1.summary: We analyze the physical properties of 8 X-ray selected active galactic nuclei (AGN) and one candidate protoquasar system (ADF22A1) in the $z = 3.09$ SSA22protocluster. We recover star formation histories for 7 of these systems which are well-fit by composite stellar population plus AGN models. We find indications that 4/9 of the SSA 22 AGN systems we study have host galaxies below the main sequence, with $\rm SFR/SFR_{MS} \leq -0.4$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06396v1.title: Time evolution of Ce as traced by APOGEE using giant stars observed with the Kepler, TESS and K2 missions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06396v1.summary: We aim to investigate one of the least studied s-process elements in the literature, Ce. We combine the global asteroseismic parameters derived from precise light curves obtained by the Kepler, K2 and TESS missions with chemical abundances from the APOGEE DR17 survey and astrometric data from the Gaia mission. We then compute stellar ages using the code PARAM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06388v1.title: Dust Properties of 870 Micron Selected Galaxies in the GOODS-S
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06388v1.summary: We analyze the dust properties of 57 870 $\mu$m selected dusty star-forminggalaxies in the GOODS-S using new deep ALMA 1.2 mm, 2 mm, and 3 mm continuum imaging. We find a negative correlation between emissivity indices and effective dust temperatures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06385v1.title: Intracluster light in the core of z~2 galaxy proto-clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06385v1.summary: Intracluster light is thought to originate from stars that were ripped away from their parent galaxies by gravitational tides and galaxy interactions. The abundance of intracluster stars is negligible in young proto-clusters at z~2 and grows to around a quarter of the stellar mass in the oldest, most mature clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06383v1.title: How to Flip a Bar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06383v1.summary: Galactic bars, made up of elongated and aligned stellar orbits, can lose angular momentum via resonant torques with dark matter particles in the halo. If a stellar bar is decelerated to zerorotation speed, it can flip the sign of its angular momentum and reverse its direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06376v1.title: X-Shooting ULLYSES: massive stars at low metallicity. I. Project Description
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06376v1.summary: The Hubble Space Telescope has devoted 500 orbits to observe 250 massive stars at low Z in the ultraviolet (UV) with the COS and STIS spectrographs. The complementary X-Shooting ULLYSES (XShootU) project provides enhanced legacy value with high-quality optical and near-infrared spectra. As uncertainties in stellar and wind parameters percolate into many surrounding areas of Astrophysics, the data and modelling of the XSh shoot project is expected to be a game-changer.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06366v1.title: A radio-jet driven outflow in the Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 2110?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06366v1.summary: We present a spatially-resolved study of the ionised gas in the central 2 kpcof the Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 2110. We use new optical integral-field observations taken with the MEGARA spectrograph at GTC. We fit the emission lines with amaximum of two Gaussian components, except at the AGN position.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06369v1.title: The Next Generation Virgo Cluster Survey (NGVS). XXXV. First Kinematical Clues of Overly-Massive Dark Matter Halos in Several Ultra-Diffuse Galaxies in the Virgo Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06369v1.summary: Keck/DEIMOS spectroscopy of the first complete sample ofultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) in the Virgo cluster. Some of them may be the most extended version of dwarf galaxies, while others are so extreme that they populate dark matter halos consistent with that of the Milky-Way or even larger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05333v2.title: Shocks Power Tidal Disruption Events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05333v2.summary: Accretion of debris seems to be the natural mechanism to power the radiation emitted during a tidal disruption event (TDE) However, this requires the prompt formation of acompact accretion disk. At most a tiny fraction of the bound mass enters such a disk on the timescale of observed flares.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06309v1.title: ALMA 1.1mm Observations of a Conservative Sample of High Redshift Massive Quiescent Galaxies in SHELA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06309v1.summary: We present a sample of 30 massive (log$(M_{\ast}/M_\odot) >11$) $z=3-5$quiescent galaxies. These galaxies were selected from the Spitzer-HETDEX Exploratory Large                Area (SHELA) Survey and observed at 1.1mm with Atacama Large                Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) Band 6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15699v5.title: A Magnified Compact Galaxy at Redshift 9.51 with Strong Nebular Emission Lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15699v5.summary: The galaxy has a radius of 16.2+4.6-7.2 parsecs. It is substantially more compact than galaxies with equivalent luminosity at z = 6 to 8. It has a high star formation rate surface density, leading to a high surface density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07738v3.title: A comprehensive study on the relation between the metal enrichment of ionised and atomic gas in star-forming galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07738v3.summary: We study the relation between the metallicities of ionised and atomic gas in star-forming galaxies at z=0-3 using the EAGLE cosmological, hydrodynamical simulations. The difference between the two metallicities decreases when moving towards the galaxy centres. This implies the mixing of the two gas phases is most efficient in the central regions of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15041v3.title: High Eddington quasars as discovery tools: current state and challenges
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15041v3.summary: A landmark of accretion processes in active galactic nuclei (AGN) is the continuum originating from a complex structure, i.e., an accretion disk and a Corona around a supermassive black hole. Modelling the broad-band spectral energy distribution (SED) effectively ionizing the gas-rich broad emission line region (BLR) is key to understanding the various radiative processes at play.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13582v2.title: Morphologies of Galaxies at $z \gtrsim 9$ Uncovered by JWST/NIRCam Imaging: Cosmic Size Evolution and an Identification of an Extremely Compact Bright Galaxy at $z\sim 12$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13582v2.summary: We present morphologies of galaxies at $z \gtrsim 9$ resolved by JWST/NIRCam imaging. Our sample consists of $22$ galaxy candidates identified by stringent dropout and photo-$z criteria in GLASS, CEERS, SMACS J0723, and Stephan's Quintet flanking fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10566v2.title: Scanning For Dark Matter Subhalos in Hubble Space Telescope Imaging of 54 Strong Lenses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10566v2.summary: Cold dark matter (DM) model predicts that every galaxy contains thousands of DM subhalos. The subhalo are invisible, but could be detected via strong gravitational lensing. They lie on the line of sight to amultiply-imaged background source, and perturb its shape.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09411v2.title: Wasserstein distance as a new tool for discriminating cosmologies through the topology of large scale structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09411v2.summary: The Wasserstein distance (a.k.a. the pair-matching distance) wasproposed to measure the difference between two networks in terms of persistentHomology. We show that one can discern two Cosmic webs (simulated or real) with different $z$ parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12137v2.title: Photometric determination of the mass accretion rates of pre-main-sequence stars. VIII. Recent star formation in NGC 299
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12137v2.summary: We studied the properties of the young stellar populations in the NGC 299 mistakenlycluster in the Small Magellanic Cloud. We identified 250stars with H$\alpha$ excess exceeding 5 $\sigma$ and an equivalent width of the $H$\ alpha$ emission line of at least 20 \r{A}. The average mass accretion rate for these stars is comparable to the values found in other low-metallicity, low-density clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05932v1.title: A 3D physico-chemical model of a pre-stellar core. I. Environmental and structural impact on the distribution of CH$_3$OH and $c$-C$_3$H$_2$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05932v1.summary: Pre-stellar cores represent the earliest stage of the star- and planet-formation process. By characterizing the physical and chemical structure of these cores we can establish the initial conditions for star and planetformation. A 3D MHD model of a pre-stellar coreembedded in a dynamic star-forming cloud is post-processed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05854v1.title: Stellar Parameters and Chemical Abundances Estimated from LAMOST-II DR8 MRS based on Cycle-StarNet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05854v1.summary: Deriving stellar atmospheric parameters and chemical abundances from stellarspectra is crucial for understanding the evolution of the Milky Way. We estimate the fundamental stellarparameters (Teff, log g, [Fe/H], vmic, and vmac) and 11 chemical abundance for 1.38 million FGKM-type stars from LAMOST-II DR8.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03862v2.title: Substructures in Compact Disks of the Taurus Star-forming Region
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03862v2.summary: Observations of substructure in protoplanetary disks have largely been limited to the brightest and largest disks, excluding the abundant population of compact disks. Here, we reanalyze 0.1'', 1.33 mm ALMA observations of 12 compact protoplanets in the Taurus star-forming region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07270v2.title: HST viewing of spectacular star-forming trails behind ESO 137-001
