http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07270v2.summary: ESO 137-001 is known to host a prominent stripped tail detected in many bands from X-rays, Halpha to CO. We trace SF over at least 100 Myr and give a full picture of the recent SF history in the tail. We alsodemonstrate the importance of including nebular emissions and a nebular tostellar extinction correction factor.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05793v1.title: Gravitational Wave Peeps from EMRIs and their Implication for LISA Signal Confusion Noise
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05793v1.summary: Gravitational wave peeps are not likely to be detected by a space-based gravitational wave detector. But an ensemble of such subthreshold sources produce an unresolvable background noise that may obscure sources otherwise detectable. Here we present the waveforms and spectra of the gravitational wave peep generated from recent calculations of extreme mass ratio inspirals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05782v1.title: The LOFAR Two-metre Sky Survey Deep Fields Data Release 1: V. Survey description, source classifications and host galaxy properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05782v1.summary: Source classifications, stellar masses and star formation rates are presented for 80,000 radio sources from the first data release of the Low Frequency ArrayTwo-metre Sky Survey (LoTSS) Deep Fields. Using deep multi-wavelength data spanning from ultraviolet to far-infrared, spectral energy distribution (SED) fitting is carried out for all of the LoTSS-Deep host galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05764v1.title: Case A or Case B? The effective recombination coefficient in gas clouds of arbitrary optical thickness
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05764v1.summary: In calculations of the ionization state, one is often forced to choose between the Case A and Case B recombination coefficients. If the cloud is optically thick to ionizing photons, the Case B coefficient is usually adopted on the basis of the "on-the-spot" approximation. In the opposite case of an optically thin cloud, one would expect theCase A recombination coefficient to better describe the effective recombinationrate in the cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07293v2.title: HALO7D III: Chemical Abundances of Milky Way Halo Stars from Medium Resolution Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07293v2.summary: The Halo Assembly in Lambda Cold Dark Matter: Observations in 7 Dimensions (HALO7D) survey measures the kinematics and chemical properties of stars in the Milky Way's stellar halo. We present the [Fe/H] and [$\alpha$/Fe] abundances for 113 HALo7D stars. The results highlight the additional information that is available on smaller spatial scales when compared to results from a spherical average.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05749v1.title: Spectrum of the linearized Vlasov--Poisson equation around steady states from galactic dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05749v1.summary: We study the linearized Vlasov-Poisson equation in the gravitational case. We identify the absolutely continuous spectrum and give criteria for the existence of oscillating modes and estimate their number. Our method allows us to take into account an attractive external potential. For more information, visit: http://www.nasa.gov/science/topics/geological-mechanics/gravitational-case.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05719v1.title: Physics and Chemistry of Radiation Driven Cloud Evolution. [C II] Kinematics of IC 59 and IC 63
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05719v1.summary: We used high-resolution [C II] 158 $\mu$m mapping of two nebulae IC 59 and IC 63 from SOFIA/upGREAT to probe the kinematics, structure, and magnetic properties of their photo-dissociation regions. We do not detect any significant correlation between the orientation of the magnetic field (Soam et al. 2017) and the velocity gradients of the gas, indicating a moderate magnetic field strength.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05698v1.title: Characterizing cool, neutral gas and ionized metals in the outskirts of low-z galaxy clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05698v1.summary: We present the first statistical detection of cool, neutral gas in low-z galaxy clusters. We find that the CGM of galaxies residing in cluster outskirts isconsiderably deficient in neutral gas compared to their field counterparts. We argue that the cool gas detected in clusteroutskirts arises from the circumgalactic gas stripped from cluster galaxies and fed by large-scale filaments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05694v1.title: A Local Universe model for constrained simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05694v1.summary: Constrained simulations of our local cosmological region up to a few hundred Mpc/h are designed to reproduce the actual cosmicweb of structures as observed. Here we introduce the Local Universe model (LUM), a new methodology, where many constrained simulations can be judged and the ''best'' initial conditions identified.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05692v1.title: Obscured AGN enhancement in galaxy pairs at cosmic noon: evidence from a probabilistic treatment of photometric redshifts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05692v1.summary: Observations of the nearby universe reveal an increasing fraction of activegalactic nuclei (AGN) with decreasing projected separation for close galaxy pairs. This implies galaxy interactions play a role in enhancing AGN activity. However, the picture at higher redshift is lessestablished, partly due to limited spectroscopic redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05679v1.title: The impact of UV variability on the abundance of bright galaxies at $z \geq 9$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05679v1.summary: JWST observations have revealed a population of galaxies bright enough that potentially challenge standard galaxy formation models. Using a minimal empirical framework, we investigate the influence of                variability on the rest-frame ultra-violet (UV) luminosity function (UVLF) of galaxies at $z\geq 9$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05680v1.title: A Bayesian chemical evolution model of the DustPedia Galaxy M74
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05680v1.summary: We introduce a new, multi-zone chemical evolution model of the DustPedia grotesquegalaxy M74. We take into account the observed stellar and gas density profiles. For both tau and nu, we find a weaker radial dependence than in the Milky Way. We also investigate the dust content of M74, comparing the observed dustdensity profile with the results of our chemical evolution models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09822v2.title: Stellar Rotation and Structure of the $α$ Persei Complex: When Does Gyrochronology Start to Work?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09822v2.summary: Gyrochronology is based on the rotation rates of Sun-like stars. The Persei open cluster may provide the needed calibrator. By assembling a list of rotationally-confirmed members, we provide strong evidence that $\alpha$ Per is part of a larger complex of similarly-aged stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05650v1.title: Measuring Dust Attenuation Curves of SINGS/KINGFISH Galaxies Using Swift/UVOT Photometry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05650v1.summary: We present Swift/Ultraviolet Optical Telescope (UVOT) integrated lightphthalphotometry of the Spitzer Infrared Nearby Galaxies Survey. We find that the average dust attenuation law of the sample changes slightly based on the SFH assumed. Using simulated data, we also find the exponential SFH fails to outperform the more complex SFHs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05564v1.title: The Dragonfly Galaxy. III. Jet-brightening of a High-redshift Radio Source Caught in a Violent Merger of Disk Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05564v1.summary: The Dragonfly Galaxy (MRC 0152-209) is the most infrared-luminous radio galaxy at redshift z~2. It consists of two galaxies with rotating disks that are in the early phase of merging. The radio jet originates from the northern galaxy and brightens when it hits the disk of the southern galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14249v2.title: Stellar variability in Gaia DR3. I. Three-band photometric dispersions for 145 million sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14249v2.summary: The unparalleled characteristics of Gaia photometry make it an excellent choice to study stellar variability. WDs and sdBs are more variable than MS or RC stars but their variabilitydecreases for the former with age. The MS region in the Gaia CAMD has an s_G distribution peaks at low values (~1-2 mmag)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05504v1.title: HSC-CLAUDS survey: The star formation rate functions since z ~ 2 and comparison with hydrodynamical simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05504v1.summary: Star formation rate functions (SFRFs) give an instantaneous view of the distribution of star formation rates in galaxies at different epochs. They are a complementary and more stringent test for models than the galaxystellar mass function. The exploration of SFRFs has been limited thus far due to difficulties in assessing the SFR from observed quantities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.09791v2.title: A Dynamical Mass Estimate from the Magellanic Stream
http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.09791v2.summary: We present a model for the formation of the Magellanic Stream (MS) due to ram pressure stripping. We find that there is a direct correlation between the observed stream length and the mass of the Milky Way. As a tracer of the dynamical mass in the outer halo, the MS is a particularly valuable probe of Milky Way'spotential.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05363v1.title: Metal-poor stars observed with the Magellan Telescope. IV. Neutron-capture element signatures in 27 main-sequence stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05363v1.summary: Based on high-resolution spectra obtained with Magellan/MIKE, we present a Chemo-dynamical analysis for 27 near main-sequence turnoff metal-poor stars. We derived chemicalabundances for 17 elements, including strontium and barium. The lighter elements generally agree well with those of other low-metallicity halo stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05362v1.title: RAM: Rapid Advection Algorithm on Arbitrary Meshes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05362v1.summary: The study of many astrophysical flows requires computational algorithms that can capture high Mach number flows, while resolving a large dynamic range. In this paper we present a novel method, RAM: Rapid                Advection Algorithm on Arbitrary Meshes. Depending on the bulk velocity and resolution, RAM can decrease the numerical cost of hydrodynamics by more than one order of magnitude.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.05345v3.title: Cosmology dependency of halo masses and concentrations in hydrodynamic simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.05345v3.summary: We employ a set of Magneticum cosmological hydrodynamic simulations that span over $15$ different cosmologies. We extract masses and concentrations of all well-resolved haloes between $z=0-1$ for critical over-densities. We find that converting masses with the aid of a Mc relation carries an additional fractional scatter ($\approx 4\%$) originated from deviations from the assumed NFW density profile.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05305v1.title: Low-Temperature Kinetics for the N + NO reaction: Experiment Guides the Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05305v1.summary: Reaction N(4S) + NO -> O(3P) + N2 plays a pivotal role in the conversion of atomic to molecular nitrogen in dense interstellar clouds. With decreasing temperature, the reaction rate was found to monotonously increase up to a value of (6.6                +- 1.3) x 10-11 cm3 s-1 at 50 K.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13048v2.title: Stars on the edge: Galactic tides and the outskirts of the Sculptor dwarf spheroidal
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13048v2.summary: A Bayesian algorithm is used to find new candidate members in theextreme outskirts of the Sculptor dwarf galaxy. The formation of "stellar halos" in dwarf galaxies have been discussed in terms of early mergers or Galactic tides. We discuss further ways to test and validate this tidal interpretation for the origin of these distant stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05250v1.title: More relaxed intracluster gas than galaxies in clusters in quasi-equilibrium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05250v1.summary: During cluster mergers, the intracluster gas and member galaxies undergoDynamic evolution, but at different timescales and reach different states. We calculate cluster orientations and three kinds of dynamicalparameters, i.e., the normalized centroid offset, the sphere index and the                ellipticity, for these clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12825v2.title: JWST Census for the Mass-Metallicity Star-Formation Relations at z=4-10 with the Self-Consistent Flux Calibration and the Proper Metallicity Calibrators
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12825v2.summary: We present the evolution of the mass-metallicity (MZ) relations at z=4-10 with 135 galaxies identified in the JWST/NIRSpec data. We confirm that 10 out of the 135 galaxies with [OIII]4363-lines have electron temperatures of 1.1-2.3*10^4K. This can be explained by heating of young massive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05213v1.title: A high-redshift calibration of the [OI]-to-HI conversion factor in star-forming galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05213v1.summary: The assembly and build-up of neutral atomic hydrogen (HI) in galaxies is one of the most fundamental processes in galaxy formation and evolution. Studying this process directly in the early universe is hindered by the weakness of thehyperfine 21-cm HI line transition. Here we present a new method to infer the HI gas masses of high-redshift galaxies using neutral atomic oxygen as a proxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05173v1.title: ALMA High-Level Data Products: Submillimetre counterparts of SDSS quasars in the ALMA footprint
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05173v1.summary: The Atacama Large Millimetre/submillimetre Array (ALMA) is the world's most advanced radio interferometric facility. It produces science data with an average rate of about 1 TB per day. The scientific data are stored in the ALMA Science Archive (ASA)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05167v1.title: The HI gas fraction scaling relation of the Green Pea galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05167v1.summary: limited samples of Green Pea galaxies have HI 21 cm measurements. The HI to stellar mass ratios deviate from the polynomial form, where a higher HI gas fraction is predicted given the current NUV-r color. In order to obtain accurate linear combinedforms, higher-resolution photometry from space-based telescopes is needed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00950v2.title: Gravitational lensing modification of the high redshift galaxy luminosity function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00950v2.summary: The bright end of the rest-frame UV luminosity function (UVLF) of high-z galaxies is modified by gravitational lensing magnification bias. The UVLF can be used to set mild constraints on the galaxies’ size, favoring smaller galaxies compared to the fiducial luminosity-size relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05104v1.title: Fisher matrix forecasts on the astrophysics of galaxies during the epoch of reionisation from the 21-cm power spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05104v1.summary: The 21-cm transition of neutral hydrogen from the early Universe is a sensitive probe of the formation and evolution of the first galaxies. Using the Fisher matrix formalism we explore the complex anddegenerate high-dimensional parameter space associated with the high-$z$sources of this era and forecast quantitative constraints. We demonstrate that it is possible to recover 5 of the 8 parameters describing these properties with better than $50$ per cent precision.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05073v1.title: An analysis of the isomers HCN and HNC in the evolution of high-mass star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05073v1.summary: The study of molecules and their chemistry in star-forming regions is necessary to understand the physical process occurring in such regions. The isomers abundances show a behavior that can be explained from the chemistry occurring as the temperature and the UV radiation increase. This work is part of an on-going study of multiple molecules that stand in the sample of analyzed regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05067v1.title: Constraining SIDM cross section models with a joint analysis of galaxies and clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05067v1.summary: We select 9 isolated galaxies and brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) with baryonic components small enough such that they do not significantly influence halo gravothermal evolution processes. We then constrain the parameters of a cross section model with the measured rotation curves and stellar kinematics through the gravothermal fluid formalism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05053v1.title: XQR-30: the ultimate XSHOOTER quasar sample at the reionization epoch
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05053v1.summary: The final phase of the reionization process can be probed by rest-frame UVabsorption spectra of quasars at z>6. This sheds light on the properties of the diffuse intergalactic medium within the first Gyr of the Universe. The ESO Large Programme "XQR-30" dedicated ~250 hours of observations at the VLT to create a high-quality sample of spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05024v1.title: The odd bunch: chrono-chemo-dynamics of sixteen unusual stars from Kepler
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05024v1.summary: This study combines asteroseismic, spectroscopic and kinematic information to perform a detailed analysis of a sample of 16 stars from the Kepler field. Our selection focuses on stars that appear to contradict Galacticchemical evolution models. Among the seven stars previously classified as young and $\alpha$-rich, only one seems to be an unambiguously older object masking its true age.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05012v1.title: Globular clusters in the central region of the Milky Way galaxy I. Bar influence on the orbit parameters according to Gaia EDR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05012v1.summary: The work is devoted to the analysis of the influence of the galactic bar on the orbital motion of globular clusters in the central region of the Galaxy. The mass of the bar exerts the greatest influence on theorbital motion, which is expressed mainly in an increase in the apocentric and pericentric distances in the vast majority of clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04997v1.title: Stellar Collisions in Galactic Nuclei: Impact on Destructive Events Near a Supermassive Black Hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04997v1.summary: We present a simplified numerical analysis of thedestructive stellar collision rate in a cluster similar to that of the MilkyWay. The analysis includes an effective average two-body relaxation Monte-Carloscheme and general relativistic effects. We also consider stars which are injected into the stellar cluster after being disrupted from a binary system by the supermassive black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04991v1.title: First observations of warm and cold methanol in Class 0/I proto-brown dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04991v1.summary: We present results from the first molecular line survey to search for thefundamental complex organic molecule, methanol. 14 Class 0/I                proto-brown dwarfs were studied. IRAM 30-m observations over the frequency range of 92-116 GHz and 213-280 GHz have revealed emission in 14 transition lines. The high excitation lines likely probe the warm ($\sim$25-50 K) corino region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04987v1.title: QLUSTER: quick clusters of merging binary black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04987v1.summary: QLUSTER is a simple tool to investigate the occurrence and properties of hierarchical black-hole mergers detectable by gravitational-wave interferometers. It is not meant to rival the complexity of state-of-the-art population synthesis and N-bodycodes. It provides a fast, approximate, and easy-to-interpret framework to investigate key ingredients of the problem.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04981v1.title: Constraining The Milky Way Bar Length using Hercules and Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04981v1.summary: Hercules increases in $V_\phi$ and becomes stronger as we move towards theminor axis of the bar. This is in direct agreement with theoreticalpredictions of a long, slow bar model in which Hercules is formed by thecorotation resonance with stars orbiting the bar's L4/L5 Lagrange points.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04965v1.title: Implementation of chemistry in the Athena++ code
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04965v1.summary: Chemistry plays a key role in many aspects of astrophysical fluids. We present the implementation of a chemistry module in the publiclyavailable magneto-hydrodynamic code Athena++. The chemical andthermal processes are evolved as a system of coupled ODEs with an implicit CVODE library.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04955v1.title: Binary neutron star populations in the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04955v1.summary: Galactic binary neutron stars (BNSs) are a unique laboratory to probe the evolution of BNSs and their progenitors. We use a new version of thepopulation synthesis code SEVN to evolve the population of Galactic B NSs. We analyze the merge rate, orbital period, eccentricity and spin period derivative of the BNSpopulation. According to our fiducial model, the Square Kilometre Array will detect 20 new BNSS in the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04953v1.title: CLEAR: The Morphological Evolution of Galaxies in the Green Valley
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04953v1.summary: Quiescent galaxies having more compact morphologies than star-forminggalaxies has been a consistent result in the field of galaxy evolution. What is not clear is at what point this divergence happens, i.e. when do quiescentgalaxies become compact, and how big of a role does the progenitor effect play?

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04948v1.title: Discovery of Radial Spectral Hardening in the Hot Bubble of Planetary Nebula BD+30 3639 with Median Energy Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04948v1.summary: Using the median energy value of the X-ray photons, we identified a rise in energy values towards the projected edge of the nebula. We argue that the radial spectral hardening is due to an increased column density at the projected nebular edge. Median energy metrics provide a promising new methodology for exploring the spatialvariations in faint extended X-rays sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04949v1.title: The Impact of Cosmic Variance on Inferences of Global Neutral Fraction Derived from Ly$α$ Luminosity Functions During Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04949v1.summary: We investigate the impact of field-to-field variation, deriving from cosmicvariance, in measured Lyman-$\alpha$ emitter (LAE) luminosity functions (LFs) This variation's impact on inferences of the neutral fraction of the                intergalactic medium (IGM) during reionization. We post-process a z=7 IGM simulations to populate the dark matter halos with LAEs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04944v1.title: Exploring the nature of UV-bright $z \gtrsim 10$ galaxies detected by JWST: star formation, black hole accretion, or a non universal IMF?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04944v1.summary: We use the Cosmic Archaeology Tool (CAT) semi-analytical model to explore the contribution of Population (Pop) III/II stars and active galactic nuclei (AGNs) to the galaxy UV luminosity function (LF) evolution. The model predicts a star formation history dominated by UV faint galaxies. The predicted stellar and AGN UV LFs reproduce the observational data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04822v1.title: Gas Sources from the Coma and Nucleus of Comet 46P/Wirtanen Observed Using ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04822v1.summary: The majority of cometary gases observed at radio wavelengths have yet to be mapped. Gas-phase molecules in cometary atmospheres (comae) originate primarily from outgassing by the nucleus, sublimation of icy grains in the near-nucleus coma, and (3) coma (photo-)chemical processes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04795v1.title: Non-thermal emissions from a head-tail radio galaxy in 3D magnetohydrodynamic simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04795v1.summary: We find that the reacceleration is essential to explain the observed radioproperties of head-tail galaxies. We also explore the origin of the collimated synchrotron threads, which are found in some head- tail galaxies. Thin and elongated flux tubes, connecting the two tails, are formed by strong backflows at an early phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03078v2.title: The isotropic center of NGC 5419 -- A core in formation?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03078v2.summary: NGC 5419 appears as a typical high-mass early-type galaxy. It hosts two distinct nuclei in its center. The low-density stellar core forms rapidly by supermassive black holes. Only afterwards the SMBHs form a hard binary and the blackhole scouring process slowly changes the central orbit distribution fromisotropic to tangential.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04753v1.title: Evolution of radioactive elements in the LMC: predictions for future gamma-ray surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04753v1.summary: Short-lived radionuclides, such as 26Al and 60Fe, are tracer of starforming. Therefore, their abundances can unravel the recent star formation history of the host galaxy. We predict theasses and fluxes of these two elements in the Large Magellanic Cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04741v1.title: RIOJA I. The core of the highest redshift galaxy overdensity at $z= 7.88$ confirmed by NIRSpec/JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04741v1.summary: We present the spectroscopic confirmation of the core of the most distant proto-cluster at $z = 7.88$, A2744-z7p9OD. The core region includes as many as 4 galaxies detected in [O III] 4960 A and 5008 A in a small area of.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04662v1.title: Efficient NIRCam Selection of Quiescent Galaxies at 3 < z < 6 in CEERS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04662v1.summary: The populations of massive quiescent galaxies at $z\ge3$ challenge our understanding of rapid galaxy growth and quenching over shorttimescales. Established techniques for identifying these galaxies are increasingly inefficient and unconstrained. As much as 70% of these galaxies may be missed from existing surveys. We propose a new empirical color selection technique designed to select massive quiedcent galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04637v1.title: The variability of the broad-line Balmer decrement for quasars from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Reverberation Mapping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04637v1.summary: The logarithm of the mean broad-line Balmer decrement is 0.62 with a standard deviation of 0.15 dex. 27 quasars show strong negative correlations between the Balmer. decrement and the continuum variance. It suggests that the size corresponding to the Balm decrement lag extends from the BLR size to the torus size.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04621v1.title: NGTS clusters survey $-$ V: Rotation in the Orion Star-forming Complex
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04621v1.summary: We present a study of rotation across 30 square degrees of the OrionStar-forming Complex. Rotation periodsgenerally lie in the range 1$-$10 d, with only 1.5 per cent of classical T Tauri stars or Class I/II young stellar objects rotating with periods shorter than 1.8 d. In period$-$colour space, the rotation period distribution moves toward shorter periods among low-mass (>M2) stars of age 3$-$6 Myr. This could reflect a mass-dependence for the dispersal of circumstellar deities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04613v1.title: Breakdown of the Newton-Einstein Standard Gravity at Low Acceleration in Internal Dynamics of Wide Binary Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04613v1.summary: A gravitational anomaly is found at weak gravitational acceleration at $10-9$ m s$^{-2}$ from analyses of the dynamics of wide binary stars. The observed sky-projected motions are deprojected to the three-dimensional relative velocity $v$ and separation $r$ through a Monte Carlo method. A statistical relation between the Newtonian acceleration. $g_{\rm{N}} and a kinematic acceleration $g \equiv v^2/r$ is compared with the corresponding relation. predicted by Newtonian dynamics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04611v1.title: ${\rm H_2CN}$/${\rm H_2NC}$ abundance ratio: a new potential temperature tracer for the interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04611v1.summary: The high-energy metastable isomer of a radical from the H2C radical has been recently detected for the first time in thestellar medium towards a handful of cold galactic sources. This isomeric ratio dependence with temperature cannot be fully explained. The shortage of them in warm sources still prevents us to confirm this hypothesis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04595v1.title: First evidence of multi-iron sub-populations in the Bulge Fossil Fragment candidate Liller 1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04595v1.summary: The obtained metallicity distribution is astonishingly similar to that predicted by the reconstructed star formation history of Liller 1. The findings provide further support to the possibility, similar to Terzan 5, also Liller1 is a Bulge Fossil Fragment. The obtained iron distribution is found to be significantly more centrally concentrated than the metal-poor population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04593v1.title: Radial velocities and stellar population properties of 56 MATLAS dwarf galaxies observed with MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04593v1.summary: Dwarf galaxies have been extensively studied in the Local Group, in nearby nearby groups, and selected clusters. We present a follow-up to the MATLAS survey in low-to-moderatedensity environments beyond the Local Volume. We find that the dwarf galaxies presented in this work show a systematic offset from the stellar mass-metallicity relation towards lower metallicities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09370v2.title: Testing Super-Eddington Accretion onto a Supermassive Black Hole: Reverberation Mapping of PG 1119+120
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09370v2.summary: We measure the black hole mass and investigate the accretion flow around the local quasar PG 1119+120. We find the disc SED to be flatter than expected with an Eddington ratio of 1. While this accretion is super-Eddington, the geometry is still unclear, however a slimophobicdisc is expected due to the high radiation pressure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04551v1.title: On networks of space-based gravitational-wave detectors
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04551v1.summary: The space-based laser interferometers, LISA, Taiji and TianQin, are targeting to observe milliHz gravitational waves (GWs) in the 2030s. The joint Observations from Multiple Space-based detectors yield significant advantages, say the authors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00931v2.title: Translators of galaxy morphology indicators between observation and simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00931v2.summary: Morphology is the most basic and fundamental property of galaxies. Observations and simulations still use different methods to determinegalaxy morphology. We measure morphological indicators using photometric and spectroscopic methods. We also measure the kinematic disk-to-total ratios using Gaussian mixture model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04528v1.title: Precise Masses, Ages of ~1.0 million RGB and RC stars observed by the LAMOST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04528v1.summary: We construct a catalogue of stellar masses and ages for 696,680 red giant                branch (RGB) stars, 180,436 primary red clump (RC) stars. The mass and age of RGBs and RCs are determined again with the neural network method by taking the LAMOST-Kepler giant stars as the training set. The RGB and RC stellar samples cover a large volume of the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04510v1.title: Radiation pressure acting on the neutral He atoms in the Heliosphere
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04510v1.summary: The Interstellar Neutral Helium (ISN He) is an important source of information on the physical state of the Local Interstellar Medium. Radiation pressure acting on typical helium causes flux differences at a level of 1-4% and is comparable to the observational errors. For the more sensitive IMAP-Lo instrument, there are some regions in the considered observations where radiation pressure causes potentially statistically significant changes in the calculated fluxes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04484v1.title: Near-Infrared Spectroscopy of Dense Ejecta Knots in the Outer Eastern Area of the Cassiopeia A Supernova Remnant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04484v1.summary: The Cassiopeia A supernova remnant has a complex structure, manifesting the multidimensional nature of core-collapse supernova explosions. We carried out near-infrared multi-object spectroscopy on the ejecta knots located in the "northeastern (NE) jet" and the "Fe K plume"Regions. We propose that they are dense knots produced by acomplete Si burning with a freezeout.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02761v2.title: The Andromeda Galaxy's Last Major Merger: Constraints from the survey of Planetary Nebulae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02761v2.summary: The Andromeda galaxy (M 31) has experienced a tumultuous merger history. We identify the older dynamically hotter thicker disc in M 31 and a distinct younger dynamically colder thin disc. The two discs are alsochemically distinct with the PN chemodynamics implying their formation in a wet major merger 2.5-4 Gyr ago.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04415v1.title: Unveiling the initial conditions of open star cluster formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04415v1.summary: Open clusters (OCs) are infrequent survivors of embedded clusters gestated in molecular clouds. Little is known about the initial conditions for the formation of OCs. The masses of the progenitor clumps where OCs were born are comparable to previously known results for clumps observed in the Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04409v1.title: An Observed Transition of Galaxy Spins on the Void Surfaces
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04409v1.summary: In simulations, the galaxy spins exhibit parallel alignments in the mass-range lower than a certain threshold. The null hypothesis of no spintransition is rejected at the 99.9% confidence level by the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. This study presents a first direct observational evidence for the existence of a mass-dependent spin transition.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04382v1.title: KURVS: The outer rotation curve shapes and dark matter fractions of $z \sim 1.5 $ star-forming galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04382v1.summary: First results from the KMOS Ultra-deep Rotation Velocity Survey. Study of 22 star-forming galaxies at $z\sim1.5$. Most rotation curves are flat or rising between three- and six-disc scale radii. Only three objects have declining outer rotation curves at more than 5$\sigma$ significance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12800v2.title: Integral Field Spectroscopy of the Cometary Starburst Galaxy NGC 4861
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12800v2.summary: Using the PMAS Integral Field Unit on the Calar Alto 3.5m telescope we studied the southern component of the `cometary' starburst galaxy NGC 4861. Mrk 59 is centred on a giant nebula and concentration of stars                1 kpc in diameter. Strong emission points to a star-formation rate at least 0.47 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00782v3.title: Discovery of Extended Fe Ka Complex X-ray Emission in NGC 5728: Ultra-Fast Outflows at Kiloparsec Scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00782v3.summary: We present Chandra ACIS imaging spectroscopy results for the extended. hard X-ray emission of the Compton thick (CT) Seyfert NGC 5728. The [red, blue] features have [6.5sigma, 5.3sigma] significance, with an equivalent width = [2.23 keV, 2.60 keV], much higher than in the nuclearspectrum. These energies imply line-of-sight velocities of ~19,000-42,000 km for the red wing, and -28,000km for the blue wing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04336v1.title: Investigating Loop Quantum Gravity Through Strong Gravitational Lensing Effects by Rotating Black Hole and EHT Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04336v1.summary: We investigate gravitational lensing in the strong deflection regime by loop-quantum gravity (LQG)-motivated rotating black hole (LMRBH) metrics. It turns out that as the LQG parameter $l$ increases, the unstable photon orbit radius and deflection angle increase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04308v1.title: Faint Galaxy Number Counts in the Durhamand SDSS Catalogues
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04308v1.summary: The Durham Extragalactic Astronomy and Cosmology catalogue could be well-fitted over their whole range using luminosity function (LF) parameters derived from the SDSS. A cosmological model treating Hubble expansion as an Einstein curvature required less correction at faint magnitudes than a $\Lambda$CDM model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04264v1.title: ATLASGAL: 3-mm class I methanol masers in high-mass star formation regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04264v1.summary: We detect narrow, maser-likefeatures towards 54, 100 and 4 sources in the maser lines near 84, 95 and 104.3 GHz. The properties of class I masers are related to shocks traced by SiO. Class I methanol masers at 84 and 95 GHz can trace a similar evolutionary stage as H$_2$O maser.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04256v1.title: Infall and Outflow Towards High-mass Starless Clump Candidates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04256v1.summary: The evolutionary sequence for high-mass star formation starts with massive starless clumps that go on to form protostellar, young stellar objects and then compact HII regions. While there are many examples of the three later stages, the very early stages have proved to be elusive. We follow-up a sample of 110 mid-infrared dark clumps selected from the ATLASGAL catalogue with the IRAMtelescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04189v1.title: Does the i-process operate at nearly solar metallicity?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04189v1.summary: The nucleosynthesis process(es) at the origin of these overabundances were however not questioned in our former study. Abundances are derived from the high-resolution HERMES spectra for Pr, Nd, Sm, and Eu. We compare the abundances of the most enriched stars with the nucleosynthetic predictions from the STAREVOL stellar evolutionary code.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04185v1.title: Revealing the intrinsic X-ray reverberation lags in IRAS 13224-3809 through the Granger causality test
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04185v1.summary: Granger causality is an econometric test for determining whether one time series is useful for forecasting another one with a certain Granger lag. We extract the Granger-lag profiles from 14 XMM-Newton observations of IRAS 13224-3809. Granger lags are a promising way to measure the intrinsic lags, and provide evidence of coronalheight variability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04098v1.title: Neutral outflows in high-z QSOs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04098v1.summary: OH+ absorption is a powerful tracer of inflowing and outflowing gas in the predominantly atomic diffuse and turbulent halo surrounding galaxies. OH+ emission is observed in 3/5 QSOs at systemic velocities. Broader CO(9-8) emission is found in obscured versus unobscured QSOS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04033v1.title: Advanced life peaked billions of years ago according to black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04033v1.summary: Dense cluster environments were less compatible with the emergence of ETIs compared to isolated elliptical galaxies. The probability for ETIs peaked in these environments around 6 billion years ago. cosmic downsizing shifted the likelihood of ETI emerging to galaxies with weak black hole feedback, such as in spiral galaxies, at late times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04025v1.title: Diverse Chemo-Dynamical Properties of Nitrogen-Rich Stars Identified From Low-Resolution Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04025v1.summary: The second generation of stars in the GCs of the MW exhibit unusually high N,                Na, or Al, compared to typical Galactic halo stars at similar metallicities. The halo field stars enhanced with such elements are believed to haveoriginated in disrupted GCs or escaped from existing GCs. More than 60% of them are not associated with those of typical Galactic populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04010v1.title: Core Collapse Supernova Explosions in Active Galactic Nucleus Accretion Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04010v1.summary: Astrophysical events that occur in active galactic nucleus (AGN) disks are believed to differ significantly from the ordinary in the interstellar medium. AGN disks provide a dense environment for supernova (SN) explosions, which inevitablyinvolve ejecta-disk interactions. The resulting SNe in the AGN disk is a promisingtransient source for UV and optical band detection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03993v1.title: Resolving supermassive black hole feeding and feedback: multiphase flows down to sub-parsec
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03993v1.summary: Mass accretion is a fundamental process for the growth of supermassive blackholes and activating the central engine. However, detailed accretion properties have not been observationally identified at the central ~10 parsec of active galaxies due to its compactness. Here we for the first time ever report the direct detection of parsec-scale (i.e., 0.01% scale of the host galaxy) dense molecular inflow in the active nucleus of the Circinus galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03979v1.title: Revisiting the Dragonfly Galaxy I. High-resolution ALMA and VLA Observations of the Radio Hotspots in a Hyper-luminous Infrared Galaxy at $z=1.92$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03979v1.summary: New observations confirm the South-East (SE) and North-West (NW) hotspots identified by previous low-resolution VLA observations at 4.7 and 8.2GHz. The SEhotspot has a higher flux density than the NW one does by a factor of 6, suggesting that there can be a Doppler boosting effect in the SE one.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v3.title: An analysis of the turbulence in the central region of M 42 (Orion Nebula) II: homogeneity and power-spectrum analyses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v3.summary: In this second communication we continue our analysis of the turbulence in the Huygens Region of the Orion Nebula. We find that the higher-ordertransverse structure functions are almost proportional to the second-order transverse structure function. This implies that there is some type of invariant statistical structure in the velocity field. We also obtain and analyse the power-spectrum of the turbulent field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03834v1.title: SDSS-IV MaNGA: The Incidence of Major Mergers in type I and II AGN Host Galaxies in the DR15 sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03834v1.summary: We present a study on the incidence of major mergers and their impact on the triggering of nuclear activity in 47 type I and 236 type II optically-selectedAGN from the MaNGA DR15 sample. The levels of AGN activity among our massive major hypertrophicmergers are similar to those reported in other works using \oiii\ tracers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03812v1.title: Exploring the environment, magnetic fields, and feedback effects of massive high-redshift galaxies with [CII]
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03812v1.summary: Massive galaxies are expected to grow through different transformative evolutionary phases. The physical mechanisms driving these phases includecompanion galaxy interactions, active galactic nuclei feedback, and magneticfields. We present evidence of a 'gas bridge' between AzTEC-3 and a companion source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03762v1.title: Vivisecting galaxies with BANG: an automated morpho-kinematical decomposition of the SDSS-DR17 MaNGA survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03762v1.summary: A new approach to galaxy decomposing. The approach is based on the SDSS-MaNGA survey. It is a computationally fast, still reliable fit of the morphological and kinematical properties of galaxies. Unexpected tails in the "hot-to-total" mass-ratio distribution are present.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03761v1.title: Weakly-Supervised Anomaly Detection in the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03761v1.summary: Classification Without                Labels (CWoLa) is a weakly-supervised anomaly detection method. CWoLa operates without the use of labeled streams or knowledge of astrophysical principles. This computationally lightweight strategy is able to detect both simulated streams and the known stream GD-1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03760v1.title: A Census of WISE-selected Dual and Offset AGN Across the Sky: New Constraints on Merger-Driven Triggering of Obscured AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03760v1.summary: Pairs of galaxies hosting active galactic nuclei (AGN) are powerful probes of merger-driven supermassive black hole (SMBH) growth. We use photometric redshifts of AGN selected by the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) to find probabilistic pairs across the sky. We find the fraction of galaxy pairs hosting WISE AGN is dominated by offset AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03758v1.title: Ram pressure stripping in the EAGLE simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03758v1.summary: Ram pressure stripping of satellite galaxies is thought to be a ubiquitous process in galaxy clusters. We track the evolution of galaxies with stellar mass between $z = 0.27$ and $z + 0.0$. We compare the evolution to predictions from either simulations or analytic models for the two gas phases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03753v1.title: High-redshift metallicity calibrations for JWST spectra: insights from line emission in cosmological simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03753v1.summary: Optical emission-line ratios are traditionally used to estimate gas metrics from observed galaxy spectra. While such estimators have been calibrated primarily at low redshift, they are commonly used to study high-redshift galaxies, where their applicability may be questioned. We use simulations including ionization by stars, active nuclei and shocks to reassess the calibrations of both optical and ultraviolet metallicity estimators.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03754v1.title: The lively accretion disc in NGC 2992. III. Tentative evidence of rapid Ultra Fast Outflow variability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03754v1.summary: The 2019 XMM-Newton+NuSTAR monitoring campaign of the Seyfert                galaxy NGC 2992, observed at one of its highest flux levels in the X-rays. Ultra Fast Outflows                (UFOs) absorbing structures above 9 keV with $> 3 \sigma$ significance. A detailed investigation of the temporal evolution on a $\sim$5 ks time scale                reveals UFO absorption lines at a confidence level $>$95% (2$\sigma)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03755v1.title: A rotational age for the open cluster NGC 2281
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03755v1.summary: We estimate the age of the open cluster NGC 2281 based on the rotational properties of its low-mass members. The spin down rates of mid-K and early-M fast rotators are significantly lower than for early-K stars. Comparisons with M37 and M48 show that all three open clusters are roughly coeval.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03750v1.title: No Surviving SN Ia Companion In SNR 0509-67.5: Stellar Population Characterization and Comparison To Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03750v1.summary: The community agrees that Type Ia supernovae arise from Carbon/Oxygen white dwarfs undergoing thermonuclear runaway. Most current models suggest that the white dwarf explodes because of interaction with a binary companion. We conducted a surviving companion search of the Large Magellanic Cloud remnant SNR 0509-67.5.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03725v1.title: Ionised gas outflows over the radio AGN life cycle
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03725v1.summary: Feedback from AGN is known to affect the host galaxy's evolution. In radio                AGN, one manifestation of feedback is seen in gas outflows. However, it is not well understood whether the effect of feedback evolves with the radioAGN life cycle. In this study, we investigate this link using the radiospectral shape as a proxy for the evolutionary stage of the AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03650v1.title: The impact of HII regions on Giant Molecular Cloud properties in nearby galaxies sampled by PHANGS ALMA and MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03650v1.summary: We identify giant molecular clouds (GMCs) associated with HII regions. We compare the distributions of GMC and HII region properties for paired and non-paired objects. The study of the full sample nevertheless hides a large variabilitygalaxy by galaxy. Our results suggests that pre-supernova feedback mechanisms in HIIregions have a subtle but measurable impact on the properties of the molecular gas, as inferred from CO observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11771v2.title: Active galactic nucleus jet feedback in hydrostatic halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11771v2.summary: Jets from active galactic nuclei are believed to be responsible for reducing cooling flows in cool-core galaxy clusters. Light, thermal jets with lowmomentum flux tend to delay the onset of a cooling flow more efficiently on a $50$ Myr timescale than heavy, kinetic jets. If the jet kinetic luminosity depends on accretion rate, collimated jets are able to reduce cooling flows without a need for precession or wide opening angles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03618v1.title: Clusters, Clouds, and Correlations: Relating Young Clusters to Giant Molecular Clouds in M33 and M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03618v1.summary: We use young clusters and giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in the galaxies M33 and M31 to constrain temporal and spatial scales in the star formation process. In M33, we compare the PHATTER catalogue of 1214 clusters with ages measuredvia colour-magnitude diagram (CMD) fitting to 444 GMCs identified from a new 35pc resolution ALMA $^{12}$CO(2-1) survey. InM31, we find that younger clusters are closer to GMCs than older clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03557v1.title: A Census of the TW Hya Association with Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03557v1.summary: I have used high-precision photometry and astrometry from the third data release of Gaia to perform a survey for members of the TW Hya association. I have identified candidate members that appear to share similarkinematics and ages with bona fide members compiled by Gagne et al. (2017) The rate of expansion corresponds to an age of 10+/-2 Myr for TWA.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03470v1.title: Mildly Relativistic Motion in the Radio Quiet Quasar PG 1351+640
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03470v1.summary: Measuring the proper motion of the emission component in radio-quiet quasars could help to distinguish between the origins of the radio emission and the jet production mechanism. PG 1351+640 is one of the few RQQs suitable for propermotion studies. Both components are >2 mJy at 5GHz and are well suited for Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10717v2.title: MIDIS: Strong (Hb + [OIII]) and Ha emitters at redshift z ~ 7-8 unveiled with JWST/NIRCam and MIRI imaging in the Hubble eXtreme Deep Field (XDF)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10717v2.summary: The JWST is revolutionizing the study of high-redshift galaxies by providing a high-sensitivity view of the early Universe at infrared wavelengths. Out of a total of 58 galaxies at z ~ 7-8, we find 18 robust candidates (~31%) for prominentHa(Hb + [O III) emitters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02262v2.title: An Interferometric SETI Observation of Kepler-111 b
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02262v2.summary: We used the European VLBI Network at $21$~cm to observe potential secondary phase calibrators in the Kepler field. A VLBA primary calibrator in the field, J1926+4441, offset only $1.88' from a nearby exoplanet Kepler-111~b, was correlated with high temporal and spectral resolution. During the analysis of the high-resolution data, we identified a spectral feature that was present in both auto and cross-correlation data with a central frequency of $1420.424\pm0.0002$ MHz and a width of 0.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03318v1.title: Steady states of the Parker instability: the effects of rotation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03318v1.summary: We model the Parker instability in vertically stratified isothermal gas using non-ideal MHD simulations. Rotation, especially differential, more strongly and diversely affects the nonlinear state than the linear stage. The horizontal magnetic field near the midplane reverses its direction propagating to higher altitudes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03311v1.title: A Catalog of Distance Determinations for the LAMOST DR8 K Giants in the Galactic Halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03311v1.summary: We present a catalog of distances for 19544 K giants drawn from LAMOST DR8. Most of them are located in the halo of the Milky Way up to ~120~kpc. The stars in the catalog lie in a region of 4-126 kpc from the Galactic Center.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03293v1.title: Weighing Andromeda: Mass estimates of the M~31 galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03293v1.summary: Andromeda (M 31) is the nearest giant spiral galaxy to our Milky Way. Over the past few decades, it has been dubbed the most massive member of the LocalGroup. I explore the evolution of the measured mass of M 31 over the past 80 years. I discuss the best present-day constraints of the mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03246v1.title: X-ray Studies of Blazar 1ES 1959+650 Using SWIFT & XMM-NEWTON Satellite
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03246v1.summary: High synchrotron energy peaked blazar 1ES 1959+650 is studied with Swift and XMM-Newton satellite. Discrete correlation function analysis indicates soft as well as hard lags. The magnetic field of the emitting region is found to be 0.64 (0.05) Gauss.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03242v1.title: Resequencing the Hubble sequence and the quadratic (black hole mass)-(spheroid stellar mass) relation for elliptical galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03242v1.summary: A new galaxy speciation model is presented. It disfavours the 'monolithic collapse' scenario for spiral, dusty lenticular, and elliptical galaxies. It unites dwarf and ordinary `early-type' galaxies. The findings have implications for feedback from active galactic nuclei.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05013v2.title: Multiple channels for nitrogen pollution by metal enriched supermassive stars and implications for GN-z11
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05013v2.summary: GN-z11 is an unusually luminous high redshift galaxy which was recently observed to have strong nitrogen lines. These observations have beeninterpreted as a super-solar nitrogen abundance which is challenging to explain with standard stellar evolution and supernovae enrichment. We present simulations of four models of metal enriched supermassive stars after the zero progressivelyage main sequence. We then show that the most massive model ends its life with a violent explosion which results in even greater nitrogen pollution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00305v2.title: The IACOB project IX. Building a modern empirical database of Galactic O9-B9 supergiants: sample selection, description, and completeness
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00305v2.summary: Blue supergiants (BSGs) are important objects to study the intermediatephase of massive star evolution. The lack of a holistic study of a statistically significant and unbiased sample of these objects makes several long-standing questions about their nature to remain unsolved. We compile an initial set of 11,000 high-resolution spectra of 1600 Galactic late O- and B-type stars. We use a newnovel spectroscopic strategy based on a simple fitting of the Hbeta line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03171v1.title: ATOMIUM: Probing the inner wind of evolved O-rich stars with new, highly excited H$_2$O and OH lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03171v1.summary: Transitions involving energy levels that are highlyexcited have been observed in both H$_2$O and OH. These and more recently discovered transitions can now be observed at a high sensitivity and angularresolution with the ALMA Array. The 268.149 GHzemission line of water in the v#2$ = 2 state is time variable, tends to be dominant radiative pumping and is widely excited.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00613v2.title: Building an Acceleration Ladder with Tidal Streams and Pulsar Timing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00613v2.summary: We analyze stellar streams in action-angle coordinates combined with recent local direct acceleration measurements. We provide joint constraints from pulsar accelerations and stellarstreams for local and global parameters that describe the potential of the Milky Way. Of the potential models that we haveconsidered here, the preferred potential for the streams is a two- component Staeckel potential. Our analysis indicates that the limit determined from streams is consistently (regardless of the choice of potential) lower than that determined from pulsars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01112v2.title: Updated Inventory of Carbon Monoxide in The Taurus Molecular Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01112v2.summary: The most extensive survey of carbon monoxide (CO) gas in the Taurus molecular cloud relied on $^{12}$CO and $^{13)$CO emission only. This represents 1395 pixels out of $1.2 million in the mark 1 region. Compared to Pineda et al. (2010) results, we find a higher volume density of molecular hydrogen.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01793v2.title: JWST UNCOVER: Discovery of $z>9$ Galaxy Candidates Behind the Lensing Cluster Abell 2744
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01793v2.summary: We present the results of a search for high-redshift ($z>9$) galaxy candidates in the JWST UNCOVER survey. Candidates have a wide range of luminosities and young ages, with low stellar masses and low star formation rates. We also find evidence for a rapidredshift-evolution of the mass-luminosity relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03080v1.title: Large-Scale Ejecta of Z CMa -- Proper Motion Study and New Features Discovered
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03080v1.summary: Z Canis Majoris is a fascinating early-type binary with a Herbig Be primary and a FU Orionis-type secondary. Both of the stars exhibit sub-arcsecondjet-like ejecta. The primary is associated with the extended jet as well as with the large-scale outflow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03073v1.title: A giant thin stellar stream in the Coma Galaxy Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03073v1.summary: Giant Coma Stream spans 510 kpc in length and appears as a free-floating structure located at a projected distance of 0.8 Mpc from the center of Coma. Study of dynamically cold stellar streams reveals information about the region where they reside and provides important constraints on dark matter properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03074v1.title: The likelihood of the 21-cm power spectrum
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03074v1.summary: Observations of the cosmic 21-cm power spectrum (PS) are starting to enable precision Bayesian inference of galaxy properties and physical cosmology. We find that the 1D PS likelihood is well described by a Gaussian.accounting for covariances between wavemodes and redshift bins. But common approaches of estimating the.forward-modeled mean and (co)variance from a random realization or at a single.point in parameter space result in biased and over-constrained posteriors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11850v1.title: MUSE AO spectroscopy confirms five dual AGNs and two strongly lensed QSOs at sub-arcsec separation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11850v1.summary: The novel Gaia Multi Peak (GMP) technique has proven to be able to successfully select dual and lensed AGN candidates at sub-arcsec separations. Dual AGNs represent one of the central, still largely untested, predictions of lamdaCDM cosmology. Compact lensedquasars allow to probe the central regions of the lensing galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11823v1.title: Constraints on star formation in Orion A from Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11823v1.summary: We develop statistical methods within a Bayesian framework to infer the starforming history from photometric surveys of pre-main sequence populations. We apply our methods to samples of populations with Gaiaphotometry in the Orion A molecular cloud. We find that, although our sample is incomplete at the youngest ages due to extinction, star formation has proceeded in Orion A at a relatively constant rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11804v1.title: Powerful Radio-Loud Quasars are Triggered by Galaxy Mergers in the Cosmic Bright Ages
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11804v1.summary: Supermassive black holes are ubiquitous features of galactic nuclei. Only a small minority are observed during episodes of luminous accretion. The mechanism(s) driving the onset of fueling and ignition in these active galaxies are still largely unknown. We test the hypothesis that major galaxy mergers are important triggers for radio-loud AGN activity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07256v2.title: JADES NIRSpec Spectroscopy of GN-z11: Lyman-$α$ emission and possible enhanced nitrogen abundance in a $z=10.60$ luminous galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07256v2.summary: We present JADES JWST/NIRSpec spectroscopy of GN-z11, the most luminous candidate for a Lyman break galaxy in the GOODS-North field. We derive a redshift of $z=10.603$ based on multiple emission lines in our low and mediumresolution spectra over $0.8-5.3 \mu$m. Remarkably, we see a highly-spatially-extended Lyman-$\alpha$ in emission (despite the highly-neutral IGMexpected at this early epoch)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11691v1.title: EUV fine structure and variability associated with coronal rain revealed by Solar Orbiter/EUI HRIEUV and SPICE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11691v1.summary: Coronal rain is the most dramatic cooling phenomenon of the solar corona. It is an essential diagnostic tool for the coronal heating properties. EUV absorption features produced by the rain are detected at scales as small as 260 km. As the rain falls, a small EUV brightening is produced immediately downstream.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11687v1.title: A New LBV Candidate in M33
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11687v1.summary: Luminous blue variables (LBVs) are particularly rare, with only afew dozen identified in the Milky Way and nearby galaxies. M33C-4119 has recently undergone photometricand spectroscopic changes consistent with an S Doradus eruption of an LBV. Since 2012, the Barber Observatory Luminous Stars Survey has monitored more than 100 luminoustargets in M33.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11656v1.title: Rotation-tunneling spectrum and astrochemical modeling of dimethylamine, CH$_3$NHCH$_3$, and searches for it in space
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11656v1.summary: Methylamine has been the only simple alkylamine detected in the interstellarmedium for a long time. Its rotational spectrum has been known only up to 45 GHz until now. Here we investigate the rotation-tunneling-spectrum of dimethylamin in selected regions between 76 and 1091 GHz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11620v1.title: CN and CO Features: Key Indicators of Red Giant Evolutionary Phase in Moderate-Resolution X-Shooter Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11620v1.summary: Data-driven analysis methods can help to infer physical properties of red giant stars where "gold-standard" asteroseismic data are not available. This makes it possible to differentiate core-helium burning red clump stars from those that are still on their first ascent of the red giant branch.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11612v1.title: Sapaki: Galactic O3If* star possibly born in isolation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11612v1.summary: WR67a (hereafter Sapaki) is an O3If* star that appears to be isolated close to the center of a well-developed giant cavity. The existence of truly isolated stars may efficiently probe the possibility that individual massive stars can be born in isolation. The study of high-mass stars may help to probe the feasibility of the core-accretion mechanism in massive star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11606v1.title: Computational Methods for Collisional Stellar Systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11606v1.summary: Dense star clusters are spectacular self-gravitating stellar systems in our                Galaxy and across the Universe. In massiveelliptical galaxies nuclear clusters harbor supermassive black holes, which might influence the evolution of their host galaxies as a whole. The evolution of dense star clusters is governed by the aging of their stellarpopulations and simple Newtonian dynamics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11578v1.title: Temperature inhomogeneities cause the abundance discrepancy in H II regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11578v1.summary: For more than 80 years, adiscrepancy of at least a factor of two between heavy-element abundances has thrown our absolute abundance determinations into doubt. HII regions, ionized nebulae where massive star formation has taken place, exhibit a wealth of emission lines that are the fundamental basis for estimating the chemical composition of the Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09383v3.title: Peeping into recent star formation history of the Magellanic Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09383v3.summary: Study of Fundamental-mode Cepheids in the Magellanic Cloud. Age of the Cep heids are determined through well knownperiod - age relations for the LMC and SMC. This indicates that a major star formation event took place in the Cloud at about 200\,Myr ago.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02252v2.title: Optical and mid-infrared line emission in nearby Seyfert galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02252v2.summary: We aim to provide a reference joint optical and mid-IR analysis for studying AGN activity. We obtained homogenous optical spectra with the Southern Africa Large Telescope for 42 Seyfert galaxies. We find that pure AGN photoionization models are good at reproducing observations with an AGN contribution larger than 50 per cent. An additional source of ionization, either from star formation or radiative shocks, can help explain observations in the mid- IR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11477v1.title: Two-Screen Scattering in CRAFT FRBs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11477v1.summary: Scattering is an important probe of the media along the line of sight to an FRB source. Measurements of characteristic scattering times alone are insufficient to constrain the position of the dominant scattering media. We quantify the scattering and scintillation in 10 FRBs with known host galaxies and captured voltage data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11415v1.title: Black Hole Feeding and Feedback in a Compact Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11415v1.summary: A massive compact galaxy has a small effective radius but a largestellar mass. The inflow rate in the compact galaxy isseveral times larger than in the reference galaxy. This higher inflowrate results in stronger SMBH feeding and feedback and a larger fountain-likeinflow-outflow structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11409v1.title: Catalytic role of HI in the interstellar synthesis of complex organic molecule
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11409v1.summary: Using quantum chemical calculations, we model the pathways for synthesizing two purine nucleobases, adenine and guanine, in the gas-phase interstellar environment. Neutral atomic hydrogen (HI) is found active infacilitating a series of fundamental proton transfer processes of organic synthesis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11331v1.title: The role of grain size in AGN torus dust models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11331v1.summary: Fits the infrared spectra from the nuclear regions of AGN can place constraints on the dust properties, distribution, and geometry by comparison with models. None of the currently available models fully describe the observations. We find that the [GoMar23]model can adequately reproduce up to 85-88% of the spectra. This work provides tentative evidence for dust grain growth in the proximity of the AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11309v1.title: Revealing mass distributions of dwarf spheroidal galaxies in the Subaru-PFS era
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11309v1.summary: Galactic dwarf spheroidal galaxies (dSphs) provide valuable insight into dark matter properties. Overcoming this requires large kinematic samples and identification of foreground contamination. PFS plus pre-imaging with Hyper Suprime Cam will make significant progress in this undertaking.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11306v1.title: The JCMT BISTRO Survey: Studying the Complex Magnetic Field of L43
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11306v1.summary: The data were taken using SCUBA-2/POL-2 on the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope. L43 is a dense molecular cloud with a starless core and two protostellar sources. One of the protostars drives a COoutflow that has created a cavity to the southeast. We see a magnetic field aligned with the cavity walls of the outflow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11263v1.title: Extragalactic neutrino factories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11263v1.summary: IceCube is mostly sensitive to <0.1 PeV energies. We find a consistent correlation between blazars and northern neutrino data. An all-sky subset of 52 objects as highly likely PeVatron extragalacticaccelerators. This implies that the spatial correlation is highly unlikely to arise by chance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11256v1.title: Testing Jeans dynamical models with prolate rotation on a cosmologically simulated dwarf galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11256v1.summary: Prolate rotation is characterized by a significant stellar rotation around agalaxy's major axis. It contrasts with the more common oblate rotation. Studies of such galaxies are important to find their gravitational potential profile, total mass, and dark matter fraction. More tests are needed to understand why prolate rotation is time enduring in the cosmological simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11232v1.title: On the Metallicities and Kinematics of the Circumgalactic Media of Damped Ly$α$ Systems at $z \sim 2.5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11232v1.summary: We use medium- and high-resolution spectroscopy of close pairs of quasars to analyze the circumgalactic medium (CGM) surrounding 32 damped Ly$\alpha$absorption systems (DLAs) The primary quasar sightline in each pair probes an intervening DLA in the redshift range $1.6<z_\text{abs}<3.5$, such that the secondary sightline probes absorption from Ly$ \alpha$ and a large suite of metal-line transitions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11225v1.title: Quasar Luminosity Function at z = 7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11225v1.summary: We present the quasar luminosity function (LF) at $z = 7$, measured with 35spectroscopically confirmed quasars at $6.55 < z < 7.15$. The sample of 22quasars from the Subaru High-$z$ Exploration of Low-Luminosity Quasars(SHELLQs) project, combined with 13 brighter quasARS in the literature, covers an unprecedentedly wide range of rest-frame ultraviolet magnitudes. We found that the binned LF flattens significantly toward thefaint end populated by the SHELLZs quas

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11223v1.title: Accurate Systemic Redshifts and Outflow Speeds for Extremely Red Quasars (ERQs)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11223v1.summary: Extremely Red Quasars (ERQs) are thought to represent a brief episode of young quasar evolution. ERQs have a higher incidence of large CIV blueshifts, accompanied by large Rest Equivalent Widths (REWs) and smaller line widths than bluequasars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11222v1.title: $clustertools$: A Python Package for Analyzing Star Cluster Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11222v1.summary: $clustertools$ is a Python package for analyzing star cluster simulations. The package is built around the $StarCluster$ class. While originally designed with star clusters in mind, it can be used to study other types of $N$-body systems, including stellar streams and dark matter sub-halos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11218v1.title: Fitting Probability Distribution Functions in Turbulent Star-Forming Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11218v1.summary: We use a suite of 3D simulations of star-forming molecular clouds to investigate the effectiveness of different fitting methods for volume and column density probability distributions. The first method fits a piecewise lognormal and power-law function to recover PDF parameters such as the PL slope and transition density. We demonstrate that fitting a polynomial spline allows us to directly determine if the data has multiple PL slopes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11219v1.title: MUSE-ALMA Halos XI: Gas flows in the circumgalactic medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11219v1.summary: The flow of gas into and out of galaxies leaves traces in the circumgalacticmedium which can then be studied using absorption lines towards backgroundquasars. We analyse 27 log(N_HI) > 18.0 HI absorbers at z = 0.2 to 1.4 from the MUSE-ALMA Halos survey with at least one galaxy counterpart.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11214v1.title: Azimuthal Anisotropy of Magnetic Fields in the Circumgalactic Medium Driven by Galactic Feedback Processes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11214v1.summary: magnetic fields in the circumgalactic medium have significant angular structure. This azimuthal anisotropy at fixed distance is driven by galactic feedback processes that launch strong outflows into the halo. At the virial radius, $z=0$ galaxies with M$_\star show the strongest an isotropy ($\sim 0.35$ dex)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.03855v2.title: Galactic bar resonances with diffusion: an analytic model with implications for bar-dark matter halo dynamical friction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.03855v2.summary: The secular evolution of disk galaxies is largely driven by resonances between the orbits of 'particles' (stars or dark matter) and the rotation of non-axisymmetric features (spiral arms or a bar) Such resonances may alsoexplain kinematic and photometric features observed in the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10980v1.title: Equilibrium dynamical models for the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10980v1.summary: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) has a complex dynamics driven by bothinternal and external processes. Here we attempt to model the proper motions of stars in the LMC as measured by Gaia Data Release 3 with an axisymmetric dynamical model. We find that this simple model is very successful at selecting a clean sample of genuine LMC member stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01909v2.title: The contribution of binary star formation via core-fragmentation on protostellar multiplicity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01909v2.summary: The origin of young multiple star systems has often been attributed to binary formation via core and disc fragmentation. Theory and simulations suggest that young stellar systems that form via core fragmentation undergo significant orbital evolution. The results indicate that a significant number of low-mass close-mass binaries with separations from 20-100AU can be produced via core fragmented or dynamical capture.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16261v2.title: EIGER III. JWST/NIRCam observations of the ultra-luminous high-redshift quasar J0100+2802
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16261v2.summary: We present the first rest-frame optical spectrum of a high-redshift quasar. The observedquasar, J0100+2802, is the most luminous quasar known at $z>6. We measure themass of the central supermassive black hole (SMBH)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10944v1.title: A Multi-Wavelength Investigation of Dust and Stellar Mass Distributions in Galaxies: Insights from High-Resolution JWST Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10944v1.summary: We study the morphological properties of mid-infrared selected galaxies in the SMACS J0723.3-7327 cluster field. We develop a new algorithm to decompose the dust and stellar components ofindividual galaxies. Our pilot study highlights that MIRI offers anefficient approach to studying the structural formation of galaxies from cosmicnoon to the modern universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11193v1.title: Implementation of Rare Isotopologues into Machine Learning of the Chemical Inventory of the Solar-Type Protostellar Source IRAS 16293-2422
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11193v1.summary: Machine learning techniques have been previously used to model and predict column densities in the TMC-1 dark molecular cloud. In interstellar sources, such as those where a protostar has been formed, the chemistry is known to be drastically different from that of largely quiescent dark clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10932v1.title: What boost galaxy mergers in two massive galaxy protoclusters at z = 2.24
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10932v1.summary: Characterizing the structural properties of galaxies in high-redshiftprotoclusters is key to our understanding of the environmental effects on galaxy evolution in the early stages of galaxy and structure formation. In this study, we assess the structural. properties of 85 and 87 Halpha emission-linecandidates (HAEs) in the densest regions of two massive. protoclusters, BOSS1244 and BOSS1542.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03875v2.title: The C-Band All-Sky Survey (C-BASS): New Constraints on the Integrated Radio Spectrum of M 31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03875v2.summary: The Andromeda galaxy (M31) is our closest neighbouring spiral galaxy, making it an ideal target for studying the physics of the interstellar medium. Using new observations of M31 at 4.76GHz by the C-Band All-Sky Survey (C-BASS), we produce the integrated spectrum and put new constraints on the synchrotron spectral index and anomalous microwave emission from M31.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10860v1.title: Dissecting the RELICS cluster SPT-CLJ0615-5746 through the intracluster light: confirmation of the multiple merging state of the cluster formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10860v1.summary: The intracluster light (ICL) fraction has been shown to provide a good marker for determining theynamical stage of galaxy clusters. We apply it for the first time to a high-redshift system, SPT-CLJ0615-5746 at z=0.97. A carefulre-analysis of the X-ray data available for this cluster points to the presence of at least one current merger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10795v1.title: HI Self-absorption toward the Cygnus X North: From Atomic Filament to Molecular Filament
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10795v1.summary: Using the HI self-absorption data from the Five-hundred-meter Aperture purposefullySpherical radio Telescope (FAST), we perform a study of the cold atomic gas in the Cygnus-X North region. The most remarkable HI cloud is characterized by a remarkable structure associated in space and in velocity with the principle                molecular filament in the region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10745v1.title: The first X-ray look at SMSS J114447.77-430859.3: the most luminous quasar in the last 9 Gyr
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10745v1.summary: The SMSS quasar has been identified in the SkyMapperSouthern Survey as the most luminous quasar in the last $\sim 9\,\rm Gyr. The broadband SED is successfully modelled by assuming either a standard accretion disc illuminated by a central X-ray source, or a thin disc with a slim disc emissivity profile.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10717v1.title: The Pristine Inner Galaxy Survey (PIGS) VII: a discovery of the first inner Galaxy CEMP-r/s star
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10717v1.summary: Pristine_184237.56-260624.5 (hereafter Pr184237) has an apocentre of about 2 kpc. It is the first star of the CEMP-r/s subclass identified in the inner Galaxy. The element abundancepattern in the Na-Zn range is typical of halo stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12518v2.title: Parallel and Perpendicular Alignments of Velocity Gradient and Magnetic Field observed in the Molecular Clouds L1478 and L1482
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12518v2.summary: Star formation is regulated by magnetic fields, magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence, and self-gravity.
