Based on the anisotropic properties of MHD turbulence, a technique termed Velocity Gradient Technique (VGT) has been proposed to address these challenges. VGT was applied to two regions of the California Molecular Cloud (CMC), namely, L1478 and L1482.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10677v1.title: The effect of environment on the properties of the most massive galaxies at $0.5<z<2.5$ in the cosmos-dash field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10677v1.summary: How the environment influences the most massive galaxies is still unclear. We select galaxies with stellar mass at $0.5<z<2.5$ in the COSMOS-DASH field. No significantenvironmental dependence is found in the distributions of S\'{e}rsic index andeffective radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10576v1.title: Multifrequency analysis of the radio emission from a post-merger galaxy CGCG 292-057
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10576v1.summary: Galaxies exhibiting a specific large-scale extended radio emission, such as X-shaped radio galaxies, belong to a rare class of winged radio galaxies. Themorphological evolution of these radio sources is explained using several theoretical models, including galaxy mergers. However, such a direct link between a perturbed radio morphology and a galaxy merger remainsobservationally sparse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10516v1.title: Searching for Intragroup Light in Deep U-band Imaging of the COSMOS Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10516v1.summary: We present the results of deep, ground based U-band imaging with the Large                Binocular Telescope of the Cosmic Evolution Survey (COSMOS) field. We utilize a seeing sorted stacking method along with night-to-night relative transparency corrections to create optimal depth and optimal resolution mosaics. These ground-based mosaics bridge the wavelength gap between the HST WFC3 F27W and ACS F435W images and are necessary to understand galaxy assembly in the last 9-10 Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01005v2.title: Self-similar growth of Bose stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01005v2.summary: The bath is described by a self-similar solution of the kineticequation, which is an attractor. Together with the conservation laws, thisfixes mass evolution of the Bose star. Our results explain slowdown of the stargrowth at a certain "core-halo" mass, but also predict formation of the heavier and lighter objects in magistral dark matter models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10428v1.title: Field-level Lyman-alpha forest modelling in redshift space via augmented non-local Fluctuating Gunn-Peterson Approximation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10428v1.summary: We present an improved analytical model to predict the Lyman-alpha forest at the field level in redshift space from the dark matter field. We introduce the dependence on the cosmic web environment (knots, filaments,sheets, voids) in the model thereby effectively accounting for non-local bias. We find evidence for a significant difference of the same modelparameters in different environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15639v2.title: The nature of an ultra-faint galaxy in the cosmic Dark Ages seen with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15639v2.summary: In the first billion years after the Big Bang, sources of ultraviolet (UV)photons are believed to have ionized intergalactic hydrogen. Fainter galaxies are thought to dominate the photon budget; however they are surrounded by neutral gas that prevents the escape of the photons. The combination of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) and gravitational lensing shows that this ultra-faint galaxy has a compact and complex morphology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10812v2.title: Identifying LISA verification binaries among the Galactic population of double white dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10812v2.summary: Double white dwarfs (DWDs) will be the most numerous gravitational-wave (GW) sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) Uniquely among GW sources, a handful of these binaries will be known in advance from electromagnetic (EM)observations and will be guaranteed sources of detectable GWs in the LISA band. These are known as verification binaries (VBs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10337v1.title: Unstable cosmic-ray nuclei constrain low-diffusion zones in the Galactic disk
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10337v1.summary: The impact of low-diffusion zones on the global properties of cosmic-ray transport is only poorly understood. The impact of regions of suppressed diffusion might be larger than usually assumed and ought to be taken into account in models of Galactic cosmic ray transport. With upcoming data from the HELIX balloon experiment, the impact could increase to $6.8 \sigma$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10269v1.title: Survey for Distant Stellar Aggregates in Galactic Disk: Detecting Two Thousand Star Clusters and Candidates, along with the Dwarf Galaxy IC10
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10269v1.summary: Distant star clusters are rarely identified, due to the challenges posed by heavy extinctionand great distance. Gaia data has continued to improve, enabling even                fainter cluster members to be distinguished from field stars. After removing member stars of known Gaia-based star clusters, we have identified 2086 objects with |b|<10 deg.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00010v2.title: Satellites of Milky Way- and M31-like galaxies with TNG50: quenched fractions, gas content, and star formation histories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.00010v2.summary: We analyse the quenched fractions, gas content, and star formation histories of ~1200 satellite galaxies in TNG50. These satellites are around 198 Milky Way- (MW) and Andromeda-like (M31) hosts. Ram pressure stripping (in combination with tidal stripping)deprives them of their gas reservoirs and ultimately quenches their star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10242v1.title: Bounding the mass of ultralight bosonic Dark Matter particles with the motion of the S2 star around Sgr A*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10242v1.summary: Dark matter is undoubtedly one of the fundamental, albeit unknown, components of the standard cosmological model. The failure to detect WIMPs, the most promising candidate particle for cold dark matter, actually opens the way for the exploration of viable alternatives. Ultralight bosonic particles with masses of $10-21$ eV represent one the most encouraging.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10240v1.title: Spectral Stacking of Radio-Interferometric Data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10240v1.summary: Mapping molecular line emission beyond the bright low-J CO transitions is still challenging in extragalactic studies. We summarise and test aspectral stacking method that has been used in the literature. The goal is to study the capabilities andlimitations of the stacking technique when applied to imaged interferometricobservations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10232v1.title: Panchromatic simulated galaxy observations from the NIHAO project
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10232v1.summary: We present simulated galaxy spectral energy distributions (SEDs) from the far ultraviolet through the far infrared, created using hydrodynamic simulations and radiative transfer calculations. SED modeling is an essential tool for inferring starformation histories from nearby galaxy observations. We explore different sub-grid post-processing recipes, using color distributions and their dependence on axis ratio of galaxies in the nearby universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12858v2.title: The impact of AGN-driven winds on physical and observable galaxy sizes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12858v2.summary: Without AGN feedback, simulated massive, star-forming galaxies become too compact relative to observed galaxies at z<2.3. We experiment with driving mechanical AGNwinds, using a state-of-the-art hyper-Lagrangian refinement technique. These winds reduce the gas surface density in theinner regions of the galaxy, suppressing the compact starburst.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10175v1.title: The Tiered Radio Extragalactic Continuum (T-RECS) simulation II: HI emission and continuum-HI cross-correlation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10175v1.summary: In this paper we extend the Tiered Radio Extragalactic Continuum Simulation to include HI emission. The HI T-RECS model is based on the most                recent HI mass function estimates. We deliver a set of mock catalogues, as well as the code to produce them.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12861v3.title: CLEAN imaging systematics of M87 radio jet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12861v3.summary: Spectral index images of the jet in the nearby radio galaxy M87 have previously been shown with Very Long Baseline Interferometric arrays at 2-43GHz. They exhibit flattening of the spectra at a location of inner (central) and outer ridges. This could imply optical depth effects or lower energy cutoff.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10099v1.title: A deep study of open cluster NGC 5288 using photometric and astrometric data from Gaia DR3 and 2MASS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10099v1.summary: This paper investigates a poorly studied open cluster, NGC 5288. Themean proper motions in Right Ascension and Declination are estimated as (-3.840+/- 0.230) and (-1.934 +/- 0.162) mas/yr, respectively. We also derive the age and distance of the cluster as 510 +/- 190 Myr and 2.64 + 0.11 kpc, using colour-magnitude diagrams.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02750v3.title: A detection of the layered structure of nearby open clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02750v3.summary: We applied the newly developed rose diagram overlay method to detect the layered structure of 88 nearby open clusters. A total of 74 clusters in our sample have a layered structure, while the remaining clusters are without a clear layered structure. We found that the layered circle core area ($s$) has a strongpositive correlation with the number of cluster members.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10047v1.title: Simulating the diversity of shapes of the Lyman-$α$ line
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10047v1.summary: The Ly$\alpha$ line is a powerful probe of distant galaxies. It contains information about inflowing/outflowing gas through which photons spew. To develop our understanding of this probe, we post-process a zoom-in simulations of a low-mass ($M_* \sim 10^9 M_\odot$) galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10001v1.title: Investigating kinematics and dynamics of three open clusters towards Galactic anti-center
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10001v1.summary: We present the intra-cluster kinematics and dynamics of three open clusters:NGC 1193, NGC 2355, and King 12. The mass function slopes for all three clusters differ from the solar neighbourhood reported by Salpeter. Stars in King 12 are moving outwards due to tidal forces from the Galactic disc, which we confirmed by plotting the cluster's orbit in the Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09540v4.title: Aligning Retrograde Nuclear Cluster Orbits with an Active Galactic Nucleus Accretion Disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09540v4.summary: Stars and stellar remnants orbiting a supermassive black hole (SMBH) can interactions with an active galactic nucleus (AGN) disc. Captured stars can be tidally disrupted by sBH or rapidly grow into massive 'immortal' stars. We show that retrograde stars are captured faster than prograde stars, flip to prograde orientation during capture, and decrease $a$ dramatically towards the SMBH.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11298v2.title: Near-infrared characterization of ultra-diffuse galaxies in Abell 2744 by JWST/NIRISS imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11298v2.summary: We present a search and characterization of ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) in the Frontier Fields cluster Abell~2744 at $z=0.308$. We use JWST/NIRISS F200Wobservations, acquired as part of the GLASS-JWST Early Release Science Program. A total number of 22 UDGs are identified by our selection criteria using morphological parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09969v1.title: Role of magnetic pressure forces in Fluctuation dynamo saturation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09969v1.summary: Magnetic pressure forces play a crucial role in dynamo saturation in turbulent flows. In supersonic flows density and magnetic field strength continue to maintain a positive correlation. However, the degree of positive correlation decreases as the dynamo saturates. We consider the work done against the components of the Lorentz force and the different sources of magnetic energy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09959v1.title: Warm Molecular Gas in the Central Parsecs of the Buried Nucleus of NGC 4418 Traced with the Fundamental CO Ro-vibrational Absorptions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09959v1.summary: We investigated the inner buried nucleus of a nearby luminous infrared galaxy using high-resolution spectroscopy. We detected a series of both very deep (partly) and moderately deep (optically thin) carbon monoxide absorption lines. The width of the absorption lines are consistent with a warm and turbulentlayer with little bulk motion in the radial direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09949v1.title: Magnetic Fields and Fragmentation of Filaments in the Hub of California-X
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09949v1.summary: We show that the X-shaped nebula in the California molecular cloud includes two elongated filamentary structures. We measured the mass per unit length of the filament and found that Fil1 and Fil2 are thermally super- and subcritical. We calculated the gravitational, kinematic, and magnetic energies of the filaments. We propose that a dominant magnetic energy may lead the filament to be fragmented into aligned cores.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09919v1.title: Sustained super-Eddington accretion around neutron stars & black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09919v1.summary: Sustained and unimpeded super-Eddington (SE) accretion could be achieved in optically thick slim accretion disks around neutron stars (NSs) and black holes (BHs) We calculate a condition such that sustained SE accretion might be possible in slim disks around BHs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10263v3.title: First emergence of cold accretion and supermassive star formation in the early universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10263v3.summary: We study the structure of the accretionflow and its evolution within small halos with sufficiently high spatial resolutions. The accretion flow eventually hits a compact disc near the halo centre, creating dense shocks over a wide area of the disc surface. The resulting post-shock gas becomes dense and hot enough with its mass comparable to theJeans mass, leading to the gravitational collapse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03555v3.title: Inverse MultiView II: Microarcsecond Trigonometric Parallaxes for Southern Hemisphere 6.7~GHz Methanol Masers G232.62+00.99 and G323.74$-$00.26
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03555v3.summary: We present the first results from the Southern Hemisphere ParallaxInterferometric Radio Astrometry Legacy Survey. Using an array of radio telescopes in Australia and New Zealand, we measured the trigonometricparalleparallax and proper motions for the masers associated with the star formation region G232.62+00.99 and G323.74--00.26. These measurementsrepresent an improvement in accuracy by more than a factor of 3 over the previous measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09829v1.title: The Diffuse Ionized Gas of the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09829v1.summary: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) has an extended, warm ionized component of its interstellar medium. We find that ionized hydrogen exists throughout the galaxy and extends several degrees beyond detected neutral hydrogen. This study continues to suggest that warm, ionized gas is as massive and dynamically-important as the neutral gas in the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09822v1.title: The flattening of dark matter halo of Centaurus A galaxy (NGC 5128) out to 40 kpc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09822v1.summary: Cosmological simulations predict dark matter shapes that deviate from spherical symmetry. The exact shape depends on the prescription of the simulations and the interplay between dark matter and baryons. This signature is most pronounced in the diffuse galactic haloes that can be observationallyprobed with planetary nebulae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10420v2.title: Surveying Nearby Brown Dwarfs with HGCA: Direct Imaging Discovery of a Faint, High-Mass Brown Dwarf Orbiting HD 176535 A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10420v2.summary: Brown dwarfs with well-measured masses, ages and luminosities provide direct benchmark tests of substellar formation and evolutionary models. HD 176535 B is a new benchmark dwarf useful for constraining evolutionary and atmospheric models of high-mass brown dwarfs. Given its angular separation and luminosity,HD 1765 35 B would make a promising candidate for Aperture Masking and Interferometry.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01825v2.title: Cosmic Radioactivity and Galactic Chemical Evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01825v2.summary: 'Modelling galactic chemical evolution' uses knowledge about sources of nucleosynthesis and how they change the interstellar gas. Tracing ejecta from sources, with their different frequencies and environments, through the interstellar medium and successive star formationcycles is the goal of model descriptions. Radioactive isotopes add important ingredients to such modelling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09723v1.title: GlobULeS-V. UVIT/AstroSat studies of stellar populations in NGC 362: Detection of Blue Lurkers in a Globular Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09723v1.summary: Four blue lurkers with low and extremely low-mass white dwarf companions in the Galactic globular cluster NGC 362. The position of blue lurker within the cluster shows that they originated via the Case A/B mass-transfer mechanism in a low-density environment. The companion cooling age is less than 4 Myr, which suggests they were just recently formed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09721v1.title: The signature of galaxy formation models in the power spectrum of the hydrogen 21cm line during reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09721v1.summary: Observations of the 21cm line of neutral hydrogen are poised to revolutionize knowledge of cosmic reionization and the high-redshift population of galaxies. harnessing such information requires robust and comprehensive theoretical modeling. We study the non-linear effects of astrophysics and astrophysical feedback processes, including stellar and AGN feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09714v1.title: An empirical study of dust properties at the earliest epochs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09714v1.summary: We present an empirical analysis of the properties of dust-continuum emission in a sample of 17 galaxies in the early Universe. With the exception of two sources, we find no significant evolution in the dust emissivity index across cosmic time. We find the dust temperature evolves mildly towards high redshift, though the LIRGs and quasars exhibit elevated temperatures indicating a more efficient and/or additionalheating mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09717v1.title: Alive and kicking: A new QPE phase in GSN 069 revealing a quiescent luminosity threshold for QPEs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09717v1.summary: X-ray quasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs) are intense repeating soft X-ray bursts from nearby galaxies. Their physical origin is still largely unconstrained, and several theoretical models have been proposed to date. We present results from a recent XMM-Newton observation of GSN 069, the Galactic nucleus where QPEs were first discovered.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09709v1.title: "Dust Giant": Extended and Clumpy Star-Formation in a Massive Dusty Galaxy at $z=1.38$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09709v1.summary: We present NOEMA CO (2-1) line and ALMA 870 $\mu$m continuum observations of a main-sequence galaxy at $z=1.38$. The galaxy was initially selected as a "gas-giant" based on the gas mass derived from sub-mm continuum. However the gasMass derived from CO (1) is consistent with typical star-forming galaxies at that redshift. Despite that the dust-to-stellar mass ratio remains elevated above the scaling relations by a factor of 5.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09710v1.title: SP(k) -- A hydrodynamical simulation-based model for the impact of baryon physics on the non-linear matter power spectrum
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09710v1.summary: Upcoming large-scale structure surveys will measure the matter power spectrum to approximately percent level accuracy with the aim of searching for evidence for new physics. We present a model for the effects of baryon physics on the non-linearmatter power spectrum based on a new large suite of hydrodynamical simulations. Most of the effects are driven by galaxy group-mass haloes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09637v1.title: Consistent clustering and lensing of SDSS-III BOSS galaxies with an extended abundance matching formalism
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09637v1.summary: An extension of Subhalo Abundance Matching, dubbed SHAMe, successfully solves the 'lensing-is-low problem' We show that this model accuratelyreproduces the GC and GGL of a mock galaxy sample in the TNG300 hydrodynamic simulations with analogous properties to BOSS galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09629v1.title: The Three Hundred Project: the evolution of physical baryon profiles
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09629v1.summary: The distribution of baryons provides a significant way to understand theformation of galaxy clusters by revealing the details of its internal structure. We present theoretical studies on the profiles of physical properties associated with the baryonic components. These include gas density, temperature, metallicity, pressure and entropy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00180v2.title: Star Formation and Molecular Gas Diagnostics with Mid- and Far-Infrared Emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00180v2.summary: Mid-infrared (MIR) emission features from polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), H$_2$ rotational lines, and fine-structure lines from ions will be widely available at JWST. MIR spectral features from 5 to 35$\mu$m correlate with SFR traced by ionized neon.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09607v1.title: Constraining the cosmic-ray pressure in the inner Virgo Cluster using H.E.S.S. observations of M 87
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09607v1.summary: The origin of the gamma-ray emission from M87 is currently a matter of debate. This work aims to localize the VHE (100 GeV-100 TeV) gamma- ray emission. It can constrain the cosmic-ray energy density and the pressure exerted by the cosmic rays onto the intra-cluster medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09491v1.title: Fullerenes in the circumstellar medium of Herbig Ae/Be stars: Insights from the Spitzer mid-infrared spectral catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09491v1.summary: This study presents the largest mid-infrared spectral catalog of Herbig Ae/Bestars to date. Based on the catalog analysis, two prominent infrared vibrational modes at 17.4 and 18.9 are detected in the spectra of nine sources. In the case of three Her big Ae/ be stars we report the tentative evidence of C\textsubscript{60} emission features originating from thecircumstellar disk or nearby diffused emission region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09414v1.title: New Near-Infrared Period-Luminosity-Metallicity Relations for Galactic RR Lyrae Stars Based on Gaia EDR3 Parallaxes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09414v1.summary: We present new period-luminosity and period- luminosity-metallicity relations for Galactic RR Lyrae stars based on a sample of 28 pulsators located at distances up to $1.5$ kpc from the Sun. We find that the dependence of absolute magnitudes on metallicity of $0.070\pm 0.042$ mag/dex ($J-$ band) ($J- band) is in agreement with previously published works.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04510v2.title: Radiation pressure acting on the neutral He atoms in the Heliosphere
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04510v2.summary: The Interstellar Neutral Helium (ISN He) is an important source of information on the physical state of the Local Interstellar Medium. Radiation pressure acting on typical helium causes flux differences at a level of 1-4% and is comparable to the observational errors. For the more sensitive IMAP-Lo instrument, there are some regions in the considered observations where radiation pressure causes potentially statistically significant changes in the calculated fluxes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09392v1.title: Strömgren photometric metallicity of the Small Magellanic Cloud stars using Gaia DR3-XP spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09392v1.summary: Spectroscopic metallicities exist only for a few thousand sources, mostly giant stars located in specific regions of the galaxies. We aim to determine the metallicities of these sources based on synthetic Str\"{o}mgren photometry derived from XP spectra and produce a high-resolution metallicity map of the SMC.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09365v1.title: X-ray polarization observations of IC 4329A with IXPE: Constraining the geometry of the X-ray corona
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09365v1.summary: X-ray polarimetry is a powerful tool to probe the geometry of the hot X-ray corona in active galactic nuclei (AGN) Here, we present our results on the characterisation of the polarization of the radio-quiet Seyfert-type AGNIC 4329A at a redshift of $z$ = 0.016.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09362v1.title: Probing $z \gtrsim 6$ massive black holes with gravitational waves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09362v1.summary: We investigate the coalescence of massive black hole binaries (MBHBs) at $6<z<10$ by adopting a suite of hydrodynamical simulations of galaxy formation. We find that 83 per cent of MBHBs will seamlesslymerge within the Hubble time, and 21 per cent within 1 Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09428v2.title: CONGRuENTS (COsmic-ray, Neutrino, Gamma-ray and Radio Non-Thermal Spectra). I. A predictive model for galactic non-thermal emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09428v2.summary: The total luminosity and spectral shape of the non-thermal emission produced by cosmic rays depends on their interstellar environment. Understanding the physical mechanisms of cosmic ray transport, loss, and emission is key to understanding these correlations. In the first paper of the series, we present a new method to compute theNon-Thermal spectra of star-forming galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00770v2.title: Another X-ray UFO without a momentum-boosted molecular outflow. ALMA CO(1-0) observations of the galaxy pair IRAS 05054+1718
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00770v2.summary: Alma CO(1-0) observations of the nearby LIRG galaxy pair. The western component of the pair, NED01, hosts a Seyfert 1.9 nucleus launching a powerful X-ray UFO. Our analysis suggests the UFO could be variable or multi- component.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09456v4.title: A measure of cosmological distance using the \civ\ Baldwin effect in quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09456v4.summary: We obtain a sample of 523 Type Iquasars with the UV/optical spectra and EW (C\,\textsc{iv) measurements in the                redshift range of $2.3< z< 7.1$ including 38 objects at $5 < z < 7. 1$ We use the anticorrelation between the equivalent width (EW) of the. 1549 {\AA} emission line and the continuum luminosity in the. quasars rest frame (Baldwin effect) to measure their luminosity distance. The data suggest that the EW of C\

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09344v1.title: Dynamical modelling of ATLAS$^{\rm 3D}$ galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09344v1.summary: Triaxial dynamical models of massive galaxies observed in the ATLAS3D project can provide new insights into the complex evolutionary processes that shape galaxies. Triaxial modelling is essential for these galaxies to understand their complex kinematical features. The modelsallow us to constrain the intrinsic shape of the stellar component, the distribution of visible and invisible matter and the orbit distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09343v1.title: A twisted and precessing Cepheid warp in the outer Milky Way disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09343v1.summary: We examine the Galactic warp in a sample of all classical Cepheids with GaiaDR3 radial velocity. We find no warping inside $R\approx 11$ kpc; for larger $R$ the disc is increasingly inclined. This suggests a leading spiral of nodes, the general behaviour of warped galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09294v1.title: S-type stars from LAMOST DR10: classification of intrinsic and extrinsic stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09294v1.summary: The main purpose of this work is to study how to divide S-type stars into intrinsic and extrinsic stars with photometric data and LAMOST spectra. Using XGBoost algorithm and color-color diagrams, we found four spectral regions of Zr I (6451.6A), Ne II (6539.6a), H{\alpha} (6564.5A), and Fe I (6611.4A) are the most important features.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09370v3.title: Testing Super-Eddington Accretion onto a Supermassive Black Hole: Reverberation Mapping of PG 1119+120
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09370v3.summary: We measure the black hole mass and investigate the accretion flow around the local quasar PG 1119+120. We find the disc SED to be flatter than expected with an Eddington ratio of 1. While this accretion is super-Eddington, the geometry is still unclear, however a slimophobicdisc is expected due to the high radiation pressure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09215v1.title: A Geometric Calibration of the Tip of the Red Giant Branch in the Milky Way using Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09215v1.summary: We use the latest parallaxes measurements from Gaia DR3 to obtain a geometricCalibration of the tip of the red giant branch (TRGB) in Cousins $I$ magnitudes. Our sample contains Milky Way halo stars at high galactic latitudes ($|b| > 36$) where impact of metallicity, dust, and crowding are minimised.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09881v2.title: The Launching of Cold Clouds by Galaxy Outflows V: The Role of Anisotropic Thermal Conduction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09881v2.summary: We explore the impact of isotropic and anisotropic electron thermal conduction on the evolution of radiatively-cooled, cold clouds embedded in hot, magnetized winds. We conduct simulations of clouds impacted by supersonic and transonic flows with magnetic fields aligned parallel and perpendicular to the flow direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09191v1.title: Ionized gas metallicity of the strong [OIII]λ emission-line compact galaxies in the LAMOST survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09191v1.summary: This article reports a sample of 1830 strong [O III] {\lambda]5007emission-line compact galaxies discovered with the LAMOST spectroscopic survey and the photometric catalog of SDSS. We newly identify 402 spectra of 346 strong galaxies by finding compactisolated point sources. Eight sources with asymmetric emission-line profiles have been identified but with no detection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13270v2.title: Satellite Content and Halo Mass of Galaxy Clusters: Comparison between Red-Sequence and Halo-based Optical Cluster Finders
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13270v2.summary: Cluster cosmology depends critically on how optical clusters are selected from imaging surveys. We compare the conditional luminosity function (CLF) and weak lensing halo masses between two different cluster samples. The red-sequence clusters have a flat distribution of red galaxies at the faint end. The halo-based clusters host a decreasing faint red and a boosted blue population at the bright end.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.11413v2.title: Chemical Evolution with Radial Mixing Redux: Extending beyond the Solar Neighborhood
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.11413v2.summary: We present a multi-zone galactic chemical evolution (GCE) model for the Milky Way that takes the most recently updated yields of major nucleosynthesis channels into account. It incorporates physical processes commonly found in previous GCE models like supernova and star formation feedback, the radial flow of gas in the disk, and the infall of fresh gas. We individually analyse the effect of different physical processes present in our model on the observed properties of the Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09138v1.title: Characterising abundance-age relations of GALAH stars using oxygen-enhanced stellar models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09138v1.summary: Main Sequence Turn-off stars (MSTO) and subgiant stars are good tracers of Galactic populations. We present a study of 41,034 MSTO and sub-giant Stars from the GALAH survey. Using a grid of stellar models, we determine their ages with a median age uncertainty of $9.4%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09121v1.title: A Conditional Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model for Radio Interferometric Image Reconstruction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09121v1.summary: In radio astronomy, signals from radio telescopes are transformed into images of observed celestial objects, or sources. These images contain real sources as well as artifacts due to signal sparsity and other factors. VIC-DDPM is a Visibility and Conditioned Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model. It uses visibility data to separate signals from noise and retaining spatialinformation in dirty images.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16455v2.title: Parametrized Asymmetric Neutral hydrogen Disk Integrated Spectrum Characterization (PANDISC) I: Introduction to A Physically Motivated H I Model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16455v2.summary: Modelling the integrated H I spectra of galaxies has been a difficult task due to their diverse shapes. Based on simple assumptions, we construct aphysically motivated model for the integrated Hi spectra. The model shows great flexibility in reproducing the diverse Hiprofiles. Further application on the whole ALFALFA sample will enable us to perform large scale ensemble studies of the H I properties andynamics in nearby galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09021v1.title: Fraction of Clumpy Star-Forming Galaxies at $0.5\leq z\leq 3$ in UVCANDELS: Dependence on Stellar Mass and Environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09021v1.summary: High-resolution imaging of galaxies in rest-frame UV has revealed theexistence of giant star-forming clumps prevalent in high redshift galaxies. Clumpy galaxies are defined as those having at least one off-center clump that contributes a minimum of 10$\%$ of the galaxy's total rest- frame UVlux.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.12275v3.title: A New Discrete Dynamical Friction Estimator Based on $N$-body Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.12275v3.summary: A longstanding problem in galactic simulations is to resolve the dynamical friction (DF) force acting on massive black hole particles. Many sub-grid models based on the traditional Chandrasekhar DF formula have been proposed. They suffer from fundamental ambiguities in the definition of some terms in ChandraseKhar's formula when applied to real galaxies. In this work we present a new sub- grid dynamicalriction estimator based on a discrete nature of $N$-body simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v4.title: An analysis of the turbulence in the central region of M 42 (Orion Nebula) II: homogeneity and power-spectrum analyses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v4.summary: In this second communication we continue our analysis of the turbulence in the Huygens Region of the Orion Nebula. We find that the higher-ordertransverse structure functions are almost proportional to the second-order transverse structure function. This implies that there is some type of invariant statistical structure in the velocity field. We also obtain and analyse the power-spectrum of the turbulent field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2101.08069v3.title: The Tully-Fisher relation in dense groups at $z \sim 0.7$ in the MAGIC survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2101.08069v3.summary: The aim of our project is to get new insights about the role of environment on the stellar and baryonic content of galaxies. We study a sample of 67 galaxies in 8 groups spanning a redshift range of $0.5<z<0.8$ We show that this evolution is consistent with a decrease of star formation or with araction of the mass distribution due to the environment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.08443v2.title: A Stream Come True -- Connecting tidal tails, shells, streams, and planes with galaxy kinematics and formation history
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.08443v2.summary: Tidal tails, shells, streams, and satelliteplanes are found in galaxies. Their existence is linked to the amount of rotational support and theformation histories of the host galaxies. Shells are preferentially found around kinematically slowly rotating galaxies, while streams only have a slight preference to be present around slowly rotate galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08921v1.title: SILVERRUSH. XIII. A Catalog of 20,567 Ly$α$ Emitters at $z=2-7$ Identified in the Full-Depth Data of the Subaru/HSC-SSP and CHORUS Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08921v1.summary: 20,567 Ly$\alpha$ emitters (LAEs) at $z=2.2-7.3$ that arephotometrically identified by the SILVERRUSH program in a large survey area up to 25 deg$^2. We select secure $>5\sigma$ sources showing narrowband color excessesvia Ly$ \alpha$ break screening.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08905v1.title: Wind-Reprocessed Transients from Stellar-mass Black Hole Tidal Disruption Events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08905v1.summary: Tidal disruptions of stars by stellar-mass black holes are expected to occur frequently in dense star clusters. We explore theformation and long-term evolution of the thick, super-Eddington accretion disks. We predict all-sky surveys such as the Vera RubinObservatory and ULTRASAT will detect up to thousands of these events per year.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08894v1.title: First Impressions: Early-Time Classification of Supernovae using Host Galaxy Information and Shallow Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08894v1.summary: A neural network with a single recurrent layer is designed explicitly for earlyphotometric classification of supernovae. The method achieves an overall accuracy of $82 \pm 2$% within 3 days of an event's discovery, and $87 \pm 5$% after 30 days of discovery.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08847v1.title: Probing bursty star formation by cross-correlating extragalactic background light and galaxy surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08847v1.summary: The star formation rate (SFR) variability is important for developing and testing theory of galaxy formation. We investigate how statistical measurements of theExtragalactic background light (EBL) can shed light on this topic. We show that the SFR variability can be characterized as a function of galaxy mass and redshift through the cross-correlation between the EBL and galaxy distributions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.00458v2.title: Jammed Keplerian gas leads to the formation and disappearance of spiral arms in a coupled map lattice for astronomical objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.00458v2.summary: The formation and disappearance of spiral arms are studied by focusing on Keplerian gas in a coupled map lattice (CML) The CML shows that a spiral arm is a type of traffic jam, and its motion is governed by both a gas inflow into and outflow from the jam.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08788v1.title: Examining transitional galaxies to understand the role of clusters and their dynamical status in galaxy quenching
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08788v1.summary: In this work, we consider four different galaxy populations and two distinct global environments in the local Universe. We also investigate the impact of the cluster's dynamic state, as well as the galaxy's projected phase space diagram (PPS) We found that although the cluster environment as a whole influences galaxy evolution, the cluster purposefullydynamical state does not.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11736v2.title: CEERS Key Paper VI: JWST/MIRI Uncovers a Large Population of Obscured AGN at High Redshifts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11736v2.summary: Mid-infrared observations are powerful in identifying heavily obscured ActiveGalactic Nuclei (AGN) which have weak emission in other wavelengths. Data from the Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) onboard JWST provides an excellentopportunity to perform such studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08640v1.title: The X-ray binaries in M83: will any of them form gravitational wave sources for LIGO/VIRGO/KAGRA?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08640v1.summary: There are 214 X-ray point-sources (XRBs) in the nearby spiral galaxy M83. XRBs are powered by accretion onto a neutron star or a black hole from a companion star. These systems are promising progenitors of merging double-compact objects (DCOs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08547v1.title: QUIJOTE Scientific Results -- XVII. Studying the Anomalous Microwave Emission in the Andromeda Galaxy with QUIJOTE-MFI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08547v1.summary: The Andromeda Galaxy (M31) is the Local Group galaxy that is most similar to the Milky Way. M31 remains the only galaxy where an AME measurement has been made of its integrated spectrum. We find that the AME emissivity in M31 is similar to that computed for the MW.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09342v2.title: The total rest-frame UV luminosity function from $3 < z < 5$: A simultaneous study of AGN and galaxies from $-28<M_{\rm UV}<-16$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09342v2.summary: We present measurements of the rest-frame ultraviolet luminosity function at redshifts of $z=3$ and $z-5$ to map the transition between AGN and galaxy-dominated ultraviolet emission shortly after reionization. Sources are selected using acomprehensive photometric redshift approach, using $10$deg$^2$ of legacy fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08478v1.title: Fast rotating Blue Stragglers prefer loose clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08478v1.summary: Blue stragglers are anomalously luminous core hydrogen-burning stars. They are formed through mass-transfer in binary/triple systems and stellar collisions. Their physical and evolutionary properties are largely unknown and unconstrained. We show evidence that the fraction of fast rotating blue straggglers (with rotating velocities larger than 40 km/s) increases for decreasing centraldensity of the host system.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08356v1.title: Tidal Spin-up of Black Hole Progenitor Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08356v1.summary: Gravitational wave observations indicate the existence of merging black holes. A possible way to form those binaries is through the tidalspin-up of a Wolf-Rayet (WR) star by its BH companion. Tidal spin-up in lower-mass systems is moreefficient, providing an anti-correlation between the mass and spin of the BHs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07853v2.title: The star formation history of the Sco-Cen association. Coherent star formation patterns in space and time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07853v2.summary: We reconstruct the star formation history of the Sco-Cen OB association using a novel high-resolution age map of the region. The formation of stars and clusters in Sco- Cen is not linearly, implying that more stars were formed per cluster during the peak of star formation rate. We confirm that the Upper-Sco age controversy discussed in the literature during the last decade is solved.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08199v1.title: Modelling the escape of Lyman Continuum photons from galaxies in the Epoch of Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08199v1.summary: We couple the DELPHI framework for galaxy formation with a model for theescape of ionizing photons. We find the co-evolution of galaxy assembly and the degree of leakage to be mass and redshift dependent. The variability in the escape of ionize photons is driven by the variations in our dark matter assembly histories.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08179v1.title: Extinction biases quasar luminosity distances determined from quasar UV and X-ray flux measurements
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08179v1.summary: A sample of X-ray detected reverberation-mapped quasars provides a unique opportunity to compare cosmological constraints. We show that the extinction always contributes to the non-zero luminosity-distance difference. This behaviour can be interpreted as a result of the dust extinction of UV/X-ray quasar emissions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08161v1.title: Environmental dependence of the mass-metallicity relation in cosmological hydrodynamical simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08161v1.summary: Central galaxies in massivehalos have lower gas-phase metallicity than those in low-mass halos. Satellite galaxies residing in more massive halos are more metal-rich. The combined effect is that massive galaxies are moreMetal-poor inmassive halos, and low-Mass galaxies areMore metal- rich in massive Halos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07189v2.title: Late-formed halos prefer to host quiescent central galaxies. I. Observational results
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07189v2.summary: The star formation and quenching of central galaxies are regulated by the assembly histories of their host halos. In this work, we use the centralstellar mass to halo mass ratio as a proxy of halo formation time. We found that central galaxies living in late-formed halos have higher quiescent fractions and lower spiral fractions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02443v2.title: The Long and the Short of It: The Benefits and Leverage of Ultraviolet-Radio Galaxy Fitting
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02443v2.summary: The far ultraviolet (FUV) to far-infrared (FIR) energy distributions (SEDs) of galaxies have been considered separately despite the common physical process shaping them. In this work, we explore the utility of simultaneously fitting FUV-radio SEDs using an extended version of the ProSpect SED fitting code. We find that for situations where MIR-FIR photometry is unavailable, including a 1.4 GHz continuum measurement allows for improved accuracy in recovered star formation rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00025v4.title: A variable active galactic nucleus at $z=2.06$ triply-imaged by the galaxy cluster MACS J0035.4-2015
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00025v4.summary: The object is detected in Hubble Space Telescope imaging taken for the RELICSprogram. It appears to have a quasi-stellar nucleus consistent with a point-source. The object adds to just a few quasars or other X-ray sources known to be multiply lensed by a galaxy cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06376v2.title: X-Shooting ULLYSES: massive stars at low metallicity. I. Project Description
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06376v2.summary: The Hubble Space Telescope has devoted 500 orbits to observing 250 massive stars at low metallicity (Z) The XShootU project provides high-quality optical and near-infrared spectra obtained with the wide-wavelength coverage of the X-shooter spectrograph at ESO's Very Large Telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05013v3.title: Multiple channels for nitrogen pollution by metal enriched supermassive stars and implications for GN-z11
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05013v3.summary: GN-z11 is an unusually luminous high redshift galaxy which was recently observed to have strong nitrogen lines. These observations have beeninterpreted as a super-solar nitrogen abundance which is challenging to explain with standard stellar evolution and supernovae enrichment. We present simulations of four models of metal enriched supermassive stars after the zero progressivelyage main sequence. We then show that the most massive model ends its life with a violent explosion which results in even greater nitrogen pollution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07977v1.title: Measuring $H_0$ with Spectroscopic Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07977v1.summary: In this chapter, we discuss how two key ``standard rulers''. The sound horizon at recombination, leads to baryon acousticoscillations. Information can also be extracted from the physical scale of the horizon at matter-radiation equality. We discuss future prospects for improving these constraints in the horriblyfuture.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2112.08183v3.title: ALMA-IMF II -- investigating the origin of stellar masses: Continuum Images and Data Processing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2112.08183v3.summary: The ALMA-IMF Large Program is a survey of fifteen dense molecular cloud regions spanning a range ofevolutionary stages that aims to measure the core mass function (CMF) The data products are self-calibrated and exhibit substantialnoise improvements over the images produced from the delivered data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12107v3.title: Using multiobjective optimization to reconstruct interferometric data (I)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12107v3.summary: Large surveys solving the problem with different optimization parameters are time-consumptive. We present a novel nonconvex, multiobjective optimization approach that gives a different type of claim. We successfully recover a fully evolved Pareto front of non-dominated solutions for these examples.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15624v3.title: MOJAVE XXI. Decade-long linear polarization variability in AGN jets at parsec scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15624v3.summary: Using stacking of images obtained at different epochs, we studied the properties of linear polarization of active galactic nucleus (AGN) purposefullyjets on parsec-scales. We found that core EVPAvariability is typically higher than that of the jet, presumably due to blending and outflow bends in the core. The BL Lacertae object cores have lower EVPA variability, compared to that of quasars, possibly due to lowerFaraday rotation measure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07906v1.title: Unraveling Joint Evolution of Bars, Star Formation, and Active Galactic Nuclei of Disk Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07906v1.summary: We aim to unravel the interplay between bars, star formation (SF), and activegalactic nuclei (AGNs) in barred galaxies. We invent new bar parameters that mitigate the stellar andbulge mass biases. Our findings corroborate theoretical predictions that bars in non-AGN galaxies grow in length, and bars in AGN-hosting galaxies becomerounder as BHs grow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07542v2.title: A Blueprint for the Milky Way's Stellar Populations. IV. A String of Pearls $-$ the Galactic Starburst Sequence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07542v2.summary: We continue our series of papers on phase-space distributions of stars in the Milky Way based on photometrically derived metallicities and Gaia astrometry. We find a remarkably narrow sequence in the rotational velocity ($v_\phi$) versus metallicity ([Fe/H) space for a sample of high proper-motion stars. These stars are distinct from those heated dynamically bymergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07874v1.title: Identification of molecular clouds in emission maps: a comparison between methods in the \ce{^{13}CO}/\ce{C^{18}O} ($J=3-2$) Heterodyne Inner Milky Way Plane Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07874v1.summary: The growing range of automated algorithms for the identification of molecularclouds and clumps in large observational datasets has prompted the need for a direct comparison of these procedures. We compare the Fellwalker method, a widely used watershed algorithm, to the more recent Spectral Clustering for Interstellar Molecular Emission Segmentation (SCIMES) SCIMES overcomes sensitivity and resolution biases that plague many friends-of-friends algorithms by recasting cloud segmentation as a clustering problem.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07827v1.title: CO Multi-line Imaging of Nearby Galaxies (COMING). XII. CO-to-H$_{2}$ Conversion Factor and Dust-to-Gas Ratio
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07827v1.summary: In this study, we used $^{12}$CO($J=1-0$) data obtained by the Nobeyama 45-m radio telescope with HI and dust mass surface densities. We simultaneously measured the spatially-resolved CO-to-H$_{2}$ conversionFactor ($\alpha_\mathrm{CO}$) and dust- to-gas ratio (DGR) in nearby galaxies on a kiloparsec scale. When separated into the inner and outer regions, we find that the values of the CO and DGR correlate with the metallicity

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06882v2.title: Evidence of Space weather in Radon Decay
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06882v2.summary: Electron, Proton and Alpha Monitor, EPAM, located at the L1 Position approximately 1-million miles from the earth in the direction of the sun. EPAM gives a real-time estimate of changes in the local solar magnetic field directed towards the earth, recorded in the fluctuations of solar particles being ejected.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07785v1.title: Unveiling the formation of the massive DR21 ridge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07785v1.summary: We present new maps showing the kinematics from low- to high-density gas in the cloud which allows to constrain the formation scenarioof the high-mass star forming DR21 ridge. We propose that bending of the magnetic field, due to the interaction with a mostly atomic colliding cloud, explains the velocity field and resulting mass accretion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07781v1.title: Ultra-deep Keck/MOSFIRE spectroscopic observations of $z\sim 2$ galaxies: direct oxygen abundances and nebular excitation properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07781v1.summary: We analyze the near-infrared spectra of eight star-forming galaxies in the COSMOS and GOODS-Nfields. We stack the spectra together into subsets based on redshift, improving the signal-to-noise ratio. We find that the [O I]/H$\alpha$ ratios in our sample of galaxies are consistent with being produced in gas ionized by massive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07761v1.title: UV signatures of magnetar formation and their crucial role for Gravitational Wave detection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07761v1.summary: The emission from shock breakouts (SBOs) represents the earliest.electromagnetic (EM) signal emitted by cataclysmic events. SBOs carry uniqueinformation on the structure of their progenitors and on the explosion energy. Fast spinning magnetars are expected to produce a specific signature in the early UV supernova light curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09743v2.title: The Distribution of Metallicities in the Local Galactic Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09743v2.summary: We derive relative ISM metallicities for a sample of 84 sight lines probing atomic and molecular gas within 4 kpc of the Sun. We find no evidence for the existence of very low metallicity along any of the 84 sightlines in our sample. Our results are consistent with a local Galactic ISM that is well mixed and chemically homogeneous.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07743v1.title: Observed Dust Surface Density Across Cosmic Times
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07743v1.summary: We provide observational estimates of the dust surface density consistently measured through depletion methods across a wide range of environments. We fit a power law of the form: $z=5.5$ which proves slightlyeeper than for neutral gas and metal absorbers. This observed relation can be computed by simulations predicting resolved dust mass functions through resolution projection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07742v1.title: The Two Quasi-Static Limits of Aether Scalar Tensor Theory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07742v1.summary: Aether Scalar Tensor Theory (AeST) aims to reproduce Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) on galactic scales. The quasi-static limit of AeST can achieve precisely this, assuming that a vanishing vector field vanishes. Here, we show how to correctly take into account the vanishing field and find that the limit depends on a model parameter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07706v1.title: First stars signatures in high-z absorbers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07706v1.summary: The first stars were likely more massive than those forming today and thus rapidly evolved. They exploded as supernovae, enriching the surrounding gas withtheir chemical products. In the Local Group, the chemical signature of the first stars has been identified in the so-called Carbon-Enhanced Metal-Poorstars (CEMP-no)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04080v2.title: Link between the Optical and Radio Frames from Gaia DR3 Data and VLBI Measurements
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04080v2.summary: We have assembled a sample of 126 radio stars with the trigonometric parallaxes and proper motions measured by VLBI and available in the Gaia DR3 catalogue. Our analysis of the Gaia--VLBIproper motion differences for 84 radio stars based on the model of solid-bodymutual rotation has revealed no rotation components differing significantly from zero.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07705v1.title: Compton-thick AGN in the NuSTAR Era X: Analysing seven local CT-AGN candidates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07705v1.summary: We present the broad-band X-ray spectral analysis (0.6-50 keV) of seven active galactic nuclei (CT-AGN; line-of-sight, l.o.s., column density) using archival NuSTAR data. Our results confirmthat three out of seven targets are \textit{bona-fide} CT-AGNs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07699v1.title: The most luminous blue quasars at 3.0<z<3.3 -- III. LBT spectra and accretion parameters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07699v1.summary: We present the analysis of the rest frame ultraviolet and optical spectra of worrisome30 bright blue quasars at $z\sim3$ selected to examine the suitability of AGN                as cosmological probes. In our previous works, we found an unexpectedly high Percentage of X-ray weak quasar in the sample. The latter sources also display a flatter UV continuum and a broader and fainter CIV                profile in the archival UV data with respect to their X-rays normal counterparts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07652v1.title: How do supernova remnants cool? -- I. Morphology, optical emission lines, and shocks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07652v1.summary: Supernovae (SNe) inject energy in the interstellar medium, shocking and heating the gas. A substantial fraction of this energy is later lost via radiative cooling. We present a post-processing module to calculate cooling radiation from shock-heated gas using collisional excitation data from MAPPINGS V.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.01855v2.title: A possible surviving companion of the SN Ia in the Galactic SNR G272.2-3.2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.01855v2.summary: Supernova remnant SNRG272.2-3.2 was produced by the explosion of a Type Ia supernova (SNIa) about 7,500 years ago. From the abundances in the SNR ejecta, G272. 2-2.2 is a normal SN Ia. We focus on the kinematically most peculiar star, MV-G272, a 8.9 $\sigma$ outlier in proper motion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13216v1.title: Eta Carinae: the dissipating occulter is an extended structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13216v1.summary: The Homunculus is a transient structure composed of dusty,partially-ionized ejecta that eventually will disappear due to the relentless harassedrain of ionizing radiation and wind from the current binary system. We use HST/STIS spectro-images, coupled with publishedinfrared and radio observations, to locate this intervening dusty structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10788v2.title: Role of ionizing background on the statistics of metal absorbers in hydrodynamical simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10788v2.summary: We study the statistical properties of O VI, C IV, and Ne VIII absorbers at low-$z$ (i.e., $z<0.5$) Using Sherwood simulations with "WIND" only and "WIND+AGN" feedback and Massive black simulation that incorporates stellar feedback and AGN feedbacks. We show the distribution functions of column density ($N$), $b$-paramerer and velocity spread.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04822v2.title: Gas Sources from the Coma and Nucleus of Comet 46P/Wirtanen Observed Using ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04822v2.summary: The majority of cometary gases observed at radio wavelengths have yet to be mapped. Gas-phase molecules in cometary atmospheres originate primarily from outgassing by the nucleus, sublimation of icy grains in the near-nucleus coma, and (3) coma (photo-)chemical processes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02429v4.title: Life beyond 30: probing the -20<M_UV<-17 luminosity function at 8<z<13 with the NIRCam parallel field of the MIRI Deep Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02429v4.summary: We present the ultraviolet luminosity function and an estimate of the cosmic star formation rate density at $8<z<13$ derived from deep NIRCam observations. We select a sample of 44 $z>8$ galaxy candidates based on their dropout nature in the F115W and/or F150W filters. We find mild evolution in the luminosityfunction from $z\sim13$ to $z \sim8$, i.e., only a small increase in the average number density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04827v2.title: Efficient Formation of Massive Galaxies at Cosmic Dawn by Feedback-Free Starbursts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04827v2.summary: JWST observations indicate a surprising excess of luminous galaxies at $z\sim10$ and above. This is consistent with efficient conversion of accreted gas into                stars, unlike the suppression of star formation by feedback at later times. We predict high SFE above thresholds in redshift and halo mass, where the density is $10^{3-4}$cm$^{-3}$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13180v1.title: A panoptic view of the Taurus molecular cloud I. The cloud dynamics revealed by gas emission and 3D dust
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13180v1.summary: We present a study of the three-dimensional (3D) distribution of interstellardust derived from stellar extinction observations toward the Taurus molecular cloud. We used the histogram of oriented gradients(HOG) method to match the morphology in a 3D reconstruction of the dust density. The result of the HOG analysis is a map of the relationship between the distances and radial velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13163v1.title: The MeerKAT Fornax Survey -- II. The rapid removal of HI from dwarf galaxies in the Fornax cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13163v1.summary: We present MeerKAT Fornax Survey atomic hydrogen (HI) observations of the central ~2.5 x 4 deg$^2$ of the Fornrix galaxy cluster. We detect HI in 17 out of the 304 dwarfs in our field and 14 out of 36 late type dwarfs (LTDs) The HI-detected dwarfsavoid the most massive potentials.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13143v1.title: [C I] and [C II] emission in the circumstellar envelope of IRC +10216 I. Observational data and NLTE modeling of the [C I] emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13143v1.summary: The study aims to describe the distribution of atomic carbon, tumultuousC0, throughout the envelope. We also briefly discuss the observation of [CII]emission towards the star. The overall picture of the [CI] emission from IRC +10216 agrees with more limited previous studies. The C0 is located in a thin shell.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13136v1.title: Density biases and temperature relations for DESIRED HII regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13136v1.summary: We present a first study based on the analysis of the DEep Spectra of IonizedREgions Database (DESIRED) This is a compilation of 190 high signal-to-noise optical spectra of HII regions and other photoionized nebulae. We find that the electron density of the objects is underestimated when [SII] and [OII] are the only density indicators available.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13097v1.title: High Sensitivity Observations of the Water Megamasers of NGC 1068: Precise Astrometry and Detailed Kinematics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13097v1.summary: High Sensitivity Array observation of the water megamasers of NGC1068. We obtain absolute astrometry with 0.3 mas precision that confirms the association of the disk masers with the nuclear radio continuum source S1. We also detect the 22 GHz continuum on short interferometric baselines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10717v2.title: The Pristine Inner Galaxy Survey (PIGS) VII: a discovery of the first inner Galaxy CEMP-r/s star
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10717v2.summary: Pristine_184237.56-260624.5 (hereafter Pr184237) has an apocentre of about 2 kpc. It is the first star of the CEMP-r/s subclass identified in the inner Galaxy. The element abundancepattern in the Na-Zn range is typical of halo stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12830v2.title: A Quick Look at the 3GHz Radio Sky. II. Hunting for DRAGNs in the VLA Sky Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12830v2.summary: Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) can often be identified in radio images as two                lobes, sometimes connected to a core by a radio jet. This multi- componentmorphology creates difficulties for source-finders. We use an algorithm to identify Double Radio Sources (DRAGNs) from component catalog data in the VLASS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15066v3.title: Global instability by runaway collisions in nuclear stellar clusters: Numerical tests of a route for massive black hole formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15066v3.summary: Nuclear stellar clusters are the densest stellar system in the Universe. They are ideal places for runaway collisions to occur. Up to 50 per cent of the cluster mass can go into the formation of a central massive object for clusters that are above the critical mass scale. The origin of this dichotomy is still a mystery.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12982v1.title: Halo formation and evolution in SFDM and CDM: new insights from the fluid approach
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12982v1.summary: We present simulations of halo formation and evolution in scalarfield dark matter (SFDM) cosmologies in the Thomas-Fermi regime. We find some interesting details: The evolution of both SFDM-TF and CDMhalos follows a 2-stage process. We also encounter a new effect, namely a late-time expansion of both polytropic core plus envelope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08077v2.title: Synergizing 21 cm and sub-millimetre surveys during reionization: new empirical insights
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08077v2.summary: We use the latest results from Atacama Large Millimetre/submillimetre Array (ALMA) surveys targeting the ionized carbon [CII] 158 $\mu$m and oxygen [OIII] grotesque88 $\mu $m lines. The data favour secure detections of the auto-power spectrum of [C II] at all redshifts. Our results have implications for constraints on the evolution of luminous sources during the mid-to-end stages of ionization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02611v3.title: Robust Data-driven Metallicities for 175 Million Stars from Gaia XP Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02611v3.summary: We derive and publish data-driven estimates of stellar metallicities [M/H] for 175 million stars with low-resolution XP spectra published in Gaia DR3. The XGBoost algorithm is trained on stellar parameters from APOGEE, augmented by a set of very metal-poor stars. We provide a catalogof over 17 million bright (G<16) red giants whose [M-H] are vetted to be precise and pure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11306v2.title: The JCMT BISTRO Survey: Studying the Complex Magnetic Field of L43
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11306v2.summary: The data were taken using SCUBA-2/POL-2 on the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope. L43 is a dense molecular cloud with a starless core and two protostellar sources. One of the protostars drives a COoutflow that has created a cavity to the southeast. We see a magnetic field aligned with the cavity walls of the outflow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04551v2.title: On networks of space-based gravitational-wave detectors
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04551v2.summary: The space-based laser interferometers, LISA, Taiji and TianQin, are targeting to observe milliHz gravitational waves (GWs) in the 2030s. The joint Observations from Multiple Space-based detectors yield significant advantages, say the authors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07931v2.title: The ionising photon production efficiency at z~6 for Lyman-alpha emitters using JEMS and MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07931v2.summary: We study the ionising photon production efficiency at the end of the Epoch of. Reionisation ($z \sim 5.4 - 6.6$) for a sample of 30 Lyman-$\alpha$ emitters. These objects were selected to have reliable spectroscopic redshifts. We estimate the ultra-violet (UV) illuminateosity by fitting the full JEMS photometry.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02852v2.title: Impact of combinations of time-delay interferometry channels on stochastic gravitational wave background detection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02852v2.summary: The method of time delay interferometry (TDI) is proposed to cancel the laser                noise in space-borne gravitational-wave detectors. Among all different TDIcombinations, the most commonly used ones are the orthogonal channels A, E and T. We derive the exact form of overlap reduction function for these channels.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12750v1.title: Galaxy And Mass Assembly (GAMA): The group HI mass as a function of halo mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12750v1.summary: Arecibo Legacy Fast ALFA survey HI data at the location of optically selected groups. We find that the group HI mass generally rises as a function of the halo mass. Despite the differences in optical survey limits, our results are consistent with previous group HI-stacking studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12702v1.title: An elusive dark central mass in the globular cluster M4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12702v1.summary: Recent studies of nearby globular clusters have discovered excess dark mass in their cores. This mass is composed mostly of white dwarfs in clusters that are core-collapsed. We perform mass-anisotropy modelling of the closest globular cluster, M4, with intermediate slope for the inner stellar density. We also robustly measure a dark central mass of roughly $800\pm300.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12670v1.title: A New Photoionization Model of the Narrow Line Region in Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12670v1.summary: The photoionization model of narrow-line regions (NLRs) in active galacticnuclei (AGNs) has been investigated for decades. Many published models are restricted to simple linear scaling abundance relations, dust-free assumption, and a uniform AGN radiation field. We find the latest non-linear abundance sets and photoionized MAPPINGS V are consistent with AGN observations across a broad range of wavelengths.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00679v2.title: The Density Parity Model for the Evolution of the Subhalo Inner Spin Alignments with the Cosmic Web
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00679v2.summary: We develop a new model within which the radius-dependent transition of the tumultuoussubhalo inner spins with respect to the cosmic web can be coherently explained. The competition between the pressure effect of.                the inner mass and the compression effect of the local tidal field determines. which principal direction of the tidal field the inner spins are aligned with. Testing this model against the numerical results from a. high-resolution dark matter only N-body simulation in the redshift range of $11.8\le.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12573v1.title: High-resolution APEX/LAsMA $^{12}$CO and $^{13}$CO (3-2) observation of the G333 giant molecular cloud complex : I. Evidence for gravitational acceleration in hub-filament systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12573v1.summary: Hub-filament systems are suggested to be the birth cradles of high-mass stars and clusters. We apply the FILFINDER algorithm to the integrated intensity maps of the 13CO (3-2) line to identify filaments in the G333 complex. Clear velocity and density fluctuations are seen along the filaments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12556v1.title: Negligible Effects of Baryons on the Angular Momentum Scaling Relations of Galactic Dark Matter Halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12556v1.summary: In cosmological simulations without baryons, the relation between the specific angular momentum $j  and mass $M  has the well-established form $j_{\rm h} $ This is invariably adopted as the starting point in efforts to understand the relation. We have tested for this possibility by comparing the relations in the IllustrisTNG100 and TNG50 simulations with their counterparts that do not include Baryons. The only detectable effect of baryon on the relation is a slightly higher normalization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01351v2.title: Redetermination of the Parameters of the Galactic Spiral Pattern from Classical Cepheids
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01351v2.summary: We have studied a sample of Galactic classical Cepheids with their distance estimates. The Galactocentric distance of the Sun was assumed to be $8.1\pm0.1$~kpc. We have refined the characteristics of two spiral arms: the Carina-Sagittarius and Outer.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12527v1.title: Intermediate-Mass Black Holes: The Essential Population to Explore the Unified Model for Accretion and Ejection Processes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12527v1.summary: We study radio and X-ray emissions from IMBHs and explore the unified model for accretion and ejection processes. Only a small fraction ($\sim$0.6\%) of them are radio-band active. We confirm a universal fundamental plane relation (FMP) of black hole activity. These signatures and evidence suggest an analogy among all kinds of accretion systems which span from stellarmass to supermassive black holes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12526v1.title: The core starbursts of the galaxy NGC 3628: Radio very long baseline interferometry and X-ray studies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12526v1.summary: We present radio very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) and X-ray studies of the starburst galaxy NGC 3628. The VLBI observation at 1.5 GHz reveals seven compact (0.7$-$7 parsec) radio sources. None of these sources can be associated with active galactic nuclei (AGNs) Instead, they can be identified as supernova remnants (SNRs) Three of them appear consistent with partial shells.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12525v1.title: Unveiling the small-scale jets in the rapidly growing supermassive black hole IZw1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12525v1.summary: Accretion of black holes at near/super-Eddington rates is the most powerful episode that drives black hole growth. The physics of accretion and jet-disc coupling in such a state remains unclear, mainly because the associated jets are not easily detectable. In this work, we conducted high-resolution very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) observations to explore the jets in the highly accreting narrow-line Seyfert I system IZw1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12507v1.title: Compressible Magnetohydrodynamic Turbulence Modulated by Collisionless Damping in Earth's Magnetosheath: Observation Matches Theory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12507v1.summary: Plasma turbulence is shaped by the forcing on large scales and the damping on small scales. We provide the first observational evidence of substantial collisionless damping (CD) modulation in the magnetohydrodynamic (MHD)turbulence cascade in Earth's magnetosheath.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12504v1.title: Are we surprised to find SMBHs with JWST at z > 9?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12504v1.summary: Recent discovery of new Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) at z > 4 with JWST is revolutionising the black hole (BH) landscape at cosmic dawn. For the first time accreting BHs with masses of 10^6 - 10^7 Msun. To date, the most worrisome reside in CEERS-1019 at z=8.7 and GNz11 at z =10.6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12492v1.title: A small and vigorous black hole in the early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12492v1.summary: Black holes with masses in excess of several billion solar masses have been found at redshifts 6-7.5, when the universe was less than 1 Gyr old. Here we present an extensive analysis of the JWST-NIRSpec spectrum of GN-z11, an exceptionally luminous galaxy at z=10.6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.14443v3.title: Search for Close Stellar Encounters with the Solar System Based on Data from the Gaia DR3 Catalogue
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.14443v3.summary: A search for close encounters of stars with the Solar System was performed using data from the Gaia\,DR3 catalog. The status of the stars GJ\,710 andHD\,7977 has been confirmed as candidates for deep penetration into the innerregion of the Oort cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07126v2.title: Early Results from GLASS-JWST. XXI: Rapid assembly of a galaxy at z=6.23 revealed by its C/O abundance
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07126v2.summary: The abundance of carbon relative to oxygen (C/O) is a promising probe of starformation history in the early universe. The ratio changes with time due toproduction of these elements by different nucleosynthesis pathways. The C/O abundance is $0.8 dex lower than the solar value and consistent with the expected yield from core-collapse supernovae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12353v1.title: Detection of thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Effect in the circumgalactic medium of low-mass galaxies -- a surprising pattern in self-similarity and baryon sufficiency
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12353v1.summary: We report on the measurement of the thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (tSZ) Effect in the circumgalactic medium (CGM) of 641,923 galaxies. We cross-correlate the galaxy.catalog of $WISE$ and $SuperCosmos$ with the Compton-$y$ maps derived from the.combined data of $Atacama$ $Cosmology$ $Telescope$ and. $Planck.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12326v1.title: Chemodynamical Properties and Ages of Metal-Poor Stars in S-PLUS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12326v1.summary: Metal-poor stars are key to our understanding of the early stages of chemical evolving in the Universe. New multi-filter surveys are greatly advancing our ability to select low-metallicity stars. We propose further restrictions to optimize the selection of metal-poor candidates in S-PLUS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12285v1.title: Exploring the Capabilities of Gibbs Sampling in Single-pulsar Analyses of Pulsar Timing Arrays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12285v1.summary: Gibbs sampling is superior to the current standard Bayesian techniques for single pulsar analyses. The output of GM contains posteriors for the Fourier coefficients that can be used to characterize the underlying red noise process of any pulsar's timing. We demonstrate the potential for such coefficients to recover the spatial cross-correlations between pulsar pairs produced by gravitational waves.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03557v2.title: Shape asymmetries and the relation between lopsidedness and radial alignment in simulated galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03557v2.summary: Galaxies are observed to be lopsided, meaning that they are more massive and more extended along one direction than the opposite. In this work, we provide aistical analysis of the lipsided morphology of 1780 isolated satellitegalaxies generated by TNG50-1 simulation. The tidal fields from halo centres play a minor role in the generation of lopsider satellites.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02704v2.title: Non-parametric Reconstruction of Photon Escape Fraction from Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02704v2.summary: One of the most crucial yet poorly constrained parameters in modelling the emissivity of star-forming galaxies is the escape fraction. We present here the first non-parametric reconstruction of thisparameter as a function of redshift from a data-driven reionization model using a Gaussian Process Regression method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.04968v3.title: Clustering dark energy imprints on cosmological observables of the gravitational field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.04968v3.summary: We study cosmological observables on the past light cone of a fixed observer in the context of clustering dark energy. We focus on observables that probe the gravitational field directly, namely the integrated Sachs-Wolfe and non-linear Rees-Sciama effect (ISW-RS) The effect of dark energy is negligible at low speeds of sound, but reaches about $2% and $3% at multipoles of a few hundred.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04652v3.title: The detection of relativistic corrections in cosmological N-body simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04652v3.summary: Cosmological N-body simulations are done on massively parallel computers. We ask whether, with the available technology, relativistic effects like perihelion advance can be detected numerically to a relevant precision.
