http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06326v1.summary: We present the first period-luminosity (PL) and period-Wesenheit (PW)relations in the Sloan-Pans-STARRS gP1rP1iP1 bands. The data for the project were collected with the network of 40-cm telescopes of Las CumbresObservatory.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06318v1.title: PROVABGS: The Probabilistic Stellar Mass Function of the BGS One-Percent Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06318v1.summary: We present the probabilistic stellar mass function (pSMF) of galaxies in the DESI Bright Galaxy Survey (BGS), observed during the One-Percent Survey. We derive pSMFs from posteriors of stellar mass, $M_*$, inferred from DESI photometry andspectroscopy using the Hahn et al. (2022a; arXiv:2202.01809) PRObabilisticValue-Added BGS (PROVABGS) Bayesian SED modeling framework. We present the redshift evolution of the pSMF in BGS as well as

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06303v1.title: Torus skin outflow in a near-Eddington quasar revealed by spectropolarimetry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06303v1.summary: Spectropolarimetry can be an important tool in investigating the circumnuclear geometry and kinematics of quasars. Even when the direct view toward the active nucleus is obscured, nuclear emission can scatter off surrounding material, become polarized and reach the observer. We demonstrate that the swinging polarization angle can be a result of the geometry of the outflow and the orientation of the observers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06271v1.title: Completeness of the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED) -- Local Volume Sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06271v1.summary: The NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED) Local Volume Sample(NED-LVS) is a subset of 1.9 million objects with distances out to 1000~Mpc. The completeness relative to NIRluminosities (which traces a galaxy's stellar mass) is roughly 100% at distances below 30% of the universe. For brighter galaxies, the completeness is about 70% out to 300%. NED- LVS is the underlying sample for the NED gravitational wave follow-up service.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06260v1.title: Metallicity Distribution Functions of 13 Ultra-Faint Dwarf Galaxy Candidates from Hubble Space Telescope Narrowband Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06260v1.summary: This represents the largest homogeneous set of stellar metallicities in UFDs. We find a nearly constant [Fe/H] ~ -2.6 over 3 decades in luminosity. 19% of stars in our UFD sample to be metal-rich, compared to 14% in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06244v1.title: NGDEEP Epoch 1: The Faint-End of the Luminosity Function at $z \sim$ 9-12 from Ultra-Deep JWST Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06244v1.summary: The NGDEEP NIRCam imaging in the Hubble UltraDeep Field Parallel Field 2 (HUDF-Par2) reaches $m=30.4$ (5$\sigma$ point-source) in F277W, making it the deepest public GO imaging set to date.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08523v2.title: Cosmic Variance and the Inhomogeneous UV Luminosity Function of Galaxies During Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08523v2.summary: When the first galaxies formed and starlight escaped into the intergalacticmedium to reionize it, galaxy formation and reionization were both highlyogeneous in time and space. To showhow this imprinted the UV luminosity function (UVLF) of reionized-eragalaxies, we use our large-scale, radiation-hydrodynamics simulation CoDa II.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14220v2.title: New Constraints on Warm Dark Matter from the Lyman-$α$ Forest Power Spectrum
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14220v2.summary: The forest of Lyman-$\alpha$ absorption lines detected in the spectra of nearby quasars encodes information on the nature and properties of dark matter. Its main observable -- the flux power spectrum (FPS) -- should exhibit a suppression on small scales and an enhancement on large scales in warm dark matter cosmologies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06172v1.title: Reconstruction of Cosmic Black Hole Growth and Mass Distribution from Quasar Luminosity Functions at $z>4$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06172v1.summary: The evolution of the quasar luminosity function (QLF) is fundamental to understanding the cosmic evolution of black holes (BHs) through their accretion phases. In the era of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), Euclid, and Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope, their unprecedented detection sensitivity and wide survey area can unveil the low-luminosity quasar and low-mass BH populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06170v1.title: Intranight optical variability of TeV blazars with parsec-scale jets dominated by slow-moving radio knots
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06170v1.summary: Bl Lac objects detected at TeV energies preferentially belong to the 'high-frequency-peaked' BL Lacs. Parsec-scale radio jets in these TeV-HBLs often show dominant, slow moving radio knots that are at most mildlysuperluminal. We report the first systematic campaign to characterise theIntra-Night Optical Variability (INOV) of these objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06168v1.title: Harmonic Analysis for Pulsar Timing Arrays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06168v1.summary: We use harmonic analysis techniques to perform measurements of the angular power spectrum on mock pulsar timing data. We examine the sensitivity of our harmonic analysis to the number of pulsars (50, 100, and 150) and length of pulsar observation time (10, 20, and 30 years) We are able to detect the quadrupole for all our mock harmonic analyses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06164v1.title: The Disturbed and Globular Cluster-Rich Ultra-diffuse Galaxy UGC 9050-Dw1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06164v1.summary: We investigate the ultra-diffuse galaxy (UDG) UGC 9050-Dw1. We use the Hubble SpaceTelescope's Advanced Camera for Surveys to identify globular clusters (GCs) associated with the galaxy. Nearly uniform GC colors suggest they were formed during a single intense episode of star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06035v1.title: On the frequencies of circumbinary discs in protostellar systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06035v1.summary: We report the analysis of circumbinary discs formed in a radiationophobichydrodynamical simulation of star cluster formation. We consider both pure                binary stars and pairs within triple and quadruple systems. We find that $89$ per cent of pure binaries with semi-major axes $a<1$ au have a circumbical disc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06025v1.title: Star formation history for the starburst dwarf galaxy in the Local Group, IC 10
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06025v1.summary: IC 10 as a starburst dwarf galaxy in the Local Group (LG) has a large population of newly formed stars that are massive and intrinsically very bright. Using the Isaac Newton Telescope (INT) in the i-band and V-band, we performed anoptical monitoring survey to identify the most evolved asymptotic giant branchstars and red supergiant stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.11977v2.title: The SOUX AGN sample: Optical/UV/X-ray SEDs and the nature of the disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.11977v2.summary: We use the SOUX sample of $\sim$700 AGN to form average optical-UV-X-rays on a 2D grid. We compare these with predictions of a new AGN SED model, QSOSED, which includes prescriptions for both hot and warm Comptonisation regions as well as an outer standard disc. The data do not match the predictions made by any current accretion flow model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05942v1.title: sMILES SSPs: A Library of Semi-Empirical MILES Stellar Population Models with Variable [$α$/Fe] Abundances
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05942v1.summary: We present a new library of semi-empirical stellar population models. The models are aimed at exploring abundance ratios in star clusters and galaxies. Age, metallicity and [$\alpha$/Fe] trends were measured for galaxy stacks with different stellar velocity dispersions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05909v1.title: Galaxy Light profile neural Networks (GaLNets). II. Bulge-Disc decomposition in optical space-based observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05909v1.summary: The Galaxy Lightprofile neural Network (GaLNet) is used to predict 2-S\'ersic model parameters. The GaLNet can achieve very good accuracy for most of the B-D parameters down to an $r$-band magnitude of 23.5 and redshift of 1.7. The best accuracy is obtained for magnitudes, implying accurate bulge-to-total(B/T) estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05858v1.title: SRG/eROSITA X-ray shadowing study of giant molecular clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05858v1.summary: SRG/eROSITA is situated in a halo orbit around L2 where the highly variable solar wind charge exchange (SWCX) emission from Earth's magnetosheath is expected to be negligible. The soft X-ray foreground emissions from the localHot bubble (LHB) and the remaining heliospheric SWCX emissions could be studied in unprecedented detail with eRosITA All-Sky Survey data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05790v1.title: A statistical and machine learning approach to the study of astrochemistry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05790v1.summary: In order to obtain a good understanding of astrochemistry, it is crucial to understand the key parameters that govern grain-surface chemistry. Formany chemical networks, these crucial parameters are the binding energies of species. However, there exists much disagreement regarding these values in the literature. In this work, a Bayesian inference approach is taken to estimate these values.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05875v2.title: Lensing with generalized symmetrons
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05875v2.summary: Generalized symmetrons are models that have qualitatively similar features to the archetypal symmetron. They can provide an explanation for the difference between baryonic and lens masses of galaxies. This motivates future studies of these only little explored models. For more information, visit the Generalized Symmetron website.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05774v1.title: The Fate of the Interstellar Medium in Early-type Galaxies. II. Observational Evidence for Morphological Quenching
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05774v1.summary: The mechanism by which galaxies stop forming stars and get rid of theirstellar medium (ISM) remains elusive. Here, we study a sample of more than two thousand elliptical galaxies in which dust emission has been detected. We infer the timescalefor removal of dust in these galaxies and investigate its dependency on physical and environmental properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12541v2.title: Uncovering the geometry of the hot X-ray corona in the Seyfert galaxy NGC4151 with IXPE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12541v2.summary: We present an X-ray spectro-polarimetric analysis of the bright Seyfertgalaxy NGC4151. The polarization could be entirely due to reflection. The observed polarization degree excludes a spherical sphericallamppost geometry for the corona, suggesting instead a slab-like geometry, possibly a wedge.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05753v1.title: Spurious heating of stellar motions by dark matter particles in cosmological simulations of galaxy formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05753v1.summary: We use two cosmological simulations to study the impact of spurious heating of stellar motions within simulated galaxies by dark matter (DM) particles. We find that many galaxy properties are                unaffected by spurious heating, including their masses, star formation histories, and the spatial distribution of their gaseous baryons. The properties of their stellar and DM particles, however, are severely affected. We predict that galaxies in the $100^3\, {\rm Mpc}^3$ EAGLE run and IllustrisTNG-100 are robust to spurious collisional effects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05737v1.title: The broadening of the main sequence in the open cluster M38
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05737v1.summary: A study of the colour width of the lower main sequence of the open cluster M37 has revealed the presence of a sizeable initial chemical composition spread in the cluster. If initial chemicalcomposition spreads are common amongst open clusters, this would have major implications for cluster formation models and the foundation of the chemicaliablytagging technique.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05703v1.title: The ultracompact regions G40.54+2.59 and G34.13+0.47: A new detection of compact radio sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05703v1.summary: Three compact radio sources (CRSs) were detected in the G040irs G040.54+2.59 and G034.13+0.47. CRSs have weak flux densities and are located at the center of their respective \uchii regions. We found no clear association between massive ionizing stars and C RSs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05648v1.title: Implications of the Stellar Mass Density of High-$z$ Massive Galaxies from JWST on Warm Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05648v1.summary: A significant excess of the stellar mass density at high redshift has been discovered from the early data release of James Webb Space Telescope. Warm dark matter (WDM), via the free streaming effect, can suppress the formation of small-scale structure. This provides an effective way to decrease the number of ionizing photons when considering a large star formation efficiency in high-$z$massive galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05619v1.title: Kinematics and flux evolution of superluminal components in QSO B1308+326
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05619v1.summary: Kinematics and flux evolutionobserved at 15GHz for the three superluminal components (knot-c, -i and -k) in QSO B1308+326 (z=0.997) It is shown that the precessing jet nozzle model previously proposed by Qian et al. can be used to fully simulate their kinematics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05508v1.title: Probing Quasar Viewing Angle with the Variability Structure Function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05508v1.summary: Quasar viewing angle affects estimates of the quasar luminosity, black-hole mass and EddingtonRatio. Discs appear overluminous when viewed pole-on and underluminous at high inclination. In radio-quiet quasars, the viewing angle is usually unknown.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05503v1.title: The VISCACHA survey -- VII. Assembly history of the Magellanic Bridge and SMC Wing from star clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05503v1.summary: The formation scenario of the Magellanic Bridge during an encounter between the Large and Small MageLLanic Clouds would be imprinted in the chemical enrichment and kinematicsof its stars. We present an analysis of 33 Bridge star clusters using photometry obtained with the SOAR 4-m telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05502v1.title: Investigating the Impact of Metallicity on Star Formation in the Outer Galaxy. I. VLT/KMOS Survey of Young Stellar Objects in Canis Major
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05502v1.summary: The effects of metallicity on the evolution of protoplanetary disks may be studied in the outer Galaxy. We present the VLT/KMOS integral field spectroscopy in thenear-infrared of candidate young stellar objects (YSOs) in the CMa-$\ell$224 star-forming region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04726v2.title: PEARLS: Low Stellar Density Galaxies in the El Gordo Cluster Observed with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04726v2.summary: A full understanding of how unusually large "Ultra Diffuse Galaxies" (UDGs) fit into our conventional understanding of dwarf galaxies remains elusive. A natural extension of UDG research is the study of similar galaxies at higher redshift to establish how their properties may evolve over time. Here, we present an identification of low stellar surface density galaxies (LDGs) at moderate redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05471v1.title: PRIYA: A New Suite of Lyman-alpha Forest Simulations for Cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05471v1.summary: We present the PRIYA suite of cosmological simulations, based on the code andhydrodynamic model of the ASTRID simulation. We show that patchy helium reionizationimprints an excess in the 1D flux power spectrum on large scales. All our simulations include a full physics model for galaxy formation, including supernova and AGN feedback, and thus also contain a realistic population of DLAs. Our simulation suite will be used to interpret Lyman-$\alpha$forest 1D data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05469v1.title: Coordinated X-ray and UV absorption within the accretion disk wind of the active galactic nucleus PG 1126-041
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05469v1.summary: Accretion disk winds launched close to supermassive black holes (SMBHs) are aiable mechanism to provide feedback between the SMBH and the host galaxy. We aim to characterize the X-ray properties of the inner accretion disk wind of PG 1126-041, and to study its connection with the ultraviolet (UV)-absorbing wind.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05466v1.title: Can the Low Redshift Lyman Alpha Forest Constrain AGN Feedback Models?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05466v1.summary: We investigate the potential of low-redshift Lyman alpha (Ly$\alpha$) forest for constraining active galactic nuclei (AGN) feedback models. We analyze the Illustris and IllustrisTNG simulation at z=0.1. The simulations are ideal for studying the impact of AGN feedback on the intergalactic medium (IGM)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05461v1.title: Revisiting mass estimates of the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05461v1.summary: We use the rotation curve from Gaia data release (DR) 3 to estimate the mass of the Milky Way. We consider an Einasto density profile to model the dark matter component. We extrapolate and obtain a dynamical mass$M=2.75^{+3.11}_{-0.48}\times 10^{11} M_\odot$ at $112$ kpc. This lower-mass Milky Way is consistent with the significant declining rotation curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05455v1.title: Negative Lags on the Viscous Timescale in Quasar Photometry and Prospects for Detecting More with LSST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05455v1.summary: The variability of quasar light curves can be used to study the structure of accretion disks. Detecting these long lags can teach us about the vertical structure ofQuasar disks. The VeraRubin Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) has the potential to detect dozens to hundreds of additional long lag.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05457v1.title: Constraining the LyC escape fraction from LEGUS star clusters with SIGNALS HII region observations: A pilot study of NGC 628
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05457v1.summary: The ionising radiation of young and massive stars is a crucial form ofstellar feedback. Most ionising (Lyman-continuum; LyC)photons are absorbed close to the stars that produce them, but some escape into the wider galaxy. We present a semi-novel method to estimate the escape fraction by combining broadband photometry of star clusters with HII regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05448v1.title: Little Red Dots: an abundant population of faint AGN at $z\sim5$ revealed by the EIGER and FRESCO JWST surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05448v1.summary: Characterising the prevalence and properties of faint active galactic nuclei(AGN) in the early Universe is key for understanding the formation of supermassive black holes. We perform a spectroscopic search for broad H$\alpha$ emitters at $z\approx4-6$ using deep JWST/NIRCam imaging and wide field slitless Spectroscopy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05449v1.title: Circumgalactic Medium on the Largest Scales: Detecting X-ray Absorption Lines with Large-Area Microcalorimeters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05449v1.summary: The circumgalactic medium (CGM) plays a crucial role in galaxy evolution. It fuels star formation, retains metals ejected from the galaxies, and hosts gas flows. For Milky Way-type and more massive galaxies, the bulk of the CGM is in hot phases best accessible at X-ray wavelengths. Traditional absorption studies utilize bright background quasars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05451v1.title: Dependence of galactic bars on the tidal density field in the SDSS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05451v1.summary: Bar formation is potentially linked to the surrounding tidal field. We characterise bar strength using the ellipticity of the isophote thatcorresponds to the bar. We conclude that there is little evidence for the tidal dependence of bar formation in the local Universe, except for the extremely hypertanisotropic environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05453v1.title: Resonant scattering of the OVII X-ray emission line in the circumgalactic medium of TNG50 galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05453v1.summary: We study the impact of resonantly scattered X-ray line emission on theobservability of the hot circumgalactic medium (CGM) of galaxies. Galaxies with higher star formation rates, AGN luminosities, and central OVII(r) Luminosities all have larger scattering enhancements, at fixedstellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05454v1.title: pysersic: A Python package for determining galaxy structural properties via Bayesian inference, accelerated with jax
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05454v1.summary: Pysersic is a Bayesian framework created to facilitate the inference of structural parameters from galaxy images. It is written in pure Python, and is built using the jax framework. Inference is performed with the numpyro package using gradient based methods, for efficient and robust posterior estimation in only a few minutes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05403v1.title: The FRB20190520B Sightline Intersects Foreground Galaxy Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05403v1.summary: The repeating fast radio burst FRB20190520B is an anomaly of the FRBpopulation thanks to its high dispersion measure (DM$=1205\,pc\,cm^{-3}$) Despite its low redshift of $z_\mathrm{frb}=0.241$. This excess has been attributed to a host contribution of $DM_{host}$ far larger than any other known FRB.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02380v3.title: The tilt of the velocity ellipsoid of different Galactic disk populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02380v3.summary: The tilt of the velocity ellipsoid is a helpful tracer of the gravitational potential of the Milky Way. We use nearly 140,000 RC starsselected from the LAMOST and Gaia to make a detailed analysis of the tilt. We determine the age and populationependence of various populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11360v3.title: The massive relic galaxy NGC 1277 is dark matter deficient. From dynamical models of integral-field stellar kinematics out to five effective radii
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11360v3.summary: The best relic galaxy candidate discovered to date is NGC 1277, in the Perseus cluster. By using Jeans anisotropic modelling we find a negligible dark matter fraction within $5 R. We speculate that the relative velocities of. the latter process to happen were possible in the progenitors of the present-day rich galaxy clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05364v1.title: An inflation model for massive primordial black holes to interpret the JWST observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05364v1.summary: The first observations of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have identified six massive galaxy candidates. The presence of suchmassive sources in the early universe challenges the standard $\Lambda$CDMmodel. This tension can be alleviated via the accretion of massive primordial black holes (PBHs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05354v1.title: The correlations between galaxy properties in different environments of the cosmic web
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05354v1.summary: We study the correlations between galaxy properties in different environments of the cosmic web. The stellar mass can be an important link between the galaxy properties and the environment. Our study suggests that the galaxy Properties and theirInterrelationships are susceptible to the geometric environments ofthe cosmicweb.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05332v1.title: A self-gravity module for the PLUTO code
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05332v1.summary: We present a novel implementation of an iterative solver for the solution of the Poisson equation in the PLUTO code for astrophysical fluid dynamics. Our findings show that the RKL-based Poisson solver is both fully parallel andrapidly convergent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10600v2.title: 3-Body Problems, Hidden Constants, Trojans and WIMPs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10600v2.summary: This work includes two new results - principally two new constants of motion for the linearised restricted 3-body problem (e.g. for the Trojan asteroids) and an important isosceles triangle generalisation of Lagrange's equilateraltriangle solution of the restricted case. Both of these results are classical, but we also include new results on Newtonian quantum gravity. The combined effect is to give a new celestial mechanics for WIMPish particles in gravitational systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10932v3.title: Scary Barbie: An Extremely Energetic, Long-Duration Tidal Disruption Event Candidate Without a Detected Host Galaxy at z = 0.995
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10932v3.summary: We report observations of the transient AT 2021lwx (ZTF20abrbeie; aka "Barbie") The host galaxy is notdetected in archival Pan-STARRS observations. Modeling of ZTFphotometry with MOSFiT suggests that the TDE was between a star and a supermassive black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05295v1.title: The Star-forming and Ionizing Properties of Dwarf z~6-9 Galaxies in JADES: Insights on Bursty Star Formation and Ionized Bubble Growth
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05295v1.summary: Reionization is thought to be driven by faint star-forming galaxies, butcharacterizing this population in detail has long remained very challenging. We utilize deep nine-band NIRCam imaging from JADES to study thestar-forming and ionizing properties of 756 $z\sim6-9$ galaxies. We find no evidence for extremely massive galaxies in our sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05252v1.title: Disentangling physics and chemistry in AGB outflows: revealing degeneracies when adding complexity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05252v1.summary: Asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars continue to reveal their chemical and dynamical complexity. Spherical asymmetries, such as spirals and disks, are prevalent and thought to be caused by binaryinteraction with a (sub)stellar companion. High density outflows show evidence of dust-gas interactions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04247v2.title: The scaling relations of galaxies back in time: the road toward virialization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04247v2.summary: This paper shows that the evolution of the SSRs back in time is governed by the combination of the virial theorem (VT) and the relation $L=L'_0 \sigma^{\beta(t)}$ The method we are proposing allows us to decipher the temporal evolution of galaxies. The distribution of galaxies in the SSR is ultimately related to the evolution in luminosity and velocity dispersion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05213v1.title: Investigating the OH-H2 relation in diffuse Galactic clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05213v1.summary: We analyse near-UV spectra extracted from theESO/VLT archives towards seventeen sightlines (five of them new) with known N(H2) N(OH) shows only amarginal correlation with N( H2) (10$^{20}$ to 2 x 10$^{21}$ cm$^{-2}$), at the                95 per cent confidence level. We use orthogonal distance regression analysis to obtain a 33 per cent higher estimate than the previous estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05086v1.title: Beyond Gaia DR3: tracing the [α/M]-[M/H] bimodality from the inner to the outer Milky Way disc with Gaia RVS and Convolutional Neural-Networks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05086v1.summary: Gaia DR3 has provided the community with about one million RVS spectra covering the CaII triplet region. Many of these spectra have low S/N(from 15 to 25 per pixel), such that they pose problems for classical spectralanalysis pipelines. We develop a hybrid Convolutional Neural-Network (CNN) which combines the Gaia DR3 RVSspectra, photometry (G, Bp, Rp), parallaxes, and XP coefficients.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08563v2.title: The Way of Water: ALMA resolves H2O emission lines in a strongly lensed dusty star-forming galaxy at z $\sim$ 3.1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08563v2.summary: We report ALMA high-resolution observations of water emission lines in the strongly lensed galaxy HATLASJ113526. We find that the lines are mainly excited by FIR pumping from dust radiation in a warm and dense environment. We discuss the possibility of J1135 hosting an AGN in its accretion phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05080v1.title: FAST reveals new evidence for M94 as a merger
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05080v1.summary: We report the first high-sensitivity HI observation toward the spiral galaxy M94 with the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST) M94 has a very extended HI disk, twice larger than that observed by THINGS. It is accompanied by an HI filament and seven HVCs (high velocity clouds) at different distances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05062v1.title: A multi-band AGN-SFG classifier for extragalactic radio surveys using machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05062v1.summary: Star-forming galaxies (SFGs) and radio-quiet Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs) are more common at fainter fluxes. Our aim is to develop a machine learning classifier that can efficiently and reliably separate AGNs and SFGs in radio continuum surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02470v2.title: JADES: Differing assembly histories of galaxies -- Observational evidence for bursty SFHs and (mini-)quenching in the first billion years of the Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02470v2.summary: We use deep NIRSpec spectroscopic data from the JADES survey to derive star formation histories. We find that high-redshift and low-mass galaxies have particularly bursty SFHs. We also present the discovery of another quenched galaxy at z = 4.4.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05013v1.title: Dense gas and star formation in the Outer Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05013v1.summary: We present maps and spectra of the HCN(1-0) and HCO$^+$ lines in theextreme outer Galaxy, at galactocentric radii between 14 and 22 kpc. The goal is to better understand the structure of molecular clouds in these poorly studied subsolar metallicityRegions and the relation with star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04963v1.title: KETJU -- resolving small-scale supermassive black hole dynamics in GADGET-4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04963v1.summary: The KETJU supermassive black hole (SMBH) Dynamics module is a new version of GADGET-4. It adds a small region around each SMBH where the dynamics of the black hole and stellar particles are integrated. The code also includes post-Newtonian corrections, which allows following dynamics to sub-parsec scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10543v3.title: B-fields And dust in interstelLar fiLAments using Dust POLarization (BALLAD-POL): I. The massive filament G11.11-0.12 observed by SOFIA/HAWC+
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10543v3.summary: First measurement of polarized thermal dust emission toward the Infrared Dark Cloud G11.11$-$0.12 taken by the SOFIA/HAWC+ at 214 $\mu m$ wavelength. Magnetic fields (B-fields) from the polarized emission tend to be perpendicular to the filament's spine. The depolarization can be explained by the decrease in RAdiative Torque (RAT) efficiency.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02308v2.title: The Assembly of Black Hole Mass and Luminosity Functions of High-redshift Quasars via Multiple Accretion Episodes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02308v2.summary: The early evolution of the quasar luminosity function (QLF) and black holemass function (BHMF) encodes key information on the physics determining theradiative and accretion processes of supermassive black holes (BHs) in high-$z$quasars. Our best-fit model to reproduce the observed QLF and BHMF at $z\simeq 6$ suggests that several episodes of moderate super-Eddingtonaccretion occur.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04888v1.title: Double SSA Spectrum and Magnetic Field Strength of the FSRQ 3C 454.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04888v1.summary: We present the results of a radio multi-frequency study of the blazar 3C~454.3. After subtracting the quiescent spectrum corresponding tooptically thin emission, we found two individual synchrotron self-absorption(SSA) features in the wide-band spectrum. The LSS emitting region was magnetically dominated before the June 2014 $\gamma$-ray flare.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04870v1.title: KMT-2022-BLG-2397: Brown Dwarf at the Upper Shore of the Einstein Desert
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04870v1.summary: KMT-2022-BLG-2397 is at the upper shoreof the Einstein Desert, 9 < theta_E / uas < 25, between free-floating planets (FFPs) and bulge brown dwarfs (BDs) In contrast to the six BD events presented by Gould+22, which all had giant-star source stars, this one has a dwarf- star source. We find `dwarfs' (including main-sequence stars andsubgiants) are likely to yield twice as many theta-E measurements for BDs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04837v1.title: Dear Magellanic Clouds, welcome back!
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04837v1.summary: We propose a scenario in which the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is on its second passage around the Milky Way. The previous pericentre passage of the LMC could have occurred 5-10 Gyr ago at a distance >~100 kpc. In addition to current LMC satellites, it could have brought a further 4-6 galaxies that have since been lost.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.12412v3.title: On the Perturbative Picture and the Chang-Refsdal Lens Approximation for Planetary Microlensing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.12412v3.summary: In the previous work, the planet was considered to act as a uniform-shear Chang-Refsdal lens on one of the two images produced by the host star. However, this approximation is only valid for isolated planetary caustics and breaks down in the resonant regime. In the new work, I introduce a new variable- shear lens approximation, which enables fullagnification maps to be calculated analytically. The analytic and semi-analytic microlensing solutions associated with this work may allow substantially faster light-curve calculations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.01226v2.title: Updated void catalogs of the SDSS DR7 main sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.01226v2.summary: We produce several public void catalogs using a volume-limited subsample of Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 7 (SDSS DR7) We identify 1163, 531, and 518774cosmic voids with radii >10 Mpc/h, respectively, out to a redshift of z = 0.114. Using 64 mock galaxy catalogs created from the Horizon Run 4 N-body simulation, we compare simulated and observed voidproperties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04804v1.title: GHOST Commissioning Science Results: Identifying a new chemically peculiar star in Reticulum II
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04804v1.summary: The Gemini High-resolution Optical SpecTrograph (GHOST) is the newest high-resolution spectrograph to be developed for a large aperture telescope. It was recently deployed and commissioned at the Gemini-South telescope. In this paper, we present the first science results from the GHOST spectrographic taking place during its commissioning runs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04760v1.title: Evidence of Extended Dust and Feedback around z$\approx$1 Quiescent Galaxies via Millimeter Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04760v1.summary: We use public data from the South Pole Telescope (SPT) and Atacama CosmologyTelescope (ACT) to measure the thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich(tSZ) effect and dust emission around massive quiescent galaxies. We analyze the thermal energy and dust mass versus stellar mass via aforward-modeled power-law to correct for photometric stellar massuncertainty.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04722v1.title: SN2023ixf in Messier 101: A Variable Red Supergiant as the Progenitor Candidate to a Type II Supernova
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04722v1.summary: We present pre-explosion optical and infrared (IR) imaging at the site of the SN II supernova (SN II) 2023ixf in Messier 101 at 6.9 Mpc. A single point source is detected at a position consistent with the SN $R$-band to Spitzer 4.5 $\mu$m.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04721v1.title: SN 2023ixf in Messier 101: Photo-ionization of Dense, Close-in Circumstellar Material in a Nearby Type II Supernova
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04721v1.summary: We present UV/optical observations and models of supernova (SN) 2023ixf, a type II SN located in Messier 101 at 6.9 Mpc. Early-time ("flash") spectroscopy reveals emission lines with a narrow core and broad, symmetricwings arising from the photo-ionization of dense, close-in circumstellar material.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04690v1.title: DELVE 6: An Ancient, Ultra-Faint Star Cluster on the Outskirts of the Magellanic Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04690v1.summary: DELVE 6 is an old ($\tau > 9.8$ Gyr, at 95%confidence) and metal-poor stellar system. It is located at an angularseparation of $\sim 10\deg$ from the center of the Small Magellanic Cloud. It may represent only the second or third ancient star cluster associated with the SMC.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04688v1.title: The Prevalence of the $α$-bimodality: First JWST $α$-abundance Results in M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04688v1.summary: We present initial results from our JWST NIRSpec program to study the perceptions$\alpha$-abundances in the M31 disk. The entire stellar population falls along a single chemical sequence similar to the MW's high-alpha component which had a high star formation rate. M31 has had a more active accretion and merger history than the MW.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04684v1.title: Alleviating the need for exponential evolution of JWST galaxies in 10$^{10} M_{\odot}$ haloes at $z > 10$ by a modified $Λ$CDM power spectrum
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04684v1.summary: We infer the evolution of the UV luminosities of galaxies in haloes of masses in the redshift range of $z \sim 9-16$ from the recent JWST data. We discuss the possibleastrophysical and cosmological reasons for such an enhancement. We find that an enhancement of power on scales $k \sim 1$ Mpc$^{-1}$ is able to alleviate this effect.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04679v1.title: A Tight Correlation Between Millimeter and X-ray Emission in Accreting Massive Black Holes from <100 Milliarcsecond-resolution ALMA Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04679v1.summary: Nuclear emission at mm-wavelenghts is nearly ubiquitous in accreting SMBHs. The strong correlation between 100GHzand X-ray emission in radio-quiet AGN could be used to estimate the columndensity based on the ratio between 2-10keV and 100GHz fluxes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04674v1.title: Milky Way satellite velocities reveal the Dark Matter power spectrum at small scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04674v1.summary: Dark Matter (DM) properties at small scales remain uncertain. This work opens a window to probe both dwarf galaxy formation models and small-scale DM properties. The results are robust against baryonicuncertainties such as the stellar mass-halo mass relation, halo occupation and subhalo tidal disruption.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04639v1.title: Lopsidedness as a tracer of early galactic assembly history
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04639v1.summary: Large-scale asymmetries (i.e. lopsidedness) are a common feature in thestellar density distribution of nearby disk galaxies both in low- and high-density environments. Lopsided galaxies have, on average, a very distinct star formation history within the last 10 Gyr, with respect to their symmetric counterparts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08997v2.title: Star Cluster Formation from Turbulent Clumps. III. Across the mass spectrum
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08997v2.summary: We study the formation and early evolution of star clusters that have a widerange of masses and background cloud mass surface densities. Initial clump masses of 300, $3,000$ and $30,000 $ are considered, from which star clusters are born. Clumps of higher mass are of lower initial volume density, but their dynamical evolution leads to higher density clumps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04662v2.title: Efficient NIRCam Selection of Quiescent Galaxies at 3 < z < 6 in CEERS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04662v2.summary: As much as 70\% of quiescent galaxies at $z>3$ may be missed from existing surveys. We propose a new empiricalcolor selection technique designed to select massive quiescence galaxies. Over half of these sources are newly discovered and, on average, exhibit specific star formation rates of post-starburst galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04536v1.title: JADES: The production and escape of ionizing photons from faint Lyman-alpha emitters in the epoch of reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04536v1.summary: We present the properties of 16 faint Lyman-$\alpha$ emitting galaxies (LAEs) from the JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey. These faint LAEs are consistent with metal-poor systems with high ionization parameters, similar to the general galaxy population at $z>6$. We measure an average ionizing photonproduction efficiency that does not evolve strongly with redshift. We use a range of galaxy properties to predict Lyman continuum escape fractions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04524v1.title: ExoMol line lists -- L: High-resolution line lists of H$_3^+$, H$_2$D$^+$, D$_2$H$^+$ and D$_3^+$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04524v1.summary: New MiZo line lists are presented for the D$_2$H$^+$ and D#$_3#$ species. These updates allow accurate frequencies forfar infrared lines for these species to be predicted. Assignments of the energy levels of H$_1$ and H$2$ are extended using a combination of high accuracy calculations and analysis of transition intensities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04513v1.title: ViCTORIA project: The LOFAR HBA Virgo Cluster Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04513v1.summary: The Virgo cluster is the nearest massive galaxy cluster and thus a primetarget to study astrophysical processes in dense large-scale environments. In the radio band, we can probe the non-thermal components of the inter-stellarmedium (ISM), intracluster medium (ICM) and of active galactic nuclei (AGN)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04475v1.title: Palatini $f(R)$ gravity tests in the weak field limit: Solar System, seismology and galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04475v1.summary: Palatini $f(R)$ gravity is probably the simplest extension of generalrelativity (GR) and the simplest realization of a metric-affine theory. It has the same number of degrees of freedom as GR and, in vacuum, it is straightforwardly mapped into GR with a cosmological constant. The mapping between GR and Palatini inside matter is possible but at the expense ofreinterpreting the meaning of the matter fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10941v2.title: A lensed radio jet at milli-arcsecond resolution II: Constraints on fuzzy dark matter from an extended gravitational arc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10941v2.summary: Using a single gravitational lens system, we can place a lower bound on the mass of the fuzzy dark matter (FDM) particle. We generalize our result to non-scalar and multiple-field models, such as vector FDM. Our analysis is directly sensitive to the presence of granule structures in the main dark matter halo of the lens.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04391v1.title: Carbon Abundance of Globular Cluster M22 (NGC 6656) and the Surface Carbon Depletion Rates of the Milky Way Globular Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04391v1.summary: The carbon depletion rates of the second generation of stars are larger than those of the first generation (FG) of stars in our sample GCs. This is likely due to different internal temperature profiles with different initial helium abundances between the FG and SG. Our results can provide critical constraints on understanding the mixing efficiency in the hydrogen burning shell.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04313v1.title: Radiative hydrodynamical simulations of super-Eddington accretion flow in tidal disruption event: the accretion flow and wind
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04313v1.summary: A key question in tidal disruption events theory is how much of thefallback debris can be accreted to the black hole. We find that for a black hole disrupting a solar type star, $15\%$ of the debris could be accretioned. The maximum velocity of wind can reach $0.7c$ (with $c$being speed of light)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04311v1.title: Unraveling the Complexity of Dwarf Galaxy Dynamics: A study of Binary Orbital Motions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04311v1.summary: Many dwarf galaxies experience central density deflated due to binary motions. An extreme binary fraction of 70% can lead to central density deflation of up to 10-20% at 3 km/s. The choice of binary orbit distribution models does not result in significant differences, and observational errors slightly weaken deflations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04266v1.title: Measurements of rate coefficients of CN$^+$, HCN$^+$ and HNC$^+$ collisions with H$_2$ at cryogenic temperatures
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04266v1.summary: A variable temperature 22 pole radio frequencyion trap was used to study the reactions in the temperature range of $17 -250\;\text{K}$. The obtained rate coefficients for the reaction of $CN$ and $HCN$ with $H_2$ are close to the Langevin value. The reaction of $\text{HNC}^+$ with the same value is quickly decreasing with increasing temperature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10531v4.title: JWST UNCOVER: Extremely red and compact object at$z_{\mathrm{phot}}\simeq7.6$ triply imaged by Abell 2744
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10531v4.summary: JWST/NIRCam imaging taken for the ultra-deep UNCOVER program reveals a very red dropout object. The object is a UV-faint dust-obscured quasar-like object, i.e. an active galacticucleus at high redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.17781v3.title: Interpretation of IR variability of AGNs in the hollow bi-conical dust outflow model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.17781v3.summary: We show that, contrary to simple predictions, most AGNs show at best only a small increase of lags with increasing wavelength in the J, H, K, and L bands. We suggest that a possible cause of this near simultaneity of the variability from the near-IR to the mid-IR is that the hot dust is in a hollow bi-conicaloutflow of which we preferentially see the near side.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08960v2.title: A z=1.85 galaxy group in CEERS: evolved, dustless, massive intra-halo light and a brightest group galaxy in the making
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08960v2.summary: CEERS JWST/NIRCam imaging of a massive galaxy group at z=1.85. The group contains >16 members (including 6 spectros. confirmations) down to log10(Mstar/Msun)=8.5. The brightest group galaxy (BGG) is in the process of actively assembling at this redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07278v2.title: The structure of magnetic fields in spiral galaxies: a radio and far-infrared polarimetric analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07278v2.summary: We propose and apply a method to quantify the morphology of the large-scale                ordered magnetic fields (B-fields) in galaxies. We find that the main contribution to the B-field structure of these spiral galaxies comes from the $m=2$ mode. We argue that our approach is moreflexible and model-independent than standard techniques.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04102v1.title: The Progenitor of the Peculiar Galaxy NGC3077
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04102v1.summary: We present a study of the structural properties and metallicity distribution of the nearby peculiar galaxy NGC3077. We show that the galaxy has an extended stellar halo and pronounced "S-shaped" tidal tails that diverge from the radial profile of the inner region. These results suggest that this peculiar galaxy was probably a rather normal dwarf elliptical galaxy before the tidal interaction with M81 and M82.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10268v3.title: Ray-tracing simulations and spectral models of X-ray radiation in dusty media
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10268v3.summary: Dust can play an important role in shaping the X-ray spectra and images ofastrophysical sources. We show how the cross-sections of the photon-gas interaction change depending on the percentage of metals in dust grains. We also show how RefleX can be used to reproduce the dust scattering halos observed in Galacticsources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04063v1.title: On the transition from efficient to inefficient line-driving in irradiated flows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04063v1.summary: At parsecscale distances in AGN, energy transfer can dominate, in which case the only force needed to launch an outflow is that from gas pressure. Only magnetic or radiation forces can then lead to outflow. It is unclear at what temperature and ionization state the radiation force weakens.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04041v1.title: Varstrometry for Off-nucleus and Dual sub-Kpc AGN (VODKA): Investigating the Nature of J0823+2418 at $z=1.81$: a Likely Lensed Quasar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04041v1.summary: Dual quasars at small physical separations are an important precursor phase of galaxy mergers. We find consistent flux ratios between the two sources in optical, NIR, UV, and radio, and similar spectral energy distributions. We conclude that J0823+2418 is likely a lensed quasar and therefore that the VODKA sample contains a population of these lensed systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04035v1.title: WALLABY Pilot Survey: The diversity of HI structural parameters in nearby galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04035v1.summary: We investigate the diversity in the sizes and average surface densities of neutral atomic hydrogen (HI) gas discs in ~280 nearby galaxies. We quantify the HI structure by the size of the HI relative to theoptical disc and the average HI surface density measured using effective andisodensity radii. For galaxies resolved by >1.3 beams, we find that galaxies with higher stellar masses and stellar surface density tend to have less extended HI discs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04024v1.title: The FLAMINGO project: cosmological hydrodynamical simulations for large-scale structure and galaxy cluster surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04024v1.summary: Virgo Consortium's FLAMINGO suite of hydrodynamical simulations for cosmology and galaxy cluster physics. Models are calibrated to the observed low-redshift galaxy stellar mass function and cluster gas fractions. The two most demanding simulations have box sizes of 1.0 and 2.8 Gpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03608v2.title: The NANOGrav 12.5-year Data Set: Bayesian Limits on Gravitational Waves from Individual Supermassive Black Hole Binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03608v2.summary: Pulsar timing array collaborations are seeking to detect nanohertz gravitational waves emitted by supermassive black hole binaries formed in theaftermath of galaxy mergers. We have searched for continuous waves fromindividual circular supermassiveBlackHole binaries using the NANOGrav's 12.5-year data set. We placed 95\% upper limits on the strain amplitude of continuous waves.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03991v1.title: Numerical evidence for a small-scale dynamo approaching solar magnetic Prandtl numbers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03991v1.summary: Magnetic fields on small scales are ubiquitous in the universe. Though they can often be observed in detail, their generation mechanisms are not fully understood. One possibility is the so-called small-scale dynamo (SSD)Prevailing numerical evidence, however, appears to indicate that an SSD is decidedlyunlikely to exist at very low magnetic Prandtl numbers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03966v1.title: The Structure and Dynamics of Massive High-$z$ Cosmic-Web Filaments: Three Radial Zones in Filament Cross-Sections
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03966v1.summary: We analyze the internal cross-section structure and dynamics of inter-haloCosmic-web filaments that connect to massive high-$z$ galaxies. Our analysis is based on a high-resolution cosmological simulation zooming in on three filaments feeding threemassive haloes of $z $ at $z 4.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03944v1.title: The Formation of Magellanic System and the total mass of Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03944v1.summary: The Magellanic Stream is unique to sample the MW potential from 50 kpc to 300 kpc. It is also unique in constraining the LMC mass, an increasinglyimportant question for the Local Group/Milky Way modeling. This model has been successful in predicting most recent observations in both properties ofstellar and gas phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03931v1.title: JADES: Balmer Decrement Measurements at redshifts 4 < z < 7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03931v1.summary: We present Balmer decrement measurements for a sample of 51 galaxies at redshifts z = 4-7 observed with the JWST/NIRSpec MSA, as part of the JADES survey. The lowest-mass galaxies inour sample (Mstar = 1-3 x 10^7 Msun ) display a remarkably low Balmerdecment of 2.88 $\pm$ 0.08.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03926v1.title: Corrected SFD: A More Accurate Galactic Dust Map with Minimal Extragalactic Contamination
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03926v1.summary: The widely used Milky Way dust reddening map was found to contain extragalactic large-scale structure imprints (Chiang & M\'enard 2019) Such contamination is inherent in mapsbased on infrared emission. We build a large set of 180 overcomplete, full-sky basis template maps from thedensity fields of over 450 million galaxies in WISE. We release this new dust map dubbed CSFD, the Corrected SFD, to the community.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03924v1.title: Monte-Carlo Stellar Dynamics near Massive Black Holes: Two-dimensional Fokker-Planck solutions of multiple mass components
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03924v1.summary: A Monte-Carlo code allows the investigation of dynamical relaxation in clusters of supermassive black holes. The method is based on two-dimensional Fokker-Planckequations in the energy and angular momentum space. The codedemonstrates remarkable flexibility to incorporate additional complex dynamics, such as resonant relaxations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03920v1.title: Outflow densities and ionisation mechanisms in the NLRs of the prototypical Seyfert galaxies NGC 1068 and NGC 4151
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03920v1.summary: The true impact of outflows driven by active galactic nuclei (AGN) on their host galaxies is unclear. In part, this may be because electron densities of gas are often underestimated. Outflow ionisation mechanisms are also uncertain. To address these issues, we have analysed archival HST/STIS spectra of the inner regions of two galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03916v1.title: Connecting the escape fraction of Lyman-alpha and Lyman-continuum photons in star-forming galaxies at $\mathbf{z\simeq 4-5}$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03916v1.summary: We present a study of the connection between the escape fraction of Lyman-alpha (Ly$\alpha$) andLyman-continuum (LyC) photons within a sample of N=152 star-forming galaxies. In accordance with previous studies, we find a positive correlation between $f.$W_\lambda(Ly\alpha)$ and $f_{\rm{esc}}^{Ly\ alpha}$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03914v1.title: The fastest stars in the Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03914v1.summary: We report a spectroscopic search for hypervelocity white dwarfs (WDs) that are runaways from Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) and related thermonuclearexplosions. Candidates are selected from Gaia data with high tangential                velocities and blue colors. We find six new runaways, including four stars with acceleratingradial velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.12365v2.title: The Astrodust+PAH Model: A Unified Description of the Extinction, Emission, and Polarization from Dust in the Diffuse Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.12365v2.summary: We present a new model of interstellar dust in which large grains are a single composite material, ''astrodust,'' and nanoparticle-sized grains come in varieties including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) We arguethat a single-composition model for grains larger than $0.02 explains the lack of frequency dependence in the far-infrared.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04613v2.title: Breakdown of the Newton-Einstein Standard Gravity at Low Acceleration in Internal Dynamics of Wide Binary Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04613v2.summary: A gravitational anomaly is found at weak gravitational acceleration. The anomaly systematically deviates from the Newtonian expectation. The deviation represents a direct evidence for the breakdown of standard gravity. The empirical acceleration relation at $< 10^{-9}$ m s$^{-2}$ systematicallydeviates from Newton's expectation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16127v2.title: Radio Galaxy Zoo: Building a multi-purpose foundation model for radio astronomy with self-supervised learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16127v2.summary: In this work, we apply self-supervised learning with instance differentiation to learn a robust, multi-purpose representation for image analysis. We train a multi-use model which compresses ourunlabelled data into a structured, low dimensional representation. We exceed baseline supervised Fanaroff-Riley classification performance by a statistically significant margin.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18012v2.title: Large-scale turbulent driving regulates star formation in high-redshift gas-rich galaxies II: Influence of the magnetic field and the turbulent compressive fraction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18012v2.summary: The observed star formation rate (SFR) in galaxies is well below what it would be if gravitational collapse alone were at play. We find that the outcome strongly depends on the initial magnetic field and on the compressibility of the turbulent driving. A higher magneticfield in high column density environment may lower the energy necessary to sustain a turbulence that is sufficiently intense to regulate star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03728v1.title: Young Stellar Object Candidates in IC 417
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03728v1.summary: IC 417 is in the Galactic Plane, and likely part of the Aur OB2 association. Stock 8 is one of the densest cluster constituents. There is a 'Nebulous Stream' (NS) that is dramatic in the IR. The lowest-ranked bins include stars that are confused, or likely carbon stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03703v1.title: Relativistic phase space diffusion of compact object binaries in stellar clusters and hierarchical triples
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03703v1.summary: LIGO/Virgo detections of compact object mergers have posed a challenge for theories of binary evolution and coalescence. One promising avenue for producing mergers dynamically is through secular eccentricity oscillations driven by an external perturber. The simplest theoretical models of these oscillations use a 'doubly-averaged' (DA) approximation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01563v2.title: Inaccuracies and biases of the Gaussian size deconvolution for extracted sources and filaments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01563v2.summary: A simple Gaussian size deconvolution method is routinely used to remove the blurry images caused by insufficient angular resolutions of existingtelescopes. The method is expected to work when theructure, as well as the telescope beams, have Gaussian shapes. When background subtraction is inaccurate, the structures acquire profoundly non-Gaussian profiles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09628v2.title: The Implications of Ultra-Faint Dwarf Galaxy Reticulum II on the Common Envelope Jets Supernova r-process Scenario
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09628v2.summary: We show that the common envelope jets supernova (CEJSN) r-process scenario iscompatible with very recent observationally determined properties of the stars in Reticulum II. The compatibility that we find between the CEJSN r- process scenario and new observations suggests that the CEjSN r/P scenariosupplies a non-negligible fraction of the r- Process elements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03472v1.title: Black Hole masses for 14 gravitational lensed quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03472v1.summary: We use spectroscopic data from the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) and the Very Large Telescope (VLT) to measure the FWHM of the broad emission lines. Combined with the bolometric luminosity measured from the spectra energy distribution, we estimate the masses of 14 lensed quasars. We have increased the sample of lenses with estimates of MBH by 20%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03404v1.title: An Escaping Outflow in a Galaxy with an Intermediate-mass Black Hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03404v1.summary: In massive galaxies active galactic nuclei (AGN) feedback plays animportant role. The role of AGN feedback is still under debate in dwarfgalaxies. The outflow size of our AGN is found to be larger than AGN in massive galaxies at the given AGN [O III] luminosity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03385v1.title: Exploring the Impact of Galactic Interactions and Mergers on the Central Star Formation of APEX/EDGE-CALIFA Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03385v1.summary: Galactic interactions and subsequent mergers are a paramount channel forgalaxy evolution. We show that the impact of interactions and mergers in the center of galaxies is revealed as anincrease in the fraction of molecular gas. We suggest that gravitational torques due to the interaction and subsequent merger transport cold molecular gas inwards, increasing the gas fraction without necessarily increasing star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03357v1.title: Varstrometry Selected Radio-Loud Candidates of Dual and Off-Nucleus Quasars at Sub-kpc Scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03357v1.summary: Dual super massive black holes at sub-kpc to kpc scales are progenitors of eventually coalescing binary SMBHs. Studying such systems is essential to learn the dynamicalevolution of binary SMbHs as well as the process of galaxy merging. If both or one of the dual SMHs are accreting, they may appear as dual AGNs or off-nucleus AGNs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03342v1.title: First Detection of A Linear Structure in the Midplane of the Young HH 211 Protostellar Disk: A Spiral Arm?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03342v1.summary: Spiral structures have been detected in evolved protostellar disks, driving the disk accretion towards the central protostars to facilitate star formation. It is still unclear if these structures can form earlier in youngprotostellar. disks. With the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array, we have detected and spatially resolved a very young and nearly edge-ondusty disk with a radius of only 20 au.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03323v1.title: Many Roads Lead to Lithium: Formation Pathways For Lithium-Rich Red Giants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03323v1.summary: Stellar models predict that lithium (Li) inside a star is destroyed during the first dredge-up phase. Yet 1.2% of red giant stars are Li-rich. We aim to uncover possible origins of this population, by analysing 1155 Li- rich giants in GALAH DR3.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.05003v2.title: A non-interacting Galactic black hole candidate in a binary system with a main-sequence star
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.05003v2.summary: We describe the discovery of a solar neighborhood (d=468 pc) binary system with a main-sequence sunlike star and a massive non-interacting black hole candidate. The spectrum shows no indication of a second luminous component. To determine the spectroscopic orbit of the binary, we measured radial velocities with the Automated Planet Finder, Magellan, and Keck.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.03281v2.title: JWST NIRCam+NIRSpec: Interstellar medium and stellar populations of young galaxies with rising star formation and evolving gas reservoirs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.03281v2.summary: We present an interstellar medium and stellar population analysis of three galaxies in the SMACS J0723.3-7327 cluster. We find that these three $z=7.6-8.5$ galaxies are young with rising SFHs and rising mass-weighted ages of $3-4$ Myr. The galaxy with the lowest gas-phase metallicity is very compact and has a high star-formation rate surface density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07234v2.title: JADES Imaging of GN-z11: Revealing the Morphology and Environment of a Luminous Galaxy 430 Myr After the Big Bang
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07234v2.summary: We present JWST NIRCam 9-band near-infrared imaging of the luminous $z=10.6$galaxy GN-z11. We find a spectral energy distribution (SED) entirely consistent with the expected form of a high-redshift galaxy. A low-surface brightness haze about $0.4''$ to the northeast of the galaxy is most likely a foreground object.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03224v1.title: BAL effect in quasars due to source orientation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03224v1.summary: We investigated a scenario where the presence of a broad absorption line (BAL) feature in quasars (QSOs) is contingent upon the line of sight being within an outflow cone emanating from the source. We examined themechanism of dust-driven winds based on the failed radiatively accelerateddusty outflow (FRADO) model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03205v1.title: Resolving galactic-scale obscuration of X-ray AGN at $z\gtrsim1$ with COSMOS-Web
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03205v1.summary: A large fraction of the accreting supermassive black hole population is shrouded by copious amounts of gas and dust. While much of the obscuration is attributed to a Parsec-scale torus, there is a known contribution from the larger-scale host galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03201v1.title: Analysis of Integral Field Spectroscopy observations of the planetary nebula Hen 2-108 and its central star
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03201v1.summary: Hen 2-108 is a poorly known planetary nebula with a slight elliptical morphology and a peculiar central star. The spectrum of the CS has been analysed with a detailed model for expanding atmospheres to infer stellarparameters. We detect and measure a number of faint heavy element recombination lines from which we find a significant abundance discrepancy factor.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03199v1.title: Rotation curves and dynamical masses of MaNGA barred galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03199v1.summary: In this paper we analyse a sample of 46 barred galaxies of MaNGA. We aim to derive the total stellar and dynamicalmasses, as well as the maximum rotation velocity. Using the Pipe3D dataproducts publicly available we obtained the rotation curves. We found a strong correlation between dynamical mass and maximum velocity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03156v1.title: On the general nature of 21cm-Lyman-$α$ emitters cross-correlations during reionisation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03156v1.summary: 21cm emission from spin-flip transition of neutral hydrogen (HI) and early Lyman-$\alpha$ radiation emitting galaxies. We explore how the characteristics of the cross-correlation functions between galaxies depend on the reionisation history and topology. We develop an analytic expression for the 21cm-LAE cross-Correlation function.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03153v1.title: Observations of neutral carbon in 29 high-z lensed dusty star forming galaxies and the comparison of gas mass tracers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03153v1.summary: The nature and evolution of high-redshift dusty star-forming galaxies remain an open question. Their massive gas reservoirs play an important role in driving the intense star-formation rates hosted in these galaxies. We aim to estimate the molecular gas content of these galaxies by using various gasmass tracers such as the [CI] emission lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03152v1.title: Spatial variations in aromatic hydrocarbon emission in a dust-rich galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03152v1.summary: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are large organic molecules that tracemillimeter-size dust grains. Dust grains absorb half of the radiation emitted by stars throughout the history of the universe, re-emitting this energy at infrared wavelengths. Observations of PAH features in very distant galaxies have been difficult due to the limited sensitivity and wavelength coverage of previous infrared telescopes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03146v1.title: The origin of cold gas in the Circumgalactic Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03146v1.summary: The presence of cold gas in the circumgalactic medium (CGM) of galaxies has been confirmed both in observations and high-resolution simulations. Possible mechanisms are cold accretion from the IGM, clumps embedded in outflows and transported from the disk. Gas detaching from the hot CGM phase via thermalinstabilities is also discussed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03139v1.title: Probing the Heart of Active Narrow-line Seyfert 1 Galaxies with VERA Wideband Polarimetry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03139v1.summary: We explored the parsec-scale nuclear regions of a sample of radio-loud Seyfert 1 galaxies (NLSy1s) Using the VLBI Exploration of RadioAstronomy (VERA) wideband (at a recording rate of $16\,\mathrm{Gbps}$) we detected Faradayrotation toward the radio core. The observed polarimetric properties of NLSy 1s are rather similar to those of flat-spectrum radio quasars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03141v1.title: Cosmic ray feedback in galaxies and galaxy clusters -- A pedagogical introduction and a topical review of the acceleration, transport, observables, and dynamical impact of cosmic rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03141v1.summary: Recent advances in astrophysical feedback strongly suggest that cosmic rays (CRs) may becrucially important for our understanding of cosmological galaxy formation. Understanding the physical mechanisms that control galaxy formation is afundamental challenge in contemporary astrophysics. The field is ripe for discovery and will remain the subject of intense theoretical, computational, and observational research over the next decade.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03136v1.title: HOLISMOKES -- XI. Evaluation of supervised neural networks for strong-lens searches in ground-based imaging surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03136v1.summary: Supervised neural networks have become state of the art for identifying rare strong gravitational lenses from large imaging data sets. Their selection remains significantly affected by the large number and diversity of nonlens contaminants. This work evaluates and compares systematically theperformance of neural networks in order to move towards a rapid selection of galaxy-scale strong lenses with minimal human input.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03131v1.title: How the dynamical properties of globular clusters impact their $γ$-ray and X-ray emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03131v1.summary: The X-ray and $\gamma$-ray emission of globular clusters (GCs) is attributed to their large fraction of compact binary systems. We analyze a population of 124 Galactic GCs to determine how their dynamical properties affect the formation and evolution of compact binaries. We find that the total number of X-rays within a GC and its luminosity are linearly correlated with the stellar encounter rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03132v1.title: Benchmarking Gaia DR3 Apsis with the Hyades and Pleiades open clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03132v1.summary: The Gaia astrophysical parameters inference system (Apsis) providesastrophysical parameter estimates for several to 100s of millions of stars. We have compiled about 1500 bona fide singlestars in the Hyades and Pleiades open clusters for validation of PARSECisochrones, and for comparison with Apsis estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03129v1.title: The relation of cosmic environment and morphology with the star formation and stellar populations of AGN and non-AGN galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03129v1.summary: In this work, we study the relation of cosmic environment and morphology with the star-formation (SF) and the stellar population of galaxies. Mostimportantly, we examine if this relation differs for systems with active and non-active supermassive black holes. We use 551 X-raydetected active galactic nuclei (AGN) and 16,917 non-AGN galaxies in the COSMOS-Legacy survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03124v1.title: The cosmic web around the Coma cluster from constrained cosmological simulations: I. Filaments connected to Coma at $z = 0$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03124v1.summary: Galaxy clusters in the Universe occupy the important position of nodes of the cosmic web. They are connected among them by filaments, elongated structures composed of dark matter, galaxies, and gas. The connection of galaxy clusters to filaments is important, as it is related to the process of matter accretion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03126v1.title: Stragglers of the thick disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03126v1.summary: Young alpha-rich (YAR) stars have been detected in the past as outliers to local age relation. These objects are enhanced in elements but apparently younger than typical thick disc stars. They are shifted in oxygen, magnesium, sodium, and the slow neutron-capture element cerium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03120v1.title: JADES: Detecting [OIII]$λ4363$ Emitters and Testing Strong Line Calibrations in the High-$z$ Universe with Ultra-deep JWST/NIRSpec Spectroscopy up to $z \sim 9.5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03120v1.summary: 10 novel auroral line detections measured from ultra-deep JWST/NIRSpec MSA spectroscopy. We leverage the deepestspectroscopic observations yet taken with NIRSpec. We find weak dependence between R2 and O3O2 with metallicity, thus suggesting these line-ratios are ineffective in the high-$z$ Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03084v1.title: The stellar mass of the Gaia-Sausage/Enceladus accretion remnant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03084v1.summary: The Gaia-Sausage/Enceladus (GS/E) structure is an accretion remnant in the Milky Way's halo that constitutes a large fraction of the nearby stellar halo. We study GS/E using high-purity samples of kinematically selected stars from APOGEE DR16 and Gaia.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03048v2.title: Runaway and Hypervelocity Stars from Compact Object Encounters in Globular Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03048v2.summary: The dense environments in the cores of globular clusters (GCs) facilitate strong dynamical encounters among stellar objects. These encounters have been shown capable of ejecting stars from the host GC, whereupon they become hypervelocity stars if unbound to the galactic potential. We find that these kinds of encounters can accelerate stars to speeds in excess of 2000 km/s.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.17959v2.title: Implications of $z>{\sim}12$ JWST galaxies for galaxy formation at high redshift
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.17959v2.summary: Using a semi-analytic galaxy-formation model, we study analogues of 8 recently discovered JWST galaxies. We select analogues from a cosmological simulation with a $311 cMpc^3$ volume. The properties of these analogues broadly agree with conventional SED fitting results. We find that only a handful of bright galaxy analogues can be identified.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11298v3.title: Near-infrared characterization of ultra-diffuse galaxies in Abell 2744 by JWST/NIRISS imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11298v3.summary: We present a search and characterization of ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) in the Frontier Fields cluster Abell~2744 at $z=0.308$. We use JWST/NIRISS F200Wobservations, acquired as part of the GLASS-JWST Early Release Science Program. A total number of 22 UDGs are identified by our selection criteria using morphological parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02877v1.title: Deuterium Fractionation across the Infrared Dark Cloud G034.77-00.55 interacting with the Supernova Remnant W44
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02877v1.summary: Supernova remnants (SNRs) may regulate star formation in galaxies. SNR-driven shocks may form new molecular gas or compress pre-existingclouds and trigger the formation of new stars. To test this scenario, we measure the deuteration of $N_2H^+$, a well-studied tracer of pre-stellar cores.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02852v1.title: FAUST X. Multi-band, multi-scale dust study of L1527 IRS. Evidence for dust properties variations within the envelope of a Class 0/I YSO
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02852v1.summary: Early dust grain growth in protostellar envelopes infalling on young discs has been suggested in recent studies. We aim to determine the maximum grain size of the dust population in the envelope of the Class 0/I protostar L1527 IRS, located in the Taurus star-forming region. We discuss how in-situ grain growth, dust differential collapse from the parent core, or upward transport of disc large grains.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02839v1.title: Measuring Galaxy Asymmetries in 3D
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02839v1.summary: 3D version of the asymmetry statistic that can be applied to datacubes. More resilient to variations due to the observed geometry than 1D asymmetry measures. Can be successfully applied to lower spatial resolutions (3-4-miles across galaxy major axis) than 2D statistic.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18077v3.title: New filamentary remnant radio emission and duty cycle constraints in the radio galaxy NGC 6086
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18077v3.summary: Radio galaxies are a subclass of active galactic nuclei in which accretiononto the supermassive black hole releases energy via relativistic jets. Remnant radio galaxies are discovered during a quiescent phase and define a class of unique sources. We present, a spatially resolved radio analysis of the radio galaxy associated with NGC 6086.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02791v1.title: Dating young open clusters using delta Scuti stars. Results for Trumpler 10 and Praesepe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02791v1.summary: Seismic indices such as the large separation and thefrequency at maximum power can help to constrain the models to bettercharacterise the stars. We propose a reliable method to identify some radialmodes, which gives us greater confidence in the constrained models. We estimate the age of Trumpler 10 to be $30_{-20}{+30}$ Myr, and that of Praesepe to be £580 \pm 230$ Myr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02179v2.title: The GLASS-JWST Early Release Science Program. II. Stage I release of NIRCam imaging and catalogs in the Abell 2744 region
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02179v2.summary: Images and a multi-wavelength photometric catalog based on all of the JWST NIRCam observations obtained to date in the region of the Abell 2744galaxy cluster. Data come from three different programs, namely the GLASS-JWST Early Release Science Program, UNCOVER, and Director's DiscretionaryTime program 2756.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14881v1.title: Molecular gas distribution and CO-to-H2 conversion factors in CO-faint low-metallicity dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14881v1.summary: Low-metallicity dwarf galaxies often show no or little CO emission, despite intense star formation observed in local samples. Constraining the relative importance ofCO-bright versus CO-dark H2 star-forming reservoirs is crucial to understand how star formation proceeds at low metallicity. We find that galaxies with high clumpiness may have CO-to-H2 conversion factor as low as the Galactic value.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14843v1.title: Merger-driven infall of metal-poor gas in luminous infrared galaxies: a deep dive beneath the mass-metallicity relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14843v1.summary: The build up of heavy elements and the stellar mass assembly are fundamental processes in the formation and evolution of galaxies. This is especially true for luminous and massive galaxies, which usually suffer strong feedback in the form of massive outflows, and large-scale gas accretion. For a sample of 77 luminousinfrared (IR) galaxies, we derive chemical abundances using new diagnostics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12363v2.title: Detection and characterization of M-L-T-Y dwarfs belonging to the Milky Way Disks and Stellar Halo with the Roman Space Telescope
