http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12363v2.summary: The High Latitude Survey with the Roman Space Telescope can search for low-mass stars, brown dwarfs and free-floating planets in our Galaxy. It can accurately model the 3D structure and the temperature and chemical evolution of the Milky Way. The totalnumber of each brown dwarf type can be used to infer the Galaxy-wide Initial Mass Function for the first time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01038v2.title: Clouds accreting from the IGM are not able to feed the star formation of low-redshift disc galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01038v2.summary: Galactic halos accrete material from the intergalactic medium (IGM) and part of this accretion is expected to be in the form of cool gas. Whether this material is able to feed star formation or evaporates into the CGM hot phase (corona) is not yet understood. We explore the evolution of cool CGM clouds accreted from the IGM and falling through the hot corona of low-redshift disc galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07745v2.title: Using [Ne V]/[Ne III] to Understand the Nature of Extreme-Ionization Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07745v2.summary: Spectroscopic studies of extreme-ionization galaxies (EIGs) are critical to understanding of exotic systems throughout cosmic time. These EIGs exhibitspectral features requiring >54.42 eV photons: the energy needed to fullyionize helium into He2+ and emit He II recombination lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14760v1.title: The temporal evolution of gas accretion onto the discs of simulated Milky Way-mass galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14760v1.summary: In the standard model of structure formation, galaxies form in the centre of dark matter haloes. After an initial period of violent growth, the gas settles into arotationally-supported structure where stars are born. The accretion of gaseous material onto the disc plays a fundamental role in its evolution as it can change its dynamical andmorphological properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.14476v2.title: A Transient Overcooling in the Early Universe? Clues from Globular Clusters Formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.14476v2.summary: Multiple stellar generations in Milky Way globular clusters indicates that each generation was unable to stop star formation. This evidence argues for an extended stage of star formation within a forming globular cluster, during which stellar feedback was substantially ineffective. It has been argued that such delayed feedback results from core collapse in most massive stars failing to trigger an energetic supernova explosion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14710v1.title: ALMA-IMF VII -- First release of the full spectral line cubes:Core kinematics traced by DCN J=(3-2)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14710v1.summary: ALMA-IMF is an Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) Large Program designed to measure the core mass function (CMF) of 15 protoclusters. The data include 12 spectral windows, with eight at 1.3mm and four at 3mm. We find that DCN (3-2) is detected toward a higher percentage of cores in evolved regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10109v2.title: Anisotropic strong lensing as a probe of dark matter self-interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10109v2.summary: Galaxy-scale strongly lensed systems have been shown to provide a uniquetechnique for exploring the underlying physics of dark matter at sub-galacticscales. In the past, much attention was given to detecting and studying individual haloes in a strong lens system. In this study, we show that line-of-sight haloes also produce a non-zero curl component of the effective deflection field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10902v2.title: Particles in Relativistic MHD Jets I: Effects of Jet Dynamics on Particle Acceleration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10902v2.summary: Relativistic jets from (supermassive) black holes are typically observed in non-thermal emission. Here, we study the interrelation between three-dimensional (special) relativisticmagnetohydrodynamics, and particle acceleration in these jets. We consider three different injection nozzles -- injecting steady, variable and precessing jets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14573v1.title: Hydrodynamic simulations of the Disk of Gas Around Supermassive black holes (HDGAS) -I; Molecular Gas Dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14573v1.summary: We present hydrodynamic simulations of the interstellar medium (ISM) within a typical AGN-dominated galaxy. We find that the inclusion of an AGN promotes the formation of CO in clumpy and dense regions surrounding supermassive-blackholes (SMBH) The CO(1-0) intensity maps seem to match well with observations of NGC 1068.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06184v2.title: Quantifying the influence of bars on action-based dynamical modelling of disc galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06184v2.summary: Action-based dynamical modelling, using stars as dynamical tracers, is an excellent diagnostic to estimate the underlying axisymmetric matter and distribution of the Milky Way. The Milky Way's bar causesnon-axisymmetry resonance features in the stellar disc. Survey volumes along the bar major axis produce larger (relative)errors in the best-fit parameter values.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14549v1.title: SHOTGLAS II. MUSE spectroscopy of blue horizontal branch stars in the core of $ω$ Centauri and NGC 6752
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14549v1.summary: In this work, we characterize the properties of HB stars in the GCs. We use dedicated model atmospheres and synthetic spectra computed using a hybrid LTE/NLTE modeling approach. The atmospheric and stellar properties that we derive are in good agreement with the theoreticalexpectations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14531v1.title: Episodic infall towards a compact disk in B335?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14531v1.summary: The presence of an outflow in B335 suggests that also a disk should be present or in formation. To constrain the earliest stages of protostellar evolution and disk formation, we aim to map the region where gas falls inwards and constrain its kinematics. We aim to put stronglimits on the size and orientation of any disk-like structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00366v3.title: CzSL: Learning from citizen science, experts and unlabelled data in astronomical image classification
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00366v3.summary: Citizen science is gaining popularity as a valuable tool for labelling large collections of astronomical images by the general public. This is often at the cost of poorer quality classifications made by amateur participants. The proposed approach first learns from unlabelled data with a convolutional autoencoder and then exploits amateur and expert labels via the pre-training and fine-tuning of a neural network.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12459v2.title: Asteroseismic sounding of bulge globular clusters with the Roman Space Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12459v2.summary: Globular clusters are relics of the early Universe and hold clues to stellar and galactic evolution. We propose to point the RomanSpace Telescope at one or more clusters either as a part of or as an extension of the Galactic Bulge Time Domain Survey. This would provide a unique opportunity to apply the powerful toolkit of asteroseismology to a globular cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14456v1.title: Rejuvenating Star Formation Activity in an Early-type Dwarf Galaxy, LEDA 1915372, with Accreted HI Gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14456v1.summary: An early-type dwarf galaxy, LEDA 1915372, is accreting gas from a nearby star-forming dwarf, MRK 0689. The two galaxies are located in a small group environment, separated by a sky-projected distance of 20.27 kpc. The gas components of both galaxies share a common direction of rotateation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11666v2.title: Neural Astrophysical Wind Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11666v2.summary: The bulk kinematics and thermodynamics of hot supernovae-driven galacticwinds is critically dependent on both the amount of swept up cool clouds and non-spherical collimated flow geometry. However, accurately parameterizing these physics is difficult because their functional forms are often unknown. We show that deep neural networks embedded as individual terms in the governing ordinary differential equations can robustly discover both of these physics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14354v1.title: The Swift Deep Galactic Plane Survey (DGPS) Phase-I Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14354v1.summary: The Deep Galactic Plane Survey is a Key Project. 380 tiled pointings covering 40 deg$^{2}$ of the Galactic Plane. Each pointing has a $5$ ks exposure, yielding a total of 1.9 Ms spread across the entire survey footprint. In total, we identify 928 X-ray sources, of which 348 are unique.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14334v1.title: The luminosity-area relation of $z>2$ quasars' Ly$α$ nebulae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14334v1.summary: Cool gas is commonly observed around $z>2$ quasars as traced by extended Ly$\alpha$ emission. Most nebulae aresymmetric and bright, the most lopsided ones being the faintest and the less extended. The Enormous Lyman-Alpha Nebulae, asymmetric due to the presence of active companions, are the exceptions to this trend.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.07021v2.title: The molecular chemistry of Type Ibc supernovae, and diagnostic potential with the James Webb Space Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.07021v2.summary: Molecules are predicted to form in SESN ejecta in significant quantities. The impact on the temperature andoptical emission depends on the density of the oxygen zones. Observations of SESNe with JWST hold promise to provide the first detections of SiS and SO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14283v1.title: The Origin of Star Formation in Early-type Galaxies Inferred from Spatially Resolved Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14283v1.summary: Star-forming early-type galaxies have two distinctive episodes of starformation. This is similar to late- type galaxies, but different from quiescent early-types with a single star formation episode. Our findings suggest that the current star formation in these galaxies has an external origin including galaxy mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14267v1.title: On the Proposed Interstellar Origin of the USG 20140108 Fireball
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14267v1.summary: A critical review of the evidence for the interstellar origin for the USG20140108 fireball is presented. Examining USG fireball velocities where vantage data are available shows the former to have significant (10-15km/s) uncertainties at large speeds. Ablation model fits to the observed lightcurve are possible for normal chondritic impactors only assuming low speeds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14206v1.title: Weisfeiler-Lehman Graph Kernel Method: A New Approach to Weak Chemical Tagging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14206v1.summary: The study utilized the Weisfeiler-Lehman (WL) Graph Kernel to examine a 15-dimensional elemental abundance space. The results highlight the capability of the WL algorithm, coupled with Gaussian Process Regression, to identify patterns within elemental point clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01246v2.title: Distance of PSR B0458+46 indicated by FAST HI absorption observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01246v2.summary: The pulsar B0458+46 was previously believed to have a distance of about 1.3 kpc and to be associated with a nearby supernova remnant, SNR HB9. The doubled distance indicates a deficiency of thermal electrons in the immediate outer outer galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14100v1.title: Unusual integrated metallicity profile of our Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14100v1.summary: Low-redshift galaxies generally have a negative metallicity gradient in their gas and stars. Such gradients are thought to be a natural manifestation of galaxy inside-out formation. The analysis of the TNG50 simulated galaxies suggests that the Milky Way's positive inner gradient may be due to an inside-outsquenching process.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11895v2.title: Performance of FAST with an Ultra-Wide Bandwidth Receiver at 500-3300 MHz
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11895v2.summary: A new Ultra-Wide Bandwidth (UWB) receiver has been mounted in the FAST feed cabin. The whole UWB band is separated into four independent bands. Each band has 1048576 channels in total, resulted in a spectral resolution of 1 kHz. At 500-3300 MHz, the antenna gain is around 14.3-7.7 K/Jy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14025v1.title: Time series photometry and multi-wavelength characterisation of the young stellar cluster Mon R2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14025v1.summary: Using the Las Cumbres Observatory Global Telescope Network (LCOGT), we have monitored over 6000 sources with $i$-band between 13 and 23 mag within a $ 26'x26'$ field of view. Based on these data, we have measured the rotations of 136 stars and identified around 90 additional variables, including 14 eclipsing binary candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13930v1.title: Probing the origin of the two-component structure of broad line region by reverberation mapping of an extremely variable quasar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13930v1.summary: The physical origins of components in the unified model of quasars such asbroad line region (BLR), dust torus, and narrow line region are unresolved. We aimed to understand the central core structure of one of the most variable Changing-State Quasars, SDSSJ125809.31+351943.0.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.11217v3.title: Covariant Formulation of refracted gravity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.11217v3.summary: We propose a covariant formulation of refracted gravity (CRG) CRG is based on the introduction of gravitational permittivity (GP) GP mimics dark matter (DM) phenomenology. We find that the same field that mimics DM also drives the accelerated expansion of the universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13846v1.title: Multi-scale accretion in dense cloud cores and the delayed formation of massive stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13846v1.summary: The formation mechanism of massive stars remains one of the main open problem                in astrophysics. Here we present a model thatorporates accretion onto the cores as well as onto the stars. This model constitutes a proof-of-concept for the simultaneous growth of the gas reservoir and thestellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.14329v2.title: Detection of stellar light from quasar host galaxies at redshifts above 6
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.14329v2.summary: Low-luminosity quasars from Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru Strategic Program (HSC-SSP) mitigate the challenge of detecting their underlying, previously-undetected host galaxies. The host galaxies are massive, compact, and disk-like. Their location in the black hole mass - stellar mass plane is consistent with the distribution at low redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08028v2.title: The impact of baryonic potentials on the gravothermal evolution of self-interacting dark matter haloes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08028v2.summary: The presence of a central baryonic potential can have a significant impact on the gravothermal evolution of self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) haloes. The presence of the potential induces changes in SIDM haloproperties, including central density, core size, and velocity dispersion, and accelerates the halo's evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13808v1.title: Improving the selection of changing-look AGNs through multi-wavelength photometric variability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13808v1.summary: We use a random-forest-based light curve classifier and spectroscopic follow-up to confirm 50 per cent of candidates as turning-on CLs. Most of the not-confirmed CLs are consistent with weak Type 1s dominated by host-galaxy contributions. The confirmed CLs present stronger optical fluctuations and experience a long increase in their MIR fluxes and the colour W1-W2 over time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13798v1.title: High-resolution SOFIA/EXES Spectroscopy of Water Absorption Lines in the Massive Young Binary W3 IRS 5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13798v1.summary: Mid-infrared (5-8~$\mu$m) spectroscopy toward the massive young binary W3~IRS~5. Two hot components over 500 K and one warm component of 190 K are identified through Gaussian fittings and rotation diagram analysis. We discuss the chemical abundances along the line of sight based on CO-to-O connection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13792v1.title: Maximizing science return by coordinating the survey strategies of Roman with Rubin, and other major facilities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13792v1.summary: The Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will be one of severalflagship survey facilities operating over the next decade. The deep near-IR imaging that Roman will deliver will be highly complementary to the capabilities of other survey telescopes. Combining data from multiple facilities can provide important astrophysical insights.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12500v2.title: Coronal Line Forest AGN -- II. Analysis of the spectral energy distribution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12500v2.summary: Coronal-Line Forest Active Galactic Nuclei (CLiF AGN) are characterized by strong, high-ionization lines. In this work, we infer the physical and geometrical properties of the dust structure that surrounds the central region. We compare the results of three models: CLUMPY, SKIRTOR and CAT3D-wind.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07742v2.title: The Two Quasi-Static Limits of Aether Scalar Tensor Theory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07742v2.summary: Aether Scalar Tensor Theory (AeST) aims to reproduce Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) on galactic scales. The quasi-static limit depends on a model parameter $m_\times$. We show that, in practice, much of the phenomenology of the AeST limit depends only very little on the value of $m_.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03419v2.title: The Universe is at Most 88% Neutral at z=10.6
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03419v2.summary: Recent observations of GN-z11 with JWST have revealed a Ly$\alpha$ emission line with an equivalent width of 18$\pm 2$ angstroms. At z=10.6, this galaxy isexpected to lie in the heart of reionization. We use a series of inhomogeneousreionization simulations to derive the distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13639v1.title: X-ray Analysis of AGN from the GALEX Time Domain Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13639v1.summary: We analyze the X-ray properties for a sample of 23 high probability AGNcandidates with ultraviolet variability identified in Wasleske et al. (2022) We explore possible reasons for why some objects lack optical spectroscopic signatures of black hole activity. We find that host galaxy stellar emission and gas and dust are all potential factors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06133v2.title: Black Hole Binary Formation in AGN Discs: From Isolation to Merger
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06133v2.summary: Black hole (BH) binary mergers in the discs of activegalactic nuclei (AGN) is investigated as a possible merger channel. BH encounters in the gas disc form mutually bound black hole binarysystems through interaction with the gas in the disc and subsequently inspiral through gravitational torques.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.00014v2.title: Strongly Lensed Supermassive Black Hole Binaries as Nanohertz Gravitational-Wave Sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.00014v2.summary: Supermassive black hole binary systems (SMBHBs) should be the most powerful sources of gravitational waves (GWs) Once Pulsar Timing Arrays detect the stochastic GW background, searching for individually resolvable binaries will take on new importance. Strong gravitational lensing can act as a tool for increasing their detection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13563v1.title: The GUAPOS project:III. Characterization of the O- and N-bearing complex organic molecules content and search for chemical differentiation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13563v1.summary: The G31.41+0.31 Unbiased ALMA sPectral Observational Survey (GUAPOS) project focuses on the hot molecular core (HMC) G31, one of the most chemically rich high-mass star-forming regions outside the Galactic Center. In the third paper of the project, we present a study of nine O-bearing and six N-bearing molecules.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18077v4.title: New filamentary remnant radio emission and duty cycle constraints in the radio galaxy NGC 6086
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18077v4.summary: Radio galaxies are a subclass of active galactic nuclei in which accretiononto the supermassive black hole releases energy via relativistic jets. Remnant radio galaxies are discovered during a quiescent phase and define a class of unique sources. We present, a spatially resolved radio analysis of the radio galaxy associated with NGC 6086.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13475v1.title: Cosmological Simulations of Galaxy Groups and Clusters-III: Constraining Quasar Feedback Models with the Atacama Large Millimeter Array
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13475v1.summary: The thermal Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SZ) effect serves as a direct potential probe of the energetic outflows from quasars. We use the GIZMO meshless finite mass finite mass simulation SIMBA to compute the SZ effect. From these theoretical simulations, we perform mock observations of the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) in four bands.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13392v1.title: The probability of identifying the cosmic web environment of galaxies around clusters motivated by the Weave Wide Field Cluster Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13392v1.summary: Upcoming wide-field spectroscopic surveys will observe galaxies in a range of cosmic web environments in and around galaxy clusters. In this paper, we test how successfully we will be able to identify the environment ofindividual galaxies in the vicinity of massive galaxy clusters, reaching out to the infall region. We focus on the WEAVE Wide                Field Cluster Survey (WWFCS), but the methods we develop can be easilygeneralised to any similar spectroscopy survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10188v2.title: Stellar-mass black holes in the Hyades star cluster?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10188v2.summary: Astrophysical models of binary-black hole mergers in the Universe require a significant fraction of stellar-mass black holes (BHs) to receive negligible natal kicks. This implies that BHsshould be retained even in open clusters with low escape velocities. We search for signatures of the presence of BHS in the nearest open cluster to the Sun - the Hyades.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10960v2.title: Simulating the LOcal Web (SLOW): I. Anomalies in the local density field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10960v2.summary: The local Universe (LU) has very prominent structures. It is difficult to connect these structures to the underlying dark matter(DM) distribution. We demonstrate that haloes and galaxies in our constrained simulationtrace the local DM density field very differently. Only 44 out of 15635 random realizations (i.e. 0.28%) are matching both the observed and simulated anomalies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13348v1.title: Gravitational Interaction of Ultralight Dark Matter with Interferometers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13348v1.summary: Ultralight dark matter exhibits an order-one density fluctuation over the scale of its wavelength. These fluctuations gravitationally interact with gravitational wave interferometers, leading to an additional noise floor. Gravitational wave Interferometers can then place upper limits on the ultralights dark matter density in the solar system.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18137v2.title: O, Ne, Mg, and Fe abundances in hot X-ray emitting halos of galaxy clusters, groups, and giant early-type galaxies with XMM-Newton RGS spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18137v2.summary: XMM-Newton RGS analysis of 14 early-type galaxies, including the well-known cluster galaxies of Perseus. The spatial distribution of the O/Fe, Ne/Fe and Mg/Fe ratios is generally flat at the central 60                arcsecond regions of each object. The dust depletion process does not work predominantly in these systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07272v2.title: Spatially resolved dust properties and quasar-galaxy decomposition of a HyLIRG at z = 4.4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07272v2.summary: We report spatially resolved dust properties of the quasar host galaxy BRI1335-0417 at redshift $z = 4.4$ constrained by the ALMA observations. We show that a model including this warm component along with cooler dust heated by star formation describes the global SED better than a single component model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13219v1.title: VaDAR: Varstrometry for Dual AGN using Radio interferometry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13219v1.summary: Binary and dual active galactic nuclei (AGN) are an important observational tool for studying the formation and dynamical evolution of galaxies. An entirely new method for identifying possible AGN pairs makes use of the exquisite positional accuracy of Gaia. The new observations are used to constrain the driver of the excess astrometric noise in Gaia.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08952v2.title: First results from the JWST Early Release Science Program Q3D: The Warm Ionized Gas Outflow in z ~ 1.6 Quasar XID 2028 and its Impact on the Host Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08952v2.summary: Quasar feedback may regulate the growth of supermassive black holes, quench                coeval star formation, and impact galaxy morphology. However, direct evidence for quasar feedback in action at the epoch of peak black hole accretion at z ~ 2 remains elusive. A good case in point is the 1.6 quasar WISEA J100211.29+013706.7.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13137v1.title: A Pulsar-Based Map of Galactic Acceleration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13137v1.summary: Binary pulsars can be used to probe Galactic potential gradients. We present the first data release of direct line-of-sight acceleration measurements for 26 binary pulsars. We validate these data with a local acceleration model, and compare our results to those extracted from indirect methods. We find evidence for an accelerating gradient in agreement with these values.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14679v1.title: Dynamical formation of $Gaia$ BH1 in a young star cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14679v1.summary: $Gaia$ BH1, the first quiescent black hole (BH) detected from data,poses a challenge to most binary evolution models. We study the properties of BH-main sequence (MS)binaries formed in YSCs with initial mass $3.5-3.3-10^2-3 at solar metallicity. None of our isolated binary systems matches the orbital period and MS mass of $Gaia#BH1. Our best matching system forms via repeated dynamical exchanges.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13132v1.title: A Unified Exploration of the Chronology of the Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13132v1.summary: The Milky Way has distinct structural stellar components linked to itsformation and subsequent evolution. We determine precise stellar properties for 21,076 red giants, mainly spanning 2-15 kpc in Galactocentric radii. We find hints of an age asymmetry between the Northern and Southern hemisphere.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13130v1.title: Dynamical Evolution of White Dwarf Triples in the Era of Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13130v1.summary: The Gaia mission has detected many white dwarfs (WDs) in binary and triple configurations. We simulate thousands of triple stellar systems for over 10 Gyr, tracking gravitational interactions, tides, general relativity, and stellar evolution up to their white dwarf fate. We find that including the effect of mass loss-induced kicks is crucial for producing a distribution of the inner binary-tertiary separations that is consistent with Gaia observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13120v1.title: Reprocessing Models for the Optical Light Curves of Hypervariable Quasars from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Reverberation Mapping Project
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13120v1.summary: We develop and apply models for quasar light curves in simple geometries that are likely to be representative of quasar inner environments. Of the 17 quasars in our sample, eleven are best-fit by a hemisphere geometry, five are classified as thick disks, and both models fail for just one object.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13121v1.title: Young Star Clusters Dominate the Production of Detached Black Hole-Star Binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13121v1.summary: Recent discovery of two detached black hole-star (BH-star) binaries has sparkled interest in understanding the formation Mechanisms of these systems. We investigate the formation of systems by dynamical processes in young open star clusters (SCs) and via isolated binary(IB) evolution. We find that dynamicalformation in SCs is nearly 40 times as efficient per unit of star formation atproducing BH- star binaries compared to IB evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13125v1.title: Formation of Galactic Disks II: the Physical Drivers of Disk Spin-up
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13125v1.summary: A disk forms as a result of the interplay between inflow and outflow carrying angular momentum in and out of the galaxy. Disk formation is also correlated with the formation of a hot halo with a significant fraction of the inflow occurring at sub-centricand transonic velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11949v2.title: Newly Discovered Wolf-Rayet Stars in M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11949v2.summary: Recent work suggested that the Wolf-Rayet (WR) content of M31 may have been underestimated. A pilot project has found 19 new WRs across three small fields in M31. The newly discovered WRs are generally fainter than the previously known sample due to slightly increased reddening as opposed to intrinsic faintness.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13048v1.title: X-ray photodesorption of complex organic molecules in protoplanetary disks -- I. Acetonitrile CH3CN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13048v1.summary: X-rays emitted from pre-main-sequence stars at the center of protoplanetarydisks can induce nonthermal desorption from interstellar ices. This X-ray photodesorption needs to be quantified for complexorganic molecules (COMs), including acetonitrile CH3CN, which has been detected in several disks.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13037v1.title: Magellanic System Stars Identified in the SMACS J0723.3-7327 JWST ERO Images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13037v1.summary: We identify 68 distant stars in JWST/NIRCam ERO images of the field of galaxy clusters SMACS J0723.3-7327 (SMACS 0723) The stars are likely to be associated with the Large                Magellanic Cloud or Leading Arm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13012v1.title: Spatially Resolved Kinematics of Extraplanar Diffuse Ionized Gas in NGC$\,$3511 and NGC$\,$3513
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.13012v1.summary: Gaseous, disk-halo interfaces are shaped by physical processes that are critical to disk galaxy evolution, including gas accretion and galacticoutflows. However, observations indicate that extraplanar diffuse ionized gas layers have scale heights several times higher than their thermal scale heights. This discrepancy poses a challenge to our current understanding of the disks. We present a spatially-resolved case study of the eDIG layers in a nearby pair of disks.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05295v2.title: The Star-forming and Ionizing Properties of Dwarf z~6-9 Galaxies in JADES: Insights on Bursty Star Formation and Ionized Bubble Growth
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05295v2.summary: Reionization is thought to be driven by faint star-forming galaxies, butcharacterizing this population in detail has long remained very challenging. We utilize deep nine-band NIRCam imaging from JADES to study thestar-forming and ionizing properties of 756 $z\sim6-9$ galaxies. We find no evidence for extremely massive galaxies in our sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14999v2.title: A JWST/NIRCam Study of Key Contributors to Reionization: The Star-forming and Ionizing Properties of UV-faint $z\sim7-8$ Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14999v2.summary: Spitzer/IRAC imaging has revealed that the brightest $z\sim7-8$ galaxies often exhibit young ages and strong nebular line emission, hinting at high                ionizing efficiency among early galaxies. Here we use CEERS JWST/NIRCam data to characterize 116 UV-faint galaxies. We find evidence for a strong (5-10$\times$) increase in specific star formation rate toward lower luminosities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04010v2.title: Core Collapse Supernova Explosions in Active Galactic Nucleus Accretion Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04010v2.summary: Astrophysical events that occur in active galactic nucleus (AGN) disks are believed to differ significantly from the ordinary in the interstellar medium. AGN disks provide a dense environment for supernova (SN) explosions, which inevitablyinvolve ejecta-disk interactions. The resulting SNe in the AGN disk is a promisingtransient source for UV and optical band detection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12990v1.title: Slowly Rotating Accretion Flow Around SMBH in Elliptical Galaxy: Case With Outflow
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12990v1.summary: Outflow shows up in accretion systems of the elliptical galaxy center. There is an unknown mechanism for removing the mass, angular momentum, and energy by outflows in this study. The effects of the outflow appear well on the outer edge of the black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12985v1.title: Shock cooling of a red-supergiant supernova at redshift 3 in lensed images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12985v1.summary: The early phases of a supernova at redshift $z \approx 3$ beginning within within 5.8\pm 3.1$ of explosion. The supernova, seen at a lookback time of 11.5 billion years, is strongly lensed by an early-type galaxy in the Abell 370 cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12954v1.title: A New Constraint on the Simulation of the Intergalactic Medium through the Evolution of the Neutral Hydrogen Fraction in the Epoch of Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12954v1.summary: Simulation is a very powerful tool to reach a suitable model for the intergalactic medium, both in terms of cosmology and astrophysics. We have eliminated many models and introduced only limited simulation models that could confirm the observations with sufficient accuracy. We hope that in future works, by enhancing the observational data and increasing their accuracy, more compatible models with the history of the interGalactic medium can be achieved.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12945v1.title: Star cluster formation and feedback in different environments of a Milky Way-like galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12945v1.summary: It remains unclear how galactic environment affects star formation andstellar cluster properties. We carry out zoom-in simulations to re-simulate100-300 pc regions of a Milky Way-like galaxy using smoothed particlehydrodynamics. We select $10^6$ Msun cloud complexes from a galactic bar,inner spiral arm, outer arm, and inter-arm region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12927v1.title: Deficit of Hot Dust in Low-redshift Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12927v1.summary: We assemble a broad-band spectral energy distribution (SED) ranging fromoptical to mid-infrared of nearby active galactic nuclei at $z < 0.4$. SEDfitting analysis is performed using semi-empirical templates derived from Palomar-Green quasars. Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests reveal that hot-dust-deficient (HDD) AGNs exhibit, on average higher AGN luminosity than normal and WDD AGNs. Analysis of the outflow properties traced by the wing of an O III galaxy suggests that outflows may be

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10175v2.title: The Tiered Radio Extragalactic Continuum (T-RECS) simulation II: HI emission and continuum-HI cross-correlation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10175v2.summary: In this paper we extend the Tiered Radio Extragalactic Continuum Simulation to include HI emission. The HI T-RECS model is based on the most                recent HI mass function estimates. We deliver a set of mock catalogues, as well as the code to produce them.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12902v1.title: Mapping non-axisymmetric velocity fields of external galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12902v1.summary: Non-circular motions caused by warps, lopsidedness, or satellite interactions are common and leave distinct signatures on galaxy velocity maps. We develop an algorithm that fits a non-axisymmetric model to the observed two-dimensional line-of-sight velocity map of an external galaxy. The method approximates a spiral galaxy as a flat disk, which is an appropriate assumption for spiral galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12894v1.title: The Galactic Extinction Horizon with Present and Future Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12894v1.summary: We have made a lot of progress in the study of the MW. In spite of this, much of our Galaxy remains unknown, and amazing breakthroughs await to be made. Focussing on the Galacticextinction horizon problem with current surveys like the Two Micron All-Sky Survey (2MASS) is a fundamental difficulty.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12864v1.title: Searching for dark matter substructure: a deeper wide-area community survey for Roman
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12864v1.summary: We recommend a deeper extension to the High-Latitute Wide Area Survey planned to be conducted by the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. The deeper-tier survey extension can support a range of astrophysicalinvestigations. It is particularly well suited to characterize the dark mattersubstructure in galactic halos and reveal the microphysics of dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08997v2.title: Formation and Evolution of Accreting Compact Objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08997v2.summary: Accreting compact objects are crucial to understand several importantastrophysical phenomena. We still do not fully understand how they form and evolve. This chapter will review the current theoretical status of our knowledge of these objects. It will discuss standing problems and potential solutions to these problems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.07879v2.title: Templates for Fitting Photometry of Ultra-High-Redshift Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.07879v2.summary: Recent data from the James Webb Space Telescope allow a first glimpse of galaxies at $z \gtrsim 11$. The most successful tool for identifying grotesqueultra-high-redshift candidates and inferring their properties is photometric template fitting. Current methods rely on templates derived from much lower-red shift conditions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01774v2.title: The Earliest Stage of Galactic Star Formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01774v2.summary: Using a recently-developed technique to estimate gas temperatures in star-forming regions from large photometric surveys, we propose a diagram to probe the evolution of individual galaxies. On this $T_\textrm{SF}$-sSFR (specific star formation rate) diagram, a small fraction of galaxies appear to be dominated by different feedback mechanisms. These galaxies generically have younger stellar populations, lower stellar masses and increase in relativeabundance towards higher redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12813v1.title: An Enhanced Massive Black Hole Occupation Fraction Predicted in Cluster Dwarf Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12813v1.summary: Using the Romulus cosmological simulations we examine the impact of environment on the occupation fraction of MBHs in low mass galaxies. The predicted occupation fractions are consistent with those of nuclear star clusters. Across cluster and field environments, dwarf galaxies with earlier formation times are more likely to host a MBH.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12782v1.title: Fantastic Fits with fantasy of Active Galactic Nuclei Spectra -- Exploring the Fe II emission near the H$α$ line
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12782v1.summary: A refined approach for multicomponent fitting of activegalactic nuclei (AGN) spectra is presented. The study highlights the benefits of fitting AGN type 1 spectra with the newly developed Python code $fantasy$ The study points that it may be used as a robust tool for analyzing a large number of AGN spectra in the coming spectral surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12775v1.title: Similar levels of deuteration in the pre-stellar core L1544 and the protostellar core HH211
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12775v1.summary: In the centre of pre-stellar cores, deuterium fractionation is enhanced due to the low temperatures and high densities. Therefore, the chemistry of deuterated molecules can be used to study the earliest stages of starformation. We analyse the deuteration of simple molecules in the envelopes of the pre- stellar core L1544 in Taurus and the protostellar core HH211 in Perseus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12751v1.title: ViCTORIA project: MeerKAT HI observations of the ram pressure stripped galaxy NGC 4523
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12751v1.summary: We present the first results of a 21 cm HI line pilot observation carried out in preparation for the ViCTORIA project. The extraordinary quality of the data allowed us to detect an extended (~10 kpc projected length) of the HI gas tail associated with the irregular galaxy NGC4523. The galaxy is located on the star formation main sequence when its star formation rate is derived using Halpha images obtained during the VESTIGE survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12692v1.title: Investigating the Correlation of Outflow Kinematics with Radio Activity. Gas Outflows in AGNs. VII
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12692v1.summary: We explore the relationship between the ionized gas outflows and radio activity using a sample of 6000 AGNs at z < 0.4. None of the binary subclasses of AGN shows a significant difference in the normalized [O III] velocity dispersion once we correct for the influence of the hostgalaxy gravitational potential. In contrast, we find a remarkable difference in ionized grotesquegas kinematics between high and low bolometric-Eddington ratio AGNs. These results suggest that accretion rate is the primary mechanism in driving ionized worrisomegas outflows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04015v3.title: Direct Collapse to Precursors of Supermassive Black Hole Seeds:Radiation Feedback-Generated Outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04015v3.summary: We use high-resolution zoom-in cosmological simulations to model outflow triggered by radiation and thermal drivers around the central mass accumulation. We observe a fast development of hot cavities, which quickly extend into polar funnels and expand dense shells. The ionization cones formed by the central UV/X-ray completely ionize the cavities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04613v3.title: Breakdown of the Newton-Einstein Standard Gravity at Low Acceleration in Internal Dynamics of Wide Binary Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04613v3.summary: A gravitational anomaly is found at weak gravitational acceleration. The anomaly systematically deviates from the Newtonian expectation. The deviation represents a direct evidence for the breakdown of standard gravity. The empirical acceleration relation at $< 10^{-9}$ m s$^{-2}$ systematicallydeviates from Newton's expectation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12636v1.title: CO survey of high-z radio galaxies, revisited with ALMA: Jet-cloud Alignments and Synchrotron Brightening by Molecular Gas in the Circumgalactic Environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12636v1.summary: Powerful radio sources associated with super-massive black holes are among the most luminous objects in the Universe. We show that the brightness of the radio source can be enhanced by its interplay with the molecular gas. This work is based on CO J>1 observations with the Atacama Largeimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09425v2.title: Investigation of Stellar Kinematics and Ionized gas Outflows in Local (U)LIRGs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09425v2.summary: We explore properties of stellar kinematics and ionized gas in a sample of local (U)LIRGs from the AKARI telescope. The highest SFRs and stellar masses are associated with ULIRGs. Our results suggest that starbursts are insufficient to produce such powerful outflows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12620v1.title: Extragalactic Star Cluster Science with the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope's High Latitude Wide Area Survey and the Vera C. Rubin Observatory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12620v1.summary: The Nancy Grace Roman Telescope's High Latitude Wide Area Survey will have a number of synergies with the Vera Rubin Observatory's Legacy Survey of Space and Time. Rubin will provide homogeneous, $ugrizy$photometric coverage, and measurements in the red Roman filters will help break down age-metallicity and age-extinction degeneracies. Roman's excellent spatial resolution will also allow measurements of cluster sizes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12541v1.title: First results from the JWST Early Release Science Program Q3D: Benchmark Comparison of Optical and Mid-IR Tracers of a Dusty, Ionized Red Quasar Wind at z=0.435
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12541v1.summary: JWST newly allows us to use mid-infrared spectral features at both high spatial and spectral resolution. The [OIII] 5007 A emission line is the most common tracer of warm, ionizedoutflows in active galactic nuclei across cosmic time. The JWST data are from the Mid-InfraRed Instrument.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12514v1.title: Roman CCS White Paper: Characterizing the Galactic population of isolated black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12514v1.summary: There are estimated to be 100 million isolated black holes (BHs) in the Milky Way. Only one has been found so far, resulting in significant uncertainty about their properties. The Galactic Bulge Time Domain Survey provides the only opportunity in the coming decades to grow this catalog by order of magnitude.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12502v1.title: Varstrometry for Off-nucleus and Dual sub-Kpc AGN (VODKA). SDSS J1608+2716: A Sub-arcsec Quadruply Lensed Quasar at $z=2.575$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12502v1.summary: Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) deep IR imaging of SDSS J1608+2716. This system, located at a redshift of 2.575, was recently reported as a triple quasar candidate with subarcsecondseparations ($\sim0.25''$)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12488v1.title: Light bending near non-asymptotically flat black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12488v1.summary: The gravitational deflection of light is a crucial test for modified gravity. A triangular array of laser beams can be designed so that the proposeddefinition of deflection angle is sensitive to a cosmological constant. Our results offer insights that could be useful for designing future theoretical or experimental investigations aimed to detect sources of curvature in the universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12485v1.title: The Galactic Center with Roman
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12485v1.summary: We advocate for a Galactic center (GC) field to be added to the GalacticBulge Time Domain Survey. The new field would yield high-cadencephotometric and astrometric measurements of an unprecedented $3.3 million stars toward the GC. This would enable a wide range of science cases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12474v1.title: A Value-added COSMOS2020 Catalog of Physical Properties: Constraining Temperature-dependent Initial Mass Function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12474v1.summary: New catalog of new photometrically-derivedphysical properties for the most well-measured galaxies in the COSMOS field on the sky. Using a recently developed technique, spectral energy distributions are modeled assuming a stellar initial mass function that depends on the temperature of gas in star-forming regions. It is found that the galaxies exhibit a continuum of IMF, and gas temperatures, most of which are bottom-lighter than measured in the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12409v1.title: Discovery of Gaia17bpp, a Giant Star with the Deepest and Longest Known Dimming Event
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12409v1.summary: We report the serendipitous discovery of Gaia17bpp/2MASS J19372316+1759029, a star with a deep single large-amplitude dimming event of $4.5 magnitudes that lasted over 6.5 years. No other significant dimmingevents of this depth and duration were identified in the optical light curves. We suggest that the main culprit of the dimming is likely due to the presence of a large, optically thick disk transiting the primary giant star.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12905v2.title: The evolution of the internal structure of massive star forming regions in the Milky Way as revealed by ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12905v2.summary: We analyze the structure of 15 protocluster forming regions in the Milky Way using their $1.3$ mm continuum emission maps from the ALMA-IMF large program. The calculated spectra display a self-similar regime on small scales as well as the presence of a prominent bump on larger scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12388v1.title: Exploring the Evolution of Massive Clumps in Simulations that Reproduce the Observed Milky Way α-element Abundance Bimodality
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12388v1.summary: The Milky Way stellar disk has both a thin and a thick component. The thin disk is composed mostly of younger stars. The thick disk contains predominantly older stars with a higher abundance of $\alpha$ elements. A proposed explanation for the bimodality is an episode of clumpy star formation, where high-$\alpha$ stars form in massive clumps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12385v1.title: Spectroscopy of the Supernova H0pe Host Galaxy at Redshift 1.78
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12385v1.summary: Supernova (SN) H0pe was discovered as a new transient in James Webb SpaceTelescope (JWST) NIRCam images of the galaxy cluster PLCK G165.7+67.0. The transient is a compact source associated with a background galaxy that is stretched and triply-imaged by the cluster's strong gravitational lensing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12464v1.title: Interstellar Comets from Post-Main Sequence Systems as Tracers of Extrasolar Oort Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12464v1.summary: "Jurads" are "exo-comets released into the Milky Way during the post-main sequence as thethermally-pulsing asymptotic giant branch (AGB) host stars lose mass. Even with the LSST's increased search volume compared to contemporary surveys, we find that detecting a Jurad is likely but not infeasible.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05378v2.title: Spectroscopic Confirmation of CEERS NIRCam-selected Galaxies at $\boldsymbol{z \simeq 8-10}$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05378v2.summary: We present JWST/NIRSpec prism spectroscopy of seven galaxies selected from the Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science Survey (CEERS) NIRCam imaging. We measure emission line redshifts of z=7.65 and 8.64 for two galaxies, and z=9.77 and 10.01 for two others via the detection of continuum breaks. The presence (absense) of strong breaks (strong emission lines) give high confidence that these two galaxies are at z>9.6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03096v1.title: HETDEX Public Source Catalog 1 -- Stacking 50K Lyman Alpha Emitters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03096v1.summary: We describe the ensemble properties of the $1.9 < z < 3.5$ Lyman Alpha Emitters (LAEs) found in the HETDEX survey's first public data release. Stacking the $R \sim$ 800) spectra greatly increases the signal-to-noise-ratio, revealing spectral features otherwise hidden by noise.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03035v1.title: Tidal debris from Omega Centauri discovered with unsupervised machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03035v1.summary: The gravitational interactions between the Milky Way and in-falling satellites offer a wealth of information about the formation and evolution ofour Galaxy. In this paper, we explore the high-dimensionality of the GALAH DR3plus Gaia eDR3 data set to identify new tidally stripped candidate stars of thenearby star cluster Omega Centauri.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03033v1.title: Primary Period-Luminosity-Relation Calibrators in the Milky Way: Cepheids and RR Lyrae Physical basis, Calibration, and Applications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03033v1.summary: In this invited review I discuss the calibration and applications of the period-luminosity relation of classical Cepheid and RR Lyrae stars. I also discuss the effect of reddening and that the use of Wesenheit indices isactually an oversimplification to dealing with the problem of redding.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.15423v2.title: High-precision chemical abundances of Galactic building blocks. The distinct chemical abundance sequence of Sequoia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.15423v2.summary: Sequoia is a retrograde kinematic substructure in the nearby Galactic halo. Its properties are a matter of debate. Previous studies have failed to agree on the chemical abundances of Sequoia stars, which are important for understanding its nature. We compared the chemical abundance of 12 stars with those of typical halo stars from the literature and Gaia-Enceladus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.11808v2.title: High-precision chemical abundances of Galactic building blocks. II. Revisiting the chemical distinctness of the Helmi streams
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.11808v2.summary: The Helmi streams are a kinematic substructure whose progenitor is likely a dwarf galaxy. 20 years after their discovery, it is still unclear whether their members are chemically distinguishable from other halo stars in the Milky Way. We analyze spectra for 11 Helmi stream stars through aline-by-line abundance analysis. We find extremely low values of [Y/Fe] at low metrics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11639v2.title: Improving metallicity estimates for very metal-poor stars in the Gaia DR3 GSP-Spec catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11639v2.summary: The Gaia DR3 GSP-Spec parameters, including metallicity, for VMP stars suffer from parameter degeneracy due to a lack of information in their spectra. The recommended quality cuts filter out the majority of the VMPstars because some of them are confused with hot stars or cool K and M-type giants.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02962v1.title: No redshift evolution in the rest-frame UV emission line properties of quasars from z=1.5 to z=4.0
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02962v1.summary: We analyse the rest-frame UV spectra of 2,531 high-redshift quasars from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey DR16Q catalogue. C IV blueshifts are highest when L/LEdd > 0.2 and Mbh > 10^9 Mo. Quasars at redshift 1.5-4.0 are on average less massive and have higher Eddington-scaled accretionrates than their luminosity-matched counterparts at 1.0-3.5.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02917v1.title: Spectroscopic study of Herbig Ae/Be stars in the Galactic Anti-center region from LAMOST DR5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02917v1.summary: We study a sample of 119 Herbig Ae/Be stars in the Galactic anti-center direction. Emission lines of hydrogen and metallic lines of species such as FeII, OI, CaII triplet are identified. A moderate correlation is observed between the emission strengths of H$\alpha$ and FeII 5169.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02914v1.title: Revealing the structure of the lensed quasar Q 0957+561 III. Constraints on the size of the broad-line region
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02914v1.summary: We examine the size, kinematics, and geometry of the broad-line region (BLR) in the double-lensed quasar Q 0957+561 by analyzing the impact ofmicrolensing on various rest-frame ultraviolet broad-emission lines (BELs) The strength of the differential microlensing indicates that the high-ionization line C IV arises from a compact inner region of the BLR with a half-light radius of $R_{1/2}.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02905v1.title: Decomposing the Origin of TeV-PeV Emission from the Galactic Plane: Implications of Multi-messenger Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02905v1.summary: High-energy neutrino and $\gamma$-ray emission has been observed from the Galactic plane. We evaluate the contribution of these two components through the multi-messenger connection between neutrinos and $gamma rays in hadronic interactions. Future observations in the Southern hemisphere are needed to accurately disentangle thesource and diffuse emission of the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.05145v2.title: Fully Adaptive Bayesian Algorithm for Data Analysis, FABADA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.05145v2.summary: The Fully Adaptive Bayesian Algorithm for Data Analysis (FABADA) yields results that, without any parameter tuning, are comparable to standard image processing algorithms. State-of-the-art non-parametric methods, such as BM3D, offer slightly better performance at high signal-to-noise ratio. Our algorithm is significantly more accurate for extremely noisy data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02898v1.title: The JWST view of the barred galaxy population in the SMACS0723 galaxy cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02898v1.summary: The cosmic evolution of the barred galaxy population provides key information about the secular evolution of galaxies and the settling of rotationallydominated discs. We study the bar fraction in the SMACSJ0723.37323 (SMACS0723) cluster of galaxies at z = 0.39 using the NIRCam instrument mounted on the JWST telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.06459v2.title: From the gates of the abyss: Frequency- and polarization-dependent lensing of gravitational waves in strong gravitational fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.06459v2.summary: Gravitational waves can be described by the geometrical optics approximation. But at large but finite frequencies the propagation is affected by the gravitational spin Hall effect. gravitational waves follow slightly different frequency- andipientpolarization-dependent trajectories, leading to dispersive and birefringent Phenomena. We present constraints on dispersive time delays from GWTC-3.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02812v1.title: Tracing the chemical footprint of shocks in AGN-host and starburst galaxies with ALMA multi-line molecular studies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02812v1.summary: Multi-line molecular observations are an ideal tool for a systematic study of physico-chemical processes in the Interstellar Medium. Recently high spatial resolution of typical shock tracers - SiO, HNCO, and CH3OH - have been studied in the potentially shocked regions in two galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02811v1.title: Machine Learning Classification of Repeating FRBs from FRB121102
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02811v1.summary: Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs) are mysterious bursts in the millisecond timescale at radio wavelengths. Currently, there is little understanding about the classification of repeating FRBs, based on difference in physics. By fine-tuning the hyperparameters of the model, we found that there is an indication for four clusters from the bursts of FRB121102.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02788v1.title: Resolving cosmic star formation histories of present-day bulges, disks, and spheroids with ProFuse
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02788v1.summary: Using ProFuse, a new technique to model the 2D distribution of light across multiple wavelengths. We show that 50% of the stars that formed at cosmic noon (8-12 Gyr ago) now reside in spheroids, and present-day bulges are composed of stars that were primarily formed in the veryearly Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03624v2.title: EDGES of the dark forest: A new absorption window into the composite dark matter and large scale structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03624v2.summary: The photons from a background source can interact with the dark matter, resulting in an absorption signal in the source spectrum. In the case of a compact source, such as a quasar, such interactions can produce a series of closely spaced absorption lines. Such novel signatures can arise for dark matter models with a composite nature and internal electromagnetic transitions. We show that the dark forest feature is a sensitive probe of dark matter self-interactions and the halo mass function.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02785v1.title: Effects of Hoyle state de-excitation on $νp$-process nucleosynthesis and Galactic chemical evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02785v1.summary: The partcle-induced hadronic de-excitation of the Hoyle state in a hot and dense plasma can enhance theTriple-alpha reaction rate. This prevents the production of heavy nuclei within the neutrino-driven winds of core-collapse supernovae. It raises a question as to the contribution of proton-rich neutrinos to solar system abundances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02335v2.title: The Classification of Galaxy Morphology in H-band of COSMOS-DASH Field: a combination-based machine learning clustering model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02335v2.summary: We present a catalog of galaxy morphology for H-band selectedmassive galaxies in the COSMOS-DASH field. This includes 17292 galaxies withstellar mass at $0.5<z<2.5$. We first use an unsupervised.machine learning method (i.e., bagging-based multi-clustering) to cluster galaxies into five. categories: spherical (SPH), early-type disk (ETD), late-type disks (LTD), irregular (IRR), and unclassified (UNC) About 48\% of galaxies (8258/

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02778v1.title: Not gone with the Wind: Survival of High-Velocity Molecular Clouds in the Galactic center
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02778v1.summary: High-velocity atomic clouds in the Galactic center have attracted significant attention. Their formation process is potentially linked to the starburst or supermassive black hole activities in the region. We find that the presence of a magnetic field provideseffective protection and acceleration to molecular clouds (MCs) within the Galactic winds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02742v1.title: Diffractive lensing of nano-Hertz gravitational waves emitted from supermassive binary black holes by intervening galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02742v1.summary: Pulsar timing array (PTA) experiments are expected to detect nano-Hertz gravitational waves (GWs) emitted from individual inspiralling supermassivebinary black holes (SMBBHs) The GW signals from a small fraction of these SMBBHs may be diffractively lensed by intervening galaxies. We find that the amplitude of the lensed GW signals may be only amplified by a factor of 1.14.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02722v1.title: Exploring the Angular Momentum - Atomic Gas Content Connection with EAGLE and IllustrisTNG
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02722v1.summary: We use the EAGLE (Evolution and Assembly of GaLaxies and their Environments) and IllustrisTNG (The Next Generation) cosmological simulations to investigate properties of the baryonic specific angular momentum (j) and mass (M) of nearby galaxies. We find an excellent agreement between EAGle and TNG, with both also matching quite well with xGASS (eXtended GALEX Arecibo SDSS Survey)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02039v2.title: ACA CO($J=2-1$) Mapping of the Nearest Spiral Galaxy M33. I. Initial Results and Identification of Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02039v2.summary: We present the results of ALMA-ACA 7 m-array observations toward the molecular-gas disk in the Local Group spiral galaxy M33. We found that high-mass clouds tend to associate with the $8 \mu$m-bright sources in the spiral arm region. We compared the cataloged clouds with GMCs observed by the IRAM 30 m telescope at 49 pc resolution (IRAM GMC: Corbelli et al. 2017)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02704v1.title: Large Myr-old Disks are Not Severely Depleted of gas-phase CO or carbon
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02704v1.summary: We present an ACA search for [CI] emission at 492GHz toward large T Tauridisks. We also identify four Keplerian double-peaked profiles. We conclude that the majority of largeMyr-old disks conform to the simple expectation that they are not significantly depleted in gas, CO, or carbon.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02678v1.title: Detailed equilibrium and dynamical tides: impact on circularization and synchronization in open clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02678v1.summary: Binary stars evolve into chemically-peculiar objects and are a major driver of the Galactic enrichment of heavy elements. During their evolution they go through interactions, including tides, that circularize orbits and synchronizestellar spins. We assess the impact of tides and initial orbital-parameter distributions oncircularization and synchronization in eight open clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02674v1.title: Extending a Physics-Informed Machine Learning Network for Superresolution Studies of Rayleigh-Bénard Convection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02674v1.summary: Machine learning techniques have demonstrated promise in up-scaling resolution in both image analysis and numerical simulations. We employ and furtherdevelop a physics-constrained convolutional neural network (CNN) ML model for superresolution studies of turbulent systems. We find that our updated architecture performs well on laminar and turbulent flows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02634v1.title: Radio WISSH: tuning on the most luminous quasars in the Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02634v1.summary: The WISSH quasar project has been performing a systematic and statistically-significant VLA study of the radio properties of the quasar. We carried out high-resolution VLA observationsaiming at: 1) identifying young radio source from the broad-band spectral shape of these objects; 2) sample an unexplored high redshift/high luminosity regime, and 3) quantifying orientation effects on the observed winds/outflows properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02630v1.title: Continuum Reverberation Mapping of Mrk 876 Over Three Years With Remote Robotic Observatories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02630v1.summary: Continuum reverberation mapping probes the sizescale of the optical-emitting region in active galactic nuclei (AGN) We measure consistent interband lags using three techniques (CCF, JAVELIN, PyROA) The lag in the $i$ band shows an excess which we attribute to strong variable H$\alpha$ broad-line emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02618v1.title: SimSpin v2.5.1 -- Constructing synthetic spectral IFU cubes for comparison with observational surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02618v1.summary: We present a methodology and a corresponding code-base for constructing mock integral field spectrograph (IFS) observations of simulatedgalaxies. Such methods are necessary to improve the collaboration and comparison of observation and theory results. This code, SimSpin, is an open-source package written in R, but also with an API interface.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02585v1.title: Abundance Analysis of Stars at Large Radius in the Sextans Dwarf Spheroidal Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02585v1.summary: We identify three chemical signatures previously unknown among stars in Sextans dwarf spheroidal galaxy. One star exhibits large overabundances of C, N, O, Na, Mg, Si, and K, and large deficiencies of heavy elements. Three stars exhibit moderate enhancements of Eu, and the abundance ratios among 12 neutron-capture elements are indicative of r-process nucleosynthesis. These chemical signatures can all be attributed to massive, low-metallicity stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02576v1.title: Measuring the hot ICM velocity structure function using XMM-Newton observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02576v1.summary: Gas velocities within the intracluster medium (ICM) can be measured by applying novel XMM-Newton EPIC-pn energy scale. We measure a turbulence driving scale of 10-20 kpc for the Virgo cluster, while the Ophiuchus cluster VSF reflects the absence of interaction between the ICM and a powerful Active Galactic Nucleus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02568v1.title: Dust attenuation, dust content and geometry of star-forming galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02568v1.summary: We analyse the joint distribution of dust attenuation and projected axisratios to infer lessons on the dust content and star/dust geometry within star-forming galaxies at 0 < z <2.5. We find that UV-to-near-IR and far-infrared constraints can be reconciled by invoking clumpier dust geometries for galaxies at higher redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02541v1.title: The Multi-Wavelength Environment of Second Bologna Catalog Sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02541v1.summary: We present the first results of the Chandra Cool Targets (CCT) survey of powerful radio sources. The survey is aimed at investigating the extended X-ray emission surrounding these sources. For the first 33 sources observed in the B2CAT CCT survey, we performed both imaging and spectral X-rays analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02530v1.title: On the origin of globular clusters in a hierarchical Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02530v1.summary: We present an end-to-end description of the formation process of globularclusters (GCs) which combines a treatment for their formation and dynamicalevolution within galaxy haloes. A deviation fromlinearity is predicted at low halo masses, which is driven by a strong dependence on morphological type. We argue that this adds further evidence for an anomalously early formation of the stars in our Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02531v1.title: Subaru High-$z$ Exploration of Low-Luminosity Quasars (SHELLQs). XVIII. The Dark Matter Halo Mass of Quasars at $z\sim6$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02531v1.summary: We present, for the first time, dark matter halo (DMH) mass measurement of                quasars at $z\sim6$ based on a clustering analysis of 107 quasars. The DMH mass of qu asars is found to be nearly constant through out cosmic time. This suggests that there is a characteristic DMHmass where quasar are always activated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02527v1.title: The AMIGA sample of isolated galaxies. XIV. Disc breaks and interactions through ultra-deep optical imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02527v1.summary: We present deep optical imaging of a sample of 25 isolated galaxies. We identify 9 galaxies (36%) showing an exponential disc (Type I) and 14 galaxies (56%) with down-bending (Type II) profile. Isolated galaxies have considerably morepurely exponential discs and fewer up-bending surface brightness profiles thanfield or cluster galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.03126v3.title: Maximum entropy distributions of dark matter in $Λ$CDM cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.03126v3.summary: Small-scale challenges to $\Lambda$CDM cosmology require a deeper understanding of dark matter physics. For systems involving long-range interactions, a spectrum of halos of different sizes is required to maximize system entropy. While velocity in halos can be Gaussian, the velocity distribution throughout entire system, involving all halo sizes, is non-Gaussian. The predicted $X$ distribution involves a shape parameter and a velocity scale.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07322v2.title: Internal kinematics of {\it GAIA} DR3 wide binaries: anomalous behaviour in the low acceleration regime
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07322v2.summary: The eDR3 catalogue has been used to study the internal kinematics of wide binaries. A non-Newtonian low acceleration phenomenology is thus confirmed. This could be interpreted as evidence of a modification in the relevantfundamental physics, or as being due to kinematic contaminants affecting the experiment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02365v1.title: Sub-arcsecond resolution imaging of M 51 with the International LOFAR Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02365v1.summary: We present an International LOFAR Telescope sub-arcsecond resolution image of nearby galaxy M 51. We find a flux density of 0.97 mJy for SN 2011dh in the ILT image. This translates into fitting the radio light curves for the supernova and its progenitor star. We also discuss the radio emission from the centre of the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03834v2.title: Active galactic nuclei feedback in an elliptical galaxy (III): the impacts and fate of cosmological inflow
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03834v2.summary: The inflow of gas into a galaxy is speculated to be able to enhance the star formation rate (SFR) and black hole accretion rate (BHAR) In this paper, we investigate the fate of the inflow and its impacts on the evolution of a massive elliptical galaxy. We find that, the gas hardly enters but is blocked beyond the central galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02333v1.title: Disentangling the Hadronic Components in NGC 1068
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02333v1.summary: Recent detection of high-energy neutrinos by IceCube in the direction of nearby Seyfert/starburst galaxy NGC 1068 implies that radio-quiet activegalactic nuclei can accelerate cosmic-ray ions. At the same time, the GeV emission detected by the {\it Fermi}-Large Area Telescope (LAT) is likely related to the galaxy's sustained star-formation activity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02320v1.title: Molecular Abundance of the Circumnuclear Region Surrounding an Active Galactic Nucleus in NGC 1068 based on Imaging Line Survey in the 3-mm Band with ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02320v1.summary: We present an imaging molecular line survey in the 3-mm band (85-114 GHz)focused on one of the nearest galaxies with an active galactic nucleus (AGN) H13CN, SiO, HCN, and H13CO+ are abundant in the CND relative to the SBR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02267v1.title: Probing neutrino production in blazars by millimeter VLBI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02267v1.summary: The advancement of neutrino observatories has sparked a surge inmulti-messenger astronomy. The Event Horizon Telescope (ngEHT) is uniquely positioned for studies of blazars. Its high frequency and resolution can probe both the accretion disk region and the parsec-scale jet. This opens up new opportunities to unravel the proton acceleration and Neutrino production.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01035v2.title: Disk galaxies are self-similar: the universality of the HI-to-Halo mass ratio for isolated disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01035v2.summary: We study the scaling relation between the neutralhydrogen (HI) and dark matter mass in isolated rotationally-supported disk galaxies at low redshift. We first show that state-of-the-art galaxy formation simulations predict that the HI-to-dark halo mass ratio decreases with stellar mass. We then infer dark matter halo masses from high-quality rotation curve data for isolated disk galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02206v1.title: VINTERGATAN-GM: How do mergers affect the satellite populations of MW-like galaxies?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02206v1.summary: Smaller mergers host up to 60% more satellites than those of the larger merger scenarios. Differences in satellite numbers seen soon after the mergers are driven by several factors, including the timings of majormergers, the masses and satellite populations of the central and merging systems, and the history of minor mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19986v2.title: Tripotential MOND theories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19986v2.summary: I present a new class of nonrelativistic, modified-gravity MOND theories. The transition from the Newtonian to the MOND regime is rather richer than in the aquadratic-Lagrangiantheory (AQUAL) and the quasilinear MOND theory (QUMOND) These theories all make the salient, primary MOND predictions. Yet they can differ materially onsecondary predictions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02104v1.title: Molecular outflow in the reionization-epoch quasar J2054-0005 revealed by OH 119 $μ$m observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02104v1.summary: Molecular outflows are expected to play a key role in galaxy evolution at high redshift. To study the impact of outflows on star formation at the epoch of reionization, we performed sensitive ALMA observations of a luminous quasar at $z=6.04$. The mass outflow rate is comparable to the star formation rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09296v3.title: Characterizing CO Emitters in the SSA22-AzTEC26 Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09296v3.summary: We report the physical characterization of four CO emitters detected near the SSA22-AzTEC26 field. Two of them are CO(2-1) at redshifts of $z=2.113 and 1.146 and one is CO(3-2) at $z =2.124$. The three sources are massive galaxies with a stellar mass but have different levels of star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02024v1.title: Ageing and Quenching through the ageing diagram II: physical characterization of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02024v1.summary: The connection between quenching mechanisms, which rapidly turn star-forming systems into quiescent, and the properties of the galaxy population remains difficult to discern. In this work we investigate the physical properties of MaNGA and SAMI galaxies at different stages of their star formation history. We find that the Ageing population comprises aheterogeneous mixture of galaxies, preferentially late-type systems. Retired galaxies, formerly Ageing or Quenched, are dominated by early-type high-mass galaxies found at low and high densities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03499v3.title: Aether scalar tensor theory confronted with weak lensing data at small accelerations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03499v3.summary: Aether scalar tensor (AeST) model reproduces both thesuccesses of particle dark matter on cosmological scales and those of modified Newtonian dynamics (MOND) on galactic scales. AeST model shows some deviations from MOND at the radiiprobed by weak gravitational lensing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01948v1.title: A Catalogue of Radio Supernova Remnants and Candidate Supernova Remnants in the EMU/POSSUM Galactic Pilot Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01948v1.summary: This paper uses data from the EMU/POSSUM surveys to study the "missing supernova remnant (SNR) problem" The discrepancy between thenumber of Galactic SNRs that have been observed and the number that are estimated to exist is known as the 'missing SNR problem' We identify 21 SNR candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01903v1.title: Probing general relativistic spin-orbit coupling with gravitational waves from hierarchical triple systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01903v1.summary: Gravitational waves propagating in inhomogeneous media experience a coupling between internal and external degrees of freedom. These are known as spin Hall effects, which are well known in optics and condensed matter physics. The gravitational spin Hall effect is expected to affect the propagation of gravitational waves on curved spacetimes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08668v2.title: Modelling uncertainties in wide binary constraints on primordial black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08668v2.summary: Dark matter can be constrained by its dynamical effects on wide binary stars. These effects all tend to increase the predicted number of wide binaries. Therefore the constraints on the halo fraction in compact objects are significantly weakened. We implement a physicallymotivated model for the initial wide-binary semi-major axis distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01863v1.title: Comparing Globular Cluster System Properties with Host Galaxy Environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01863v1.summary: We present Hubble Space Telescope photometry in optical (F475X) andnear-infrared (F110W) bands of the globular cluster (GC) systems of a sample of 15 massive elliptical galaxies. Because much of the GC population is built up through accretion, the metallicity distribution might be expected to vary with galaxy environment. We find that almost no GCSproperties and host galaxy environmental properties are correlated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01854v1.title: MOKA3D: An innovative approach to 3D gas kinematic modelling. I. Application to AGN ionized outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01854v1.summary: Study of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) requirescharacterising multiple kinematical components, such as rotating gas andstellar disks, outflows, inflows, and jets. To compare the observed properties with theoretical predictions of galaxy evolution and feedback models, one usually relies on simplified kinematic models.
