Here, we present MOKA3D, an innovative approach to model the 3D gas and jets from observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03074v2.title: Exploring the likelihood of the 21-cm power spectrum with simulation-based inference
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03074v2.summary: Observations of the cosmic 21-cm power spectrum (PS) are starting to enable precision Bayesian inference of galaxy properties and physical cosmology. We find that the 1D PS likelihood is well described by a Gaussian.accounting for covariances between wavemodes and redshift bins. But common approaches of estimating the.forward-modeled mean and (co)variance from a random realization or at a single.point in parameter space result in biased and over-constrained posteriors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01771v1.title: AT2023fhn (the Finch): a Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transient at a large offset from its host galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01771v1.summary: Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transients (LFBOTs) are a rare class of events whose origins are poorly understood. They are characterised by rapid evolution, featureless blue spectraat early times, and luminous X-ray and radio emission. We present Hubble Space Telescope, Gemini, Chandra and Very Large Array observations of a new LFBOT, AT2023fhn.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01733v1.title: Discovery of H$_2$CCCH$^+$ in TMC-1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01733v1.summary: 14 mm-wave lines of the molecular ion have been measured in high resolution. The chemistry of H$_2$CCCH$^+$ is modelled using the most recent chemical network. New insights into the chemistry of C$_3$ bearing species in TMC-1 are obtained.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01731v1.title: Finding LoTSS of hosts for GRBs: a search for galaxy - gamma-ray burst coincidences at low frequencies with LOFAR
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01731v1.summary: The LOFAR Two-Metre Sky Survey (LoTSS) is an invaluable new tool for researching the properties of sources at low frequencies. In this work, we perform a search for host galaxies of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) We use the relative density of sources in Data Release 2 of LoTSS to define the Probability of a chance alignment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01692v1.title: The vanishing of the primary emission region in PKS 1510-089
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01692v1.summary: In July 2021, PKS 1510-089 exhibited a significant flux drop in the high-energy gamma-ray (by a factor 10) and optical ( by a factor 5) bands. The optical polarization in the source vanished, resulting in the optical spectrum being fully explained through the steady flux of the accretion disk and the broad-line region. This suggests that thesteady-state very-high-energy Gamma-ray and X-ray fluxes originate from a different emission region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07882v2.title: The role of baryons in self-interacting dark matter mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07882v2.summary: Mergers of galaxy clusters are promising probes of dark matter (DM) physics. We investigate the role of the intraclustermedium (ICM) and its influence on DM-galaxy offsets in self-interacting dark matter models. We found that different DM models affect the DM distribution and also the galaxy and ICMribution, including its temperature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04788v2.title: MUSEQuBES: The relation between Ly$α$ emitters and C IV absorbers at $z \approx 3.3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04788v2.summary: We present a detailed study of the column density and covering fraction of C IV absorption around 86 redshift $z \approx 3.3$ Ly$\alpha$ Emitters (LAEs) detected in 8 Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) fields centered on 8 bright background quasars. Using Voigt profile fitting of all the C IV absorbers detected along these 8 sightlines, we generated a ``blind'' absorbers' catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01629v1.title: The Gaia alerted fading of the FUor-type star Gaia21elv
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01629v1.summary: FU Orionis objects (FUors) are eruptive young stars, which exhibit outbursts that last from decades to a century. Gaia21elv was reported as a Gaia science alert due to its recent fading by more than a magnitude. The rapid fading of the source in 2021 was most likelydominated by an increase of circumstellar extinction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08284v3.title: Discovery of Five Green Pea Galaxies with Double-peaked Narrow [OIII] Lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08284v3.summary: Double-peaked narrow emission-line galaxies have been studied extensively in the past years. Here we present our discovery of five GPs with double- peaked narrow [OIII] emission lines. We find that these five DPGPs have blueshifted/.narrow components more prominent than the redshifted components.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03408v2.title: Partial stellar tidal disruption events and their rates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03408v2.summary: Tidal disruption events (TDEs) of stars operated by massive black holes will be detected in thousands by upcoming facilities such as the VeraRubin Observatory. We assess rates of standard total TDEs, destroying the entire star, and partial TDE, in which a stellar remnant                survives the interaction. Our rateestimates are based on a novel definition of the loss cone whose size is commensurate to the largest radius at which partial disruptions can occur.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01544v1.title: SDSS-IV MaNGA: Ionization sources of diffuse extra-planar galactic medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01544v1.summary: We explore sources of ionization of diffuse gas at different altitudes in                galaxies in dependence of their stellar mass, luminosity, and specific star formation rate. We use the MaNGA data from SDSS-IV data release DR16 and photoionization and shock ionization models provided by the 3MdB database.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01431v1.title: Reconciling the magnetic field in central disc galaxies with the dynamical mass using the cosmological simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01431v1.summary: Magnetic fields are ignored in most cosmological simulations. We find a linear correlation between the average magnetic field pervading galaxies in relative isolation and their circular velocities. The massive galaxies with active wind-driven black hole feedback, do not follow this trend, as their magnetic field is substantially decreased.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01409v1.title: Winds versus jets: a comparison between black hole feedback modes in simulations of idealized galaxy groups and clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01409v1.summary: kinetic jet feedback is more efficient at quenching star formation in the brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) than thermal isotropic feedback. A hybrid model with both types of AGN feedbackyields moderate star formation rates, while having the coolest cores. The former indicates that jet velocities need to be carefully chosen in cosmological simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17748v2.title: Constraining cosmology with the Gaia-unWISE Quasar Catalog and CMB lensing: structure growth
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17748v2.summary: We study the angular clustering of Quaia, a Gaia- and unWISE-based catalog of over a million quasars with an exceptionally well-defined selection function. From these data, and including a prior from measurements of the baryon acoustic oscillations scale, we place constraints on the amplitude and growth of structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08991v3.title: Sub-Halo Spreading of Thin Tidal Star Streams
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08991v3.summary: Kinematic properties of streams are measured in cosmological Milky Way-like halo simulations. Distance along a stream is a proxy for the time a star has spent in the stream, although there are a range of ages at any distance. Dark matter sub-halos that pass near or through a thin tidal star stream will increase its velocity dispersion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01331v1.title: PM 1-322: new variable planetary nebula
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01331v1.summary: The object is ZTFJ201451.59+120353.4 and identifies with PM 1-322.4. The object was discovered in Zwicky Transient Facility archival data. The ZTF r and g data show a one magnitude deep, eclipse-like event with a duration of about half a year.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00274v2.title: Identifying the SN 2022acko progenitor with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00274v2.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope identified a candidate progenitor star of the Type II-plateau supernova SN 2022acko in the barred spiral galaxy NGC 1300. To our knowledge, our discoveryrepresents the first time JWST has been used to localize a progenitors system in archival Hubble Space Telescope images.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01290v1.title: Three is the magic number -- distance measurement of NGC 3147 using SN 2021hpr and its siblings
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01290v1.summary: The nearby spiral galaxy NGC 3147 hosted three Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) in the past decades. We present and analyse new BVgriz and Swiftphotometry of SN 2021hpr to constrain its general physical properties. We confirm that SN~2021hpr is a Branch-normal Type autoimmuneIa SN that ejected from its progenitor white dwarf.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08894v3.title: First Impressions: Early-Time Classification of Supernovae using Host Galaxy Information and Shallow Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08894v3.summary: A neural network with a single recurrent layer is designed explicitly for earlyphotometric classification of supernovae. The method achieves an overall accuracy of $82 \pm 2$% within 3 days of an event's discovery, and $87 \pm 5 $% within 30 days of discovery.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01278v1.title: Metallicity Dependence of Molecular Cloud Hierarchical Structure at Early Evolutionary Stages
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01278v1.summary: The formation of molecular clouds out of HI gas is the first step toward starforming. Its metallicity dependence plays a key role to determine starforming through cosmic history. The Cold NeutralMedium (CNM) clumps form faster with higher meetallicity due to more efficientcooling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01277v1.title: X-ray metal line emission from the hot circumgalactic medium: probing the effects of supermassive black hole feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01277v1.summary: We compare IllustrisTNG, EAGLE, and SIMBA galaxy simulations. The three simulations consistently predict a dichotomy between star-forming and quiescent galaxies at the Milky-Way and Andromeda mass range. This is a signature of SMBH-driven outflows, which are responsible for quenching star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01276v1.title: Fly-by galaxy encounters with multiple black holes produce star-forming linear wakes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01276v1.summary: We look for simulated star-forming linear wakes such as the one recently discovered by van Dokkum et al. in the cosmological hydrodynamical simulations ASTRID. We predict the feature to persist for approximately 100 Myr in such a system and hence constitute a rare event. X-ray emission from AGN in the knot should be detectable in such systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01273v1.title: EIGER IV: The cool 10$^4$K circumgalactic environment of high-$z$ galaxies reveals remarkably efficient IGM enrichment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01273v1.summary: New observations of the cool diffuse gas around 29, $2.3<z<6.3$galaxies. Using deep JWST/NIRCam slitless grism spectroscopy around thesightline to the quasar J0100+2802. galaxies span a stellar mass range of $7.1-10.7.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01269v1.title: Properties of the Line-of-Sight Velocity Field in the Hot and X-ray Emitting Circumgalactic Medium of Nearby Simulated Disk Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01269v1.summary: The hot, X-ray-emitting phase of the circumgalactic medium in galaxies is believed to be the reservoir of baryons from which gas flows onto the central galaxy. These effects shape the velocity fields of the hot gas, which can be observed by Doppler shifting and broadening of emission lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01265v1.title: Inferring reionization and galaxy properties from the patchy kinetic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich signal
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01265v1.summary: The patchy kinetic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (kSZ) signal is an integral probe of the timing and morphology of the epoch of reionization (EoR) Recent observations have claimed a low signal-to-noise (S/N) measurement, with a dramatic increase in S/N expected in the near future.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01252v1.title: ReveaLLAGN 0: First Look at JWST MIRI data of Sombrero and NGC 1052
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01252v1.summary: We present the first results from the Revealing Low-Luminosity ActiveGalactic Nuclei (ReveaLLAGN) survey, a JWST survey of seven nearby LLAGN. We find that the emission-line widths in both NGC 1052 and Sombrero increase with increasing ionization potential.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01256v1.title: Can cuspy dark matter dominated halos hold cored stellar mass distributions?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01256v1.summary: According to the current concordance cosmological model, the dark matter (DM) are collision-less and produce self-gravitating structures with acentral cusp which, generally, is not observed. If cores exist in these galaxies they have to reflect departures from DM. Measuring the DM mass distribution in these faint galaxies is extremely challenging.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01259v1.title: Mapping the imprints of stellar and AGN feedback in the circumgalactic medium with X-ray microcalorimeters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01259v1.summary: The Astro2020 Decadal Survey has identified the mapping of the circumgalactic tumultuous (CGM, gaseous plasma around galaxies) as a key objective. We explore the prospects for characterizing the CGM in and around nearby galaxy halos with future X-ray microcalorimeters. We demonstrate the ability to construct temperature, velocity, and abundance ratio maps from spectral fitting.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01247v1.title: Strongly lensed [O III] emitters at Cosmic Noon with Roman: Characterizing extreme emission line galaxies on star cluster complex scales (100 pc)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01247v1.summary: Extreme emission line galaxies (EELGs) are valuable laboratories to study the astrophysics of massive stars. It is strongly expected that Roman's High Latitude Wide Area Survey will find many strongly gravitationally lensed [O III] emitters at Cosmic Noon. Roman imaging and grism spectroscopy willsimultaneously confirm these strong lens systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13898v2.title: X-ray Polarization of BL Lacertae in Outburst
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13898v2.summary: We report the first $> 99\%$ confidence detection of X-ray polarization in BL                Lacertae. Our data suggest that the energy band is at the crossover between the low- and high-frequency blazar emission humps. We discuss possible implications of our observations, including previous BL Lacertae pointings.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01147v1.title: An environment-dependent halo mass function as a driver for the early quenching of $z\geq1.5$ cluster galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01147v1.summary: Many galaxies with a stellar mass of $z=1.5$ are already quenched in both galaxy clusters ($>50$per cent) and the field ($>20$ per cent) A puzzling issue is that these massive quencher galaxies have stellar populations of similar age. This suggests that the dominant quenching mechanism for massive galaxies is similar in both environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01106v1.title: The truncation of the disk of NGC 4565: Detected up to z=4 kpc, with star formation, and affected by the warp
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01106v1.summary: Truncations are low surface brightness features in the disk outskirts of external galaxies. They indicate where the disk brightness abruptly drops and their location is thought to changeynamically. In previous analyses of Milky Way-like galaxies, truncations weredetected up to 3 kpc above the mid-plane but whether they remain present beyond that height remains unclear.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01090v1.title: Streamlined Lensed Quasar Identification in Multiband Images via Ensemble Networks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01090v1.summary: Quasars experiencing strong lensing offer unique viewpoints on subjects like cosmic expansion rate, the dark matter profile within the foreground, and the quasar host galaxies. Unfortunately, identifying them in astronomical images is challenging since they are overwhelmed by the abundance of non-lenses. To address this, we have developed a novel approach by using convolutional networks and visiontransformers trained on galaxy-quasar lens simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.03735v4.title: Star formation inefficiency and Kennicutt-Schmidt laws in early-type galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.03735v4.summary: Star formation in disk galaxies is observed to follow the empirical Kennicutt-Schmidt law. In contrast to disk galaxies, early-type galaxies (ETGs) typically associated with little to no star formation. Recent observations have noted the presence of massive gaseous cold disks in ETGs, raising the question as to why the conversion of gas into stars is so inefficient.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17313v2.title: ALMACAL XI: Over-densities as signposts to proto-clusters? A cautionary tale
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17313v2.summary: The most common approach to finding proto-clusters is to search for over-densities of galaxies. We report the serendipitous discovery of an extremely dense region centred on the blazar, J0217-0820. Its density is 8x higher than that predicted by blind submm surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02550v2.title: The Way to Quench: Galaxy evolution in Abell 2142
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02550v2.summary: We show how the star formation activity of galaxies is progressivelyinhibited from the outer region to the center of the massive cluster A2142. Most actively forming galaxies are within the cluster infall region, whereas most galaxies in the central region are quiescent. In addition, star formation in substructure grotesquegalaxies is generally more active than in halo galaxies and less active in outskirt galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01025v1.title: Geometric distortion and astrometric calibration of the JWST MIRI Medium Resolution Spectrometer
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01025v1.summary: The optics of the MRS introducesubstantial distortion. This needs to be rectified in order to reconstruct the observed astrophysical scene. We use data from the JWST/MIRI commissioning and cycle 1 calibration phase. The precision of the geometric distortion solution is estimated to be better than one tenth of a spatialresolution element.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01007v1.title: Origins of the north-south asymmetry in the ALFALFA HI velocity width function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01007v1.summary: The number density of extragalactic 21-cm radio sources as a function of spectral line-widths -- the HI width function (HIWF) -- is a tracer of the dark matter halo mass function. The ALFALFA survey measured the HIWF in northern and southern Galactic fields finding a systematically higher number of radio sources in the north. The asymmetry has two origins: the sensitivity of the survey is different in the two fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12902v2.title: Mapping non-axisymmetric velocity fields of external galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12902v2.summary: Non-circular motions caused by warps, lopsidedness, or satellite interactions are common and leave distinct signatures on galaxy velocity maps. We develop an algorithm that fits a non-axisymmetric model to the observed two-dimensional line-of-sight velocity map of an external galaxy. The method approximates a spiral galaxy as a flat disk, which is an appropriate assumption for spiral galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00753v1.title: KMT-2022-BLG-0475Lb and KMT-2022-BLG-1480Lb: Microlensing ice giants detected via non-caustic-crossing channel
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00753v1.summary: We investigate the microlensing data collected in the 2022 season from thehighest-cadenceMicrolensing surveys. We find that two lensingevents KMT-2022-BLG-0475 and K MT-20 22- BLG-1480 exhibit weak short-term                anomalies. From the detailed modeling of the lensing light curves, we identify that the anomalies are produced by planetary companions with a mass ratio to the primary.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00710v1.title: JWST Identification of Extremely Low C/N Galaxies with [N/O]$\gtrsim 0.5$ at $z\sim 6-10$ Evidencing the Early CNO-Cycle Enrichment and a Connection with Globular Cluster Formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00710v1.summary: We present chemical abundance ratios of 70 star-forming galaxies at $z\sim4$-10 observed by the JWST/NIRSpec ERO, GLASS, and CEERS programs. Among the 70 galaxies, we pinpointed 2 galaxies, CEERS_01019 and GLASS_150008, with extremely low C/N and high N/O ratios. These 3 galaxies are explained by scenarios with dominant CNO-cyclematerials, i.e. Wolf-Rayet stars, supermassive ($10^{3}-10^{5}\ M_{\odot}

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05743v3.title: Compact Binary Formation in Open Star Clusters I: High Formation Efficiency of Gaia BHs and Their Multiplicities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05743v3.summary: Gaia BHs, black hole (BH) binaries discovered from database of an astrometrictelescope Gaia, pose a question to the standard binary evolution model. We have performed gravitational$N$-body simulations of $100$ open clusters with $10^5 M_\odot$ in total for each metallicity $Z=0.02$ and $0.005$. We have discovered one Gaia BH-like binary escaping from an open cluster, and found that the formation efficiency of Gaia Bhs in open clusters is larger than in isolated binaries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10675v2.title: A search for kilonova radio flares in a sample of Swift/BAT short GRBs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10675v2.summary: The multi-messenger detection of GW170817 showed that binary neutron star(BNS) mergers are progenitors of (at least some) short gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) Short GRB jets (and their afterglows) can have structures more complex than predicted by the standard top-hat scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00641v1.title: Condensation in Dust-Enriched Systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00641v1.summary: Full chemical equilibrium calculations of the sequence of condensation of the elements from cosmic gases made by total vaporization of dust-enriched systems were performed. Condensation at logP=-3 bar and dust enrichments of 100x, 500x and 1000x occurs at oxygen fugacities of IW-3.1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14592v2.title: Astraeus VIII: A new framework for Lyman-$α$ emitters applied to different reionisation scenarios
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14592v2.summary: We use the {\sc astraeus} framework to investigate how the visibility and geographically distribution of Lyman-$\alpha$ emitters (LAEs) is sensitive to a halo mass-dependent fraction of ionisingradiation escaping from the galactic environment. To this end, we consider the two physically plausible scenarios of $f_\mathrm{esc}$ increasing and decreasing with rising halomass. We derive the corresponding observed Ly$\ alpha$ luminosities of galaxies for three different analytic Ly$ \alpha$ line profiles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15642v2.title: Separating the blue cloud and the red sequence using Otsu's method for image segmentation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15642v2.summary: The observed colour bimodality allows a classification of the galaxies into two distinct classes. Such classification is often carried out using empirical cuts in colour and othergalaxy properties that lack solid mathematical justifications. We propose a method for separating the galaxies in the `blue cloud' and the `red sequence'

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00594v1.title: Quantifying the 'Needle in a Haystack' Problem of Finding Supermassive Black Hole Related Flares in the ZTF Public Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00594v1.summary: Transient accretion events onto supermassive black holes (SMBHs) offer a new window into the population, accretion physics and stellar dynamics in galaxy centers. Such transients are rare, and finding them in wide-field transientsurveys is challenging. Here we present the results of a systematic real-time search for SMBH-related transients in Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) public alerts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02256v1.title: Magnetic braking during direct collapse black hole formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02256v1.summary: Magnetic fields are expected to be efficiently amplified during the formation of the first massive black holes via the small-scale dynamo. We find that after the initial amplification, magnetic fields contribute to the transport of angular momentum and reduce it compared to pure hydrodynamical simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12905v3.title: The evolution of the internal structure of massive star forming regions in the Milky Way as revealed by ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12905v3.summary: We analyze the structure of 15 protocluster forming regions in the Milky Way using their $1.3$ mm continuum emission maps from the ALMA-IMF large program. The calculated spectra display a self-similar regime on small scales as well as the presence of a prominent bump on larger scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00463v1.title: Confronting a Thin Disk-Wind Launching Mechanism of Broad-Line Emission in AGN with GRAVITY Observations of Quasar 3C 273
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00463v1.summary: Quasars show a remarkable degree of atomic emission line-broadening. This emission from the nucleus is often used to infer the mass of the centralsupermassive black hole. The radius estimate depends on the structure andkinematics of this so-called Broad-Line Region (BLR)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00367v1.title: Dark Dust III: The high-quality single-cloud reddening curve sample. Scrutinizing extinction curves in the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00367v1.summary: The nature of dust in the diffuse interstellar medium can be best investigated by means of reddening curves where only a single interstellar cloud lies between the observer and the background source. Published reddeningcurves often suffer from various systematic uncertainties. We exclude stars with composite spectra in the FORS2/FUSE data due to multiple stellar systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00333v1.title: Investigating Possible Correlations between Gamma-Ray and Optical Lightcurves for TeV-Detected Northern Blazars over 8 Years of Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00333v1.summary: Blazars are a subclass of active galactic nuclei (AGN) having relativisticjets aligned within a few degrees of our line-of-sight. Blazars form the majority of AGN detected in the TeV regime. The Fermi-Large Area Telescope (LAT) is a sensitive to photons having energies between 20 MeV and 2 TeV.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00311v1.title: Gas phase Elemental abundances in Molecular cloudS (GEMS) VIII. Unlocking the CS chemistry: the CH + S$\rightarrow$ CS + H and C$_2$ + S$\rightarrow$ CS + C reactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00311v1.summary: We revise the rates of reactions CH + S, CS + H and C_2 + S. These reactions were selected for their open-shell species with many degenerate electronic states. We find a reasonable agreement between model predictions and observations with a sulphur depletion factor of 20 relative to the sulphur cosmic abundance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08111v2.title: Conditional Colour-Magnitude Distribution of Central Galaxies in Galaxy Formation Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08111v2.summary: We investigate the conditional colour-magnitude distribution (CCMD) of the central galaxies in semi-analytic galaxy formation model (SAM) and hydrodynamic simulations. We find that the CCMD can be decomposed into red and blue components nearly orthogonal to each other. Central galaxy colour is correlated with halo assembly properties for low mass haloes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.05047v2.title: Mapping the Galactic Magnetic Field Orientation and Strength in Three Dimensions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.05047v2.summary: Mapping of the Galactic Magnetic Field (GMF) in three dimensions is essential to comprehend various astrophysical processes that occur within the Milky Way. This study endeavors to map the GMF by utilizing the latest MM2technique, the Velocity Gradient Technique (VGT), the Column Density Variance Approach, and the GALFA-H I survey of Neutral Hydrogen (H I) emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.15939v2.title: Inside MOND: Testing Gravity with Stellar Accelerations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.15939v2.summary: In a Milky Way-like galaxy the maximal transverse acceleration is well beyond even the most optimistic extrapolations of current capabilities. The maximum difference in the line-of-sight acceleration is within reach of future instruments. We quantify the differences between stellar accelerations in disk galaxies in a MONDian universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13220v2.title: Scalar dark matter vortex stabilization with black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13220v2.summary: Galaxies and their dark-matter halos are commonly presupposed to spin. It is an open question how this spin manifests in halos and soliton cores made of dark matter. One way spin could manifest in a necessarily irrotational SDM velocity field is with a vortex. But recent results have cast doubt on this scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08847v2.title: Probing bursty star formation by cross-correlating extragalactic background light and galaxy surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08847v2.summary: The star formation rate (SFR) variability is important for developing and testing theory of galaxy formation. We investigate how statistical measurements of theExtragalactic background light (EBL) can shed light on this topic. We show that the SFR variability can be characterized as a function of galaxy mass and redshift through the cross-correlation between the EBL and galaxy distributions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00074v1.title: Stellar properties of observed stars stripped in binaries in the Magellanic Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00074v1.summary: Massive stars stripped of their hydrogen-rich envelopes are thought to be the main progenitors for merging neutron stars and stripped-envelope supernovae. We recently presented the discovery of the first set of such stripped stars in a companion paper. We find that the stellar properties align well with the theoretical expectations from binary evolution models for helium-core burning envelope-stripped stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00060v1.title: Connection Between SDSS Galaxies and ELUCID Subhaloes in the Eye of Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00060v1.summary: We explore the feasibility of learning the connection between SDSS galaxies and ELUCID subhaloes with random forest (RF) RF models predict $M_r$ magnitude, $M*$ stellar mass, and specific star formation rate (sSFR) with several subhalo properties. We find that the colour-subhalo correlation in S DSS is lower than both the SAM and TNG.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00059v1.title: A study of extreme CIII]1908 & [OIII]88/[CII]157 emission in Pox 186: implications for JWST+ALMA (FUV+FIR) studies of distant galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00059v1.summary: Carbon spectral features are ubiquitous in the ultraviolet (UV) andfar-infrared (FIR) spectra of galaxies in the epoch of reionization (EoR) We investigate the ionized carbon content of a blue compact dwarf galaxy Pox 186 using UV, optical, mid-inf infrared and FIR data taken with telescopes in space and on the ground.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00053v1.title: Structure, Kinematics, and Observability of the Large Magellanic Cloud's Dynamical Friction Wake in Cold vs. Fuzzy Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00053v1.summary: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) will induce a dynamical friction (DF) wake on infall to the Milky Way. The MW's stellar halo will respond to the LMC and the dark matter (DM) wake, forming a stellar counterpart to the DM wake. This provides a novel opportunity to constrain the properties of the DM particle.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00051v1.title: The incidence of AGN in galaxies with different stellar population ages
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00051v1.summary: It has been argued that recycled gas from stellar mass loss in galaxies might serve as an important fuelling source for black holes (BHs) in their centers. We found that, among these most massive galaxies at low redshift, the fractionof low specific-accretion-rate (31 $<$ log $L_{\rm X}$/$M_\star$ $ <$ 32) AGNsincreases with time. This may be associated with additional halo gas and/or enhanced accretion capability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00052v1.title: Does God play dice with star clusters?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00052v1.summary: When a detailed model of a stellar population is unavailable, it is most typicallycommon to assume that stellar masses are independently and identically distributed. However, stellar masses resulting from causal, long-ranged physics cannot be truly random and independent. To compare stochastic sampling with a physical model, we run a suite of 100STARFORGE radiation magnetohydrodynamics simulations of low-mass star clusterformation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00050v1.title: Modeling the High-Energy Ionizing Output from Simple Stellar and X-ray Binary Populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00050v1.summary: We present a methodology for modeling the joint ionizing impact due to a simple X-ray population and its corresponding simple stellar population. We construct composite spectral energy distributions (SEDs) that include contributions from ultra-luminous X-rays and stars. We find that the addition of the SXP prolongs the high-energy ionizing output from the population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00041v1.title: Probing The Longest Dark Matter Lifetimes with the Line Emission Mapper
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00041v1.summary: The Line Emission Mapper (LEM) telescope concept is poised to revolutionize Galactic and extragalactic X-ray sensitivity. LEM features unprecedented eV scale energy resolution and aneffective area of 1600 cm$^2$ at 0.5 keV. Such features are ideally suited to explore decaying dark matter candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00042v1.title: Stellar halo striations from assumptions of axisymmetry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00042v1.summary: A series of vertical striations in space form as the LMC approaches its pericentre. These result from the formation of overdensities in angular momentum owing to a relationship between the precession rate of near radial orbits and the torquing of these orbits. This effect is heavily dependent on the shape of the inner potential. If a quadrupole component of the potential is included these striations become significantly less apparent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17822v1.title: Limits on scalar-induced gravitational waves from the stochastic background by pulsar timing array observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17822v1.summary: NANOGrav, PPTA, EPTA and CPTA have independently reported their evidence of the Stochastic Gravitational Wave Background (SGWB) We explore the possibility of explaining such a signal by the scalar-induced gravitationalwaves (IGWs) in the early universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01097v2.title: Small-scale dynamo with finite correlation times
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01097v2.summary: Fluctuation dynamos occur in most turbulent plasmas in astrophysics. They are prime candidates for amplifying and maintaining cosmic magnetic fields. A few analytical models exist to describe their behaviour but they are based onsimplifying assumptions. The Kazantsev model assumes an incompressible flow that is delta-correlated in time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17780v1.title: On the Tremaine-Weinberg method: how much can we trust gas tracers to measure pattern speeds?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17780v1.summary: Pattern speeds are a fundamental parameter of the dynamical features (e.g.bars, spiral arms) of a galaxy, setting resonance locations. The Tremaine-Weinberg (TW) method has become the most common method used to measure them in galaxies. When applied to observations of gas, the TW method may return invalid results.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17758v1.title: Long-Period Variables as distance and age indicators in the era of Gaia and LSST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17758v1.summary: Long-period variables are bright, evolved red giant stars showing periodicphotometric changes due to stellar pulsation. They make them highly promising distance indicators and tracers of young and intermediate-age stellar populations. Crucially, applications require a clear theoretical understanding of pulsation in connection with stellar evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17749v1.title: Quaia, the Gaia-unWISE Quasar Catalog: An All-Sky Spectroscopic Quasar Sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17749v1.summary: Quasar catalog, Quaia, has the cleanest selection function of any existingspectroscopic quasar sample. Quasar catalog draws on the 6,649,162 quasar candidates identified by the Gaia mission that have redshift estimates from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. The catalog is publicly available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.8060755.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17713v1.title: Deep Search for Glycine Conformers in Barnard 5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17713v1.summary: Glyine is found in meteorites and comets. Most searches for glycine in interstellar medium have focused on warm, high-mass molecular cloud sources. We aim to detect glycine towards the so-called methanol hotspot in the Barnard 5 dark cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17701v1.title: Initial sizes of star clusters: implications for cluster dissolution during galaxy evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17701v1.summary: Massive star clusters are often used as tracers of galaxy formation and assembly. We must understand their properties at formation, and how those properties change with time, galactic environment, and galaxyassembly history. The two most important intrinsic properties that govern star cluster evolution are mass and radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.15443v2.title: Inferring dark matter halo properties for HI-selected galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.15443v2.summary: We set constraints on the dark matter halo mass and concentration of ~22,000individual galaxies visible both in HI and optical light. This is achieved by combining two Bayesian models, one for the HI line width as a function of the stellar and neutral hydrogen mass distributions in a galaxy. The other for thegalaxy's total baryonic mass using the technique of inverse subhalo abundance matching.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17663v1.title: AGN STORM 2. IV. Swift X-ray and ultraviolet/optical monitoring of Mrk 817
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17663v1.summary: The AGN STORM 2 campaign is a large, multiwavelength reverberation mapping project. Swift performed daily monitoring of Mrk 817 for approximately 15 months. The X-ray spectrum is heavily obscured. UV/optical light curves show significant variability throughout the campaign.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17632v1.title: From binary to singular: the AGN PSO J334.2028+1.4075 under the high-resolution scope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17632v1.summary: PSO J334 is a luminous quasar located at redshift                z=2.06. The source gained attention when periodic flux density variations were discovered in its optical light curve. These variations were initiallyinterpreted as the variability due to the orbital motion of a supermassive black hole binary (SMBHB)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17627v1.title: Reanalysis of neutron-capture elements in the benchmark r-rich star CS 31082-001
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17627v1.summary: We revisit the abundances of neutron-capture elements in the metal-poor r-process-rich halo star CS 31082-001. In general, the r- process dominated elements are as enhanced as those in the Sun. However, the abundance of the lighter elements in our sample, from Ge to Sn, do notscale with the solar abundance pattern.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17545v1.title: The precession and inclinational variation across the plane of the Milky Way revealed by open clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17545v1.summary: Study of the geometry and motion of the Galactic disk using open clusters in the Gaia era. Findings suggest that the inclined orbits may beelliptical rather than circular. An analysis of the vertical motion along the Galactocentric radius reveals that the disk has warped with precession.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17454v1.title: Ghostly galaxies: accretion-dominated stellar systems in low-mass dark matter halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17454v1.summary: Wide-area deep imaging surveys have discovered large numbers of extremely low surface brightness dwarf galaxies. In this scenario, inefficient radiative cooling prevents starforming in the main branch of the merger tree of a low mass dark matterhalo. Almost all its stellar mass is acquired through mergers with less massive (but nevertheless star-forming) progenitors. Present-day systemsformed in this way would be `ghostly' isolated stellar halos with no central galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17432v1.title: Is it possible to measure the Lense-Thirring orbital shifts of the short-period S-star S4716 orbiting Sgr A$^\ast$?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17432v1.summary: S4716 has the shortest orbital period of all the S-stars that orbit the supermassive black hole (SMBH) in Sgr A. Its orbital shifts are of the order of $\simeq5-16$ arcseconds per revolution. Measuring these orbital shifts to the same level of accuracy would take 48 years.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00806v2.title: Distant Echoes of the Milky Way's Last Major Merger
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00806v2.summary: The majority of the Milky Way's stellar halo consists of debris from our last major merger, the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE) In the past few years, stars from GSE have been kinematically and chemically studied in theinner $30$ kpc of our Galaxy. simulations predict that accreted debris could lie at greater distances, forming substructures in the outer halo.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17405v1.title: General Physical Properties of Fermi blazars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17405v1.summary: We study the general physical properties of Fermi blazars. The jet kinetic power of most FSRQs can not be explained by the BP mechanism. There is a moderately strong correlation between the jet kineticpower and jet radiation power and the accretion disk luminosity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01395v2.title: The Anatomy of a Turbulent Radiative Mixing Layer: Insights from an Analytic Model with Turbulent Conduction and Viscosity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01395v2.summary: Turbulent Radiative Mixing Layers (TRMLs) form at the interface of cold, dense gas and hot, diffuse gas in motion with each other. TRMLs host intermediate temperature gases that areefficient in radiative cooling. They play a crucial role in controlling the cold gas supply, phase structure, and spectral features of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17334v1.title: Correlation Between Optical and X-ray Break Frequencies in Power Spectra of Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17334v1.summary: We analyze the optical power spectral density (PSD) for 22 active galacticnuclei. We fit either a damped random walk (DRW) or a broken power law model to constrain the model and break frequency. We find a high-frequency timescale which is proportional to both the X-ray and the black hole masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17333v1.title: Rubin Observatory LSST Stars Milky Way and Local Volume Star Clusters Roadmap
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17333v1.summary: The Vera C. Rubin Observatory will undertake the Legacy Survey of Space and Disorders. It will provide an unprecedented, volume-limited catalog of star clusters in the Southern Sky. The Star cluster subgroup of the Stars, Milky Way and Local Volume Working Group has identified key areas where the observatory will enable significant progress.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07886v2.title: Observational Signatures of Carbon-Oxygen White Dwarf Merger Remnants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07886v2.summary: Many double white dwarf (WD) mergers likely do not lead to a prompt nuclear explosion. We investigate the prospects for observationallydetecting the surviving remnants of such mergers. Merger remnants should produce strong carbon and oxygen recombination and fine-structure lines in the UV, optical and IR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17231v1.title: Roman CCS White Paper: Tracing stellar mass assembly and emerging quiescence at cosmic noon -- the case for deep imaging with all of Roman's wide filters in the HLTDS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17231v1.summary: We present arguments for including observations with all of the Wide Field Instrument imaging filters, with the exception of F146, within the Nancy GraceRoman Space Telescope. Our case is largely driven by the extragalactic deep field science that can be achieved with HLTDS observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17229v1.title: Spectral index variation across X-shaped radio galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17229v1.summary: 'X-shaped radio galaxies' (XRGs), or 'winged' radio galaxies, account for 10% of the radio galaxy population. The formation mechanism of the enigmatic subclass of radio galaxies is still unknown. The XRG model attributing their origin to an unresolved binary of active supermassive black holes within the nucleus of the host galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17228v1.title: Roman CCS White Paper: Options to Increase the Coverage Area of Prism Time Series in the High-Latitude Time Domain Core Community Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17228v1.summary: The current reference High-latitude time domain survey increases thecompleteness of transients with prism temporal time series data by adjusting ratio of prism-to-imaging time. In this white paper, we discuss how changes to the prism cadence and exposure time. affect supernova cosmology, transient typing and template building,and the study of rare transients.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17225v1.title: A Robust Study of High-Redshift Galaxies: Unsupervised Machine Learning for Characterising morphology with JWST up to z ~ 8
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17225v1.summary: We employ variational auto-encoders to perform feature extraction on galaxies at z $>$ 2 using JWST/NIRCam data. We identify 11 distinct morphological classes that exhibit clear separation in structural parameters. We observe a decline in the presence of spheroidal-type galaxies with increasing redshift, indicating a dominance of disk-like galaxies in the early universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17226v1.title: Roman CCS White Paper: Considerations for Selecting Fields for the Roman High-latitude Time Domain Core Community Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17226v1.summary: We recommend Akari Deep Field South (ADFS)/Euclid DeepField South (EDFS) in the Southern Hemisphere. It avoids bright stars, has minimal Milky Way dust, is in Roman Continuous viewing zone, overlaps withmultiple past and future surveys. In the North, Extended Groth Strip (EGS) is good except for its zodiacal variation. Supernova/Acceleration Probe North (SNAP-N) and European Large AreaInfrared Space Observatory Survey-North 1 (ELAIS N-1) are good.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17215v1.title: Using the motion of S2 to constrain scalar clouds around SgrA*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17215v1.summary: The motion of S2, one of the stars closest to the Galactic Centre, has been measured accurately and used to study the compact object at the centre. It is commonly accepted that this object is a supermassive blackhole but the nature of its environment is open to discussion. We use the available data for S2 to perform a Markov Chain Monte Carlo analysis and find the best-fit estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17208v1.title: Gaia EDR3 proper motions, energies, angular momenta of Milky Way dwarf galaxies: a recent infall to the Milky Way halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17208v1.summary: Gaia EDR3 has provided proper motions of Milky Way (MW) dwarf galaxies with unprecedented accuracy. We found that the total energy and angular momentum of MW dwarf galaxies are much larger than that of MW K-giant stars, Sagittarius streamishlystars and globular clusters. It suggests that manyMW dwarf galaxies have had a recent infall into the MW halo.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17166v1.title: Fossil group origins XIII. A paradigm shift: fossil groups as isolated structures rather than relics of the ancient Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17166v1.summary: Fossil systems selected using the magnitude gap appear to be, on average, more isolated from the cosmic web than non-fossil system. Fossil systems are located in regions of the cosmicweb not influenced by intersections. This result supports aformation scenario for fossil systems in which the lack of infalling galaxies from the galactic web favours the building of a magnitude gap.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17163v1.title: An Overdensity of Lyman Break Galaxies Around the Hot Dust-Obscured Galaxy WISE J224607.56$-$052634.9
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17163v1.summary: We identify Lyman Break Galaxy (LBG) candidates around the most luminous Hot Dust-Obscured Galaxy (Hot DOG) known. The number density of LBG candidates is not concentrated around W2246$-$0526. This suggests that the Hot DOG may not be the most massive galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17143v1.title: Dark Matter Spike surrounding Supermassive Black Holes Binary and the nanohertz Stochastic Gravitational Wave Background
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17143v1.summary: The amplitude and spectrum of this inferred signal align closely with the astrophysical predictions. We explore the possibility to detect dark matter spikes surrounding massive black holes, which could potentially impact the gravitational-wave waveform. We demonstrate that the combined effects of GW radiation and the friction of the dark matter spike exhibits detectable manifestations within the nHz frequency range of the SGWB.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12514v2.title: Roman CCS White Paper: Characterizing the Galactic population of isolated black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12514v2.summary: There are estimated to be 100 million isolated black holes (BHs) in the Milky Way. Only one has been found so far, resulting in significant uncertainty about their properties. The Galactic Bulge Time Domain Survey provides the only opportunity in the coming decades to grow this catalog by order of magnitude.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01038v3.title: Clouds accreting from the IGM are not able to feed the star formation of low-redshift disc galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01038v3.summary: Galactic halos accrete material from the intergalactic medium (IGM) and part of this accretion is expected to be in the form of cool gas. Whether this material is able to feed star formation or evaporates into the CGM hot phase (corona) is not yet understood. We explore the evolution of cool CGM clouds accreted from the IGM and falling through the hot corona of low-redshift disc galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17022v1.title: Footprints of Axion-Like Particle in Pulsar Timing Array Data and JWST Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17022v1.summary: Pulsar Timing Array (PTA) collaborations have independentlyreported the evidence for a stochastic gravitational-wave background (SGWB), which can unveil the formation of primordial seeds of inhomogeneities in theearly universe. With the SGWB parameters inferred from PTAs data, we can make a Prediction of the Primordial Black Hole (PBH) clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16977v1.title: Astrophysical neutrino oscillations after pulsar timing array analyses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16977v1.summary: The pattern of neutrino flavor oscillations could be altered by the influence of noisy perturbations such as those arising from a gravitational wavebackground. A stochastic process consistent with a GWB has been reported by the independent analyses of pulsar timing array (PTA) data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16959v1.title: Complex Organic Molecules in a Very Young Hot Corino, HOPS 373SW
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16959v1.summary: HOPS 373SW is a component of a protostellar binary with a separation of 1500 au. The dust continuum opacity is very high toward the source center. High abundance of singly, doubly, and triply deuterated methanol (CH2DOH, CHD2OH, and CD3OH) suggests a very early evolutionary stage in the hot corinophase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.02821v2.title: Dark matter halo properties of the Galactic dwarf satellites: implication for chemo-dynamical evolution of the satellites and a challenge to $Λ$CDM
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.02821v2.summary: Elucidating dark matter density profiles in the Galactic dwarf satellites isessential to understanding not only the quintessence of dark matter, but also the evolution of the satellites themselves. In this work, we present the current constraints on dark matter densities in the galactic ultra-faint dwarf galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05793v2.title: Confronting fuzzy dark matter with the rotation curves of nearby dwarf irregular galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05793v2.summary: We investigate phenomenologically the viability of fuzzy dark matter (FDM) We do this by confronting the predictions of the model, in particular, theformation of a solitonic core at the center of dark matter halos. FDM provides an excellent fit to the rotation curves of the ''LITTLE THINGS in 3D'' catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.15466v3.title: On the Hα faintness of the North Polar Spur
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.15466v3.summary: The ratio of H$\alpha$ intensity to 1.4 GHz radio continuum intensity in the North Polar Spur (NPS) is measured to be two orders of magnitude smaller than in the typical shell-type oldsupernova remnants, Cygnus Loop and S147. This favours the Galactic-Centre explosion model for NPS, whichpostulates a giant shock wave at a distance of several kilo parsecs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16923v1.title: NAUTILUS: boosting Bayesian importance nested sampling with deep learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16923v1.summary: We introduce a novel approach to boost the efficiency of the importance.nested sampling (INS) technique for Bayesian posterior and evidence estimation. We show how to combine INS with deep learning via neural network regression to achieve this task. We also introduce NAUTILUS, a reference open-source Python implementation of this technique.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05242v3.title: The many reasons that the rotation curves of low-mass galaxies can fail as tracers of their matter distributions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05242v3.summary: It is routinely assumed that galaxy rotation curves are equal to their circular velocity curves. We take a visualisation-driven approach to explore the limits of the validity of this assumption. We use ourvisualisations to guide an assessment of how many galaxies are likely to be strongly perturbed by processes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16887v1.title: The History of The Milky Way: The Evolution of Star Formation, Cosmic Rays, Metallicity, and Stellar Dynamics over Cosmic Time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16887v1.summary: We study the long-term evolution of the Milky Way (MW) over cosmic time by modeling the star formation, cosmic rays, metallicity, stellar dynamics, outflows and inflows of the galactic system. The mass accretion is modeled by the results of $N$-body simulations for the cold dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16875v1.title: Gravitational collapse and accretion flows in the hub filament system G323.46-0.08
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16875v1.summary: G323.46-0.08 consists of three filaments that converge toward the central high_mass clump AGAL323.459-0,079. F-west and Part 1 of the F-south show clear large-scale velocityipientgradients 0.28 and 0.44 km s-1 pc-1, respectively. They seem to be channeling material into AGAL 323.459.079 and to propel star forming activity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16818v1.title: Galaxies in voids assemble their stars slowly
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16818v1.summary: Galaxies in the Universe are distributed in a web-like structurecharacterised by different large-scale environments. These environments include dense clusters, elongated                filaments, sheetlike walls, and under-dense regions, called voids. The lowdensity in voids is expected to affect the properties of their galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02416v2.title: Simulations of high-redshift [OIII] emitters: Chemical evolution and multi-line diagnostics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02416v2.summary: Recent observations by James Webb Space Telescope discovered a number of high-redshift galaxies with strong emission lines from doubly ionized oxygen. We show that young stellar populations in the star-forming galaxies boost the ratio of line luminosity to starformation rate. Measuring the flux ratios of rest-frame optical and far-infrared lines allows us to estimate the physical conditions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16748v1.title: A Dynamically Distinct Stellar Population in the Leading Arm of the Sagittarius Stream
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16748v1.summary: We present a chemical and dynamical analysis of the leading arm (LA) and trailing arm (TA) of the Sagittarius (Sgr) stream. One striking finding is a relatively larger fraction of low-eccentricity stars (e < 0.4) in the LA than in the TA and SC. We attempt to explain the different e-distribution by introducing a time-dependentperturbation of the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.11217v4.title: Covariant formulation of refracted gravity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.11217v4.summary: We propose a covariant formulation of refracted gravity (CRG) CRG is based on the introduction of gravitational permittivity (GP) GP mimics dark matter (DM) phenomenology. We find that the same field that mimics DM also drives the accelerated expansion of the universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16683v1.title: The Seoul National University AGN Monitoring Project IV: H$α$ reverberation mapping of 6 AGNs and the H$α$ Size-Luminosity Relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16683v1.summary: The size-luminosity relation has paramount importance for estimating the mass of black holes in active galactic nuclei (AGNs) The size of the H$\beta$ BLR is often estimated from the opticalcontinuum luminosity at 5100\angstrom{} , while the size of H$''alpha'' BLR and its correlation with the luminosity is much less constrained.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.15611v2.title: The Stellar Abundances and Galactic Evolution Survey (SAGES) -- -- I. General Description and the First Data Release (DR1)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.15611v2.summary: The Stellar Abundances and Galactic Evolution Survey (SAGES) is a specifically-designed multi-band photometric survey aiming to provide reliable stellar parameters. It was carried out with the 2.3-m Bok telescope and three other telescopes. The observations in the $u_s$ and $v_s $ passband produced over 36,092 frames of images in total.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00762v2.title: AGN Feedback in SDSS-IV MaNGA: AGNs have Suppressed Central Star Formation Rates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00762v2.summary: Despite the importance of feedback from active galactic nuclei, observational constraints on the influence of AGN feedback on star formation remain weak. We have compared the starformation trends of 279 low-redshift AGN galaxies with 558 inactive control galaxies using integral field unit spectroscopy from the SDSS-IV MaNGA survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16609v1.title: Dust Formation in Common Envelope Binary Interaction -- I: 3D Simulations Using the Bowen Approximation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16609v1.summary: We carried out 3D smoothed particle hydrodynamics simulations of the common                envelope binary interaction using the approximation of Bowen. We found that the dust-driven wind leads to a relatively small.increase in the unbound gas, with the effect being smaller for the tabulated.equation of state simulations and for the more massive primary.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02468v2.title: The Cosmos in its Infancy: JADES Galaxy Candidates at z > 8 in GOODS-S and GOODS-N
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02468v2.summary: We present a catalog of 717 candidate galaxies at $z > 8$ selected from 125 square arcminutes of NIRCam imaging. The high-redshift galaxyipientcandidates were selected from their estimated photometric redshifts calculated using a template fitting approach. We explore these candidates in detail, highlightinginteresting resolved or extended sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16500v1.title: Kinematics of the Local Group gas and galaxies in the Hestia simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16500v1.summary: The Local Group (LG) consists of two giant spiral galaxies, the Milky Way(MW) and Andromeda (M31), and several smaller galaxies. The MW and M31 are approaching each other at a radial velocity of about $-109\,$km. This flow imprints a velocity dipole pattern when Galactic rotation is removed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16479v1.title: New Compact Object Binary Populations with Precision Astrometry (Roman White Paper)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16479v1.summary: Compact object binaries (a black hole or a neutron star orbiting a non-degenerate stellar companion) are key to our understanding of late massivemassivestar evolution. Gaia has opened the door to astrometric studies of these systems. We propose to use the microlensing.Galactic Bulge Time Domain Survey to identify new wide-orbit black hole compact.object binaries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16475v1.title: Synthetic Gaia DR3 surveys from the FIRE cosmological simulations of Milky-Way-mass galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16475v1.summary: The third data release (DR3) of Gaia has provided a five-fold increase in thenumber of radial velocity measurements of stars. The synthetic surveys are publicly available and can be found at http://ananke.hub.yt/. Similarly to the previous release of Ananke,these surveys are based on cosmological simulations and thus can model non-equilibrium dynamical effects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16474v1.title: XQR-30: Black Hole Masses and Accretion Rates of 42 z>6 Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16474v1.summary: We present bolometric luminosities, black hole masses and Eddington ratios for 42 luminous quasars at z>6 using high signal-to-noise ratio VLT/X-Shooterspectra. The MgII-derived masses are between (~(0.8-12) x 10^9 Msun, and thederived EdDington ratios are within ~0.13-1.73, with a mean (median) of 0.84                                .

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16467v1.title: Light and colour of cirrus, translucent and opaque dust in the high-latitude area of LDN 1642
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16467v1.summary: We have performed a 5-colour surface photometric study of the high-galactic-latitude area of dark nebula LDN 1642. Scattered light properties are presented of diffuse, translucent and opaque dust over the range of 3500 -- 5500 A. The intensity of the scattered light depends on dust column density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16465v1.title: Lithium in Kepler Red Giants: Defining Normal and Anomalous
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16465v1.summary: Lithium abundance in red giant stars is mass dependent, with higher mass stars having higher lithium abundances. Highly lithium enhanced stars may cluster around 0.8 or 1.8 M$_\odot$. We find no simple correlation between lithium abundance and indicators of binarity. Most lithium rich giants are in the core-helium burning phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16433v1.title: Period-Luminosity-Metallicity relations for Classical Pulsators at Near-infrared Wavelengths
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16433v1.summary: Classical pulsating stars such as Cepheid and RR Lyrae variables exhibit well-defined Period-Luminosity relations at near-infrared wavelengths. Despite their extensive use as stellar standard candles, the effects of metallicity onPeriod-L luminosity relations for these pulsating variables, and in turn, on possible biases in distance determinations, are not well understood.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16436v1.title: The cosmological star formation history from the Local Volume of galaxies and constraints on the matter homogeneity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16436v1.summary: The Lilly-Madau plot is commonly interpreted as the history of the cosmic star formation of the Universe by showing the co-moving star formation rate (SFRD) over cosmic time. We reconstruct the SFHs of galaxies located in the Local Volume (LV) based on delayed-$\tau$ and power-law SFH models. The SFRDs of the LV are significantly lower at redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16437v1.title: NuSTAR Observations of Four Mid-IR Selected Dual AGN Candidates in Galaxy Mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16437v1.summary: Mergers of galaxies are a ubiquitous phenomenon in the Universe. It is generally accepted that the peak of AGNaccretion activity occurs at nuclear separations of $lesssim10$ kpc for major mergers. Here we present new NuSTAR and XMM-Newton observations for a subsample of mid-IR preselected dual AGN candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16441v1.title: The IR Compactness of Dusty Galaxies Set Star-formation and Dust Properties at z~0-2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16441v1.summary: Surface densities of gas, dust and stars provide a window into the physics of star-formation. Until the advent of high-resolutionfar-infrared/sub-millimeter observations, it has been difficult to assess dust in dusty galaxies. Changes in the gas and dust conditions might help drive star- formation efficiency up.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11179v2.title: The Northern Cross Fast Radio Burst project -- III. The FRB-magnetar connection in a sample of nearby galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11179v2.summary: Fast radio bursts (FRBs) are millisecond radio transients. The nature of their progenitors is still a matter of debate. The proposedFRB-magnetar connection was strengthened by the discovery of an FRB-like event from the Galactic magnetar SGR J1935+2154.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14354v2.title: The Swift Deep Galactic Plane Survey (DGPS) Phase-I Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14354v2.summary: The Deep Galactic Plane Survey is a Key Project. 380 tiled pointings covering 40 deg$^{2}$ of the Galactic Plane. Each pointing has a $5$ ks exposure, yielding a total of 1.9 Ms spread across the entire survey footprint. In total, we identify 928 X-ray sources, of which 348 are unique.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v5.title: An analysis of the turbulence in the central region of the Orion Nebula (M42) -- II. homogeneity and power-spectrum analyses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v5.summary: In this second communication we continue our analysis of the turbulence in the Huygens Region of the Orion Nebula. We find that the higher-ordertransverse structure functions are almost proportional to the second-order transverse structure function. This implies that there is some type of invariant statistical structure in the velocity field. We also obtain and analyse the power-spectrum of the turbulent field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16228v1.title: The second data release from the European Pulsar Timing Array: VI. Challenging the ultralight dark matter paradigm
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16228v1.summary: Pulsar Timing Array experiments probe the presence of possible ultralight dark matter particles through decade-long timingof an ensemble of galactic millisecond radio pulsars. We focus on the most robust scenario, in which dark matter interacts only gravitationally with ordinarybaryonic matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16227v1.title: The second data release from the European Pulsar Timing Array: V. Implications for massive black holes, dark matter and the early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16227v1.summary: The European Pulsar Timing Array (EPTA) measured a low-frequency common signal in the gravitational wave background. Such signal may have its origin in a number of physical processes including a cosmic population of inspiralling supermassive black hole binaries. If this origin isconfirmed, this is the first direct evidence that SMBHBs merge in nature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16226v1.title: The second data release from the European Pulsar Timing Array IV. Search for continuous gravitational wave signals
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16226v1.summary: The most significant candidate event from this search has a gravitational wave frequency of 4-5 nHz. Such a signal could be generated by a supermassive black hole binary (SMBHB) in the local Universe. We present results of simulations that demonstrate that data containing a weak gravitational wave background can bemisinterpreted as data including a CGW.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16224v1.title: The second data release from the European Pulsar Timing Array I. The dataset and timing analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16224v1.summary: Pulsar timing arrays offer a probe of the low-frequency gravitational wavespectrum (1 - 100 nanohertz) We present the dataset and results of the timing analysis from the second data release of the European Pulsar Timing Array (EPTA) We discuss the improvements to the individual pulsarparameter estimates, as well as new measurements of the physical properties ofthese pulsars and their companions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16218v1.title: The NANOGrav 15-Year Data Set: Detector Characterization and Noise Budget
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16218v1.summary: Pulsar timing arrays (PTAs) are galactic-scale gravitational wave detectors. Each arm is composed of a millisecond pulsar, a radio telescope, and akiloparsecs-long path. We present a noise and sensitivity analysis to accompany the NANOGrav 15-year data release.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16216v1.title: Searching for the nano-Hertz stochastic gravitational wave background with the Chinese Pulsar Timing Array Data Release I
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16216v1.summary: Chinese Pulsar Timing Array(CPTA) is a collaboration aiming at the direct GW detection with observations carried out using Chinese radio telescopes. Observing and timing a group of millisecond pulsars (MSPs) enables the direct detection of gravitational waves (GWs) The GW signals can be identified from the spatial correlations encoded in thetimes-of-arrival of widely spaced pulsar-pairs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16215v1.title: Search for an isotropic gravitational-wave background with the Parkes Pulsar Timing Array
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16215v1.summary: Pulsar timing arrays aim to detect nanohertz-frequency gravitational waves. A background of GWs modulates pulsar arrival times and manifests as a process common to all pulsars. Here we describe a search for an isotropic stochastic gravitational wave background.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16214v1.title: The second data release from the European Pulsar Timing Array III. Search for gravitational wave signals
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16214v1.summary: Findings based on data from the European Pulsar Timing Array (EPTA) for 25 millisecond pulsars and a combination with the first data release of the Indian Pulse TimingArray (InPTA) With the full EPTA data set, we find marginal evidence for a GWB, with a Bayes factor of four and a false alarm probability of $4\%$. With the 10.3-year subset, we report evidence. for aGWB with aBayes factors of $60$ and afalse alarm probability. of about$0.1\%$ ($

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10188v3.title: Stellar-mass black holes in the Hyades star cluster?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10188v3.summary: Astrophysical models of binary-black hole mergers in the Universe require a significant fraction of stellar-mass black holes (BHs) to receive negligible natal kicks. This implies that BHsshould be retained even in open clusters with low escape velocities. We search for signatures of the presence of BHS in the nearest open cluster to the Sun - the Hyades.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16100v1.title: Probing Galaxy structure with VHE $γ$ rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16100v1.summary: As an observer from within the Milky Way, it is difficult to determine its global structure. Despite extensive observational data, we have no conclusive description of the structure of our own Galaxy. For very-high-energy (VHE) rays, the most.comprehensive catalogue of Galactic sources resulting from the H.GPS. shows a striking asymmetry in the. distribution of the sources in the latitudinal direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16078v1.title: The LOFAR view of massive early-type galaxies: Transition from radio AGN to host emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16078v1.summary: We extend the study of the radio emission in early-type galaxies (ETGs) in the nearby Universe (recession velocity <7,500 km/s) Most (85%) of the detected sources are compact, with sizes <4 kpc. The radio emission of 31 mETGs is extended on scales ranging from 2 to 180 kpc (median 12 kpc)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16073v1.title: 2.5-MHD models of circumstellar discs around FS~CMa post-mergers : I. Non-stationary accretion stage
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16073v1.summary: We investigate the dynamic evolution of gaseous region around FS~CMa post-mergers. Due to the slow rotation of a central B-type star, the dynamics are driven mainly by the magnetic field of the central star. Jets are probably detected as discrete absorption components in the resonance lines ofFS~C ma stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16040v1.title: GAMA/DEVILS: Cosmic star formation and AGN activity over 12.5 billion years
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16040v1.summary: We use the Galaxy and Mass Assembly (GAMA) and the Deep Extragalactic VisibleLegacy Survey (DEVILS) observational data sets to calculate the cosmic starformation rate (SFR) and active galactic nuclei (AGN) bolometric luminosity history. We find that both the CSFH and CAGNH evolve similarly, rising in the early Universe up to a peak at look-back time ($z \approx 2$), before declining toward the present day.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06823v1.title: Multi-TeV dark matter density in the inner Milky Way halo: spectral and dynamical constraints
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06823v1.summary: We develop a comprehensive study of the gamma-ray flux observed by H.E.S.S., in 5 regions of the Galactic Center (GC) Motivated by previous works on a possible Dark Matter (DM) explanation for the TeV cut-off observed in theinnermost of the Galaxy. We set upper limits on the density distribution of thermal multi-TeV WIMPs, compatible with the observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05838v2.title: Precession-induced Variability in AGN Jets and OJ 287
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05838v2.summary: The physics of the underlying jet leads to shocks, instabilities, or to ejections of plasmoids. The appearance of the jet can, however, be strongly affected by precession. We demonstrate this modulating power of precession for OJ 287. We show that the spectral state of the Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) can be directly related to the jet's precession phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.10450v2.title: A simple spectroscopic technique to identify rejuvenating galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.10450v2.summary: Rejuvenating galaxies are unusual galaxies that fully quench and then experience a "rejuvenation" event to become star-forming once                more. Rejuvenation rates vary substantially in models of galaxy formation: 10%-70% of massive galaxies are expected to experience rejuvenation by z = 0.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06749v1.title: Zwicky Transient Facility and Globular Clusters: the gr-Band Period-Luminosity Relations for Mira Variables at Maximum Light and Their Applications to Local Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06749v1.summary: Based on 14 Miras located in 7 globular clusters, we derived the first                gr-band period-luminosity (PL) at maximum light. We applied our derived PL relations to the known extragalactic Miras in five local galaxies. We demonstrated that our PL relations can be applied to short-period Miras.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01605v3.title: Multiwavelength Bulge-Disk Decomposition for the Galaxy M81 (NGC 3031). I. Morphology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01605v3.summary: A panchromatic investigation of morphology for the early-type spiral galaxy                M81 is presented in this paper. We perform bulge-disk decomposition in M81 images at a total of 20 wavebands from FUV to NIR. The morphology as a function of wavelength appears as a variable-slope trend of the Sersic index and effective radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06694v1.title: Interstellar Conditions Deduced from Interstellar Neutral Helium Observed by IBEX and Global Heliosphere Modeling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06694v1.summary: In situ observations of interstellar neutral (ISN) helium atoms by the Interstellar Boundary Explorer (IBEX) mission. Most ISN helium atoms penetrating the heliosphere originate in the pristine VLISM. As the primary atoms travel through the outer heliosheath, they charge exchange with ions in slowed and compressed plasma creating the secondary population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06692v1.title: Ejecta, Rings, and Dust in SN 1987A with JWST MIRI/MRS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06692v1.summary: Supernova (SN) 1987A is the nearest supernova in $\sim$400 years. We spatially resolved the ejecta, equatorial ring (ER) and outer rings in the mid-infrared 12,927 days after the explosion. The spectra are rich in line and dust continuum emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07412v2.title: Multi-class classification of Fermi-LAT sources with hierarchical class definition
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07412v2.summary: Multi-class classification of Fermi-LAT gamma-ray sources using machine learning with hierarchical determination of classes. One of the main challenges is that the size of some of the classes is relatively small. We find that the classification with many classes gives a more detailed information about the physical nature of the sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06596v1.title: Investigating 16 Open Clusters in the Kepler/K2-Gaia DR3 field. I. Membership, Binary, and Rotation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06596v1.summary: Using data from the Gaia Data Release 3 (Gaia DR3) and Kepler/K2, we present a catalog of 16 open clusters with ages ranging from 4 to 4000 Myr. We find that the rotational features of binaries are similar to that of single stars, while features for binaries are more scattered in the rotation period.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01175v2.title: Dynamic Wisp Removal in JWST NIRCam Images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01175v2.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) near-infrared camera (NIRCam) has been found to exhibit serious wisp-like structures in four of its eight short-wavelength detectors. The exact structure and strength of these wisps ishighly variable with the position and orientation of JWST, so the use of static templates is non-optimal.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09673v2.title: The physical drivers of gas turbulence in simulated disc galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09673v2.summary: We use the EAGLE cosmological simulations to study the evolution of thevertical velocity dispersion of cold gas. We look at its connection to stellar feedback, gravitational instabilities, gas accretion and galaxy mergers. The prevalence of local instabilities in discs is uncorrelated with low redshift and becomes only weakly correlated at high redshifts.
