http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06557v1.title: The kinematics of young stellar population in the W5 region of the Cassiopeia OB6 association: implication on the formation process of stellar associations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06557v1.summary: The star-forming region W5 is a major part of the Cassiopeia OB6 association. Its internal structure and kinematics may provide hints of the star formation process in this region. A total of 490 out of 2,000 young stars are confirmed as members of W5.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07324v2.title: Spectroscopic follow-up of black hole and neutron star candidates in ellipsoidal variables from Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07324v2.summary: We present multi-epoch spectroscopic follow-up of a sample of ellipsoidalvariables selected from Gaia DR3 as candidates for hosting quiescent blackholes (BHs) and neutron stars (NSs) Our targets were identified as BH/NS candidates because their optical light curves -- when interpreted with models that attribute variability to tidal distortion of a star by a companion -- suggest that the companions are compact objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06460v1.title: Infrared action spectroscopy as tool for probing gas-phase dynamics: Protonated Dimethyl Ether, (CH$_3$)$_2$OH$^+$, formed by the reaction of CH$_3$OH$_{2}^{+}$ with CH$_3$OH
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06460v1.summary: Methanol is one of the most abundant interstellar Complex Organic Molecules (iCOMs) It represents a major building block for the synthesis of increasingly complex oxygen-containing molecules. The formation of protonated dimethyl ether as a product of the reaction is spectroscopically confirmed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06411v1.title: Magnetic Fields in Multiphase Turbulence: Impacts on Dynamics and Structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06411v1.summary: The influence of magnetic fields on mixing of the different phases is still largely unexplored. We generally observe a higher mean magnetic field in the cold. gas phase due to flux freezing and reveal fractal-like magnetic field lines in a turbulent environment. We, furthermore, find the cold gas clump size distribution to beindependent of the magnetic fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06378v1.title: Closing the stellar labels gap: An unsupervised, generative model for $\textit{Gaia}$ BP/RP spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06378v1.summary: The recent release of 220+ million BP/RP spectra in DR3 presents an opportunity to apply deep learning models to an unprecedentednumber of stellar spectra, at extremely low-resolution. No previous spectroscopic survey can provide enough stellar labels to cover theBP/RP parameter space. We present an unsupervised, deep learning model for BP/ RP spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06374v1.title: Environmental dependence of AGN activity and star formation in galaxy clusters from Magneticum simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06374v1.summary: Cluster environment has a strong impact on the star formation rate and AGN activity in cluster galaxies. We examined the influence of stellar mass, distance to the nearest neighbouring galaxy, clustercentric radius, substructure membership and large-scale surroundings on the fraction of galaxies hosting an AGN. We found that in low-mass galaxies,AGN activity and star formation are similarlyaffected by the environment and decline towards the cluster centre. In massivegalaxies, the impact is different.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06368v1.title: Metallicity beats sSFR: The connection between superluminous supernova host galaxy environments and the importance of metallicity for their production
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06368v1.summary: We analyse 33 Type I superluminous supernovae (SLSNe) taken from ZTF's BrightTransient Survey to investigate the local environments of their host galaxies. We find that SLSN hosts are also rarely found within high-density environments. Only $3\substack{+9 \\-1}$ per cent of SLSNe hosts were found in regions with 2 or more bright galaxies within 2 Mpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06360v1.title: An Exploration of AGN and Stellar Feedback Effects in the Intergalactic Medium via the Low Redshift Lyman-$α$ Forest
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06360v1.summary: We explore the role of galactic feedback on the low redshift Lyman-$\alpha$(Ly$\ alpha$)~forest. We find that both AGN and stellar feedback in Simba play a role in setting the column density distribution function (CDD) and the Dopplerwidth ($b$-value) distribution. The Simba AGN jet feedback mode is able to efficientlyly transport energy out to the diffuse IGM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06363v1.title: Varstrometry for Off-nucleus and Dual Sub-kpc AGN (VODKA): Very Long Baseline Array Searches for Dual or Off-nucleus Quasars and Small-scale Jets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06363v1.summary: Dual and off-nucleus active supermassive black holes are expected to be common in the hierarchical structure formation paradigm. Their identification at parsec scales remains a challenge due to strict angularresolution requirements. We conduct a systematic study using the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) to examine 23 radio-bright candidate dual quasars. The radio emission from three candidates is likely to originate from small-scale jets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06358v1.title: Looking ahead to the sky with the Square Kilometre Array: simulating flux densities & resolved radio morphologies of $0<z<2.5$ star-forming galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06358v1.summary: SKA-MID surveys will be the first in the radio domain to achieve clearlysub-arcsecond resolution at high sensitivity over large areas. We create images at the proposed depths of the band 2 wide, deep and ultradeep reference surveys. We measure galaxy flux density, half-light radius, Gini and asymmetry before and after simulation with the SKA response.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06351v1.title: The Kiloparsec Scale Influence of the AGN in NGC 1068 with SALT RSS Fabry-Pérot Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06351v1.summary: Fabry-P\'erot (FP) imaging and longslit spectroscopy of the nearby Type II Seyfert II galaxy NGC 1068 using the Robert Stobie Spectrograph (RSS) on theSouthern African Large Telescope (SALT) We observe the impact of the centralActive Galactic Nucleus on the ionized gas in the galaxy on kiloparsecscales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06352v1.title: The Atacama Cosmology Telescope: Galactic Dust Structure and the Cosmic PAH Background in Cross-correlation with WISE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06352v1.summary: We present a cross-correlation analysis between $1'$ resolution totalintensity and polarization observations from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope. We detect a spatially isotropic signal in the WISE$\times$ACT $TT$cross power spectrum at 30$\sigma$ significance that we interpret as the correlation between the cosmic infrared background at ACT frequencies and PAH emission from galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06353v1.title: High-energy electromagnetic, neutrino, and cosmic-ray emission by stellar-mass black holes in disks of active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06353v1.summary: Some Seyfert galaxies are detected in high-energy gamma rays. The origins of the cosmic neutrino and MeV gamma-ray backgrounds have been veiled in mystery. We propose emission from stellar-mass BHs(sBHs) embedded in disks of active galactic nuclei (AGN)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06336v1.title: Ultraviolet Compactness of High-Redshift Galaxies as a Tracer of Early-Stage Gas Infall, Stochastic Star Formation, and Offset from the Fundamental Metallicity Relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06336v1.summary: There is evidence that the most metal-deficient high-redshift galaxies are also the most compact. We measure the rest-ultraviolet (UV) sizes of $z > 4$galaxies, inferring the mass-size relation at $z = 4-10$ with a power-law slope of $0.21 \pm 0.04$. We investigate the redshift evolution of theMass-sizerelation, finding that at a fixed stellar mass, higher redshift galaxies appear more compact.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06308v1.title: The Spatial and Emission Properties of the Large [O III] Emission Nebula Near M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06308v1.summary: A 1.5 degree long [O III] emission nebula was found 1.2 degrees southeast of the M31 nucleus. We discuss SDSO as a possible unrecognized supernova remnant, a large and unusually nearby planetary nebula, or an interaction of M31's outer halo gas with circumgalactic gas. We conclude that galactic origins are unlikely and favor an extragalactic M31 halo--circumgalactic cloud interaction scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06345v1.title: Cornerstone: Octree Construction Algorithms for Scalable Particle Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06345v1.summary: Cornerstone is based on algorithms developed for 3D computer graphics. It is able to operate on all levels of tree hierarchies in parallel. The resulting octrees are suitable for supporting the computation of various kinds of short and long range interactions in N-body methods, such as Barnes-Hut.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06237v1.title: Physical parameters of stellar population in star formation regions of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06237v1.summary: The study is based on the catalogue of 1510 starforming regions with ages ~10-20 Myr in 19 spiral galaxies. Extinctions, gas chemical abundances, and sizes of star formation regions are measured. Using numerical SSP models, we estimated ages and masses of 400 young stellar groupings.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06231v1.title: Submillimeter Observations of Magnetic Fields in Massive Star-forming Region W75N
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06231v1.summary: This paper presents the results of full polarization observations of the massive star-forming region W75N, conducted with 3 arcsec spatial resolutions at 345 GHz using the Submillimeter Array. The overall magnetic field strength and orientation are found to agree with those from the previous observations. Further analyses indicated that the cloud is undergoing global gravitational collapse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06222v1.title: The physical and chemical structure of Sagittarius B2 VIIIa. Dust and ionized gas contributions to the full molecular line survey of 47 hot cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06222v1.summary: Sagittarius B2 (Sgr B2) is a giant molecular cloud complex in the central                molecular zone of our Galaxy hosting several sites of high-mass star formation. We used ALMA toperform an unbiased spectral line survey of all 47 sources in ALMA band 6 with a frequency coverage from 211 GHz to 275 GHz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17215v2.title: Using the motion of S2 to constrain scalar clouds around SgrA*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17215v2.summary: The motion of S2, one of the stars closest to the Galactic Centre, has been measured accurately and used to study the compact object at the centre. It is commonly accepted that this object is a supermassive blackhole but the nature of its environment is open to discussion. We use the available data for S2 to perform a Markov Chain Monte Carlo analysis and find the best-fit estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06178v1.title: Disk and Envelope Streamers of the GGD27-MM1 Massive Protostar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06178v1.summary: Atacama Large (sub)Millimeter Array 0.98 mm observations of continuum emission and several molecular lines toward the high-massprotostellar system GGD27-MM1. We analyze the physical properties of the system, producing temperature and column density maps, and radial profiles for the disk and the envelope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06161v1.title: Towards an automatic approach to modelling the circumgalactic medium: new tools for mock making and fitting of metal profiles in large surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06161v1.summary: We present two new tools for studying and modelling metal absorption lines in the circumgalactic medium. The first tool uses a non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) method and provides a robust means to generate large libraries of realistic metal absorptionprofiles. The second tool is a Monte Carlo code based on nested sampling that decomposes metal lines into individual Voigt components.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06087v1.title: Star formation efficiency and AGN feedback in narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxies with fast X-ray nuclear winds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06087v1.summary: We present the first systematic study of the molecular gas and star formation efficiency in a sample of ten galaxies. Most of the galaxies in our sample lie above the main sequence (MS) and the moleculardepletion time is one to two orders of magnitude shorter than the one typically measured in local star-forming galaxies. We conclude that quenching by the AGN activity is minor and that star formation will likely stop in a short time due to gas exhaustion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06063v1.title: Bending instabilities of m=1 mode in disc galaxies: interplay between dark matter halo and vertical pressure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06063v1.summary: A self-gravitating, differentially rotating galactic disc is supported by the vertical pressure gradient force against the gravitational collapse. Such discs are known to support variousbending modes e.g., warps, corrugation, or scalloping (typically, higher orderbending modes) of which m=1 bending modes (warps) are the most prevalent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06062v1.title: Predicting the turbulent transport of cosmic rays via neural networks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06062v1.summary: A fast artificial neural network is developed for the prediction of cosmic ray transport in turbulent astrophysical magnetic fields. The neural network uses, as input, particle andfield properties and estimates transport coefficients 10^7 faster than standardnumerical simulations with an overall error of ~5% .

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06059v1.title: Discovery of spectacular quasar-driven superbubbles in red quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06059v1.summary: Quasar-driven outflows on galactic scales are a routinely invoked ingredient for galaxy formation models. We report the discovery of ionized gas nebulae as traced by [O III] emission surrounding three luminous redquasars at $z \sim 0.4$ The line-of-sight velocity difference between the red- and blue-shifted bubbles reaches up to $1200 km.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09924v2.title: Cosmic ray processes in galactic ecosystems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09924v2.summary: Galaxy evolution is an important topic, and our physical understanding must be complete to establish a correct picture. The effects of CRs are yet to be fully comprehended, and their complex multi-channel feedback mechanisms pose a significant technical challenge. We presentrecent advancements in our understanding of CR processes and interpretation of their signatures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05931v1.title: Infrared Spectroscopy of Nearby Radio Active Early-Type Galaxies -- II: Spectral Atlas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05931v1.summary: We present a near infrared spectroscopic atlas of nearby, bright early-typegalaxies with radio emission, containing 163 galaxies. We measure the emission line fluxes for H, He, [FeII] and H$_2$ and determined the nuclear excitation mechanisms. Stacking produces an "average"spectrum of absorption features and spectral indices from the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05852v1.title: JWST Confirms the Nature of CID-42
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05852v1.summary: The galaxy CID-42 (CXOC J100043.1+020637.2) at z=0.359 has been proposed to contain a promising candidate for a gravitational wave. Existing HST, Chandra and ground-based imaging and spectroscopy are unable to confirm either scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02024v2.title: Ageing and Quenching through the ageing diagram II: physical characterization of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02024v2.summary: The connection between quenching mechanisms, which rapidly turn star-forming systems into quiescent, and the properties of the galaxy population remains difficult to discern. In this work we investigate the physical properties of MaNGA and SAMI galaxies at different stages of their star formation history. We find that the Ageing population comprises aheterogeneous mixture of galaxies, preferentially late-type systems. Retired galaxies, formerly Ageing or Quenched, are dominated by early-type high-mass galaxies found at low and high densities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05808v1.title: Sampling Faraday rotation sky of IllustrisTNG50: I. Imprint of the magnetised circumgalactic medium around Milky Way-like galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05808v1.summary: Faraday rotation measure (RM) is arguably the most practical observationaltracer of magnetic fields in the diffuse circumgalactic medium (CGM) We sample synthetic Faraday rotation skies of Milky Way-like galaxies in IllustrisTNG50. We test whether the RMvariation produced by the CGM is correlated with global galaxy properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05806v1.title: Enabling Stellar Flare Science in the Roman Galactic Bulge Survey: Cadence, Filters, and the Read-Out Strategy Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05806v1.summary: Large stellar flare surveys have never been performed before in the Roman spectral range. Roman may reveal new information about flare mechanisms and how flare rates change with stellar age and metallicity. The information yield will likely depend on sky location, cadence, read-out strategy, and filter choices.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06400v2.title: Revisiting the Properties of X-ray AGN in the SSA22 Protocluster: Normal SMBH and Host-Galaxy Growth for AGN in a $z=3.09$ Overdensity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06400v2.summary: We analyze the physical properties of 8 X-ray selected active galactic nuclei (AGN) and one candidate protoquasar system (ADF22A1) in the $z = 3.09$ SSA22protocluster. We recover star formation histories for 7 of these systems which are well-fit by composite stellar population plus AGN models. We find indications that 4/9 of the SSA 22 AGN systems we study have host galaxies below the main sequence, with $\rm SFR/SFR_{MS} \leq -0.4$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05706v1.title: Data-driven Discovery of Diffuse Interstellar Bands with APOGEE Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05706v1.summary: Data-driven models of stellar spectra are useful tools to study non-stellar information. Diffuse Interstellar Bands (DIBs) are caused by intervening gas and dust. We identify 84 absorption features that have less than a 50% (5%) probability of being explained by chance alone.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05691v1.title: KPM: A Flexible and Data-Driven K-Process Model for Nucleosynthesis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05691v1.summary: The element abundance pattern found by APOGEE and GALAH in Milky Way disk is close to two-dimensional, dominated by production from one prompt process and one delayed process. We find that KPM with $K=2$ is able to explain the observed abundance bimodality. The results of KPM have implications for theformation of the Galaxy disk, the relationship between abundances and ages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05690v1.title: Ages, metallicities and structure of stellar clusters in the Magellanic Bridge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05690v1.summary: The formation of the Magellanic Bridge would be imprinted in the chemical evolvements and kinematics of its stellar population. Since it contains hundreds of stellar clusters and associations, we combined deep photometry from VISCACHA and SMASH surveys to explore this topic. We identified a group of 13 clusters probably stripped from the Small Mageller Cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05684v1.title: The Signature of the Northern Galactic Center Region in Low-Velocity UV Absorption
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05684v1.summary: The Galactic Center (GC) is surrounded by plasma lobes that extend up to 14kpc above and below the plane. Until now, UV absorption studies of these lobes have only focused on high-velocity components (|v_LSR| > 100 km/s) We compare the LIV absorption between different structures within the GC region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05682v1.title: Galaxy Quenching with Mass Growth History of Galaxy Groups and Clusters: The Importance of Post-Processing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05682v1.summary: Most satellites arequenched after they fall into their final hosts. Post-processing is a more dominant mechanism of galaxy quenching than pre-processing. The fraction of quenched satellites at $z=0$ increases with host mass. More massive hosts have higher quenming efficiency because they have more massive groups.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05672v1.title: Scientific Objectives of the Hot Universe Baryon Surveyor (HUBS) Mission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05672v1.summary: The Hot Universe Baryon Surveyor (HUBS) is a proposed space-based X-raytelescope. HUBS will be uniquely qualified to measure the physical and chemical properties of the hot gas in the universe. The mission will unravel the AGN and stellar feedbackphysics that governs the formation and evolution of galaxies, and to probe the budget and multi-phase states from galactic to cosmological scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05669v1.title: The Dependence of Iron-rich Metal-poor Star Occurrence on Galactic Environment Supports an Origin in Thermonuclear Supernova Nucleosynthesis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05669v1.summary: Iron-rich metal-poor (IRMP) stars formed from molecular cores dominated by thermonuclear supernova nucleosynthesis. If this interpretation is accurate, IRMP stars should be more common in environments where supernovae are important contributors to chemical evolution. We use data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05670v1.title: Mid-Infrared Outbursts in Nearby Galaxies: Nuclear Obscuration and Connections to Hidden Tidal Disruption Events and Changing-Look Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05670v1.summary: We study the properties of galaxies hosting mid-infrared outbursts in the Sloan DigitalSky Survey. We find that nuclear obscuration, as inferred by the surrounding surroundingdust mass, does not correlate with host galaxy type, stellar properties or extinction of the host galaxy. We identify a region in the galaxy catalog parameter space that contains all unobscured tidal disruption events but only harbors 9% of the mid- Infrared outburst hosts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05666v1.title: JASMINE: Near-Infrared Astrometry and Time Series Photometry Science
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05666v1.summary: JASMINE will be the first dedicated NIR astrometry space mission. It will provide precise astrometric information of the stars in the Galactic center, taking advantage of the significantly lower extinction in the Near-Infrared band. The data will be valuable for studies of exoplanet transits, asteroseismology, variable stars and microlensing studies, including discovery of black holes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05478v1.title: Chemistry of multiple stellar populations in the mono-metallic, in situ, bulge globular cluster NGC 6388
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05478v1.summary: We present the homogeneous abundance analysis for a combined sample of 185                giants in the bulge globular cluster (GC) NGC 6388. Proton-capture elements indicate that a single class of                first-generation polluters is sufficient to reproduce both the extreme and intermediate parts of the anti-correlations among light elements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05475v1.title: Primordial magnetic fields and the Hubble tension
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05475v1.summary: Magnetic fields appear to be present in essentially all astrophysicalenvironments, including galaxies, clusters of galaxies and voids. There are observational and theoretical motives for considering the possibility of their origin tracing back to the events in the very early universe. Such a primordial magnetic field would remain embedded in the plasma and evolve to persist through the tumultuousradiation and matter eras, and to the present day.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05452v1.title: A reproduction of the Milky Way's Faraday rotation measure map in galaxy simulations from global to local scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05452v1.summary: Magnetic fields are of critical importance for our understanding of the origin and long-term evolution of the Milky Way. Faraday rotation measures (RM) along many different sightlines across the Galaxy are a primary means to infer the magnetic field topology and strength from observations. The results reproduce the observations of the Galaxy not only on global scales, but also on local scales of individual star-forming clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05421v1.title: Clumping and X-Rays in cooler B supergiant stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05421v1.summary: B supergiants (BSGs) are evolved stars with effective temperatures between 10 and 30 kK. Study of their atmospheres is helpful to understand phenomena such as the bi-stability jump. Key UV features have so far not been reproduced by models for types later than B1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05291v1.title: An update of the catalog of radial velocity standard stars from the APOGEE DR17
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05291v1.summary: We present an updated catalog of 46,753 radial velocity (RV) standard stars from the APOGEE DR17. These stars cover the Northern and Southern Hemispheres almost evenly, with 62% being red giants and 38% beingmain-sequence stars. These RV standard stars are stable on a baseline longer than 200 days.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05278v1.title: A helium nova in the Large Magellanic Cloud -- the faint supersoft X-ray source [HP99]159
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05278v1.summary: We propose a helium nova model for the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) supersoftX-ray source (SSS) [HP99]159. This object has long been detected as a faint and persistent SSS for about 30 years, and recently been interpreted to be a source of steady helium-shell burning. We find that the object can also be interpreted as in a decaying phase of a heliumnova.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05274v1.title: Variability, flaring and coherence -- the complementarity of the maser and superradiance regimes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05274v1.summary: Superradiance readily accounts for the different time-scales observed in the multi-wavelength monitoring of the periodic flaring in G9.62+0.20E. We will consider examples of observational diagnostics that can help discriminate between the two, and identify superradiance as the source of the latter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05240v1.title: The filament determination depends on the tracer: comparing filaments based on dark matter particles and galaxies in the GAEA semi-analytic model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05240v1.summary: Filaments are elongated structures that connect groups and clusters of galaxies. They are visually the striking feature in cosmological maps. Typically filaments are defined only using galaxies, assuming that these are good tracers of the dark matter distribution. Here we apply the topological filamentExtractor DisPerSE to the predictions of the semi-analytic code GAEA.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05202v1.title: Accelerated structural evolution of galaxies in a starbursting cluster at z=2.51
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05202v1.summary: Structural properties of cluster galaxies during their peak formation epoch provide key information on whether and how environment affects galaxy formation and evolution. Based on deep HST/WFC3 imaging towards the 2.51 cluster, J1001, we explore environmental effects on the structure, coloripientgradients, and stellar populations of a statistical sample of cluster SFGs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12886v2.title: X-ray Emission from the Interstellar and Circumgalactic Medium of Elliptical Galaxies based on MACER simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12886v2.summary: X-ray emission of the ISM and CGM of elliptical galaxies simulated using MACERcode. X-ray spectra from these simulations are fitted with standard fitting procedures. Future high-resolution observations can reliably reveal the properties of the gas in the galaxies, the authors say.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00226v2.title: Cluster aggregates surrounding Pismis 5 in the Vela Molecular Ridge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00226v2.summary: We identify eight open clusters surrounding Pismis 5 in the Vela Molecular Ridge. The open cluster QZ 1 is newly discovered. Binary and triple open cluster candidates have been identified as potential primordial aggregates. According to kinematic speculations, the two aggregate candidates will gradually separate, and their interiors will slowly disintegrate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05130v1.title: EDGE: The direct link between mass growth history and the extended stellar haloes of the faintest dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05130v1.summary: Ultra-faint dwarf galaxies (UFDs) are commonly found in close proximity to the Milky Way and other massive spiral galaxies. As such, their projectedstellar ellipticity and extended light distributions are often thought to owe to tidal forces. In this paper, we study the projected stellar ellipticities and faint stellar outskirts of tidally isolated ultra-faints drawn from a cosmological simulation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08150v2.title: SPYGLASS. IV. New Stellar Survey of Recent Star Formation within 1 kpc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08150v2.summary: Young stellar populations provide a powerful record that traces millions of years of star formation history in the solar neighborhood. Using a revised form of the SPYGLASS young star identification methodology, we produce an expanded census of nearby young stars (Age $<50$ Myr) We then use the HDBSCAN clustering algorithm to produce a new SPyGLASS Catalog of Young Associations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06855v3.title: White Dwarfs Revealed in Gaia's Candidate Compact Object Binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06855v3.summary: Discovery and characterisation of black holes (BHs), neutron stars (NSs), and white dwarfs (WDs) with detached luminous companions (LCs) in wide orbits is exciting. 187 candidates have been identified from Gaia's non-single star catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.12177v4.title: Automated Detection of Double Nuclei Galaxies using GOTHIC and the Discovery of a Large Sample of Dual AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.12177v4.summary: Algorithm to detect double nuclei galaxies (DNG) called Graph BOosted iterated HIll Climbing. It detects whether a given image of a galaxy has two or more closely separated nuclei. Results show that dual AGN are not common, and triple AGN even rarer.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04993v1.title: Uncertainty Quantification of the Virial Black Hole Mass with Conformal Prediction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04993v1.summary: Precise measurements of the black hole mass are essential to gain insight on co-evolution. A direct measure of black holemass is often restricted to nearest galaxies. We propose the application of conformalised                quantile regression (CQR) to quantify the uncertainties of theblack hole mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04967v1.title: Detecting Tidal Features using Self-Supervised Representation Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04967v1.summary: Tidal features are a valuable tool in the detection of past or ongoing galaxy mergers. Their properties can answer questions about the progenitor galaxies involved in the interactions. This paper presents promising results from a self-supervised machine learning model trained on data from the Ultradeeplayer.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04911v1.title: CLASSY VII Lyα Profiles: The Structure and Kinematics of Neutral Gas and Implications for LyC Escape in Reionization-Era Analogs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04911v1.summary: Lyman-alpha line profiles are a powerful probe of ISM structure, outflowspeed, and Lyman continuum escape fraction. Such profiles reveal an inhomogeneous interstellar medium (ISM) We find an inverse relation betweenLy$\alpha$ peak separation and the [O III]/[O II] flux ratio.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04888v1.title: Siena Galaxy Atlas 2020
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04888v1.summary: The 2020 version of the Siena Galaxy Atlas (SGA-2020) is amulti-wavelength optical and infrared imaging atlas of 383,620 nearby galaxies. It is more than 95%complete for galaxies larger than $R(26)\approx25$ arcsec and $r<18$ measured in the $r$-band. Coupled with existing and forthcomingoptical spectroscopy from the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI), the atlas will facilitate new detailed studies of the star formation and mass assembly histories.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04230v2.title: Mass Dependence of Galaxy-Halo Alignment in LOWZ and CMASS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04230v2.summary: We measure the galaxy-ellipticity (GI) correlations for the Slogan DigitalSky Survey DR12 LOWZ and CMASS samples. We find that the alignment of central galaxies with their host halos increases monotonically with galaxy stellar mass or host halo mass. These results have important implications for intrinsic alignment (IA) correction in weak lensing studies and theory of massive galaxy formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04878v1.title: The Impact of Black Hole Scaling Relation Assumptions on the Mass Density of Black Holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04878v1.summary: We examine the effect of supermassive black hole (SMBH) mass scaling relation on the inferred SMBH mass population since redshift $z \sim 3$ We find that there is a substantial difference in predictions especially for $z > 1$ The GWB that pulsar timing arrays find evidence for is higher in amplitude than expected from GWB predictions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04876v1.title: Density and Velocity Correlations in Isothermal Supersonic Turbulence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04876v1.summary: In star-forming clouds, high velocity flow gives rise to large fluctuations of density. In this work we explore the correlation between velocity magnitude(speed) and density. We develop an analytic formula for the joint probability distribution (PDF) of density and speed. We confront our results with a suite of 12 supersonic isothermal simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01792v4.title: Close encounters of black hole - star binaries with stellar-mass black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01792v4.summary: Dynamical interactions involving binaries play a crucial role in the evolution of star clusters and galaxies. We focus on binary black hole (BBH)formation, stellar disruption, and electromagnetic (EM) emission in dynamical interactions between a BH-star binary and a stellar-mass BH. BBHs are more likely to form when the star and the incoming BH encounter first.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04853v1.title: Spatially-Resolved Recent Star Formation History in NGC 6946
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04853v1.summary: The nearby face-on star forming spiral galaxy NGC 6946 is known as the                Fireworks Galaxy due to its hosting an unusually large number of supernova. We analyze its resolved near-ultraviolet (NUV) stellar photometry measured from images taken with the Hubble Space Telescope's Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04807v1.title: The Dragon-II simulations -- III. Compact binary mergers in clusters with up to 1 million stars: mass, spin, eccentricity, merger rate and pair instability supernovae rate
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04807v1.summary: Compact binary mergers forming in star clusters may exhibit distinctive features that can be used to identify them among observed gravitational-wave sources. Such features likely depend on the host cluster structure and the physics of massive star evolution. We find a substantial population of black hole binary (BBH) mergers, some of them involving an intermediate-mass-BH.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04806v1.title: The Dragon-II simulations -- II. Formation mechanisms, mass, and spin of intermediate-mass black holes in star clusters with up to 1 million stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04806v1.summary: The processes that govern the formation of intermediate-mass black holes(IMBHs) in dense stellar clusters are still unclear. Here, we discuss the role of stellar mergers, star-BH interactions and accretion, as well as BH binary(BBH) mergers in seeding and growing IMHs. We find a link between the IMBH formation mechanism and the cluster structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04805v1.title: The Dragon-II simulations -- I. Evolution of single and binary compact objects in star clusters with up to 1 million stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04805v1.summary: We present the first results of the \textsc{Dragon-II} simulations of star clusters with up to $10^6$ stars. All clusters form in their centre a black hole (BH) subsystem with a density $10-100$ times larger than the stellar density. We find that BH-main sequence star binaries have properties similar to recently observed systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04797v1.title: The Characteristic Shape of Damping Wings During Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04797v1.summary: Spectroscopic analysis of Ly$\alpha$ damping wings of bright sources at $z>6$ is a promising way to measure the reionization history of the universe. We find that the damping wingprofile remains a tight function of volume-weighted neutral fraction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04790v1.title: The hunt for formamide in interstellar ices: A toolkit of laboratory infrared spectra in astronomically relevant ice mixtures and comparisons to ISO, Spitzer, and JWST observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04790v1.summary: This work aims at characterizing the mid-IR spectra of formamide in its pure form as well as in mixtures of the most abundant interstellar ices. It also demonstrates how theselaboratory spectra can be used to search for formamide. Three bands are identified as potential.formamide tracers in observational ice spectra: the overlapping C=O stretch and the overlapping NH$_2 stretch.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04782v1.title: Deeper than DEEP: A Spectroscopic Survey of $z>3$ Lyman-$α$ Emitters in the Extended Groth Strip
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04782v1.summary: Using Keck/DEIMOS, we observed 947 high-$z$ candidates with photometric redshifts from 3 $< z_\text{phot} <$ 7 and down to an $H$-band (HST/WFC3 F160W) limit of < 27.5. Our survey secured 137 unique redshifting, 126 of which are Ly$\alpha$ emitters at 2.8 $ < z <$ 6.5 with a mean redshift of 4.3%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04753v1.title: Redshifting galaxies from DESI to JWST CEERS: Correction of biases and uncertainties in quantifying morphology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04753v1.summary: We used a sample of 1816 nearby DESI galaxies, with a mass range of $10.75-11.25. We found that $R_p$ and $R_{50}$, calculated using non-parametric methods, are slightly overestimated due to PSF smoothing. We improve the computation of $A$ by incorporating a more worrisomeaccurate noise effect removal procedure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04724v1.title: The individual abundance distributions of disc stars across birth radii in GALAH
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04724v1.summary: Individual abundances in the Milky Way disc record stellar birth properties such as age, birth radius, and capture the diversity of the star-forming environments over time. We examine the distributions of individual abundances [X/Fe] of elements C, O, Mg, Si, Ca, Al (odd-z), Mn (iron-peak), Y, and Ba (neutron-capture) for stars. Older stars have a $R_{\rm birth}$ distribution with smaller mean values than younger stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11106v2.title: The effect of tidal forces on the Jeans instability criterion in star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11106v2.summary: Tidal forces determine the mass that a protostar can accrete to explain theIMF. In this scenario, gravitationally unstable fragments will compete for the gas reservoir in a star-forming clump. We found that an external gravitational potential can reduce the critical mass required for a perturbation to collapse if the tidal force produced is compressive.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.05096v2.title: Cross Correlation of Pencil-Beam Galaxy Surveys and Line-Intensity Maps: An Application of the James Webb Space Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.05096v2.summary: Line-intensity mapping (IM) experiments seek to perform statisticalmeasurements of large-scale structure with spectral lines. A challenge in these observations is to ensure astrophysical foregrounds, such as galactic synchrotron emission in 21cm measurements, are properly removed. One method that has the potential to reduce this contamination is to cross correlate with a galaxy survey that overlapping with the IM volume.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04635v1.title: Self-consistent Combined HST, K-band, and Spitzer Photometric Catalogs of the BUFFALO Survey Fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04635v1.summary: This manuscript presents new astronomical source catalogs using data from the BUFFALO Survey. These catalogs contain detailed information for over 100,000astronomical sources in the 6 BUFFalO clusters. The catalogs are publicly available for use by the community.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05281v2.title: SBI++: Flexible, Ultra-fast Likelihood-free Inference Customized for Astronomical Applications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05281v2.summary: Simulation-based inference (SBI) can attain complex posterior distributions with the accuracy of traditional methods but with a $>10^4$ increase in speed. Standard SBI requires the simulated data to have identical characteristics to the observed data. We show that out-of-distribution errors can be approximated by using standard SBI evaluations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04621v1.title: Recipes for Jet Feedback and Spin Evolution of Black Holes with Strongly-Magnetized Super-Eddington Accretion Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04621v1.summary: A black hole with near-Eddington accretion experiences a mild degree of spin-down because of angular momentum loss through the jet. As the accretion rate increases above Eddington, thespin-down effect becomes progressively stronger. The formulae developed in this letter may be applied to galaxy and cosmological scale simulations that include black holes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04590v1.title: Physical properties of circumnuclear ionising clusters. I. NGC 7742
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04590v1.summary: This work aims to derive the physical properties of the CNSFRs in the ring of the face-on spiral NGC 7742 using IFS observations. We have selected 88individual ionising clusters that power HII regions that may have originated in a minor merger event. Their metal abundances as traced by sulphur have been found to be between 0.25%-2.4 times solar, with most regions showing values slightly below solar.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04523v1.title: 1D non-LTE corrections for chemical abundance analyses of very metal-poor stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04523v1.summary: The galactic archaeology research requires homogeneous determinations of chemical abundance. For VMP stars, their elemental abundances should be derived based on non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (non-LTE = NLTE) line formation. The data is publicly available, and we provide the tools for interpolating in the grids online.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02494v2.title: The bright end of the galaxy luminosity function at $z \simeq 7$ from the VISTA VIDEO survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02494v2.summary: We have conducted a search for Lyman break galaxies over 8.2 square degrees of near-infrared imaging from the VISTA Deep ExtragalacticObservations survey. Candidate galaxies were selected from a full photometric redshift analysis down to a $Y+J$ depth of 25.3. We find that the inclusion of $YJHK_{s}$ photometry is vital for removing brown-dwarfcontaminants.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04487v1.title: The abundance and excitation of molecular anions in interstellar clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04487v1.summary: We report new observations of molecular anions with the Yebes 40m and IRAM 30m telescopes toward the cold dense clouds TMC-1 CP, Lupus-1A, L1527, L483, L1495B, and L1544. Excitation calculations indicate that the lines of anionsaccessible to radiotelescopes run from subthermally excited to thermalized as the size of anion increases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04469v1.title: Beyond spectroscopy. II. Stellar parameters for over twenty million stars in the northern sky from SAGES DR1 and Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04469v1.summary: We present precise photometric estimates of stellar parameters, including effective temperature, metallicity, luminosity classification, distance, andstellar age, for nearly 26 million stars. This huge data set in the Northern sky from SAGES, together with similar data in the Southern sky from SkyMapper Southern Survey (SMSS), will greatly advance our understanding of the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05247v2.title: Co-evolution of Dust and Chemistry in Galaxy Simulations with a Resolved Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05247v2.summary: Nearby dwarf irregular galaxies are ideal laboratories for studying the intergalactic medium (ISM) at low metallicity. We find that dust growth in dense gas is required to produce CO as otherwise CO would be completely destroyed by sputtering. The newly-produced dust mixes with the ISM through supernova feedback without being completely destroyed. This leads to galactic outflows 20% - 50%dustier than the IsM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04427v1.title: Observation of high-energy neutrinos from the Galactic plane
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04427v1.summary: origin of high-energy cosmic rays has been a mystery for over a century. Due to deflection instellar magnetic fields, cosmic rays from the Milky Way arrive at Earthfrom random directions. Near their sources and during propagation,cosmic rays interact with matter and produce high- energy neutrinos. The signal is consistent with modeled diffuse emission from the Galactic plane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04357v1.title: Survey-scale discovery-based research processes: Evaluating a bespoke visualisation environment for astronomical survey data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04357v1.summary: Next generation astronomical surveys pose challenges for human-centred visualisation and analysis workflows. As the number of sources in a survey grows, there is need to both modify and simplify repetitive visualisation processes. As tasks such as per-source quality control, candidate rejection, and morphological classification all share a single instruction, multiple data work pattern, they are amenable to a parallel solution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04294v1.title: Accretion rates and radiative efficiencies of Sagittarius A* and nearby supermassive black holes estimated using empirical relations: Implications for accretion models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04294v1.summary: The Bondi accretion rate of black holes in our and nearby galaxies Messier87, NGC 3115, and NGC 1600, and Cygnus A have been determined or constrained using observations. It remains unknown how much mass from                the Bondi radius reaches each black hole and how much is accreted.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04234v1.title: Extreme N-emitters at high-redshift: signatures of supermassive stars and globular cluster or black hole formation in action?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04234v1.summary: Using the JWST/NIRSpec observations from CEERS we found an extreme N-emitter, CEERS-1019 at z=8.6782 showing intense NIV and NIII emission. Fromthe observed rest-UV and optical lines we conclude that it is compatible with photoionization from stars. The observations provide possible evidence for the presence of superhuman stars in the early Universe (z>8)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04178v1.title: Shock excitation of H$_2$ in the James Webb Space Telescope era
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04178v1.summary: H2 is the most abundant molecule in the Universe. It predominantly lights up in warm gas, T > 100 K, and it is one of the key targets of JWST observations. These include shocks from protostellar outflows, all the way up to starburst galaxies. Shock models are able to simulate H2 emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04152v1.title: Star formation history of $\rm{0.1\leq\,\textit{z}\,\leq\,1.5}$ mass-selected galaxies in the ELAIS-N1 Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04152v1.summary: We measure the specific star formation rates of selected galaxies from the ELAIS-N1 by stacking GMRT data at 610 MHz. Most massive galaxies form their stars earlier and more rapidly than low mass galaxies. The massive galaxies in our sample have the lowest sSFRs which is in agreement with previous studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04120v1.title: Toward a stellar population catalog in the Kilo Degree Survey: the impact of stellar recipes on stellar masses and star formation rates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04120v1.summary: The Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS) is currently the only sky survey providingoptical ($ugri$) plus near-infrared (NIR, $ZYHJK_S$) seeing matched photometry. We use a spectroscopic sample of galaxies for which we possess ``gaussianized'' magnitudes from KiDS data release 4. As a science validation test, we derive the mass function, the star formation rate function, and the SFR-$M_*$ relation for a low-redshift sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04117v1.title: SPar: estimating stellar parameters from multi-band photometries with empirical stellar libraries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04117v1.summary: The stellar parameters derived from multi-band photometries are in good agreement with those from the spectroscopic surveys. The algorithm proved to be robust and effective and will be applied to the data offuture large-scale photometric surveys such as the Mephisto and CSST surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04088v1.title: Cracking the Puzzle of CO2 Formation on Interstellar Ices. Quantum Chemical and Kinetic Study of the CO + OH -> CO2 + H Reaction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04088v1.summary: CO2 is one of the dominant components of the interstellar ice. Recent observations show CO2 exists more abundantly in polar (H2O-dominated) ice. CO2 ice formation is primarily attributed to the reaction between CO and OH, which has a barrier. The CO + OH reaction proceeds through the remarkably stable intermediate HOCO radical.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04086v1.title: Age of FGK Dwarfs Observed with LAMOST and GALAH: Considering the Oxygen Enhancement
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04086v1.summary: Varying oxygen abundance could impact the modeling-inferred ages. The age differences between the two types of models are correlated to [Fe/H] and [O/$\alpha$ The [O/Fe] of these stars increases with age from 7.5-9 Gyr to 3-4 Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04072v1.title: The LSST AGN Data Challenge: Selection methods
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04072v1.summary: The AGN Science Collaboration Data Challenge (AGNSCDC) is aimed at validating machine learning approaches for AGN selection and characterization in large surveys like LSST. The training and the blinded datasets were constructed to mimic the future LSST release catalogs using the data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04788v3.title: MUSEQuBES: The relation between Ly$α$ emitters and C IV absorbers at $z \approx 3.3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.04788v3.summary: We present a detailed study of the column density and covering fraction of C IV absorption around 86 redshift $z \approx 3.3$ Ly$\alpha$ Emitters (LAEs) detected in 8 Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) fields centered on 8 bright background quasars. Using Voigt profile fitting of all the C IV absorbers detected along these 8 sightlines, we generated a ``blind'' absorbers' catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.03742v4.title: Galaxy formation catalyzed by gravastars and the JWST, revisited
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.03742v4.summary: In this note we review problems with our original formula for the disk galaxy scale length. We modify the model by including a probability $P$ for a collision to lead to nucleation of starformation. The revised formula is in reasonable accord with both late time data and early universe data from the JWST.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08390v3.title: A cosmological distance measure using radio-loud quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08390v3.summary: We use the X-ray luminosity relation of radio-loud quasars (RLQs) to measure these luminosity distances as well as estimate cosmological parameters. By Bayesian information criterion (BIC), the data suggest that the relation for RLQs has better goodness of fit than other models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09456v5.title: A measure of cosmological distance using the \civ\ Baldwin effect in quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09456v5.summary: We obtain a sample of 471 Type Iquasars with the UV/optical spectra and EW (C\,\textsc{iv) measurements in the                redshift range of $2.3< z< 7.1$ including 25 objects at $5 < z < 7. 1$ We use the anticorrelation between the equivalent width (EW) of the. 1549 {\AA} emission line and the continuum luminosity in the. quasars rest frame (Baldwin effect) to measure their luminosity distance. We apply a combination of Type I quas

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08280v2.title: Free-Floating planet Mass Function from MOA-II 9-year survey towards the Galactic Bulge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08280v2.summary: We present the first measurement of the mass function of free-floating                planets (FFP) or very wide orbit planets down to an Earth mass. Six events are likely to be due to planets with Einstein radius crossing times. The number of FFPs is $19_{-13}^{+23}$times the number of planets in wide orbits (beyond the snow line)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03975v1.title: Reframing the Galaxy and Cluster Mass Discrepancy Problem: A Consequence of Virial Equilibrium and Other Energy Considerations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03975v1.summary: Galaxy and galaxy clusters exhibit tight robust physical scaling relationsbetween baryons and system dynamics. One such phenomenon is mass discrepancy between LCDM and MOND. We propose theubiquitous Baryonic Tully-Fisher Relation as the preferred dynamic configuration for these thermodynamic systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03915v1.title: Galaxy-dark matter connection of photometric galaxies from the HSC-SSP Survey: Galaxy-galaxy lensing and the halo model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03915v1.summary: We infer the connection between the stellar mass of galaxies and their dark matter halo masses and its evolution in two bins of redshifts between $[0.3, 0.8]$. We use the measurements of the weak lensing signal of galaxies using background sources from the Year 1 shape catalog from the HSC survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07860v2.title: ODIN: Where Do Lyman-alpha Blobs Live? Contextualizing Blob Environments within the Large-Scale Structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07860v2.summary: Many Lyman-alpha Blobs are found in and around several well-known protoclusters at high redshift. How they trace the underlying large-scale structure is still poorly understood. LABs preferentially reside in regions of higher-than-average density and are located in closer proximity to overdense structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03780v1.title: The Radial Distribution and Excitation of H2 around Young Stars in the HST-ULLYSES Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03780v1.summary: The spatial distribution and evolution of gas in the inner 10 au ofprotoplanetary disks form the basis for estimating the initial conditions of planet formation. We analyze far-ultraviolet spectroscopy of 71 (63 accreting) pre-mainsequence systems in the ULLYSES DR5 release. We find a strong correlation between accretion-dominated Ly$\alpha$ emission and the inner disk dust clearing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05752v1.title: A compilation of optical polarization catalogs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05752v1.summary: Polarimetry of stars at optical and near-infrared wavelengths is an                invaluable tool for tracing interstellar dust and magnetic fields. Data are gathered from 81 separate publications spanning two decades. The compilation contains a total of 55,742 measurements of stellar polarization. We combine this database with stellar distances based on the Gaia early data release 3.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03775v1.title: Eccentric Binaries in Retrograde Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03775v1.summary: We present the first full-domain grid-based hydrodynamics simulations of equal-mass, eccentric binaries accreting from retrogradecircumbinary disks. We find that, at all eccentricities, retrograde accretion shrinks the binary semi-major axis and pumps its eccentricity leading to the previously identified possibility of highly eccentric mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.10092v2.title: Discovery of inverse-Compton X-ray emission and estimate of the volume-averaged magnetic field in a galaxy group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.10092v2.summary: Inverse-Compton (IC) X-ray emission has so far not been unambiguously detected on cluster/group scales. The detection provides an estimate for the volume-averaged magneticfield of the central part of the group. This value can serve as an anchor for studies of magnetic fields in the largest                gravitationally bound systems in the Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03771v1.title: Towards ultra metal-poor DLAs: linking the chemistry of the most metal-poor DLA to the first stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03771v1.summary: We present new Keck/HIRES data of the most metal-poor damped Lyman-alpha(DLA) system currently known. By targeting the strongest accessible Fe IIfeatures, we have improved the upper limit of the [Fe/H] abundance by ~1 dex. We also provide the first upper limit on the relative abundance of an odd-atomic number element for this system.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03770v1.title: Establishing the impact of luminous AGN with multi-wavelength observations and simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03770v1.summary: Cosmological simulations fail to reproduce realistic galaxy populations without energy injection from active galactic nuclei. Multi-phase AGN outflows are common, some with potential for significant impact. Radio jets from `radio quiet' quasars can inject turbulence on ISM scales, and displace CGM-scale molecular gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03743v1.title: Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbon Size Tracers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03743v1.summary: We examine the dependence of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) bandintensity ratios as a function of the average number of carbon atoms. We assess their effectiveness as tracers for PAH size, utilising the data, models, and tools provided by the NASA Ames PAH Infrared Spectroscopic Database.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03725v1.title: A census of star formation histories of massive galaxies at 0.6 < z < 1 from spectro-photometric modeling using Bagpipes and Prospector
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03725v1.summary: We present individual star-formation histories of massive galaxies from the Large Early Galaxy Astrophysics Census. We quantify the population trends leveraging 20hr-deep integratedspectra of these galaxies. Our results reveal trends in both stellar mass and stellar velocity as in the local universe. This census sets a benchmark forfuture deep spectro-photometric studies of the more distant universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.00910v3.title: On the statistical theory of self-gravitating collisionless dark matter flow
http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.00910v3.summary: The flow of dark matter might possess the widest presence in our universe. By contrast to hydrodynamics of normal fluids, dark matter flow is self-gravitating, long-range, and collisionless. The peculiar velocity field is of constant divergence nature on smallscale and irrotational on large scale.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03676v1.title: A Local Model for the Spherical Collapse/Expansion Problem
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03676v1.summary: Spherical flows are a classic problem in astrophysics which are typicallystudied from a global perspective. Much like with accretion discs, there are likely many instabilities and small scale phenomena which would beeasier to study from a local perspective. We develop a local model for a spherically contracting/expanding gas cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03663v1.title: Milliarcsecond structure and variability of methanol maser emission in three high-mass protostars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03663v1.summary: The variability study of 6.7\,GHz methanol masers has become a useful way to improve our understanding of the physical conditions in high-mass star-forming regions. All three targets show a few groups of masercloudlets of a typical size of 3.5\,mas. The majority of them show linear or grotesquearched structures with velocity gradients of order 0.22\kms/mas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.09068v2.title: Massive quiescent galaxies at $z\sim3$: a comparison of selection, stellar population and structural properties with simulation predictions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.09068v2.summary: We study stellar population and structural properties of massive, quiescent galaxies at $z\sim 2.7$ in the Magneticum and IllustrisTNG hydrodynamical simulations and GAEA semi-analytic model. We find evidence for significant contamination (up to 60 percent) by dusty star-forming galaxies in the UVJ region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03644v1.title: Looking for evidence of high-mass star formation at core scale in a massive molecular clump
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03644v1.summary: We present a comprehensive physical and chemical study of the fragmentationand star formation activity towards the massive clump AGAL G338. The main goal of this work is to find evidence of such high-mass star formation, but at core scale. We found that the discovered molecular outflow arising from core C1 should be the main responsible for the 4.5 $\mu$m extended emission. The region is chemically very rich with several complex molecular species.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01445v2.title: The long-term spectral changes of eta Carinae: are they caused by a dissipating occulter as indicated by CMFGEN models?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01445v2.summary: Eta Carinae exhibits a unique set of P Cygni profiles with both                broad and narrow components. Over many decades, the spectrum has changed -- there has been an increase in observed continuum fluxes and a decrease in FeIIand HI emission line equivalent widths. The spectrum is evolving towards that of a P CyGNi star such as P~Cygni itself and HDE~316285.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04298v2.title: JADES: Probing interstellar medium conditions at $z\sim5.5-9.5$ with ultra-deep JWST/NIRSpec spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04298v2.summary: We present emission line ratios from a sample of 26 Lyman break galaxies. We find that these $z\sim5.5-9.5$ galaxies occupy distinct regions of line-ratio space compared to typical z~0-3 galaxies. The results highlight the value of deep observations in constraining theproperties of individual galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03763v1.title: Accelerating global parameter estimation of gravitational waves from Galactic binaries using a genetic algorithm and GPUs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03763v1.summary: The Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) is a planned space-based gravitational wave telescope with the goal of measuring gravitational waves. The milli-Hertz frequency band is dominated by millions of Galacticbinaries. We use a new approach to accelerate the extraction of the best fitting solutions for Galactic binaries across the entire frequency band.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03588v1.title: Exploring the chemodynamics of metal-poor stellar populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03588v1.summary: Metal-poor stars are key for studying the formation and evolution of the Galaxy. Evidence of the early mergers that built up the Galaxy remains in the distributions of abundances, kinematics, and orbital parameters of its stars. Several substructures resulting from these mergers have been tentativelyidentified in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.05709v2.title: HST-Based Lens Model of SDSS J1226+2152, in Preparation for JWST-ERS TEMPLATES
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.05709v2.summary: Strongly lensed z=2.9233 Lyman break galaxy, SGAS J122651.3+215220, was first targeted by JWST as part of theJWST-ERS program. The lens model outputs are publicly available to the community through the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST) Portal.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.11550v3.title: Blowups and longtime developments with near-boundary mass accretions of irregularly-shaped Euler--Poisson dominated molecular clouds in astrophysics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.11550v3.summary: The main difficulty of the blowups of the irregular-shaped fluids with vacuum (molecular clouds) comes from the initial irregular configurations of its density. This inevitably causes far more complicated movements than the one with spherical symmetry. This paper partially answers Makino's conjecture [37] in 1992 on the finite time blowup of any tame solution without symmetries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03521v1.title: Formation Channels for Population III Stars at Cosmic Dawn
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03521v1.summary: In the absence of radiation, we find the minimum halo mass required to bring about collapse and star formation to be 10^5 Msun. We find an inverse relationship between the mass of a halo and the time required for it to recover its molecular gas after being disrupted by radiation from a nearby star.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03470v1.title: The chemical DNA of the Magellanic Clouds --II. High-resolution spectroscopy of the SMC globular clusters NGC 121, NGC 339 and NGC 419
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03470v1.summary: The Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) is the host of a rich system of globularcularclusters (GCs) that span a wide age range. The chemical fingerprints of these clusters closely resemble those of SMC field stars. This supports the SMC'sspecific history of chemical enrichment relative to the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03453v1.title: A model local interpretation routine for deep learning based radio galaxy classification
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03453v1.summary: Radio galaxy morphological classification is one of the critical steps whenproducing source catalogues for large-scale radio continuum surveys. While many studies attempted to classify source radio morphology from survey image data using deep learning algorithms, they focused on model robustness most time. In this work, we used local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanation (LIME) technique to explain model prediction behaviour.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08376v2.title: Strange Quasar Candidates with Abnormal Astrometric Characteristics from Gaia EDR3 and SDSS (SQUAB-II): Optical Identifications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08376v2.summary: There are some strange quasars with multiple Gaia detections or observed with abnormal astrometric characteristics. They could be potential candidates of quasar-star pairs, dual quasar (DQs), or lensed qu asars (LQs) We select 143 SDSS spectroscopically confirmedquasars that have multiple Gaia EDR3 detections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03369v1.title: Molecular environment of the thermal composite supernova remnant G352.7$-$0.1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03369v1.summary: SNR G352.7$-$0.1 is special for its thermal composite morphology and double-ring structure. We have performed spectroscopic mapping in $^{12}$CO and $€13$CO lines toward the remnant. We also find an expanding structure around the remnant, which is possibly related to the wind-blown bubble of the progenitor star. From the Fermi-LAT data in an energy range of 0.1-500 GeV, we find no gamma-raycounterparts of G 352.7#.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02811v2.title: Machine Learning Classification of Repeating FRBs from FRB121102
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02811v2.summary: Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs) are mysterious bursts in the millisecond timescale at radio wavelengths. Currently, there is little understanding about the classification of repeating FRBs, based on difference in physics. By fine-tuning the hyperparameters of the model, we found that there is an indication for four clusters from the bursts of FRB121102.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03344v1.title: Deep Synoptic Array Science: First FRB and Host Galaxy Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03344v1.summary: Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs) are luminous enough to be detected at cosmological distances. The 110-antenna Deep Synoptic Array (DSA-110) is a radio interferometer built to maximize the rate at which it can simultaneously detect and localize FRBs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03341v1.title: A model for molecular hydrogen-dependent star formation in simulations of galaxy evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03341v1.summary: Star formation, together with the associated chemical and energy feedback, is one of the most important processes in galaxy evolution. Simple models for star formation in cosmological hydrodynamical simulations have shown to be successful in reproducing the star formation rate (SFR) levels and shapes of different types of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03320v1.title: Discovering new B[e] supergiants and candidate Luminous Blue Variables in nearby galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03320v1.summary: Mass loss is one of the key parameters that determine stellar evolution. The ASSESS project aims to determine the role of episodic mass in the evolution of massive stars. We used spectroscopic, photometric, and light curve information to better constrain the nature of the reported objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07688v2.title: The Eighteenth Data Release of the Sloan Digital Sky Surveys: Targeting and First Spectra from SDSS-V
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07688v2.summary: The eighteenth data release of the Sloan Digital Sky Surveys (SDSS) is the first one for SDSS-V, the fifth generation of the survey. DR18 also includes ~25,000 new S DSS spectra and supplemental information for X-ray sources identified by eROSITA in its eFEDS field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03300v1.title: Hydrodynamical simulations of galaxy formation with non-Gaussian initial conditions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03300v1.summary: Collisionless simulations have shown that a non-Gaussian tail can significantly change the merging history of galaxy-sized dark matter halos. These hydrodynamical simulations on small scales will need to be complemented with larger box simulations to statistically confirm these trends and explore their observational consequences.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03295v1.title: Lensing in the Blue II: Estimating the Sensitivity of Stratospheric Balloons to Weak Gravitational Lensing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03295v1.summary: The Superpressure Balloon-borne Imaging Telescope (SuperBIT) is a wide-field, 0.5 m, near-infrared to near-ultravioletobservatory designed to exploit the stratosphere's space-like conditions. SuperBIT's 2023 science flight will deliver deep, blue imaging of galaxy clusters for gravitational lensing analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01384v2.title: Distinguishing Dark Matter Cusps from Cores using Globular Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01384v2.summary: Globular Clusters (GCs) provide valuable insight into the properties of their host galaxies' dark matter halos. Multiple mergers required to form the NSC only take place when the dark matter halo is cuspy. In a cored halo, stalling of the dynamical friction within the core of the halo stops the inspiral of the GCs, and so the GC merger rate falls significantly.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03264v1.title: Stellar Half-Mass Radii of $0.5<z<2.3$ Galaxies: Comparison with JWST/NIRCam Half-Light Radii
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03264v1.summary: We use CEERS JWST/NIRCam imaging to measure rest-frame near-IR light profiles of galaxies in the redshift range $0.5<z<2.3$. We compare the resulting 1.5-2$\mu$m half-light radii with stellar half-mass radii (\rmass) derived from CANDELS HST imaging. We also deproject the profiles to estimate \rmassd, the circumference of a sphere containing 50% of the stellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03259v1.title: On the Neutrino and Gamma-Ray Emission from NGC 1068
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03259v1.summary: IceCube has recently reported the detection of neutrinos from the nearby active galaxy, NGC 1068. The lack of TeV-scale emission from this source suggests that these neutrino are generated in the corona that surrounds the supermassive black hole. In this paper, we present a physical model for this source, including the processes of pair production, pion production, synchrotron, and inverse Compton scattering.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13739v2.title: Discovery of a Low-Redshift Hot Dust-Obscured Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13739v2.summary: We report the discovery of the hyperluminous, highly obscured AGN WISEJ190445.04+485308.9. W1904+4853 contains an actively accreting supermassive black hole hidden in its dusty cocoon. Its well-sampled spectral energy distribution (SED) isdominated by infrared dust emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09398v2.title: Formation of Galactic Disks I: Why did the Milky Way's Disk Form Unusually Early?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09398v2.summary: The stellar disk of our Milky Way was formed quite early, within the first few billion years of its evolution. Chemo-kinematic signatures of disk formation in cosmological zoom-in simulations appear to be in tension with these data. We investigate the formation of galactic disks using arepresentative sample of MW-like galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03237v1.title: Asteroseismology with the Roman Galactic Bulge Time-Domain Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03237v1.summary: Asteroseismology can be used to infer masses, ages and radii for large numbers of stars. The Roman galactic bulge is well-suited for asteroseismologists. A precision of 1 mmag per 15-min cadence or better will enable detections of the populous red clump star population in the Galactic bulge.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03230v1.title: Rotation measure variations in Galactic Centre pulsars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03230v1.summary: We report the results of an observational campaign using the Effelsberg 100-mtelescope of the pulsars J1746$-$2849, J1745$-$2912. The pulsars are located in the Central Molecular Zone (CMZ) close to the Galacticcentre. We report for the first time the RM value of PSR J1747$ to be $-12234.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03228v1.title: TuRMoiL of Survival: A Unified Survival Criterion for Cloud-Wind Interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03228v1.summary: Clouds can grow if they are able to mix and cool gas from the hot wind faster than it advects by the cloud. We present a new criterion which agrees with a previously proposed empirical formulae but is based on simple physical principles. We develop this insight into a predictive expression and validate it with hydrodynamic ENZO-E simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03221v1.title: Astrometry with Extended-Path Intensity Correlation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03221v1.summary: Extended-Path Intensity Correlator (EPIC) would enable ground-based astrometry at microarcsecond-level precision in a field of view as large asseveral arcseconds. EPIC can be employed to detect the astrometric wobble of Earth-like planets around Sun-like stars at hundreds of parsecs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03218v1.title: The imprint of galaxy mergers on satellite planes in a cosmological context
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03218v1.summary: Major mergers do not appear to form correlated planes in our statistical sample. Mergers that efficiently transfer their angular momentum can marginally enhance their phase-space correlation, but cannot form highly flattened and orbitally coherent configurations as observed in our local Universe. Even high-angular momentum mergers are inefficient at slinging satellites outward due to the extended nature of simulated satellite distributions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03219v1.title: Stochastic star formation in early galaxies: JWST implications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03219v1.summary: The star formation rate (SFR) in high redshift galaxies is expected to be time-variable due to competing physical processes. Such stochastic variability might boost the luminosity of galaxies, possibly explaining the over-abundanceseen at $z\gtrsim 10$ by JWST. We aim at quantifying the amplitude andtimescales of such variability, and identifying the key driving physical processes behind it.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03207v1.title: H$α$ Kinematics of Superbubbles and Supernova Remnants of the Dwarf galaxy NGC 4214
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03207v1.summary: We analysed the ionised gas kinematics of the dwarf galaxy NGC 4214 using high resolution Fabry-Perot interferometry observations. We also present for the first time, three-dimensional kinematic maps of the complexes N GC 4214-I and NGC4214-II.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05514v1.title: Impact of Non-Thermal Particle Acceleration on Radiative Signatures of AGN Jet-Cloud Interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05514v1.summary: This study investigates the complex dynamics of AGN (Active Galactic Nucleus) jet-cloud interactions. Findings reveal a two-fold increase in the magnetic field strength up to 5 {\mu}G due to cloud disruption and absorption. Inverse Compton scattering saw a 30% increase within the first 0.125 Myr, reflecting in an abrupt X-ray and gamma-ray emissions spike.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03202v1.title: Do old globular clusters in low mass galaxies disprove modified gravity?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03202v1.summary: The controversy "dark matter vs. modified gravity" constitutes a major topic of discussion. It was proposed that dynamical friction could be used to discriminate between the two alternatives. Analytic calculations indicate that, with modified gravity, globular clusters (GCs) of low-mass galaxies experience much stronger friction than in the equivalent system with Newtoniangravity and dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16152v1.title: A FUV and optical study of star formation in closely interacting galaxies: star forming rings, tidal arms and nuclear outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16152v1.summary: We present a study of the morphology of star formation and the associatednuclear activity in a sample of 8 closely interacting southern galaxies. Most of our sample galaxies are gas-rich and show evidence of recent, massive starforming in tidal tails, rings and spiral arms. IC5250 and NGC7733N, show extended nuclearflows of size 5 kpc and 8 kpc respectively. We compared the star formation rate in the barred and unbarred galaxies in our sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.14265v2.title: Seeing sharper and deeper: JWST's first glimpse of the photometric and spectroscopic properties of galaxies in the epoch of reionisation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.14265v2.summary: We analyse the photometric and spectroscopic properties of four galaxies in the SMACS 0723 JWST Early ReleaseObservations field. We find that all four sources exhibit strong (\geq 0.6 mag) F356W-F444W colours, which sit at theextreme end of theoretical predictions from numerical simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16078v1.title: Modeling of the high-velocity jet powered by the massive star MWC 349A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16078v1.summary: MWC 349A is a massive star with a well-known circumstellar disk rotating following a Keplerian law, and an ionized wind launched from the disk surface.
