ALMA observations have revealed an additional high-velocity component in the strong, maser emission of hydrogen radio recombination lines (RRLs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16050v1.title: JWST reveals widespread CO ice and gas absorption in the Galactic Center cloud G0.253+0.015
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16050v1.summary: We report JWST NIRCam observations of G0.253+0.015, the molecular cloud in the Central Molecular Zone known as The Brick. We catalog 56,146 stars detected in all 6                filters using the crowdsource package. Stars within and behind The Brick demonstrate prodigious absorption in the F466N filter that is produced by a combination of CO ice and gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02618v2.title: SimSpin v2.6.0 -- Constructing synthetic spectral IFU cubes for comparison with observational surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02618v2.summary: We present a methodology and a corresponding code-base for constructing mock integral field spectrograph (IFS) observations of simulatedgalaxies. Such methods are necessary to improve the collaboration and comparison of observation and theory results. This code, SimSpin, is an open-source package written in R, but also with an API interface.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03476v2.title: Galactic Dynamos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03476v2.summary: Spiral galaxies, including the Milky Way, have large-scale magnetic fields with significant energy densities. The dominant theory attributes these magnetic fields to a large- scale dynamo. We review the current status of dynamotheory and discuss various numerical simulations designed to explain or reproduce galactic magnetic fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15976v1.title: The dawn is quiet here: Rise in [$α$/Fe] is a signature of massive gas accretion that fueled proto-Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15976v1.summary: Proto-Milky Way epoch forms the earliest stars in our Galaxy and sets theinitial conditions for subsequent disk formation. Gas inflow also plays a vital role in shaping the star formation history and chemical evolution of galaxies. We find that the rise in [$\alpha$/Fe] is caused by a large inflow of fresh gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15970v1.title: On the dominant role of wind in the quasar feedback mode in the late stage evolution of massive elliptical galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15970v1.summary: This paper investigates the role of AGN feedback on the late stage of elliptical galaxies. By comparing models that take into account different feedback mechanisms, namely AGN and stellar feedback, we find that AGN is crucial in keeping the black hole in a low accretion state and suppressing star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15955v1.title: Circumgalactic Ly$α$ emission around submillimeter-bright galaxies with different quasar contributions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15955v1.summary: We present VLT/MUSE observations of five high-redshift submillimeter galaxies with increasing quasar (QSO) radiation. We find larger Ly$\alpha$ linewidths than usually reported around radio-quiet systems, pointing to large-scale outflows. We show that photoionization from the QSO and QSO outflows can contribute to power the emission. A statistical survey targeting similar high redshift massive systems is needed to confirm our findings.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15951v1.title: How widespread are aromatic cycles in cold clouds?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15951v1.summary: We report the detection of large hydrocarbon cycles toward several cold denseClouds. We observed four sources (L1495B, Lupus-1A, L483, and L1527) using the Yebes 40m radiotelescope. This indicates that aromaticcycles are specially favored in those interstellar clouds where long carbonchains are abundant.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14081v2.title: TIC 43152097. The first eclipsing binary in NGC 2232
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14081v2.summary: A low-mass totally eclipsing system in the young open cluster NGC2232. The primary component of TIC 43152097 is a late F-type dwarf. The lower-mass secondary results to be a late K-type star (Teff = 4130 K) that is still in the pre-main-sequence phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15919v1.title: Asteroseismology sheds light on the origin of carbon-deficient red giants: likely merger products and linked to the Li-rich giants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15919v1.summary: Carbon-deficient red giants (CDGs) are a peculiar class of stars. We aim to better characterise CDGs by usingasteroseismology (Kepler, TESS) combined with spectroscopy (APOGEE, LAMOST), and astrometry (Gaia) We discovered 15 new CDGs in the Kepler field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15908v1.title: Dynamics of Dwarf Galaxies in Scalar-Tensor-Vector-Gravity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15908v1.summary: Scalar-Tensor-Vector Gravity theory (STVG) modifies General Relativity by adding extra scalar and vector fields. The main aim is to replace dark matter in astrophysical self-gravitating systems. The weak-field limit of STVG brings a Yukawa-like modification to the Newtonian gravitational potential.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15903v1.title: The destiny of Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15903v1.summary: Dark matter (DM) makes up the remaining $85\%$ of the matter in the universe. The fate of DM is unknown. The destiny of DM particles follows one of two possible routes. The first is that massive DM particles lose sufficient energy through gravitational radiation causing them to spiral into a supermassive black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15859v1.title: On the source counts of VLBI-detected radio sources and the prospects of all-sky surveys with current and next generation instruments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15859v1.summary: We present an analysis of the detection fraction and the number counts of southeastern radio sources imaged with Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) at 1.4 GHz. From a sample of 24,903 radio sources identified by FIRST, 4,965 are detected on VLBI-scales, giving an overalldetection fraction of $19.9\pm2.9~$per cent. We find that compactness at arcsec-sc scales is the dominantFactor in determining whether a radio source is detected with VL BI.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03219v3.title: Stochastic star formation in early galaxies: JWST implications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03219v3.summary: The star formation rate (SFR) in high redshift galaxies is expected to be time-variable due to competing physical processes. Such stochastic variability might boost the luminosity of galaxies, possibly explaining the over-abundanceseen at $z\gtrsim 10$ by JWST. We aim at quantifying the amplitude andtimescales of such variability, and identifying the key driving physical processes behind it.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15781v1.title: On the galaxy counterpart and environment of the dusty Damped Lyman-$α$ Absorber at $z=2.226$ towards Q1218+0832
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15781v1.summary: Geier et al. (2019) presented the discovery of the quasar resulting from a search for quasars reddened and dimmed by dust in foreground Damped Lyman-alphaAbsorbers (DLAs) The DLA is remarkable by having a very large HI columndensity close to 10^22 cm^-2. Its dust extinction curve shows the 2175 AA-bump known from the Local Group. It also shows absorption from cold gas exemplified by CI and CO-molecules.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15761v1.title: Metal Enrichment due to Embedded Stars in AGN Discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15761v1.summary: We find He/H enhancements in some AGN, exceeding what can be explained by normal chemical evolution. We also reaffirm 3) a N/O ratio consistent with secondary production. We interpret 6) the larger metallicity in the BLR than NRL in terms of an in situ stellar evolution and pollution in AGN discs (SEPAD) model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17545v2.title: Geometry and Kinematics of a Dancing Milky Way: Unveiling the Precession and Inclination Variation across the Galactic Plane via Open Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17545v2.summary: The mid-plane of the Milky Way may not possess a stationary or fixed position. The inclined orbits of celestial bodies within our Galaxy exhibit a consistent pattern of elliptical shapes. An analysis of the vertical motion along the Galactocentric radius reveals that the disk has warped with precession. The study also finds that the inclinational variation of the disk is significant.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15707v1.title: Jet power extracted from ADAFs and the application to Fermi BL Lacertae objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15707v1.summary: We study the formation mechanism of the jets of BL Lacs with known redshifts detected by the Fermi satellite. We calculate the jet power of the Blandford-Znajek (BZ) model and the hybrid                model based on the self-similar solution of advection-dominated accretion flows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01792v2.title: Compactness of supermassive dark objects at galactic centers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01792v2.summary: Compactness of a gravitational lens is the scaled closest distance of the null geodesic giving rise to an image. Just an observation of a relativistic image would give an incredibly accurate upper bound to the compactness of the lens. These results, though obtained for supermassive dark objects at galactic centers, are valid for any object compact enough to give rise to images.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15623v1.title: Discovery of Spherules of Likely Extrasolar Composition in the Pacific Ocean Site of the CNEOS 2014-01-08 (IM1) Bolide
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15623v1.summary: We have conducted an extensive towed-magnetic-sled survey over the seafloor centered around the calculated path of the CNEOS 2014-01-08. We found about 700 spherules of diameter 0.05-1.3 millimeters of which 57 were analyzed so far. Mass spectrometry of 47 spherulenear the high-yield regions along IM1's path reveals a distinct extra-solar pattern for 5 of them.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.05508v2.title: Resolved velocity profiles of galactic winds at Cosmic Noon
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.05508v2.summary: We study the kinematics of the interstellar medium (ISM) in 20 gravitationally lensed galaxies during Cosmic Noon. 16 out of the 20 galaxies demonstrate a clear positive skewness, with a blueshifted tail. We examine scaling relations in outflow velocities with stellar mass and star formation rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15599v1.title: A 9-Month $\textit{Hubble Space Telescope}$ Near-UV Survey of M87. I. Light and Color Curves of 94 Novae, and a Re-determination of the Nova Rate
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15599v1.summary: M87 has been monitored with a cadence of 5 days over a 9 month-long span. This unprecedented dataset yields the NUV and optical light and color curves of 94 M87 novae. We test and confirm nova modelers' prediction that novae cannot erupt more frequently that once every 45 days.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.08461v2.title: Searching for Islands of Reionization: A Potential Ionized Bubble Powered by a Spectroscopic Overdensity at z = 8.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.08461v2.summary: Spectroscopic survey using the MOSFIRE near-infrared spectrograph on the 10m Keck telescope. Found Ly$\alpha$ emission from candidate galaxies at z ~9-10 in four CANDELS fields. Suggests existence of large (~1 pMpc) ionized bubbles fairly early in reionization process.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15592v1.title: Non-local Interactions are Essential Elements for Dark Matter Halo Stability: A Cross-Model Study
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15592v1.summary: This paper introduces a comprehensive methodology for examining the stability of dark matter (DM) halos. We highlight the inadequacy of vanilla cold.collision-less DM models in forecasting a stable halo. We find that halos made of bosons with notable quantum effects have sharp edges, while those made of fermions show more diffuse boundaries extending toward infinity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08918v2.title: A CEERS Discovery of an Accreting Supermassive Black Hole 570 Myr after the Big Bang: Identifying a Progenitor of Massive z > 6 Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08918v2.summary: We report the discovery of an accreting supermassive black hole at z=8.679, in CEERS_1019. We detect a significant broad (FWHM~1200 km/s) component in the H$\beta$ emission line, which we conclude originates in the broad-line region of an active galacticucleus (AGN) The mass of the black hole is $6.95 (-0.5) x the Eddington limit. We use this presently highest-redshift AGN discovery to place constraints on black hole seeding models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15586v1.title: Improved Redshifts for DESI EDR Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15586v1.summary: The Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) survey will provide opticalspectra for 3 million quasars. The majority of the DESI pipeline redshifts are reliable. However, 19\%$of the EDR qu asars have pipeline red shifts that deviate from our new redshift estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15583v1.title: Rapid Chemical Enrichment by Intermittent Star Formation in GN-z11
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15583v1.summary: We interpret the peculiar super-solar nitrogen abundance recently reported by James Webb Space Telescope observations for GN-z11 (z=10.6) using our state-of-the-art chemical evolution models. The observed CNO ratios can be successfully reproduced -- independently of the adopted initial mass function, nucleosynthesis yields and presence of supermassive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15582v1.title: Investigating Mass Segregation of the Binary Stars in the Open Cluster NGC 6819
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15582v1.summary: This is the first study to investigate mass segregation of the binaries in the open cluster NGC 6819. Within this primary sample, we find the binary radial distribution is significantly shifted toward the cluster center as compared to single stars. The same is true for the single stars, and the expected mass segregation timescale is significantly shorter than the cluster age.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19460v2.title: Chemo-Dynamical Tagging in the Outskirts: The Origins of Stellar Substructures in the Magellanic Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19460v2.summary: We present the first detailed chemical analysis from APOGEE-2S observations of stars in six regions of recently discovered substructures in the outskirts of the Magellanic Clouds. We also present, for the first time, the metallicity and alpha-abundance radialgradients of the LMC and SMC out to 11 degrees and 6 degrees, respectively. We conclude that the southern region closest to                the LMC has likely an LMC origin.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05793v2.title: Gravitational Wave Peeps from EMRIs and their Implication for LISA Signal Confusion Noise
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05793v2.summary: Gravitational wave peeps are not likely to be detected by a space-based gravitational wave detector. But an ensemble of such subthreshold sources produce an unresolvable background noise that may obscure sources otherwise detectable. Here we present the waveforms and spectra of the gravitational wave peep generated from recent calculations of extreme mass ratio inspirals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15551v1.title: The New Swift/UVOT+MaNGA (SwiM) Value-added Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15551v1.summary: SwiM_v4.1 is designed to study star-formation and dust attenuation within nearby galaxies. It comprises 559 objects, 4 times more than the original SwiM catalog. The galaxy maps, catalog files, and associated data models are publicly released on the SDSS website.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15543v1.title: Characterizing X-ray, UV, and optical variability in NGC 6814 using high-cadence Swift observations from a 2022 monitoring campaign
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15543v1.summary: We present the first results of a high-cadence Swift monitoring campaign of the Seyfert 1.5 galaxy NGC 6814. The structure function break-time is consistent across the UV/opticalwavebands, suggesting a very compact emission region in the disc. The lag-wavelength spectrum requires more modest truncation at an extreme accretion rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15538v1.title: The Dark Matter Discovery Potential of the Advanced Particle-Astrophysics Telescope (APT)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15538v1.summary: The new technique could be used to test the predicted proportionality between the gamma-ray fluxes and $J$-factors of individual dwarf galaxies, providing us with an unambiguous test of the origin of the Galactic Center Excess. It could also be used in the study of dark matter in the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15537v1.title: What drives the wheels of evolution in NGC 1512? A UVIT study
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15537v1.summary: Ongoing star formation in spiral galaxies can be affected by these processes. Environmental and secular processes play a pivotal role in the evolution ofgalaxies. We aim to understand the recent star formation activity in the galaxy NGC 1512 and thus gain insight into its evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15534v1.title: DES J024008.08-551047.5: A New Member to the Family of Polar Ring Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15534v1.summary: The galaxy DJ0240 is a potential PRG candidate with a ring component positioned almost perpendicular to the host galaxy. The position angles of the ring and host components have been determined to be 80 and 10 degrees, respectively, indicating that they are nearly orthogonal to each other. The host galaxy’s color and the presence of a bulge and disk indicate the possibility of the host galaxies being a lenticular type.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15521v1.title: Protonated hydrogen cyanide as a tracer of pristine molecular gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15521v1.summary: Protonated hydrogen cyanide plays a fundamental role in rochemistry. It is abundant in cold and quiescent regions, but is deficit in active star-forming regions. The decrease in the abundance of HCNH$^{+}$ iscaused by the fact that its main precursors (e.g., HCN and HNC) undergofreeze-out as the number density of H$1$ increases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15388v1.title: Are there any extragalactic high speed dark matter particles in the Solar neighborhood?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15388v1.summary: We use the APOSTLE suite of cosmological hydrodynamical simulations to examine the high speed tail of the local dark matter velocity distribution in simulated Milky Way analogues. The velocity distribution is well approximated by a generalized Maxwellian distribution sharply truncated at a well-defined maximum speed. Particles in the Solar neighborhood with speeds close to the local maximum speed can reach well outside the virial radius of the Galaxy. The local manifestation of such particles is thus not a distinct high-speed component, but rather the truncated Maxwellian tail.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09380v2.title: Multiphase condensation in cluster halos: interplay of cooling, buoyancy and mixing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09380v2.summary: Gas in the central regions of cool-core clusters and other massive halos has a short cooling time. Theoretical models predict that this gas is susceptible to multiphase condensation. We explore the parameters relevant to galaxy and cluster halos. We also study the effect of the steepness of the entropy profile, the strength of tumultuous forcing and the nature of turbulent forcing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15274v1.title: Multiple imaging of the quasar 2005+403 formed by anisotropic scattering
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15274v1.summary: We report on the low Galactic latitude ($b=4.3^\circ$) quasar 2005$+$403, the second active galactic nuclei. We detected a rare phenomenon of                multiple imaging induced by refractive-dominated scattering. The pattern formed by anisotropic decidedlyscattering is stretched out along the line of constant Galactic latitude.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15504v1.title: Planet formation throughout the Milky Way: Planet populations in the context of Galactic chemical evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15504v1.summary: Giant planets and super-Earths are most common around thin-disc ($\alpha$-poor) stars since these stars have an overall higher budget of solid particles. Water-rich planets are less commonaround low-metallicity stars since their low metallicity prohibits efficient growth beyond the water ice line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05679v2.title: The impact of UV variability on the abundance of bright galaxies at $z \geq 9$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05679v2.summary: JWST observations have revealed a population of galaxies bright enough that potentially challenge standard galaxy formation models. Using a minimal empirical framework, we investigate the influence of                variability on the rest-frame ultra-violet (UV) luminosity function (UVLF) of galaxies at $z\geq 9$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03758v2.title: Ram pressure stripping in the EAGLE simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03758v2.summary: Ram pressure stripping of satellite galaxies is thought to be a ubiquitous process in galaxy clusters. We track the evolution of galaxies with stellar mass between $z = 0.27$ and $Z = 0$. We find that the analytic models generally underpredict the stripping rate of neutral gas and overpredict that of ionized gas. This is due to opposing physical effects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15134v1.title: Evidence for a large off-centered galactic outflow and its connection to the extraplanar diffuse ionized gas in IC 1553
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15134v1.summary: We analyze a MUSE optical integral field spectrum of IC 1553 to study its extraplanar diffuse ionized gas. We find that the eDIGscale height has a maximum value of approximately 1.0 kpc. The asymmetric distribution of currently star-forming clusters produce a range of different ionization conditions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15073v1.title: Theoretical Analysis of Random Scattering Induced by Microlensing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15073v1.summary: Theoretical investigations into the deflection angle caused by microlenses offer a direct path to uncovering principles of the cosmological microlensingeffect. This work specifically concentrates on the the probability densityfunction (PDF) of the light deflected angle induced byMicrolenses. We have made several significant improvements to the widely used formula from Katz et.al.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03670v2.title: Flares from stars crossing active galactic nuclei disks on low-inclination orbits
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03670v2.summary: The origin of the recently discovered new class of transients, X-rayquasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs), remains a puzzle. In this paper, we predict the properties of emission from bow shockshocks produced by stars crossing AGN disks. We find that when a star's orbit is retrograde and has a low inclination, the breakout emission from the bow shock can explain the observed duration.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04311v2.title: Unraveling the Complexity of Dwarf Galaxy Dynamics: A study of Binary Orbital Motions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04311v2.summary: Many dwarf galaxies experience central density deflated due to binary motions. An extreme binary fraction of 70% can lead to central density deflation of up to 10-20% at 3 km/s. The choice of binary orbit distribution models does not result in significant differences, and observational errors slightly weaken deflations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09121v2.title: A Conditional Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model for Radio Interferometric Image Reconstruction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.09121v2.summary: In radio astronomy, signals from radio telescopes are transformed into images of observed celestial objects, or sources. These images contain real sources as well as artifacts due to signal sparsity and other factors. VIC-DDPM is a Visibility and Conditioned Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model. It uses visibility data to separate signals from noise and retaining spatialinformation in dirty images.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15029v1.title: Dynamical Influence of a Central Massive Object on Double-Barred Galaxies: Self-Destruction Mechanism of Secondary Bars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15029v1.summary: Double-barred galaxies exhibit sub-kpc secondary stellar bars that are crucial for channeling gases towards a central massive object (CMO) Recent $N$-body simulations uncovered a novel galaxy evolution scenario wherein the mass of the CMO progressivelyincreases owing to the secondary bar, resulting in the eventual destruction of the latter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15011v1.title: A massive quiescent galaxy in a group environment at $z=4.53$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15011v1.summary: The object was first identified as a galaxy with suppressed star formation at $z4.65$ from the COSMOS2020 catalog. It is in an extremely dense region; there are four massive star-forming galaxies at $4.4-4.7$ located within 150 physical kpc from the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14986v1.title: Constraining the Properties of Black Hole Seeds from the Farthest Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14986v1.summary: Over 60 years after the discovery of the first quasar, more than $275$ such sources are identified in the epoch of reionization at $z>6. JWST is now exploring higher redshifts and lower mass ranges. The discovery of progressively farther quasars is instrumental to constraining the properties of first population of blackhole seeds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13702v2.title: Extending the Chemical Reach of the H3 Survey: Detailed Abundances of the Dwarf-galaxy Stellar Stream Wukong/LMS-1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13702v2.summary: We present the first detailed chemical-abundance analysis of stars from the tumultuousdwarf-galaxy stellar stream Wukong/LMS-1. We find abundance patterns that are indistinguishable from the bulk of Indus and Jhelum, a pair of smaller stellar streams.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14185v3.title: Low-Frequency Radio Recombination Lines Away From the Inner Galactic Plane
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14185v3.summary: Diffuse radio recombination lines (RRLs) in the Galaxy are possible grounds for redshifted 21~cm experiments. We use EDGES drift scans centered at $-26.7^o$~declination to characterize diffuse RRLs across the southern sky. We find no evidence for carbon or hydrogen lines at the noise level of 3.4~mK.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14866v1.title: Spherical solutions of the Schrödinger-Poisson system with core-tail structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14866v1.summary: We construct spherically symmetric equilibrium solutions of the Schr\"odinger-Poisson system of equations with a core-tail structure. The tail has a radial velocity profile, whereas the core isstationary. We find that the tail initially perturbs the core, and consequently, the whole solution oscillates around a virialized solution that we call 'relaxed'

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14844v1.title: The SN 2023ixf Progenitor in M101: II. Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14844v1.summary: The star is heavily dust-obscured, likely the dustiest progenitor candidate yet encountered. We found maximum-likelihood estimates of the star's effective temperature and luminosity of 3450 K and 9.3e4 L_Sun. The candidate may have a Galactic RSG analog, IRC -10414, with a strikingly similar SED.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14822v1.title: CASCO: Cosmological and AStrophysical parameters from Cosmological simulations and Observations -- I. Constraining physical processes in local star-forming galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14822v1.summary: We compare the structural properties and dark matter content of star-forming galaxies taken from the CAMELS cosmological simulations to the observed trends. We consider the size-, internal DM fraction, internal DM mass- and total-stellar mass-relations for all the 1065 simulations from the IllustrisTNG, SIMBA and ASTRID suites of CAMELS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14817v1.title: Punctuated chaos and the unpredictability of the Galactic center S-star orbital evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14817v1.summary: Chaos arises from close encounters, particularly among pairs and near themassive central body. These encounters induce perturbations, causing suddenchanges in the orbital energies of the interacting stars. Consequently, neighboring solutions experience roughly exponential growth in separation. For the coming millennium, chaos in the S-star cluster will be driven mainly by the closest orbiting stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14813v1.title: Gauging the mass of metals in the gas phase of galaxies from the Local Universe to the Epoch of Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14813v1.summary: The chemical enrichment of dust and metals are vital processes inconstraining the star formation history of the universe. Previously, the dust masses of high-redshift star-forming galaxies have been determined through the far-infrared continuum. Here, we present a new method of inferring the metal mass of galaxies out to $z\approx 8$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14812v1.title: The cosmic build-up of dust and metals. Accurate abundances from GRB-selected star-forming galaxies at $1.7 < z < 6.3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14812v1.summary: The chemical enrichment of dust and metals in the interstellar medium (ISM) throughout cosmic time is one of the key driving processes of galaxy evolution. Here we study the evolution of the gas-phase metallicities,dust-to-gas (DTG), and dust- to-metal (DTM) ratios of 36 star-forming galaxies probed by gamma-ray bursts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14805v1.title: Precision ${\tt MARS}$ Mass Reconstruction of Abell 2744: Synergizing the Largest Strong Lensing and Densest Weak Lensing Datasets from JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14805v1.summary: We present a new high-resolution free-form mass model of Abell 2744. The mass reconstruction remarkably well traces the brightest cluster galaxies. We do not detect any unusual mass peaks that are not traced by the cluster galaxies, unlike previous studies. We make our mass and magnification maps publicly available.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14803v1.title: Punctuated Chaos and Indeterminism in Self-gravitating Many-body Systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14803v1.summary: Dynamical chaos is a fundamental manifestation of gravity in astrophysical, many-body systems. Here, exponential divergence is not a continuous process but rather the cumulative effect of an ever-increasing linear response driven by discrete events at regular intervals. We show that long-lived systems with punctuated chaos can magnify Planck length-like perturbations to astronomical scales within their lifetime.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14798v1.title: Detecting a disk bending wave in a barred-spiral galaxy at redshift 4.4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14798v1.summary: Recent discovery of barred spiral galaxies in the early universe. Study investigates the morphology and kinematics of the far infrared (FIR) continuum and [CII] emission in BRI1335-0417. The variations inposition angle and ellipticity of the isophotes show the characteristic signature of a barred galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14799v1.title: The young massive SMC cluster NGC 330 seen by MUSE III. Stellar parameters and rotational velocities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14799v1.summary: The origin of initial rotation rates of stars, and how a star's surface's rotational velocity changes during the evolution, remain open questions in stellar astrophysics. Here, we aim to derive the physicalparameters and study the distribution of rotational velocities of B-type stars in the 35 Myr-old, massive cluster NGC 330.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.10412v2.title: JWST's TEMPLATES for Star Formation: The First Resolved Gas-Phase Metallicity Maps of Dust-Obscured Star-Forming Galaxies at $z$ $\sim$ 4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.10412v2.summary: We present the first spatially resolved maps of gas-phase metallicity for two dust-obscured star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) at $z\sim$ 4. We argue that both systems have already undergone significant metal enrichment as a result of their extremely high star formationrates. The data are indicative of the enormous potential of JWST to probe the enrichment of the interstellar medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14791v1.title: The morphological transformation of ram pressure stripped galaxies: a pathway from late to early galaxy types
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14791v1.summary: We investigate how the ageing of stellar populations can drive amorphological transformation in galaxies whose star formation activity has been quenched on short timescales. We find that, in all scenarios considered, the initial.galaxy population dominated by blue-cloud spirals evolves into a mixed.population mostly composed by red-sequence spirals and lenticulars. The morphology transformation is completed after just 1.5-3.5 Gyr in more efficient quenching scenarios.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14793v1.title: IllustrisTNG in the HSC-SSP: image data release and the major role of mini mergers as drivers of asymmetry and star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14793v1.summary: At fixed galaxy stellar mass, there is a clear observational connection between structural asymmetry and offset from the star forming main sequence. We use the TNG50 simulation to investigate the relativeroles of major mergers (stellar mass ratios) and mini mergers ($0.01 \leq \mu < 0.1$) in driving this connection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14794v1.title: A Parsec-Scale Catalog of Molecular Clouds in the Solar Neighborhood Based on 3D Dust Mapping: Implications for the Mass-Size Relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14794v1.summary: We dendrogram the Leike et al. 2020 3D dust map to produce a uniform catalog of molecular clouds. We measure the properties of 65 molecular clouds in true 3D space. We create 2D dust extinction maps from the 3D data by projecting the clouds onto a 2D "Sky" view.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14790v1.title: A striking relationship between dust extinction and radio detection in DESI QSOs: evidence for a dusty blow-out phase in red QSOs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14790v1.summary: We present the first eight months of data from our secondary target program within the ongoing Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) survey. Our program uses a mid-infrared and optical colour selection to preferentiallytarget dust-reddened QSOs that would have otherwise been missed by the nominal DESI QSO selection. So far we have obtained optical spectra for 3038 candidates, of which ~70% of the high-quality objects (those with robust redshifts) are visually confirmed to be Type 1 Q SOs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08263v3.title: What Causes The Formation of Disks and End of Bursty Star Formation?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08263v3.summary: galaxies can transition from irregular/spheroidal with 'bursty' star formation histories (SFHs), to disky with smooth SFHs. We show that gas supply, cooling/thermodynamics, star formation model, Toomre scale, galaxy dynamicaltimes, and feedback properties do not have a direct causal effect on these transitions. Rather, both the formation of disks and cessation of bursty starforming are driven by the gravitational potential, but in different ways.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06851v2.title: Novel Conservative Methods for Adaptive Force Softening in Collisionless and Multi-Species N-Body Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06851v2.summary: Modeling self-gravity of collisionless fluids is challenging and requires some force softening. We derive a generalized form of the energy-and-momentumConserving gravitational equations of motion. We also derive new methods to maintain better accuracy and conservation when symmetrizing forces between particles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05811v2.title: A Simple Sub-Grid Model For Cosmic Ray Effects on Galactic Scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05811v2.summary: Many recent numerical studies have argued that cosmic rays (CRs) from supernovae or active galactic nuclei (AGN) could play a crucial role in galactic formation. But explicit CR-magneto-hydrodynamics (CR-MHD) remains computationally expensive. We present an intentionallyextremely-simplified sub-grid model for CRs, which attempts to capture the key behaviors of greatest interest.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14696v1.title: The puzzling properties of the MACS1149-JD1 galaxy at z=9.11
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14696v1.summary: We analyze new JWST NIRCam and NIRSpec data on the redshift 9.11 galaxyMACS1149-JD1. Our N IRCam imaging data reveal that JD1 comprises three spatially distinct components. Our spectroscopic data indicate thatJD1 appears dust-free but is already enriched. A recent burst of star formation is also revealed by the star formation history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14691v1.title: Scalar Field Dark Matter: Impact of Supernovae-driven blowouts on the soliton structure of low mass dark matter halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14691v1.summary: We present the first study on the gravitational impact of supernova feedback in an isolated soliton and a spherically symmetric dwarf SFDM halo. We simulate the.rapid gas removal from the center of the soliton by a concentric external.time-dependent Hernquist potential. The range in the density amplitudedepends on the strength of the blowout.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14664v1.title: Explaining the oblate morphology of dwarf spheroidals with Wave Dark Matter perturbations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14664v1.summary: We investigate whether the oblate, spheroidal morphology of common dwarf774spheroidals (dSph) may result from the slow relaxation of stellarorbits within a halo of Wave Dark Matter. Stellar orbits randomly walk over a Hubble time,perturbed by the pervasive "granular" interference pattern of $\psi$DM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13160v2.title: Revisiting X-ray-Bright-Optically-Normal-Galaxies with the Chandra Source Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13160v2.summary: X-ray bright optically normal galaxies (XBONGs) are galaxies with X-ray luminosities consistent with those of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) but no evidence of AGN optical emission lines. 43% of the XBONG sample have X-rays suggesting NH > 1022 cm-2, double the fraction in the QSO sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13159v2.title: The Chandra Source Catalog Normal Galaxy Sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13159v2.summary: We present an extensive and well-characterized Chandra X-ray Galaxy Catalog. The CGC was extracted from the Chandra Source Catalog version 2 (CSC2) by cross-correlating with optical and IR all-sky survey data. We estimate ~5% false match fraction and contamination by QSOs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.08865v2.title: Structure of the equivalent Newtonian systems in MOND N-body simulations. Density profiles and the core-cusp problem
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.08865v2.summary: We investigate the core-cusp problem of the cold dark matter scenario in the context of Modified Newtonian Dynamics. By means of particle-mesh $N-$body simulations in MOND we explore processes of galaxyformation via cold dissipationless collapse. We find that the dark matter density of ENSs of most spherical galaxies ha a markedly cored structure, in particular for the lowest virial ratios.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01906v2.title: Two-population Bayesian hierarchical model of type Ia supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01906v2.summary: The currently used standardisation of type Ia supernovae results in Hubble                residuals whose physical origin is unaccounted for. Here, we present a complete                physical interpretation of the Hubble residuals based on a novel Bayesianhierarchical model. We find strong evidence for the presence of two                overlapping, but distinct, populations differentiated primarily by their mean stretch.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13959v3.title: Swift Deep Galactic Plane Survey Classification of Swift J170800$-$402551.8 as a Candidate Intermediate Polar Cataclysmic Variable
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13959v3.summary: The Swift J170800$-$402551.8 star is part of the Deep Galactic Plane Survey. The X-ray spectrum can be described by thermal bremsstrahlung radiation. The faintness of the counterpart favors a low-mass donor star. The spin period of the white dwarf is 784 s.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14489v1.title: Inferring the presence of very massive stars in local star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14489v1.summary: Study aims to detect VMS in local star-forming region from imprint they leave on integrated UV and optical light. We show that the UV range alone is not sufficient to distinguish between VMS- and WR-dominated sources. A high equivalent width of HeII 1640 is not a sufficient condition foridentifying VMS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08276v3.title: Spectroscopic age estimates for APOGEE red-giant stars: Precise spatial and kinematic trends with age in the Galactic disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08276v3.summary: We estimate spectroscopicstellar ages for 178 825 red-giant stars observed by the APOGEE survey with amedian statistical uncertainty of 17%. We analyse the dispersion about the abundance gradient as a function of age. We find a clear power-law trend for this relation, indicating a relatively smooth radial migration history in the Galactic disc over the past $7-9$ Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14458v1.title: Electromagnetic signatures of white dwarf collisions in AGN discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14458v1.summary: The collision of two white dwarfs (WDs) through Jacobi capture might be inevitable, leading to a Type Ia supernova (SN Ia) explosion. This transient event is influenced by the disc gas and the gravity of the supermassive black hole (SMBH) The energy of the explosion is mainly stored in the ejecta in the form of kinetic energy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14454v1.title: Identification of the simplest sugar-like molecule glycolaldehyde towards the hot molecular core G358.93-0.03 MM1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14454v1.summary: Glycolaldehyde is the simplest monosaccharide sugar in the interstellar medium. It is directly involved in the origin of life via the 'RNA world' hypothesis. We present the first detection of glycolaldehyde towards the hot molecular core G358.93-0.03 MM1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14449v1.title: White Dwarf--White Dwarf collisions in AGN discs via close encounters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14449v1.summary: White dwarfs (WDs) in active galactic nucleus (AGNs) discs might migrate to inner radii of the discs and form restricted three-body systems with twoWDs moving around the central supermassive black hole (SMBH) in close orbits. These systems could be dynamical unstable, which can lead to very close                encounters or direct collisions. We use N-body simulations to study the evolution of such systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06452v2.title: Origin of neutron capture elements with the Gaia-ESO survey: the evolution of s- and r-process elements across the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06452v2.summary: We study abundance patterns and radial gradients of s-process and r-process elements in the Galactic thin disc by means of a detailed chemical evolution model. The predictions of our model are compared with data from the Gaia-ESO survey. We conclude that: i) the [Eu/Fe] vs. [Fe/H] is reproduced by both a prompt and a delayed source, but the quick source completely dominates the Eu production.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14305v1.title: 3D stellar motion in the axisymmetric Galactic potential and the e-z resonances
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14305v1.summary: The full phase space information on the kinematics of a huge number of stars has been provided by the Gaia third Data Release. In this paper, we investigate the possible regimes of motion of stars in the axisymmetric approximation of a Galactic potential model. The results obtained can be helpful in the understanding and interpretation of the features observed in thestellar 3D distribution around the Sun.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14303v1.title: A large sample of newly-identified carbon-deficient red giants from APOGEE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14303v1.summary: Based on the APOGEE survey we conducted a search for carbon-deficient red                giants (CDGs) We found 103 new CDGs, increasing the number in the literature by more than a factor of 3. CDGs are very rare, representing $0.03$~per cent of reptiles. They appear as an extended tail off the normal carbon distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14281v1.title: Signatures of the Self-organized Criticality Phenomenon in Precursors of Gamma-ray bursts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14281v1.summary: Precursors provide important clues to the nature of gamma-ray burst (GRB)central engines and can be used to contain GRB physical processes. We study the self-organized criticality in precursors of long GRBs in the third Swift/BAT Catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14278v1.title: Simulation Of The Microlensing Effect Near The Critical Curve Of The Galaxy Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14278v1.summary: Simulating microlensing near the critical curve poses challenges due to magnification divergence and the substantial computational demands involved. To achieve therequired simulation accuracy, direct inverse ray-shooting would require tremendouslysignificant computational resources. Using the GPU of NVIDIA Tesla V100S PCIe 32GB, it takes approximately                7000 seconds to calculate the effects of around 13,000 microlenses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07419v2.title: Mapping the Decline with Redshift of Dusty Star-forming Galaxies Using JWST and SCUBA-2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07419v2.summary: We use JWST NIRCam observations of the massive lensing cluster field A2744 to develop a red galaxy selection of f(F444W) > 1 uJy. We show that by using the red galaxies as priors, we can probe deeper in the SCUBA-2 850 micron image. We also show that there is a strong drop between z<4 and z>4.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14248v1.title: Constraints on the $z\sim5$ Star-Forming Galaxy Luminosity Function From $\textit{Hubble Space Telescope}$ Imaging of an Unbiased and Complete Sample of Long Gamma-ray Burst Host Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14248v1.summary: We present rest-frame UV imaging of the largest and most complete sample of 23 long duration gamma-ray burst (GRB) host galaxies between redshifts 4 and 6. We find that when assuming the standard Schechter-function parameterization for the UV LF, the GRB host sample is best fit with $\alpha = -1.30^{+0.30}_{-0.25}$ and $M_* = grotesque-20-20.33-20+.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14234v1.title: An initial analysis of a strongly-lensed QSOs candidate identified by LAMOST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14234v1.summary: From 2011 to 2021, LAMOST has released a total of 76,167 quasar data. We try to search for gravitationally lensed QSOs by limiting coordinate differences and redshift differences. We accidentally find a galaxy group near the component A and B. We will investigate the possibility when the redshifts of nearby galaxies are available.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09755v2.title: A unified model for the co-evolution of galaxies and their circumgalactic medium: the relative roles of turbulence and atomic cooling physics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09755v2.summary: The circumgalactic medium (CGM) plays a pivotal role in regulating gas flows around galaxies. The details of how galaxies and their CGM co-evolve remain poorly understood. We demonstrate that, depending on parameters, the CGM can go through a phase transition (''thermalization'')

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14027v1.title: The EDIBLES survey VI. Searching for time variations of interstellar absorption features
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14027v1.summary: Interstellar lines observed toward stellar targets change slowly over long timescales. This is mainly due to the proper motion of the background target relative to the intervening clouds. The cloud's slowly changing physical and chemical conditions can also cause variation. We found evidence for variations in the profiles of the diffuse interstellar DIBs in a few sightlines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14021v1.title: Determining the parameters of the spiral arms of the Galaxy from kinematic tracers based on Gaia DR3 data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14021v1.summary: We use the stars Gaia DR3, whose absolute magnitude is $M_G$ < 4, and which allow tracing spiral arms at large distances from the Sun. We use the centroids of stellar spherical regions with a radius of                0.5 kpc, in which the deformation velocities along the coordinate axis R are areinsignificant. These kinematic tracers cover the Galactic plane within the tumultuousGalactocentric coordinate ranges 140{\deg] < ${\theta}$ < 220{\deg} and 4 kpc < 14 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13974v1.title: Measuring the dust attenuation law of galaxies using photometric data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13974v1.summary: Fitting model spectral energy distributions (SED) to galaxy photometric data is a widely used method to recover galaxy parameters from galaxy surveys. The parameter space used to describe galaxies is wide andinterdependent, and distinctions between real and spurious correlations that are found between these parameters can be difficult to discern.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07327v2.title: Search for directional associations between Baikal Gigaton Volume Detector neutrino-induced cascades and high-energy astrophysical sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07327v2.summary: Baikal-GVD has recently published its first measurement of the diffuseastrophysical neutrino flux. We use high-energy cascade-like events to explore possible associations between Baikal neutrinos and astrophysical sources. We primarily focus on energies exceeding 100 TeV, which we employ to search for correlation with radio-bright blazars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01277v2.title: X-ray metal line emission from the hot circumgalactic medium: probing the effects of supermassive black hole feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01277v2.summary: We compare IllustrisTNG, EAGLE, and SIMBA galaxy simulations. The three simulations consistently predict a dichotomy between star-forming and quiescent galaxies at the Milky-Way and Andromeda mass range. This is a signature of SMBH-driven outflows, which are responsible for quenching star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13889v1.title: HI in Molecular Clouds: Irradiation by FUV plus Cosmic Rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13889v1.summary: We extend the analytic theory for the production of atomic hydrogen (HI) via FUVphotodissociation at the boundaries of dense interstellar molecular (H$_2$)clouds. We present computations for a wide range of FUV fieldstrengths, cosmic-ray ionization rates, and dust-to-gas ratios. For most Galactic GMCs and conditions, FUV photodiss association dominates over cosmic-rays for the growth of the HI column densities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00226v3.title: Cluster aggregates surrounding Pismis 5 in the Vela Molecular Ridge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00226v3.summary: We identify eight open clusters surrounding Pismis 5 in the Vela Molecular Ridge. The open cluster QZ 1 is newly discovered. Binary and triple open cluster candidates have been identified as potential primordial aggregates. According to kinematic speculations, the two aggregate candidates will gradually separate, and their interiors will slowly disintegrate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13648v1.title: Emulating Radiative Transfer with Artificial Neural Networks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13648v1.summary: Monte Carlo radiative transfer is often used in post-processing on a galaxy-by-galaxy basis. This is computationally expensive, especially if one wants to make predictions for suites of many cosmological simulations. An artificial neural network (ANN) can predict SEDs of simulated galaxies using a small number of integrated properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13638v1.title: HH 80/81: Structure and Kinematics of the Fastest Protostellar Outflow
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13638v1.summary: Hubble Space Telescope images obtained in 2018 are combined with archival HST data taken in 1995 to detect changes and measure proper motions in the HH 80/81 shock complex. The complex is powered by the fastest known jet driven by a forming star, the massive object IRAS 18162-2048.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13631v1.title: Exploring the Origin of the Distance Bimodality of Stars in the Periphery of the Small Magellanic Cloud with APOGEE and Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13631v1.summary: The Magellanic Cloud system represents a unique laboratory for study of both interacting dwarf galaxies and the ongoing process of the formation of the Milky Way and its halo. We focus on one aspect of this complex, 3 bodyinteraction - the dynamical perturbation of the Small Mageller Cloud (SMC) by the Large Magellan Cloud (LMC) We explore the well-known distance bimodality on the eastern side of the SMC.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10802v3.title: Identification of Galaxy-Galaxy Strong Lens Candidates in the DECam Local Volume Exploration Survey Using Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10802v3.summary: We perform a search for galaxy-galaxy strong lens systems using aconvolutional neural network. We present a list of 581 strong lens candidates, 562 of which arepreviously unreported. We categorize our candidates using their human-assigned scores. We additionally highlight eight potential quadruply lensedquasars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13602v1.title: UVIT/AstroSat Investigation of a low luminous Blue Straggler Star in NGC 362: Detection of extremely low mass white dwarf as companion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13602v1.summary: We identified an extremely low-mass white dwarf as acompanion to a low luminous blue straggler star within the Galactic globularcluster NGC 362. We determined the effective temperature, radius, and luminosity for both the white dwarf and the blue star. The position of the stragglers suggests their formation via the Case A/B mass-transfer mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07518v2.title: A jolt to the system: ram pressure on low-mass galaxies in simulations of the Local Group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07518v2.summary: Low-mass galaxies are highly susceptible to environmental effects that can efficiently quench star formation. We explore the role of ram pressure in quenching low-mass galaxy within 2 Mpc of Milky Way hosts. Ram pressure is highlyvariable across different environments, within individual MW haloes, and forindividual low- mass galaxies over time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13598v1.title: Linking ice and gas in the Coronet cluster in Corona Australis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13598v1.summary: Chemical composition of protostellar envelope material can be preserved or processed to various degrees depending on the surrounding physical environment. We present 1.3 mm Submillimeter Array (SMA) and Atacama Pathfinder Experiment (APEX) observations towards the envelopes of four low-mass protostars in the Coronet.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13599v1.title: A comprehensive model for the formation and evolution of the faintest Milky Way dwarf satellites
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13599v1.summary: In this study, we modify the semi-analytic model Galacticus in order to reproduce the observed properties of dwarf galaxies in the MilkyWay. We find that reproducing observational determinations of the halooccupation fraction and mass-metallicity relation for dwarf galaxies requires H$_2$ cooling, an updated UV background radiation model, and a model for the metal content of the intergalactic medium. We predict a total of $300 ^{+75} _{-99} satellites with an absolute $V$-band magnitude less than $0$ within $300$ kpc from

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13600v1.title: Where is the End of the Cosmic-Ray Electron Spectrum?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13600v1.summary: Detecting the end of the cosmic-ray (CR) electron spectrum would provideimportant new insights. At the highest energies, the accelerators may not have sufficientuminosity, or the sources may not allow sufficient escape. For each step, we calculate a rough range of possibilities. Although all of the inputs are uncertain, a clear vista ofexciting opportunities emerges.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13593v1.title: Constraints on sub-terrestrial free-floating planets from Subaru microlensing observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13593v1.summary: The abundance of protoplanetary bodies ejected from their parent star system is currently poorly-constrained. The three primary microlensing surveys currently searching for FFPs operate at a cadence greater than 15 minutes. This limits their ability to observe events associated with FFP bodies with a mass much below an Earth mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11610v3.title: UNCOVER: A NIRSpec Identification of a Broad Line AGN at z = 8.50
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11610v3.summary: Deep observations with JWST have revealed an emerging population of red-point-like sources that could provide a link between the postulatedsupermassive black hole seeds and observed quasars. We present aJWST/NIRSpec spectrum of amassive accreting black hole at $z=8.50.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13508v1.title: CECILIA: The Faint Emission Line Spectrum of z~2-3 Star-forming Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13508v1.summary: We present the first results from CECILIA, a Cycle 1 JWST NIRSpec/MSA program that uses ultra-deep G235M/F170LP observations. Emission lines of eight different elements (H, He, N, O, Si, S, Ar, and Ni) are detected. We find T_e[NII]=13630+/-2540$ K, representing the first measurement of electron temperature using [NII] in the                high-redshift universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11609v3.title: UNCOVER: A NIRSpec Census of Lensed Galaxies at z=8.50-13.08 Probing a High AGN Fraction and Ionized Bubbles in the Shadow
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11609v3.summary: JWST NIRSpec prism spectroscopy of gravitationally lensed galaxies found behind the massive galaxy cluster Abell 2744 in the Cycle 1 Treasury Program. We confirm the source redshift via emissionlines and/or the Ly$\alpha$ break feature for ten galaxies at z=8.50-13.08.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16204v2.title: Transiting Exoplanet Yields for the Roman Galactic Bulge Time Domain Survey Predicted from Pixel-Level Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16204v2.summary: The Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope (Roman) is NASA's next astrophysics flagship mission, expected to launch in late 2026. Roman will collect photometric and astrometric data for over 100 million stars in the Galactic bulge to search for microlensing planets. From simulations, we predict Roman will find between $60,000 and $200,000 transiting planets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13446v1.title: Density calculations of NGC 3783 warm absorbers using a time-dependent photoionization model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13446v1.summary: Outflowing wind as one type of AGN feedback, which involves noncollimated                ionized winds prevalent in Seyfert-1 AGNs. However, the distance of the outflowing winds is poorly constrained due to a lack of direct imaging observations. It is expected that future spectroscopic observations with more sensitive instruments will provide more accurate constraints on the outflow density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09372v3.title: Euclid preparation. XXXI. Performance assessment of the NISP Red-Grism through spectroscopic simulations for the Wide and Deep surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09372v3.summary: This work focuses on the pilot run of a simulation campaign aimed at investigating the spectroscopic capabilities of the Euclid Near-InfraredSpectrometer and Photometer. To this purpose we constructed, emulated, and analysed the spectra of 4992 star-forming galaxies using the NISP pixel-level simulator.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18198v2.title: The saturation mechanism of thermal instability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18198v2.summary: The literature on thermal instability (TI) reveals that even for a simplehomogeneous plasma, the nonlinear outcome ranges from a gentle reconfiguration of the initial state to an explosive one. The mechanism by which TI saturates: whenever the boundary of the instability region (the Balbus contour) is crossed, a dynamical change is triggered.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13580v1.title: HI 21 cm observations and dynamical models of superthin galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13580v1.summary: The primary objective of this thesis is to identify the key dynamicalmechanisms responsible for the superthin stellar discs. We use HI 21cmradio-synthesis observations and stellar photometry to construct detailedDynamic models of a sample of superthin galaxies. The major contributions are from $A/b$ and $Q/R. This possibly indicates high values of the disc dynamical stability and dark matter dominance at inner galactocentric radii.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10150v2.title: Dust attenuation in galaxies at cosmic dawn from the FirstLight simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10150v2.summary: We study the behavior of dust in galaxies at cosmic dawn, z=6-8, by coupling simulations with the radiative transfer code POLARIS. The complex nature of these galaxies and their complex distribution of dust lead to a large diversity of attenuation curves. These follow the Calzetti model only for relatively massive galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13347v1.title: Objects in JWST's mirrors are closer than they appear
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13347v1.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) has revealed extremely distant galaxies at unprecedentedly early cosmic epochs. However, as larger samples continue to be followed up spectroscopically, it has become apparent that nearly all photometric redshifts at these epochs are biased high.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02333v3.title: Disentangling the Hadronic Components in NGC 1068
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02333v3.summary: Recent detection of high-energy neutrinos by IceCube in the direction of nearby Seyfert/starburst galaxy NGC 1068 implies that radio-quiet activegalactic nuclei can accelerate cosmic-ray ions. At the same time, the GeV emission detected by the {\it Fermi}-Large Area Telescope (LAT) is likely related to the galaxy's sustained star-formation activity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13312v1.title: \HI{} 21cm observations and dynamical modelling of the thinnest galaxy: FGC 2366
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13312v1.summary: Superthin galaxies are bulgeless low surface brightness galaxies with an unusually high major-to-minor axes ratio of the stellar disc. We present Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT) observations of FGC 2366, the thinnest galaxy known with $a/b=21.6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03484v2.title: A Systematic Study of Associations between Supernova Remnants and Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03484v2.summary: We universally search for evidence of kinematic and spatial correlation of supernova remnant (SNR) and molecular cloud (MC) associations. Overall, there could be as high as 80% of SNRs associated with MCs. We find that SNR-MC associations are mainly distributed in a thin disk along the Galactic plane, while a small amount are in a thick disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13288v1.title: Star Formation at the Epoch of Reionization with CANUCS: The ages of stellar populations in MACS1149-JD1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13288v1.summary: We present measurements of stellar populations properties of a z = 9.1gravitationally lensed galaxy MACS1149-JD1 using deep JWST NIRISS slitlessspectroscopy. The galaxy is split into four components. Three magnified star-forming components are unresolved, giving them sizes of < 50pc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13283v1.title: Tracing obscured galaxy build-up at high redshift using deep radio surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13283v1.summary: A fundamental question of extra-galactic astronomy is the evolution of the star formation rate (SFR) and supermassive black hole (SMBH) activity with cosmic time. A primary focus is the study of merging systems, comprising highly star-forming galaxies (SFGs) and active galactic nuclei (AGN) at the earliest stages of galactic formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11477v2.title: Two-Screen Scattering in CRAFT FRBs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11477v2.summary: Temporal broadening is a commonly observed property of fast radio bursts. Scattering is an important probe of the media along the line of sight to an FRB source. We quantify the scattering and scintillation in 10 FRBs with known host galaxies and redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13571v1.title: On the most reliable value of the Galactic aberration constant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13571v1.summary: Galactic aberration (GA) is a small effect in proper motions of celestialobjects. It is noticeable in highlyaccurate astrometric observations such as VLBI and Gaia. However accurateaccounting for this effect faces difficulty caused by the uncertainty in the GAamplitude (GA constant)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13190v1.title: Numerical models of planetary nebulae with different episodes of mass ejection: the particular case of HuBi 1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13190v1.summary: We have studied the evolution of HuBi 1-like planetary nebulae, considering several stages of mass injection. We have carried out numerical ionization+1Dhydrodynamics+atomic/ionic rate models with our code Coral 1D. This is our first step with a 1D code to study these two physical phenomena at the same time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13185v1.title: The mid-infrared variability of the SDSS optical quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13185v1.summary: Based on the Seventh Data Release (DR7) quasar catalog from the Sloan Digital DigitalSky Survey. No obvious correlation is found between W1-W2 and g-r color. We think the mid-infraredemission of quasars may be smoothed out by the extended dust distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13121v1.title: Devouring The Centaurus A Satellites: Modeling Dwarf Galaxies with Galacticus
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13121v1.summary: For the first time, systematic studies of dwarf galaxies are being conducted                throughout the Local Volume. Given Centaurus As mass (roughly ten times that of the Milky Way), AGN activity, and recent major mergers, investigating their star formation physics is imperative. simulating the slightest dwarfs in a massive galaxy like Centaurus A with sufficient resolution is computationally expensive and currentlyfeasible.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13064v1.title: The relationship between IGM Lyman-alpha opacity and galaxy density near the end of reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13064v1.summary: Observed scatter in the Lyman-alpha opacity of quasar sightlines at $z<6$ has motivated measurements of the correlation between Ly$\alpha$ opacity and galaxydensity. Models that predict this scatter make strong and sometimes oppositepredictions for how they should be related. The results at high opacities are consistent with models that invoke UV background fluctuations or late reionization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13037v1.title: Multimass modelling of Milky Way globular clusters -- II. present-day black hole populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13037v1.summary: Populations of stellar-mass black holes (BHs) in globular clusters (GCs) have important implications on one of the main formation channels for gravitational wave sources. Inferring the sizeof these populations remains difficult, however. In this work, multimass models are used to explore the present-day BH populations of a large sample of clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13019v1.title: A systematic analysis of the X-ray emission in optically selected tidal disruption events: observational evidence for the unification of the optically and X-ray selected populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13019v1.summary: X-ray light curves show a diverse range of temporalbehaviors, with most sources not following the expected power-law decline. Three sources show the formation of a hard X-ray corona around 200                days after the UV/optical peak. The evolution of the derived physical parameters favors a decrease in the optical depth of a reprocessing layer instead of delayed disk formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12998v1.title: Black-hole mergers in disk-like environments could explain the observed $q - χ_\mathrm{eff}$ correlation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12998v1.summary: Current gravitational-wave data from stellar-mass black-hole binary mergers suggest a correlation between the binary mass ratio $q$ and the effective spin. We show that the symmetry of the astrophysical environment is a crucialfeature to shed light on this otherwise puzzling piece of observationalevidence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12993v1.title: The MUSE Ultra Deep Field (MUDF). IV. A pair of X-ray weak quasars at the heart of two extended Lyα nebulae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12993v1.summary: We present the results obtained from follow-up observations of the MUSE Ultra                Deep Field (MUDF) at X-ray energies with XMM-Newton. The MUDF is centred on aunique field with two bright, physically associated quasars at $z\simeq3.23$separated by $sim$500 kpc in projection. Both qu asars are embedded within extended Ly$\alpha$ nebulae ($\gtrsim 100~\rm kpc)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12992v1.title: Birth of the first stars amidst decaying and annihilating dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12992v1.summary: The first stars are expected to form through molecular-hydrogen (H$_2$)cooling. This channel is especially sensitive to the thermal and ionization state of gas. It can thus act as a probe of exotic energy injection from decaying or annihilating dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12987v1.title: The host dark matter haloes of the first quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12987v1.summary: Satellites accelerate as they approach the quasar host galaxy, producing a line-of-sight velocity profile. This increase in velocity is particularly pronounced if the host halo mass is higher than $z = 6. A comparison with existing ALMA, JWST and MUSE velocity measures reveals that observed $z > 6$ quasar companions closely follow the velocity distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.16733v3.title: Painting baryons onto N-body simulations of galaxy clusters with image-to-image deep learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.16733v3.summary: Mass-free inference can bypass this challenge, but it requires large suites of simulations spanning a range of cosmologies and models for directly observablequantities. We devise a U-net - an image-to-image machinelearning algorithm - to paint the IllustrisTNG model of baryons onto simulations of galaxy clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12906v1.title: Tracing Dense Gas in Six Resolved GMCs of the Andromeda Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12906v1.summary: We present dense-gas--tracing molecular observations of six resolved Giant Molecular Clouds (GMCs) in the Andromeda Galaxy (M31) Using the NOEMAinterferometer, we observed the transitions of HCN(1-0), HCO$^+$(1 -0), and HNC(1 – 0) and 100 GHz continuum emission. This suggests that the 230 GHz dust continuum and most importantly the HCNEmission traces the dense gas component of these GMCs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.06846v2.title: New dipole instabilities in spherical stellar systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.06846v2.summary: Dipole modes are the precursors to the radial-orbit instability (ROI) The new mode peaks inside thehalf-mass radius but has a pattern speed typical of an outer-halo orbit. Halos that are less extended than NFW, such as the Hernquist model, tend to be stable to this instability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15511v3.title: Massive binary black holes from Population II and III stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15511v3.summary: Population III stars, born from the primordial gas in the Universe, lose anegligible fraction of their mass via stellar winds and possibly follow a top-heavy mass function. They have often been regarded as the idealprogenitors of massive black holes. Here, we evolve a large set of Population III binary stars with our population-synthesis code SEVN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12835v1.title: Initial conditions of star formation at $\lesssim$2000 au: physical structure and NH$_{3}$ depletion of three early-stage cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12835v1.summary: Pre-stellar cores represent a critical evolutionary phase in low-mass starformation. We aim to unveil the detailed thermal structure and density distribution of three early-stage cores. Among the three cores, L429 has the highest central gas density, close to sonic velocity line-width, and largest localised velocity gradient.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12823v1.title: Uncovering a Massive z~7.65 Galaxy Hosting a Heavily Obscured Radio-Loud QSO Candidate in COSMOS-Web
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12823v1.summary: We identify a powerful, radio-loud (RL),growing supermassive black hole (SMBH) with significant spectral steepening of the radio SED. This source represents the furthest known obscured RL QSO candidate, and its level of obscuration aligns with the most representative but observationally scarcepopulation of QSOs at these epochs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12731v1.title: An asteroseismic age estimate of the open cluster NGC 6866 using Kepler and Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12731v1.summary: Asteroseismology of solar-like oscillations in giant stars allow the comprehension of their masses and radii. For members of open clusters this allows an age estimate of the cluster which should be identical to the age estimate from the colour-magnitude diagram, but independent of the uncertainties that are present for that type of analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00576v2.title: Modified Newtonian Dynamics as an Alternative to the Planet Nine Hypothesis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00576v2.summary: A new class of Kuiper belt objects that lie beyond Neptune show orbital anomalies that have been interpreted as evidence for an undiscovered ninth planet. We show that amodified gravity theory known as MOND (Modified Newtonian Dynamics) provides an alternative explanation for the anomalies using the well-established secularparalleapproximation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12699v1.title: Milky Way globular clusters on cosmological timescales. III. Interaction rates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12699v1.summary: The most active globular cluster in the collision sense is Terzan 4, which has 5.65 collision events on average. Most collisions are located inside the Galactic disk and form two ring-like structures. About ten close passages with relative distances shorter than 50 pc for every billion years for each of the five external potentials.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12690v1.title: The comparison of optical variability of broad-line Seyfert 1 and narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxies from the view of Pan-STARRS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12690v1.summary: We investigate the relationship between the variability amplitude and luminosity at 5100 \AA, black hole mass, Eddingtonratio and $ R_{\rm Fe \, II}$ We also analyze the similarities and differences of the variability characteristics between the BLS1 and NLS1 galaxies. No significant correlations are found in our results.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12689v1.title: Optical spectroscopy of Gaia detected protostars with DOT: can we probe protostellar photospheres?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12689v1.summary: Optical spectroscopy offers the most direct view of the stellar properties and accretion indicators. Out of 330 protostars in the HOPS sample, an opticalcounterpart within 2" is detected for 62 of the protostar. Mass accretion rates derived from the spectra are similar to those found for T-Tauri stars. The spectra hint that photospheres can form early on in the starforming process.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02718v2.title: A MUSE view of the massive merging galaxy cluster ACT-CL J0102-4915 (El Gordo) at z = 0.87: robust strong lensing model and data release
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02718v2.summary: We present a detailed strong lensing analysis of the massive and distant galaxy cluster ACT-CL J0102$-$4915 (ACT0102) We take advantage of new spectroscopic data from the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescope, and archival imaging from the Hubble Space Telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13448v3.title: Improvement of graviton mass constraints using GRAVITY's detection of Schwarzschild precession in the orbit of S2 star around the Galactic Center
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13448v3.summary: Study of the stellar orbits around the SMBH at the GC in the framework of Yukawa gravity. Findings consistent with LIGO's estimate of graviton mass from the first GW signal GW150914. Analysis of the orbits of S-stars around the GC represents a tool for constraining the upper bound for the gravitonMass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12565v1.title: AMUSE-antlia I: Nuclear X-ray properties of early-type galaxies in a dynamically young galaxy cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12565v1.summary: Nuclear X-ray sources are detected in 7/84 (8.3%) early-type galaxies (ETG) and 2/8 (25%) late- type galaxies with a median detection limit of 8x10^38 erg/s. More than half of the AGN in Antlia are hosted by a younger subcluster, centered on NGC 3258.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12489v1.title: Kinematics of the Local Spiral Structure Revealed by Young Stars in \emph{Gaia}~DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12489v1.summary: Using young open clusters and O--B2-type stars, we investigate the kinematics of the local spiral structure. In general, the young sources in the outer spiral arms may present larger peculiar motions than those in the inner spiral arms. The sources in both the Perseus and Local Arms may show an inward motion toward the Galactic center and rotate slower than Galactic rotation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.06221v2.title: The unusual 3D distribution of NaCl around the AGB star IK Tau
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.06221v2.summary: NaCl is a diatomic molecule with a large dipole moment, which allows for its detection even at relatively small abundances. It has been detected towards several evolved stars, among which is the AGB star IK Tau. We aim to study the three-dimensional distribution of NaCl around the star. We find clump abundances between $9 \times 10^{-9}$ and $5 \times10^{-8}$ relative to H$_2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12468v1.title: Evolution of low mass population III stars from the pre-main sequence to the white dwarf cooling track
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12468v1.summary: Radiation feedback from massive population III stars may have given rise to low mass star formation from primordial or nearly primordial material. If early low mass stars did form, some should remain locally as white dwarfs,sub-giants, or main sequence stars. One goal of this work is to identify potentialobservable markers for potential observed progenitors of first or nearly first-generation stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12437v1.title: LISA Detectability of a Stochastic Gravitational Wave Background from Unresolved White Dwarf Binaries in the LMC
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12437v1.summary: The Laser Interferometer Space Antenna is expected to detect a wide variety of gravitational wave sources in the mHz band. Some of these signals will elude individual detection, instead contributing as confusion noise to one of several stochastic gravitational-wave backgrounds. We use the Bayesian LISA Inference Package to evaluate the detectability by LISA of an anisotropic SGWBgenerated by unresolved DWDs in the LMC.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12363v1.title: Pre-supernova feedback sets the star cluster mass function to a power law and reduces the cluster formation efficiency
