http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12363v1.summary: The star cluster initial mass function is observed to have an inverse power-law exponent around 2. There is no consensus on what determines this distribution, and why some variation is observed in different galaxies. We test different combinations of stellar feedbackmechanisms, including stellar winds, ionizing radiation, and supernovae. Each mechanism affects the cluster formation efficiency and cluster mass function.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.11721v2.title: Variability Catalog of Stars Observed During the TESS Prime Mission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.11721v2.summary: During its 2-year Prime Mission, TESS observed over 232,000 stars. The data provide a record of photometricvariability across a range of astrophysically interesting time scales. We have identified 46,000 periodic variables with high confidence, and another 38,000 with moderate confidence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12347v1.title: The MeerKAT Absorption Line Survey (MALS) data release I: Stokes I image catalogs at 1-1.4 GHz
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12347v1.summary: The MeerKAT Absorption Line Survey (MALS) has observed 391 telescopepointings at L-band (900 - 1670 MHz) at 1006 MHz (1381 MHz) We presentradio continuum images and a catalog of 495,325 (240,321) radio sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12344v1.title: Evolution of eccentric stellar disks around supermassive black holes: the complex disk disruption dynamics and the milliparsec stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12344v1.summary: We study the 10 Myr evolution of parsec-scale stellar disks. All disks are unstable and evolve on Myrtimescales towards similar eccentricity distributions. For higher disk masses the disk disruptionynamics is more complex than the standard secular eccentric disk instability. None of the simulated models can simultaneously reproduce the kinematic and stellar population properties of the Milky Way center clockwise disk and S-cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12340v1.title: The progenitors of the intra-cluster light and intra-cluster globular clusters in galaxy groups and clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12340v1.summary: We use the IllustrisTNG50 cosmological hydrodynamical simulation to investigate the build-up of two extended luminous components. We select the 39 most massive groups and clusters in the box. The stellar mass of the ICL is only $10%-20% of the stellarmass in the central galaxy but encodes useful information on the assembly history of the group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12342v1.title: The VLT MUSE NFM view of outflows and externally photoevaporating discs near the Orion Bar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12342v1.summary: We present VLT/MUSE Narrow Field Mode (NFM) observations of a pair of young stellar objects towards the Orion Bar: 203-504 and 203-506. Both of these discs are subject to external photoevaporation, where winds are                launched from their outer regions due to environmental irradiation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12330v1.title: Astrometric Weak Lensing with Gaia DR3 and Future Catalogs: Searches for Dark Matter Substructure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12330v1.summary: Small-scale dark matter structures lighter than a billion solar masses are an important probe of primordial density fluctuations and dark mattermicrophysics. We report on results of a search forastrometric weak lensing by compact dark matter subhalos in the Milky Way with Gaia DR3 data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12331v1.title: JWST CEERS & JADES Active Galaxies at z = 4-7 Violate the Local $M_\bullet-M_\star$ Relation at $>3σ$: Implications for Low-Mass Black Holes and Seeding Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12331v1.summary: New detections of high-z systems offerunprecedented insights into the formation of the first black holes and theirearly co-evolution with galaxies. Black holes are overmassive by $10-100\times$ compared to their local counterparts in similar galactic hosts. The lighter black holes preferentially occupy galaxies with a stellar mass of $7.5-10^8.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12283v1.title: Constraining Circumgalactic Turbulence with QSO Absorption-line Measurements
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12283v1.summary: Our knowledge of the circumgalactic medium (CGM) is mostly based on quasarabsorption-line measurements. Here we analyze a suite of CGM simulations to determine how these indirect measures are related to the underlying CGM. Our simulationstrack the non-equilibrium evolution of all commonly observed ions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12278v1.title: Predicting the Yields of $z$ > 6.5 Quasar Surveys in the Era of Roman and Rubin
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12278v1.summary: Around 70 $z>6.5$ luminous quasars have been discovered, strongly biased toward the bright end, thus not providing a comprehensive view on quasar abundance beyond cosmic dawn. We present the predicted results of Roman/Rubin's high-redshift quasar survey, yielding 3 times more, $2-4$ magnitudes deeper.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11060v2.title: Kinematics of the Milky way from the statistical analysis of the Gaia Data Release 3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11060v2.summary: Researchers have obtained precise characteristics of the collective motion of stars in a part of ourgalaxy. We have shown that the various kinematic characteristics can be very welldescribed in the studied region by a simple Monte-Carlo simulation model based on five parameters. The optimal values of these parameters were determined by comparison with the data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10141v2.title: An HI story of galaxies in Abell 2626 and beyond
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10141v2.summary: The HI deficiency of a galaxy is strongly correlated with the projected distance from the centre of A2626. The substructure galaxies tend to be more asymmetric than the isolated galaxies in the cluster. galaxies in all three environments have slightly lower star-formation rates than the typical SFR for normal galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15013v3.title: High-Resolution Chemical Abundances of the Nyx Stream
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15013v3.summary: Nyx is a nearby, prograde, and high-eccentricity stellar stream physicallycontained in the thick disk but with an unknown origin. Nyx could be the result of an early minor dwarf galaxy merger or that it is a record of the early spin-up of the Milky Way disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06811v2.title: Redshift Evolution of the Electron Density in the ISM at $z\sim 0-9$ Uncovered with JWST/NIRSpec Spectra and Line-Spread Function Determinations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06811v2.summary: electron densities of star-forming galaxies at $z=4-9$ are significantly higher than those of low-$z$ galaxies at a given stellar mass, star-formation rate, and specific SFR. These results may suggest that nebuladensities of high-$z’ galaxies are generally high due to the compact morphology of the galaxies. The $p\sim 1-2$ evolutionary relation can be explained by a combination of the compact. morphology and the reduction of $n_{\rm e}$ due. to the high electron temperature of the high-$Z$ metal poor ne

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06762v2.title: QUIJOTE scientific results -- X. Spatial variations of Anomalous Microwave Emission along the Galactic plane
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.06762v2.summary: Anomalous Microwave Emission (AME) is an important emission component between 10 and 60 GHz that is not yet fully understood. We use the new QUIJOTE-MFI wide survey data at 11, 13, 17 and 19 GHz to constrain the AME on degree scales. We find spatial variationsthroughout the Galactic plane for AME, but only with reduced statistical significance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02038v2.title: Measuring the photo-ionization rate, neutral fraction and mean free path of HI ionizing photons at $4.9 \leq z \leq 6.0$ from a large sample of XShooter and ESI spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02038v2.summary: We measure the mean free path, photo-ionization rate and neutral fraction of hydrogen in 12 redshift bins at $4.85<z<6.05$ from a large sample of moderate resolution XShooter and ESI QSO absorption spectra. The simulations show remarkable agreement with simulations performed with the radiative transfer code Aton.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11638v2.title: A population of faint, old, and massive quiescent galaxies at 3 < z < 4 revealed by JWST NIRSpec Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11638v2.summary: Ground-based spectroscopy has suggested ages of 200-300 Myr at redshifts 3<z<4. The true number and ages of these objects have however been highly uncertain. The launch of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) enables more sensitive and constraining spectroscopic observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05104v2.title: Fisher matrix forecasts on the astrophysics of galaxies during the epoch of reionisation from the 21-cm power spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05104v2.summary: The 21-cm transition of neutral hydrogen from the early Universe is a sensitive probe of the formation and evolution of the first galaxies. Using the Fisher matrix formalism we explore the complex anddegenerate high-dimensional parameter space associated with the high-$z$sources of this era and forecast quantitative constraints. We demonstrate that it is possible to recover 5 of the 8 parameters describing these properties with better than $50$ per cent precision.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10900v2.title: Little Red Dots or Brown Dwarfs? NIRSpec Discovery of Three Brown Dwarfs Masquerading as NIRCam-Selected Highly-Reddened AGNs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10900v2.summary: Cold, substellar objects such as brown dwarfs have long been recognized as Contaminants in color-selected samples of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) In the near-infrared filters, brown dwarFS appear much bluer than the highly-reddened AGN, providing an avenue for distinguishing the two.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11803v1.title: GMC Collisions As Triggers of Star Formation. IX. Chemical Evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11803v1.summary: Collisions between giant molecular clouds (GMCs) have been proposed as a Mechanism to trigger massive star and star cluster formation. To investigate the astrochemical signatures of such collisions, we carry out 3Dmagnetohydrodynamics simulations of colliding and non-colliding clouds. In the colliding case, we find clumps have typical densities of $n_{\rm H}\sim10^5$ and temperatures of $K.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11723v1.title: Modeling Dust Production, Growth, and Destruction in Reionization-Era Galaxies with the CROC Simulations II: Predicting the Dust Content of High-Redshift Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11723v1.summary: We model the interstellar dust content of the reionization era with a suite of cosmological, fluid-dynamical simulations. We find that we are unable to simultaneously match existing observational constraints with any one set of model parameters. Our results indicate that theobservable properties of the dust distribution in high redshift galaxies are aparticularly strong test of stellar feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10783v2.title: The SN 2023ixf Progenitor in M101: I. Infrared Variability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10783v2.summary: Observational evidence points to a red supergiant (RSG) progenitor for SN2023ixf. This object isinctly variable in the infrared (IR) We characterize the variability using Spitzer and ground-based near-IR archival data. We use a period-luminosity relation for RSGs to derive a value of M_K.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11717v1.title: On the Lifetime of Molecular Clouds with the "Tuning-Fork" Analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11717v1.summary: The "tuning-fork" analysis of CO and Halpha emission has been used to estimate the lifetimes of molecular clouds in nearby galaxies. We show that this analysis does not necessarily estimate cloud lifetimes, but instead captures a duration of the cloud evolutionarycycle. We adopt a hypothetical setup in which molecular clouds (e.g., traced in CO) live forever and form stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11712v1.title: The internal Faraday screen of Sagittarius A*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11712v1.summary: We report on 85-101 GHz light curves of the Galactic Center supermassive black hole, Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*), observed in April 2017 with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. We obtain time-dependent rotation measure (RM) measurements, with the mean RM at 85- 101 GHz being a factor of two lower than that at 212-230GHz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11709v1.title: Investigating the characteristic shape and scatter of intergalactic damping wings during reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11709v1.summary: Damping wings in the spectra of bright objects at high redshift are a useful probe of the ionization state of the intergalactic medium during the reionization epoch. The characteristic shape andscatter of the damping wings are determined by the average neutral hydrogen density along the line of sight, weighted by its contribution to the optical depth.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11618v1.title: The Panchromatic Hubble Andromeda Treasury: Triangulum Extended Region (PHATTER). V. The Structure of M33 in Resolved Stellar Populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11618v1.summary: We present a detailed analysis of the the structure of the Local Group                flocculent spiral galaxy M33. We find that the oldest populations aredominated by a smooth exponential disk with two distinct spiral arms. The two spiral arms are asymmetric in orientation and strength, and likely represent the innermost impact of the recent tidal interactions responsible for M33's warp.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12107v1.title: UNCOVER: JWST Spectroscopy of Three Cold Brown Dwarfs at Kiloparsec-scale Distances
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12107v1.summary: We report JWST/NIRSpec spectra of three distant T-type brown dwarfs. One source was previously reported as a candidate T dwarf on the basis of NIRCam photometry. The spectrum of the warmest source, UNCOVER-BD-1, shows evidence of subsolar metallicity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05333v3.title: Shocks Power Tidal Disruption Events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05333v3.summary: Accretion of debris seems to be the natural mechanism to power the radiation emitted during a tidal disruption event (TDE) However, this requires the prompt formation of acompact accretion disk. At most a tiny fraction of the bound mass enters such a disk on the timescale of observed flares.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11499v1.title: Constraining the assembly time of the stellar haloes of nearby Milky Way-mass galaxies through AGB populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11499v1.summary: Star formation histories (SFHs) of galactic stellar haloes offer crucial insights into the merger history of the galaxy. While the Milky Way's mostimportant merger was 8-10 Gyr ago, M31's largest merger was more recent, within the last few Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11496v1.title: Ultra diffuse galaxies in the Hydra I cluster from the LEWIS Project: Phase-Space distribution and globular cluster richness
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11496v1.summary: Ultra diffuse galaxies (UDGs) are found in large numbers in clusters of galaxies. The role of the cluster environment in shaping their low surface brightness and large sizes is still uncertain. Here we examine a sample of UDGsin the Hydra I cluster (D = 51 Mpc) with new radial velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11493v1.title: Looking into the faintEst WIth MUSE (LEWIS): on the nature of ultra-diffuse galaxies in the Hydra-I cluster.I. Project description and preliminary results
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11493v1.summary: MUSE is an ESO large observingprogramme aimed at obtaining the first homogeneous integral-field spectroscopicsurvey of 30 extremely low-surface brightness (LSB) galaxies. The majority of LSB galaxies in the sample (22 in total) are ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) The distribution of velocities Vsys ranges between 2317 km/s and 5198km/s.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11398v1.title: Interior solution of azimuthally symmetric case of Laplace equation in orthogonal similar oblate spheroidal coordinates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11398v1.summary: Curvilinear coordinate systems are particularly valuable in the field calculations. The solution of the azimuthally symmetric case of the Laplace equation was found for the interior space in the orthogonal SOS coordinates. Recursion formula facilitatingdetermination of the higher-degree harmonic functions was found.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11392v1.title: Rest-Frame Near-Infrared Radial Light Profiles up to z=3 from JWST/NIRCam: Wavelength Dependence of the Sérsic Index
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11392v1.summary: We examine the wavelength dependence of radial light profiles based on measurements of 1067 galaxies. Star-forming galaxies have $n = 1-1.5$ in rest-frame optical and near-infrared. The strong correlation at all wavelengths between $n$ and star-formation activity implies a physical connection between the radial stellar mass profile and star formation activity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11391v1.title: Probing magnetic fields in the circumgalactic medium using polarization data from MIGHTEE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11391v1.summary: magnetic fields are tracer for dynamical processes in the circumgalactic medium (CGM) Faraday rotation measure (RM) of background radio sources passing through the magnetized CGM of intervening galaxies can be used as a tracer. We conclude that mostly. star-forming galaxies with impact parameters less than 130 kpc contribute to the RM of the background. radio source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13672v3.title: Central radio galaxies in galaxy clusters: Joint surveys by eROSITA and ASKAP
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13672v3.summary: The extended ROentgen Survey with an Imaging Telescope Array (eROSITA) and the Spectrum-Roentgen-Gamma (SRG) mission are used to study Active Galactic Nuclei in clusters. In order to understand theefficiency of radio-mode feedback at the centers of galaxy clusters, we relate the radio properties of brightest cluster galaxies to the X-ray properties of the host clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11372v1.title: The population of Galactic supernova remnants in the TeV range
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11372v1.summary: SNRs are likely to be significant sources of Galactic cosmic rays. They produce gamma rays in the very-high-energy (E>100 GeV) range mainly via two mechanisms: hadronic interactions of accelerated protons with the interstellar medium and leptonic interactions with photons. Observations with current instruments have lead to the detection of about a dozen SNRs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04721v2.title: SN 2023ixf in Messier 101: Photo-ionization of Dense, Close-in Circumstellar Material in a Nearby Type II Supernova
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04721v2.summary: We present UV/optical observations and models of supernova (SN) 2023ixf, a type II SN located in Messier 101 at 6.9 Mpc. Early-time ("flash") spectroscopy reveals emission lines with a narrow core and broad, symmetricwings arising from the photo-ionization of dense, close-in circumstellar material.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11094v1.title: WKB approximation to boson dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11094v1.summary: Galactic dark matter halos may be composed of ultralight axions (ULAs) with wave functions that satisfy nonlinearSchr\"{o}dinger-Poisson equations (SPA) We find eigenstates of SPA in WKBapproximation. Future plans include investigations of collapse through timedependent generalizations, and inclusion of self-interactions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11059v1.title: Radial Distribution of Distant Trans-Neptunian Objects Points to Sun's Formation in a Stellar Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11059v1.summary: Scattered Disk Objects (SDOs) are a population of trans-Neptunian bodies with orbits beyond the reach of Neptune. The semimajor axis profile of SDOs at 50--500~au, as characterized from the Dark Energy Survey, is radially extended. This problem is most likelyrelated to Sun's birth environment in a stellar cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19312v2.title: Reversing the verdict: Cataclysmic variables could be the dominant progenitors of AM CVn binaries after all
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19312v2.summary: AM CVn binaries are potential progenitors of thermonuclear supernovae and strong sources of persistent gravitational wave radiation. For a long time, it has been believed that these systems cannot descend from large numbers. We show that both claimed weaknesses of the CV formation channel are model-dependent and rely on poorly constrained assumptions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11023v1.title: Statistical Prediction of [CII] Observations by Constructing Probability Density Functions using SOFIA, Herschel, and Spitzer Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11023v1.summary: The [CII] emission at 158$\mu$m is a critical tracer in studying the life cycle of interstellar medium and galaxy evolution. Its frequency is in the far infrared, which is opaque through the troposphere and cannot be observed from the ground except for highly red-shifted sources. We present a statistical algorithm for predicting the [C II] emission from Herschel and Spitzer continuum images.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11007v1.title: Mitigating Bias in Deep Learning: Training Unbiased Models on Biased Data for the Morphological Classification of Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11007v1.summary: Most galaxy morphology catalogs have been labelled by human annotators or by machine learning models trained on human labelled data. Human generated labels have been shown to contain biases in observational properties of the data, such as image resolution. These biases are independent of the annotators, that is, are present even in galaxy catalogs labelled by experts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10992v1.title: The Baryonic Content of Galaxies Mapped by MaNGA and the Gas Around Them
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10992v1.summary: We analyze the cool gas in and around 14 nearby galaxies (at $z$$<$0.1) with the SDSS-IV MaNGA survey. Galaxies with higher stellar mass have weaker H I absorption. We find that the neutral gas seen in absorption lines co-rotates with the disk out to $R_{e}$. Sight lines with lower.elevation angles show lower metallicities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10980v1.title: r-process Abundance Patterns in the Globular Cluster M92
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10980v1.summary: The literature contains evidence both for and against a neutron-capture dispersion in M92. Unlike M15, the dispersion is limited to "first-generation" (low Na, high Mg) stars. We propose that a source of heavier r-process polluted the cluster shortly before or concurrently with the first generation of star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.20016v2.title: Detecting and Characterizing Mg II absorption in DESI Survey Validation Quasar Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.20016v2.summary: We present findings of the detection of Magnesium II (Mg II) absorbers from the early data release of the Dark EnergySpectroscopic Instrument (DESI) DESI is projected to obtain spectroscopy of approximately 3 million quasars (QSOs) of which over 99% are anticipated to be at redshifts greater than z > 0.3.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10963v1.title: The Large Magellanic Cloud's $\sim30$ Kiloparsec Bow Shock and its Impact on the Circumgalactic Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10963v1.summary: The interaction between the supersonic motion of the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) and the Circumgalactic Medium (CGM) is expected to result in a bow shock. Over the past 500 Myr, the MW's CGM in the southern hemisphere should have interacted with the shock front. This interaction may have had the effect of smoothing over inhomogeneities and increasing mixing in the CGM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10948v1.title: Looking for a needle in a haystack : how to measure the length of a stellar bar?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10948v1.summary: One of the challenges related to stellar bars is to determine accurately theiablylength of the bar in a disc galaxy. In past literature, a wide variety of methods has been employed to measure the extent of a bar. Here, we investigate the accuracy and the correlation (if any) between different bar length measurement methods.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10944v1.title: Towards an astronomical foundation model for stars with a Transformer-based model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10944v1.summary: A Transformer-based model can perform both discriminative and generative tasks. The model can also generate XP spectra from stellar parameters, inpaint unobserved spectral regions, extract empirical stellar loci, and determine interstellar extinction curve. Such "Large Astronomy Models" trained on largequantities of observational data will play a large role in the analysis of current and future large surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10941v1.title: Stellar Wind Yields of Very Massive Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10941v1.summary: The most massive stars provide an essential source of recycled material for young clusters and galaxies. While very massive stars (VMS, M>100M) are relatively rare compared to O stars, they lose disproportionately large amounts of mass already from the onset of core H-burning. VMS with enhanced winds eject 5-10 times more H-processed elements (N, Ne, Na, Al) on the main sequence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10943v1.title: VERTICO VII: Environmental quenching caused by suppression of molecular gas content and star formation efficiency in Virgo Cluster galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10943v1.summary: We study how environment regulates the star formation cycle of 33 Virgo Cluster satellite galaxies on 720 parsec scales. We demonstrate that the observed quenching in HI-poor galaxies is caused by environmental processes such as ram pressurestripping. We quantify how RPS and starvationaffect the starformation cycle of inner and outer galaxy discs as they areprocessed by the cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10927v1.title: HST UV Spectroscopy of the Dwarf Starburst Galaxy Pox 186
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10927v1.summary: Low-mass galaxies are thought to play a dominant role in reionization. Pox 186 is one such system with physical conditions that are representative of a starburst galaxy. The C/O relative abundance is consistent with other low-metallicity dwarf galaxies and suggests a comparable star formation history in these systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10932v1.title: COSMOS-Web: Intrinsically Luminous z$\gtrsim$10 Galaxy Candidates Test Early Stellar Mass Assembly
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10932v1.summary: 15 exceptionally luminous galaxies discovered in the first 0.28 deg$^2 of JWST/NIRCam imaging. These sources span rest-frame UV magnitudes of $20.5-22.5. The assembly of such stellar reservoirs is made possible due to rapid, burst-driven star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10894v1.title: Dynamics of supermassive black hole triples in the ROMULUS25 cosmological simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10894v1.summary: Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in the remnant of a dualgalaxy merger. We track the orbital evolution from the galactic inspiral to the formation of hard binaries at sub-parsec separation. The coalescence times of the lighter black holes are significantly longer than for the heavier binary.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10884v1.title: Binary black hole mergers in nuclear star clusters: eccentricities, spins, masses, and the growth of massive seeds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10884v1.summary: We investigate the formation of intermediate mass black holes (IMBHs) through hierarchical mergers of stellar origin black holes. BH mergers areformed dynamically in nuclear star clusters. Metal-rich, young, dense clusters can produce up to $20\%$ of their DBH merger with eccentricity at $10\,\rm Hz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10880v1.title: Detailed study of the Bootes field using 300-500 MHz uGMRT observations: Source Properties and radio--infrared correlations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10880v1.summary: The dominant source of radio continuum emissions at low frequencies issynchrotron radiation. It originates from star-forming regions in disk galaxies and from powerful jets produced by active galactic nuclei (AGN) We studied the Bootes field using the upgraded Giant Meterwave Radio Telescope at 400 MHz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18174v2.title: First Light And Reionisation Epoch Simulations (FLARES) XIII: The Lyman-continuum emission of high-redshift galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18174v2.summary: The history of reionisation is highly dependent on the ionising properties of high-redshift galaxies. We use the First Light and ReionisationEpoch Simulations (FLARES) to study the Lyman-continuum (LyC) We find that the specific ionising emissivity (i.e.intrinsic ionisingEmissivity per unit stellar mass) decreases as stellar mass increases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12153v1.title: Deep optical imaging of star-forming blue early-type galaxies: Color map structures and faint features indicative of recent mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12153v1.summary: Blue early-type galaxies with galaxy-scale ongoing star formation areinteresting targets in order to understand the stellar mass buildup in the local Universe. Low surface brightness features found around galaxies could be remnants of recent merger events. The star-forming population of blue early- type galaxies is a stage in the evolution of early-types.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09403v2.title: Breaking degeneracies in the first galaxies with clustering
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09403v2.summary: UVLF has become essential for understanding the formation and evolution of the first galaxies. Yet, UVLFs only measure galaxy abundances, giving rise to a degeneracy between the meangalaxy luminosity and its stochasticity. New clustering measurements with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) and Roman, will be able to break this degeneracy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10732v1.title: A Search for Gas-Rich Dwarf Galaxies in the Local Universe with ALFALFA and the WIYN One Degree Imager
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10732v1.summary: We present results from an optical search for Local Group dwarf galaxy candidates associated with the Ultra-Compact High Velocity Clouds. The ALFALFA UCHVCs areisolated, compact HI clouds with projected sizes, velocities, and estimated HIestinalmasses that suggest they may be nearby dwarf galaxies. We identify one promising dwarf galaxy candidate, and five other candidates that may deserve additional follow-up.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10726v1.title: The molecular clouds in a section of the third Galactic quadrant: observational properties and chemical abundance ratio between CO and its isotopologues
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10726v1.summary: We compare the observational properties between $^{12}$CO, $^{13}$ CO, and C$^{18}$O. We find that the abundance ratios stay the same across the molecular cloud scale with lower flux ratio. The abundanceratio inside clouds shows a strong correlation with column density and temperature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07540v3.title: First Light And Reionisation Epoch Simulations (FLARES) VIII. The Emergence of Passive Galaxies at $z \geqslant 5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07540v3.summary: Passive galaxies are ubiquitous in the local universe, and various physicalchannels have been proposed that lead to this passivity. To date, robustipient galaxy candidates have been detected up to $z \leqslant 5$, but it is still unknown if they exist at higher redshifts. We present predictions from the First Light And Reionisation Epoch Simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10575v1.title: Photometry and astrometry with JWST -- III. A NIRCam-Gaia DR3 analysis of the open cluster NGC 2506
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10575v1.summary: This is the third paper in a series aimed at developing tools for analysing stellar populations using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) We present a detailed multi-band study of the 2 Gyr Galacticopen cluster NGC 2506. We employ public calibration data-sets collected in multiple filters to: (i) derive improved effective Point Spread Functions for ten NIRCam filters; (ii) extract high-precision photometry andastrometry for stars in the cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09027v2.title: JWST observations of the Ring Nebula (NGC 6720): I. Imaging of the rings, globules, and arcs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09027v2.summary: JWST images of the well-known planetary nebula NGC 6720. The shell is strongly fragmented with some 20 000 dense globules. The central cavity is shown to be filled with high ionization gas. Linear features (`spikes') extend outward from the ring, pointing away from the central star.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10519v1.title: Preliminary Exploration of Areal Density of Angular Momentum for Spiral Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10519v1.summary: The specific angular momenta ($j_t$) of stars, baryons as a whole and dark matter haloes contain clues of vital importance about how galaxies form and evolve. The percentage of spiral galaxies having jet(s) shows strong correlation with the ADAM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10484v1.title: Distributions and Physical Properties of Molecular Clouds in the Third Galactic Quadrant: $l$ = [219.75, 229.75]$^\circ$ and $b$ = [-5.25, 5.25]$^\circ$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10484v1.summary: We present the results of an unbiased $^{12}$CO/$^{13]$CO/C$^{18}$O ($J$ =1-0) survey in a portion of the third Galactic quadrant (TGQ): $l$ = [219.75,229.75]$^\circ$ and $b$ = [-5.25, 5.25]$ ^\circ$. The high-resolution and high-sensitivity data sets help to unravel the distributions and physicalproperties of the molecular clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09626v2.title: Milliarcsecond Core Size Dependence of the Radio Variability of Blazars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09626v2.summary: Study focuses on the radio variability of 1157 blazars at 15 GHz. Most compact sources at milliarcsecond scales exhibit larger variability amplitudes and shorter variability timescales than more extended sources. correlation between linear core sizes and intrinsic timescale is also significant. At 1 GHz, core sizes are dominated by interstellar scattering.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10391v1.title: How much large dust could be present in hot exozodiacal dust systems?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10391v1.summary: Large dust grains might have a more important impact on the observational appearance of HEZD than previously assumed, especially at millimeter wavelengths. In the most extreme cases of some of the investigated systems, large grains might dominate the mass budget of HEzD while contributing up to 25$\,$% of the total flux density originating from the dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10356v1.title: Comparing measurements and limits on the warm dark matter temperature-to-mass ratio
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10356v1.summary: Limits on the "thermal relic" warm dark matter mass are apparentlyinconsistent with measurements of the warm dark Matter temperature-to-massratio. We try to understand this problem. We also try to find out why dark matter is thought to be so small.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.03968v2.title: Do minor interactions trigger star formation in galaxy pairs?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.03968v2.summary: We analyze the galaxy pairs in a set of volume limited samples from the SDSS to study the effects of minor interactions on the star formation rate (SFR) andcolour of galaxies. We find that the majority of theminor pairs are quiescent systems that could be quenched due to minor interactions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10318v1.title: Dynamical binaries in star clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10318v1.summary: Clusters on average have only one dynamically-assembled Carbunclebinary at any given time. This is different from theoretical expectations andmodels of binary populations. We argue that the presence of multiple Carbunclebinaries is suppressed by a high rate of binary-binary interactions. These also lead to tripleformation and potentially gravitational wave (GW) captures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10286v1.title: What can be learnt from a highly informative X-ray occultation event in NGC 6814? A marvellous absorber
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10286v1.summary: A unique X-ray occultation event in NGC 6814 during an XMM-Newton observation in 2016 has been reported. We revisit the event with the aid of the hardness ratio (HR) - count                rate (CR) plot and comparison with two other absorption-free XMM exposures in 2009 and 2021. We show that the eclipsing absorber shall be clumpy (instead of a single Compton-thin cloud), with an inner denser region composed of both Compton- thin and Compton-thick clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10254v1.title: Unveiling the Dynamics of Dense Cores in Cluster-Forming Clumps: A 3D MHD Simulation Study of Angular Momentum and Magnetic Field Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10254v1.summary: We conducted isothermal MHD simulations with self-gravity to investigate theproperties of dense cores in cluster-forming clumps. We focused on determining the extent to which the formed dense cores inherit the rotation and magnetic field of the parental clump. In single rotating clumps, we found that the magnetic field globally bends along the shock-compressed layer of the clump and aligns with it. We also found a higher proportion of unbound cores in collidingclumps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10211v1.title: Chemical evolution of some selected complex organic molecules in low-mass star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10211v1.summary: The destiny of complex organic molecules (COMs) in star-forming regions is intertwined with various evolutionary phases. We identified multiple COMs utilizing the Large Program `Astrochemical Surveys At IRAM' (ASAI) data. We found that the abundance of all of the COMs, except for HCCCHO, increased from the L1544 (prestellar core) and peaks at IRAS16293-2422 (class 0phase)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10200v1.title: Broadband multi-wavelength study of LHAASO detected AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10200v1.summary: Large High Altitude Air Shower Observatory (LHAASO) presents the first catalog of $gamma$-ray sources. This catalog contains fiveactive galactic nuclei (AGNs), of which four are blazars and one is aliner-type AGN. We establish averaged multi-wavelength SEDs by combining data from $Fermi$-Large Area Telescope, $Swift$, $ZTF$, and $WISE$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10118v1.title: Titans metal-poor reference stars II. Red giants and CEMP stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10118v1.summary: We find that the ionization equilibrium of Felines under LTE is not valid in metal-poor giants. We add 47 giants to the sample of metal- Poor dwarfs of Giribaldi et al. 2021, constituting the Titans metal- poor reference stars. We achieve precision of $T$50~K for 34 stars with spectra with the highest S/N.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04230v3.title: Mass Dependence of Galaxy-Halo Alignment in LOWZ and CMASS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04230v3.summary: We measure the galaxy-ellipticity (GI) correlations for the Slogan DigitalSky Survey DR12 LOWZ and CMASS samples. We find that the alignment of central galaxies with their host halos increases monotonically with galaxy stellar mass or host halo mass. These results have important implications for intrinsic alignment (IA) correction in weak lensing studies and theory of massive galaxy formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10071v1.title: Powerful Radio Sources in the Southern Sky. I. Optical Identifications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10071v1.summary: New catalog of powerful radio sources visible from the Southern Hemisphere. Based on the GLEAM 4-Jy (G4Jy) catalog and based on the same selection criteria as the 3CR. List of 264 sources at declines below -5 degrees and with 9 Jy limiting sensitivity at ~178 MHz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09867v1.title: AT2018dyk Revisited: a Tidal Disruption Event Candidate with Prominent Infrared Echo and Delayed X-ray Emission in a LINER Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09867v1.summary: Nuclear transient AT2018dyk, initially discovered as a changing-look low-ionization nuclear emission-line region (LINER) galaxy, has been revisited by us. The X-ray spectra are softer than normal active galactic nuclei (AGNs) although they show a slight trend of hardening.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09838v1.title: Scalar-tensor-vector-gravity and NGC-1277
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09838v1.summary: NGC1277 is a compact but massive lenticular galaxy that shows no signs of the presence of dark matter. The compact size of the galaxy, in combination with its large mass, ensures that there are no observable deviations between the predictions of Newtonian and MOG velocities within the galaxy's visible radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09762v1.title: Periodic changes in the morphology of the Galactic resonance rings
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09762v1.summary: We study the periodic enhancement of either trailing or leading segments of the resonance elliptical rings in the dynamical model of the Galaxy. The model disc forms a nuclear ring, aninner combined ring and outer resonance rings R1 and R2. We have found the changes of the morphology of the inner ring with a period of P=0.57+.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09760v1.title: The compactness of ultra faint dwarf galaxies : a new challenge ?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09760v1.summary: Numerical simulations of ultra-faint dwarf galaxies (UFDs) have failed to reproduce the observed size-luminosity relation. We have developed a simple but numerically clean and powerful method in which predictions of thestellar content of UFDs from LCDM cosmological hydro-dynamical-simulations is combined with very high resolution dark matter only runs. This method allows totrace the build-up history of U FDs and determine the impact of the merger of objects on their final size.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09750v1.title: CEERS Key Paper VII: JWST/MIRI Reveals a Faint Population of Galaxies at Cosmic Noon Unseen by Spitzer
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09750v1.summary: The Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) on the James WebbSpace Telescope (JWST) in 2022. We find that a significantportion of MIRI galaxies are "mid-IR weak" -- they have strong near-IR emission and relatively weaker mid- IR emission. Most of the star formation is unobscured. We present new IR templates that capture how the mid-IR to near- IRemission changes with increasing infrared luminosity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09749v1.title: Near-Infrared Flux Distribution of Sgr A* from 2005-2022: Evidence for an Enhanced Accretion Episode in 2019
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09749v1.summary: Sgr A* is the variable electromagnetic source associated with accretion onto the Galactic center supermassive black hole. Since 2019, we have observed a maximum $K_s$ (2.2 $\mu$m) flux of 0.9 mJy, compared to the highest pre-2019 flux of 2.0 mJY and highest 2019 flux of 5.6mJy. Our results suggest that the temporary accretion increase onto Sgr A*, possibly due to delayed accretion of tidally-stripped gas from the gaseousobject G2 in 2014.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09742v1.title: Ionised gas kinematics and dynamical masses of $z\gtrsim6$ galaxies from JADES/NIRSpec high-resolution spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09742v1.summary: We explore the kinematic gas properties of six galaxies in the JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey. The objects are small and of low stellar mass, less massive than any galaxy studied kinematically at $z>1$ thus far. We find that their ionised gas is spatially resolved by JW ST, with evidence for broadened lines and spatial velocity gradients.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00756v2.title: Supermassive Primordial Black Holes From Inflation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00756v2.summary: There is controversy surrounding the origin and evolution of our universe's largest supermassive black holes (SMBHs) In this study, we consider the possibility that some of these black holes formed from the direct collapse ofprimordial density perturbations. We present a model of multi-field inflation which can viably yield such dramatic non-Gaussinities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09665v1.title: EPOCHS IX. When cosmic dawn breaks: Evidence for evolved stellar populations in $7 < z < 12$ galaxies from PEARLS GTO and public NIRCam imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09665v1.summary: The presence of evolved stars in high-redshift galaxies can place valuableipientindirect constraints on the onset of star formation in the Universe. We find that our Balmerbreak candidates at $z \sim 10.5$ tend to be older (115 Myr) and have lower specific star formation rates (6 Gyr$^{-1}$) than our control sample of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09657v1.title: A deep learning approach for the 3D reconstruction of dust density and temperature in star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09657v1.summary: A new deep learning approach for the reconstruction of 3Ddust density and temperature distributions from multi-wavelength dust emission Observations on the scale of individual star-forming cloud cores. We train a conditional invertible neural network (cINN) for this purpose. We test different cINN setups, ranging from a scenario thatincludes all 23 wavelengths down to a more realistically limited case with only seven wavelengths.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09615v1.title: The face-on projection of the Miyamoto & Nagai disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09615v1.summary: The face-on density profile of the Miyamoto & Nagai disks of                arbitrary flattening is obtained analytically in terms of incomplete ellipticintegrals of first and second type, by using two complementary approaches. The correct identities in the Byrd & Friedman tables of elliptic integrals have been identified, and their correct expression is given.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09608v1.title: Statistical association between the candidate repeating FRB 20200320A and a galaxy group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09608v1.summary: We present results from angular cross-correlations between select samples of CHIME/FRB repeaters and galaxies in three photometric galaxy surveys. We find a statistically significant correlation ($p$-value $<0.001$ after accounting for other factors) between a sample of repeaters with extragalactic DM $>395$ pc cm$^{-3}$ and WISE$\times$SCOS galaxies with redshift $z>0.275.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07761v2.title: UV signatures of magnetar formation and their crucial role for Gravitational Wave detection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07761v2.summary: The emission from shock breakouts (SBOs) represents the earliest.electromagnetic (EM) signal emitted by cataclysmic events. SBOs carry uniqueinformation on the structure of their progenitors and on the explosion energy. Fast spinning magnetars are expected to produce a specific signature in the early UV supernova light curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09584v1.title: Parsec scales of carbon chain and complex organic molecules in AFGL 2591 and IRAS 20126
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09584v1.summary: Warm carbon chain sources are the warm and dense regions near a protostar containing unsaturated carbon chain molecules. We have conducted targeted spectral surveys of two sources in the direction of Cygnus X -- AFGL 2591 and IRAS 20126+4104 -- with the Green Bank Telescope and the IRAM 30m Telescope. We detect several lines of propyne, CH$_3$CCH, as tracer of carbon chain chemistry.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02898v2.title: The JWST view of the barred galaxy population in the SMACS0723 galaxy cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02898v2.summary: The cosmic evolution of the barred galaxy population provides key information about the secular evolution of galaxies and the settling of rotationallydominated discs. We study the bar fraction in the SMACSJ0723.37323 (SMACS0723) cluster of galaxies at z = 0.39 using the NIRCam instrument mounted on the JWST telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.08540v2.title: First spectroscopic observations of the galaxies that reionized the Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.08540v2.summary: Low-mass galaxies in the early universe are believed to be the buildingblocks of present-day galaxies. These fledgling systems likely played a pivotal role in cosmic reionization, a major phase transition from neutral Hydrogen to ionized plasma. These galaxies have eluded comprehensive spectroscopic studies owing to their extreme                faintness.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.09745v2.title: Periodic interstellar scintillation variations of PSRs~J0613$-$0200 and J0636+5128 associated with the Local Bubble shell
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.09745v2.summary: PSRs~J0613$-$0200 and J0636+5128 show strong annual variations in their scintillation velocity. The former additionally exhibits an orbitalfluctuation. Bayesian theory and Markov-chain-Monte-Carlo methods are used to interpret these periodic variations. The positions of these scattering screens are coincident with the shell of the Local Bubble.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16912v1.title: Karhunen-Loève Data Imputation in High Contrast Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16912v1.summary: The Karhunen-Lo\`eve transform (DIKL) is a data-imputation concept for high contrast imaging. DIKL achieves high-quality results with significantly reduced computational cost. It is seamlesslyintegrable into high contrast Imaging pipelines for RDI observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16895v1.title: MIDIS: JWST/MIRI reveals the Stellar Structure of ALMA-selected Galaxies in the Hubble-UDF at Cosmic Noon
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16895v1.summary: James Webb Space Telescope (JWST)/MIRI F560W observations of flux-limited, ALMA-selected sample of 28 galaxies at z=0.5-3.6 in the HubbleUltra Deep Field (HUDF) The data from the MIRI Deep Imaging Survey (MIDIS) reveal the stellar structure of the HUDF galaxies at rest-wavelengths of >1 micron for the first time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16883v1.title: Unravelling multi-temperature dust populations in the dwarf galaxy Holmberg II
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16883v1.summary: Holmberg II - a dwarf galaxy in the nearby M81 group - is a very informative source of distribution of gas and dust in the interstellar discs. High-resolution observations in the infrared (IR) allows us to distinguishisolated star-forming regions, photodissociation (PDR) and HII regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16872v1.title: Constraining the geometry of the reflection nebula NGC 2023 with [O I]: Emission & Absorption
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16872v1.summary: We have mapped the NGC 2023 reflection nebula in the 63 and 145 microntransitions of [O I] and the 158 micron [C II] spectral lines. The observations were used to identify the diffuse and dense components of the PDR. The velocity-resolved observations reveal the presence of a significant column of low-excitation atomic oxygen.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.11821v2.title: Polarimetry and Astrometry of NIR Flares as Event Horizon Scale, Dynamical Probes for the Mass of Sgr A*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.11821v2.summary: We present new astrometric and polarimetric observations of flares from SgrA* obtained with GRAVITY, the near-infrared interferometer at ESO's Very LargeTelescope Interferometer. Given the apparent similarities of the flares, we present a common fit, taking into account the absence of strong Doppler boosting peaks in the light curves.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16780v1.title: VLBI Observations of a sample of Palomar-Green quasars II: characterising the parsec-scale radio emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16780v1.summary: The study uses multi-frequency Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) to study the radio emission from 10 radio-quiet quasars (RQQs) and four radio-loudquasars. Unlike RLQs, where the parsec-scale radio emission is dominated.by a relativistically boosted core, the radio cores of RQQS are either not.dominant or are mixed with significant jet emission. Future high-resolution observations could help to determine the fraction of different emission sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16768v1.title: On the accretion of a new group of galaxies onto Virgo: III. The stellar population radial gradients of dEs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16768v1.summary: Using MUSE data, we investigate the radial gradients of stellar population.properties (namely age, [M/H], and the abundance ratio of. $\alpha$ elements[$\alpha$/Fe) for a sample of nine dwarf early-type (dE) galaxies. We find that these nine dE galaxies have truncated[Mg/Fe]vs..[Fe/H] profiles than equally-massive Virgo dE. galaxies with longer past infall times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17045v3.title: Strong Outflows and Inefficient Star Formation in the Reionization-era Ultra-faint Dwarf Galaxy Eridanus II
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17045v3.summary: We present novel constraints on the underlying galaxy formation physics at the Local Group. We find that the evolution of Eri II is well-characterized by a short, exponentially declining star-formation history. We make predictions for the distribution of [Mg/Fe] and [Fe/H] in Ei II as well as the prevalence of ultra-metal-poor stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16733v1.title: PDRs4All IV. An embarrassment of riches: Aromatic infrared bands in the Orion Bar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16733v1.summary: Mid-infrared observations of photodissociation regions (PDRs) aredominated by strong emission features called aromatic infrared bands (AIBs) The most prominent AIBs are found at 3.3, 6.2, 7.7, 8.6, 11.2 and 12.7. We report trends in the widths and relativestrengths of AIBs across the five template spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16732v1.title: PDRs4All II: JWST's NIR and MIR imaging view of the Orion Nebula
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16732v1.summary: The JWST has captured the most detailed and sharpest infrared images ever taken of the inner region of the Orion Nebula. We investigate the fundamental interaction of far-ultravioletphotons with molecular clouds. These transitions are relevant to understanding theeffects of radiative feedback from massive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16691v1.title: Prospects for observing supermassive black hole binaries with the space-ground interferometer
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16691v1.summary: An artificial neural network is constructed to estimate the radiation flux at 240~GHz. The result is presented as a table of 17 candidate SMBBHs. Confirmation (or refutation) of the duality of these objects will be an important milestone in the development of the theory of galaxy formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16663v1.title: The Orion-Taurus ridge: a synchrotron radio loop at the edge of the Orion-Eridanus superbubble
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16663v1.summary: Large-scale synchrotron loops are recognized as the main source of diffuse radio-continuum emission in the Galaxy. Their origin, however, remains rather unexplained. We traced the Orion-Taurus ridge using 3D maps of dust extinction and column-density maps of molecular gas. We found a flat distribution of $\beta$ with a median value of $-2.24^{+0.03]/.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16656v1.title: 21cm signal sensitivity to dark matter decay
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16656v1.summary: Redshifted 21cm signal from the Cosmic Dawn is expected to provide unprecedented insights into early Universe astrophysics and cosmology. We provide the first dedicated Fisher matrix forecasts on the sensitivity of the HydrogenEpoch of Reionization Array (HERA) telescope to dark matter decays.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13574v2.title: Quiescent low-mass galaxies observed by JWST in the Epoch of Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13574v2.summary: JWST discovery of a quiescent, low-mass galaxy at redshift $z=7.3$ (JADES-GS-z7-01-QU) represents a uniqueopportunity to study the imprint of feedback processes on early galaxyevolution. We build a sample of 130 low- mass galaxies from the SERRA cosmological zoom-in simulations, which show a feedback-regulated star formation history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16620v1.title: GA-NIFS: JWST/NIRSpec IFU observations of HFLS3 reveal a dense galaxy group at z~6.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16620v1.summary: HFLS3 was originally identified as an extreme starburst galaxy with mild gravitational magnification. The 3"x3" field is crowded, with a lensed arc, two galaxies to the south and two low-redshift interlopers. The projected distances andocity offsets of each galaxy suggest that they will merge within the next 1Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16605v1.title: Influence of star-forming galaxy selection on the galaxy main sequence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16605v1.summary: This work aims to determine how the galaxy main sequence (MS) changes using seven different commonly used methods to select the star-forming galaxies. The form and redshift evolution of the MS will then be compared between selection methods. The slopes of all star-formation samples were found to either remain constant or increase with redshift. There is no clear redshift dependency of the presence of a high-mass turn-over for the majority of samples.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16531v1.title: Strong [O III] λ5007 Compact Galaxies Identified from SDSS DR16 and Their Scaling Relations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16531v1.summary: Green pea galaxies are a special class of star-forming compact galaxies. They are considered as analogs of high-redshiftLy{\alpha}-emitting galaxies and potential sources for cosmic reionization. These galaxies present relatively low stellar mass, high star formation rate, and low metallicity. The lower MZR implies that they may be less chemically evolved.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16521v1.title: Are "Changing-Look'' Active Galactic Nuclei Special in the Coevolution of Supermassive Black Holes and their Hosts? I
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16521v1.summary: The nature of the so-called ''changing-look'' (CL) active galactic nucleus(AGN) remains an open question. We here attempt to understand the CL phenomenon from a view of the coevolution of AGNs and their host galaxies. The host galaxies of the CL-AGNs are biased against young stellar populations and tend to be dominated bymediate-age stellar populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2105.01631v4.title: The Hubble Constant in the Axi-Higgs Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2105.01631v4.summary: Theaxi-Higgs model couples an ultralight axion to the Higgs field. It relaxes the $H_0$ tension as well as explains the $^7$Li puzzle in Big-Bang nucleosynthesis. It also explains the observed isotropic cosmic cosmic birefringence in CMB.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.06022v2.title: ALMA/ACA CO Survey of the IC 1459 and NGC 4636 Groups: Environmental Effects on the Molecular Gas of Group Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.06022v2.summary: We present new results of a 12CO(J=1-0) imaging survey using the AtacamaCompact Array (ACA) for 31 HI detected galaxies in the IC 1459 and NGC 4636 groups. This is the first CO imaging survey for loose galaxy groups. We find that CO and/or HI morphologies are disturbed in our group members.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16342v1.title: The abundance of core--collapsed subhalos in SIDM: insights from structure formation in $Λ$CDM
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16342v1.summary: Dark matter halos can enter a phase of gravothermal core--collapse in the presence of self-interactions. This phase that follows a core--expansion phase is thought to be subdominant due to the long time-scales involved. The collapse can be accelerated in tidal environmentsparticularly for halos that are centrally concentrated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08511v2.title: JWST/NIRSpec Measurements of Extremely Low Metallicities in High Equivalent Width Lyman-$α$ Emitters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08511v2.summary: Deep VLT/MUSE optical integral field spectroscopy has recently revealed an abundance of ultra-faint galaxies. The galaxies with the highest Lyman-$\alpha$ equivalent widths can be in excess of 90 Angstrom. This indicates extremely young ages, small stellar masses, and a very low amount of metal enrichment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16282v1.title: Goodbye to Chi-by-Eye: A Bayesian Analysis of Photometric Binaries in Six Open Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16282v1.summary: Using Gaia DR3, Pan-STARRS and 2MASS data, we self-consistently define the cluster parameters and binary demographics for the open clusters (OCs) NGC 2168(M35), NGC 7789, N GC 6819, NGC 2682 (M67), N GC 188, and NGC 6791. We use the BayesianAnalysis of Stellar Evolution software suite (BASE-9) to derive the age, distance, reddening, metallicity, binary fraction, and binary mass-ratio.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16268v1.title: The opacity limit
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16268v1.summary: The opacity limit is an important concept in star formation. cooling radiation is eventuallytrapped and the temperature rises quasi-adiabatically. If the radiation field is strong and dust is abundant it scales. This could make the IMF less bottom-heavy in dust-rich and/or radiation-dense environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16263v1.title: The MUSE-Faint survey. IV. Dissecting Leo T, a gas-rich relic with recent star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16263v1.summary: Leo T ($M_V = -8.0$) is both the faintest and the least massive galaxy known to contain neutral gas and to display signs of recent star formation. We analyze photometry and stellar spectra to identify member stars and to better understand the overall dynamics and stellar content of the galaxy. We find two distinct populations of stars in Leo T.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16261v1.title: The Missing Link: Testing Galactic Chemical Evolution Models with the First Multi-Isotopic Abundances in Solar Twin Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16261v1.summary: This project is the first in a stellar chemical abundance series seeking to: (1)support the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) by providing host star abundances; (2) identify how unexplored stellar abundances reveal the process of galactic chemical evolution; and (3) provide improved stellar ages using stellar abundance measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16260v1.title: Cross-correlation of the thermal Sunyaev--Zel'dovich and CMB lensing signals in Planck PR4 data with robust CIB decontamination
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16260v1.summary: We use the full-mission Planck PR4 data to measure the CMB lensing coalescence ($\kappa$)--thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (tSZ, $y$) We mitigate this by deprojecting the CIB in our NILC, using a moment-deprojection approach. We validate our method on mm-sky simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16253v1.title: Figure Rotation of IllustrisTNG Halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16253v1.summary: Figure rotation in the presence of baryons is marginally less common, shorter-lived, faster, and betteraligned with the minor axis than in DM-only halos. Longer-lived rotations showed greater alignment with the halo minor or major axis in both simulations. This updated understanding of figure rotation will be consequential for future efforts to constrain figure rotation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.20016v3.title: Detecting and Characterizing Mg II absorption in DESI Survey Validation Quasar Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.20016v3.summary: We present findings of the detection of Magnesium II (Mg II) absorbers from the early data release of the Dark EnergySpectroscopic Instrument (DESI) DESI is projected to obtain spectroscopy of approximately 3 million quasars (QSOs) of which over 99% are anticipated to be at redshifts greater than z > 0.3.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16239v1.title: Bars and boxy/peanut bulges in thin and thick discs III. Boxy/peanut bulge formation and evolution in presence of thick discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16239v1.summary: Boxy/peanut (b/p) bulges are the vertically extended inner part of a bar. They form in almost all our models via a vertical buckling instability, even in the presence of a massive thick disc. With increasing thick disc mass, the final b/p structure gets progressively weaker in strength andlarger in extent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16238v1.title: The High-Redshift Clusters Occupied by Bent Radio AGN (COBRA) Survey: Investigating the Role of Environment on Bent Radio AGNs using LOFAR
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16238v1.summary: Bent radio AGN morphology depends on the density of the surrounding gas. Bent sources are found inside and outside clusters. We measure the impact of environment on size, lobe symmetry, and radio luminosity. We conclude that the non-cluster sample may be more representative of bent AGNs in weaker groups.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03879v3.title: Measuring the 8621 Å Diffuse Interstellar Band in Gaia DR3 RVS Spectra: Obtaining a Clean Catalog by Marginalizing over Stellar Types
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03879v3.summary: Diffuse interstellar bands (DIBs) are broad absorption features associated with interstellar dust and can serve as chemical and kinematic tracers. We model the spectrum as a combination of stellar, dust, and                residual components, with full posteriors on the joint distribution of the components. We believe MADGICSprovides a viable path forward for large-scale spectral line measurements in the presence of complex spectral contamination.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10558v2.title: Relative intrinsic scatter in hierarchical Type Ia supernova siblings analyses: Application to SNe 2021hpr, 1997bq & 2008fv in NGC 3147
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10558v2.summary: We present Young Supernova Experiment $grizy$ photometry of SN 2021hpr, the third Type Ia supernova sibling to explode in the Cepheid calibrator galaxy, NGC 3147. Siblings are useful for improving SN-host distance estimates, and investigating contributions towards the SN Ia intrinsic scatter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04411v2.title: Bimodal Star Formation in Simulations of Strongly Magnetized Giant Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04411v2.summary: We find that as we increase the strength of the magnetic field, star formation transitions to bimodal. This effect is clearest in the most stronglyMagnetized GMCs ($\mu=1$) The first burst of star formation is followed by a second starformation episode in which only low-mass stars are formed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00501v1.title: FAUST X: Formaldehyde in the Protobinary System [BHB2007] 11: Small Scale Deuteration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00501v1.summary: Deuterium in H-bearing species is enhanced during the early stages of star formation. Only a small number of high spatial resolution deuteration studies exist towards protostellar objects. We aim to constrain the deuteriumfractionation ratios in a Class 0/I protobinary object in formaldehyde.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00461v1.title: The miniJPAS survey quasar selection IV: Classification and redshift estimation with SQUEzE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00461v1.summary: We present a list of quasar candidates including photometric redshift estimates from the miniJPAS Data Release constructed using SQUEzE. We train our models using specialized mocks from Queiroz et al. (2022) We estimate our redshift precision using the normalized grotesquemedian absolute deviation. We discuss the impact of including extended sources in our predictions (they are not included in the mocks) We also give an explanation of SQUEZE reasoning.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00459v1.title: Faint [CI](1-0) emission in z $\sim$ 3.5 radio galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00459v1.summary: We present Atacama Large Millimeter/sub-millimeter Array (ALMA) neutralcarbon, [C I](1-0), line observations that probe molecular hydrogen gas (H$_2$) Within seven radio galaxies at $z = 2.9 - 4.5$ surrounded by extended Ly-$\alpha$ nebulae. We detect faint[C I] emission in four out of seven sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00449v1.title: The evolution of the cold gas fraction in nearby clusters ram-pressure stripped galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00449v1.summary: Cluster galaxies are affected by the surrounding environment, which influences their gas, stellar content and morphology. The ram-pressure exerted by the intracluster medium promotes theformation of multi-phase tails of stripped gas. We find that in most galaxies with a star forming tail the global content is enhanced.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00960v2.title: Hard X-ray emission from blazars associated with high-energy neutrinos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00960v2.summary: Bright blazars were found to be prominent neutrino sources. Their energy range is well-suited for probing protons. neutrinos are produced within compact blazar jets. They interact with target X-ray photons emitted from accelerated jet regions. The chance coincidence probability is p=0.5%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00412v1.title: RXCJ1111.6+4050 galaxy cluster: the observational evidence of a transitional fossil group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00412v1.summary: We present a detailed kinematical and dynamical study of the galaxy cluster                RXCJ1111. We use 104 new spectroscopic redshifts of galaxies observed at the TNG 3.5m telescope and SDSS DR16 public archive. The substructure is characterized by a magnitude gap $1.8$ so it fits the "fossil-like" definition of a galaxy group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11811v2.title: Calibrating mid-infrared emission as a tracer of obscured star formation on HII-region scales in the era of JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11811v2.summary: Infrared (IR) emission from small dust grains and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are widely used to trace the obscured component of star formation. The relation between IR emission and dust attenuation is complicated by the combined effects of dustheating from old stellar populations and an uncertain dust geometry. We use images obtained with NIRCam and MIRI as part of the PHANGS--JWST survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00318v1.title: Gas phase Elemental abundances in Molecular cloudS (GEMS). IX. Deuterated compounds of H2S in starless cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00318v1.summary: H2S is thought to be the main sulphur reservoir in the ice. It can be used to understand sulphur chemistry in the star formation process and to solve the missing sulphur problem. The H2S single and double deuterium fractions are analysed with regard to their relation with the cloud physical parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00291v1.title: Ultraluminous Quasars At High Redshift Show Evolution In Their Radio-Loudness Fraction In Both Redshift And Ultraviolet Luminosity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00291v1.summary: We take a sample of 94 ultraluminous, optical quasars from the search of over 14,486 deg^2 by Onken et al. 2022. The radio-loud fraction for this sample is 8.5 \pm 2.9 per cent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07929v2.title: Probing the interplay between jets, winds and multi-phase gas in 11 radio-quiet PG Quasars: A uGMRT-VLA study
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07929v2.summary: We present polarization-sensitive images from the Karl G. Jansky Very LargeArray (VLA) at 5 GHz of 11 radio-quiet PG quasars. Localized or small-scale jet-medium interactions can be inferred across the sample based on the VLA jet kinetic power arguments and polarization data. These may have the potential as a feedback mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00272v1.title: Discovery of compact disc Galaxies with High Surface Brightness in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00272v1.summary: Compact disc galaxies (CDGs) with high surface brightness were identified in Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) data. The CDGs have higher central brightness and older stellar age than the NDGs. We suggest that the CDGs are ancient galaxies in the quenching phase following the initial central starburst.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00198v1.title: Flux evolution and kinematics of superluminal components in blazar 3C345
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00198v1.summary: The precessing jet-nozzle scenario previously proposed was applied to the kinematics of five superluminal components (C19,C20,C21,B5 and B7) of jet-B in blazar 3C345. Based on a specific pattern for the the                precessing common trajectory ofJet-B, kinematic properties were studied. The bulk Lorentz factor, viewing angle and Doppler factor were derived as continuous functions of time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09867v2.title: AT2018dyk Revisited: a Tidal Disruption Event Candidate with Prominent Infrared Echo and Delayed X-ray Emission in a LINER Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09867v2.summary: Nuclear transient AT2018dyk, initially discovered as a changing-look low-ionization nuclear emission-line region (LINER) galaxy, has been revisited by us. The X-ray spectra are softer than normal active galactic nuclei (AGNs) although they show a slight trend of hardening.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11264v2.title: Revisiting the black hole mass of M87* using VLT/MUSE Adaptive Optics Integral Field Unit data I: Ionized gas kinematics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11264v2.summary: The stellar dynamic-based black hole mass measurements of M87 are twice that determined via ionized gas kinematics. The complexity of the nuclear morphology and kinematic precludes the accurate measurement of a black hole's mass. A disk inclination close to 25\deg for the nuclear gas disk, and the warp in the sub-arcsec ionizedGas disk, help to reconcile the contradictory nature of the mass discrepancy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00110v1.title: Optical- & UV-Continuum Morphologies of Compact Radio Source Hosts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00110v1.summary: New HST images show extended UV continuum. in 6/7 CSS galaxies. 5 CSS hosts exhibiting UV knots co-spatial and aligned along the radio-jet axis. Young (<10 Myr), massive. populations are likely to be the dominant source of the blue excess. UV emission in radio galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00102v1.title: The LOFAR Two-Metre Sky Survey (LoTSS): VI. Optical identifications for the second data release
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00102v1.summary: The second data release of the LOFAR Two-Metre Sky Survey (LoTSS) covers 27% of the northern sky. 4,116,934 radio sources lie in the area with good optical data, of which 85% have an optical or infrared identification and 58% have a good redshift estimate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04882v2.title: Inferred galaxy properties during Cosmic Dawn from early JWST photometry results
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04882v2.summary: Early photometric results from JWST have revealed a number of galaxy candidates above redshift 10. We explore the contribution of supermassive black holes, stellar binaries, and an excess ofmassive stars to the overall luminosity of high-redshift galaxies. We find that four of the 12 high- redshift galaxy candidates are the best fit with a non-negligible active galactic nuclei component.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00062v1.title: Very Massive Star Models: I. Impact of Rotation and Metallicity and Comparisons with Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00062v1.summary: Very Massive Stars (VMS) are suspected to have a tremendous impact on their environment and on the wholecosmic evolution. The nucleosynthesis both during their advanced stages and their final explosion may contribute greatly to the overall enrichment of the Universe. Their extreme conditions also lead to very important radiative and feedback effects, from local to cosmic scale.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00057v1.title: Aspects of Machian Gravity (II): Testing Theory against Rotation Curves of 175 SPARC Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00057v1.summary: Machian Gravity (MG) presents a mathematical framework that captures the essence of Mach's principle. Previous investigations have revealed MG's potential to explain diverse phenomena, such as galactic velocity patterns and galaxy cluster mass distribution. This study applies the MG accelerating law to a wide array of galaxies sourced from the SPARC galactic database.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00053v1.title: The first comprehensive study of a giant nebula around a radio-quiet quasar in the $z < 1$ Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00053v1.summary: We present the first comprehensive study of a giant, 70kpc-scale nebula around a radio-quiet quasar at $z<1$. The analysis is based on deep integral field spectroscopy with MUSE of the field of HE$\,$0238$-$1904. The nebula exhibits largely quiescent kinematics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00051v1.title: The Nature of the IMBH Candidate CXO~J133815.6+043255: High-Frequency Radio Emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00051v1.summary: The ultra-luminous X-ray source CXO~J133815.6+043255 is a strong candidate for a bona-fide intermediate mass black hole, residing in the outskirts ofNGC~5252. We present 22~GHz radio observations of this source obtained from an ongoing high-frequency imaging survey of radio-quietActive Galactic Nuclei.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00050v1.title: Illuminating the Dark Side of Cosmic Star Formation II. A second date with RS-NIRdark galaxies in COSMOS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00050v1.summary: The StarFormation Rate Density (SFRD) is traditionally observed in the Near-InfraRed (NIR), Optical and UV bands. We aim to fill this knowledge gap by studying Radio Selected NIR-dark sources. We estimate that the contribution of RS-NIRdark to the Cosmic SFRD at 3$<$z$ <$5 is $10--25% of that based on UV-selected galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00048v1.title: Detection of the Keplerian decline in the Milky Way rotation curve
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00048v1.summary: We have identified, for the first time, a Keplerian decline of the Keplerianrotation curve, starting at 19 kpc and up to 26.5 kpc from the Galaxy center. This results in a sharply decreasing rotation curve for the Milky Way. The total mass is revised downwards to $2.06^{+0.24] kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00041v1.title: EDGE -- Dark matter or astrophysics? Clear prospects to break dark matter heating degeneracies with HI rotation in faint dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00041v1.summary: Low-mass dwarf galaxies are expected to showcase pristine inner dark matter density profiles compared to their stellar sizes. They form too fewstars to significantly drive dark matter heating through supernovae-drivenoutflows. But five dwarf galaxies from the suite showcase a detectable HI reservoir. These reservoir is similar to the observed population of faint, HI-bearing dwarf galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00045v1.title: The energy distribution of the first supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00045v1.summary: For the first time we account simultaneously for the unknown initial mass function (IMF),stellar mixing, and energy distribution function (EDF) of Pop III stars. We discover degeneracies between the adopted Pop III unknowns and the predicted metallicity and carbonicity distribution functions of C-enhanced stars. All very metal-poor stars are predicted to be predominantly enriched by Pop III supernovae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00039v1.title: Fuzzy dark matter dynamics in tidally perturbed dwarf spheroidal galaxy satellites
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00039v1.summary: Fuzzy dark matter (FDM) has dynamical properties that differ significantly from cold dark matter. These differences are stronglymanifested on the spatial scale of dwarf spheroidal galaxies (dSphs) We find that a perturbed FDM soliton develops a long-standing breathing mode, whereas for CDM such a breathing mode quicklyphase-mixes and disappears.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00031v1.title: PEARLS: Near Infrared Photometry in the JWST North Ecliptic Pole Time Domain Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00031v1.summary: These new observations cover a field of approximately 230 arcmin^2 in Y, H, and K. The new observations will provide a baseline for time-domainstudies of bright sources in the TDF.
