This paper describes the observations and reduction of the NIR imaging and combines these NIR data with archival imaging.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06430v1.title: Into the Mystic: ALMA ACA observations of the Mystic Mountains in Carina
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06430v1.summary: New observations of the Mystic Mountains cloud complex in the Carina Nebula using the ALMA Atacama Compact Array. Find no clear correlation between the velocity orurbulent structure of the gas and the incident radiation. This may reflect differences in densities of regions that go on to collapse into pillars and those that still look like clouds or walls.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06366v1.title: Quasi-stationary tidal evolution with arbitrarily misaligned orbital and stellar angular momenta with a preliminary numerical investigation in the non-dissipative limit
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06366v1.summary: We extend the results of our 2021 paper concerning the problem.of tidal evolution of a binary system with a rotating primary component. Only the contribution of quasi-stationary tides is discussed. We present evolution equations derived 'from first principles' The governing equations contain two groups of terms. The first group determines the evolution of orbital parameters. The second group of terms is due tostellar rotation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06334v1.title: On the non-dissipative tidal evolution of the misalignment between spin and orbital angular momenta
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06334v1.summary: We extend our previous work on the evolution of close binary systems with misaligned orbital and spin angular momenta to include all physical effects contributing to apsidalmotion. In addition to tidal distortion of the primary by the compact secondarythese include relativistic Einstein precession and the rotational distortion ofthe primary. The influence of the precession of the line of nodes is included.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06319v1.title: Spatially-resolved H$α$ and ionizing photon production efficiency in the lensed galaxy MACS1149-JD1 at a redshift of 9.11
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06319v1.summary: We detect, for the first time, spatially-resolvedH$\alpha$ emission in a galaxy at redshift above 9. The structure of the emitting gas consists of two clumps, S and N. The total H$\ alpha$luminosity implies an instantaneous star formation rate of 5.3$\pm$0.4$M_{\odot}$ yr$^{-1}$ for solar metallicities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06311v1.title: Spatially-resolved Spectroscopic Analysis of Ly$α$ Haloes: Radial Evolution of the Ly$α$ Line Profile out to 60 kpc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06311v1.summary: Deep MUSE observations have unveiled pervasive Ly$\alpha$ haloes (LAHs) around high-redshift star-forming galaxies. However, the origin of the extended emission is still a subject of debate. We analyse the average spatial extent and spectral variation of the circumgalactic LAHs by stacking a sample of 155 emitters (LAEs) at redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06283v1.title: Co-moving groups around massive stars in the Nuclear Stellar Disk
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06283v1.summary: During the last 30 Myr the nuclear stellar disk in the Galactic center has been the most prolific star forming region of the Milky Way. The stellardensity in the area is so high that only the most massive clusters would bedetectable against the dense background of stars. We focus our search on known, spectroscopically identified massive young stars to see whether they can pinpoint such structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06273v1.title: Experimental oscillator strengths of Al I lines for near-infrared astrophysical spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06273v1.summary: neutral aluminium is found in young, massive stars and is a key element for tracing ongoing nucleosynthesis throughout the Galaxy. The near-infrared(NIR) wavelength region is of particular importance, since extinction in this region is lower than for optical wavelengths. This makes the NIR wavelength region a better probe for highly obscured regions, such as those located close to the Galactic center.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.04484v2.title: Stellar Bars in Spinning Halos: Delayed Buckling and Absence of Slowdown
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.04484v2.summary: We use high resolution numerical simulations in order to analyze the stellarbar evolution in spinning dark matter (DM) halos. We find that varying the DM density has a profound effect on the stellar bar evolving. Strong stellar bars in spinning halos can avoid fast braking, resolving the long standing discrepancy between observations and $N$-body simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06257v1.title: The problem of dust attenuation in photometric decomposition of edge-on galaxies and possible solutions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06257v1.summary: The presence of dust in spiral galaxies affects the ability of photometricdecompositions to retrieve the parameters of their main structural components. For galaxies in an edge-on orientation, the optical depth integrated over the line-of-sight is significantly higher than for those with intermediate or face-on inclinations. We test several approaches, including various masking methods and an analytical model that incorporates dust absorption.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06187v1.title: The Three Hundred: $M_{sub}-V_{circ}$ relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06187v1.summary: The sub-halos observed in clusters exhibit greater compactness compared to those predicted by $\Lambda$CDM simulations. Neither the GADGET-X nor GIZMO-SIMBA( albeit a little closer) simulations' predictions for the sub-halo mass function align with the observational result.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15781v2.title: The galaxy counterpart and environment of the dusty Damped Lyman-alpha Absorber at z=2.226 towards Q1218+0832
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15781v2.summary: Geier et al. 2019 presented the discovery of the quasar resulting from a search for quasars reddened and dimmed by dust in foreground damped Lyman-alphaabsorbers (DLAs) The DLA is remarkable by having a very large HI columndensity close to 10^22 cm-2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06137v1.title: Gaia's brightest very metal-poor (VMP) stars: A metallicity catalogue of a thousand VMP stars from Gaia RVS spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06137v1.summary: Gaia DR3 has offered the scientific community a remarkable dataset of approximately one million spectra acquired with the Radial VelocitySpectrometer (RVS) in the Calcium II triplet region. Over 40% of these spectra have no released parameters by Gaia's GSP Spec pipeline. VMP stars are key tracers of early Galactic evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06126v1.title: AstroLLaMA: Towards Specialized Foundation Models in Astronomy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06126v1.summary: AstroLLaMA is a 7-billion-parameter model fine-tuned from LLaMA-2 using 300,000 astronomy abstracts from arXiv. Its public release aims to spur astronomy-focusedresearch, including automatic paper summarization and conversational agent development.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.12487v2.title: Modeling the JWST high-redshift galaxies with a general formation scenario and the consistency with the $Λ$CDM model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.12487v2.summary: Early results from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have hinted at two traces beyond the standard cosmological framework. We construct rest-frame UV luminosity functions (LFs) based on a general formation model for these high-redshift galaxy candidates. We also reveal a potential nonmonotonic trend of SFE with the progressivelyincreasing redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02722v2.title: Exploring the Angular Momentum - Atomic Gas Content Connection with EAGLE and IllustrisTNG
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02722v2.summary: We use the EAGLE (Evolution and Assembly of GaLaxies and their Environments) simulations and IllustrisTNG (The Next Generation) cosmological simulations to investigate properties of the baryonic specific angular momentum (j) and mass (M) of nearby galaxies. We find EAGle and TNG to be in excellent agreement with each other. Despite the challenges posed by resolution limits at low gas fractions,our findings suggest a potential disconnect between angular momentum and gas fraction in the gas-poor regime.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06092v1.title: A remarkably stable accretion disc in the Seyfert galaxy MCG-5-23-16
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06092v1.summary: MCG-5-23-16 is a Seyfert 1.9 galaxy at redshift z=0.00849. X-ray spectra obtained with XMM-Newton and NuSTAR data. Two reflectionfeatures, producing a narrow core and a broad component of the Fe K$\alpha$,are clearly detected in the data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06076v1.title: Grain Growth and Dust Segregation Revealed by Multi-wavelength Analysis of the Class I Protostellar Disk WL 17
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06076v1.summary: Grain growth has been reported not only in protoplanetary disks but also in Class 0/I protostellar envelopes. The analysis shows that the disk is expected to be massive and gravitationally unstable. We suggest a single Jupiter-mass protoplanet formed by gravitational instability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02756v2.title: ED-2: a cold but not so narrow stellar stream crossing the Solar neighbourhood
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02756v2.summary: ED-2 is a stellar stream identified as a compact group in integrals of motion in a local sample of halo stars from the third Gaia data release. It is similar to the globular clusters NGC 3201 and NGC 6101, and the stellarstream Ylgr and Phlegethon.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06037v1.title: Fast resolving Galactic binaries in LISA data and its ability to study the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06037v1.summary: We propose a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) threshold for LISA to confirm the detection of DWD binaries. We find that both methods have a similar ability to detect the Milky Way structure by their confirmed sources. The relative error of distance and chirp mass is about 20\% for DWD binary whose gravitational wave frequency is higher than $4\times10^{-3}$ Hz.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06028v1.title: Accretion disk's environmental effects on gravitational waves from LISA for extreme mass ratio black hole binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06028v1.summary: The merger of supermassive black holes (BBH) produces mHz gravitational waves. Such binary systems are usually embedded in an accretion disk at the centre of the active galactic nuclei (AGN) Recent studies suggest the plasma environment imposes measurable imprints on the GW signal. We investigate this effect by measuring the disk torques on the binary.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06012v1.title: Blue Large-Amplitude Pulsators and Other Short-Period Variable Stars in the OGLE-IV Galactic Disk Fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06012v1.summary: Blue Large-Amplitude Pulsators (BLAPs) form a mysterious class of variablestars with typical periods of tens of minutes and amplitudes above 0.1 mag. Twenty-five BLAPs have been detected, 20 of which are new discoveries. We have also found six new eclipsing binary systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05962v1.title: Neutral Hydrogen content of dwarf galaxies in different environments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05962v1.summary: Environments play an important role in galaxy formation and evolution, particularly in regulating the content of neutral gas. Current HIsurveys have limitations in their depth, which prevents them from adequatelystudying low HI content galaxies in high-density regions. We observe a positive relationship between HI mass and stellarMass in dwarf galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05937v1.title: The Gas Accretion Rate of Star-forming Galaxies over the last 4 Gyr
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05937v1.summary: Star-forming galaxies are believed to replenish their atomic gas reservoir through accretion of gas from theircircumgalactic mediums. However, there are few observational constraints on the gas accretion rate in external galaxies. We use our recent measurement of the scaling relation between the atomic hydrogen (HI) mass and the stellar mass $M_*$ to determine the evolution of the neutral gas reservoir.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02828v3.title: Probing the Galactic halo with RR Lyrae stars -- IV. On the Oosterhoff dichotomy of RR Lyrae stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02828v3.summary: We use 3653 (2661 RRab, 992 RRc) RR Lyrae stars (RRLs) with 7D information selected from SDSS, LAMOST, and GaiaEDR3. We divide the sample into two Oosterhoff groups (Oo I and Oo II) according to their amplitude-period behaviour in the Bailey Diagram. We find that Oo I RRLs are relatively more metal rich, withpredominately radially dominated orbits and large eccentricities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05406v2.title: Galactic ChitChat: Using Large Language Models to Converse with Astronomy Literature
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.05406v2.summary: We demonstrate the potential of the state-of-the-art OpenAI GPT-4 largelanguage model to engage in meaningful interactions with Astronomy papers. To optimize for efficiency, we employ a distillationtechnique that effectively reduces the size of the original input paper by 50%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.04546v2.title: The Unified Cluster Catalogue: towards a comprehensive and homogeneous database of stellar clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.04546v2.summary: The Unified Cluster Catalogue lists nearly 14,000 objects in the Milky Way. The catalogue is accompanied by a publicly accessible website designed to simplify the search and data exploration of stellar clusters. We employ Gaia DR3 data up to a G magnitude of 20, resulting in the identification of over a million probable members. The website can be accessed at https://ucc.ar.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05841v1.title: WALLABY Pilot Survey: the Potential Polar Ring Galaxies NGC~4632 and NGC~6156
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05841v1.summary: We report on the discovery of two potential polar ring galaxies (PRGs) in the WALLABY Pilot Data Release 1 (PDR1) These untargetted detections are some of the first galaxies where observations show two distinct components. We have generated plausible 3D kinematic models for each galaxy assuming that the rings are circular and inclined at 90 degrees to the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05839v1.title: The Perseus ALMA Chemical Survey (PEACHES). III. Sulfur-bearing species tracing accretion and ejection processes in young protostars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05839v1.summary: Sulfur chemistry is poorly understood in the process of low-mass star and planet formation. We analyzed a total of 50 Class 0/I sources with an average angular resolution of about 0.6" (~180 au) in ALMA band 6. We present detection rates for CS, SO, 34SO, and SO2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05835v1.title: Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science Survey (CEERS): Multi-classing Galactic Dwarf Stars in the deep JWST/NIRCam
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05835v1.summary: Low mass (sub)stellar objects represent the transition to free-floating planets and a prominent interloper in the search for high-redshift galaxies. Without proper motions orspectroscopy, can one identify these objects photometrically? JWST/NIRCam has more filters, a greater wavelength range and greater spatial resolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08516v2.title: JADES: Insights on the low-mass end of the mass--metallicity--star-formation rate relation at $3 < z < 10$ from deep JWST/NIRSpec spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08516v2.summary: We study scaling relations between stellar mass, oxygen abundance (O/H), and star-formation rate (SFR) for 146 galaxies at 3 < z < 10. We find evidence for a shallower slope at the low-mass-end of the mass-metallicityrelation (MZR) The inferred slope is well matched by models including 'momentum-driven' SNe winds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05811v1.title: Predicting the Radiation Field of Molecular Clouds using Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05811v1.summary: Accurately quantifying the impact of radiation feedback in star formation is difficult. We employ deep learning techniques to predict the Interstellar radiation field (ISRF) strength. We train DDPMs to estimate the ISRF using synthetic three-band dust emission. The dispersion between the predictions and true values is within a factor of 0.1 for the test set.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05772v1.title: Tracing Evolution in Massive Protostellar Objects (TEMPO) -- I: Fragmentation and emission properties of massive star-forming clumps in a luminosity limited ALMA sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05772v1.summary: First paper from the Tracing Evolution in MassiveProtostellar Objects (TEMPO) project. Explores the fragmentation,clustering and flux density properties of the sample. A tentative evolutionary trend is seen between the luminosity of the clump and the `spectral line richness' of the TEMPO fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05758v1.title: Zero Metallicity with Zero CPU Hours: Masses of the First Stars on the Laptop
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05758v1.summary: We develop an analytic model for the mass of the first stars forming in the Center of primordial gas clouds. The model is based on the estimation of key timescales determining the following three processes: the collapse of the gas cloud, the accretion onto the protostellar core, and the radiative feedback of the core.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05737v1.title: A rest-frame near-IR study of clumps in galaxies at $1<z<2$ using JWST/NIRCam: connection to galaxy bulges
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05737v1.summary: Clumpiness' of high redshift galaxies is a key question in galaxy evolution. Until now, this property has been mainly investigated in rest-frame UV. We use JWST/NIRCam imaging from CEERS to explore the connection between the presence of these 'clumps' in a galaxy and its overall stellar morphology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05733v1.title: Impact of the Galactic bar on tidal streams within the Galactic disc: The case of the tidal stream of the Hyades
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05733v1.summary: Tidal streams of disrupted clusters are routinely detected in the halo of the Galactic Milky Way. It was recently shown that tidal streams of open clusters can now also be detected within the disc. In this work, we highlight the fact that these streams provide a powerful new diagnostic of the non-axisymmetric disc potential.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05732v1.title: Nearby galaxies in the LOFAR Two-metre Sky Survey III. Influence of cosmic-ray transport on the radio-SFR relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05732v1.summary: We analyse the spatiallyresolved radio continuum-star-formation rate (radio-SFR) relation in 15 nearbygalaxies. We use data from the LOw Frequency ARray (LOFAR) and the WesterborkSynthesis Radio Telescope (WSRT) at 144 and 1365 MHz, respectively.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05724v1.title: Chemical enrichment of ICM within the Ophiuchus cluster I: radial profiles
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05724v1.summary: The analysis of the elemental abundances in galaxy clusters offers valuableinsights into the formation and evolution of galaxies. We model the X/Fe ratio profiles with a linear combination of core-collapse supernovae (SNcc) and type~Ia supernovAE (SNIa) models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05719v1.title: The Scale of Stellar Yields: Implications of the Measured Mean Iron Yield of Core Collapse Supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05719v1.summary: The scale of alpha-element yields is difficult to predict from theory because of uncertainties in massive star evolution, supernova physics, and black holeforming. The impact of higher yields can be compensated by greater metal loss in galactic winds. We find that the population-averaged yields of O and Mg perunit mass of star formation are about equal to the mass fractions of these elements in the sun.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05717v1.title: Role of ionizing background on the non-thermal broadening inferred for the aligned absorbers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05717v1.summary: Using cosmological hydrodynamical simulations at $z\sim0.5$ we identify the                aligned absorbers and measure their contribution to the line broadening using OVI and HI absorption lines. We find that the inferred temperature based on $b_{t}$ correlates strongly with theoptical depth-weighted kinetic temperature of the absorbing gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05713v1.title: GA-NIFS: Early-stage feedback in a heavily obscured AGN at $z=4.76$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05713v1.summary: Dust-obscured galaxies are thought to represent an early evolutionary phase of massive galaxies. The active galactic nucleus (AGN) is still deeplyburied in significant amounts of dusty material and its emission is stronglysuppressed. The unprecedented sensitivity of the James Webb Space Telescope enables us for the first time to detect the rest-frame optical emission of obscured AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05714v1.title: UNCOVER spectroscopy confirms a surprising ubiquity of AGN in red galaxies at $z>5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05714v1.summary: JWST is revealing a new population of dust-reddened broad-line active galactic nuclei (AGN) at redshifts $z\gtrsim5$. The confirmed AGN have black hole masses of $10^7-10^9$ and are 100 times more common than the faintest UV-selected quasars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05707v1.title: Phase-space simulations of prompt cusps: simulating the formation of the first haloes without artificial fragmentation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05707v1.summary: The first generation of haloes forms from the collapse of the smallest peaks. $N$-body simulations of this process suggest aprompt formation of a steep power-law cusp. The presence of artificial clumps just before peak collapse can significantly shallow the inner profiles of the cusps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05708v1.title: Modeling the orbital histories of satellites of Milky Way-mass galaxies: testing static host potentials against cosmological simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05708v1.summary: Understanding the evolution of satellite galaxies of the Milky Way requires modeling their orbital histories across cosmic time. We fit a near-exact axisymmetric gravitational potential to each host at $z=0$ and backward integrate the orbits of satellites in this way. Orbital energy and angular momentum are not well conserved throughout an orbital history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05699v1.title: The Cosmic Ultraviolet Baryon Survey: Empirical Characterization of Turbulence in the Cool Circumgalactic Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05699v1.summary: This paper reports the first measurement of the relationship betweenturbulent velocity and cloud size in the diffuse circumgalactic medium (CGM) in typical galaxy halos at redshift z~0.4-1. The turbulence is consistent with a roughly constant energy transfer rate per unit mass. No significant difference is found between massive quiescent and star-forminghalos in the sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05701v1.title: The 50 Mpc Galaxy Catalog (50MGC): Consistent and Homogeneous Masses, Distances, Colors, and Morphologies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05701v1.summary: We assemble a catalog of 15424 nearby galaxies within 50 Mpc. We use galaxy color information to separate early and late-type galaxies. This catalog is widely applicable for studies of nearby galaxies, and placing these studies in the context of more distant galaxies. We present one application here; a preliminary analysis of the nuclear X-ray activity of surrounding galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05694v1.title: Nested solitons in two-field fuzzy dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05694v1.summary: A two-field fuzzy dark matter (FDM) model features two species of ultralight axion particles withdifferent masses. The formationof this nested soliton is subject to many factors, including the densityfraction and mass ratio of the two fields. We study non-linear structure formation in two- field cosmological simulations with self-consistent initial conditions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05697v1.title: 21cmEMU: an emulator of 21cmFAST summary observables
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05697v1.summary: 21cmEMU is an emulator of several summaryobservables from the popular 21cmFAST simulation code. It takes as input nine parameters characterizing EoR galaxies, and outputs the following summary statistics. All viewpoints are predicted with sub-percent median accuracy, with a reduction of the computational cost by a factor of over 10$^4$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05651v1.title: Testing external photoevaporation in the $σ$-Orionis cluster with spectroscopy and disk mass measurements
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05651v1.summary: Study of the impact of external photoevaporation on the evolution of disks in the Orionis cluster. Study is the first combined large-scale UV to IRspectroscopic and mm-continuum survey of this region. Results show that the presence of a massive stellar system affects disk evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05647v1.title: Forecasting constraints on the high-z IGM thermal state from the Lyman-$α$ forest flux auto-correlation function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05647v1.summary: The auto-correlation function of the Lyman-$\alpha$ (Ly$\alpha) forest flux can statistically probe all scales of the intergalacticmedium (IGM) just after the epoch of reionization. We create mock data sets of 20 quasars to forecast constraints on $T_0$ and $\gamma$, which characterize tight temperature-density relation in the IGM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05635v1.title: Can massive stars form in low mass clouds?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05635v1.summary: The conditions required for massive star formation are debated, particularly whether massive stars must form in conjunction with massive clusters. Here we investigate the relation between cluster mass and the maximum stellar mass (M\textsubscript{max}) using a suite of SPH simulations. We find that more massive clusters will have, on average, higher mass stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05567v1.title: Kinematics and Collimation of the Two-Sided Jets in NGC 4261: VLBI Study on Sub-parsec Scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05567v1.summary: We report multi-frequency VLBI studies of the sub-parsec scale structure of the two-sided jet in the nearby radio galaxy NGC 4261. Our results show an extended double-sided structure at 43/44 GHz andprovide a clear image of the nuclear region at 88 GHz. We also confirm the parabolic shape of the upstream jet on both sides of the central engine.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05524v1.title: Empirical 2MASS-WFC3/IR filter transformations from synthetic photometry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05524v1.summary: Near-infrared bandpasses on spaceborne observatories diverge from their ground-based counterparts as they are free of atmospheric telluric absorption. We present transformations between the 2MASS $JHK_S$ and HST WFC3/IR photometric systems based on synthetic photometry of empirical stellarspectra from four spectral libraries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05513v1.title: Median Surface Brightness Profiles of Lyman-$α$ Haloes in the MUSE Extremely Deep Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05513v1.summary: We present the median surface brightness profiles of diffuse Ly$\alpha$haloes (LAHs) around star-forming galaxies. LAHs are stacked in the MUSE Extremely Deep Field(MXDF) We find no clear evidence of redshift evolution of the observedLy$\ alpha$ profiles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12827v2.title: Impact of symmetron screening on the Hubble tension: new constraints using cosmic distance ladder data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12827v2.summary: The fifth force can influence the calibration of the cosmic distance ladder, changing the inferred value of the Hubble constant $H_0. For the standard coupling case, the constraint on the symmetron wavelength is $2.5 \, \mathrm{Mpc}$. Thus, distance ladder data constitutes a novel and powerful way of testing this theory.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14994v2.title: Beyond Ultra-diffuse Galaxies. I. Mass--Size Outliers among the Satellites of Milky Way Analogs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.14994v2.summary: Large diffuse galaxies are hard to find, but understanding the environments where they live, their numbers, and ultimately their origins is of intense interest and importance for galaxy formation and evolution. Using Subaru's Hyper Suprime-Cam Strategic Survey Program, we perform a systematic search for low surface brightness galaxies and present novel and effective methods for detecting and modeling them.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14108v2.title: Beyond Ultra-diffuse Galaxies. II. Environmental Quenching of Mass-Size Outliers among the Satellites of Milky Way Analogs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14108v2.summary: The origin and evolution of these mass-size outliers and the role of the environment are still unclear. Despite being outliers in size, the ultra-puffy galaxies have a similar quenched fraction as normal-sized satellites of Milky Way analogs. This suggests that quenching is not tied to being a mass- size outlier.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05408v1.title: An in-depth view of the metallicity distribution of the Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05408v1.summary: Spatial metallicity distribution of star clusters in the Small MagellanicCloud (SMC) has recently been found to correlate as a V-shaped function with the semi-major axis of an elliptical framework. We report results on the impact that the use of such a framework can produce on our understanding of the SMC formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05397v1.title: Influence of protostellar outflows on star and protoplanetary disk formation in a massive star-forming clump
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05397v1.summary: Protostellar jets are a natural consequence of accretion onto protostars. They provide additional turbulent and magnetic support to the clump, impact the disk temperatures, and reduce the accretion rate onto the protostar. While they promote a more numerous stellar population, they do not control the mass scale of the stellar IMF.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04377v2.title: EPOCHS VI: The Size and Shape Evolution of Galaxies since z ~ 8 with JWST Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04377v2.summary: We present the results of a size and structural analysis of 1395 galaxies at 0.5 and 9.5 redshifts. At fixed rest-frame wavelengths and stellar mass, galaxies get progressively smaller, evolving as. $\sim (1+z)^{-0.71\pm0.19}$ up to $z \sim 8$. We show that galaxies are more compact at redder wavelengths, independent of sSFR or stellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03837v2.title: Radio Emission From a $z =$ 10.1 Black Hole in UHZ1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03837v2.summary: The seeds of the first quasars may have been direct-collapse black holes (DCBHs) from the collapse of supermassive primordial stars. This object was identified in James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) NIRcam and Chandra X-ray data. It may be possible to see this object with VLA now with longer integration times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05332v1.title: Gas-phase metallicity of local AGN in the GASP and MaNGA surveys: the role of ram-pressure stripping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05332v1.summary: There is growing evidence in support of a connection between Active Galactic Nuclei(AGN) activity and the Ram-Pressure Stripping (RPS) phenomenon. We find that the distributions of metallicity and luminosity of galaxies undergoing RPS are similar to the ones of undisturbed galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05307v1.title: FOREVER22: Gas and metal outflow from massive galaxies in protocluster regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05307v1.summary: We study gas and metal outflow from massive galaxies in protocluster regions at $z=3-9$ Our simulations contain massive haloes with high star formation rates and supermassive black holes. We show that the mass loading factor of the gas depends on the halo mass. Also, the metal inflow and outflow rates sensitively depend on the redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12970v2.title: FOREVER22: the first bright galaxies with population III stars at redshifts $z \simeq 10-20$ and comparisons with JWST data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12970v2.summary: We study the formation of the first galaxies in overdense regions modelled by FORmation and EVolution of galaxies in Extremely overdense Regions project. We suggest that the observed galaxies are hosted by dark-matter haloes and are in short-period starburst phases. Even simulated massive galaxies cannot reproduce the intense star formation rates observed by James Webb SpaceTelescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05265v1.title: Ionized regions in the central arcsecond of NGC 1068. YJHK spatially resolved spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05265v1.summary: Several bright emission line regions have been observed in the central 100 parsecs of the active galaxy NGC 1068. The emission line spectra of the three regions are almost identical to each other and contribute to most of the emission line flux in the nuclear region. Based on our comparisons, we conclude that they are shock regions located where the jet of theactive galactic nucleus impacts massive molecular clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05252v1.title: A severe challenge to the MOND phenomenology in our Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05252v1.summary: Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) is one of the most popular alternative theories of dark matter to explain the missing mass problem in galaxies. MONDphenomenology has been shown to widely apply in different galaxies, which gives challenges to the standard cold dark matter model. The recent discovery of the declining Galactic rotation curve in the outer region can almost rule out the MOND phenomenology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11805v2.title: Mean-field dynamo due to spatiotemporal fluctuations of the turbulent kinetic energy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11805v2.summary: Fluctuations of the mean turbulent kinetic energy at the mesoscale can lead to the growth of a large-scale magnetic field. Turbulent diamagnetism leads to growing mean field solutions even when statistically isotropic. We also study the effects of nonzero correlation time and anisotropy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05061v1.title: First constraints on compact binary environments from LIGO-Virgo data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05061v1.summary: The LIGO-Virgo analysis of the signals from compact binary mergers observed so far have assumed in-vacuum isolated binary systems. Non-trivial environments may alter gravitational-wave emission, leaving imprints that can be observable via acharacteristic dephasing of the emitted signal.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05052v1.title: Dwarf galaxies with the highest concentration are not thicker than ordinary dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05052v1.summary: The formation mechanism of high-concentration dwarf galaxies is still a mystery. We perform a comparative study of the intrinsic shape of nearbylow-mass galaxies with different stellar concentration. We find that our galaxies have typical intrinsic shape, regardless of the stellar mass, star formation activity, and local environment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05037v1.title: Astrophysical Parameters of the Open Cluster NGC 2509
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05037v1.summary: This study presents structural and fundamental astrophysical parameters of the poorly studied open cluster NGC 2509. We used the third photometric andastrometric data release of the Gaia (Gaia DR3) to perform analyses. The colour excess, distance and age were obtained simultaneously by fitting solar metallicity PARSECisochrones to a colour-magnitude diagram.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05000v1.title: Multiphase Neutral Interstellar Medium: Analyzing Simulation with H I 21cm Observational Data Analysis Techniques
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05000v1.summary: Several different methods are regularly used to infer the properties of the interstellar medium (ISM) using atomic hydrogen (H I) 21cm absorption and emission spectra. We propose a physically motivated model to explain the $T_B(v)-\tau(v)$ distribution and relate the model parameters to properties like warm gas spin and cold cloud length.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15305v2.title: Bursty Star Formation Naturally Explains the Abundance of Bright Galaxies at Cosmic Dawn
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15305v2.summary: Recent discoveries of a significant population of bright galaxies at cosmic dawn have enabled critical tests of cosmologicalgalaxy formation models. In particular, the bright end of the galaxy UVluminosity function (UVLF) appears higher than predicted by many models. Using approximately 25,000 galaxy snapshots, we show that the observed abundance of UV-bright galaxies is reproduced in these simulations with a multi-channel implementation of standard stellar feedback processes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12502v2.title: Varstrometry for Off-nucleus and Dual sub-Kpc AGN (VODKA). SDSS J1608+2716: A Sub-arcsec Quadruply Lensed Quasar at z=2.575
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12502v2.summary: Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) deep IR imaging of SDSS J1608+2716. This system, located at a redshift of 2.575, was recently reported as a triple quasar candidate. Findings indicate that this system is a quadruply lensed quasar.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04854v1.title: HI Rich but Low Star Formation galaxies in MaNGA: Physical Properties and Comparison to Control Samples
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04854v1.summary: Gas rich galaxies are typically star-forming. Out of 1575 MaNGA galaxies with HI-MaNGA detections, we find 83 (5%) to be HI rich with low SFR. Some galaxies in the sample are consistent with simply having their HI in a high angular momentum, large radius, low density disc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04772v1.title: Secondary cosmic-ray nuclei in the model of Galactic halo with nonlinear Landau damping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04772v1.summary: We employ our recent model of the cosmic-ray (CR) halo to compute the Galactic spectra of stable and unstable secondary nuclei. confinement of the Galactic CRs is entirely determined by the self-generated Alfvenic turbulence. We also show that agreement with observations at lower energies may be further improved by taking into account the effect of ion-neutral damping.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04714v1.title: Why should Models of Dwarf Galaxy Evolution care about the Initial Mass Function at low Star-formation Rates?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04714v1.summary: When star clusters are formed at low star-formation rates, their initial mass function (IMF) can hardly be filled continuously. Since galaxy evolution is strongly affected by massive stars,umerical models should account for this lack. The higher SFR of the truncated IMF in the simulation leads to more supernovae II (SNeII), driving Galactic winds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04677v1.title: Tracing the Energetic Outflows from Galactic Nuclei: Observational Evidence for a Large-Scale Bipolar Radio and X-ray-emitting Bubble-like Structure in M106
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04677v1.summary: The role of energetic outflows from galactic nuclei in shaping galaxyformation and evolution is still shrouded in uncertainty. This study presents evidence for a large-scale bipolar radio/X-ray-emitting bubble-like structure emanating from the nearby disk galaxy M106. The analysis of the X-ray data gives an estimate of the thermal energy of the bubbles as 8 x 10^56 erg.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04614v1.title: EIGER V. Characterizing the Host Galaxies of Luminous Quasars at $z\gtrsim6$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04614v1.summary: We report measurements of quasar host galaxy emissions and supermassive black hole (SMBH) masses. We obtain deep NIRCam imaging in the F115W, F200W, and F356W bands. Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) fitting suggests the host galaxies have stellar masses of $M_*\gtrsim10^{10}M_\odot$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00053v2.title: Structure, Kinematics, and Observability of the Large Magellanic Cloud's Dynamical Friction Wake in Cold vs. Fuzzy Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.00053v2.summary: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) will induce a dynamical friction (DF) wake on infall to the Milky Way. The MW's stellar halo will respond to the LMC and the dark matter (DM) wake, forming a stellar counterpart to the DM wake. This provides a novel opportunity to constrain the properties of the DM particle.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14786v2.title: Detecting Low-Mass Perturbers in Cluster Lenses using Curved Arc Bases
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14786v2.summary: Strong gravitationally lensed arcs produced by galaxy clusters have been detected for several decades now. We present a novel method to detect and measure individual perturbers (subhalos,line-of-sight halos, and wandering supermassive black holes) by exploiting their proximity to highly distorted lensed arc in galaxy clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04541v1.title: Dark Matter Fraction in Disk-Like Galaxies Over the Past 10 Gyr
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04541v1.summary: We present an observational study of the dark matter fraction in star-formingdisk-like galaxies up to redshift $z \sim 2.5$ We provide novel observational evidence, showing that at a fixed redshift, the darkmatter fraction gradually increases with radius. We observe adecreasing trend in the dark Matter fraction as baryon surface densities progressivelyincrease.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04535v1.title: Gravitational imaging through a triple source plane lens: revisiting the $Λ$CDM-defying dark subhalo in SDSSJ0946+1006
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04535v1.summary: Gravitational lens modelling has been used to measure the imprints of darksubstructures on lensed arcs. We present a case study of the unique compound gravitational lens SDSSJ0946+1006. A dark, massive substructure has been detected, whose reported high concentration would be unlikely in a $Lambda$CDM universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04532v1.title: The Global Structure of Molecular Clouds: I. Trends with Mass and Star Formation Rate
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04532v1.summary: We introduce a model for the large-scale, global 3D structure of molecularcularclouds. Motivated by the morphological appearance of clouds in surface densitymaps, we model clouds as cylinders. We find that cylindrical clouds can becharacterized by a universal structure that sets the timescale on which theyforming stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04529v1.title: JADES: Resolving the Stellar Component and Filamentary Overdense Environment of HST-Dark Submillimeter Galaxy HDF850.1 at $z=5.18$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04529v1.summary: HDF850.1 is the brightest submillimeter galaxy (SMG) in the Hubble DeepField. It is known as a heavily dust-obscured star-forming galaxy embedded in an overdense environment at $z = 5.18$. The galaxy hosts a stellar mass of $10^{11.0\pm0.1} and a star-formation rate of 10%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04525v1.title: Mapping dusty galaxy growth at $z>5$ with FRESCO: Detection of H$α$ in submm galaxy HDF850.1 and the surrounding overdense structures
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04525v1.summary: HDF850.1 shows a clear detection in the F444W imaging data, distributed between a northern and southern component, mirroring that seen in [CII] from the Plateau de Bure Interferometer. The northern component has a higher mass, star formation rate (SFR), and dust extinction than the southern component. The prominence of H$\alpha$ line emission from HDF850. 1 and other knownhighly-obscured $z>5$ galaxies illustrates the potential of NIRCam-grismprograms to map both the early build-up of IR-l

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04526v1.title: Synchrotron Emission on FIRE: Equipartition Estimators of Magnetic Fields in Simulated Galaxies with Spectrally-Resolved Cosmic Rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04526v1.summary: Synchrotron emission is one of few observable tracers of galactic magneticfields (\textbf{B}) and cosmic rays (CRs) It remains unclear how well these assumptions hold, and what these estimates physically represent. Using FIRE simulations, we present the first synthetic synch rotron emission predictions from galaxies with "live" CR-MHD.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04521v1.title: Deep Search For Molecular Oxygen in TW Hya
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04521v1.summary: Some models predict that gas-phase molecular oxygen (O$_2$) should be a major carrier of volatile oxygen in disks. No other major oxygen-carrying molecules have been detected. The dominant form of oxygen in cold molecular clouds is gas- phase carbon monoxide (CO)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04467v1.title: A search for faint resolved galaxies beyond the Milky Way in DES Year 6: A new faint, diffuse dwarf satellite of NGC 55
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04467v1.summary: We report results from a systematic wide-area search for faint dwarf galaxies at heliocentric distances from 0.3 to 2 Mpc. Unlike previous searches over the DES data, this search specifically targeted a field population of faint galaxies located beyond the Milky Way virial radius. We find no new field dwarfs in the DES footprint, but we report the discovery of one high-significance candidate dwarf galaxy. This is the largest, most diffuse galaxy known at this luminosity, suggesting possible tidal interactions with its host.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04466v1.title: The Local Group Symbiotic Star Population and its Weak Relation with Type Ia Supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04466v1.summary: Symbiotic stars (SySt) population and its relation with type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) in the galaxies of the Local Group. SySt are low-                and/or intermediate-mass evolved binary systems. A fraction of these WDs can become massive enough to reach the Chandrasekhar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04435v1.title: The evolution and impact of 3000 Msol stars in the early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04435v1.summary: We present evolutionary models of massive, accreting population III stars with constant and variable accretion rates until the end of silicon burning. In all our models, after the core-hydrogen burning phase, the star expands towards the red side of the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram. During core helium burning, the models exhibit an outer convective envelope as well as many large intermediate convective zones.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07072v4.title: JWST/NIRSpec Spectroscopy of $z=7-9$ Star Forming Galaxies with CEERS: New Insight into Bright Ly$α$ Emitters in Ionized Bubbles
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07072v4.summary: New JWST/NIRSpec observations of galaxies at $z\gtrsim7$ taken from the CEERS survey. Previous observations of this area have revealed associations of Ly$\alpha$ emitters at redshifts ($z=7.5, $7.7, $8.7)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04392v1.title: The impermanent fate of massive stars in AGN disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04392v1.summary: Stars are likely to form or to be captured in AGN disks. Their mass reaches equilibrium when their rate of accretion is balanced by that of wind. If the exchanged gas is well mixed with the stellar core, this metabolic process would sustain an "immortal" state on the main sequence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03276v2.title: A complete catalogue of merger fractions in AGN hosts: No evidence for an increase in detected merger fraction with AGN luminosity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03276v2.summary: Major mergers of galaxies contribute strongly to AGNfuelling, particularly at high AGN luminosities. Some studies find a strong connection between mergers and AGN, while others find merger fractions in AGN hosts to match those in the inactive galaxy population. We assess if discrepancies between studies are indicative of systematic uncertainties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06904v2.title: The Kinematics, Metallicities, and Orbits of Six Recently Discovered Galactic Star Clusters with Magellan/M2FS Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06904v2.summary: We present Magellan/M2FS spectroscopy of four recently discovered Milky Way star clusters. We measure line-of-sight velocities and stellar parameters. We identify 20-80 members per star cluster. We determine thekinematics and chemical properties of each cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04285v1.title: Andromeda's Parachute: Time Delays and Hubble Constant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04285v1.summary: The gravitational lens system PS J0147+4630 (Andromeda's Parachute) consists of four quasar images ABCD and a lensing galaxy. We obtained $r$-band light-curves of ABCD in the 2017$-$2022 period from monitoring with two 2-m class Telescopes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04260v1.title: High-resolution APEX/LAsMA $^{12}$CO and $^{13}$CO (3-2) observation of the G333 giant molecular cloud complex : II. Survival and gravitational collapse of dense gas structures under feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04260v1.summary: We investigate the physical properties of gas structures under feedback in the G333 complex using data of the 13CO (3-2) line in the LAsMA observation. We find that external pressure from the surrounding cloud plays an important role in confining the observed gas structures. Although the feedback disrupting the molecular clouds will break up the original cloud complex, the substructures of the original complex can be reorganized into new gravitationally governed configurations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04239v1.title: Investigating a Global Collapsing Hub-Filament Cloud G326.611+0.811
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04239v1.summary: We present the dynamics study toward the G326.611+0.811 (G326)hub-filament-system (HFS) cloud using the new APEX observations. The G326 HFS cloud constitutes a central hub and at least four hub-composing filaments that are divided into a major branch and a side branch. Along the five filaments, the velocity gradients are found in both $^{13}$CO and C$^{18}$O (J = 2-1) emission, suggesting that the filament-aligned gravitational collapse toward the central hub is being

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04234v1.title: Astrometric VLBI observations of H$_2$O masers in an extreme OH/IR star candidate NSV17351
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04234v1.summary: Results of astrometric very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) observations toward an extreme OH/IR star candidate NSV17351 are presented. We derived an annual parallax of 0.247$\pm$0.035 maswhich corresponds to a distance of 4.05$Â£0.59 kpc. We confirmed that the time variation of H$_2$O masers can be used as a period estimator of variable OH/ IR stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01544v2.title: SDSS-IV MaNGA: Ionization sources of diffuse extra-planar galactic medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01544v2.summary: We explore sources of ionization of diffuse gas at different altitudes in                galaxies in dependence of their stellar mass, luminosity, and specific star formation rate. We use the MaNGA data from SDSS-IV data release DR16 and photoionization and shock ionization models provided by the 3MdB database.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04173v1.title: Magnetic Fields and Velocity Gradients in L1551: The Role of Stellar Feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04173v1.summary: Magnetic fields play a crucial role in star formation, yet tracing them can be difficult. We targeted the star-forming region L1551, notable for its apparent outflows, to investigate the magnetic fields. All three measurements show that the                magnetic fields twist towards the protostar IRS 5. This suggests that the outflows might be dynamically significant.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19986v3.title: Tripotential MOND theories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19986v3.summary: I present a new class of nonrelativistic, modified-gravity MOND theories. The transition from the Newtonian to the MOND regime is rather richer than in the aquadratic-Lagrangiantheory (AQUAL) and the quasilinear MOND theory (QUMOND) These theories all make the salient, primary MOND predictions. Yet they can differ materially onsecondary predictions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02713v2.title: Seen and unseen: bursty star formation and its implications for observations of high-redshift galaxies with JWST

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09940v1.title: Testing the near-far connection with FIRE simulations: inferring the stellar mass function of the proto-Local Group at z > 6 using the fossil record of present-day galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09940v1.summary: The shape of the low-mass (faint) end of the galaxy stellar mass function (SMF) or ultraviolet luminosity function (UVLF) at z > 6 is an open question. Resolvedphotometry allows us to reconstruct starformation histories, stellar masses, and UV luminosities at early times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09909v1.title: Radio multifrequency observations of Abell~781 with the WSRT

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01681v2.title: The dust enrichment of early galaxies in the JWST and ALMA era

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03186v2.title: HCN emission from translucent gas and UV-illuminated cloud edges revealed by wide-field IRAM 30m maps of Orion B GMC: Revisiting its role as tracer of the dense gas reservoir for star formation

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09766v1.title: Calibrating baryonic feedback with weak lensing and fast radio bursts

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00999v2.title: Primordial power spectrum in light of JWST observations of high redshift galaxies

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09691v1.title: TeV gamma-ray sensitivity to velocity-dependent dark matter models in the Galactic Center

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09687v1.title: The Cygnus Allscale Survey of Chemistry and Dynamical Environments: CASCADE. II. A detailed kinematic analysis of the DR21 Main outflow

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09683v1.title: TRAO Survey of Nearby Filamentary Molecular clouds, the Universal Nursery of Stars (TRAO-FUNS). III. Filaments and dense cores in the NGC 2068 and NGC 2071 regions of Orion B

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11790v2.title: Velocity dispersion of dark matter deficient ultra-diffuse galaxies: A case for modified gravity

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13190v3.title: Numerical models of planetary nebulae with different episodes of mass ejection: the particular case of HuBi 1

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.01330v2.title: A comparison of the Milky Way's recent star formation revealed by dust thermal emission and high-mass stars

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09585v1.title: A MUSE/VLT spatially resolved study of the emission structure of Green Pea galaxies

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02722v3.title: Exploring the Angular Momentum -- Atomic Gas Content Connection with EAGLE and IllustrisTNG

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19978v2.title: On the fundamentality of the radial acceleration relation for late-type galaxy dynamics

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04392v2.title: The impermanent fate of massive stars in AGN disks

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09544v1.title: Opacities of dense gas tracers in galactic massive star-forming regions

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00026v3.title: 3D-Spatiotemporal Forecasting the Expansion of Supernova Shells Using Deep Learning toward High-Resolution Galaxy Simulations

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10012v2.title: Simulating supermassive black hole mass measurements for a sample of ultra massive galaxies using ELT/HARMONI high spatial resolution integral-field stellar kinematics

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09385v1.title: A Data-Driven Model for Abundances in Metal-poor Stars and Implications for Nucleosynthetic Sources

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09293v1.title: Star formation in CALIFA survey perturbed galaxies.III. Stellar & ionized-gas kinematic distributions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09293v1.summary: We obtain the kinematic distributions of stars and ionized gas for star-forming regions in CALIFA survey tidally perturbed (perturbed) and non-tidallyperturbed (control) galaxies. In perturbed galaxies, median velocity dispersions for thestellar and gaseous components are minimally higher and equal, respectively, than those in control galaxies. Unlike the well-known trend in strongly interacting systems, the stellar and ionize-gasmotions are not disturbed by the influence of close companions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09232v1.title: Preliminary characterization of an active spiral galaxy near m57
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09232v1.summary: M57 is one of the most observed and popular planetary nebulae. At a greater angular distance from M57 and IC 1296, there is a very faint object called WISEA J185309.64+330538.7. The author presents preliminary results of the spectral analyses of both galaxies, obtained at the Skinakas Observatory in Greece.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09046v1.title: Starbursts driven by central gas compaction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09046v1.summary: Starburst (SB) galaxies are a rare population of galaxies with star formation rates greatly exceeding those of the majority of star-forming galaxies. Tidal torques resulting from gas-rich galaxy mergers are known to enhance the SFR by funneling gas towards the centre. The driving mechanism behind the SB varies depending on the mass of the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08028v3.title: The impact of baryonic potentials on the gravothermal evolution of self-interacting dark matter haloes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08028v3.summary: The presence of a central baryonic potential can have a significant impact on the gravothermal evolution of self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) haloes. The presence of the potential induces changes in SIDM haloproperties, including central density, core size, and velocity dispersion, and accelerates the halo's evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09031v1.title: Formation of dense filaments induced by runaway supermassive black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09031v1.summary: A narrow linear object extending 60kpc from the centre of a galaxy at $z \sim 1$ has been recently discovered. The host galaxy presents an irregular morphology,implying recent merger events. We find that the CGM temperature prior to the RSMBH perturbation should be below the peak temperature in the cooling function to trigger star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09015v1.title: The PCA Filtering method for an unbiased spectral survey of Complex Organic Molecules (COMs)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09015v1.summary: In the protostellar and protoplanetaryenvironments, their complex kinematics make line profiles blend each other and the line strength of weak lines weaker. We develop a filtering method which can extract COM spectra from the main kinematic component associated with COMemission and increase the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of spectra. This method corrects non-Gaussian line profiles caused by the kinematically.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08998v1.title: Understanding the Kinetic Energy deposition within Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08998v1.summary: We investigate the contributions of their internal gas motions and relative motions to the total velocity dispersions of MCs. We find that the contribution of the relative.motion between $^{13}$CO structures is larger than that from their internal. gas motion. This result provides a manifestation of the macro-turbulent within MCs, which gradually becomes the dominant way to store the kinetic energy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08992v1.title: Rotational spectroscopy of the thioformaldehyde isotopologues H$_2$CS and H$_2$C$^{34}$S in four interacting excited vibrational states and an account on the rotational spectrum of thioketene, H$_2$CCS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08992v1.summary: An investigation of the rotational spectrum of the interstellar moleculethioformaldehyde between 110 and 377 GHz through a pyrolysis reaction revealed a multitude of absorption lines. The $v_2 = 1$ state has been included in analyses of low-lying fundamental states of H$_2$CS for the first time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08986v1.title: Discovery of a Planar Black Hole Mass Scaling Relation for Spiral Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08986v1.summary: Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) are tiny in comparison to the galaxies they reside in. Yet they manage to influence and coevolve along with their hosts. Evidence of this mutual development is observed in the structure and dynamics of galaxies and their correlations with black hole mass. We focus on relative parameters that are unique to only disk grotesquegalaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08930v1.title: Radial Outflow Explains the Rotation Curves of Disk Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08930v1.summary: Circular velocities of the inner region of disk galaxies are predicted by Newtonian physics. But the material there is not gravitationally bound and so does not trace the gravitational field in the way that is usually assumed. In fact, the circular velocity can exceed the escape velocity so that these galaxies are gravitationly unstable.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05808v2.title: Sampling the Faraday rotation sky of TNG50: Imprint of the magnetised circumgalactic medium around Milky Way-like galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.05808v2.summary: Faraday rotation measure (RM) is arguably the most practical observationaltracer of magnetic fields in the diffuse circumgalactic medium (CGM) We sample synthetic Faraday rotation skies of Milky Way-like galaxies in TNG50 of theIllustrisTNG project by placing an observer inside the galaxies at a solarcircle-like position.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07834v2.title: DUALZ: Deep UNCOVER-ALMA Legacy High-Z Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07834v2.summary: DUALZ aims to establish a joint ALMA and JWST public legacy field targeting the massive galaxy cluster Abell 2744. DUALZ features a contiguous $4'\times6'$ ALMA 30-GHz-wide mosaic in Band 6. We have identified 8 HST-dark galaxies and 2 JW ST-dark galaxy candidates among the ALMA continuum sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08831v1.title: Global kinematics study of OH masers in W49N
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08831v1.summary: Star formation is underway in the W49N molecular cloud (MC) with almost twenty ultra-compact (UC) HII regions observed. Previous works have suggested that this cloud is undergoing a global contraction. We analysed the data on OH masers in the molecular cloud, observed with the VLBA.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08683v1.title: Shining Light on the Hosts of the Nano-Hertz Gravitational Wave Sources: A Theoretical Perspective
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08683v1.summary: The formation of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in the Universe is one of the open questions inastrophysics and cosmology. gravitational waves (GW) bring anindependent avenue to detect numerous binary SMBHs in the observable Universe. The masses of the sources show a correlation with the halo mass and stellar mass of the host galaxies. This theoretical study will help in understanding the host properties of the GW sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08675v1.title: The DESI One-Percent Survey: Evidence for Assembly Bias from Low-Redshift Counts-in-Cylinders Measurements
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08675v1.summary: We model the halo occupation distribution from z=0.1-0.3 using Survey Validation 3 (SV3) data of the DESI Bright Galaxy Survey (BGS) We incorporate counts-in-cylinders (CiC) measurements, which drastically tighten HOD constraints. Our models also favor positive central assembly bias for brighter galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08669v1.title: Measuring the physical imprints of gas flows in galaxies I: Accretion rate histories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08669v1.summary: Galaxies are expected to accrete pristine gas from their surroundings to sustain their star formation over cosmic timescales. Its lower abundance vehementlyaffects the metallicity of the ISM in which stars are born, leaving chemicalimprints in the stellar populations. More massive galaxies accrete more gas and at higher redshifts than less massive galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08660v1.title: Astronomaly at Scale: Searching for Anomalies Amongst 4 Million Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08660v1.summary: Modern astronomical surveys are producing datasets of unprecedented size andrichness. This has led to the development of novel machine-learning-based anomaly detection approaches. We test the scalability of Astronomaly by applying it to almost 4 million images of galaxies from the Dark Energy Camera Legacy Survey. We find 1635 anomalies among the top 2000 sources in the dataset.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08661v1.title: Dark Matter-Induced Baryonic Feedback in Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08661v1.summary: We demonstrate that non-gravitational interactions between dark matter and                baryonic matter can affect structural properties of galaxies. Dark matter which collects inside white dwarf stars and ignites Type Ia supernovae can substantially alter star formation, stellar feedback, and the halo density profile.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08653v1.title: What can galaxy shapes tell us about physics beyond the standard model?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08653v1.summary: We present a general study into the observational consequences of vector and tensor modes in the early and late Universe. Shear is found to be a powerful probe of cosmic strings. Flexion adds little to the constraining power except on very small scales. Such probes could be used to constrain new physics proposed to explain recent pulsar timing arrayobservations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08657v1.title: On the Red Supergiant Wind Kink. A Universal mass-loss concept for massive stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08657v1.summary: Red supergiants (RSG) are key objects for the evolution of massive stars and their endpoints. uncertainties in their underlying mass-loss mechanism have prevented an appropriate framework for massive star evolution. We argue that a universalbehaviour of radiation-driven winds across the HR diagram, independent of the exact source of opacity, is a key feature of the most massive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08658v1.title: Taking the Milky Way for a spin: disc formation in the ARTEMIS simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08658v1.summary: In almost all galaxies discs spin up at a higher [Fe/H] than the Milky Way. Those that contain an analogue of the Gaia Sausage-Enceladus (GSE) spin up with a lower average metallicity than those without. The fraction of stars accreted from outside the host galaxy is smaller in galaxies with earlier spin-ups.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08605v1.title: The IA Guide: A Breakdown of Intrinsic Alignment Formalisms
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08605v1.summary: Intrinsic Alignments refers to physical correlations involving galaxy shapes, galaxy spins, and the underlying cosmic web. Its characterization is an important aspect of modern cosmology, particularly in weak lensing analyses. This resource is both a reference for those already familiar with IA anddesigned to introduce someone to the field by drawing from various studies and references.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08592v1.title: Confirmation of an anomalously low dark matter content for the galaxy NGC1052-DF4 from deep, high resolution continuum spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08592v1.summary: NGC1052-DF4 was found to be the second "galaxy lacking dark matter" in the NGC1052 group. We observed the diffuse stellar light in the galaxy with the Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI) in its highest resolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14775v2.title: The stability of some galaxy disks is still perplexing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14775v2.summary: The problem of how some disk galaxies avoid forming bars remains unsolved. The unstable mode that creates a bar is understood as a standing wave in a cavity that reflects off the disk center and the corotation radius. No widely-accepted idea has yet been advanced to account for how some Disk galaxies manage to avoid this instability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08515v1.title: MIDIS. JWST NIRCam and MIRI unveil the stellar population properties of Ly$α$-emitters and Lyman-Break galaxies at z ~ 3-7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08515v1.summary: We study the stellar population properties of 182 spectroscopically-confirmed(MUSE/VLT) Lyman-$\alpha$ emitters (LAEs) and 450 photometrically-selectedLyman-Break galaxies (LBGs) at z = 2.8 - 6.7 in the Hubble eXtreme Deep Field(XDF) Leveraging the combined power of HST and JWST NIRCam and MIRI, we analyse their rest-frame UV-through-near-IR spectral energy distributions (SEDs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.10354v2.title: Neutron Star Mergers and their Impact on Second Generation Star Formation in the Early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.10354v2.summary: The exact evolution of elements in the universe, from primordial to heavier elements produced via the r-process, is still under scrutiny. We study the scenario where a single NSmerger (NSM) enriches a halo early in its evolution to understand the impact on second generation of stars and their metal abundances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08466v1.title: Iron K-alpha echoes from the circumnuclear disk orbiting Sgr A*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08466v1.summary: Molecular clouds in the Galactic center (GC) reprocess radiation from past high-energy sources, generating a bright Fe K-alphafluorescence at 6.4 keV. The study of fluorescence emission can lead to a characterization of the source-reflector system's global geometry.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13548v2.title: Dynamical friction of a massive black hole in a turbulent gaseous medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13548v2.summary: orbital decay of massive black holes in galaxies is at the heart of whether black holes successfully pair and merge. The role of dynamical friction sourced from the gas distribution has been uncertain. We find that the black hole slows down to the sound speed, rather than the turbulent speed, and that the orbital decay is well captured if the Bondi-Hoyle-Lyttleton radius is resolved.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08403v1.title: The stratification of ISM properties in the edge-on galaxy NGC 891 revealed by NIKA2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08403v1.summary: The IMEGIN large program aims to map the millimeter Continuinguum emission of 22 nearby galaxies at 1.15 and 2 mm. Using the NIKA2 camera, we explore the existence of very cold dust and take possible contamination by free-free and synchrotron emission into account.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09459v2.title: The first detection of SiC$_2$ in the interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09459v2.summary: We report the first detection of SiC$_2$ in the interstellar medium. The molecule was identified through six rotational transitions toward G\,+0.693$-$0.027, a molecular cloud located in the Galactic center. It can be formed by a reaction between the sputtered atomic silicon and the silicon atoms in dust grains.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04741v2.title: Reionization and the ISM/Stellar Origins with JWST and ALMA (RIOJA): The core of the highest redshift galaxy overdensity at $z = 7.88$ confirmed by NIRSpec/JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04741v2.summary: The core of the most distant protocluster at $z = 7.88$, A2744-z7p9OD, has been confirmed by James Webb Space Telescope NIRSpec integral field unit spectroscopy. The core region includes as many as 4 galaxies detected in [OIII] 4960 \AA\ and 5008:\AA\ in a small area.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08293v1.title: A theoretical approach to the complex chemical evolution of phosphorus in the interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08293v1.summary: phosphorus chemistry in the interstellar medium has become a topic of growing interest in astrobiology. P mainly appears in the form of PO and PN in molecular clouds and star-forming regions. PO is systematically more abundant than PN by factors typically typically of $1.4-3$, independently of the physical properties of the observedsource.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14509v2.title: CEERS MIRI Imaging: Data Reduction and Quality Assessment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14509v2.summary: The Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science Survey (CEERS) is targeting the Extended Groth Strip extragalactic field. To date, all observations have been executed and include NIRCam/MIRI imaging and NIRSpec/NIRCam spectroscopicexposures. We present asummary of the data, the data quality, and data reduction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08242v1.title: Spatially-resolved spectroscopic investigation of the born-again planetary nebula A 78
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08242v1.summary: We present the analysis of spatially-resolved spectroscopic observations of the born-again planetary nebula (PN) A 78. The low N/O ratio and He/Habundances of the outer shell are indicative of a low-mass progenitor. Dust-rich material seems to diffuse into outer nebular regions, resulting in enhanced extinction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08098v1.title: The creation of a massive UCD by tidal threshing from NGC 936
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08098v1.summary: We study a compact nucleus embedded in an early-type dwarf galaxy, MATLAS-167, which is in the process of disruption by the tidal force of the neighboring giant S0 galaxy, NGC 936. We find that NGC936_UCD is significantly larger and brighter compared to the typical UCDpopulations observed in the Virgo cluster. Our findings suggest that tidal threshing is a possibleformation mechanism of bright UCD populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07208v2.title: Tilted Dark Halos are Common, Long-Lived, and can Warp Galactic Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07208v2.summary: In the $\Lambda$-CDM paradigm, the dark halo governs the gravitational potential within which a galaxy can form and evolve. We show that the present-day inner ($r<50\text{ kpc}$) dark h Halo can be significantly misaligned with the stellar disk. Such "tilted" dark halos can arise from a variety of processes including major mergers,massive fly-bys, or interactions with satellite companions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08078v1.title: A sub-pc BBH system in SDSS J1609+1756 through optical QPOs in ZTF light curves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08078v1.summary: optical quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) are the most preferred signs of sub-pc binary black hole (BBH) systems in AGN. Four different methods are applied to analyze the years-long ZTF g/r/i-band light curves of SDSS J1609+1756.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07590v2.title: Sciences with the 2.5-meter Wide Field Survey Telescope (WFST)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07590v2.summary: The Wide Field Survey Telescope (WFST) is a dedicated photometric surveyingfacility being built jointly by the University of Science and Technology of                China and the Purple Mountain Observatory. It is equipped with a 2.5-meter primary mirror, an active optics system, and a mosaic CCD camera with                0.73 gigapixels on the primary focal plane for high-quality image capture.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04828v2.title: Orbital support and evolution of flat profiles of bars (shoulders)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04828v2.summary: Many barred galaxies exhibit upturns (shoulders) in their bar major-axisdensity profile. Simulation studies have suggested that shoulders are supported by looped $x_1$ orbits, occur in growing bars, and can appear after bar-buckling. We investigate the orbital support and evolution of shoulders viafrequency analyses of orbits in simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07969v1.title: A massive compact quiescent galaxy at z=2 with a complete Einstein ring in JWST imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07969v1.summary: Massive galaxies formed inside-out, with their cores largely in place by z~2 and approximately half of their present-daymass added later through minor mergers. The ring was found in the JWST COSMOS-Web survey and is produced by a background galaxy at 2.98 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12805v3.title: JADES: Discovery of extremely high equivalent width Lyman-alpha emission from a faint galaxy within an ionized bubble at z=7.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12805v3.summary: JADES-GS-z7-LA, with EW$_0$(Ly$\alpha$) $= 388.0 \pm 88.8$\AA and UVmagnitude -17.0. The spectroscopic redshift is confirmed via rest-frame opticallines [O II], H$\beta$ and [O III] in its JWST/NIRSpec Micro-Shutter Assembly(MSA) spectrum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07960v1.title: Energy balance SED modelling can be effective at high redshifts regardless of UV-FIR offsets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07960v1.summary: Energy balance spectral energy distribution (SED) fitting codes may be of limited use for studying high-redshift galaxies. We test how well the SED fitting code Magphys can recover the stellar mass, star formation rate, specific SFR, dust mass and luminosity. Overall, we obtain acceptable fits for 83 per cent of the synthetic SEDs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07955v1.title: Quokka-based Understanding of Outflows (QED) I. Metal loading, phase structure, and convergence testing for Solar neighbourhood conditions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07955v1.summary: Multiphase galactic outflows, generated by supernova feedback, are likely to be more metal-rich than the interstellar media from which they are driven. This is due to incomplete mixing between supernova ejecta and the ambient ISM. But measuring it quantitatively from simulations requires resolution high enough to resolve mass, momentum and energy exchanges.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07957v1.title: Spatially resolved Kennicutt-Schmidt relation at z~7 and its connection with the interstellar medium properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07957v1.summary: We exploit moderately resolved [OIII], [CII] and dust continuum ALMAobservations to derive the gas density ($n$), the gas-phase metallicity ($Z$) and the deviation from the Kennicutt-Schmidt (KS) relation ($\kappa_s) on interstellar medium scales. We use GLAM, a state-of-art, physically motivated Bayesian model. All five sources are characterized by a central starbursting region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07958v1.title: Characterising the true descendants of the first stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07958v1.summary: The metal-poor stars in the Galactic halo are thought to show the imprints of the first (PopIII) stars. In this work, we aim at understanding whether all very metal- poor stars formed in environments polluted by PopIII supernovae (SNe) and if so, at what level.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07919v1.title: Expanding on the Fundamental Metallicity Relation in Dwarf Galaxies with MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07919v1.summary: The mass-metallicity relation (MZR) represents one of the most important scaling relations in galaxy evolution. We investigate the FMR in nine nearby, spatially-resolved, dwarf galaxies. We find that the SFR surface density - metallicity anti-correlation is tighter in low-mass galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07912v1.title: An Observationally Driven Multifield Approach for Probing the Circum-Galactic Medium with Convolutional Neural Networks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07912v1.summary: The circum-galactic medium (CGM) can feasibly be mapped by multiwavelengthsurveys covering broad swaths of the sky. We develop a likelihood-free Deep Learningtechnique using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to infer broad-scale physical properties of a galaxy's CGM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16050v2.title: JWST reveals widespread CO ice and gas absorption in the Galactic Center cloud G0.253+0.016
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16050v2.summary: We report JWST NIRCam observations of G0.253+0.016, the molecular cloud in the Central Molecular Zone known as The Brick. We catalog 56,146 stars detected in all 6                filters using the crowdsource package. Stars within and behind The Brick demonstrate prodigious absorption in the F466N filter that is produced by a combination of CO ice and gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.09266v2.title: Revisiting Andromeda's Parachute
