http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.09266v2.summary: The gravitational lens system PS J0147+4630 (Andromeda's Parachute) consists of four quasar images ABCD and a lensing galaxy. We obtained $r$-band light curves of ABCD in the 2017$-$2021 period from a monitoring with two 2-m classtelescopes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05332v2.title: A self-gravity module for the PLUTO code
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05332v2.summary: We present a novel implementation of an iterative solver for the solution of the Poisson equation in the PLUTO code for astrophysical fluid dynamics. Our findings show that the RKL-based Poisson solver is both fully parallel andrapidly convergent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07854v1.title: A Differentiable Model of the Evolution of Dark Matter Halo Concentration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07854v1.summary: We introduce a new model of the evolution of the concentration of dark matter. For individual halos, our model approximates c(t) as a power law with a time-dependent index. At early times, concentration has a nearly constant value of c=3-4, and as cosmic time progresses, c( t) smoothlyincreases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07833v1.title: Infrared spectroscopy of SWIFT J0850.8-4219: Identification of the second red supergiant X-ray binary in the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07833v1.summary: High mass X-ray binaries hosting red supergiant (RSG) donors are a rare butcrucial phase in massive stellar evolution. Only one source previously known in the Milky Way. We identify the source as SWIFT J0850.8-4219.14 as the likely infrared counterpart.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07751v1.title: Host Galaxy Dispersion Measure of Fast Radio Burst
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07751v1.summary: Fast radio bursts are a class of transient radio sources that are thought to originate from extragalactic sources. Host Galaxies of twenty-two fast radio bursts have already been identified. The dispersion measurement of these fast radiobursts produced by the Milky Way interstellar medium is obtained through known physical models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07746v1.title: Gas absorption towards the eta Tel debris disc: winds or clouds?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07746v1.summary: eta Telescopii is a ~23 Myr old A-type star surrounded by an edge-on debris hypothesized to harbour gas. Recent analysis of far- and near-ultraviolet observations of eta Tel found absorption features at ~-23 km/s. This strongly implies that the absorption lines previously attributed to circumstellar gas are more likely due to an interstellar cloud traversing the line of sight.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05841v2.title: WALLABY Pilot Survey: the Potential Polar Ring Galaxies NGC~4632 and NGC~6156
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05841v2.summary: We report on the discovery of two potential polar ring galaxies (PRGs) in the WALLABY Pilot Data Release 1 (PDR1) These untargetted detections are some of the first galaxies where observations show two distinct components. We have generated plausible 3D kinematic models for each galaxy assuming that the rings are circular and inclined at 90 degrees to the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07732v1.title: Finding substructures in protostellar disks in Ophiuchus
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07732v1.summary: High-resolution, millimeter observations of disks at the protoplanetary stage show substructures such as gaps, rings, arcs, spirals, and cavities. The presence of these features at the earliest stages suggests an early start for dust graingrowth and, subsequently, planet formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07653v1.title: Discerning Parallax Amplitude in Astrometric Microlensing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07653v1.summary: Gravitational microlensing is a powerful method for discovering IsolatedStellar-Mass Black Holes (ISMBHs) We numerically investigate the possibility of inferring parallax amplitude from astrometric deflections in ISMBH events. We assume these events are potentially detected in upcomingmicrolensingsurveys of the Galactic bulge.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07622v1.title: The very compact dust disk in the Red Rectangle
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07622v1.summary: Most of the dust emission in the Red Rectangle is concentrated in the inner disk regions, with a typical size of 250 AU in diameter. The settlement of dust grains onto innerequatorial regions is remarkable when compared with the relatively widespread gas distribution. This region is basically coincident with the warm PDR(photo-dominated region) where CI, CII, and certain molecules such as HCN are presumably formed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07619v1.title: A revised age greater than 50 Myr for the young cluster IC 4665
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07619v1.summary: IC 4665 is one of only a dozen young open clusters with a "lithium depletionboundary" (LDB) age. Re-analysis of archival spectra suggests that the LDB of IC 4665 has not been detected and that the published LDB age should be interpreted as alower limit.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07613v1.title: The dusty heart of Circinus II. Scrutinizing the LM-band dust morphology using MATISSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07613v1.summary: In this paper we present the first-ever $L$- and $M$-band interferometricobservations of Circinus. We used these observations to reconstruct images and fit Gaussian models. Our findings reveal a thin edge-on disk whose width is marginallyresolved. We also demonstrate that there is notrace of direct sightlines to hot dust surfaces.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06012v2.title: Blue Large-Amplitude Pulsators and Other Short-Period Variable Stars in the OGLE-IV Galactic Disk Fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06012v2.summary: Blue Large-Amplitude Pulsators (BLAPs) form a mysterious class of variablestars with typical periods of tens of minutes and amplitudes above 0.1 mag. Twenty-five BLAPs have been detected, 20 of which are new discoveries. We have also found six new eclipsing binary systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07497v1.title: Kinetic Study of the Gas-Phase Reaction between Atomic Carbon and Acetone. Low Temperature Rate Constants and Hydrogen Atom Product Yields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07497v1.summary: Reactions of ground state atomic carbon, C(3P), are likely to beimportant in astrochemistry due to the high abundance levels of these atoms in the interstellar medium. Here we present a study of the gas-phasereaction between C( 3P) and acetone, CH3COCH3.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07494v1.title: Preprocessing in small groups: Three simulated galaxies interacting prior to cluster infall
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07494v1.summary: The formation of galaxy clusters is a complicated process that probablyinvolves the accretion of galaxies in groups, as observed in nearby clusters, such as Virgo and Fornax. The members of the groups undergo "preprocessing" prior to cluster infall, which affects their stellar populations andmorphology. In this paper I present an extreme example of such an accretion event selected from the IllustrisTNG100 simulation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07480v1.title: The growth history of local M33-mass bulgeless spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07480v1.summary: We construct a simple chemical evolution model by assuming that discs grow gradually with continuous metal-free gas infall and metal-enriched gas outflow. The model results are in excellent agreement with the general predictions of the inside-out growth scenario for the evolution of spiral galaxies. About 80\% of the stellar mass of NGC\,7793 is assembled within the last 8\,Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07421v1.title: Where are the Pevatrons that Form the Knee in the Spectrum of the Cosmic Ray Nucleon Component around 4 PeV?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07421v1.summary: The paper discusses an approach that made it possible to estimate the distance to the nearest pevatrons, which form a knee in the spectrum of the cosmic cosmic ray nucleon component of about $4$ PeV. It is based on the spectra of                nucleons and electrons obtained by the authors in the framework of thesuperdiffusion model of nonclassical cosmic rays diffusion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07420v1.title: A new break near 10 TeV in the energy spectrum of protons according to data from space-based instruments: astrophysical interpretation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07420v1.summary: The energy spectrum of particles in the Earth's atmosphere is between 2.5 and 3.5 times the speed of light. This is due to the fact that the Earth is surrounded by a large area of space-time. The energy of the particles is determined by the distance from the Earth to the source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04466v2.title: The Local Group Symbiotic Star Population and its Weak Relation with Type Ia Supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04466v2.summary: Symbiotic stars (SySt) population and its relation with type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) in the galaxies of the Local Group. SySt are low-                and/or intermediate-mass evolved binary systems. A fraction of these WDs can become massive enough to reach the Chandrasekhar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07348v1.title: Predicting reliable H$_2$ column density maps from molecular line data using machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07348v1.summary: The total mass estimate of molecular clouds suffers from the uncertainty in the H$_2$-CO conversion factor. We demonstrate the machine learning's ability to predict column density from the data set of Orion A, Orion B, Aquila, and M17. We also demonstrated that this method could predict the columndensity toward the area not observed by Herschel.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07341v1.title: Astrochemical Modeling of Propargyl Radical Chemistry in TMC-1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07341v1.summary: The propargyl radical is an important aromatic precursor in combustion flames and possibly interstellar environments. We performed astrochemical modeling of TMC-1 using the three-phase gas-grain code NAUTILUS and an updated chemicalnetwork. Predicted abundances for the related C4H3N isomers within an order of magnitude of observed values corroborate the high efficiency of CN addition to closed-shellHydrocarbons under dark molecular cloud conditions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07326v1.title: The JWST Discovery of the Triply-imaged Type Ia "Supernova H0pe" and Observations of the Galaxy Cluster PLCK G165.7+67.0
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07326v1.summary: A Type Ia supernova (SN) at $z=1.78$ was discovered in James Webb SpaceTelescope Near Infrared Camera imaging of the galaxy cluster PLCK G165.7+67.0(G165; $z = 0.35$). The SN is situated 1.5-2kpc from its host galaxy Arc 2 and appears in three different locations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07321v1.title: Why does the Milky Way have a bar?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07321v1.summary: The Milky Way is a barred galaxy, but factors that establish its prominent morphology remain largely elusive. We find that the strength of the MW's bars at $z=0$ correlates well not only with the total mass build-up of galaxies but also with the time of rapid onset of stellar discs. We conclude that the presence of a strong bar in the MW is a natural manifestation of the early formation of the stellar disc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08056v2.title: A multi-tracer empirically-driven approach to line-intensity mapping lightcones
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08056v2.summary: Line-intensity mapping (LIM) is an emerging technique to probe the large-scale structure of the Universe. By targeting the integrated intensity of specific spectral lines, it captures the emission from all sources. Relating processes to the underlying distribution of matter introduces observational and theoretical challenges.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07256v1.title: Refractive lensing of scintillating FRBs by sub-parsec cloudlets in the multi-phase CGM
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07256v1.summary: We consider the refractive lensing effects of ionized cool gas cloudlets in the circumgalactic medium (CGM) of galaxies. We show that, if the CGM comprises a mist of sub-parsec cloudlets, then FRBs whose sightlines pass within a virial radius of a CGM will generically be lensed into tens of refractive images. These images will be resolved by plasma screens in the Milky Way interstellar medium, and therefore are expected to suppress scintillation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07241v1.title: PG1004+130: Hybrid Morphology Source or a Restarted FRII? A uGMRT Polarimetric Investigation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07241v1.summary: P polarization image of the hybrid morphology (HYMOR) andbroad-absorption line (BAL) quasar PG1004+130 at 694~MHz. The visible discontinuity in totalintensity between the inner jets and the kpc-scale lobes suggests that the source is restarted. The inferred poloidal magnetic (B-) field structure in theinner jet is consistent with that observed in Fanaroff-Riley (FR) type II sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07219v1.title: Smooth kinematic and metallicity gradients between the Milky Way's nuclear star cluster and nuclear stellar disc. Different components of the same structure?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07219v1.summary: The innermost regions of most galaxies are characterised by the presence of extremely dense nuclear star clusters. The Milky Way's centre, at only 8 kpc, hosts a nuclear star cluster and a nuclear stellar disc, constituting a unique template to understand their relation and formation scenario. We aim to study the kinematics and stellar metallicity of stars from the Milky Way’s nuclear star Cluster and disc to shed light on the relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07209v1.title: A Tilted Dark Halo Origin of the Galactic Disk Warp and Flare
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07209v1.summary: The outer disk of the Milky Way Galaxy is warped and flared. This misalignment of the dark halo and the disk holds clue to the history of the Galaxy. It represents the next step in the dynamicalmodeling of the Galactic potential. The results provide compelling evidence that our Galaxy is embedded in a tilted dark matter halo.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07210v1.title: TRINITY IV: Predictions for Supermassive Black Holes at $z \gtrsim 7$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07210v1.summary: We present predictions for the high-redshift halo-galaxy-supermassive blackhole (SMBH) connection from the TRINITY model. The number of SMBHs with $M_\bullet > 10^9 M_\odot$ in the observable Universe increases by six orders of magnitude from $z\sim10$ to $z \sim2$ and by another factor of $z=0$ We also show that seeds from runaway mergers in nuclear star clusters are viable progenitors for the SMHs in GN-z11 andCE

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07215v1.title: A New Probe of the High-z BAO scale: BAO tomography With CMB $\times$ LIM-Nulling Convergence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07215v1.summary: Next-generation instruments will be able to constrain the BAO scale to percent-level precision at $7.2 \%$, while a futuristic observing scenario can constrain it to $4\%$precision. This constitutes a fundamentally new kind of BAO measurement duringearly epochs in our cosmic history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07216v1.title: On the relative importance of shocks and self-gravity in modifying tidal disruption event debris streams
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07216v1.summary: In a tidal disruption event (TDE), a star is destroyed by the gravitationalfield of a supermassive black hole. Some debris accretes onto the SMBH and creates a luminous flare. The distribution of mass along the stream has a direct impact on the accretion rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12097v2.title: Determination of the Spiral Pattern Speed in the Milky Way from Young Open Star Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12097v2.summary: We have estimated the spiral pattern speed in the Galaxy $Omega_p$ from a large sample of young open star clusters (OSCs) For this purpose, we have used OSCs younger than 50 Myr. Their mean proper motions, line-of-sight                velocities, and distances were calculated by Hunt and Reffert (2023) based on Gaia~DR3 catalogue.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12048v1.title: Cosmology with multiple galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12048v1.summary: Using multiple galaxies enables the inference of other parameters that were poorly constrained with one single galaxy. We find that using the properties of more than one galaxy increases the precision of the inference. We show that the same subset of galaxy properties are responsible for the constraints on one and multiple galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12045v1.title: Collisional excitation of methyl (iso)cyanide by He atoms: rate coefficients and isomerism effects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12045v1.summary: Methyl cyanide(CH$_3$CN) is the second most abundant of those (after ammonia, NH$3$) Its less abundant isomer, methyl isocyanide (CH$5$NC), has been detected in many astrophysical sources. In order to assess their absolute and relativeabundances, it is essential to understand their collisional excitationproperties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.08756v3.title: Reviving stochasticity: uncertainty in SMBH binary eccentricity is unavoidable
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.08756v3.summary: We study supermassive black hole (SMBH) binary eccentricity of equal-mass galaxy mergers. In simulations with realistic, high eccentricity galactic merger orbits, the hardbinary eccentricity is found to be a non-linear function of the deflection angle in the SMBH orbit during the final, nearly radial close encounter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11982v1.title: Properties of Barred Galaxies with the Environment: I. the case of the Virgo cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11982v1.summary: Bar shapes are widespread in a considerable fraction of galacticdiscs, spanning diverse environments and galaxy luminosities. It is plausible that the structural parameters of bars resulting from tidal interactions in high-density galactic environments differ from those formed through internaldisc instabilities in isolated galaxies. We have collected data on the bar radius and bar strength for a sample of 36 SB0 and SBa galaxies located within the                Virgo cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15534v2.title: DES J024008.08-551047.5:A new member of the polar ring galaxy family
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15534v2.summary: Galaxy DES J024008.08-551047.5 (DJ0240) has a ring component almost perpendicular to the host galaxy. The position angles of the ring and host components have been determined to be 80 and 10 degrees, indicating that they are nearly orthogonal to each other. The ring component extends three times more than the host and shows a distinct colour separation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11952v1.title: The metallicity and distance of Leo A from blue supergiants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11952v1.summary: We have obtained high-quality spectra of blue supergiant candidates in the irregular galaxy Leo A with the Low Resolution Imaging Spectrometer at the Keck I telescope. We identify one outlier of low bolometric magnitude as a post-AGB star. Its metallicity is consistent with that of the young population of Leo A.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00826v2.title: Quenching star formation with low-luminosity AGN winds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00826v2.summary: We present a simple model for low-luminosity active galactic nucleus (LLAGN) The wind carriesconsiderable energy and deposits it on the host galaxy at kiloparsec scales. The typical LLAGN can quench more than $10\%$ of star formation in its host galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03258v2.title: $\mathbf{12\times2}$pt combined probes: pipeline, neutrino mass, and data compression
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03258v2.summary: With the rapid advance of wide-field surveys it is increasingly important to perform combined cosmological probe analyses. We present a new pipeline for simulations-based multi-probe analyses. The pipeline combines tomographic large-scalestructure (LSS) probes (weak lensing and galaxy clustering) with cosmicmicrowave background (CMB) primary and lensing data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07958v2.title: Characterising the true descendants of the first stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07958v2.summary: The metal-poor stars in the Galactic halo are thought to show the imprints of the first (PopIII) stars. In this work, we aim at understanding whether all very metal- poor stars formed in environments polluted by PopIII supernovae (SNe) and if so, at what level.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.04358v4.title: The Laser Interferometer Space Antenna mission in Greece White Paper
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.04358v4.summary: The Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) mission is scheduled for launch in the mid-2030s. LISA is a gravitational wave observatory in space designed to detect sources emitting in the millihertz band. On the 23rd of February 2022 we organized the LISA in Greece Workshop.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11831v1.title: Deep Photometry of Suspected Gravitational Lensing Events: Potential Detection of a Cosmic String
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11831v1.summary: Cosmic strings (CS) are one-dimensional cosmological-size objects predicted in realistic models of the early Universe. Analysis of the cosmic microwavebackground (CMB) and Planck surveys revealed several CS candidates. CSc-1 was found to be most reliable because of the statistically significant chains of gravitational lensing (GL) candidates in its field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11799v1.title: WALLABY Pre-Pilot Survey: Ultra-Diffuse Galaxies in the Eridanus Supergroup
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11799v1.summary: We present a pilot study of the atomic neutral hydrogen gas (HI) content of putative ultra-diffuse galaxy (UDG) candidates. Most SMUDGes UDGs candidates in this study have effective radii smaller than 1.5 kpc and thus fail to meet the defining size threshold. We only find one HI detection, which we classify as a low-surface-brightness dwarf.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16521v2.title: Are "Changing-Look'' Active Galactic Nuclei Special in the Coevolution of Supermassive Black Holes and their Hosts? I
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16521v2.summary: The nature of the so-called ''changing-look'' (CL) active galactic nucleus(AGN) remains an open question. We here attempt to understand the CL phenomenon from a view of the coevolution of AGNs and their host galaxies. The host galaxies of the CL-AGNs are biased against young stellar populations and tend to be dominated bymediate-age stellar populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07452v3.title: Temperature Fluctuations in Quasar Accretion Discs from Spectroscopic Monitoring Data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07452v3.summary: The dominant pattern of disc temperature perturbations is either slow.inward/outward moving waves with typical amplitudes. at 0.01-0.1c. In nearly none of the cases do we find clear evidence for coherent, fast outgoing temperature. perturbation at the speed of light, reminiscent of the lamppost model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11652v1.title: Selection of powerful radio galaxies with machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11652v1.summary: Pipeline of three machine learning (ML) models can predict which sources are more likely to be an AGN and to be detected in specific radio surveys. Also, it can estimate redshift values for predictedradio-detectable AGNs. Models combine predictions from tree-based                and gradient-boosting algorithms.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.09232v2.title: Preliminary characterization of an active spiral galaxy near m57

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11578v1.title: The Role of Groups in Galaxy Evolution: compelling evidence of pre-processing out to the turnaround radius of clusters

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11574v1.title: A Comparison Between the Morphologies and Structures of Dwarf Galaxies with and without Active Massive Black Holes

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11571v1.title: Modeling Quasar Proximity Zones in a Realistic Cosmological Environment with a Self-consistent Light Curve

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11561v1.title: Gas Assisted Binary Black Hole Formation in AGN Discs

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11559v1.title: A Close Look at Ly$α$ Emitters with JWST/NIRCam at $z\approx3.1$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11558v1.title: Estimating major merger rates and spin parameters ab initio via the clustering of critical events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11558v1.summary: We build a model to predict from first principles the properties of major                mergers. We predict these from the coalescence of peaks and saddle points in the vicinity of a given larger peak. The typical typical typical spin brought by mergers is of the order of a few tens of per cent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11557v1.title: Deprojection and stellar dynamical modelling of boxy/peanut bars in edge-on discs

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11548v1.title: Studying [CII] Emission in Low-mass Galaxies at z ~ 7

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11545v1.title: Galaxy Archaeology for Wet Mergers: Globular Cluster Age Distributions in the Milky Way and Nearby Galaxies

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11482v1.title: X-rays Trace the Volatile Content of Interstellar Objects

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11425v1.title: Galaxy Zoo DESI: Detailed Morphology Measurements for 8.7M Galaxies in the DESI Legacy Imaging Surveys

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11415v1.title: Stellar Populations in STARFORGE: The Origin and Evolution of Star Clusters and Associations

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11386v1.title: One, Two, Three ... An Explosive Outflow in IRAS 12326$-$6245 revealed by ALMA

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02676v2.title: A complete catalogue of broad-line AGNs and double-peaked emission lines from MaNGA integral-field spectroscopy of 10K galaxies: stellar population of AGNs, supermassive black holes, and dual AGNs

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11533v1.title: S-PLUS: Photometric Re-calibration with the Stellar Color Regression Method and an Improved Gaia XP Synthetic Photometry Method

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11324v1.title: Building Semi-Analytic Black Hole Seeding Models Using IllustrisTNG Host Galaxies

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11265v1.title: Infrared spectral fingerprint of neutral and charged endo- and exohedral metallofullerenes

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.08629v2.title: The galactic acceleration scale is imprinted on globular cluster systems of early-type galaxies of most masses and on red and blue globular cluster subpopulations

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07480v2.title: The growth history of local M33-mass bulgeless spiral galaxies

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13945v2.title: Constraints on the Local Cosmic Void from the Pantheon Supernovae Data

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10038v2.title: A JWST investigation into the bar fraction at redshifts 1 < z < 3

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.11237v3.title: Prompt cusps and the dark matter annihilation signal

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10404v2.title: Robust Evidence for the Breakdown of Standard Gravity at Low Acceleration from Statistically Pure Binaries Free of Hidden Companions

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07463v2.title: Model of a `Warm Corona' as the Origin of the Soft X-ray Excess of Active Galactic Nuclei

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10995v1.title: Statistical analysis of the gravitational anomaly in {\it Gaia} wide binaries

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10956v1.title: Powerful Radio Sources in the Southern Sky. II. A SWIFT X-Ray Perspective

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.12371v2.title: Exploring the Correlation between $\rm{H}α$-to-UV Ratio and Burstiness for Typical Star-forming Galaxies at $z\sim2$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08515v2.title: MIDIS. JWST NIRCam and MIRI unveil the stellar population properties of Ly$α$-emitters and Lyman-Break galaxies at z ~ 3-7

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10842v1.title: Variation of the high-mass slope of the stellar initial mass function: Theory meets observations

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10798v1.title: Probing the spatial and velocity anisotropies in stellar halos from the Aquarius simulations

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10778v1.title: Chemical abundances of the young inner-disk open cluster NGC 6705 observed by APOGEE: sodium-rich and not $α$-enhanced

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10777v1.title: The Kinematic Structure of Magnetically Aligned HI Filaments

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10755v1.title: A new method for spatially resolving the turbulence driving mixture in the ISM with application to the Small Magellanic Cloud

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10735v1.title: Radio-continuum decrements associated to shadowing from the central warp in transition disc DoAr44

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10712v1.title: Small Molecules, Big Impact: A tale of hydrides past, present, and future

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10693v1.title: The unusual planetary nebula nucleus in the Galactic open cluster M37 and six further hot white dwarf candidates

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.02750v3.title: UNCOVER: The growth of the first massive black holes from JWST/NIRSpec -- spectroscopic redshift confirmation of an X-ray luminous AGN at z=10.1

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10615v1.title: To clump or not to clump The impact of wind inhomogeneities on the optical and NIR spectroscopic analysis of massive OB stars

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10610v1.title: An accretion disc with magnetic outflows triggered by a sudden mass accretion event in changing-look active galactic nucleus 1ES 1927+654

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.01918v2.title: Mapping dust attenuation and the 2175 Å bump at kpc scales in nearby galaxies

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10572v1.title: Investigating the impact of quasar-driven outflows on galaxies at redshift 0.3-0.4

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04613v4.title: Breakdown of the Newton-Einstein Standard Gravity at Low Acceleration in Internal Dynamics of Wide Binary Stars

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10493v1.title: Neutrino Imaging of the Galactic Centre and Millisecond Pulsar Population

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10410v1.title: JOYS: Disentangling the warm and cold material in the high-mass IRAS 23385+6053 cluster

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03936v2.title: No strong radio absorption detected in the low-frequency spectra of radio-loud quasars at z > 5.6

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10358v1.title: Cold gas in the heart of Perseus A

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10351v1.title: Determination of the branching ratio of CH$_3$OH + OH reaction on water ice surface at 10 K

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10322v1.title: On the Migration Origin of the Hercules Moving Group with GAIA, LAMOST, APOGEE, and GALAH Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10322v1.summary: Using Gaia DR3 data and the wavelet transformation technique, we study the Hercules moving group (HMG) Hercules 1 (H1) and Hercules 2 (H2) The HMG is on average richer in metal than the Galactic disk, with H2 being metal richer than H1. The metallicity and age distributions of the HMG depend mainly on the Galactic radius but show no dependence on the azimuthal velocity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.11149v2.title: The Enhanced Population of Extreme Mass-Ratio Inspirals in the LISA Band from Supermassive Black Hole Binaries

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.17162v3.title: Sizes and mass profiles of candidate massive galaxies discovered by JWST at 7<z<9: evidence for very early formation of the central ~100 pc of present-day ellipticals

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10191v1.title: The One-hundred-deg^2 DECam Imaging in Narrowbands (ODIN): Survey Design and Science Goals

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01047v2.title: The Supersonic Project: Star Formation in Early Star Clusters without Dark Matter

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08592v2.title: Confirmation of an anomalously low dark matter content for the galaxy NGC1052-DF4 from deep, high resolution continuum spectroscopy

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10148v1.title: HdC and EHe stars through the prism of Gaia DR3: 3D distribution and Gaia's chromatic PSF effects

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10120v1.title: How Tycho Brahe's recordings in 1572 support SN 1572 as a type I(a) supernova

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10096v1.title: Tracing the Galactic Disk with Planetary Nebulae using Gaia DR3

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10040v1.title: The effect of relativistic precession on light curves of tidal disruption events

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10039v1.title: Figuring Out Gas & Galaxies In Enzo (FOGGIE) VII: The (Dis)Assembly of Stellar Halos

http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.08725v2.title: Determining the Dark Matter distribution in galaxies with Deep Learning

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10022v1.title: The Progenitor Star of SN 2023ixf: A Massive Red Supergiant with Enhanced, Episodic Pre-Supernova Mass Loss

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16626v1.title: Chemical evolution of local post-starburst galaxies: Implications for the mass-metallicity relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16626v1.summary: A majority of post-starburst regions increased in stellar metallicity during the recent starburst, with an average increase of 0.8 dex and a standard deviationof 0.4 dex. A much smaller fraction of PSBs are found to have remained constant or declined in meetallicity. The results are consistent with hydrodynamic simulations, which suggest that mergers between gas-rich galaxies are the primary formation mechanism of local PSBs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16531v1.title: Revisiting Galaxy Evolution in Morphology in the COSMOS field (COSMOS-ReGEM):I. Merging Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16531v1.summary: This paper is the first in a series that investigates merging galaxies and their properties. We identify 3,594 majormerging galaxies through visual inspection and find 1,737 massive galaxy pairs with log($M_\ast$/M$_\odot$)$>10.1$. We propose a criterion for selecting candidates of violently star-forming mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16528v1.title: A new discovery space opened by eROSITA: Ionised AGN outflows from X-ray selected samples
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16528v1.summary: In an evolutionary model, the outflow phase of an Active                Galactic Nuclei (AGN) occurs at the peak of its activity. This phase plays a vital role in galaxy evolution. We apply various selection methods to isolate powerful AGNs in the feedbackphase, trace and characterise their outflows. We find that the majority of the outflows have momentum flux ratios lower than 20.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16516v1.title: Effects of heterogeneous data sets and time-lag measurement techniques on cosmological parameter constraints from MgII and CIV reverberation-mapped quasar data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16516v1.summary: Previously, we demonstrated that MgII and CIV reverberation-mapped quasars are standardizable. In this study, we test the effect of adding 25 OzDES Mg II RM QSOs as well as 25 lower-quality SDSS RM CIV Q SOs. The new combined data sets have an increased maximum difference in R-L relation parameter values, and thus a lower standardizability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16510v1.title: Variations of the HCO$^{+}$, HCN, HNC, N$_2$H$^+$ and NH$_{3}$ deuterium fractionation in high-mass star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16510v1.summary: We use spectra and maps to study deuteration processes in five high-mass star-forming regions. The temperature was estimated from CH$_3$CCH lines, also observed with the IRAM-30m telescope. The relative abundances of these species decrease with increasing temperature, but the DCN/H$_2$ratio is almost constant.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05635v2.title: Can massive stars form in low mass clouds?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05635v2.summary: The conditions required for massive star formation are debated, particularly whether massive stars must form in conjunction with massive clusters. Here we investigate the relation between cluster mass and the maximum stellar mass (M\textsubscript{max}) using a suite of SPH simulations. We find that more massive clusters will have, on average, higher mass stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15733v2.title: The informativeness of [C II] line-intensity mapping as a probe of the H I content and metallicity of galaxies at the end of reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15733v2.summary: New model suggests that gas mass andmetallicity most directly determine [C II] luminosity. Line-intensity mapping (LIM) experiments coming online now will survey aggregate emission in the [CII] ionized carbon line from star-forming galaxies at the end of reionization. We expect a baseline 4000-hour LIM survey from the CCAT facility to have the fundamental sensitivity to detect the signal.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16472v1.title: Fragmentation and dynamics of dense gas structures in the proximity of massive young stellar object W42-MME
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16472v1.summary: We present an analysis of the dense gas structures in the immediatesurroundings of the massive young stellar object (MYSO) W42-MME. We performed a dendrogram analysis to study multi-scale structures and their spatio-kinematic properties. We also analyzed the fragmentation and dynamics of dense structures down to $2000AU scale.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10944v2.title: Towards an astronomical foundation model for stars with a Transformer-based model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10944v2.summary: A Transformer-based model can perform both discriminative and generative tasks. The model can also generate XP spectra from stellar parameters, inpaint unobserved spectral regions, extract empirical stellar loci, and determine interstellar extinction curve. Such "Large Astronomy Models" trained on largequantities of observational data will play a large role in the analysis of current and future large surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16423v1.title: A deep dive into the Type II Globular Cluster NGC 1851
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16423v1.summary: About one-fifth of the Galactic globular clusters (GCs), dubbed Type II GCs,host distinct stellar populations with different heavy elements abundances. NGC1851 is one of the most studied Type IIGCs, surrounded by several controversies regarding the spatial distribution of its populations and the presence of star-to-star differences.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16410v1.title: Simulated non-thermal emission from SNR G1.9+0.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16410v1.summary: Supernova remnants are the nebular leftover of defunct stellar environments. They display a large variety of non-spherical morphologies such as ears that shinenon-thermally. We have modelled the structure and the non-thermal emission of G1.9+0.3 through 3D magnetohydrodynamic numerical simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16403v1.title: Evidence of a Cloud-Cloud Collision from Overshooting Gas in the Galactic Center
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16403v1.summary: The Milky Way is a barred spiral galaxy with "bar lanes" that bring gas toward the Galactic Center. Gas flowing along these bar lanes oftenovershoots, and instead of accreting onto the Central Molecular Zone, it collides with the bar lane on the opposite side of the Galaxy. We observed G5, a cloud which we believe is the site of one such collision.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19064v2.title: A neural network emulator for the Lyman-$α$ 1D flux power spectrum
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19064v2.summary: The Lyman-$\alpha$ forest offers a unique avenue for studying the distribution of matter in the high redshift universe. In this work, we build a neural network that serves as a surrogate model for rapid predictions of the one-dimensional flux power spectrum. We show that our emulator achieves sub-percent precision across the full range of scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16297v1.title: The relation between the cool-core radius and the host galaxy clusters: thermodynamic properties and cluster mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16297v1.summary: Cool cores are formed by radiative cooling of the intracluster medium (ICM) Cool cores are characterized by a significant drop in the ICM temperature toward the cluster center. Our findings suggest that cool cores are linked to the evolution of their host galaxy clusters. We present a detailed study of cool-core systems in a sample of four galaxy cluster clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16244v1.title: The Hyper Suprime-Cam extended Point Spread Functions and applications to measuring the intra-halo light
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16244v1.summary: We present extended point spread function (PSF) models for the HSC-SSP PDR3. These new PSFs provide the community with a crucial tool to characterise LSB properties at large angles. We apply our HSC PSFs and demonstrate that they behave reasonably in two cases: first, to generate a 2-D model of a bright star, and second, to remove the PSF-scattered light from an Ultra Deep image.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16232v1.title: A new, purely photometric method for determination of resonance locations in spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16232v1.summary: Corotation resonance in spiral arms is a key way to estimate their pattern speed. Various methods for its estimation have been developed, but they all demonstrate certain limitations and a lack of agreement with each other. This method takes into account the shape of the profile across the arm and its width.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09129v2.title: Stellar/BH Population in AGN Disks: Direct Binary Formation from Capture Objects in Nuclei Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09129v2.summary: The population of massive stars and blackholes in AGN disks captured from the nuclei cluster plays a crucial role in determining the efficiency of binary formation. The captured objects are found to be dynamically crowded within the AGN disk. Direct binary formation right after the capture would be promising, especially for stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13230v2.title: Strong lensing selection effects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13230v2.summary: Strong lens galaxies are biased towards larger stellar masses, smaller half-mass radii and larger dark matter masses. The amplitude of the strong lensing bias depends on the intrinsic scatter in the mass-related parameters of the lens population. Strong lensing observations can be used directly to improve our current knowledge of the inner structure of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16125v1.title: Tides in clouds: control of star formation by long-range gravitational force
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16125v1.summary: Gravity drives the collapse of molecular clouds through which stars form. The exact role of gravity in cloud collapse remains a complex issue. Tides were first recognized by Newton, yet this is the first time its dominance in cloud evolution has been revealed. We expect this link between cloud density structure and role gravity will be strengthened by future studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16028v1.title: PEARLS: A Potentially Isolated Quiescent Dwarf Galaxy with a TRGB Distance of 31 Mpc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16028v1.summary: An isolated quiescent dwarf galaxy in the nearby Universe was imaged as part of the PEARLS GTO program. Remarkably, individual red-giant branch stars are visible in this near-IR imaging, suggesting a distance of $31$ Mpc. The galaxy was either quenched from internal mechanisms or had a very high-velocity interaction with a nearby massive galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15998v1.title: LMC-driven anisotropic boosts in stream--subhalo interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15998v1.summary: Using FIRE-2 simulations of Milky Way-mass galaxies, we show that presence of a Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC)--analog significantly changes stream-subhalo encounter rates. Three key factors drive these changes. The dependence of encounter rates on stream location andorbit has important implications for where to search for new streams with spurs and gaps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15986v1.title: The COSMOS-Web ring: in-depth characterization of an Einstein ring lensing system at z~2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15986v1.summary: An Einstein ring at z=2 was discovered in the COSMOS-Web survey. The lens is a massive and quiescent galaxy at z = 2.02 with a total mass Mtot(<thetaE) = (3.66%) x 10^11 Msun. Its reconstructed morphology is complex and highlywavelength dependent, possibly because it is a merger or a main sequence galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15958v1.title: Review on $f(Q)$ Gravity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15958v1.summary: Recent years have witnessed a rise in interest in the geometrical trinity of General Relativity and its extensions. $f(Q)$ gravity has also inspired numerous works on black holes, wormholes, and cosmology. The emergence of new black hole solutions and the potential existence of wormhole solutions suggest the presence of novel physics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15952v1.title: The Discovery of the Zeeman Effect in 38 GHz Class II Methanol Masers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15952v1.summary: Magnetic fields likely play an important role in star formation, but the number of directly measured magnetic field strengths remains scarce. Magnetic fields in the regions traced by these masers would be in the range of 8-46 mG. Such magnetic field values in the high mass star forming regions agree with those detected in the better-known 6.7 GHz Class II CH$_3$OH maser line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15948v1.title: The ALMA Reionization Era Bright Emission Line Survey (REBELS): The molecular gas content of galaxies at z~7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15948v1.summary: A key to understanding the formation of the first galaxies is to quantify the content of the molecular gas as the fuel for star formation activity through the epoch of reionization. In this paper, we use the 158$\mu$m [CII]fine-structure emission line as a tracer of molecular gas in the Interstellar medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15934v1.title: The effect of cluster dynamical state on ram-pressure stripping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15934v1.summary: Theoretical and observational studies have suggested that ram-pressure stripping by the intracluster medium can be enhanced during cluster interactions. We find a mild increase in the RPS fraction in interactingclusters with respect to all other classes (including post-mergers) This mildenhancement could hint at a short-lived enhanced ram- pressure stripping in tumultuous cluster mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15931v1.title: The outer dusty edge of accretion disks in active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15931v1.summary: Recent models for the inner structure of active galactic nuclei (AGN) aim atconnecting the outer region of the accretion disk with the broad-line region and dusty torus through a radiatively accelerated, dusty outflow. Such an outflow not only requires the outer disk to be dusty and so predicts disk sizes beyond the self-gravity limit but requires the presence of nuclear dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15930v1.title: MESA-Web: A cloud resource for stellar evolution in astronomy curricula
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15930v1.summary: MESA-Web is a cloud resource with an online interface to the Modules for Experiments in Stellar Astrophysics (MESA) software instrument. Since being released in 2015, MESA- Web has delivered over 17,000 Calculations to over 2,200 unique learners and currently performs about 11 jobsper day.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15911v1.title: Dynamical stellar mass-to-light ratio gradients: Evidence for very centrally concentrated IMF variations in ETGs?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15911v1.summary: Evidence from different probes of the stellar initial mass function (IMF) of massive early-type galaxies has repeatedly converged on IMFs morebottom-heavy than in the Milky Way. Radial gradients of the IMF can potentially resolve this issue. We construct Schwarzschild models allowing for $\Upsilon$-gradients in seven massive ETGs with MUSE and SINFONI observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15906v1.title: [CII] Spectral Mapping of the Galactic Wind and Starbursting Disk of M82 with SOFIA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15906v1.summary: M82 is an archetypal starburst galaxy in the local Universe. The centralburst of star formation is thought to be triggered by M82's interaction with other members in the M81 group. We find that the fraction of [CII] actually flowing from M82 is small compared to the bulk gas outside the midplane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15909v1.title: The link between star-formation and supermassive black hole properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15909v1.summary: Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) and their host galaxies co-evolve. AGN feedback plays an important role on this symbiosis. We compare the SFR of AGN and non-AGNgalaxies as a function of L$_X$, M$_{BH}$ and Eddington ratio (n$Edd)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15902v1.title: In-situ vs accreted Milky Way globular clusters: a new classification method and implications for cluster formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15902v1.summary: We present a new scheme for the classification of the in-situ and accreted GCs. The scheme uses total energy $E$ and $z$- component of angular momentum. The in-Situ GCs in our classification show a clear disc spin-up signature. This signature signals the MW's disc formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15898v1.title: Three regimes of black hole feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15898v1.summary: In theoretical models of galaxy evolution, black hole feedback is a necessary.ingredient in order to explain the observed exponential decline in number.density of massive galaxies. Most contemporary black hole. feedback models rely on a constant radiative efficiency at all black hole accretion rates. We present a synthesis model for the spin-dependent radiative efficiencies of three physical accretion rate regimes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15900v1.title: Simulating ionization feedback from young massive stars: impact of numerical resolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15900v1.summary: Modelling galaxy formation in hydrodynamic simulations has increasinglyadopted various radiative transfer methods. However, the evolution of HII regions around massive stars begins in dense star-forming clouds and spans large dynamical ranges in space and time. Insufficient spatial resolution leads to reduced ionizing fraction but enhanced ionized gas mass and momentum feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02959v2.title: Evidence for Large-scale, Rapid Gas Inflows in z~2 Star-forming Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02959v2.summary: We report high-quality H${\alpha}$/CO, imaging spectroscopy of nine massive. disk galaxies on the star-forming, main sequence (henceforth `SFGs'), near the peak of cosmic galaxy.evolution. We fit the major axis. position-velocity cuts with beam-convolved, forward models with a bulge, a.turbulent rotating disk, and a dark matter (DM) halo. We then subtract the inferred 2D model-galaxy velocity and velocity dispersion maps from those of the observed galaxies. We find that all nine galaxies

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15720v1.title: Identification of a transition from stochastic to secular star formation around $z=9$ with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15720v1.summary: Star formation histories (SFH) of early galaxies have been found to be highly stochastic in both observations and models. At $z>9, 87% of massive galaxies have SFR gradients consistent with a star-formation activity during the last 100 Myr. This fraction drops to 15% at $z<7.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15671v1.title: MIDIS: Unveiling the Role of Strong Ha-emitters during the Epoch of Reionization with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15671v1.summary: We make use of the deepest JWST/MIRI image at 5.6 um, obtained in the HubbleeXtreme Deep Field, to constrain the role of strong Ha emitters (HAEs) in Cosmic Reionization at z~7-8. Our sample of bright (M(UV) < -20 mag) HAEs is comprised of young (<30 Myr) galaxies with low stellar masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13117v2.title: Testing strengths, limitations and biases of current Pulsar Timing Arrays detection analyses on realistic data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13117v2.summary: State-of-the-art searches for gravitational waves (GWs) model the signal as an isotropic, Gaussian and stationary process described by a power-law. In practice, none of these properties areexpected to hold for an incoherent superposition of GWs generated by a cosmicensemble of supermassive black hole binaries. We perform a systematic investigation of the performance of current search algorithms, using a simple power law model to characterize GW signals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15431v2.title: A cautionary lesson from Gaia systematics: the mono-metallic globular cluster NGC 5904
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15431v2.summary: The study of the chemistry of the stellar populations in Globular Clusters is a fundamental task to unveil their formation in the high-redshiftuniverse. Using metallicityestimates from BP/RP low-resolution Gaia DR3 spectra, a recent work presented the surprising detection of two stellar populations with distinct metallicities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02526v2.title: Gravito-turbulence in local disk simulations with an adaptive moving mesh
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02526v2.summary: Self-gravity plays an important role in the evolution of rotationallysupported systems such as protoplanetary disks, accretion disks around blackholes, or galactic disks. We present a novel self-gravity solver for the shearing box based on the TreePM method of the AREPO code. We apply our new implementation to two- and three-dimensional, self-gravitating disks.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11712v2.title: MaNGA DynPop -- II. Global stellar population, gradients, and star-formation histories from integral-field spectroscopy of 10K galaxies: link with galaxy rotation, shape, and total-density gradients
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11712v2.summary: This is the second paper of the MaNGA DynPop series. It analyzes the global stellar population, radial gradients, and non-parametric star-formation history of galaxies. We also discover a population of low-mass star-forming galaxies with low rotation but physically distinct from massive slow rotators.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15539v1.title: Galaxy mergers in Subaru HSC-SSP: a deep representation learning approach for identification and the role of environment on merger incidence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15539v1.summary: We take a deep learning-based approach for galaxy merger identification in Subaru HSC-SSP. We use Zoobot, a deep representation learning model pre-trained on citizen science votes on Galaxy Zoo DeCALS images. Fine-tuned model returns an accuracy on the synthetic validation data of 76%. We find that galaxies with higher merger scores favor higher density environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04664v2.title: Stellar mass dependence of galaxy size-dark matter halo radius relation probed by Subaru-HSC survey weak lensing measurements
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04664v2.summary: We investigate the stellar mass-dependence of the galaxy size-dark matter                halo radius relation for low redshift galaxies using weak gravitational lensing signals. We confirm that this relationappears linear given the statistical errors, i.e. the ratio of galaxy size to halo radius remains constant over two orders of magnitudes in stellar mass. At stellar mass the ratio becomes 30% smaller than its value in the linear regime.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15450v1.title: Environmental impacts on the rest-frame UV size and morphology ofstar-forming galaxies at $z\sim2$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15450v1.summary: We measure rest-frame UV size and morphology of star-forming galaxies in four protoclusters. We find the size distributions of protocluster and field HAEs are similar with typical half-light radius of 2.5 kpc. At fixed stellar mass, there is no significant difference between HAE and field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09076v2.title: The Structure and Morphology of Galaxies during the Epoch of Reionization Revealed by JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09076v2.summary: We analyze 347 galaxies at redshift $4<z<9.5$ using JWST observations from the CEERS program. Galaxies follow arelation between rest-frame optical luminosity and effective radius in the redshift range $4 < z < 5$ and $5 \leq z < 9.5$, with a very similar slope but a marginally lower zero point in the higher redshift bin.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00937v2.title: Spectroscopic Observations of Selected Planetary Nebulae from the HASH Database
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00937v2.summary: We conducted research on the classification and physical properties of 10 objects from the HASH database. The sample consisted of 6 Likely PNe, 2 new candidates, one emission-line star, and one object of unknown nature. Our analysis revealed that the ionic abundances of the majority of these objects were in agreement with Galactic PNe. Our spectral observations have led to the updating of 10 PNe in HASH.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14270v2.title: MOND via Matrix General Relativity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14270v2.summary: MOND theory has arisen as a promising alternative to dark matter in explaining the collection of discrepancies that constitute the so-calledmissing mass problem. It is shown that MOND theory can be incorporated into the framework of Matrix General Relativity. In particular, we demonstrate that Matrix Generalrelativity contains MOND as a particular case.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07023v2.title: The power spectrum of extended [C II] halos around high redshift galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07023v2.summary: ALMA observations have detected extended ($\simeq 10$ kpc) [C II] halos around high-redshift ($z \gtrsim 5$) star-forming galaxies. If such extended structures are common, they may have an impact on the line intensity mapping(LIM) signal. We model the central galaxy and the [CII] halo brightness with a S\'ersic+exponential profile.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15341v1.title: Representing low mass black hole seeds in cosmological simulations: A new sub-grid stochastic seed model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15341v1.summary: The nature of the first seeds of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) is currently unknown. We introduce a novel sub-grid BH seed model that is directlycalibrated from high resolution zoom simulations. The results are used to build a new stochastic seeding model that seeds these descendants in lower resolution versions of our zoom region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13008v2.title: PEARLS: JWST counterparts of micro-Jy radio sources in the Time Domain Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13008v2.summary: The Time Domain Field (TDF) near the North Ecliptic Pole will become a premier "blank field" for extragalacticscience. JWST/NIRCam data in a 16 arcmin$^2$ portion of the TDF identify 4.4$\mu$m counterparts for 62 of 63 3 GHz sources with S(3 GHz) > 5 {\mu}Jy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15321v1.title: All-sky Kinematics and Chemistry of Monoceros Stellar Overdensity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15321v1.summary: Monoceros is a structure located towards the Galactic anticenter and close to the disk. We identified that its stars have azimuthal velocity in the range of $200 to $250. Our results confirm its similarity to stars found in the thin disk of the Galaxy and suggest an in situ formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15310v1.title: Microlensing Discovery and Characterization Efficiency in the Vera C. Rubin Legacy Survey of Space and Time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15310v1.summary: The Vera C. Rubin Legacy Survey of Space and Time will discover thousands ofmicrolensing events across the Milky Way Galaxy. It will reach deeperlimiting magnitudes over a wider area than any previous survey. We evaluate numerous survey strategies simulated in the Rubin Operation Simulations to assess the discovery and characterization efficiencies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15306v1.title: The Beyond-Halo Mass Effects of the Cosmic Web Environment on Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15306v1.summary: The secondary galaxy bias is the component component of the galaxy-halo connection. Galaxy properties primarily depend on their host halo mass. Halo mass, in turn, depends on the cosmic web environment. We explore if the effect of the cosmosmic web on galaxy properties is entirely transitive.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15296v1.title: Self-gravitating N-body systems and Cosmological Large Scale Structures
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15296v1.summary: Extended galaxy surveys revealed that at a large-scale the Universe consists of galactic clusters, filaments and vast regions devoid of galaxies. We reformulate the dynamics of a self-gravitating N-body system in terms of a geodesic flow on a curved Riemannian manifold of dimension 3N.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15281v1.title: Post-processing of galaxies due to major cluster mergers I. hints from galaxy colours and morphologies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15281v1.summary: Galaxy clusters, which underwent a recent ($\leq3$ Gyr) major merger, offer a potentiallyharsher environment due to the global hydrodynamical disturbance. However, the aftermath of such extreme cluster interactions on the member galaxy properties is not very well constrained. We conclude that different global star formation histories lead to considerable scatter in galaxy properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13208v2.title: The impact of magnetic fields on cosmological galaxy mergers -- II. Modified angular momentum transport and feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13208v2.summary: Magnetic fields play a crucial role in major mergers between disc galaxies. In hydrodynamic simulations of such mergers, the Auriga model produces compact remnants. In magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations, remnants form radially-extended discs with prominent spiral arm structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15213v1.title: Constraining the LIGO/Virgo AGN channel with black hole spins
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15213v1.summary: Merging black holes (BH) are expected to produce remnants with large                dimensionless spin parameters. However, gravitationalwave (GW) observations with LIGO/Virgo suggest that merging BH are consistent with modestly positive but not high spin. We also point out that the fraction of BBH mergers with significant in-plane spin components is a strong test of interactions between disk binary black holes and nuclear spheroid orbiters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02007v2.title: The Role of Mass and Environment on Satellite distributions around Milky Way analogs in the Romulus25 simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02007v2.summary: We study satellite counts and quenched fractions for satellites in Romulus25, a large-volume cosmological hydrodynamic simulation. The number of satellites hosted by a Milky Way analog increases predominantly with host stellar mass. We find potential evidence, though not conclusive, that pairs, defined as being within 1 Mpc of another Milky Way-mass or larger halo, may have higher satellite quencher fractions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15161v1.title: Multiple stellar population mass loss in massive Galactic globular clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15161v1.summary: The degree of mass loss, i.e. the fraction of stars lost by globular clusters, is still poorly understood. We have tested whether such strong mass loss could take place in a massive globular cluster orbiting the Milky Way. The cluster mass can be as much as 20 times lower after a tumultuousHubble time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15155v1.title: Sulfur Isotope Ratios in the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15155v1.summary: Sulfur isotope ratios have emerged as a promising tool for tracing stellar populations, quantifying stellar stellar populations. While extensively studied in the Milky Way, inextragalactic environments they remain largely unexplored. We present the first robust detection of C$^{33}$S in the LMC.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15150v1.title: A$^3$COSMOS: the infrared luminosity function and dust-obscured star formation rate density at $0.5<z<6$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15150v1.summary: Aims: We leverage the largest available Atacama LargeMillimetre/submillimetre Array (ALMA) survey from the archive. We study infrared luminosity function and dust-obscured star formation rate densities of sub-millimeter/millimeter (sub-mm/mm) galaxies. We find an evolutionary trend in the typical density and luminosity of the galaxy population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15148v1.title: The star formation histories of quiescent ultra-diffuse galaxies and their dependence on environment and globular cluster richness
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15148v1.summary: We derive the stellar population parameters of 11 quiescent ultra-diffuse                galaxies (UDGs) from Keck/KCWI data. We supplement these with 14 literature                UDGs, creating the largest spectroscopic sample of UDGs to date. UDGs that formed on very short timescales have elevated [Mg/Fe]abundance ratios, whereas those forming over extended periods present lower                values. Those forming earlier and faster are overall found in high-density environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15144v1.title: 3D tomography of the giant Ly$α$ nebulae of $z$$\approx$3--5 radio-loud AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15144v1.summary: Ly$\alpha$ emission nebulae are ubiquitous around high-z galaxies. They areacers of the gaseous environment on scales out to >100 kpc. All the HzRGs have large scale Lya emission neBulae with sevenof them extended over 100 kpc at the observed surface brightness (SB) limit.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15147v1.title: The OGLE Collection of Variable Stars. Over 15,000 Delta Scuti Stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15147v1.summary: We present the OGLE collection of delta Scuti stars in the Large MagellanicCloud. Our dataset encompasses a total of 15,256 objects, the largest sample of extragalactic delta Sct stars published so far. We also report the enhancement of the OGle collection of Cepheids and RRLyrae stars with newly identified and reclassified objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15099v1.title: Seimei KOOLS-IFU mapping of the gas and dust distributions in Galactic PNe: Unveiling the origin and evolution of Galactic halo PN H4-1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15099v1.summary: H4-1 is a planetary nebula (PN) located in the Galactic halo. It is notablycarbon-rich and one of the most metal-deficient PNe in the Milky Way. To unveil its progenitor evolution through the accurate measurement of the gas mass, we conducted a comprehensive investigation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17663v2.title: AGN STORM 2. IV. Swift X-ray and ultraviolet/optical monitoring of Mrk 817
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17663v2.summary: The AGN STORM 2 campaign is a large, multiwavelength reverberation mapping project. Swift performed daily monitoring of Mrk 817 for approximately 15 months. The X-ray spectrum is heavily obscured. UV/optical light curves show significant variability throughout the campaign.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15705v2.title: Integral Field Spectroscopy of 13 Tidal Disruption Event Hosts from the ZTF Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15705v2.summary: Host galaxies of tidal disruption events (TDEs) have been shown to possess peculiar properties, including high central light concentrations and unusual star-formation histories. We present the first population study of integral field spectroscopy for thirteen TDE host galaxies across all spectral classes and X-raybrightnesses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13755v2.title: No Tension: JWST Galaxies at $z > 10$ Consistent with Cosmological Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13755v2.summary: Recent observations by JWST have uncovered galaxies in the very early                universe via the JADES and CEERS surveys. These galaxies have been measured to have very high stellar masses with substantial star formation rates. There are concerns that these observations are in tension with the $\Lambda$CDM model of the universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02487v2.title: Extreme Tidal Stripping May Explain the Overmassive Black Hole in Leo I: a Proof of Concept
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02487v2.summary: A recent study found evidence of a supermassive black hole at the center of Leo I. Extreme tidal disruption from one or two close passages within the Milky Way's virial radius could have removed most of its stellar mass. Evidence from this extreme tidal disruption event could be present in current Gaia data in the form of extended tidal streams.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14961v1.title: Adding Value to JWST Spectra and Photometry: Stellar Population and Star Formation Properties of Spectroscopically Confirmed JADES and CEERS Galaxies at $z > 7$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14961v1.summary: The study looked at 43 galaxies in the JADES and CEERS observationalprograms. 35% of our sample formed at least 30% of their stellar mass inrecent (< 10 Myr) starburst events. We find that the star formation rates (SFRs) measured from line emission are higher than those estimated from Bayesian SED fitting.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14914v1.title: Polymer amide as a source of the cosmic 6.2 micron emission and absorption
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14914v1.summary: Hemoglycin is a well-defined polymer of glycine that also contains iron. Hemoglycin has been found in CV3 meteorites of the primordial CV3 class and therefore originated in the solarprotoplanetary disc. The cosmic 6.2 micron emission and absorption could be from small grains that are hemoglycin lattices or vesicles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14901v1.title: Recovering lost light: discovery of supernova remnants with integral field spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14901v1.summary: We found 19 unique regions that pass our quality cuts, four of which match the locations of previously discovered SNe. The stellar ages measured at the location of these SNRcandidates are systematically lower by about 0.5 dex. The methods open a new window into the study of nearby SNe with Integral Field Spectroscopy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10566v4.title: Scanning For Dark Matter Subhalos in Hubble Space Telescope Imaging of 54 Strong Lenses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10566v4.summary: Cold dark matter (DM) model predicts that every galaxy contains thousands of DM subhalos. Subhalos are invisible, but could be detected via strong gravitational lensing, if they lie on the line of sight to amultiply-imaged background source. We present apredominantly automated strong lens analysis framework.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14852v1.title: Influence of the optical Fe II quasi-continuum on measuring the spectral parameters of active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14852v1.summary: We explore the influence of optical Fe II quasi-continuum on the spectra of Type 1 activegalactic nuclei (AGNs) We assume that the broad line region is composed of two subsections: the very broad region (VBLR) and the intermediate line region (ILR) We constructed a large set of synthetic AGN spectra by taking differentportions of the VBLR and ILR contributions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14830v1.title: GALAXY CRUISE: Spiral and ring classifications for 700K bright galaxies at z=0.01-0.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14830v1.summary: This paper presents a morphology classification catalog of spiral and ring galaxies at $z$=0.01-0.3 (r<20 mag) based on the Third Public Data Release of the Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru StrategicProgram. We employ two deep learning classifiers to determine the spiral andRing structures separately based on GALAXY CRUISE Data Release 1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14818v1.title: Black Hole Growth, Baryon Lifting, Star Formation, and IllustrisTNG
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14818v1.summary: Quenching of star formation in the central galaxies of cosmological halos is thought to result from energy released as gas accretes onto a supermassive black hole. The same energy source also appears to lower the central density and raise the cooling time of baryonic atmospheres in massive halos. We present theincreasingly strong observational evidence supporting a such a relationship.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10322v2.title: On the Migration Origin of the Hercules Moving Group with GAIA, LAMOST, APOGEE, and GALAH Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10322v2.summary: Using Gaia DR3 data and the wavelet transformation technique, we study the Hercules moving group (HMG) Hercules 1 (H1) and Hercules 2 (H2) The HMG is on average richer in metal than the Galactic disk, with H2 being metal richer than H1. The metallicity and age distributions of the HMG depend mainly on the Galactic radius but show no dependence on the azimuthal velocity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14743v1.title: The galactic tooth-fairy and a cosmic bullet: Amateur discoveries and a call for further research
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14743v1.summary: Shaheer I and Shaheer II are identified and studied. Both galaxies lay at a distance of 6.67 arc-minutes from each other in the Camelopardalis constellation. One boasts an unusual morphological profile, while the other seems to be shooting through space at high velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14710v1.title: GALAXY CRUISE: Deep Insights into Interacting Galaxies in the Local Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14710v1.summary: We present the first results from GALAXY CRUISE, a community (or citizen)science project based on data from the Hyper Suprime-Cam Subaru StrategicProgram (HSC-SSP) We first characterize the accuracy of the participants' classifications and demonstrate that it surpasses previous studies based on shallower imaging data. We then investigate various aspects of interacting galaxies in detail.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14692v1.title: Selection of Compton-thick AGN from a hard photometric sample using XMM-Newton observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14692v1.summary: We present a selection technique to detect Compton-thick (CT) active galacticnuclei (AGNs) in the 3XMM/SDSS-DR7 cross-correlation. A subsample of 3481 X-raysources that are detected in the hard band (2-8 keV) and have photometric redshifts constitute our sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14686v1.title: Clump-scale Gas Infall in High-mass Star Formation: a Multi-transition View with JCMT HCN (4--3) Mapping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14686v1.summary: Gas infall motions play a crucial role in high-mass star formation. They arecharacterized by observable signatures in the form of blue-shifted asymmetricspectral line profiles ("blue profiles") However, the connection between blueprofiles and infall motions is unclear due to complex gas motions at parsecs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14684v1.title: The ALMA Survey of Star Formation and Evolution in Massive Protoclusters with Blue Profiles (ASSEMBLE): Core Growth, Cluster Contraction, and Primordial Mass Segregation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14684v1.summary: The ALMA Survey of Star Formation and Evolution in Massive Protoclusters with Blue Profiles (ASSEMBLE) aims to investigate the process of mass assembly and its connection to high-mass star formation theories in protoclusters. We observed 11 massive (Mclump>1000 Msun), luminous (Lbol>10,000 Msun) and blue-profile (infall signature) clumps by ALMA with resolution of2200-5500 au at 350 GHz (870 um) 248 dense dense cores were identified, including 106 cores showing protostellar signatures and142 prestellar core candidates

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14637v1.title: SOFIA FEEDBACK Survey: The Pillars of Creation in [C II] and Molecular Lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14637v1.summary: We investigate the physical structure and conditions of photodissociation between the Pillars of Creation and molecular gas. We find pillar masses of 103, 78, 103, and 18 solar masses for P1a, P1b, P2, and P3 respectively. The dense clumps at the tops of the pillars are currently supported by the magnetic field. Our analysis suggests thatambipolar diffusion is rapid.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07854v2.title: A Differentiable Model of the Evolution of Dark Matter Halo Concentration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07854v2.summary: We introduce a new model of the evolution of the concentration of dark matter. For individual halos, our model approximates c(t) as a power law with a time-dependent index. At early times, concentration has a nearly constant value of c=3-4, and as cosmic time progresses, c( t) smoothlyincreases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14603v1.title: MgAl burning chain in Omega Centauri
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14603v1.summary: The study looked at the abundance of Fe, Mg, Al, and Si in 439 stars in Omega Centauri. It found four distinct Fe populations, with the main peak occurring at low metallicity. The study suggests that the MgAl cycle plays acrucial role in the formation of multiple populations in the system.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2108.12985v2.title: What's in a name? Quantifying the interplay between the Definition, Orientation, and Shape of Ultra-diffuse Galaxies Using the Romulus Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2108.12985v2.summary: We explore populations of ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) in isolated, Satellite, and cluster environments using the Romulus25 and RomulusC simulations. Using a fiducial definition of UDGs, we find that isolated UDGs have notably larger semi-major and smaller semi-minor (c/a) axis ratios. We also find that a galaxy's classification as a UDG is dependent on its viewing orientation, and this dependency decreases as environmental density increases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.15458v2.title: Evidence for heavy seed origin of early supermassive black holes from a z~10 X-ray quasar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.15458v2.summary: The origin of supermassive black holes (BHs) remains a mystery. Seeds of the first BHs are postulated to be either light (i.e., $10-100~‘M’odot’) or heavy. The discovery of an X-ray-luminous massive BH in a nearby galaxy is consistent with a picture wherein BH’s originated from heavy seeds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14449v1.title: Explaining the Chemical Inventory of Orion KL through Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14449v1.summary: The interplay of the chemistry and physics that exists within astrochemicallyrelevant sources can only be fully appreciated if we can gain a holistic understanding of their chemical inventories. Previous work by Lee et al. (2021)demonstrated the capabilities of simple regression models to reproduce the chemical inventory of the Taurus Molecular Cloud 1 (TMC-1)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14436v1.title: The VANDELS ESO public spectroscopic survey: The spectroscopic measurements catalogue
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14436v1.summary: VANDELS is a deep spectroscopic survey, performed with the VIMOS instrument. It is aimed at studying in detail the physical properties of high-redshiftgalaxies. VANDELS targeted about 2100 sources at 1<z<6.5 in the CANDELS ChandraDeep-Field South (CDFS) and Ultra-Deep Survey (UDS) fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14434v1.title: A disc wind model for blueshifts in quasar broad emission lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14434v1.summary: Blueshifts - or, more accurately, blue asymmetries - in broad emission lines are common in luminous quasars. The formation of these blueshifts is still not fully understood, and neither is their physical connection to the BAL phenomenon or accretion disc. In this work, we present Monte Carlo radiative transfer and photoionization simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14433v1.title: Black Hole Binaries in AGN Accretion Discs II: Gas Effects on Black Hole Satellite Scatterings
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14433v1.summary: The black hole (BH) binaries in active galactic nuclei (AGN) are expected to mainly through scattering encounters in the ambient gaseous medium. We identify the region of parameter space in initial energy vs impact parameter where a scattering leads to binary formation. We provide a ready-to-use analytic criterion that utilises these two pre-encounterparameters to determine the outcome of an encounter.
