http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14431v1.title: GA-NIFS: co-evolution within a highly star-forming galaxy group at z=3.7 witnessed by JWST/NIRSpec IFS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14431v1.summary: We present NIRSpec IFS observations of a galaxy group around the massiveGS_4891 galaxy at z=3.7 in GOODS-South. These observations, obtained as part of the GTO GA-NIFS program, allow for the first time to study the properties of the interstellar medium and ionized gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14414v1.title: Characterizing the line emission from molecular clouds. II. A comparative study of California, Perseus, and Orion A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14414v1.summary: California, Perseus, and Orion A. are three clouds whose star-formation rates span one order of magnitude. We find that the line intensities depend most strongly on the H2Column density. A secondary effect, especially visible in Orion A, is a dependence of the line intensity on the gas temperature. The clouds have similar chemical compositions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14415v1.title: Initial mass function variability from the integrated light of diverse stellar systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14415v1.summary: We show that compact stellar systems do not follow the same trends with physical parameters that have been found for early-type galaxies. Most globular clusters in our sample have an IMF consistent with that of the MilkyWay, over a wide range of [Fe/H] and [Mg/Fe]. For this sample, the IMF appears to vary between objects in a way that is not explained by a single single metric-dependent prescription.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14407v1.title: Protostellar cores in Sagittarius B2 N and M
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14407v1.summary: We present 500 AU and 700 AU resolution 1 mm and 3 mm ALMA observations of protostellar cores in protoclusters Sagittarius B2 (Sgr B2) and Main (M) Parts of the most actively star-forming cloud in our                Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14408v1.title: Characterising ultra-high-redshift dark matter halo demographics and assembly histories with the GUREFT simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14408v1.summary: Dark matter halo demographics and assembly histories are a manifestation ofcosmological structure formation and have profound implications for theformation and evolution of galaxies. We present a new suite of Gadget atUltrahigh Redshift with Extra-Fine Timesteps (GUREFT) dark matter-only simulations that are carefully designed to capture halo mergerhistories.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14299v1.title: Intraday variations of polarization vector in blazars: a key to the optical jet structure?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14299v1.summary: This report presents the results of optical polarimetric observations carried out with 6-m and 1-m telescopes at SAO RAS. The study of the blazar S5 0716+714774radiation showed the presence of a period of the variability of brightness and polarization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14294v1.title: AspGap: Augmented Stellar Parameters and Abundances for 23 million RGB stars from Gaia XP low-resolution spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14294v1.summary: AspGap is a neural-network based regression model trained on APOGEE spectra. In the training step it learns to use XP spectra not only to predict stellar labels but also the high-resolution APOGee spectra that lead to the same labels. The inclusion of this last model component creates a more physically motivated mapping and significantlyimproves the prediction of stellar labels.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14257v1.title: iMaNGA: mock MaNGA galaxies based on IllustrisTNG and MaStar SSPs. -- III. Stellar metallicity drivers in MaNGA and TNG50
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14257v1.summary: The iMaNGA project uses a forward-modelling approach to compare the predictions of cosmological simulations with observations from SDSS-IV. The key of our analysis is that observational biases affecting the observationalinterpretation of MaNGA data are emulated in the theoretical sample. The simulations reproduce the observed global stellar population scaling relations quite well and produce younger stellar populations in late-type in agreement with observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14244v1.title: A Multi-Frequency View of the Radio Phoenix in the Abell 85 Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14244v1.summary: Radio phoenices are complex and filamentary diffuse radio sources found in merging and relaxed clusters. The formation of these sources was proposed to be adiabatic compression of old Active Galactic Nucleus (AGN) plasma inshock waves. Most of the previous spectral studies were limited to integrated spectral indices, which were found to be very steep.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10900v3.title: Little Red Dots or Brown Dwarfs? NIRSpec Discovery of Three Distant Brown Dwarfs Masquerading as NIRCam-Selected Highly-Reddened AGNs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10900v3.summary: Cold, substellar objects such as brown dwarfs have long been recognized as Contaminants in color-selected samples of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) Their near- to mid-infrared colors (1-5 $mu$m) can closelysemble the V-shaped spectra of highly-reddened accreting black holes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00041v2.title: UV-Bright Star-Forming Clumps and Their Host Galaxies in UVCANDELS at 0.5 $\leq$ z $\leq$ 1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00041v2.summary: Giant star-forming clumps contain important clues on galaxy formation and evolution. The demographics of clumps and their host galaxies remain uncertain. We construct a clump sample whose rest-frame1600 {\AA} luminosity is 3 times higher than the most luminous local HIIregions (M$_{UV} \leq -$16 AB) In our sample, 35 $\pm$ 3$\%$ of low-mass and high-mass galaxies are clumpy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02671v2.title: The UNCOVER Survey: A first-look HST+JWST catalog of 60,000 galaxies near Abell 2744 and beyond
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02671v2.summary: In November 2022, the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) returned deep near-infrared images of Abell 2744. Together with the existingHubble Space telescope (HST) imaging, this publicly available dataset opens afundamentally new discovery space to understand the remaining mysteries of theformation and evolution of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.07368v2.title: SUNRISE: The rich molecular inventory of high-redshift dusty galaxies revealed by broadband spectral line surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.07368v2.summary: Molecular ISM at high-$z$ is commonly studied using only a few species beyond CO. We report the detection of 38 and 25 emission lines in APM and NC. The spectra reveal the chemical richness and the complexity of the ISM. Our astrochemical model suggests that at such high column densities, FUVradiation is less important in regulating the IsM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17077v2.title: ComPACT: ACT+Planck galaxy cluster catalogue
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17077v2.summary: Galaxy clusters are the most massive gravitationally bound systems consisting of dark matter, hot baryonic gas and stars. They play an important role in observational cosmology and galaxy evolution studies. We have developed a deep learning model for segmentation of SZ signal on ACT+Planck intensity maps. The ComPACT catalogue contains 2,934 galaxy clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09569v2.title: Multimessenger study of merging massive black holes in the OBELISK simulation: gravitational waves, electromagnetic counterparts, and their link to galaxy and black hole populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09569v2.summary: Massive black-hole (BH) mergers are predicted to be powerful sources of low-frequency gravitational waves (GWs) Coupling the detection of GWs with anelectromagnetic (EM) detection can provide key information about merging BHs and their environments. We study the high-resolution cosmologicalradiation-hydrodynamics simulation OBELISK to assess the GW and EM detectability of BH mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00766v2.title: Black hole mergers as tracers of spinning massive black hole and galaxy populations in the OBELISK simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00766v2.summary: Massive black hole (BH) mergers will be key targets of future gravitationalwave and electromagnetic observational facilities. Galaxy mergers can temporarily boost the BH accretion rate and the host's star formation rate. When dynamical delays are not taken into account, the burst has generally faded by the time BHs merge.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17451v1.title: Are Odd Radio Circles virial shocks around massive galaxies? Implications for cosmic-ray diffusion in the circumgalactic medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17451v1.summary: Odd Radio Circles (ORCs) encircles massive galaxies in the sky with stellar mass situated at $z=0.2$-$0.6$, suggesting a possible physical connection. We found that pure advection of electrons from the shock results in a radio-emitting shell that is considerably narrower than the observed one.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17440v1.title: Investigating the Drivers of Electron Temperature Variations in HII Regions with Keck-KCWI and VLT-MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17440v1.summary: HII region electron temperatures are a critical ingredient in metallicity determining. Recent observations reveal systematic variations in the temperatures measured using different ions. We find that the temperatures from [OII] and [SII] are likely over-estimated due to the presence of electron density inhomogeneities in HII regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17405v1.title: The Surface Mass Density of the Milky Way: Does the Traditional $K_Z$ Approach Work in the Context of New Surveys?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17405v1.summary: We revisit the classical $K_Z$ problem -- determination of the vertical force and implied total mass density distribution of the Milky Way disk. We use chemically selected thin and thick disk samples based on APOGEE spectroscopy combined with the Gaiaastrometry. We conclude that the growing detail in hand on the chemodynamicaldistributions of Milky Way stars challenges traditional analytical treatments of the problem.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17386v1.title: The ALMA REBELS survey: obscured star formation in massive Lyman-break galaxies at z = 4-8 revealed by the IRX-$β$ and $M_{\star}$ relations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17386v1.summary: We investigate the degree of dust obscured star formation in 49 massive. Lyman-break galaxies (LBGs) at 6.5$-$8$ observed as part of the ALMA Reionization Era Bright EmissionLine Survey (REBELS) large program. From measurements of the rest-frame UV slope, we find that the brightest LBGs at these redshifts show bluer colours than expected.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15934v2.title: The effect of cluster dynamical state on ram-pressure stripping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15934v2.summary: Theoretical and observational studies have suggested that ram-pressure stripping by the intracluster medium can be enhanced during cluster interactions. We find a mild increase in the RPS fraction in interactingclusters with respect to all other classes (including post-mergers) This mildenhancement could hint at a short-lived enhanced ram- pressure stripping in tumultuous cluster mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17271v1.title: Spiral shocks induced in galactic gaseous disk: hydrodynamic understanding of observational properties of spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17271v1.summary: We investigate the properties of spiral shocks in a steady, adiabatic, non-axisymmetric, self-gravitating, mass-outflowing accretion disk around a compact object. We find that the dispersion between the pitch angle and shear rate and the star formation rate in spiral galaxies contains important physical information.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17248v1.title: Introducing the Condor Array Telescope. II. Deep imaging observations of the edge-on spiral galaxy NGC 5907 and the NGC 5866 Group: yet another view of the iconic stellar stream
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17248v1.summary: We used the Condor Array Telescope to obtain deep imaging observations of the entirety of the NGC 5866 Group. We find that the stellar stream consists of a single curved structure thatstretches $220$ kpc from a brighter eastern stream to a fainter western stream that bends to the north.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17246v1.title: The soft X-ray background with Suzaku II: Supervirial temperature bubbles?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17246v1.summary: Observations of the hot X-ray emitting interstellar medium in the Milky Way are important for studying the stellar feedback and understanding the formation and evolution of galaxies. The 0.8 keV component of the 0.7--1.7 keV spectra of some regions is probably heated by supernovae in the galaxy's disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17236v1.title: Millimetre and submillimetre spectroscopy of isobutene and its detection in the molecular cloud G+0.693
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17236v1.summary: Isobutene is one of the four isomers of butene (C$_4$H$_8$). Given the detection of propene (CH$_3$CH=CH $_2$) toward TMC-1, we believe that isobutene is a promising candidate to be searched for in space.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15948v2.title: The ALMA Reionization Era Bright Emission Line Survey (REBELS): The molecular gas content of galaxies at z~7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15948v2.summary: A key to understanding the formation of the first galaxies is to quantify the content of the molecular gas as the fuel for star formation activity through the epoch of reionization. In this paper, we use the 158$\mu$m [CII]fine-structure emission line as a tracer of molecular gas in the Interstellar medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17180v1.title: A new tidal scenario for double bar formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17180v1.summary: Double bars make up a significant fraction of barred galaxies. We propose a new formation scenario for double bars that involves tidal interactions. In the proposed scenario, the inner bar forms first, either in isolation, via instabilities, or through previous tides. The outer bar forms later from the material that is tidallyorted by a strong interaction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17153v1.title: The role of radial migration in open cluster and field star populations with Gaia dr3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17153v1.summary: The survival time of a star cluster depends on its total mass, density, and size. This study aims to investigate if open clusters and field stars respond differently to the perturbations that causeradial migration. Older survived clusters are usually more massive and move on orbiting with higher eccentricity. Such orbits lead them to reach higher elevations on the Galactic plane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09760v2.title: The compactness of ultra faint dwarf galaxies : a new challenge ?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09760v2.summary: Numerical simulations of ultra-faint dwarf galaxies (UFDs) have failed to reproduce the observed size-luminosity relation. We have developed a simple but numerically clean and powerful method in which predictions of thestellar content of UFDs from LCDM cosmological hydro-dynamical-simulations is combined with very high resolution dark matter only runs. This method allows totrace the build-up history of U FDs and determine the impact of the merger of objects on their final size.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17075v1.title: Hydrodynamical simulations of the galaxy population: enduring successes and outstanding challenges
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17075v1.summary: State-of-the-art simulations can reproduce the observed spatial clustering of galaxies. However, these models generally predict markedly different gas flow rates into, and out of, galaxies. CGMobservations are a promising means of breaking this degeneracy and guiding the development of new feedback models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14737v2.title: SRG/eROSITA Survey in the Lockman Hole: Classification of X-ray Sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14737v2.summary: We have classified the point-like X-ray sources detected by the SRG/eROSITAtelescope in the deep Lockman Hole survey. 357 sources have been classified as Galactic and 5929 as extragalactic. 539 out of 6885 have been treated as hostless.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17015v1.title: Dissociative Recombination of Rotationally Cold OH$^+$ and Its Implications for the Cosmic Ray Ionization Rate in Diffuse Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17015v1.summary: Observations of OH$^+$ are used to infer the interstellar cosmic ray exponentiallyionization rate in diffuse atomic clouds. In regions where the H$_2$ to H number density is low, dissociative recombination is the dominant destruction process. We have studied DR of electronically and vibrationally relaxed OH$+$ in its lowest rotational levels.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16958v1.title: PopSED: Population-Level Inference for Galaxy Properties from Broadband Photometry with Neural Density Estimation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16958v1.summary: We present PopSED, a framework for population-level inference of galaxyproperties from photometric data. We validate our method using mock observations and apply it to galaxiesfrom the GAMA survey. With the unprecedented number of galaxies in upcoming surveys, our method offers an efficient tool for studyinggalaxy evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16926v1.title: The Close AGN Reference Survey (CARS): An interplay between radio jets and AGN radiation in the radio-quiet AGN HE 0040-1105
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16926v1.summary: He 0040-1105 is an unobscured radio-quiet AGN at a high accretion rate. It hosts an ionized gas outflow with the largest spatial offset from its nucleus. We show that neither AGN coronal emission nor star formation processes wholly explain the radio morphology/spectrum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16875v1.title: Galaxy And Mass Assembly: The xSAGA Galaxy Complement in Nearby Galaxy Groups
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16875v1.summary: Groups of galaxies are the intermediate density environment in which much of the evolution of galaxies is thought to take place. In spectroscopic redshiftsurveys, one can identify these as close spatial redshift associations. We find 1825 xSAGA galaxies within the bounds of the GAMA equatorial fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16863v1.title: M67 Blue Stragglers with High-resolution Infrared Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16863v1.summary: We report on the first detailed infrared chemical analysis of five binary members in the open cluster M67. These stars are located outside (bluer and/or brighter than) the main-sequence turnoff region. We detect vsin i greater than or equal to 25 km s-1 in three of our program stars: S1031, S975, and S1195.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16856v1.title: A 9-Month Hubble Space Telescope Near-UV Survey of M87. II. A Strongly Enhanced Nova Rate near the Jet of M87
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16856v1.summary: The 135 classical novae that we have discovered in M87 with two Hubble Space Telescope imaging surveys appear to be strongly focused along that galaxy's jet. The enhanced rate of novae along M87's jet is now firmlyestablished, and unexplained. We explore whether the remarkable nova distribution could be caused by the jet'sirradiation of the hydrogen-rich donors in the galaxy's cataclysmic binaries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16832v1.title: ALMA Lensing Cluster Survey: average dust, gas, and star formation properties of cluster and field galaxies from stacking analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16832v1.summary: We develop new tools for continuum and spectral stacking of ALMA data. We derive the average molecular gas content by stacking the emission line in a SFR-selected subsample. Cluster and field galaxies show similar trends in their contents of dust and gas, even when field galaxies were brighter in the stacked maps.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11961v2.title: A characterization of ASAS-SN core-collapse supernova environments with VLT+MUSE: I. Sample selection, analysis of local environments, and correlations with light curve properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11961v2.summary: The analysis of core-collapse supernova (CCSN) environments can provide important information on the life cycle of massive stars. The MUSE instrument enables detailed local environment constraints of the progenitors of large samples of CCSNe. We found that stripped-envelope (SE) SNe occur in environments with a higher median SFR, H$\alpha$ EW, and oxygen abundances than SNe II and SNeIIn/Ibn.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16811v1.title: Bar formation and destruction in the FIRE-2 simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16811v1.summary: Bar formation is influenced by satellite interactions and the stellar-to-dark matter ratio in the inner galaxy. Bar formation is more likely to occur, and the bars formed are stronger and longer-lived, if the disks are kinematically cold. galaxies with high central gas fractions and/or vigorous star formation tend to form weaker bars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16800v1.title: Resolved star formation in TNG100 central and satellite galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16800v1.summary: Proper modeling of energetic feedback from supernovae and active galactic nuclei is critical to the ability of simulations to reproduce observed galaxy properties. Here, we analyze local properties of central and satellite galaxies in the $z=0$ snapshot of the TNG100 simulation as a test of feedback models. We find that, on average, high-mass galaxies quench from the inside-out, while low-mass galaxy have similar, flatter profiles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16769v1.title: Sp1149 II: Spectroscopy of HII Regions Near the Critical Curve of MACS J1149 and Cluster Lens Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16769v1.summary: Galaxy-cluster gravitational lenses enable the study of faint galaxies even at large lookback times. We use the GLAFIC lens model to constrain the Balmer L-sigmarelation for HII regions in a galaxy at redshift z=1.49 strongly lensed by the MACS J1149 galaxy cluster. We find that the models predict magnifications an average factor of 6.2 smaller, a factor that is consistent with our measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16767v1.title: Sp1149 I: Constraints on the Balmer L-sigma Relation for HII Regions in a Spiral Galaxy at Redshift z=1.49 Strongly Lensed by the MACS J1149 Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16767v1.summary: We measure the luminosities and velocity dispersions of H-alpha and H-beta emission from 11 HII regions in Sp1149, a spiral galaxy at redshift 1.49 multiply imaged by the MACS J1149 galaxy cluster. We identify an HII region that is dramatically brighter (by 2.03+-0.44 dex) than the low-redshift L-sigma relation predicts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16764v1.title: Compact groups from semi-analytical models of galaxy formation -- IV: effect of group assembly on the evolution of their galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16764v1.summary: The evolution of CG galaxy properties with time is a clear function of their stellar masses. High-stellar-mass CG galaxies have lived their last 8 Gyr with little cold gas content while maintaining their reservoir of hot gas. Low-massCG galaxies still preserve some of their cold gas. content at the present but they have completely drained their hot gas reservoir.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16757v1.title: A SPectroscopic survey of biased halos In the Reionization Era (ASPIRE): JWST Discovers an Overdensity around a Metal Absorption-selected Galaxy at $z\sim5.5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16757v1.summary: The launch of the JWST opens a new window for studying the connection between metal-line absorbers and galaxies at the end of the Epoch of                Reionization (EoR) Previous studies have detected absorber-galaxy pairs in                limited quantities through ground-based observations. We report the discovery of a MgII-associated                galaxy at $z=5.428$ using data from the ASPIRE program.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16752v1.title: Synchrotron Signatures of Cosmic Ray Transport Physics in Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16752v1.summary: Cosmic rays (CRs) may drive outflows and alter the phase structure of the tumultuouscircumgalactic medium. However, these effects ultimately depend on the dominant mode oftransport of CRs within and around galaxies, which remains highly uncertain. We investigate potential observable constraints on CR transport in a set of cosmological FIRE-2 CR-MHD simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14818v2.title: Black Hole Growth, Baryon Lifting, Star Formation, and IllustrisTNG
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14818v2.summary: Quenching of star formation in the central galaxies of cosmological halos is thought to result from energy released as gas accretes onto a supermassive black hole. The same energy source also appears to lower the central density and raise the cooling time of baryonic atmospheres in massive halos. We present theincreasingly strong observational evidence supporting a such a relationship.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09139v2.title: The Pandora project. I: the impact of radiation and cosmic rays on baryonic and dark matter properties of dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09139v2.summary: Dwarf galaxies have been extensively studied to learn about the underlying cosmology, notwithstanding that physical processes regulating their properties are poorly understood. To shed light on these processes, we introduce the Pandora suite of 17 high-resolution dwarf galaxy formation cosmologicalsimulations. We find hydrodynamical `SN feedback-only' models struggle to produce realistic dwarf galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14168v1.title: The population of young low-mass stars in Trumpler 14
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14168v1.summary: Massive star-forming regions are thought to be the most common birth environments in the Galaxy and the only birth places of very massive stars. Their presence in the stellar cluster alters the conditions within the cluster at the same time the evolution of other cluster members. Spectroscopic studies of low-mass members of the whole Carina Nebula Complex are missing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19149v2.title: Relativistic binary-disc dynamics and the timing of OJ-287's flares
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19149v2.summary: We revisit the precessing black hole binary model, a candidate to explain the quasi-periodic optical flares in OJ-287's light curve. We showcase our model's predicting power by timing the 2019 Eddington flare within 40 hr of the observed epoch, exclusively using data available prior to it. According to the model, the 26th of August 2023 $\pm$ 32 days, shifted by approximately a year with respect to previous expectations. Our improved methodology can uncover previously unstated correlations in the parameter posteriors and patterns in the flare timing uncertainties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14147v1.title: Comparison of distance measurements to dust clouds using GRB X-ray halos and 3D dust extinction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14147v1.summary: X-ray photons from energetic sources such as gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) create a time-evolving halo around the GRB position. X-ray observations of such halos allow the measurement of distances in the Galaxy on which the scattering occurs. We found that in all GRBs we can find at least one local maximum in the 3D dust extinction map that is in agreement with the dust distance measured from X-Ray rings.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14095v1.title: Velocity-resolved high-J CO emission from massive star-forming clumps
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14095v1.summary: Massive star formation is associated with energetic processes, which result in significant gas cooling via far-infrared (IR) lines. Velocity-resolved SOFIA/GREAT spectra of 13 high-mass star forming clumps of various luminosities and evolutionary stages are studied using CO 11-10 and 16-15 lines. Gas rotational temperatures cover a narrow range of 120-220K for the line wings.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14093v1.title: Nuclear rings are the inner edge of a gap around the Lindblad Resonance
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14093v1.summary: Gaseous nuclear rings are large-scale coherent structures commonly found at the centres of barred galaxies. We propose that they are an accumulation of gas at the inner edge of an extensive gap that forms around the Inner LindbladResonance (ILR) The speed at which the gap progressively moves and its final distance from the ILR strongly depend on the sound speed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14075v1.title: Bayesian inference of 3D densities of galactic HI and H2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14075v1.summary: Knowing the spatial distribution. of atomicand molecular hydrogen gas is of great importance for interpreting and.modelling cosmic ray data and diffuse emission. We reconstruct the 3D densities of atomic and molecular hydrogen in the Galaxy together with (part of) the galactic velocity field. Basis for these reconstructions are the data-sets from the HI4PI-survey on the 21-cm emission line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14020v1.title: Multiple emission lines of H$α$ emitters at $z \sim 2.3$ from the broad and medium-band photometry in the ZFOURGE Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14020v1.summary: We present a multiple emission lines study of HAEs at $z \sim 2.3$ in the ZFOURGE survey. We investigate the relationship between the equivalent widths (EWs) of these emission lines and various galaxy properties. We have identified a discrepancy between the properties of low-mass H AEs and typical local star-forming galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.02886v3.title: PRUSSIC II -- ALMA imaging of dense-gas tracers in SDP.81: Evidence for low mechanical heating and a sub-solar metallicity in a z=3.04 dusty galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.02886v3.summary: Deep ALMA Band 3 observations of the HCN, HCO+, and HNC (4-3) emissions in SDP.81, a well-studied z = 3.042 strongly lensed galaxy. These lines trace the high-density gas, which remains almost entirely unexplored in high-redshift galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00042v2.title: Reaching for the stars -- JWST/NIRSpec spectroscopy of a lensed star candidate at $z=4.76$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00042v2.summary: JWST/NIRSpec observations of a highly magnified star candidate at a photometric redshift of 4.8%. The spectrum is in principle consistent with a star cluster. The presented spectrum seen at a time when the Universe was only $sim1.2$ Gyr old showcases the ability of JWST to study early stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13983v1.title: Numerical studies on the link between radioisotopic signatures on Earth and the formation of the Local Bubble. II. Advanced modeling of interstellar 26Al, 53Mn, 60Fe, and 244Pu influxes as traces of past supernovae in the solar neighborhood
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13983v1.summary: Using Gaia EDR3, we identified 14 SN explosions, 13 occurring in UCL/LCC, and one in V1062 Sco. We then performed 3D hydrodynamic simulations based on these initial conditions to explore the evolution of the LB in an inhomogeneous local interstellar medium. The simulations include the stellar winds from the SN progenitors and additional radioisotopes (26Al, 53Mn, and 244Pu) besides 60Fe. We find that our simulations are consistent with measurements of 60Fe, in particular, a peak 2-3 Myr before present.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13912v1.title: Merging Filaments and Hub Formation in the G083.097$+$03.270 Molecular Complex
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13912v1.summary: We uncover a hub-filament system associated with massive star formation in the G083.097$+$03.270. We propose that merging of large-scale filaments and velocity gradients along filaments are the driving factors in the mass accumulation process at the hub.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03926v3.title: Corrected SFD: A More Accurate Galactic Dust Map with Minimal Extragalactic Contamination
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03926v3.summary: The widely used Milky Way dust reddening map was found to contain extragalactic large-scale structure imprints (Chiang & M\'enard 2019) Such contamination is inherent in mapsbased on infrared emission. We build a large set of 180 overcomplete, full-sky basis template maps from the density fields of over 600 million galaxies in WISE.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04015v4.title: Direct Collapse to Precursors of Supermassive Black Hole Seeds:Radiation-feedback-generated Outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04015v4.summary: We use high-resolution zoom-in cosmological simulations to model outflow triggered by radiation and thermal drivers around the central mass accumulation. The radiation transfer is modeled using the ray-tracing algorithm. We follow the expanding wind-driven shell to break out of the central parsec and will reach the halo virial radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13821v1.title: An ALMA resoved view of 7,000 au Protostellar Gas Ring around the Class I source CrA-IRS 2 as a possible sign of magnetic flux advection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13821v1.summary: A ring-like structure produced by magnetic flux loss has been predicted theoretically, but no observationalidentification has been presented. We have performed ALMA observations of the Class I protostar IRS 2 in the Corona Australis star-forming region and resolved a distinctive gas ring. Similar structures reported in the other young stellar sources could likely be candidates formed by the same mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13809v1.title: Pulsar Scintillation through Thick and Thin: Bow Shocks, Bubbles, and the Broader Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13809v1.summary: Observations of pulsar scintillation are among the few astrophysical probes of very small-scale phenomena in the interstellar medium. At least nine arcs are observed toward B1929$+$10 at screen distances spanning 90% of the pulsar's $361$ pcpath-length to the observer.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13789v1.title: BayeSED-GALAXIES I. Performance test for simultaneous photometric redshift and stellar population parameter estimation of galaxies in the CSST wide-field multiband imaging survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13789v1.summary: The forthcoming CSST wide-field multiband imaging survey will produce seven-band photometric spectral energy distributions (SEDs) for billions of galaxies. The effective extraction of astronomical information from these datasets of SEDs relies on the techniques of both SED synthesis and analysis. The SED models with moreflexible (or complicated) forms of SFH/DAL do not necessarily lead to better estimation of redshift and stellar population parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13750v1.title: Tests of subgrid models for star formation using simulations of isolated disk galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13750v1.summary: We use smoothed-particle hydrodynamics simulations of isolated Milky Way-mass disks to test subgrid prescriptions for star formation. Our fiducial model combines a Schmidt law with agravitational instability criterion, but we also test density thresholds and temperature ceilings. We show that our model agrees with observed KS relations for neutral,atomic and molecular gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11558v2.title: Estimating major merger rates and spin parameters ab initio via the clustering of critical events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.11558v2.summary: We build a model to predict from first principles the properties of major                mergers. We predict these from the coalescence of peaks and saddle points in the vicinity of a given larger peak. Our model allows us to (a) compute the probability distribution of the satellite-merger separation in Lagrangian space.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14846v3.title: Khronometric theories of modified Newtonian dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14846v3.summary: In 2011 Blanchet and Marsat suggested a fully relativistic version of Milgrom's modified Newtonian dynamics. This theory is simpler than the alternative relativsiticformulations. We show that the theory has a consistent non-relativistic or slow motion limit.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13594v1.title: Probing Schwarzschild-like Black Holes in Metric-Affine Bumblebee Gravity with Accretion Disk, Deflection Angle, Greybody Bounds, and Neutrino Propagation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13594v1.summary: Metric-affine bumblebee gravity theory offers a unique perspective on the nature of gravitational interactions. We analyze the behavior of accretion disks around Schwarzschild-like black holes in this modified gravity scenario. We also explore neutrino propagation around black holes within metric-affines gravity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13560v1.title: Multi-stream radial structure of cold dark matter haloes from particle trajectories: deep inside splashback radius
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13560v1.summary: We track trajectories of dark matter (DM) particles accreting onto halos in cosmological $N$-body simulations. We find that the radial densityprofile for particles having the same value of $p$ generally shows a double-power law feature. The double- power law nature is shown to be persistent and generic not only in mass-selected haloes but also in haloes selected in different criteria.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00023v2.title: Machine Learning Uncovers the Universe's Hidden Gems: A Comprehensive Catalogue of CIV Absorption Lines in SDSS DR12
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00023v2.summary: We assemble the largest CIV absorption line catalogue to date. The catalogue contains probabilities classifying the reliability of the absorption system within aquasar spectrum. Our catalogue can be used to investigate the physicalproperties of the circumgalactic and intergalactic media. We detect CIV absorbing systems with a redshiftrange of 1.37-5.1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13521v1.title: JWST MIRI and NIRCam Unveil Previously Unseen Infrared Stellar Populations in NGC 6822
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13521v1.summary: NGC 6822 is a nearby non-interacting low-metallicity dwarf galaxy. It hosts several prominent Hii regions, includingsites of highly embedded active star formation. JWST observations reveal for the first time in the near-IR the red clump stellar population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14370v1.title: Kinetic rate coefficients for electron-driven collisions with CH$^+$: dissociative recombination and rovibronic excitation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14370v1.summary: Cross sections and rate coefficients for rovibronic excitation of the CH$^+$ion by electron impact and dissociative recombination of CH$$+$ with electrons are evaluated. The method has been developed and tested, comparing the theoretical results with the data from the recent CryogenicStorage Ring experiment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03084v2.title: The stellar mass of the Gaia-Sausage/Enceladus accretion remnant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03084v2.summary: The GS/E structure is an accretion remnant that comprises a large fraction of the Milky Way's stellar halo. We measure a stellar mass of $6.7-8.4 per cent of the mass of the galactic halo, which is lower than others in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13453v1.title: Dissecting the Gaia HR diagram II. The vertical structure of the star formation history across the Solar Cylinder
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13453v1.summary: We use the Gaia DR3 HR diagram to study star formation history. We find a significant peak of star formation in the 2 to 3yr age bin. The total mass of stars formed per unit area over time is $118.7%-6.2%. This is nearly twice the presentstellar mass derived from kinematics within 1~kpc from the Galactic Plane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13418v1.title: Supermassive Black Holes with High Accretion Rates in Active Galactic Nuclei. XIII. Ultraviolet Time Lag of H$β$ Emission in Mrk 142
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13418v1.summary: We performed a rigorous reverberation-mapping analysis of the broad-line region (BLR) in a highly accreting nucleus, Markarian 142. We used continuum data taken with the Niel Gehrels Observatory in the UVW2 band, and the Las Cumbres Observatory, Dan Zowada Memorial Observatory, and Liverpool Telescope in the g band.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13374v1.title: Catalogue of model star clusters in the Milky Way and M31 galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13374v1.summary: Clusters in M31 span a wider range of age and metallicity, relative to the MW, possibly due to M31's recent major merger. Such a merger also heated up the in-situ GC population to higher orbital energy. Understanding the impacts of galaxymergers and accretion on the GC populations is crucial for uncovering the galaxy assembly histories.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13351v1.title: New insights in the bubble wall of NGC 3324: intertwined sub-structures and a bipolar morphology uncovered by JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13351v1.summary: We report the discovery of intertwined/entangled sub-structures towards the bubble wall of NGC 3324 below a physical scale of 4500 AU. The James Webb Space Telescope's (JWST) near- and mid-infrared images are employed to resolve the sharp edge. A massive star candidate VPHAS-OB1 #03518 seems to be responsible for the bipolar HII region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13313v1.title: New Insights on 30 Dor B Revealed by High-Quality Multi-wavelength Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13313v1.summary: The supernova remnant (SNR) 30 Dor B is associated with the OB association LH99. The stellar population in the vicinity of the SNR indicates a continuous star formation in the past 8--10 Myr. The observed very massive stars in LH99 cannot be coeval with the observed SNR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08992v2.title: Rotational spectroscopy of the thioformaldehyde isotopologues H$_2$CS and H$_2$C$^{34}$S in four interacting excited vibrational states and an account on the rotational spectrum of thioketene, H$_2$CCS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08992v2.summary: An investigation of the rotational spectrum of the interstellar moleculethioformaldehyde between 110 and 377 GHz through a pyrolysis reaction revealed a multitude of absorption lines. The $v_2 = 1$ state has been included in analyses of low-lying fundamental states of H$_2$CS for the first time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00441v2.title: A rotating satellite plane around Milky Way-like galaxy from the TNG50 simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00441v2.summary: Halo395 resembles the MW in a number of intriguing ways. It hosts a spiral central galaxy and its satellite plane is almostpendicular to the central stellar disk. It isembedded in a sheet plane, with a void on the top and bottom, similar to the local environment of MW.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13228v1.title: A physically motivated framework for measuring the mass and redshift dependence of galaxy pair fractions across cosmic time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13228v1.summary: Low mass galaxy pair fractions are under-studied across cosmic time. We use theIllustris TNG100 simulation to identify physically associated pairs between $z=0-4.2$. The low mass pair fraction, i.e.the fraction of galaxies in pairs, increases from $z =0-2.5. We advocate for separation limits that vary with the mass and redshift of the system.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04854v2.title: HI Rich but Low Star Formation galaxies in MaNGA: Physical Properties and Comparison to Control Samples
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04854v2.summary: Gas rich galaxies are typically star-forming. Out of 1575 MaNGA galaxies with HI-MaNGA detections, we find 83 (5%) to be HI rich with low SFR. Some galaxies in the sample are consistent with simply having their HI in a high angular momentum, large radius, low density disc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13149v1.title: Imaging the ring and jet in M87 at 85 GHz with the ngEHT and ngEHT+ngVL
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13149v1.summary: The Global mm-VLBI Array (GMVA) has demonstrated the ability to resolved what may be the general relativistic shadow of the supermassive black hole in M87. While the resolution does not improve due to the limit set by the diameter of the Earth, the ngEHT alone should provide both a higher fidelity image of the ring.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13148v1.title: The Effect of Multiple Cooling Channels on the Formation of Dark Compact Objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13148v1.summary: A dissipative dark sector can result in the formation of compact objects comparable to stars and planets. We investigate theformation of such compact objects from a subdominant inelastic dark mattermodel. The resulting distribution of these astrophysical compact objects and their properties can be used to furtherdefine and differentiate between dark sectors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01382v2.title: The Mass-Metallicity Relation of Dwarf Galaxies at Cosmic Noon from JWST Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01382v2.summary: We present a study of the mass-metallicity relation (MZR) of 51 dwarf galaxies. The dwarf galaxies are identified and confirmed by deep JWST/NIRISS imaging and slitless grismspectroscopic observations. We find that the MZR has a shallower slope at the low-mass end.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13122v1.title: The dominant mechanism(s) for populating the outskirts of star clusters with neutron star binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13122v1.summary: It has been argued that heavy binaries composed of neutron stars (NSs) andmillisecond pulsars (MSPs) can end up in the outskirts of star clusters via an interaction with a massive black hole (BH) binary. We argue here, however, that this mechanism will rarely account for such                observed objects. The most likely mechanism is a three-body interaction involving the NS/MSP binary and a normal star.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14945v2.title: The HERBAL model: A hierarchical errors-in-variables Bayesian lognormal hurdle model for galactic globular cluster populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14945v2.summary: Smaller dwarfs are increasingly likely to have no GCs, and these zeros cannot be easily incorporated into linear models. We introduce the Hierarchical-in-variables Bayesian lognormAL hurdle (HERBAL) model to represent the relationship between dwarf galaxies and their GC populations. We find that 50% of galaxies are expected to host globular cluster populations at a stellar mass of 6.996%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13115v1.title: FORGE'd in FIRE: Resolving the End of Star Formation and Structure of AGN Accretion Disks from Cosmological Initial Conditions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13115v1.summary: It has recently become possible to zoom-in from cosmological to sub-pc scales in galaxy simulations to follow accretion onto supermassive black holes. However, at some point the approximations used on ISM scales (e.g.optically-thin cooling and stellar-population-integrated star formation [SF] and feedback [FB] break down. We therefore present the first cosmologically realistic radiation-magnetohydrodynamic (RMHD) simulation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13104v1.title: Magnetic field amplification in cosmological zoom simulations from dwarf galaxies to galaxy groups
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13104v1.summary: Magnetic fields are ubiquitous in the Universe. We show that with sufficient numerical resolution the magnetic field Amplification and saturation is converged. Our results pave the way for detailed studies of cosmic rays and other physical processes that crucially depend on the strength and structure of magnetic fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13011v1.title: JWST NIRCam Observations of SN 1987A: Spitzer Comparison and Spectral Decomposition
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13011v1.summary: JWST NIRCam observations at 1.5-4.5 $\mu$m have provided broad and narrowband imaging of the evolving remnant of SN 1987A. Comparing with previous marginally spatially resolvedSpitzer IRAC observations from 2004-2019 confirms that the emission arises from the circumstellar equatorial ring.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12989v1.title: A determination of the LMC dark matter subhalo mass using the MW halo stars in its gravitational wake
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12989v1.summary: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) in its orbit on the stellar halo of the Milky Way. We employed the Gaia Data Release 3 to construct a halo tracers data set. We have compared the data with a theoretical model to estimate the DM subhalo mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12966v1.title: INSPIRE: INvestigating Stellar Population In RElics -- V. Final Data Release: the first catalogue of relics outside the local Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12966v1.summary: This paper presents the final sample and data release of the INvestigatingStellar Population In RElics (INSPIRE) project. It comprises 52 ultra-compactmassive galaxies (UCMGs) observed with the ESO-VLT X-Shooter spectrograph. The 52 UMCGs span a large range of DoR from 0.83 to 0.06, with 38 having formed more than 75% of their mass by $z=2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.08442v2.title: The impact of stochastic modeling on the predictive power of galaxy formation simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.08442v2.summary: All modern galaxy formation models employ stochastic elements in their prescriptions to discretise continuous equations. We find that the scatter in scaling relations predicted by the SWIFT code can be significantly impacted by random variability. We suggest that studies of individual objects within cosmological simulations should be treated with caution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12957v1.title: Probabilistic Classification of Infrared-selected targets for SPHEREx mission: In search of YSOs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12957v1.summary: We apply machine learning algorithms to classify Infrared (IR)-selected targets for NASA's upcoming SPHEREx mission. In particular, we are interested in classifying Young Stellar Objects (YSOs), which are essential for understanding the star formation process. We utilize photometric colors and magnitudes from seven near and mid-infraredbands simultaneously and employ machine and deep learning algorithms.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12939v1.title: Bright beacons? ALMA non-detection of a supposedly bright [OI] 63-um line in a redshift-6 dusty galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12939v1.summary: We report a non-detection of the [OI] 63-um emission line from the z = 6.03galaxy G09.83808 using ALMA Band 9 observations. This refutes the previouslyclaimed detection with APEX by (Rybak et al. 2020)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13100v1.title: JWST early Universe observations and ΛCDM cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13100v1.summary: Deep space observations of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have shown that the structure and masses of very early Universe galaxies at high redshifts (z~15) may be as evolved as galaxies in existence for ~10 Gyr. The JWST findings are thus in strong tension with the ${\Lambda}$CDM cosmological model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14412v2.title: JWST Photometry of Globular Cluster Populations in Abell 2744 at $z=0.3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.14412v2.summary: JWST imaging of the rich galaxy cluster Abell 2744 at $z=0.308$ has been used by the UNCOVER team to construct mosaic images in the NIRCAM filters. The exceptionally deep images reveal a large population of unresolved pointlike sources across the field, the vast majority of which are globular clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03635v2.title: Toward Microarcsecond Astrometry for the Innermost Wobbling Jet of the BL Lacertae Object OJ 287
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.03635v2.summary: BL Lacertae object OJ 287 is a very unusual quasar producing a wobblingradio jet and some double-peaked optical outbursts. This variability is widely explained by models of binary supermassive black hole (SMBH) or precessing jet/disk from a single SMBH. To enable an independent and nearly bias-free investigation on these possible scenarios, we explored the feasibility of extremely high-precision differential astrometry on its innermost restless jet.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00048v4.title: Detection of the Keplerian decline in the Milky Way rotation curve
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.00048v4.summary: We have identified, for the first time, a Keplerian decline of the Keplerianrotation curve, starting at 19 kpc and up to 26.5 kpc from the Galaxy center. This results in a sharply decreasing rotation curve for the Milky Way. The total mass is revised downwards to $2.06^{+0.24] kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12745v1.title: Revised gas-phase formation network of methyl cyanide: the origin of methyl cyanide and methanol abundance correlation in hot corinos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12745v1.summary: Methyl cyanide (CH$_3$CN) is one of the most abundant and widely spread interstellar complex organic molecules (iCOMs) Several studies found that, in hot corinos, methyl cyanide and methanol abundances are correlated suggesting achemical link. In this article, we present a revised network of the reactionsforming methyl cyanides in the gas-phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12730v1.title: The [CII] 158 $μ$m emission line as a gas mass tracer in high redshift quiescent galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12730v1.summary: Many efforts have been done in recent years to probe the gas fraction progressivelyevolution of massive quiescent galaxies (QGs) A clear picture has not yet been established. We propose overcoming this impasse by using the carbon [CII] 158 $\mu$m emission line to systematically probe the budget of unlensed QGs at z>2.8. This is when these galaxies could still host non-negligible star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12725v1.title: Scalable stellar evolution forecasting: Deep learning emulation vs. hierarchical nearest neighbor interpolation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12725v1.summary: Many astrophysical applications require efficient yet reliable forecasts of stellar evolution tracks. Running detailed stellar codes over wide and densely sampled parameter grids is prohibitively expensive computationally. We provide two solutions of auto-interpolation methods that find satisfactory trade-off points between cost-efficiency and accuracy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16360v2.title: Multi-phase gas nature in the sub-pc region of the active galactic nuclei II: Possible origins of the changing-state AGNs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16360v2.summary: "changing-look AGNs" are extreme cases where broad emission lines become faint/bright or even evendisappear/emerge between multi-epoch observations. The time-dependent behaviour arises primarily from gas dynamics, particularly the formation of non-steady, radiation-driven outflows within theinnermost region of the disc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12587v1.title: Coverage Dependent H$_2$ Desorption Energy: a Quantitative Explanation Based on Encounter Desorption Mechanism
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12587v1.summary: Recent experiments show that the desorption energy of H$_2$ on a diamond-likecarbon (DLC) surface depends on the coverage of the surface. We derive a math formula to calculate an effective H$-2$ Desorption Energy. We argue that the difference between the effective H-2-Desorption-Energy and the experimental results is due to the lack of knowledge about these two parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07072v5.title: JWST/NIRSpec Spectroscopy of $z=7-9$ Star Forming Galaxies with CEERS: New Insight into Bright Ly$α$ Emitters in Ionized Bubbles
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07072v5.summary: New JWST/NIRSpec observations of galaxies at $z\gtrsim7$ taken from the CEERS survey. Previous observations of this area have revealed associations of Ly$\alpha$ emitters at redshifts ($z=7.5, $7.7, $8.7)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10217v2.title: The JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey: Discovery of an Extreme Galaxy Overdensity at $z = 5.4$ with JWST/NIRCam in GOODS-S
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10217v2.summary: We report the discovery of an extreme galaxy overdensity at $z = 5.4$ in theGOODS-S field. We identified $N = 81$ galaxies at $5.2 < z < 5.5$ using HST+JWST photometry spanning $0.4-5.0\ \mu\mathrm{m}$. These data provide accurate and                well-constrained photometric redshifts down to $m.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.01111v2.title: Observational constraints on the origin of the elements. VI. Origin and evolution of neutron-capture elements as probed by the Gaia-ESO survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.01111v2.summary: Most heavy elements beyond the iron peak are synthesized via neutron captureprocesses. The nature of the astrophysical sites of neutron capture processes is still very unclear. This work explores the observational constraints of the chemical abundances of s-process and r-process elements on the sites.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12503v1.title: Revealing the Chemical Structure of the Magellanic Clouds with APOGEE. II. Abundance Gradients of the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12503v1.summary: We present the abundance gradients of the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) for 25 progressivelyelemental abundance ratios and their respective temporal evolution. We also present age-[X/Fe] trends using 6130 LMC field red giant branch (RGB) stars observed by SDSS-IV and APOGEE.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12467v1.title: CRIRES-POP: a library of high resolution spectra in the near-infrared. III. Line identification in the K-giant 10 Leo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12467v1.summary: High-resolution spectra in the near-infrared (NIR) are an important tool for the detailed study of stellar atmospheres. The accurate identification of elements and molecules in these spectra can be used to determine chemicalabundances and physical conditions in the photosphere of the observed star.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14354v3.title: The Swift Deep Galactic Plane Survey (DGPS) Phase-I Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14354v3.summary: The Deep Galactic Plane Survey is a Key Project. 380 tiled pointings covering 40 deg$^{2}$ of the Galactic Plane. Each pointing has a $5$ ks exposure, yielding a total of 1.9 Ms spread across the entire survey footprint. In total, we identify 928 X-ray sources, of which 348 are unique.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12410v1.title: Dissecting the morphology of star forming complex S193
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12410v1.summary: We have studied a star-forming complex S193 using near-infrared (NIR) and other archival data covering optical to radio wavelengths. We identified stellar clusters in the complex using the NIR photometric data and estimated the membership and distance of the clusters. We suggest the feedback from the massive stars might have triggered the formation of the central cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12401v1.title: The dependence of assembly bias on the cosmic web
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12401v1.summary: The physical origins of halo assembly bias have been linked to the slowdown of accretion due to tidal forces. The galaxy population displays significant low-mass secondary bias when split by distance to critical points representing nodes, filaments, and saddles. The maximum attenuation is measured for galaxies close to saddlepoints, where less than 35$\%$ of the signal remains.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12395v1.title: MaNGA DynPop -- V. The dark-matter fraction versus stellar velocity dispersion relation and initial mass function variations: dynamical models and full spectrum fitting of integral-field spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12395v1.summary: Using the final MaNGA sample (DR17) of 10K galaxies, we investigate the dark matter fraction $f_{\rm DM}$ within one half-light radius. We employ two techniques to estimate $f DM$: Jeans Anisotropic Modelling (JAM) and Stellar Population Synthesis (SPS) We find that both methods show a significant trend of increasing $f_DM$ with progressivelydecreasing $sigma e$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12394v1.title: Bridging the gap in the mass-size relation of compact galaxies with MaNGA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12394v1.summary: We present the analysis of the full MaNGA DR17 sample to characterize its populations of compact galaxies. We focus on galaxies that fill the stellar mass gap between compact elliptical galaxies (cEs) and compact massive galaxies (CMGs) We study theirstellar populations and kinematics to reveal how their properties depend on their stellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12376v1.title: Rotational Curves of the Milky Way Galaxy and Andromeda Galaxy in Light of Vacuum Polarization around Eicheon
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12376v1.summary: Eicheon properties are discussed. It is shown that the eicheon surface allowssetting a boundary condition for the vacuum polarization. This allows the production of the large distance shape of the Milky Way Galaxy rotationalcurve. Andromeda Galaxy's rotational curve is also discussed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04410v1.title: Evidence for Spatial Separation of Galactic Dust Components
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04410v1.summary: We present an implementation of a Bayesian mixture model to search for spatial separation of Galactic dust components. While no spatial information is built into the likelihood, our investigation unveils structures with high significance. The presence of amulti-population dust has implications for component separation techniques frequently employed in the recovery of the Cosmic Microwave Background.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04404v1.title: Seeding the CGM: How Satellites Populate the Cold Phase of Milky Way Halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04404v1.summary: The origin of the cold phase in the CGM is a highly debated question. We find that the less massive satellites not only lose all of their cold gas in a short period, but their stripped cold clouds also mix with the hot CGM gas and get heated up quickly. The more massive satellites can add cold gas to the total gas budget of the host CGM for several Gyrs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04382v1.title: Supernova Remnants in the Irregular Galaxy NGC4449
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04382v1.summary: The nearby irregular galaxy NGC4449 has a star formation rate of about 0.4                solar masses/yr and should host of order 70 SNRs younger than 20,000 years. We have carried out an optical imaging and spectroscopicsurvey in an attempt to identify these SNRs. Of these, 15 nebulae are almost certainly SNRs, based on a combination of higher [OI]:H-alpha ratios and broader line widths.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04372v1.title: Rotation Curve Fitting Model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04372v1.summary: A model ofrelativistic frame effects on Doppler shifts due to the slightly curved frames of an emitting galaxy and the Milky Way is derived. Fits to the175 galaxies reported in the SPARC database of galactic rotation profiles and photometry measurements. Implications of this model are discussed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04370v1.title: First Adiabatic Invariant and the Brightness Temperature of Relativistic Jets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04370v1.summary: The dependence of the brightness temperature on the distance to the central engine can be explained. We show that in this case the observed break inthe dependence of. the brightness Temperature on the Distance to the Central Engine can't be explained by the first adiabatic invariant for radiating particles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01516v2.title: The birth and early evolution of a low mass protostar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01516v2.summary: We carry out a high resolution numerical simulation of the collapse of a dense molecular cloud core to stellar densities. We find that the sub-critical behavior of the protostar's shock front causes it to swell as it accretes matter. We also find that it is turbulent from the moment of its inception despite its radiative stability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04287v1.title: Spectroscopic variability of massive pre-main-sequence stars in M17
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04287v1.summary: We have access to a unique sample of (massive) pre-main-sequence (PMS) stars in M17. The aim is to understand the variability properties of the hot gaseous disks. We have obtained multiple-epoch (4-5 epochs) VLT/X-shooterspectra of six young stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04260v1.title: An X-rays-to-radio investigation of the nuclear polarization from the radio-galaxy Centaurus A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04260v1.summary: Centaurus A is one of the closest radio-galaxies to Earth. Its proximityallowed us to extensively study its active galactic nucleus. The core's emission mechanism remains elusive because of local strong dust and gas. The capability of polarimetry to shave-off contaminating emission has been exploited without success in the near-infrared.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.13359v2.title: The strongest cool core in REXCESS: Missing X-ray cavities in RXC J2014.8-2430
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.13359v2.summary: We present a multiwavelength study of RXC J2014.8-2430, the most extreme cool-core cluster in the Representative $XMM-Newton$ Cluster Structure Survey. Whilefeedback from an active galactic nucleus (AGN) is thought to be the dominant Mechanism by which a cooling flow is suppressed, the $Chandra$ images surprisingly do not reveal the bi-lateral X-ray cavities expected.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04204v1.title: Exploring the interstellar medium of NGC 891 at millimeter wavelengths using the NIKA2 camera
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04204v1.summary: We used the NIKA2 camera on theIRAM 30-m telescope to observe the edge-on galaxy NGC 891 at 1.15 mm and 2 mm. Indications of mm excess emission have also been found in the outer parts of the galactic disk. Small grains constitute 9.5% of the total dust mass in the galactic plane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04234v2.title: Extreme N-emitters at high-redshift: signatures of supermassive stars and globular cluster or black hole formation in action?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.04234v2.summary: Using the JWST/NIRSpec observations from CEERS we found an extreme N-emitter, CEERS-1019 at z=8.6782 showing intense NIV and NIII emission. Fromthe observed rest-UV and optical lines we conclude that it is compatible with photoionization from stars. The observations provide possible evidence for the presence of superhuman stars in the early Universe (z>8)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04133v1.title: Revising the cross correlation technique at high spectral resolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04133v1.summary: Cross-correlation techniques have been used since 1974 and, since 1979, the Fourier Method has been applied. We are currently obtaining data with spectral resolution higher than those for which this technique was developed, hence some revision seems timely. We propose to calculate the galaxy-galaxy and star-Galaxy correlations, with widths of $mu and $gt respectively.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09459v3.title: The first detection of SiC$_2$ in the interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.09459v3.summary: We report the first detection of SiC$_2$ in the interstellar medium. The molecule was identified through six rotational transitions toward G\,+0.693$-$0.027, a molecular cloud located in the Galactic center. It can be formed by a reaction between the sputtered atomic silicon and the silicon atoms in dust grains.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11946v2.title: A JWST/NIRSpec First Census of Broad-Line AGNs at z=4-7: Detection of 10 Faint AGNs with M_BH~10^6-10^8 M_sun and Their Host Galaxy Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11946v2.summary: We present a first statistical sample of faint type-1 AGNs at $z>4$identified by JWST/NIRSpec deep spectroscopy. The AGNs have low-mass black holes with remarkably lower than those of low-luminosity quasars previously identified with ground-based telescopes. Such faint AGNs contribute to cosmicipientreionization, while the total contribution is not large because of their faint nature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05937v2.title: The Gas Accretion Rate of Star-forming Galaxies over the last 4 Gyr
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05937v2.summary: Star-forming galaxies are believed to replenish their atomic gas reservoir through accretion of gas from theircircumgalactic mediums. However, there are few observational constraints on the gas accretion rate in external galaxies. We use our recent measurement of the scaling relation between the atomic hydrogen (HI) mass and the stellar mass $M_*$ to determine the evolution of the neutral gas reservoir.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04045v1.title: A low-mass line-rich core found in Massive Star-forming Region IRAS 16351-4722
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04045v1.summary: We present ALMA sub-arcsecond-resolution observations of both continuum and molecular lines at 345 GHz towards the massive star-forming region IRAS16351-4722 (hereafter I16351) A total of 12 dust cores were detected based on high spatial resolution observations of the continuum. Among them, a high-masscore (11.6 Msun) and a low-mass core (1.7Msun) show abundant molecular line emissions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02816v2.title: Total and dark mass from observations of galaxy centers with Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02816v2.summary: Mass estimator can accurately predict the galaxy dark masses inside the effective radius in all samples. Mass estimates are reproduced within 0.30 dex ($\sim2\sigma$), with a limited handful of outliers and almost no bias. This is independent of the kinematical data collected (fiber vs. 3D spectroscopy) and the dynamical analysis adopted.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13560v2.title: Multi-stream radial structure of cold dark matter haloes from particle trajectories: deep inside splashback radius
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13560v2.summary: We track trajectories of dark matter (DM) particles accreting onto halos in cosmological $N$-body simulations. We find that the radial densityprofile for particles having the same value of $p$ generally shows a double-power law feature. The double- power law nature is shown to be persistent and generic not only in mass-selected haloes but also in haloes selected in different criteria.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04014v1.title: Submillimetre galaxies as laboratories for dust grain coagulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04014v1.summary: Coagulation in the dense interstellar medium (ISM) is an important process that determines the size of the largest grains. We use submillimetre galaxies as laboratories of grain coagulation. Weamine how large the grains can be in such dense environments based on the observed typical dust mass density in SMGs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09220v4.title: Axion and the Supermassive Black Holes at high $z$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09220v4.summary: Axion dark matter (DM) is studied on the formation of supermassive blackholes (SMBHs) at high red shift $z$. It is shown that the attractive self-interaction of this DM may solve the tension between the high angular momentum of SMBH and its early time formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03943v1.title: Disentangling the Black Hole Mass Spectrum with Photometric Microlensing Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03943v1.summary: Modern astronomy frequently leverages surveys to understand populations of objects to answer fundamental questions. Photometric microlensing observables aredegenerate for different types of lenses. We apply a Bayesian framework that treats lens typeprobabilistically and jointly with a lens population model. This method allows lens population characteristics to be inferred despite intrinsic uncertainty in any single event.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03904v1.title: Velocity-Resolved Reverberation Mapping of NGC 3227
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03904v1.summary: A new reverberation mapping program focused on the Seyfert galaxy NGC 3227. Photometric and spectroscopic monitoring was carried out from 2022 December to 2023 June with the Las Cumbres Observatory. We detected time delays in several optical broademission lines, with H$\beta having the longest delay.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02231v2.title: Predicting the impact of feedback on matter clustering with machine learning in CAMELS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02231v2.summary: Baryonic physics affects matter clustering at $z=0$ using a library of power spectra. The magnitude of this effect is dependent on the galaxy formation implementation and variations of cosmological and astrophysical parameters. Increasing AGN feedback strength decreases halo                baryon fractions and yields stronger suppression of power relative to N-body simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03858v1.title: Spectral Survey of the Star Formation Region DR21OH in the 4 mm Wavelength Range
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03858v1.summary: Results of a spectral survey of the region of massive star formation in the 4-mm wavelength range are presented. Sixty-nine molecules and their isotopologues have been detected, ranging from simple diatomic ortriatomic species such as SO, SiO and CCH. The bulk of the molecules detected at 4~mm are common for dense cores.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.10877v3.title: The 2017 Release of Cloudy
http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.10877v3.summary: We describe the 2017 release of the spectral synthesis code Cloudy. Many large datasets have been incorporated with the result that we can now predict well over an order of magnitude more emission lines. We give examples of the accuracy limits using small models, and the performance requirements of large complete models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03832v1.title: The Evolution of Inclined Binary Black Holes in the Disks of Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03832v1.summary: Embedded neutron stars and black holes may form binaries and merge, emitting gravitational waves detectable by LIGO/VIRGO. AGN disks are a promising environment for the production of high-mass gravitational wave events involving black holes in the pair instability massgap. However, many orders of magnitude separate the typical length scales of binary formation and those on which gravitational waves can drive binaryinspirals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03806v1.title: Temporal Properties of the Compressible Magnetohydrodynamic Turbulence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03806v1.summary: The majority of fluctuation power in turbulence does not follow any of the MHD wavedispersion relations but has very low temporal frequency. The Lorentzian broadening widths of the three MHD Modes exhibit scaling relations to the global frame wavenumbers. The results provide a new window to investigate the temporal properties of turbulence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03803v1.title: Investigating Protostellar Accretion-Driven Outflows Across the Mass Spectrum: JWST NIRSpec IFU 3-5~$μ$m Spectral Mapping of Five Young Protostars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03803v1.summary: This paper introduces the NIRSpec 2.9--5.3 $\mu$m data of theinner 840-9000 au with spatial resolutions from 28-300 au. The spectra showrising continuum emission, deep ice absorption, emission from H$_2$ and H~I, and knots of [FeII] emission with dynamical times of $< 30$~yrs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03799v1.title: The Supersonic Project: Lighting up the faint end of the JWST UV luminosity function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03799v1.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is capable of probing extremely early tumultuouseras of our Universe when the supersonic relative motions between dark matter and baryonic overdensities modulate structure formation. We study low-mass galaxy formation including this "stream velocity" using highresolution AREPO hydrodynamics simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03794v1.title: The relationships between AGN power and molecular gas mass within 500 pc of the center of elliptical galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03794v1.summary: The discovery of molecular gas around the AGNs suggests that the gas is fueling the AGN. We analyze Atacama LargeMillimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) data on CO line (J=1-0, 2-1, 3-2)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03796v1.title: Searching for [CII] Emission from the First Sample of $z\sim 6$ OI Absorption-Associated Galaxies with ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03796v1.summary: We report the first statistical analyses of [CII] and dust continuumobservations in six strong OI absorber fields. At redshifts of OI-absorbers in non-detection fields, no emitters are brighter than our detection limit. The contribution of massive galaxies that contributed to metal enrichment cannot be ignored.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03790v1.title: Low-mass globular clusters from stripped dark matter halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03790v1.summary: The origin and formation of globular clusters has remained a mystery. We provide a formation scenario for ancient globular cluster-like objects. The clusters exhibit short, episodic star formation histories, occasionally marked by the presence of multiple stellar generations. The presence of these objects is attributable to star formation occurring within low-mass dark matter halos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03787v1.title: Unveiling the hidden universe with JWST: The contribution of dust-obscured galaxies to the stellar mass function at $\mathbf{z\sim3-8}$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03787v1.summary: The emergence of massive, optically-faint galaxies in infrared observations has revealed that our view of the high-redshift Universe was previously incomplete. With the advent of JWST, we can for the first time probe therest-frame optical emission of galaxies at $z>3$ with high sensitivity and spatial resolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03788v1.title: Looking in the axion mirror: An all-sky analysis of stimulated decay
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03788v1.summary: Axion dark matter (DM) produces echo images of bright radio sources. These images appear as a faint radio line centered at half the axion mass. We present an all-skyanalysis of axion DM-induced echo images. The aggregate signal strength is not significantly affected by individual sources of stimulating radiation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03783v1.title: The THESAN project: connecting ionized bubble sizes to their local environments during the Epoch of Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03783v1.summary: An important characteristic of cosmic reionization is the growth of ionized gas bubbles surrounding early luminous objects. Understanding the connections between the formation and coalescence of these bubbles and their originatingstellar sources is equally critical. We present results from a study of bubble sizes using the state-of-the-art THESAN radiation-hydrodynamics simulations suite.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03741v1.title: EFTofLSS meets simulation-based inference: $σ_8$ from biased tracers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03741v1.summary: Simulation-based inference (SBI) does not require an explicit form for the likelihood but only a prior and asimulator. The form of the covariance is more important than the non-Gaussianity of the likelihood, although this conclusion is expected todepend on the cosmological parameter inferred.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12234v2.title: Wet Compaction to a Blue Nugget: a Critical Phase in Galaxy Evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12234v2.summary: High-redshift galaxies tend to undergo a robust `wet compaction' event. This is a gaseousshrinkage to a compact star-forming phase, a 'blue nugget' This is followed by a central quenching of star formation. Such nuggets are observed at cosmic noon and seed today's early-type galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15274v2.title: Multiple imaging of the quasar 2005+403 formed by anisotropic scattering
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15274v2.summary: We report on the low Galactic latitude ($b=4.3^\circ$) quasar 2005$+$403, the second active galactic nuclei. We detected a rare phenomenon of multiple imaging induced by refractive-dominated scattering. The pattern formed by anisotropic774scattering is stretched out along the line of constant Galactic latitude.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03603v1.title: Cepheid Metallicity in the Leavitt Law (C- MetaLL) survey: IV. The metallicity dependence of Cepheid Period-Luminosity relations
