http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03603v1.summary: Classical Cepheids (DCEPs) play a fundamental role in the calibration of the extra-galactic distance ladder. We aim at quantifying the metallicity dependence of the Galactic DCEPs' $PL/PW$ relations for a variety of photometric bands ranging from optical to near-infrared.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03588v1.title: BAL Outflow in Quasar B0254-3327B: Analysis and Comparison with Other Extreme UV Outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03588v1.summary: We have identified a broad absorption line (BAL) outflow in the HST/STISspectrum of the quasar QSO B0254-3327B. The outflow has absorption troughs from ions such as Ne VIII, Na                IX, Si XII, and Ne V. We also report the first detection of S XIV absorptiontroughs, implying very high ionization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11314v2.title: The underlying radial acceleration relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11314v2.summary: The radial acceleration relation (RAR) of late-type galaxies relates theirynamical acceleration to that sourced by baryons alone. I use Hamiltonian Monte Carlo to perform the full joint inference of RAR and galaxy parameters for the Spitzer Photometry and Accurate RotationCurves (SPARC) dataset. This reveals the intrinsic RAR underlying that vantageobserved. I find an acceleration scale $a_0=(1.19 \pm 0.04 \, \text{(stat)})$ and weak evidence for theexternal field effect.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03552v1.title: A JWST survey of the Trapezium Cluster & inner Orion Nebula. I. Observations & overview
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03552v1.summary: A near-IR survey of the Trapezium Cluster and inner Orion Nebula using the NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope. The survey with the NIRCam instrument covers 10.9 x 7.5 arcminutes (~1.25 x 0.85 pc) in twelve wide-,Medium-, and narrow-band filters. Highlights include the discovery of large numbers of free-floating planetary-mass candidates as low as 0.6 Jupiter masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03544v1.title: UV Fe II emission model and its relation to broad-line time delays for HE 0413-4031 observed in the optical and IR bands
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03544v1.summary: The MgII emission is one of the lines used for black hole massmeasurement and for cosmological applications. We test different Fe II emission models when modeling the UV emission of the intermediate-redshift quasar HE0413-4031. The time delay of the Mg II emission is not significantly affected. We see a need to create better Fe II templates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.01039v3.title: The Horizon Run 5 Cosmological Hydrodynamic Simulation: Probing Galaxy Formation from Kilo- to Giga-parsec Scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.01039v3.summary: Horizon Run 5 (HR5) is a cosmological hydrodynamical simulation. It captures the properties of the Universe on a Gpc scale while achieving aresolution of 1kpc. The simulation successfullyreproduces observations, such as the cosmic star formation history andconnectivity of galaxy distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05749v3.title: Spectrum of the linearized Vlasov--Poisson equation around steady states from galactic dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05749v3.summary: We study the linearized Vlasov-Poisson equation in the gravitational case. We identify the absolutely continuous spectrum and give criteria for the existence of oscillating modes and estimate their number. Our method allows us to take into account an attractive external potential. For more information, visit: http://www.nasa.gov/science/topics/geological-mechanics/gravitational-case.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03520v1.title: Identification of Gravitational-waves from Extreme Mass Ratio Inspirals
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03520v1.summary: Space-based gravitational wave detectors like TianQin or LISA could observeextreme-mass-ratio-inspirals (EMRIs) at millihertz frequencies. The accurateidentification of EMRI signals from the data plays a crucial role in the study of astronomy and physics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10615v2.title: HST imaging of star-forming clumps in 6 GASP ram-pressure stripped galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10615v2.summary: Clumps are detected in H alpha and near-UV, tracing star formation on differenttimescales. Only 15 per cent of star-forming clumps are spatiallyresolved, meaning that most are smaller than 140 pc. The results suggest that the star formation is turbulence-driven and scale-free, as in main-sequence alaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03460v1.title: Deriving the intrinsic properties of M51 with radiative transfer models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03460v1.summary: A quantitative derivation of the intrinsic properties of galaxies related to their fundamental building blocks, gas, dust and stars is essential for our understanding of galaxy evolution. Here we present an                axi-symmetric RT model of the UV-optical-FIR/submm spectral and spatial energy distribution of the face-on spiral galaxy M51.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03454v1.title: Dust from evolved stars: a pilot analysis of the AGB to PN transition
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03454v1.summary: We present a novel approach to address dust production by low- and intermediate-mass stars. We study the asymptotic giant branch (AGB) phase, during which the formation of dust takes place. While the post-AGB phase traces the history of dust production back to the tip of the AGB.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03448v1.title: Serendipitous detection of the dusty Type IIL SN 1980K with JWST/MIRI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03448v1.summary: The Type IIL supernova (SN) 1980K was captured in mid-infrared (mid-IR) images by the James Webb Space Telescope. SN 1980K serves as a promising candidate for studying the transitional phase between young SNe and older SN remnants. It also provides a great opportunity to investigate its the close environment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03428v1.title: Constraining Millimeter Dust Emission in Nearby Galaxies with NIKA2: the case of NGC2146 and NGC2976
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03428v1.summary: Study presents the first millimeter continuum mapping observations of two nearby galaxies. The galaxies are the starburst spiral galaxy NGC2146 and the dwarf galaxyNGC2976. Maps of dust mass surface density, temperature, emissivity index, and thermal radio component of the galaxies are presented.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03413v1.title: HST FUV Spectroscopy of Super Star Cluster A in the Green Pea Analog Mrk 71: Revealing the Presence of Very Massive Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03413v1.summary: Mrk 71 is a low metallicity (Z = 0.16 Z_sun) starburst region in the local grotesquedwarf galaxy NGC 2366. The STIS and FOS far-ultraviolet (FUV) spectra of theembedded SSC Mrk 71-A were obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07958v3.title: Characterising the true descendants of the first stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07958v3.summary: The metal-poor stars in the Galactic halo are thought to show the imprints of the first (PopIII) stars. In this work, we aim at understanding whether all very metal- poor stars formed in environments polluted by PopIII supernovae (SNe) and if so, at what level.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03321v1.title: Hunting Gamma-ray emitting FR0 radio galaxies in wide-field sky surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03321v1.summary: Fanaroff-Riley type 0 (FR0) galaxies are the latest in a long line of radio galaxies. They are similar to more common FR I and II radio galaxies, but have a different core structure. They have a common gamma-ray production mechanism and are likely to have misaligned jets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.05095v3.title: XookSuut a code for modeling circular and non-circular flows on 2D velocity maps
http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.05095v3.summary: The XookSuut algorithm is optimized to perform robust Bayesian inference on models of circular and noncircular rotation in galaxies. It implements efficient sampling methods, specifically Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) and Nested Sampling (NS) In this way, kinematic models are obtained by pure sampling methods rather than standard minimization techniques.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03299v1.title: Dynamical Architectures of S-type Transiting Planets in Binaries I: Target Selection using Hipparcos and Gaia proper motion anomalies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03299v1.summary: The effect of stellar multiplicity on planetary architecture and orbital Dynamics provides an important context for exoplanet demographics. We present a volume-limited catalog up to 300 pc of 66 stars hosting planets and planet candidates from Kepler, K2 and TESS with significant Hipparcos-Gaia propermotion anomalies. We assess the reliability of each transiting planet candidate using ground-based follow-up.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03277v1.title: 3D structure of HII regions in the star-forming complex S254-S258
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03277v1.summary: The S254-258 star-forming complex is a place of massive star formation. Five OB-stars have created HII regions, visible as optical nebulae. The HII emission is attenuated by neutral material with $2 \leq A_V\leq 5$ mag.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03263v1.title: The Intracluster Light and its Link with the Dynamical State of the Host Group/Cluster: the Role of the Halo Concentration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03263v1.summary: We investigate on the role of the halo concentration in the formation of the                intra-cluster light (ICL) in galaxy groups and clusters. The fractional budget of ICL depends on both halo mass (very weakly) until group scales, and concentrations (remarkably) The ICL fraction is higher in more concentrated objects, a result of the stronger tidal forces acting in theinnermost regions of the haloes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03259v1.title: The EDIBLES Survey. VII. A survey of C2 and C3 in interstellar clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03259v1.summary: C$_2$ and C$_3$ molecules are detected in the same velocity components. No clear differences among sightlines with and without detection of the molecules. We find a very good correlation between $N$(C$2$) and $N $(C $3$) with Pearson $r = 0.93$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03236v1.title: Dissonance in harmony: The UV/optical periodic outbursts of ASASSN-14ko exhibit repeated bumps and rebrightenings
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03236v1.summary: ASASSN-14ko was identified as an abnormal periodic nuclear transient with a potential decreasing period. Its outbursts in the optical and UV bands havedisplayed a consistent and smooth "fast-rise and slow-decay" pattern since its discovery. The light curve profiles show a bump during the rising stages and arebrightening during the declining stages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03204v1.title: An Extremely Massive White Dwarf Escaped From the Hyades Star Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03204v1.summary: We searched the Gaia DR3 database for ultramassive white dwarfs withkinematics consistent with having escaped the nearby Hyades open cluster. Two of these candidates have masses estimated from Gaia photometry of approximately 1.1 solar masses. The remaining candidate has an expected mass >1.3 solar masses, significantly reducing the likelihood of it being an interloper. Analysis of follow-up Gemini GMOSspectroscopy for this source reveals a non-magnetized hydrogen atmosphere white dwarf.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03141v1.title: The galaxy cluster AC114 -- II. Stellar populations and the mass-metallicity relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03141v1.summary: We investigate the mass-metallicity relation for galaxies in the Abellcentriccluster AC114 from 7 hours of VIMOS/MR data collected at the ESO-VLT telescope. Active and passive galaxies are identified based on the presence/absence of the [\ion{O}{II}]\ Lambda3727, Hbeta4959,5007 and/or H\beta emission lines, depending on the galaxy redshift. We find that active galaxies have lower average masses than passive ones.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.11660v2.title: Properties of the jet in M87 revealed by its helical structure imaged with the VLBA at 8 and 15 GHz
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.11660v2.summary: Full-track high-resolution radio observations of the jet of M87 at 8 and 15 GHz. The jet is dominated by three helicalthreads, likely produced by the Kelvin-Helmholtz (KH) instability developing in the galaxy. We detect polarised emission in the jet at distances of approximately 20 milliarcseconds from the core.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01005v3.title: Self-similar growth of Bose stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01005v3.summary: We find that after the nucleation of this object, the bath is described by a self-similar solution of the kineticequation. Together with the conservation laws, this fixes mass evolution of the Bose star. Our theory explains, in particular, the slowdown of its growth at a certain "core-halo" mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03097v1.title: FRIED v2. A new grid of mass loss rates for externally irradiated protoplanetary discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03097v1.summary: We present a new FRIED grid of mass loss rates for externally far-ultraviolet(FUV) irradiated protoplanetary discs. As a precursor to the new grid, we also explore the microphysics of external photoevaporation. We find that metallicity typically has a small effect on the mass loss rate. When the PAH-to-dust ratio is lower, or the dust in the wind more abundant, themass loss rate can substantially lower.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03083v1.title: On the origin of star-formation quenching in massive galaxies at $z \gtrsim 3$ in the cosmological simulations IllustrisTNG
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03083v1.summary: Using the cosmological simulations IllustrisTNG, we perform a comprehensiveanalysis of quiescent, massive galaxies at $z \gtrsim 3$. The goal is to understand what suppresses their star formation so early in cosmic time. We find that activegalactic nuclei (AGN) feedback is the primary cause of halting star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03081v1.title: Star formation and AGN activity 500 Myr after the Big Bang: Insights from JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03081v1.summary: We consider the effect of including an Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) component when fitting spectral energy distributions of 109 spectroscopically confirmed galaxies with JWST. Remarkably, we find that the resulting cosmic star formation history is 0.9$ dex lower at $z\gtrsim 9.5$ when an AGN component is included in the fitting. This alleviates previouslyreported excess star formation at $ZWST 9. 5$ compared to models based on baryon conversion efficiencies inside dark matter halos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03077v1.title: On the ellipticity parameterization for an NFW profile: an overlooked angular structure in strong lens modeling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03077v1.summary: Galaxy-scale gravitational lenses are often modeled with two- component massprofiles. ellipticity can be introduced via the lensing potential (NFWp) or via the mass by approximating the NFW profile as a sum of analytical profiles. The NFWp method has been the default for lensing applications, but it gives a different prescription of the azimuthal structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03075v1.title: Probing the early Milky Way with GHOST spectra of an extremely metal-poor star in the Galactic disk
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03075v1.summary: Pristine_183.6849+04.8619 (P1836849) is an extremely metal-poor. star on a prograde orbit confined to the Galactic disk. Such stars are rare and may have their origins in protogalactic fragments that formed the early Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03074v1.title: Evidence for the evolution of black hole mass function with redshift
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03074v1.summary: We investigate the joint primary mass, mass ratio, and redshift distribution of astrophysical black holes using gravitational wave events detected by LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA. We reconstruct this distribution using Bayesian non-parametric methods. We find evidence for the evolution with redshift of both the primary mass and mass ratio distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03067v1.title: A surprisingly high number of dual active galactic nuclei in the early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03067v1.summary: Merger events can trigger gas accretion onto supermassive black holes (SMBHs) The fraction of AGN in pairs gives key information to constrain environmental properties and evolution of SMBHs and their host galaxies. Only very few dual AGN have been found in the distant Universe so far.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03063v1.title: $Λ$CDM not dead yet: massive high-z Balmer break galaxies are less common than previously reported
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03063v1.summary: Early JWST observations that targeted so-called double-break sources                (attributed to Lyman and Balmer breaks at $z>7$), reported a previously unknown population of very massive, evolved high-redshift galaxies. This surprising discovery led to a flurry of attempts to explain these objects' unexpectedexistence including invoking alternatives to the standard $Lambda$CDM paradigm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03065v1.title: Can supernovae quench star formation in high-$z$ galaxies?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03065v1.summary: JWST is providing the unique opportunity to directly study feedback processes regulating star formation (SF) in early galaxies. The two $z>5$ quiescent galaxies detected so far show a recent starburst after which SF is suppressed. To clarify whether such quenching is due to supernova (SN) feedback, we have developed a minimal physical model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03021v1.title: Effects of feedback-free starburst galaxies on the 21-cm signal and reionization history
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03021v1.summary: Different star-formation models at Cosmic Dawn produce detectable signatures. We show that FFBs affect the evolution of the brightness temperature and the 21-cm power spectrum, but they only have a limited effect on the neutral hydrogen fraction. We forecast the capability of the next-generation Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array to detect the existence of FFB galaxies via power spectrum measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03019v1.title: FRAMEx IV: Mechanical Feedback from the Active Galactic Nucleus in NGC 3079
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03019v1.summary: Using the Very Long Baseline Array, we observed the active galactic nucleus in NGC 3079 over a span of six months. We found evidence for positional differences in the positions of $A$ and $B$ over the six months consistent with the apparent motion of the galaxy. We calculated the amount of mechanical feedback on the ISM for both the expulsion and jet scenarios.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02999v1.title: Exploring X-ray Properties of Low Metallicity Dwarf Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02999v1.summary: Low metallicity dwarf galaxies may offer the mostrepresentative local analogs to pristine early galaxies, making them a vital tool in probing black hole seed models. These dwarf galaxies, and the IMBHs they may host, are typically not as well-studied in this context as their higher-metallicity counterparts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07266v2.title: Probable low-frequency quasi-periodic oscillations in blazars from the ZTF survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07266v2.summary: Quasi-periodic oscillation (QPO) signals are detected in 2103 blazars from the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) time-domain survey. Such nearly periodic signals on these timescales in opticalwavebands most likely originate from a precessing jet with high Lorentz factor.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10428v2.title: Field-level Lyman-alpha forest modelling in redshift space via augmented non-local Fluctuating Gunn-Peterson Approximation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10428v2.summary: We present an improved analytical model to predict the Lyman-alpha forest at the field level in redshift space from the dark matter field. We introduce the dependence on the cosmic web environment (knots, filaments,sheets, voids) in the model thereby effectively accounting for non-local bias. We find evidence for a significant difference of the same modelparameters in different environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02939v1.title: Identifying physical structures in our Galaxy with Gaussian Mixture Models: An unsupervised machine learning technique
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02939v1.summary: We explore the potential of the Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) to identify coherent physical structures in the ISM. The implementation we present can be used on any kind of spatially andspectrally resolved data set. We provide a step-by-step guide to use these models on different sources and data sets. We run the models on NGC 1977, RCW 120 and RCW 49.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02888v1.title: A versatile classification tool for galactic activity using optical and infrared colors
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02888v1.summary: The overwhelming majority of diagnostic tools for galactic activity are focused on active galaxies. Passive or dormant galaxies are often excluded from these diagnostics which usually employ emission line features. We develop a diagnostic tool using machine learningmethods that includes both active and passive galaxies under one unified scheme using 3 colors. We find that the combination of W1-W2, W2-W3, and g-r colors offers good performance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08657v2.title: On the Red Supergiant Wind Kink. A Universal mass-loss concept for massive stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.08657v2.summary: Red supergiants (RSG) are key objects for the evolution of massive stars and their endpoints. uncertainties in their underlying mass-loss mechanism have prevented an appropriate framework for massive star evolution. We argue that a universalbehaviour of radiation-driven winds across the HR diagram, independent of the exact source of opacity, is a key feature of the most massive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02857v1.title: A kinematic study of the disc-outflow system around a high-mass protostar G59.783+0.065 probed by methanol and water masers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02857v1.summary: Class II CH3OH masers are used as a convenient tracer of disc-like structures in high-mass star formation. More than half of them show a complex distribution in Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) maps. We suggest that the complex distribution arises from several distinct circumstellar structures that simultaneously achieve maser excitation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13809v3.title: The Influence of Subhaloes on Host Halo Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13809v3.summary: Dark matter haloes are comprised of both a smooth component and a population of smaller, gravitationally bound subhaloes. These components are often treated as a single halo when halo properties, such as density profiles, are extracted from simulations. Recent work has shown thatdensity profiles change substantially when subhalo mass is excluded.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15296v2.title: Caustics in Self-gravitating N-body systems and Cosmological Large Scale Structures
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15296v2.summary: Gravitational caustics are space regions where the density of matter is higher than the average density in the surrounding Universe. Extended galaxy surveys revealed that at a large scale the Universe consists of galactic clusters, filaments and vast regions devoid of galaxies. In our approach the dynamics of a self-gravitating N-body system is outlined in terms of a geodesic flow on a curved Riemannian manifold.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02780v1.title: Transonic galactic wind model including stellar feedbacks and application to outflows in high/low-$z$ galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02780v1.summary: Galactic winds play a crucial role in the ejection of the interstellar medium (ISM) into intergalactic space. Our model includes injections of mass and energy resulting from supernovae feedback along a flow line. The mass flux in galactic winds is a critical factor in determining the acceleration process of the flow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06756v2.title: The ultra-dense, interacting environment of a dual AGN at z $\sim$ 3.3 revealed by JWST/NIRSpec IFS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06756v2.summary: LBQS 0302-0019 is a blue quasar (QSO) at z ~ 3.3, hosting powerful outflows. It is located in a complex environment consisting of an obscured AGN candidate, multiple companions, all within 30 kpc in projection. The results support a scenario where mergers can trigger dual AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02758v1.title: Exploring the Brown Dwarf Desert with Precision Radial Velocities and Gaia DR3 Astrometric Orbits
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02758v1.summary: Brown dwarfs in close orbits (within 10 au) around solar-type stars poses significant questions about the origins of these companions. Most of the brown dwarfs have been discovered by radial velocity surveys. This method introduces uncertainty due to its inability to determine the orbital inclination. Combining radial velocity measurements with Gaia DR3 data led to more precise mass estimations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00366v4.title: CzSL: Learning from citizen science, experts and unlabelled data in astronomical image classification
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00366v4.summary: Citizen science is gaining popularity as a valuable tool for labelling large collections of astronomical images by the general public. This is often at the cost of poorer quality classifications made by amateur participants. The proposed approach first learns from unlabelled data with a convolutional autoencoder and then exploits amateur and expert labels via the pre-training and fine-tuning of a neural network.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01044v2.title: NIKA2 observations of starless cores in Taurus and Perseus
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01044v2.summary: Dusty starless cores play an important role in regulating the initial phases of the formation of stars and planets. In their interiors, dust grainscoagulate and ice mantles form, thereby changing the millimeter emissivities and hence the ability to cool. We mapped four regions with more than a dozenstellarcores in the nearby Galactic filaments of Taurus and Perseus using the IRAM 30-meter telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02661v1.title: Large-scale turbulence cascade in the spiral galaxy NGC~6946
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02661v1.summary: The generation mechanism of compressible fluid turbulence at kiloparsecs in the Interstellar Medium (ISM) is a long-lasting puzzle. In this work, we explore the nature of large-scale turbulence in the external spiral galaxyNGC~6946. We use the Visibility Moment Estimator (VME) to measure the column density and line of sight turbulent velocity power spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01589v2.title: Generalizations of Quasilinear MOND (QUMOND)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.01589v2.summary: I present a class of theories that generalize quasilinear MOND. These GQUMOND theories require solving only the linear Poisson equation. Unlike QUMOND, their Lagrangian depends on higher derivatives of the Newtonian potential. These theories mightopen new avenues to more fundamental theories.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11784v2.title: Quasar Factor Analysis -- An Unsupervised and Probabilistic Quasar Continuum Prediction Algorithm with Latent Factor Analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11784v2.summary: Quasar Factor Analysis (QFA) combines factor analysis (FA) with physical priors of the intergalactic medium (IGM) QFA captures the posterior distribution of quasar continua through generatively modeling quasar spectra. QFA can achieve thestate-of-the-art performance, $\sim 2\%$ relative error, for continuum Prediction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02595v1.title: Effect of low-mass galaxy interactions on their star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02595v1.summary: According to the cold dark matter model of galaxy formation, the assembling process is scale-free. The effects of interactions between dwarf galaxies on their evolution are not well understood. Future studies will help us to understand the effect of dwarf galaxy interactions on the spatial distribution of star forming clumps and to identify starforming in tidal tails.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02584v1.title: Infrared view of the multiphase ISM in NGC 253 II. Modelling the ionised and neutral atomic gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02584v1.summary: Multi-wavelength studies of galaxies and galactic nuclei allow us to build a relatively more complete picture of the interstellar medium. An understanding of the physical processes in nearby galaxies can assist in the study of more distant sources at higher redshifts, which cannot be resolved. We find that the hypothetical active galactic nucleus within NGC 253 has only a minor impact compared to the starburst on the heating of the ISM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00571v2.title: Identification of Galaxy Protoclusters Based on the Spherical Top-hat Collapse Theory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.00571v2.summary: We propose a new method for finding galaxy protoclusters that is motivated by structure formation theory and also directly applicable to observations. We use the critical overdensity for complete collapse at $z = 0$ predicted by the spherical top-hat collapse model. We also confirm that the redshift-space distortion does not significantly affect the performance of the protocluster identification scheme.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02558v1.title: New Dynamical Channel: Wide Binaries in the Galactic Center as a Source of Binary Interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02558v1.summary: The inner $500\rm pc$ in the galactic center is dense with stars and aynamically hot environment. We focus on wide binaries as a source of collisional interactions. During Galaxy's lifetime, we predict thousands of MS-MS interacting binaries that may form G2-like objects that appear younger than their environment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02415v2.title: A Photon Burst Clears the Earliest Dusty Galaxies: Modelling Dust in High-redshift Galaxies from ALMA to JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02415v2.summary: The generation and evolution of dust in galaxies are important tracers for star formation. Understanding dust in high-redshift galaxies is important for observational cosmology. We update the semi-analytical model A-SLOTH (Ancient Stars and Local Observables by Tracing Halos) to model the evolution of Dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02503v1.title: Validating posteriors obtained by an emulator when jointly-fitting mock data of the global 21-cm signal and high-z galaxy UV luminosity function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02503v1.summary: The accuracy of such constraints is poorly understood. We employ nested sampling to fit mock data of the global 21-cm signal and high-$z$galaxy ultraviolet luminosity function (UVLF) We compare for the first time the emulated posteriors to the 'true' posteriors obtained using the full model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02500v1.title: UNCOVER: The rest ultraviolet to near infrared multiwavelength structures and dust distributions of sub-millimeter-detected galaxies in Abell 2744
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02500v1.summary: Astronomers used ALMA and JWST to study the multiwavelength (0.5-4.4um) structures of 11 sub-millimeter (sub-mm) detected galaxies at z~0.9-3.5. The smaller sizes of these objects at long wavelengths indicate that their stellar mass profiles are more compact than their optical light profiles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02490v1.title: Positivity from Cosmological Correlators
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02490v1.summary: Causality and unitarity are hard to demonstrate in cosmological backgrounds. The expansion of the universe ensures that late-time cosmology correlators are classical. For multi-field inflation, the resulting positivityconstraints have long been known in terms of the Suyama-Yamaguchi inequality. We demonstrate that similar statistical bounds imply nontrivial constraints for massive fields in early universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02484v1.title: An updated survey of Active Galaxies with the HAWC gamma-ray observatory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02484v1.summary: We present an update of the survey of Active Galaxies with the High AltitudeWater Cherenkov (HAWC) gamma-ray observatory. We fit a modified power-law to their very high energyspectra, including the exponential attenuation caused by the ExtragalacticBackground Light. We found four sources with significant detections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02464v1.title: Anisotropies in the spatial distribution and kinematics of dwarf galaxies in the Local Group and beyond
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02464v1.summary: The Local Group (LG) of galaxies is dominated by the M31 and Milky Way (MW) Pair, a configuration which suggests that the mass distribution in the LG and its surroundings should be highly anisotropic. We use the APOSTLE cosmological simulations to examine how this anisotropy manifests on the spatial distribution and kinematics of dwarf galaxies out to a distance of 3 Mpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02441v1.title: Finding the dispersing siblings of young open clusters. Dynamical traceback simulations using Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02441v1.summary: Stars tend to form in clusters, but many escape their birth clusters very early. Identifying the escaped members of clusters can inform us about the Dissolution of star clusters. Methods capable of finding escaped stars from many clusters are required to fully exploit the large amounts of data in the Gaia era.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.08593v2.title: Too dense to go through: The importance of low-mass clusters for satellite quenching
http://arxiv.org/abs/2012.08593v2.summary: The majority of galaxies that are quenched at $z=0$ ($\gtrsim$ 80$\%$)reached this state in a dense environment. At low redshift, regardless of the final cluster mass, galaxies appear to reach their quenching state in low-mass clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02376v1.title: Black hole binary mergers in dense star clusters: the importance of primordial binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02376v1.summary: Dense stellar clusters are expected to house the ideal conditions for binary black hole (BBH) formation. We use theoretical arguments as well as $N$-body simulations to make predictions for the evolution of BBHs. We identify three key populations: those that form in the cluster, and merge before experiencing any dynamical interaction; those that are ejected from the cluster after only one strong interaction; and those that experience more than one strong interactions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02358v1.title: Shock enhanced [CII] emission from the infalling galaxy Arp 25
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02358v1.summary: We present SOFIA observations with HAWC+ and FIFI-LS of the peculiar galaxy NGC 2276 or UGC 3740. The morphology is deformed by its impact with the intra-group medium of the NGC 2300 galaxy group. We estimate that the shock due to. the impact increases the [CII] emission along the impact front by 60% and the global [C II] emission by approximately 25% withrespect to the predicted [Cii] emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02352v1.title: The formation channels of multiphase gas in nearby early-type galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02352v1.summary: The processes responsible for the assembly of cold and warm gas in early-type galaxies are not well-understood. We report on the multiwavelengthproperties of 15 non-central, nearby ($z \leq$ 0.00889) ETGs primarily through Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) and Chandra X-ray observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02333v1.title: Galaxy evolution in modified gravity simulations: using passive galaxies to constrain gravity with upcoming surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02333v1.summary: We present a quantitative analysis of the properties of galaxies andstructures evolving in universes dominated by different modified gravitational models. Using two different criteria to compare, we find that structures formed within modified gravity tend to show a denser gas density profile than their GR counterparts. We find that haloes evolving in MG universes show, in general, larger quenched fractions than GR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02330v1.title: Obscuration beyond the nucleus: infrared quasars can be buried in extreme compact starbursts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02330v1.summary: In the standard quasar model, the accretion disk obscuration is due to thecanonical dusty torus. We argue that a substantial part of the quasarophobicobscuration can come from the interstellar medium (ISM) when the quasars areembedded in compact starbursts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02312v1.title: Growing Local arm inferred by the breathing motion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02312v1.summary: Theoretical models of spiral arms suggest that the spiral arms provoke a horizontally bulk motion in disc stars. By analysing the breathing motion around the mid-plane of the Milky Way disc, we found that a compressing breathing motion presentsalong the Local arm. We also identified the tentative signatures of the expanding breathing motion associated with the Perseus arm and also the Outer arm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02314v1.title: Bursty star formation and galaxy-galaxy interactions in low-mass galaxies 1 Gyr after the Big Bang
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02314v1.summary: We use CANUCS JWST/NIRCam imaging to investigate star formation burstiness in low-mass galaxies. Sixty percent of the 123 galaxies in this sample have H$\alpha$-to-UV flux ratios that deviate significantly from smooth and steady star formation histories. We also searched for interacting galaxies in our sample and found that they are remarkably common ($\sim40\ \%$ of the sample)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02310v1.title: Exploring the low-mass regime of galaxy-scale strong lensing: Insights into the mass structure of cluster galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02310v1.summary: We aim at a direct measurement of the compactness of three galaxy-scale lenses in massive clusters. We tested the accuracy of the scaling laws that describe the members in strong lensing (SL) models of galaxy clusters. Our work significantly extends the regime of the current samples of lens galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02305v1.title: Wrinkles in Time -- I: Rapid Rotators Found in High Eccentricity Orbits
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02305v1.summary: TESS data allow for powerful new insights into our understanding of the Milky Way's dynamical history. We identify 141 unique, rapidly rotating stars in highlyeccentric orbits in the disk, some of which appear as rotationally young as the 120-Myr-old Pleiades.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02307v1.title: RESCUER: Cosmological K-corrections for star clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02307v1.summary: The advent of JWST (the James Webb Space Telescope) now allows entire star clusters populations to be imaged in galaxies at cosmologically significant redshifts. Since the stellar populations within star clusters can be approximated by a single age and metallicity, their spectral energy distributions are very different from those of galaxies or supernovae. We derive the photometric K-corrections decidedlyversus redshift for model star clusters that cover a wide range of ages andmetallicities. We introduce a simple webtool called RESCUER that can generate K-values for any user-defined combination

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02256v1.title: Detecting New Visual Binaries in Gaia DR3 with Gaia and 2MASS Photometry I. New Candidate Binaries Within 200 pc of the Sun
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02256v1.summary: We present a method to identify likely visual binaries in Gaia eDR3 that does not rely on parallax or proper motion. This method utilizes the various PSFsizes of 2MASS/Gaia. Using these multidimensional distributions, we compute the likelihood of a close pair of stars to be a chance alignment. We find a total(clean) catalog of 68,725(50,230) likely binaries within 200 pc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02225v1.title: Mapping the Intracluster Medium in the Era of High-resolution X-ray Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02225v1.summary: High-resolution spectroscopy in soft X-rays will open a new window to map multiphase gas in galaxy clusters and probe physics of the intracluster medium. An eV-level spectral resolution, large field-of-view and effective area are essential to separate cluster emissions from the Galactic foreground and efficiently map the clusteroutskirts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02213v1.title: Turbulent Structure In Supernova Remnants G46.8-0.3 And G39.2-0.3 From THOR Polarimetry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02213v1.summary: We present the continued analysis of polarization and Faraday rotation for the supernova remnants (SNRs) G46.8-0.3 and G39.2- 0.3 in L-band (1-2 GHz) radiocontinuum in The HI/OH/Recombination line (THOR) survey. We find evidence for sigma_phi >~ 30 rad m^-2 in localized regions where we detect no polarization in THOR. We combine the Faraday depth dispersion with the rotation measure (RM) structure function (SF)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02202v1.title: H I content of selected mid-infrared bright, starburst blue compact dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02202v1.summary: We report measurements of H I content in 11 nearby, actively star-forming galaxies. H I emission was detected in six sources. The majority of the sources (10/11) in the Arecibo sample are very red in W1[3.4 $\mu$m]$-$W2[4.6 $m] colour implying the presence of warm dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12410v2.title: Pre-solar grains from novae and "Born-again giants"
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12410v2.summary: We review the properties of dust formed during classical nova eruptions and the Very Late Thermal Pulses. In both cases, carbon and hydrocarbon dust is produced. Novae may also produce silicate dust, contrary to the usual paradigm about the C:O ratio and dust composition.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.12355v2.title: Simulations of Weakly Magnetized Turbulent Mixing Layers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.12355v2.summary: Radiative turbulent mixing layers are expected to form pervasively at thephase boundaries in multiphase astrophysical systems. This inherently smallscale structure is dynamically crucial because it regulates the mass, momentum and energy exchanges between adjacent phases. We find that even relatively weak background magnetic fields can significantly reduce the surface brightness and inflow velocity of the hot gas in the mixing layer.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01062v2.title: Bayesian inference methodology to characterize the dust emissivity at far-infrared and submillimeter frequencies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01062v2.summary: We use the Galactic HI map from the Galactic All-Sky Survey (GASS) as a template to trace the Galactic dustemission. We jointly infer the pixel-dependent dust emissivity and the zero level present in the Planck intensity maps. We demonstrate that the methodology is unbiased when applied to realistic Planck sky simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01369v2.title: Dissecting Cosmological Filaments at High Redshifts: Emergence of Spaghetti-type Flow Inside DM Haloes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01369v2.summary: We use high-resolution zoom-in simulations to study the fueling of the                central galaxies by gas accretion from cosmological filaments at high redshifts. We focus on the filamentary and galactic accretion within few virial radii, R_vir, down to the central galaxies. Using a hybrid d-web/entropy method we have mapped the gaseous filaments, and invoking particle kinematics allowed us to separate inflows fromoutflows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02125v1.title: Main sequence companions to white dwarfs II: the age-activity-rotation relation from a sample of Gaia common proper motion pairs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02125v1.summary: Magnetic activity and rotation are related to the age of low-mass main-sequence stars. We find that stars older than 5 Gyr do not display Halpha nor Caii H&K emission. We also find moderately old stars (~2-6 Gyr) that are active presumably because they rotate faster than they should for their given ages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11962v2.title: A metallicity dependence on the occurrence of core-collapse supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11962v2.summary: Core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe) are widely accepted to be caused by theexplosive death of massive stars with initial masses. We present a minimally biased sample of galaxies from the ASAS-SN survey whose host galaxies were observed with MUSE at the VLT. We estimate the occurrence of CCSNe as a function of oxygen abundance per unit star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02109v1.title: Simulations of two-temperature jets in galaxy clusters: I. Effect of jet magnetization on dynamics and electron heating
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02109v1.summary: Non-radiating protons in the radio lobes have an essential role to form the jet morphology which is shown by recent radio and X-ray observations. Since protons and electrons are not always in energy equilibrium due to weakCoulomb coupling, it is difficult to estimate the energy contribution ofprotons.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02105v1.title: Simulations of two-temperature jets in galaxy clusters: II. X-ray property of forward shock
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02105v1.summary: X-ray observations show the Mach numbers of powerfulradio jets are smaller compared to that of theoretical and numerical studies. The aim is to investigate various factors, such as projection effects and temperature non-equilibration betweenprotons and electrons, that influence the Mach number estimate in a powerful jet.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02077v1.title: Cold atomic gas identified by HI self-absorption. Cold atomic clouds toward giant molecular filaments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02077v1.summary: Stars form in the dense interiors of molecular clouds. It is critical to investigate the relationship between the atomic and molecular gasphase to understand the global star formation process. We use the high angularresolution data from The HI/OH/Recombination line survey of the Milky Way to constrain the kinematic and physical properties of the cold atomic hydrogen gas phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06931v2.title: Science Opportunities for IMAP-Lo Observations of Interstellar Neutral Helium, Neon and Oxygen During a Maximum of Solar Activity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06931v2.summary: Direct-sampling observations of interstellar neutral (ISN) species and their secondary populations give information about the physical state of the local interstellar medium and processes occuring in the outer heliosheath. Such observations are performed from Earth's orbit by the IBEX-Lo experiment on board the Interstellar Boundary Explorer (IBEX) mission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02033v1.title: A plausible link between dynamically unsettled molecular gas and the radio jet in NGC 6328
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02033v1.summary: We report the detection of outflowing molecular gas at the center of a radio galaxy. The bulk of the gas is situated within a highly warped disk structure. Two anti-diametricmolecular gas structures are kinematically detached from the main disk. The energy required to maintain such a molecular outflow is aligned with the mechanical power of the jet.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07328v2.title: Dissecting a 30 kpc galactic outflow at $z \sim$ 1.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07328v2.summary: We present the spatially resolved measurements of a cool galactic outflow in the galaxy RCS0327. We probe the cool outflowing gas, traced by blueshifted Mg II and Fe II absorption lines, in 15 distinct regions of the same galaxy in its image-plane. Different physical regions, 5 to 7 kpc apart within the galaxy, drive the outflows at different velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01771v2.title: AT2023fhn (the Finch): a Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transient at a large offset from its host galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.01771v2.summary: Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transients (LFBOTs) are a rare class of events whose origins are poorly understood. They are characterised by rapid evolution, featureless blue spectraat early times, and luminous X-ray and radio emission. We present Hubble Space Telescope, Gemini, Chandra and Very Large Array observations of a new LFBOT, AT2023fhn.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07201v2.title: Signatures of Cosmic Ray Heating in 21-cm Observables
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07201v2.summary: Cosmic rays generated by supernovae carry away a significant portion of the lifetime energy emission of their parent star. This makes them a plausible mechanism for heating the early universe intergalactic medium (IGM) We develop aflexible model of this heating mechanism for use in 3D semi-numerical 21-cm simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01903v1.title: The AstroSat UV Deep Field North: Direct determination of the UV Luminosity Function and its evolution from z $\sim$ 0.8-0.4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01903v1.summary: We characterize the evolution of the rest-frame 1500 $\unicode{xC5}$ UVapologluminosity Function (UVLF) from AstroSat/UVIT F154W and N242W imaging in the GOODS-N field. With deep NUV observations, we are able to construct the UVLF in seven redshift bins in the range z 0.8 - 0.4. The fitted Schechter functionparameters are obtained for these UVLFs. We infer that this is a short-lived instance of increased cosmic star-formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01899v1.title: Chemical Evolution in Galactic Nuclear Discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01899v1.summary: Nuclear Stellar Discs have been observed in the vast majority of barred disc galaxies including the Milky Way. Their intense star formation is sustained by intense gas inflows driven by their surrounding bars. Despite their central role in galaxy evolving, their chemical evolution remains largely unexplored. Here we present the first systematic, multizonal modelling of the chemical evolution of nuclear stellar discs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06433v3.title: Rapidly Rotating Massive Pop III stars: A Solution for High Carbon Enrichment in CEMP-no Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06433v3.summary: Very metal-poor stars that have no heavy elements are known as CEMP-no stars. These stars are thought to be produced from a gas polluted by the supernova (SN) ejecta of the veryfirst generation (Pop III) massive stars. The very high enrichment of C observed in many of these stars is difficult to explain by current models of SN explosions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01813v1.title: Semi-analytic calculations for extended mid-Infrared emission associated with FU Ori-type objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01813v1.summary: Near-infrared imaging polarimetry at high-angular resolutions has revealed intriguing distribution of circumstellar dust towards FU Ori-type objects. Follow-up observations would lead us to a better understanding of the hierarchy of themass accretion processes onto FUors. These dust grains are probably associated with either an accretion disk or an infalling envelope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01782v1.title: J0107a: A Barred Spiral Dusty Star-forming Galaxy at $z=2.467$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01782v1.summary: Dusty Star-Forming Galaxies (DSFGs) are amongst the most massive and activestar-forming galaxies during the cosmic noon. Theoretical studies have proposed various formation mechanisms of DSFGs, including major merger-driven starbursts and secular star-forming disks. We report J0107a, a bright DSFG at $z=2.467$ that appears to be a gas-rich massive disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01763v1.title: Distinguishing the impact and signature of black holes from different origins in early cosmic history
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01763v1.summary: We use semi-analytical models to study the effects of primordial black hole accretion on the cosmic radiation background during the epoch of reionization. We consider PBHs floating in the intergalacticMedium (IGM), and located inside haloes, where star formation can occur. We find that at lower redshifts, the accretion feedback power from haloes dominates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01703v1.title: Spatially-Resolved Temperature and Density Structures of Nearby HII regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01703v1.summary: Photoionization models frequently assume constant temperature or densitywithin HII regions. We investigate this assumption by measuring the detailed temperature and density structures of four regions in the Large MagellanicCloud and the Small Magellan Cloud. We create a series of nebula models with a constant ISM pressure and varyingtemperature and density distributions. All four nebulae present a negative gradient in the electron density profile.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01657v1.title: The SOFIA FEEDBACK Legacy Survey: Rapid molecular cloud dispersal in RCW 79
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01657v1.summary: It has long been discussed whether stellar feedback in the form of winds and radiation can shred the nascent molecular cloud, thereby controlling the star formation rate. This finding provides direct observational evidence of rapid molecular cloud dispersal. The resulting mass ejection rate estimate for the cloud is 0.9-3.5 Myr. This suggests a different scenario for the evolution of RCW 79.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01200v3.title: Dark matter halo mass functions and density profiles from mass and energy cascade
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01200v3.summary: We analytically analyze the halo mass function and cuspy halo density (inner slope of -4/3) based on the mass and energy cascade theory in dark matter flow. The corresponding Fokker-Planck solution for halo random walk in mass space gives rise to a power-law behavior on small scale and exponential decay on large scale.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13347v2.title: Objects in JWST's mirrors are closer than they appear
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13347v2.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) has revealed extremely distant galaxies at unprecedentedly early cosmic epochs. However, as larger samples continue to be followed up spectroscopically, it has become apparent that nearly all photometric redshifts at these epochs are biased high.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01607v1.title: The GBT Diffuse Ionized Gas Survey (GDIGS): Discrete Sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01607v1.summary: Green Bank Telescope (GBT) Diffuse Ionized Gas Survey (GDIGS) traces ionized gas in the Galactic midplane by observing radio recombination line(RRL) emission from 4-8 GHz. Using GDIGS data, we identify the velocity of 35 H II regions that have multiple detected RRL velocity components. We also identify and characterize RRL emission from eight locations that appear to be previously-unidentified H II Regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01601v1.title: Uncovering the MIR emission of quiescent galaxies with $JWST$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01601v1.summary: We present a study of the mid-IR (MIR) emission of quiescent galaxies (QGs) beyond the local universe. We find that QGs exhibit a range of MIRspectra that are composed of a stellar continuum and a dust component that is 1-2 orders of magnitude fainter to that of star-forming galaxies. We augment the average UV-to-MIR spectrum of the population with cold dust and gas emission in the far-IR/mm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10099v2.title: Reconstructing Galactic magnetic fields from local measurements for backtracking ultra-high-energy cosmic rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10099v2.summary: Ultra-high energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) are highly energetic particles with energies exceeding $10^{18}$ eV. Identifying their sources and production mechanism can provide insight into many open questions in astrophysics and high energy physics. The Galactic magnetic field (GMF) deflects UHECR, and the high uncertainties in our current understanding of the $3$-dimensional structure of the GMF does not permit us to accurately determine their true arrival direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01576v1.title: Ultracool Spectroscopic Outliers in Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01576v1.summary: Gaia DR3 provided a first release of RP spectra and astrophysical parameters for ultracool dwarfs. These objects havespectral types of M7 or later and might be young brown dwarfs or low-metallicity objects. This study is intended as a proof-of-concept for future iterations of the Gaia data releases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01531v1.title: A comprehensive hydrodynamical study of SB DEM L50: understanding off-centre SNe and soft X-ray luminosity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01531v1.summary: Models that assume a constant density medium andcentral SNe events fail to reproduce the soft X-ray luminosity that is observed in some SBs. We address this problem by generating models that trace the history of SNe in the SB and that produce off-centre SNe. We test the models against archival, radio,optical, and X-rays observations of the SB DEM\,L50 located in the Large                Magellanic Cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10884v2.title: Double black hole mergers in nuclear star clusters: eccentricities, spins, masses, and the growth of massive seeds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.10884v2.summary: We investigate the formation of intermediate mass black holes (IMBHs) through hierarchical mergers of stellar origin black holes. We find that BH mergers areformed dynamically in nuclear star clusters. Metal-rich, young, dense clusters canproduce up to $20\%$ of their DBH merger with eccentricity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01502v1.title: Distinguishing AGN Feedback Models with the Thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Effect
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01502v1.summary: Current models of galaxy formation require strong feedback from activegalactic nuclei to explain the observed lack of star formation. We use SIMBA cosmological galaxy formation simulations to assess the ability of thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (tSZ) measurements to provide such evidence. We map the pressure structure of the circumgalactic medium around massivez~0.2-1.5 galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02905v2.title: Decomposing the Origin of TeV-PeV Emission from the Galactic Plane: Implications of Multi-messenger Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.02905v2.summary: High-energy neutrino and $\gamma$-ray emission has been observed from the Galactic plane. It may come from individual sources and/or diffuse cosmic rays. We evaluate the contribution of these two components through the multimessenger connection between neutrinos and $gamma rays in hadronic interactions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05834v1.title: Observations of Multiphase, High-Velocity, Shocked Gas in the Vela Supernova Remnant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05834v1.summary: High-resolution far-ultraviolet archival spectra were obtained with the Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph on the Hubble SpaceTelescope of the star HD 75309. The results indicate that the highly ionized species at high velocity probe gas in a region immediately behind a shock driven into an interstellar cloud. The lower ionization species trace material further downstream in the cooling region of the post-shock flow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05819v1.title: The XXL Survey LV. Pressure profile and $Y_{\rm SZ}$-$M$ scaling relation in three low-mass galaxy clusters at $z\sim1$ observed with NIKA2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05819v1.summary: Three galaxy clusters XLSSC~072 ($z=1.002$), XL SSC~100 ($z =0.915$), andXL SSC--102 ($z--0.969$) were studied. XMM-Newton X-ray data were used to derive masses based on the $Y_X - M$ relation and thehydrostatic equilibrium. The SZ images of the three clusters, along with the XXLX-ray and optical data, indicate dynamical activity related to merging events.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12331v2.title: JWST CEERS & JADES Active Galaxies at z = 4-7 Violate the Local $M_\bullet-M_\star$ Relation at $>3σ$: Implications for Low-Mass Black Holes and Seeding Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12331v2.summary: JWST is revolutionizing our understanding of the high-$z$ Universe by expanding the black hole horizon, looking farther and to smaller masses. By examining JWST galaxies at $z=4-7$ that host H$\alpha$-detected black holes, we investigate the $M_\bullet-M_ \star$ relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05774v1.title: JWST: Deuterated PAHs, PAH-nitriles, and PAH Overtone and Combination Bands I: Program Description and First Look
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05774v1.summary: NIRSpec 1-5 observations from JWST's program 1591 that targets 7 objects along the low-mass stellar life cycle with PAH emission. Spectra extracted from a 1.5$^{\prime\prime} radius sizedcircular aperture are explored, showing a wealth of features.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05745v1.title: Impact of the uncertainties of $3 α$ and $^{12}{\rm C}(α,γ)^{16}{\rm O}$ reactions on the He-burning phases of low- and intermediate-mass stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05745v1.summary: We estimate the impact on the stellar evolution of the uncertainties in the $3\alpha$ and the $^{12}{\rm C] reaction rates. The models were calculated for two different initial chemicalcompositions to represent different stellar populations. The impact of the two reaction rates on the central He-burning lifetime and the asymptotic giant branch (AGB) lifetime, as well as the mass of the C/O core and the internal C and O abundances, was investigated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18540v2.title: Gravitational waves from binary black holes in a self-interacting scalar dark matter cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18540v2.summary: We investigate the imprints of accretion and dynamical friction on the gravitational-wave signals emitted by binary black holes embedded in a scalar dark matter cloud. As a key feature in this work, we focus on scalar fieldswith a repulsive self-interaction that balances against the self-gravity of the cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11134v4.title: Microlensing and event rate of static spherically symmetric wormhole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11134v4.summary: The lensing effects play a vital role in modern cosmology. A newframework is developed for the static spherically symmetrical wormhole. Compared with the event rate of blackhole, it is also claimed that the value of WH will be larger, in which their mass and the distance of them between the light source and observer are comparable.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05693v1.title: CONGRuENTS (COsmic-ray, Neutrino, Gamma-ray and Radio Non-Thermal Spectra). II. Population-level correlations between galactic infrared, radio, and γ-ray emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05693v1.summary: Galaxies obey a number of empirical correlations between their radio, infrared, and radio emission. The physical origins of these correlations remain uncertain. Here we use the CONGRuENTS model for broadband non-thermal emission from star-forming galaxies to explain these correlations. In addition to explaining existing observations, we use our analysis to predict a heretofore unseen correlation between galaxies' radio spectra and their pion-driven {\gamma}-ray emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16691v2.title: Prospects for observing supermassive black hole binaries with the space-ground interferometer
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16691v2.summary: An artificial neural network is constructed to estimate the radiation flux at 240~GHz. The result is presented as a table of 17 candidate SMBBHs. Confirmation (or refutation) of the duality of these objects will be an important milestone in the development of the theory of galaxy formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05574v1.title: Constraints on the narrow-line region of the X-ray quasi-periodic eruption source GSN 069
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05574v1.summary: The origins of quasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs) are poorly understood. Most theoretical explanations invoke an accretion disk around a supermassive black hole. In this paper, we present an analysis of archival Hubble Space Telescope images to study the narrow-line [O III] emission in the QPE source GSN 069.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07396v2.title: GMP-selected dual and lensed AGNs: selection function and classification based on near-IR colors and resolved spectra from VLT/ERIS, KECK/OSIRIS, and LBT/LUCI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.07396v2.summary: The Gaia-Multi-Peak (GMP) technique can be used to identify large numbers of dual or lensed AGN candidates at sub-arcsec separation. We show that the GMP selection is very efficient for separations above 0.15'' when the secondary (fainter) object has magnitude G<20.5.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05496v1.title: A resolved study of the inner regions of nearby galaxies with an excess of young massive stars: missing link in the AGN-starburst connection?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05496v1.summary: Study focuses on 14 very well-resolved nearbygalaxies with stellar masses in the range $9.5 < 11.5$. Excess [NeIII] is detected in 4 out of 8 of the WR regions and there are tentative [FeX] detections in 2 galaxies. Galaxy regions containing excess Wolf Rayet stars are more often associated with the presence of high-ionization emission lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05389v2.title: The Structure Function of Mid-infrared Variability in Low-redshift Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05389v2.summary: The variability amplitude of dust-deficient AGNs is systematically larger than that of normal AGNs. We argue that either low-luminosity type 2 AGNs have distinctive central structures due to their low luminosity or their MIRbrightness is contaminated by emission from the cold dust in the host galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03313v4.title: Universal scaling laws and density slope for dark matter haloes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03313v4.summary: Small scale challenges suggest some missing pieces in our understanding of dark matter. A cascade theory for dark matter is proposed to provide extra insights. The largest halo scale $r_l$ can be determined by $-u_0^3/\varepsilon_u$ The smallestscale $r_{\eta}$ is dependent on the nature of dark Matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05287v1.title: Dead man tells tales: metallicity distribution of the Milky Way stellar halo reveals the past of the GSE progenitor galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05287v1.summary: The Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus~(GSE) stands out as the largest known ancientaccretion event in the Milky Way~(MW) history. Despite this significance, theparameters of its progenitor galaxy are still poorly constrained. We identify GSE stars from the APOGEE DR17 using Gaussian mixture models and recover a negative radial metallicity gradient for the GSE debris.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14408v2.title: Characterising ultra-high-redshift dark matter halo demographics and assembly histories with the GUREFT simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.14408v2.summary: Dark matter halo demographics and assembly histories are a manifestation ofcosmological structure formation and have profound implications for theformation and evolution of galaxies. We present a new suite of Gadget atUltrahigh Redshift with Extra-Fine Timesteps (GUREFT) dark matter-only simulations that are carefully designed to capture halo mergerhistories.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05244v1.title: Orbital evolution of eccentric perturbers under dynamical friction: crossing the sound barrier
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05244v1.summary: In a gaseous medium, dynamical friction (DF) reaches a maximum when the orbital speed is close to the sound speed. Most trajectories tend to circularize as the perturber moves into the supersonic regime. orbits with eccentricities $e\gtrsim 0.8$ below the sound barrier experience a slight increase in eccentricity as they loose orbital energy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05206v1.title: COALAS II. Extended molecular gas reservoirs are common in a distant, forming galaxy cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05206v1.summary: This paper presents the results of 475 hours of interferometric observations with the Australia Telescope Compact Array towards the Spiderweb protocluster. We search for large, extended molecular gas reservoirs among 46 previously detected CO(1-0) emitters. We found 13 (potentially) extended gas reservoirs located in nine proto (proto)clusters from the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01397v2.title: Halo Scaling Relations and Hydrostatic Mass Bias in the Simba Simulation From Realistic Mock X-ray Catalogues
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.01397v2.summary: We present a new end-to-end pipeline for Mock Observations of X-ray Halos. We use it to investigate X-rays scaling relations and hydrostatic mass bias. We compare MOXHA-derived halo properties in Simba to their emission-weighted counterparts. We forecast the systematic mass bias in mock Athena observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05089v1.title: Broad-line region in active galactic nuclei: dusty or dustless?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05089v1.summary: The dust in the active galactic nuclei is clearly present right outside the broad-line region (BLR) Some models of the BLR predict that dust may also exist within theBLR. We calculate a range of models with the use of CLOUDYphotoionization code for dusty and dustless plasma.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05065v1.title: Systematic Search for Water Fountain Candidates using the Databases of Circumstellar Maser Sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05065v1.summary: Water fountains (WFs) are thought to be objects in the morphologicalevolution of the circumstellar envelopes of low- and intermediate-mass evolvedstars. We useddatabases of circumstellar 1612 MHz OH and 22.235 GHz H$_2$O maser sources to search for new WF candidates. We find that the maservelocity criterion can discover other astrophysically interesting objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05023v1.title: TREX: Kinematic Characterisation of a High-Dispersion Intermediate-Age Stellar Component in M33
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05023v1.summary: The dwarf galaxy Triangulum (M33) presents an interesting testbed for studying stellar halo formation. It is sufficiently massive so as to have accreted smaller satellites, but also lies within the regime where "in-situ" formation mechanisms are expected to play a role.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01478v2.title: Pavo: Discovery of a star-forming dwarf galaxy just outside the Local Group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01478v2.summary: Pavo is a faint ($M_V = -10.0$), star-forming,irregular, and extremely isolated dwarf galaxy at $D\approx2$ Mpc. Pavo was identified in Dark Energy Camera Legacy Survey imaging via a novel approach that combines low surface brightness galaxy search algorithms and machine learning.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04888v1.title: A HST Study of the Substellar Population of NGC 2024
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04888v1.summary: We performed a HST/WFC3-IR imaging survey of the young stellar cluster NGC2024 in three filters probing the 1.4~$\mu$m H$_2$O absorption feature. We detect 812 point sources, 550 of them in all 3filters with signal to noise greater than 5. There is some evidence of an excess of luminous stars in the most embedded region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13967v2.title: Identifying Strongly Lensed Gravitational Waves with the Third-generation Detectors
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13967v2.summary: Joint detection of GW signals by a network of instruments will increase the detecting ability of faint and far GW signals with higher signal-to-noiseratios. However, identifying Strongly Lensed Gravitational Waves (SLGWs) is still challenging. We focus on the identification ability of 3G detectors in this article.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14793v2.title: IllustrisTNG in the HSC-SSP: image data release and the major role of mini mergers as drivers of asymmetry and star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14793v2.summary: At fixed galaxy stellar mass, there is a clear observational connection between structural asymmetry and offset from the star forming main sequence. We use the TNG50 simulation to investigate the relativeroles of major mergers (stellar mass ratios) and mini mergers ($0.01 \leq \mu < 0.1$) in driving this connection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04666v1.title: How Nested Bars Enhance, Modulate, and are Destroyed by Gas Inflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04666v1.summary: The inner bar in double-barred galaxies can help drive gas flow from thenuclear ring to the center. Gas flows in the presence of two independently-rotating nested bars remain fully understood. We find that the star formation rate is higher in the model with two bars than in that with one bar.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03141v2.title: Cosmic ray feedback in galaxies and galaxy clusters -- A pedagogical introduction and a topical review of the acceleration, transport, observables, and dynamical impact of cosmic rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03141v2.summary: Recent advances in astrophysical feedback strongly suggest that cosmic rays (CRs) may becrucially important for our understanding of cosmological galaxy formation. Understanding the physical mechanisms that control galaxy formation is afundamental challenge in contemporary astrophysics. The field is ripe for discovery and will remain the subject of intense theoretical, computational, and observational research over the next decade.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04629v1.title: The composition and thermal properties of a cool core lacking a brightest cluster galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04629v1.summary: We present a multiwavelength observation of a cool core that does not appear to be associated with any galaxy, in a nearby cluster, Abell~1142. The lack of a galaxy may contribute to an inefficient conversion of the ionized warm gas to the coldmolecular gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.00006v2.title: A Phantom Menace: On the Morphology of the Galactic Center Excess
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.00006v2.summary: The characteristics of the Galactic Center Excess (GCE) emission -- especially the morphology of the GCE -- remain a hotly debated subject. The manner in which the dominant diffuse gamma-ray background is modeled has been claimed to have a determining effect on the preferredmorphology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04530v1.title: Galactic Archaeology with [Mg/Mn] versus [Al/Fe] abundance ratios -- Uncertainties and caveats
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04530v1.summary: The diagram depicting the abundance ratios [Mg/Mn] vs. [Al/Fe] has gained attention in recent literature. The combination of elements is supposed to be highly sensitive to the starformation history (SFH), unveiled by the imprints left on those abundances. The proposed diagram is therefore uncertain from a theoretical point of view.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04508v1.title: Boltzmann Equation Field Theory I: Ensemble Averages
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04508v1.summary: A quasi-nonlinear field theory describes how to take ensemble averages unique to the Collisionless Boltzmann Equation. The assumption that the ensemble average of the distribution function is equal to the extremum entropy state is shown to be wrong. An application describes the nonlinear saturation of Jeans' instability, and the gravitational amplification of Poisson noise.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04507v1.title: An Analytic Model For Magnetically-Dominated Accretion Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04507v1.summary: Recent numerical cosmological simulations have resolved the formation of quasar accretion disks with Eddington or super-Eddington accretion rates. These 'flux-frozen' and hyper-magnetized disks appear to be qualitatively distinct from classical $alpha$ disks.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04506v1.title: FORGE'd in FIRE II: The Formation of Magnetically-Dominated Quasar Accretion Disks from Cosmological Initial Conditions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04506v1.summary: We see the formation of a well-defined, steady-state accretion disk which is stable against star formation at sub-pc scales. The disks are strongly turbulent, with trans-Alfvenic and highly super-sonic turbulence, and balance this via a cooling time that is short. We show how the magnetic field strengths and geometries arise from rapid advection of flux with the inflow from much weaker galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04503v1.title: ${\rm H{\scriptsize ALO}F{\scriptsize LOW}}$ I: Neural Inference of Halo Mass from Galaxy Photometry and Morphology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04503v1.summary: We present a new machine learning approach for inferring the mass of host dark matter halos, $M_h$, from the photometry and morphology of galaxies. It is trained on state-of-the-art synthetic galaxy images from Bottrell et al. (2023) that are constructed from the IllustrisTNG hydrodynamic simulation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04499v1.title: Exploring chemical enrichment of the intracluster medium with the Line Emission Mapper
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04499v1.summary: Most metals disperse overcosmic scales and are ultimately deposited well outside the gravitational potential of their host galaxies. Since their presence is well visible through their X-ray emission lines in the hot gas pervading galaxy clusters, measuring metals in the intracluster medium offers us a unique view of chemical enrichment of the Universe as a whole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04498v1.title: UV-continuum $β$ slopes of individual $z \sim 2-6$ clumps and their evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04498v1.summary: Study of ultraviolet (UV) continuum of 166 star-forming regions observed in high redshift galaxies. They are hosted by 67 galaxies with redshift between 2 and 6.2, strongly lensed by the Hubble Frontier Fields cluster of galaxies MACS J0416.1-2403. The aim of this study is to investigate possible physical differences between these regions and their hosts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04492v1.title: Identifying the possible ex-situ origin of the globular clusters of the Milky Way: A kinematic study
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04492v1.summary: This is the second paper in a series, which studies the likelihood that someglobular clusters (GCs) of the Milky Way could have originated from a dwarf satellite galaxy. We focus on the Magellanic Clouds and Sagittarius. In total, we find 29 (19%) MW GCs which could be kinematicallyassociated with MW DSGs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04485v1.title: Methanol isotopologues as a probe for spatial and temporal variations of the electron-to-proton mass ratio
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04485v1.summary: We present results on numerical calculations of the sensitivity coefficients, or Qmu, of microwave molecular transitions in (13C)H3OH and CH3(18O)H to the fundamental physical constant mu. We show that the thermal emission lines observed in the star-forming region NGC6334I constrain thevariability of mu at a level of 3x10^-8.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06831v1.title: Impacts of the Local arm on the local circular velocity inferred from the Gaia DR3 young stars in the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06831v1.summary: A simple one-dimensional axisymmetric disc model is applied to the kinematics of OB stars near the Sun obtained from Gaia DR3 catalogue. The model determines the 'local centrifugal speed' - defined as the circular velocity in the Galactocentric rest frame. By comparing with an N-body/hydrodynamic simulation of a Milky Way-like galaxy, we conclude that the Local arm is affecting the young stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13431v2.title: On the origin of the Galactic thin and thick discs, their abundance gradients and the diagnostic potential of their abundance ratios
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13431v2.summary: Using a semi-analytical model of the evolution of the Milky Way, we show how secular evolution can create distinct overdensities in the phase space of various properties. We show how keyproperties of the Solar vicinity can be obtained by secular evolution, with no need for external or special events.
