http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06785v1.title: Linking the Metallicity Enrichment History to the Star Formation History: An SFH-regulated Chemical Evolution Model and Its Implications for the Gas Cycling Process
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06785v1.summary: The metallicity enrichment history (MEH) of a galaxy is determined by its star formation history (SFH) and the gas cycling process. We construct a chemical evolution model that is regulated by the SFH of the system. We test this model on sixlocally isolated dwarf galaxies covering three dwarf types.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05061v2.title: First constraints on compact binary environments from LIGO-Virgo data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.05061v2.summary: The LIGO-Virgo analysis of the signals from compact binary mergers observed so far have assumed in-vacuum isolated binary systems. Non-trivial environments may alter gravitational-wave emission, leaving imprints that can be observable via acharacteristic dephasing of the emitted signal.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06781v1.title: Quantifying the Effects of Known Unknowns on Inferred High-redshift Galaxy Properties: Burstiness, the IMF, and Nebular Physics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06781v1.summary: The era of the James Webb Space Telescope ushers stellar populations models into uncharted territories, particularly at the high-redshift frontier. Here we present a comprehensive errorbudget in spectral energy distribution (SED) modeling. We find that the IMF exerts the strongest influence on the inferred properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06363v2.title: Varstrometry for Off-nucleus and Dual Sub-kpc AGN (VODKA): Very Long Baseline Array Searches for Dual or Off-nucleus Quasars and Small-scale Jets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06363v2.summary: Dual and off-nucleus active supermassive black holes are expected to be common in the hierarchical structure formation paradigm. Their identification at parsec scales remains a challenge due to strict angularresolution requirements. We conduct a systematic study using the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) to examine 23 radio-bright candidate dual quasars. The radio emission from three candidates is likely to originate from small-scale jets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06757v1.title: New red giants in NGC 6791 and NGC 6819 using Kepler superstamps
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06757v1.summary: We identified previously unknown red giants in the open clusters NGC 6791 and NGC 6819. We performed an asteroseismic membership study to identify which of these stars are likely to be cluster members. We were able to find 149 red giant stars within the Kepler superstamps, 93 of which are likely Cluster members.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03745v3.title: UNCOVER: Illuminating the Early Universe -- JWST/NIRSpec Confirmation of $z > 12$ Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03745v3.summary: The galaxies are spatially resolved, having lensing-corrected rest-UV effective radii on the order of 300-400 pc. The galaxies are young, rapidly-assembling, metal-poor, and star-forming. The dynamic range of $z \gtrsim 10$ sizes spans over 1 order of magnitude, suggesting a significant scatter in the size-mass relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.10215v2.title: The miniJPAS & J-NEP surveys: Identification and characterization of the Ly$α$ Emitter population and the Ly$α$ Luminosity Function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.10215v2.summary: We present the Lyman-$a$ (Lya) Luminosity Function (LF) at $2.05<z<3.75$,estimated from a sample of 67 Lya-emitter (LAE) candidates in the J-PAS surveys. We test this method by applying it to the miniJPAS and J-NEP data. In order to compute the corrections needed to estimate the Lya LF and to test the performance of the candidates selection method we build mock catalogs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13035v2.title: The MUSE-Faint survey. III. Constraining scalar field dark matter with Antlia B
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13035v2.summary: We use the stellar line-of-sight velocities of Antlia B (Ant B), a faint dwarf galaxy in the NGC 3109 association, to derive constraints on the properties of scalar field dark matter (SFDM) We find a virial mass of $M_\odot$ 1.66 and a mass-concentration parameter of 17.38% for Ant B. The results are consistent with the mass- Constraint relations in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11214v2.title: Azimuthal Anisotropy of Magnetic Fields in the Circumgalactic Medium Driven by Galactic Feedback Processes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11214v2.summary: magnetic fields in the circumgalactic medium have significant angular structure. This azimuthal anisotropy at fixed distance is driven by galactic feedback processes that launch strong outflows into the halo. At the virial radius, $z=0$ galaxies with M$_\star show the strongest an isotropy ($\sim 0.35$ dex)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06614v1.title: Stellar and AGN Feedback Probed with Outflows in JWST Galaxies at z=3-9: Implications of Frequent Nearly-Spherical Galactic Fountains
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06614v1.summary: We study outflows in 130 galaxies with -22<MUV<-16 at z=3-9 identified in JWST NIRSpec and NIRCam WFSS data. Four out of the 30 outflowing galaxies are Type 1 AGN whose emission lines include line profile components as broad as FWHM>1000 km/s.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06558v1.title: Confirmation and characterization of neglected WDS systems using Gaia DR3 and the Virtual Observatory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06558v1.summary: The aim of this paper is, making use of the Gaia DR3 catalogue and VirtualObservatory tools, to confirm and characterize 428 binary and multiple stellar systems. The components of the stellar systems have the same parallax and proper motion (within the errors) and are separated by less than 50,000 AU.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06551v1.title: Gaia Focused Product Release: Sources from Service Interface Function image analysis -- Half a million new sources in omega Centauri
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06551v1.summary: New software pipeline exploits Service Interface Function (SIF) images of crowded fields. Half a million additional Gaia sources produced in the omega Centauri ($\omega$ Cen) cluster. New catalogue contains parallaxes and proper motions, but no meaningful colour information. We discuss the dedicated SIF CF datareduction pipeline, validate its data products, and introduce their Gaiaarchive table.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06539v1.title: Surface chemical composition of single WNh stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06539v1.summary: Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars of the WNh category contain a significant fraction of hydrogen at their surface. We aim to better characterise the properties of single WR stars in the Galaxy and the Magellanic Clouds. We find that all WNn stars show the signatures of CNO-cycle material at their surfaces.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02330v2.title: Obscuration beyond the nucleus: infrared quasars can be buried in extreme compact starbursts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02330v2.summary: In the standard quasar model, the accretion disk obscuration is due to thecanonical dusty torus. We argue that a substantial part of the quasarophobicobscuration can come from the interstellar medium (ISM) when the quasars areembedded in compact starbursts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06501v1.title: A sensitive, high-resolution, wide-field IRAM NOEMA CO(1-0) survey of the very nearby spiral galaxy IC 342
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06501v1.summary: We present a new wide-field 10.75 x 10. 75 arcmin^2 (~11x11 kpc^2) NOEMA CO(1-0) survey of the very nearby spiral galaxy IC 342. The typical surface density and line width of molecular gas increase from the inter-arm region to the arm and bar region. We speculate that bar-driven gas inflow could explain the large gas concentration in the central kiloparsec.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06463v1.title: IAS/CEA Evolution of Dust in Nearby Galaxies (ICED): the spatially-resolved dust properties of NGC4254
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06463v1.summary: We use the millimetre maps observed with NIKA2 at IRAM-30m, as part of the IMEGIN Guaranteed Time Large Program. We derive the global and local properties of interstellar dust grains through infrared-to-radio spectral distribution fitting. We find an evident anti-correlation between the averagestellar radiation field and the fraction of small grains in the centre of NGC4254.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06295v1.title: Gaia Focused Product Release: A catalogue of sources around quasars to search for strongly lensed quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06295v1.summary: GravLens was built to analyse all Gaia detections around quasars and to cluster them into sources. It produced a catalogue of secondary sources around each quasar. We propose a list of 381 lensed candidates, of which we identified 49 as the most promising. The associate tables allow the entire community to explore the unique Gaia data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06280v1.title: Local star-forming galaxies build up central mass concentration most actively near $M_{*}=10^{10}M_{\odot}$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06280v1.summary: We present a study on what mass regime star-forming galaxies (SFGs) build up most actively. The mean age gradient is negative, consistent with the inside-outdisk formation scenario. SFGs with positive age typically have more compact sizes and morecentricly concentrated star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17822v2.title: Limits on scalar-induced gravitational waves from the stochastic background by pulsar timing array observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17822v2.summary: The search for new physics remains plausible in this observational window. We explore the possibility of explaining such a signal by the scalar-induced gravitationalwaves (IGWs) in the very early universe. We find that this approach can put constraints on the parameters of IGW energy spectrum and further yield restrictions on various inflation models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06264v1.title: Astronomical Diffuse Interstellar Bands Analyzed by Hydrocarbon Pentagon-Hexagon Combined PAH Molecules
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06264v1.summary: This study theoretically predicted the specific Polycyclic AromaticHydrocarbon (PAH) molecules to satisfy both astronomically observed DiffuseInterstellar Bands (DIB) and Infrared B bands (IR) Under astronomical top-downmaterial creation scheme, we have previously found the hydrocarbonpentagon-hexagon combined PAH molecules.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03259v2.title: The EDIBLES Survey. VII. A survey of C2 and C3 in interstellar clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03259v2.summary: C$_2$ and C$_3$ molecules are detected in the same velocity components. No clear differences among sightlines with and without detection of the molecules. We find a very good correlation between $N$(C$2$) and $N $(C $3$) with Pearson $r = 0.93$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.06771v2.title: Primordial Black Hole Dark Matter Simulations Using PopSyCLE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.06771v2.summary: Primordial black holes (PBHs) are speculated to be a viable form of dark matter. If they exist, they should be detectable through photometric and astrometric signals resultingfrom gravitational microlensing of stars in the Milky Way. We detail our PBH population model, and demonstrate our PopSyCLE + PBH results through simulations of the OGLE-IV and Roman microlensed surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06222v1.title: Evolved galaxies in high-density environments across $2.0\leq z<4.2$ using the ZFOURGE survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06222v1.summary: High density environments are the most significant regions, which consist of elevated quiescent fractions and suppressed star formation activity. The Butcher-Oemler effect and SFR-density relation may not reverse towards higher redshifts as previously thought. Overall, our results suggest that well-evolved, passive galaxies are already in place in high density environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06216v1.title: An Extreme FeLoBAL Outflow in the VLT/UVES Spectrum of Quasar SDSS J1321-0041
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06216v1.summary: Quasar outflows are often analyzed to determine their ability to contribute to active galactic nucleus (AGN) feedback. We have identified abroad absorption line (BAL) outflow in the VLT/UVES spectrum of the quasar SDSS J1321-0041. The outflow shows troughs from Fe II, and is therefore identified as an FeLoBAL.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15599v2.title: A 9-Month Hubble Space Telescope Near-UV Survey of M87. I. Light and Color Curves of 94 Novae, and a Re-determination of the Nova Rate
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.15599v2.summary: M87 has been monitored with a cadence of 5 days over a 9 month-long span. We test and confirm nova modelers' prediction that recurrent novae cannot erupt more than once every 45 days. We show that novae closely follow the K-band light of M87 to within a fewarcsec of the galaxy nucleus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06175v1.title: Gaia Focused Product Release: Spatial distribution of two diffuse interstellar bands
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06175v1.summary: Diffuse interstellar bands (DIBs) are absorption features seen in optical andinfrared spectra of stars. They are probably caused by large and complexmolecules in the ISM. We investigate the Galactic distribution andproperties of two DIBs identified in almost six million stellar spectra collected by the Gaia Radial Velocity Spectrometer.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06156v1.title: The Evaporating Massive Embedded Stellar Cluster IRS 13 Close to Sgr A*. I. Detection of a rich population of dusty objects in the IRS 13 cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06156v1.summary: A detailed analysis of the Nuclear Stellar Cluster (NSC) concedes not only the existence of the Scluster with its fast-moving stars and the supermassive black hole (SMBH) Sgr A*. It also reveals an embedded region of gas and dust with an exceptionally high stellar density called IRS 13.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15442v3.title: The Need For Speed: Rapid Refitting Techniques for Bayesian Spectral Characterization of the Gravitational Wave Background Using PTAs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15442v3.summary: Pulsar timing arrays (PTAs) have recently found evidence for a stochastic gravitational-wave background (SGWB) These techniques refit SGWB spectral models to previously computed Bayesian posterior estimates of the timing power spectra. Our techniques are much faster than the production-level likelihood and scale much more favorably as a PTA is expanded.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06120v1.title: XLSSC 122 caught in the act of growing up: Spatially resolved SZ observations of a z=1.98 galaxy cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06120v1.summary: How protoclusters evolved from sparse galaxy overdensities to mature galaxy clusters is still not well understood. We study the dynamical state and morphology of the z=1.98 galaxy cluster XLSSC 122 with high-resolution observations of the ICM through the SZ effect. By reconstructing the interferometric observations and modeling in the uv-plane, we obtain a tentative detection of an infalling group or filamentary-like structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13070v2.title: The Calar Alto Legacy Integral Field Area Survey: spatial resolved properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13070v2.summary: We present the analysis performed using the pyPipe3D pipeline for the 895galaxies that comprises the eCALIFA data release Sanchez et al. submitted. We illustrate the results of the analysis using the NGC\,2906 as an archetypal galaxy. In general our results agree with previous published ones, however, tracing radial patterns is improved when using the current dataset.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13022v2.title: The Calar Alto Legacy Integral Field Area Survey: extended and remastered data release
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13022v2.summary: This paper describes the extended data release of the Calar Alto LegacyIntegral Field Area (CALIFA) survey (eDR) It comprises science-grade quality data for 895 galaxies obtained with the PMAS/PPak instrument at the 3.5 mtelescope. It includes galaxies of any morphological type, star-formation stage, a wide range of stellar masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06055v1.title: Secondary outflow driven by the protostar Ser-emb 15 in Serpens
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06055v1.summary: We present the detection of a secondary outflow associated with a Class Isource, Ser-emb 15, in the Serpens Molecular Cloud. We discuss two scenarios to explain the driving mechanism of the primary and secondary outflows. Detecting these outflows should contribute to understanding complex star-forming environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06037v1.title: NEATH II: N$_2$H$^+$ as a tracer of imminent star formation in quiescent high-density gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06037v1.summary: Star formation activity in molecular clouds is often found to be correlated with the amount of material above a column density threshold. We post-process hydrodynamical simulations of molecular clouds with a time-dependent chemical network. We find thatmany molecules widely assumed to specifically trace the dense, star-forming component of Molecular clouds (e.g. HCN, HCO) actually also exist in substantial quantities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06032v1.title: Toward interpreting the IBEX ribbon with mirror diffusion in interstellar turbulent magnetic fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06032v1.summary: The mirroring by compressible modes of MHD turbulence dominates over that by the mean magnetic field. The ribbon width is determined by both the range of pitch angles for effective turbulent mirroring and the field line wandering induced by Alfv\'{e}nic modes. The field line worrisomewandering also affects the coherence of the ribbon structure across the sky.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06011v1.title: On the root cause of the host `mass-step' in the Hubble residuals of type Ia supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06011v1.summary: It is well established that the Hubble residuals of type Ia supernovae show the luminosity step with respect to their host galaxy stellar masses. Here we investigate the root cause of the mass-step and propose that the bimodal nature of the host $age$ distribution is responsible for the step.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06016v1.title: Floating binary planets from ejections during close stellar encounters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06016v1.summary: Jupiter Mass Binary Objects (JuMBOs) by the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) may form as a result of ejection after a close stellar flyby. We consider a system of two Jupiter-likeplanets moving in circular orbits with velocities $v_1$ and $v-2$ around a Sun-like star. The ratio of the cross section of JuMBO's cross section to that of single ejected free-floating planets can approach 0.75-0.8.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07709v1.title: Dust depletion of of metals from local to distant galaxies II: Cosmic dust-to-metal ratio and dust composition
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07709v1.summary: The chemical enrichment of the Universe can be traced through the evolution of the dust-to-metals ratio (DTM) We find that the DTM and DTG ratios increase with metallicity and with the dust tracer [Zn/Fe]. This suggests that grain growth in the ISM is a dominant process of dust production.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07695v1.title: Strong lensing by galaxies: past highlights, current status, and future prospects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07695v1.summary: Galaxy-scale strong lensing is a powerful tool in Astrophysics and Cosmology. It enables studies of massive galaxies' internal structure, their formation and evolution, stellar initial mass function, and cosmological parameters. In this conference, we highlight key findings from the past decade inastrophysical applications.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07627v1.title: Cosmology from LOFAR Two-metre Sky Survey Data Release 2: Angular Clustering of Radio Sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07627v1.summary: The LOFAR Two-metre Sky Survey Data Release 2 (LoTSS-DR2) provides the largest low-frequency radio catalogue to date. We use the data to investigate the angular two-point correlation function of galaxies within the survey. We discuss systematics in the data and an improvedmethodology for generating random catalogues.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1907.10532v2.title: Chirping compact stars: gravitational radiation and detection degeneracy with binary systems A conceptual pathfinder for space-based gravitational-wave observatories
http://arxiv.org/abs/1907.10532v2.summary: Compressible, Riemann S-type ellipsoids can emit gravitational waves (GWs) with a chirp-like behavior. We show that the GW frequency-amplitude evolution of CELs is indistinguishable from that emitted by double white dwarfs (DWDs) and by extreme mass-ratio inspirals (EMRIs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07502v1.title: Exoplanet Occurrence Rates from Microlensing Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07502v1.summary: The number of exoplanets detected using gravitational microlensing technique is currently larger than 200. Microlensing isuniquely sensitive to low-mass planets orbiting at separations of several severalastronomical units. Free-floating planets are an elusive population of objects that seem to be more common than ordinary, gravitationally bound planets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07498v1.title: Low-mass Quiescent Galaxies Are Small in Isolated Environments: Environmental Dependence of the Mass-Size Relation of Low-mass Quiescent Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07498v1.summary: The mass-size relation of low-mass quiescent galaxies depends on their environment. LQGs in the highest-density environments exhibit an average size larger than those in isolated environments. The slope of the mass- size relation for LQG in high-density. environments is significantly shallower than that of their counterparts in isolated. environments. We suggest that the steep slope and low normalization of the. mass-sized relation of LQGS in the lowest-densityvironments may originate from recent gas-rich mergers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07384v1.title: Nonlinear redshift space distortion in halo ellipticity correlations: Analytical model and N-body simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07384v1.summary: The three-dimensional ellipticity field is notaffected by the redshift-space distortion (RSD) at linear order. The Finger-of-God effect is caused by the coordinatetransformation from real to redshift space. Adopting a simple Gaussian damping function to describe the RSD effect and the nonlinear alignment model, we derive analytic formulas for the multipole moments of the power spectra of the field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00343v2.title: Application of Deep Learning Methods Combined with Physical Background in Wide Field of View Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00343v2.summary: The HADAR experiment, which will be constructed in Tibet, China, combines the wide-angle advantages of traditional EAS array detectors with the high-sensitivity advantages of focused Cherenkov detectors. Its physics objective is to observe transient sources such as gamma-ray bursts and counterparts of gravitational waves.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07304v1.title: CAHA/PPAK Integral-field Spectroscopic Observations of M81. II. Testing Photoionization Models in A Spatially-resolved LINER
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07304v1.summary: The origin of the low-ionization nuclear emission-line region (LINER) in local galaxies and its relationship with supermassive black holes are debated for decades. We preform a comprehensive evaluation of traditionalphotoionization models against the circumnuclear ionized gas in M81. It is found that the integrated photoionization by theLLAGN and hot, low-mass stars distributed in the bulge can roughly reproduce the observed radial intensity distributions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00487v2.title: JWST Measurements of Neutral Hydrogen Fractions and Ionized Bubble Sizes at $z=7-12$ Obtained with Ly$α$ Damping Wing Absorptions in 26 Bright Continuum Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00487v2.summary: We present volume-averaged neutral hydrogen fractions and bubble radii of galaxies at the epoch of reionization. We construct 4 composite spectra binned by redshift, and find the clear evolution of softening break towards high redshift. We estimate Ly$\alpha$ damping wing absorption in the galaxyspectra with realistic templates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07285v1.title: A spectroscopic survey of Ly$α$ emitters and Ly$α$ luminosity function at Redshifts 3.7 and 4.8
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07285v1.summary: We present a spectroscopic survey of Ly$\alpha$ emitters (LAEs) at $z\sim3.7$ and $z''sim4.8$ The LAEs are selected using the narrowband technique based on the combination of deep narrowband and broadband imaging data. TheirLy$\ alpha$ luminosities are measured using the secure redshifts and deepphotometric data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07283v1.title: Lyman Continuum Emission from Spectroscopically Confirmed Ly$α$ Emitters at $z\sim3.1$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07283v1.summary: We present a study of Lyman continuum (LyC) emission in a sample of galaxies at $z\approx3.1$ in the Subaru-XMM Deep Surveyfield. We detect 5 individual LyC galaxycandidates in the $U_{\rm J}$ band, and their escape fractions are roughly between 40% and 80%. Compared with the non-LyC LAEs, the LyCLAEs tend to have higher Ly$\alpha$ luminosities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.08043v2.title: The MASSIVE Survey. XVIII. Deep Wide-Field $K$-band Photometry and Local Scaling Relations for Massive Early-Type Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.08043v2.summary: We present wide-field, deep $K$-band photometry of 98 luminous early-type galaxies from the MASSIVE survey. The most luminous galaxies tend to have larger sizes and smaller velocity dispersions than expected from a simple power-law fit to less massive galaxies. Our measured relations are qualitatively consistent with the most massive elliptical galaxies forming largely through dissipationless merge.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07267v1.title: Morphology of star-forming clumps in ram-pressure stripped galaxies as seen by HST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07267v1.summary: We characterize the morphological properties of a statistically relevantsample of H$\alpha$ and UV young star-forming clumps and optical complexes. The clump number and size increase with the complex size, while the median complex filling factor islarger for UV clumps. When studying the position of the clumps inside their complexes, we find a displacement from the complex center.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07257v1.title: A survey of SiO $J=$ 1 -- 0 emission toward massive star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07257v1.summary: The application of silicon monoxide (SiO) as a shock tracer arises from itsensity to occur in the gas phase as a result of shock-induced phenomena. We detected SiO emission toward 104 regions that include 57 IRDCs, 21 HMPOs, and 26 UCHIIs. The determined median SiO columndensity and abundance relative to $N$(H$_2$) are similar to those obtained toward other star-forming regions. This suggests a similarorigin for the SiO and Class I CH$_3$OH emission in these sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07201v1.title: Quantifying the stellar ages of dynamically-separated bulges and disks of CALIFA spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07201v1.summary: We employ a recently-developed population-orbit superposition technique to simultaneously fit the stellar kinematic and age maps of 82 CALIFA spiralgalaxies. The recovered mean ages of dynamically cold, warm and hot components match the true values well, with up to $20\%$ observationalerror in the mock age maps. The average younger stellar age in disks than in bulges suggests that either the disks formed later and/or experienced a more prolonged period of formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2106.14349v3.title: PNet -- A Deep Learning Based Photometry and Astrometry Bayesian Framework
http://arxiv.org/abs/2106.14349v3.summary: Time domain astronomy has emerged as a vibrant research field in recent years. The development of an algorithm capable of detecting them and determining their magnitudes and positions has become imperative. We present the PNet, an end-to-endframework designed not only to detect celestial objects and extract their positions but also to estimate photometry uncertainty.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07095v1.title: Interesting Clues to Detect Hidden Tidal Disruption Events in Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07095v1.summary: In the manuscript, effects of Tidal Disruption Events (TDEs) are estimated on long-term AGN variability. The results provide aninteresting forward-looking method to detect probable hidden TDEs in normal broad line AGN, due to quite different variability properties, in different epochs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07036v1.title: The look of high-velocity red-giant star collisions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07036v1.summary: High-velocity stellar collisions driven by a supermassive black hole (BH) can rival theenergetics of supergiant star explosions following gravitational collapse of their iron core. Collisions from more extended or stronger collisions (higher velocity or smaller impact parameter) yield bolometric luminosities on the order of 1e43 erg/s at 1d.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07011v1.title: The impact of bar origin and morphology on stellar migration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07011v1.summary: Bar origin is distinguishable, with the tidal disc displaying larger migration overall. The affect of closest approach on populations of stars formed before, after and during this period is evident. Similar bars produce similar traits in migration tendency and radius. Bar morphology is also found to be a significant factor in the evolution of disc stellar properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06928v2.title: Unraveling the Complex Structure of AGN-driven Outflows. VI. Strong Ionized Outflows in Type 1 AGNs and the Outflow Size-Luminosity Relation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06928v2.summary: We present spatially resolved gas kinematics, ionization, and energetics of type 1 and 5 type 2 active galactic nuclei. We find a strongly blueshifted region in [OIII] velocity maps,representing an approaching cone in biconical outflows. AGN photoionization is dominant in the central region of most targets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06900v2.title: Halfway to the peak: Spatially resolved star formation and kinematics in a z=0.54 dusty galaxy with JWST/MIRI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06900v2.summary: JWST/MIRI/MRS observations of an infrared luminous disk galaxy,FLS1, at z=0.54. With a lookback time of 5 Gyr, FLS1 is chronologically at the midpoint between the peak epoch of star formation and the present day. MRS data provide maps of the atomic fine structure lines [Ar II]6.99 micron, [ArIII]8.99micron, and [Ne II]12.81 micron.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06898v1.title: The origin of supermassive black holes at cosmic dawn
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06898v1.summary: We investigate the steady spherically symmetric accretion in the combined potential of a central black hole and a dark matter halo. We find that the trans-sonic solution to the centre is not possible without a black hole. In the second phase, the black hole mass increases rapidly to super-supermassive scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06894v1.title: Binary mergers in strong gravity background of Kerr black hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06894v1.summary: Binary-black-hole (BBH) mergers can take place close to a supermassive blackhole (SMBH) while being in a bound orbit around the SMBH. Study shows that including the strong gravity.effects of describing theSMBH with a Kerr metric can significantly modify. the dynamics of the system.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06885v1.title: The distribution of stellar orbits in Eagle galaxies -- the effect of mergers, gas accretion, and secular evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06885v1.summary: The merger history of a galaxy is thought to be one of the major factors determining its internal dynamics. We study the instantaneous orbital distribution of                galaxies in the Eagle simulation. We find that older stars have warmer orbits, with the oldest ones showing orbits consistent with both hot and counter-rotating classifications, consistent with the trend found in the Milky-Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06887v1.title: FRESCO: An extended, massive, rapidly rotating galaxy at z=5.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06887v1.summary: This study pilots a new method for measuring galaxy dynamics by combining FRESCO NIRCam grismspectroscopy and JADES medium-band imaging. We find a significantvelocity gradient, which, if interpreted as rotation yields $V_{rot} = grotesque240\pm50$km/s and we hence refer to this galaxy as Twister-z5. The high rotation velocity in this galaxy is not due to a compact size as may be expected in the early universe but rather a high total mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06890v1.title: The WISDOM of power spectra: how the galactic gravitational potential impacts a galaxy's central gas reservoir in simulations and observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.06890v1.summary: Mass surface density power spectrum is a powerful tool to constrain thedegree of structure within a gas reservoir. Observations indicate that the central gas discs are smoother in early-type galaxies than their late-type counterparts. Recent simulations predict that the dynamical suppression of star formation in spheroid-dominated galaxies is preceded by the suppression of fragmentation of interstellar media.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08525v1.title: An enhanced abundance of bright galaxies in protocluster candidates at z~3-5
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08525v1.summary: Protocluster candidates are selected as regions with a significantlyenhanced surface density of dropout galaxies. Rest-frame UV bright galaxies are over-abundant inprotoclusters candidates, a trend seen across the full redshift range studied. This suggests that the cosmic clock is ahead in high-density environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08521v1.title: Bottom-up dust nucleation theory in oxygen-rich evolved stars II. Magnesium and calcium aluminate clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08521v1.summary: Spinel (MgAl) and krotite (CaAl) are alternative candidates to alumina (Al$_2$O$_3$) as primary dust condensates in oxygen-rich evolved stars. Spinel was proposed as a potential carrier of the circumstellar 13 $mu$m feature. The growth of larger clusters with $n$=2$-$7 is described by the temperature-dependent Gibbs free energies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08482v1.title: DIISC-III: Signatures of Stellar Disk Growth in Nearby Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08482v1.summary: We explore the growth of the stellar disks in 14 nearby spiral galaxies as part of the Deciphering the Interplay between the Interstellar medium, Stars, and the Circumgalactic medium (DIISC) survey. We study the radial distribution of specific star formation rates (sSFR) and investigate the ratio of the outer and inner sSFR. We find that star formation and disk growth are likely to proceed outward in galactic disks with high HI gas fractions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08441v1.title: Ly-alpha emission in low-redshift most metal-deficient compact star-forming galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08441v1.summary: We present observations with the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph onboard theHubble Space Telescope of nine most metal-deficient compact star-forming galaxies. We aim to study theproperties of Ly-alpha emission in these extremely metal- deficient objects. We find a relatively tight relation between theLy-alpha and LyC escape fractions. We propose to use the latter relation to estimate indirectly the escaping ionizing radiation in LAEs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08389v1.title: Modelling Deuterated Isotopologues of Methanol toward the Pre-Stellar Core L1544
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08389v1.summary: We aim to improve a previous model for the prediction of column densities and deuterium fractions of non- and singly deuterated methanol. We employ a gas-grain chemical code to devise a model that is in agreement with the observed column density and Deuterium fraction profiles of interstellar dust grains.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08354v1.title: Nonlinear magnetic buoyancy instability and turbulent dynamo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08354v1.summary: Stratified disks with strong horizontal magnetic fields are susceptible to magnetic buoyancy instability (MBI) This can play an important role in galactic evolution. The MBIand the Parker instability, in which cosmic rays exacerbate MBI, are often studied using an imposed magnetic field. In galaxies, the magnetic field is continuously replenished by a large-scale dynamoaction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08273v1.title: Five years of 6.7 GHz methanol maser monitoring with Irbene radio telescopes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08273v1.summary: 5-year monitoring program of 42 sources targeted at 6.7 GHz methanol masers, conducted from March 2017 to October 2022. More than 55 per cent of the sources showed significant variability, but often only one or a few spectral features were varying significantly. Sources were observed with irregularintervals where time between two consecutive observation ranged from twenty-four hours to thirty five days.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08253v1.title: EVStabilityNet: Predicting the Stability of Star Clusters in General Relativity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08253v1.summary: Deep neural network predicts stability of isotropicsteady states of the asymptotically flat, spherically symmetric Einstein-Vlasovsystem in Schwarzschild coordinates. Network takes as input the energyprofile and the redshift of the steady state. Network was trained on more than ten thousand steady states using an active learning scheme.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08180v1.title: A High-Mass Young Star-forming Core Escaping from Its Parental Filament
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08180v1.summary: We studied the unique kinematic properties in massive filament G352.63-1.07 at $10^3$-AU spatial scale with the dense molecular tracers observed with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) We find the centralmassive core M1 (12 $M_\odot$) being separated from the surrounding filament with a velocity difference of $v- {v}_{sys}=-2$ km/s.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08103v1.title: Radio Galaxy Zoo: tagging radio subjects using text
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08103v1.summary: RadioTalk is a communication platform that enabled members of the RadioGalaxy Zoo (RGZ) citizen science project to engage in discussion threads. For the first time, we combine text and images to automatically classify radio galaxies using a multi-modal learning approach. We also discovered over 10,000 new radio sources beyond the RGZ-DR1 catalogue in this dataset.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08086v1.title: An SiO Toroid and Wide-angle Outflow associated with the Massive Protostar W75N(B)-VLA2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08086v1.summary: VLA2 is an enigmatic protostar associated with a wind-driven H$_2$O maser shell. It has evolved from an almost isotropic outflow to acollimated one in just 20 years. The shell expansion seemed to be halted by an obstacle to the northeast of VLA2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08079v1.title: The difficult path to coalescence: massive black hole dynamics in merging low mass dark matter haloes and galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08079v1.summary: We present a high resolution numerical study of the sinking and merging ofmassive black holes (MBHs) with masses in the range of $10^3 - 10^7. The study highlights the difficulty to bring in and keep low mass MBHs in the centres of low mass halos/galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08052v1.title: Collisional excitation of PO$^+$ by $para$-H$_2$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08052v1.summary: We report the derivation of rate coefficients for the rotational(de-)excitation of PO$^+$ induced by collisions with H$_2$. The calculations were performed on a four-dimensional potential energy surface, obtained on top of highly accurate $ab$ $initio$ energy points. Preliminary tests pointed out the low influence of the coupling between $j=0$ and the higher rotational.levels of H $_2$ on the cross sections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08030v1.title: An improved dynamical Poisson equation solver for self-gravity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08030v1.summary: Self-gravity is crucial in the structure formation of the universe. The multigrid method is widely used as a solver for the Poissonequation of the self-gravity. To perform large-scale parallel simulations, developing a new gravity solver with good parallelization efficiency is beneficial.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08023v1.title: VERTICO and IllustrisTNG: The spatially resolved effects of environment on galactic gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08023v1.summary: The TNG100 simulation reproduces the observed reduction in each of the total atomic and total molecular hydrogen gas for galaxies within massive halos. We select galaxies in the simulation thatare analogous to those in the HERACLES and VERTICO surveys, and mock-observethem to the common specifications of the data. The result promises that modern cosmological hydrodynamic simulations can be used to reliably model the post-infall histories of cluster satellite galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07907v1.title: The Pristine survey -- XXII. A serendipitous discovery of an extremely Li-rich very metal-poor giant and a new method of $^6$Li/$^7$Li isotope measurement
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07907v1.summary: We report the serendipitous discovery of a very metal-poor (VMP) Li-rich giant star. We analyse the Li I 6103 and 6707 \r{A} lines accounting for departures from local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) and correcting for 3Deffects. We also derive NLTE abundances for 16 elements, most of which show similar abundances to those found in VMP stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07579v2.title: JWST's PEARLS: Transients in the MACS J0416.1-2403 Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07579v2.summary: The James WebbSpace Telescope (JWST) has opened a new window for time-domain discoveries in the infrared. We report observations in the only field that has received four epochs (spanning 126 days) of JWST NIRCam observations in Cycle 1. Thisfield is towards MACS J0416.1-2403, which is a rich galaxy cluster at redshift 0.4 and is one of the Hubble Frontier Fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10930v2.title: Active galactic nuclei with high-resolution X-ray spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10930v2.summary: The imminent launch of XRISM will usher in an era of high-resolution X-rayspectroscopy. For active galactic nuclei (AGN) this is an exciting epoch that is full of potential for uncovering the ins and outs of supermassive black holes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02703v2.title: JWST constraints on the UV luminosity density at cosmic dawn: implications for 21-cm cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02703v2.summary: JWST observations for radio experiments aimed at detecting the redshifted 21-cm hyperfine transition of diffuse neutral hydrogen. Accounting for an early.radiation excess above the CMB suggests a shallower or flat evolution to simultaneously reproduce low and high-$z$ current UV luminosity density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07773v1.title: Shock imprints on the radio mini halo in RBS797
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07773v1.summary: X-ray observations have detected three pairs of shock fronts, connected with the activity of the central AGN. The diffuse radio emission iselongated in different directions at 144 MHz (east-west) with respect to 1.4GHz (north-south) The spectral index profile of the mini halo shows a gradual flattening from the centre to the periphery.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07764v1.title: The APOGEE Value Added Catalogue of Galactic globular cluster stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07764v1.summary: The catalogue contains a total of 7,737 entries for 6,422 unique stars associated with 72 GalacticGCs. Full APOGEE DR17 information is provided, including radial velocities andabundances for up to 20 elements. The catalogue in fits format is available for public download from the SDSS-IV value added catalogue website.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07766v1.title: CEERS: 7.7 μm PAH Star Formation Rate Calibration with JWST MIRI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07766v1.summary: We test the relationship between UV-derived star formation rates (SFRs) and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) luminosities. We utilize multi-band photometry from HST, CFHT, JWST, Spitzer, and Herschel for the Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science (CEERS) Survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07769v1.title: Simulations of galaxy cluster mergers with velocity-dependent, rare and frequent self-interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07769v1.summary: Self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) has been proposed to solve small-scaleproblems in cosmology. In previous work, constraints on the self-interaction cross-section of dark matter have been derived assuming that it is independent of velocity. We find that the effects of velocity-dependent cross-sections are observed when comparing early-time and late-time oscillation amplitude of brightest cluster galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07757v1.title: The Farmer: A reproducible profile-fitting photometry package for deep galaxy surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07757v1.summary: The Farmer is anautomated, reproducible profile-fitting photometry package. It pairs a library of smooth parametric models from The Tractor with a decision tree that determines the best-fit model in concert with neighboring sources. The Farmer is already being utilized to produce catalogs for several large-area deep extragalactic surveys.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07758v1.title: The Evolution of Accreting Binaries: from Brown Dwarfs to Supermassive Black Holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07758v1.summary: Circumbinary accretion occurs throughout the universe, from the formation ofstars and planets to the aftermath of major galactic mergers. We study disks with mass ratios $q\equiv M_2/M_1$ from 0.01 to 1 and at each mass ratio probing the effects of disk thickness and viscosity. Colder circumbinary disks remain eccentric even at $0.01$ and sustain deep, asymmetric cavities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07750v1.title: Cosmological and idealised simulations of dark matter haloes with velocity-dependent, rare and frequent self-interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07750v1.summary: There are a variety of self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) models that lead to varying astrophysical predictions and hence varying success in explaining observations. Studies of dark matter density cores suggest a velocity-dependent scattering cross-section. In this work, we investigate how a velocity dependence alters the evolution of the DMoutheastern distribution for frequent DM scatterings.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07753v1.title: Bird-Snack: Bayesian Inference of dust law $R_V$ Distributions using SN Ia Apparent Colours at peaK
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07753v1.summary: To reduce systematic uncertainties in Type Ia supernova (SN Ia) cosmology, the host galaxy dust law shape parameter, $R_V$, must be accurately constrained. We develop a computationally-inexpensive pipeline, Bird-Snack, to rapidly infer dust population distributions from optical-near-infrared SN colours at peak brightness.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07754v1.title: How time weathers galaxies: The temporal impact of the cluster environment on galaxy formation and evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07754v1.summary: Galaxies with a residence time of 10 Gyr increase their stellar-to-halo mass ratio, by around 1 dex. Galaxies must have had the opportunity to `splash back' to the first caustic to trace out a representative value of $R_{\rm st}$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10589v1.title: Delayed Massive-Star Mechanical Feedback at Low Metallicity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10589v1.summary: Metal-poor stellar winds are much weaker, and more massivesupernova progenitors likely collapse directly to black holes without exploding. For 0.4 Zsun we find reductions in the total integratedmechanical energy and momentum of ~40% and 75%, respectively, compared to classically expected at solar metallicity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19331v2.title: CEERS: MIRI deciphers the spatial distribution of dust-obscured star formation in galaxies at $0.1<z<2.5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19331v2.summary: We combined HST images from the Cosmic Assembly Near-infrared DeepExtragalactic Legacy Survey with JWST images to measure the stellar and dust-obscured starformation distributions of 69 star-forming galaxies. Galaxies above the main sequence (MS; i.e., starbursts) have rest-MIR sizes that are a factor 2 smaller than theirrest-optical sizes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03521v2.title: The Role of Radiation and Halo Mergers in Pop III Star Formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.03521v2.summary: Study of population of primordial star-forming minihalos at Cosmic Dawn. In absence of radiation, minimum halo mass required to bring about collapse to be 10^5 Msun. This increases to 10^6 Msun after two stars have formed. 'Mixed' merger between recently evacuated halos and gas-rich ones accelerate star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10356v1.title: The evolution of sulphur-bearing molecules in high-mass star-forming cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10356v1.summary: To understand the chemistry of sulphur (S) in the interstellar medium, models need to be tested by observations of S-bearing molecules in different physicalconditions. We analyse observations obtained with the IRAM 30m telescope. cores classified in the three main evolutionary stages of the high-mass star-formation process.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10341v1.title: GMRT observations of the radio trail from CXOU J163802.6-471358
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10341v1.summary: The X-ray source CXOU J163802.6-471358 is thought to be a pulsar wind nebula. The radio trail points back to the supernova remnant (SNR) G338.1+0.4. There are no knowngalactic SNRs close to the PWN and radio trail.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10335v1.title: Exploring the Sun's birth radius and the distribution of planet building blocks in the Milky Way galaxy: A multi-zone Galactic chemical evolution approach
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10335v1.summary: We explore the influence of the Milky Way galaxy's chemical evolution on theformation, structure, and habitability of the Solar system. We use a multi-zone grotesqueGalactic Chemical Evolution (GCE) model to reproduce key observational constraints. Our GCE model suggests that the Sun formed in the inner Galactic meticulouslydisc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10328v1.title: Is the M81 Fast Radio Burst Host Globular Cluster Special?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10328v1.summary: Fast RadioBurst FRB 20200120E is located in the M81 globular cluster. We estimate the relative encounter rate of the FRB host and 210 other globular clusters in M81. The estimated encounter rate is moderately higher than the median stellar encounter rate in our two comparison samples.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10327v1.title: Resonant Effects of a Bar on the Galactic Disk Kinematics Perpendicular to Its Plane
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10327v1.summary: Kinematics of the Milky Way disk in the solar neighborhood based on the GAIA DR3 catalog. We study the influence of resonances of a rotating bar withstellar oscillations perpendicular to the plane of the disk. We show that, in the model with the long and fast rotating bar, some stars in the 2:1 OLR region deviate far from their originalplaces.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v1.title: The Quasar Feedback Survey: characterising CO excitation in quasar host galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v1.summary: 17 Type 2quasars at $z <$ 0.2 from the Quasar Feedback Survey. We measure the total molecular gas content using the CO(1-0) emission and homogeneously sample the CO spectralline energy distributions (SLEDs) The ionised gas traced by [OIII] exhibit systematically higher velocities than that traced by CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10225v1.title: Measuring the Milky Way Vertical Potential with the Phase Snail in a Model Independent Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10225v1.summary: The vertical phase-space spiral (snail) is a direct sign of dis-equilibrium of Milky Way's disc. The wrapping of the phase snail contains information of the vertical potential. We propose a novel method to measure thevertical potential utilizing the intersections between the snail and $z/V$ axes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13406v2.title: Dust-to-neutral gas ratio of the intermediate velocity HI clouds derived based on the sub-mm dust emission for the whole sky
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13406v2.summary: We derived, as a proxy for the metallicity, the dust-to-HI ratio of the intermediate-velocity clouds (IVCs), the high-vel velocity clouds (HVCs), and the local HI. Major results include that the ratio of dust-poor gas in the IVCs is in a range of 0.1-1.5 with a mode at 0.6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16232v2.title: A new, purely photometric method for determination of resonance locations in spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16232v2.summary: Corotation resonance in spiral arms is a key way to estimate their pattern speed. Various methods for its estimation have been developed, but they all demonstrate certain limitations and a lack of agreement with each other. This method takes into account the shape of the profile across the arm and its width.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10066v1.title: A search for extragalactic fast optical transients in the Tomo-e Gozen high-cadence survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10066v1.summary: The population of optical transients evolving within a time-scale of a few                hours or a day has recently been debated extensively. We present a search for extragalactic FOTs with the Tomo-e Gozen high-cadence survey. Most of these candidatesare in fact supernovae, variable quasars, and Galactic dwarf novae, that werepartially observed around their peak brightness.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10018v1.title: Host Galaxies for Four Nearby CHIME/FRB Sources and the Local Universe FRB Host Galaxy Population
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10018v1.summary: We present the host galaxies of four apparently non-repeating fast radiobursts (FRBs), FRBs 20181223C, 20190418A, 20191220A, and 20190425A, reported in the first Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME/FRB) catalog. We also search for possible multi-messenger counterparts, including persistent compact radio and gravitational wave (GW) sources, and find none.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10007v1.title: Broadband radio study of the North Polar Spur: Origin of the spectral turnover with insights into the X-ray and Gamma-ray spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10007v1.summary: The North Polar Spur (NPS) is a giant structure that is clearly visible in both radio and X-ray all-sky maps. We analyzed broadband radio observations covering a range between 22 MHz and 70 GHz to systematically analyze thethermal/non-thermal emissions associated with the NPS. We also estimated the gamma-ray emission associated with NPS through inverse Comptonization of the cosmic microwavebackground (CMB)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09945v1.title: SDSS J125417.98+274004.6: An X-ray Detected Minor Merger Dual AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09945v1.summary: A dual AGN has been discovered in a merger between two galaxies. The galaxies are in the early stages of the merger and connected by a tidal bridge. The secondary AGN should experience a brief but intensive period of Eddington-limit-approaching accretion during the merger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09910v1.title: Till the core collapses: the evolution and properties of self-interacting dark matter subhalos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09910v1.summary: One of the hottest questions in the cosmology of self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) is whether scatterings can induce detectable core-collapse in halos by the present day. Because gravitational tides can accelerate core-Collapse, the most promising targets to observe core- Collapse are satellite galaxies and subhalo systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09868v1.title: The treasure behind the haystack: MUSE analysis of five recently discovered globular clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09868v1.summary: The number of new globular cluster candidates has increased importantly. Most of them need to be properlycharacterised, both spectroscopically and photometrically, by means of radialvelocities, metallicities, and deeper photometric observations. We confirm the nature of Gran 4, a newly discovered globular. cluster behind the Galactic bulge, with a mean radial.velocity of -265.28 km s.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03073v2.title: A giant thin stellar stream in the Coma Galaxy Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03073v2.summary: Giant Coma Stream spans ~510 kpc in length and appears as a free-floating structure. It is located at a projected distance of 0.8 Mpc from the centre of Coma. We interpret it as being a recently accreted, tidally disrupting passive dwarf.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13821v2.title: An ALMA-resolved view of 7000 au Protostellar Gas Ring around the Class I source CrA-IRS 2 as a possible sign of magnetic flux advection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.13821v2.summary: A ring-like structure produced by magnetic flux loss has been predicted theoretically, but no observationalidentification has been presented. We have performed ALMA observations of the Class I protostar IRS 2 in the Corona Australis star-forming region and resolved a distinctive gas ring. Similar structures reported in the other young stellar sources could likely be candidates formed by the same mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11610v4.title: UNCOVER: A NIRSpec Identification of a Broad Line AGN at z = 8.50
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11610v4.summary: Deep observations with JWST have revealed an emerging population of red-point-like sources that could provide a link between the postulatedsupermassive black hole seeds and observed quasars. We present aJWST/NIRSpec spectrum of amassive accreting black hole at $z=8.50.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09790v1.title: A Lens Finder Map to check claimed High-z Galaxies behind SMACS J0723.3-7327
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09790v1.summary: The first science image released by the JWST reveals numerous galaxies in the distant background of the galaxy cluster SMACS J0723.3-7327. Some have claimed redshifts of up to $z \simeq 20$, challenging standard cosmological models for structure formation. Here, we present a lens model for the cluster that is based on five spectroscopically-confirmed systems at $1.38 \leq z.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09777v1.title: A global view on star formation: The GLOSTAR Galactic plane survey. IX. Radio Source Catalog III: 2<l<28, 36<l<40, 56<l<60 and |b|<1, VLA B-configuration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09777v1.summary: GLOSTAR is currently the highest resolution as well as the most sensitive radio survey of the northern Galactic plane at 4-8GHz. We extracted 13354 sources.above a threshold of 5sigma and 5437 sources above 7sigma that represent the.high-reliability catalog. A significant fraction of HII region and PNe candidates have alpha<-0.1 indicating that these candidates could contain radio jets, winds or outflows from high-mass and low-mass stellarobjects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03236v2.title: Dissonance in harmony: The UV/optical periodic outbursts of ASASSN-14ko exhibit repeated bumps and rebrightenings
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03236v2.summary: ASASSN-14ko was identified as an abnormal periodic nuclear transient with a potential decreasing period. Its outbursts in the optical and UV bands havedisplayed a consistent and smooth "fast-rise and slow-decay" pattern since its discovery. The light curve profiles show a bump during the rising stages and arebrightening during the declining stages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09703v1.title: New technique to select recent fast-quenching galaxies at $z\sim2$ using the optical colors
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09703v1.summary: Many massive quiescent galaxies have been discovered at $z>2$ thanks tomulti-wavelength deep and wide surveys. Here, we present a new technique to select galaxies with a short quenching timescale. We construct a set of color criteria for $z\sim2$ fast-quenching galaxies on $g-r$ vs. $r-i$ and $i-J$ vs $J-H$ or $R-i' vs. 'J-J' and test their robustnesses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07592v2.title: Cosmological constraints from Type I radio-loud quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07592v2.summary: We obtain a new sample of 1192 Type I quasars with the UV-optical, radio and X-ray wavebands coverage. By Bayesianinformation criterion, the data suggest that the X-Ray luminosity of RQQs indirectly correlative with radio luminosity because of the connection between UV and radio. We compare the results from RLQs with different results from UV- optical power law index.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15769v3.title: Carbon-Chain Chemistry in the Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15769v3.summary: The presence of carbon-chain molecules in the interstellar medium (ISM) has been known since the early 1970s. More complex species of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and fullerenes have been detected in circumstellar envelopes around carbon-rich stars and planetary nebulae. These new findings raise fresh questions about carbon-bearing species in the Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09514v1.title: Identification and chemical modelling of phosphorus nitride (PN) towards the hot molecular cores G10.47+0.03 and G31.41+0.31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09514v1.summary: Phosphorus (P) is one of the important elements for the formation of life. The P-bearing molecule phosphorus nitride (PN) is detected in several star-forming regions. PN is created in the gas phase via the neutral-neutral reaction between PO and N in the warm-up stage.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10610v2.title: An accretion disc with magnetic outflows triggered by a sudden mass accretion event in changing-look active galactic nucleus 1ES 1927+654
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.10610v2.summary: 1ES 1927+654 was known as a type 2 Seyfert galaxy, which exhibited drastic variance recently in ultraviolet (UV)/optical and X-ray bands. An UV/optical outburst was observed in the end of 2017, and it reached the peak luminosity 50 days later. We assume an episodic accretion event taking place in the outer region of the disc surrounding a central black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03828v2.title: Signatures of Massive Black Hole Merger Host Galaxies from Cosmological Simulations I: Unique Galaxy Morphologies in Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03828v2.summary: Low-frequency gravitational wave experiments are expected to detect individualmassive black hole (MBH) binaries and mergers. However, secure methods of identifying the exact host galaxy of each MBH merger amongst the large number of galaxies in the gravitational wave localization region are currently lacking. We show that combining multiple morphological statistics via a linear discriminantanalysis enables identification of the host galaxies of MBH mergers, with an accuracy of >80%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09445v1.title: Observational Constraints on Sunyaev-Zeldovich Effect Halos Around High-z Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09445v1.summary: We present continuum observations from the Atacama LargeMillimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) of 10 high-redshift quasars (QSOs) and constrain the presence of hot, ionized,circum-galactic gas in a stacking analysis. We compare our stacked observations to active galactic nucleus(AGN) feedback wind models and generalized Navarro-Frenk-White (gNFW) pressureprofile models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09422v1.title: On the Origin of the Ancient, Large-Scale Cold Front in the Perseus Cluster of Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09422v1.summary: The Perseus Cluster exhibits spiral-shaped X-ray brightness discontinuities known as 'cold fronts' These are caused by the sloshing motion of the gas after the passage of a subcluster. Recent observations of Perseus have shown that these fronts extend                to large radii.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09399v1.title: Interstellar Meteors from Tidal Disruption of Rocky Planets on Eccentric Orbits Around M Dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09399v1.summary: Meteor CNEOS-2014-01-08 (IM1) can be explained by tidal disruption of rocky planets on highly eccentricorbits around the most common stars, M-dwarfs. Rocky planets can develop a highorbital eccentricity as a result of a secular torque from an outer giant planet or a binary companion. Melting of their rocky crust during many tight perihedralpassages may result in additional elemental differentiation, leading to enhanced abundances of beryllium, lanthanum and uranium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09389v1.title: The H-alpha Emission Signature: The Role of Critical Ionization Velocity in Interstellar Space
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09389v1.summary: In low-velocity gas, the Critical Ionization Velocity(CIV) effect ionizes the atoms and produces the signatures of He (34 km/s), CNO (13.4km/s) and the metals (around 6 km-s) In anomalous-vel velocity gas, however, the CIV effect ionized the ions and produces signatures of ionized CNO and H-alpha. These distinct CIV signatures indicate that the physical conditions are different in each velocity regime.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09376v1.title: The Debris of the "Last Major Merger" is Dynamically Young
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09376v1.summary: The Milky Way's inner stellar halo contains an [Fe/H]-rich component with highly eccentric orbits. Hypotheses for the origin of this component include Gaia-Sausage/Enceladus and Virgo Radial Merger. The morphology of debrisdepends on how long it has had to phase mix.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09374v1.title: Cosmic Dragons: Galactic evolution in the COSMOS field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09374v1.summary: Using the photometric population prediction method Red Dragon, we characterize the Red Sequence (RS) and Blue Cloud (BC) of DES galaxies in the COSMOS field. Red Dragon uses a redshift-evolving, error-correctedGaussian mixture model to detail the distribution of photometric colors. We find that the BC is consistently more star-forming and typically younger than the RS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09365v1.title: Simultaneous Estimates of Star-cluster Age, Metallicity, Mass, and Extinction (SESAMME) I: Presenting an MCMC Approach to Spectral Stellar Population Fitting
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09365v1.summary: SESAMME is a public, Python-based full-spectrum fitting tool for Simultaneous Estimates of Star-cluster Age, Metallicity, Mass, and Extinction. It compares an input spectrum of a star                cluster to a grid of stellar population models with an added nebular continuum component. We illustrate the ability of SESAM ME to recover accurate ages and metallicities even at a moderate signaling ratio.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16050v3.title: JWST reveals widespread CO ice and gas absorption in the Galactic Center cloud G0.253+0.016
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16050v3.summary: We report JWST NIRCam observations of G0.253+0.016, the molecular cloud in the Central Molecular Zone known as The Brick. We catalog 56,146 stars detected in all 6                filters using the crowdsource package. Stars within and behind The Brick demonstrate prodigious absorption in the F466N filter that is produced by a combination of CO ice and gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09353v1.title: The cylindrical jet base of M87 within 100$μ\rm{as}$ of the central engine
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09353v1.summary: A recent article on high-resolution 86 GHz observations with the Greenland Telescope describes the detection of a limb-brightened jet. It was shown to be much wider and much more collimated than 2D simulations of electromagnetic(Blandford-Znajek) jets from the event horizon predicted. This was an unanticipated discovery.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09331v1.title: A catalogue of Galactic GEMS: Globular cluster Extra-tidal Mock Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09331v1.summary: This work presents the Globular cluster Extra-tidal Mock Star (GEMS)catalogue of extra-t tidal stars and binaries created via three-body dynamicalencounters in globular cluster cores. Sky positions, kinematics, stellar properties and escape information are provided for all simulated stars. We find that the action coordinates of the mock stars are largely Galactic model independent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09327v1.title: MAGNIF: A Tentative Lensed Rotating Disk at $z=8.34$ detected by JWST NIRCam WFSS with Dynamical Forward Modeling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09327v1.summary: Galaxy MACS0416-Y3 behind the lensing cluster MACSJ0416.1--2403 detected as a tentative rotating disk at $z=8.34$ detected through its [OIII]$\lambda5007$emission in JWST NIRCam wide-field slitless spectroscopic observations. If confirmed, this suggests rotating gaseous disks may have already existed within 600 million years after Big Bang.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09328v1.title: Exploring the Dependence of Gas Cooling and Heating Functions on the Incident Radiation Field with Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09328v1.summary: It is computationally expensive to exactly compute these functions in the presence of an incident radiation field. These computations can be greatly sped up by using interpolation tables of pre-computed values. We find that the primary bottleneck to increasing accuracy lies in accurately capturing the metallicity dependence of cooling and heating functions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09329v1.title: Unraveling emission line galaxy conformity at z~1 with DESI early data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09329v1.summary: Emission line galaxies (ELGs) are now the preeminent tracers of large-scale structure at z>0.8 due to their high density and strong emission lines. However, relatively little is known about ELG evolution and the ELG-halo connection. In this paper, we propose a physical picture of ELGs and improve ELG and halo connection modeling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09330v1.title: Ultra-Diffuse Galaxies -- a Distinct Population? Dwarf Galaxies in the Coma Cluster and Abell 262 from Deep u'-g'-r' Wendelstein Imaging Data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09330v1.summary: In this study, we compare the structural parameters of Ultra-Diffuse Galaxies (UDGs) to those of other dwarf galaxies and investigate whether UDGs form a distinct population. We find 11 UDGs in Abell 262 and 48UDGs inAbell 1656. The latter is 6 times more than van Dokkum et al. found in the overlapping region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07549v2.title: Halo Properties from Observable Measures of Environment: I. Halo and Subhalo Masses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.07549v2.summary: The stellar mass - halo mass relation provides a strong basis for connecting                galaxies to their host dark matter halos in both simulations and observations. Other observable information, such as the density of the local environment, canplace further constraints on a given halo's properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01657v2.title: The SOFIA FEEDBACK Legacy Survey: Rapid molecular cloud dispersal in RCW 79
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01657v2.summary: It has long been discussed whether stellar feedback in the form of winds and radiation can shred the nascent molecular cloud, thereby controlling the star formation rate. This finding provides direct observational evidence of rapid molecular cloud dispersal. The resulting mass ejection rate estimate for the cloud is 0.9-3.5 Myr. This suggests a different scenario for the evolution of RCW 79.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09226v1.title: Early phases of star formation: testing chemical tools
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09226v1.summary: The star forming processes strongly influence the ISM chemistry. Nowadays, there are available many high-quality databases at millimeter wavelengths. We found that the use of HCN/HNC ratio as an ISM should be taken with care because the HCNoptical depth is a big issue that can affect the method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14696v2.title: The puzzling properties of the MACS1149-JD1 galaxy at z=9.11
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.14696v2.summary: We analyze new JWST NIRCam and NIRSpec data on the redshift 9.11 galaxyMACS1149-JD1. Our N IRCam imaging data reveal that JD1 comprises three spatially distinct components. Our spectroscopic data indicate thatJD1 appears dust-free but is already enriched. A recent burst of star formation is also revealed by the star formation history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07766v2.title: CEERS: 7.7 $μ$m PAH Star Formation Rate Calibration with JWST MIRI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07766v2.summary: We test the relationship between UV-derived star formation rates (SFRs) and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) luminosities. We utilize multi-band photometry from HST, CFHT, JWST, Spitzer, and Herschel for the Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science (CEERS) Survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08547v2.title: QUIJOTE Scientific Results -- XVII. Studying the Anomalous Microwave Emission in the Andromeda Galaxy with QUIJOTE-MFI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08547v2.summary: The Andromeda Galaxy (M31) is the Local Group galaxy that is most similar to the Milky Way (MW) The similarities between the two galaxies make M31 useful for studying integrated properties common to spiral galaxies. We use the datafrom the recent QUIJOTE-MFI Wide Survey, together with new raster observationsfocused on M31 to study its integrated emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15741v1.title: The proto-galaxy of Milky Way-mass haloes in the FIRE simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15741v1.summary: Proto-Milky Way populations are predominantly centrally concentrated. Large/rich/chemical-kinematic-age samples of metal-poor stars in the inner Galaxy should help characterise the different mass fragments. These data may also help reveal if the Milky Way formed from one or two dominant/lower masssystems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13263v2.title: Evidence for low power radio jet-ISM interaction at 10 parsec in the dwarf AGN host NGC 4395
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.13263v2.summary: Black hole driven outflows in galaxies hosting active galactic nuclei (AGN) may interact with their interstellar medium (ISM) affecting star formation. Here wedemonstrate radio jet-ISM interaction on the scale of an asymmetric tripleradio structure of $10 parsec size in NGC 4395.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.08553v1.title: A giant radio galaxy with three cycles of episodic jet activity from LoTSS DR2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.08553v1.summary: J1225+4011 is only the fourth radio source showing atriple-double radio structure. All four sources have overall sizes greater than 700 kpc, making them giants. Our observations suggest that the power of theirjets may decrease with time. We also present the LoTSS 144 MHz map of the TDRG J0929+4146 and report its updated size.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11205v1.title: The 'spectral index-flux density relation' for extragalactic radio sources selected at metre and decametre wavelengths
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11205v1.summary: We use the recent releases of sensitive VLA/LOFAR large-area surveys at 340MHz and 54 MHz, in conjunction with the 1.4 GHz NVSS, to accurately determine the `spectral index - flux density relation' ($\alpha$ - S) for extragalacticradio sources. The relation shows a progressive flattening of the index towards lower flux densities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10234v2.title: Measuring the giant radio galaxy length distribution with the LoTSS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.10234v2.summary: Radio galaxies are luminous structures created by the jets of supermassive black holes. They consist of atomic nuclei, relativistic electrons, and magneticfields. In exceptional cases, radio galaxies attain megaparsecextents - and thus turn into giants. Giants embody the most extreme knownchanism through which galaxies can impact the Cosmic Web around them.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.02130v2.title: Decoding the giant extragalactic radio sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.02130v2.summary: Giant radio sources (GRSs) defined to be > 0.7 Mpc are the largest single objects in the Universe. These radio-loud active galactic nuclei (RLAGN) interact with the interstellar medium of the host galaxy. This review article summarises our current understanding of these radio sources based on nearly five decades of research.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13059v2.title: Barbell-shaped giant radio galaxy with ~100 kpc kink in the jet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13059v2.summary: We present for the first time a study of peculiar giant radio galaxy (GRG) We measure the overall size of this GRG to be 1.83 Mpc; it exhibits lobes without any prominent hotspots. Despite its enormous size, the Barbell GRG is found to be housed in a low-mass galaxy cluster. We discuss the possible causes leading to the formation of the observed kink feature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.06100v1.title: RAD@home citizen science discovery of an AGN spewing a large unipolar radio bubble onto its merging companion galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.06100v1.summary: AGN feedback during galaxy merger has been the most favoured model to explain black hole-galaxy co-evolution. How the AGN-driven jet/wind/radiation is coupled with the gas of the merging galaxies is poorly understood. Only a few cases are known where the jet and companion galaxy interaction leads to minor distortions in the jets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06284v1.title: Comparison of the Stellar Populations of Bulges and Discs using the MaNGA Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06284v1.summary: We use the MaNGA integral-field survey of low-redshift galaxies to compare the stellar populations of the bulge and disc components. Bulge dominated galaxies tend to be more metal-rich and have slightly older stellar ages than their associated disc dominated regions. The age difference is due to star formation continuing longer in discs relative to bulges. This suggests high-mass galaxies quench from the inside out.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.05307v2.title: The AGEL Survey: Spectroscopic Confirmation of Strong Gravitational Lenses in the DES and DECaLS Fields Selected Using Convolutional Neural Networks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.05307v2.summary: We present spectroscopic confirmation of candidate strong gravitational lenses using the Keck Observatory and Very Large Telescope. We measure 104 redshifts in 77 systems selected from a catalog in the DES and DECaLS imaging fields. The AGEL survey is a resource for refining automated all-sky searches and addressing a range of questions in cosmology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.06939v1.title: The SAMI galaxy survey: galaxy size can explain the offset between star-forming and passive galaxies in the mass-metallicity relationship
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.06939v1.summary: In this work, we investigate how the central stellar metallicity ([Z/H) of galaxies from the SAMI galaxy survey is related to their stellar mass. We then build a simple model of galaxy evolution to explain and understand our results. Our model implies that metal-rich galaxies have always been the smallest objects for their mass in a population. The findings reiterate the need to consider galaxy size when studying stellar populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.04642v1.title: Gliding on ice in search of accurate and cost-effective computational methods for astrochemistry on grains: the puzzling case of the HCN isomerization
