http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.04642v1.summary: The isomerization of hydrogen cyanide to hydrogen isocyanide on icy grain surfaces is investigated by an accurate composite method. Four water molecules are directly involved in a proton relay mechanism, which strongly reduces the activation energy with respect to the directHydrogen transfer occurring in the isolated molecule. Computation of reaction rates by transition state theory shows that on icy surfaces the isomerizing of HNC to HCN could occur easily.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.14728v2.title: Precursors of the RNA-world in space: Detection of ($Z$)-1,2-ethenediol in the interstellar medium, a key intermediate in sugar formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.14728v2.summary: We present the first detection of ($Z$)-1,2-ethenediol, (CHOH)$_2$, in the interstellar medium towards the G+0.693-0.027 molecular cloud located in the Galactic Center. We discuss several viable formation routes through chemical reactions from precursors such as HCO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.01054v2.title: The LEGA-C and SAMI Galaxy Surveys: Quiescent Stellar Populations and the Mass-Size Plane across 6 Gyr
http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.01054v2.summary: We investigate the change in mean stellar population age and metallicity for quiescent galaxies from intermediate redshift to low redshift. We find that galaxies with deeper gravitational potential wells are more metal-rich. This supports the hypothesis that the gravitational potential regulates the retention of worrisomemetals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.04530v1.title: An improved study of HCO+ and He system: interaction potential, collisional relaxation and pressure broadening
http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.04530v1.summary: In light of its ubiquitous presence in the interstellar gas, the chemistry and reactivity of the HCO+ ion requires special attention. We have tested the accuracy of explicitly correlated correlated cluster methods for mapping the short- and long-range multi-dimensional potential energy surface of atom-ion systems. A validation of the methodology employed for the calculation of the potential well has been obtained from experimentally derived bound-state spectroscopic parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2108.08530v1.title: Formation of phosphorus monoxide (PO) in the interstellar medium: insights from quantum-chemical and kinetic calculations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2108.08530v1.summary: phosphorus monoxide (PO) has been detected in star-forming regions and in the 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. In the interstellar medium, PO is systematically the most abundant P-bearing species. The reaction of atomic phosphorus in its gound state with water is not a relevant source of PO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.13567v3.title: The MAGPI Survey -- science goals, design, observing strategy, early results and theoretical framework
http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.13567v3.summary: The IntegralField Spectroscopy (MAGPI) survey is a Large Program on ESO/VLT. MAGPI is designed to study the physical drivers of galaxy transformation at a lookbacktime of 3-4 Gyr. The survey uses new medium-deep adaptive optics aided MUSE observations of fields selected from GAMA.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2101.12224v1.title: The SAMI Galaxy Survey: the third and final data release
http://arxiv.org/abs/2101.12224v1.summary: Data Release 3 (DR3) includes the SAMI cluster sample of 888 unique galaxies for the first time. For each galaxy, there are two primary spectral cubes covering the blue (370-570nm) and red (630-740nm) wavelengths. All data are available online through Australian Astronomical Optics (AAO) DataCentral.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.03736v1.title: The Sami Galaxy Survey: stellar populations of passive spiral galaxies in different environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.03736v1.summary: We investigate the stellar populations of passive spiral galaxies. We use integral field spectroscopy data from the Sydney-AAO Multi-object Integral field spectrograph Galaxy Survey. In the clusters, we find that passive spirals show slightly younger age and lower [$\alpha$/Fe] than the S0s over the whole mass range. The field/group, stellar populations show a similar trend.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2010.11651v1.title: Methanimine as a key precursor of imines in the interstellar medium: the case of propargylimine
http://arxiv.org/abs/2010.11651v1.summary: A gas-phase formation route is proposed for the recently detected PGIM molecule. In analogy to other imines, such as cyanomethanimine, the addition of a reactive radical (C$_2$H in the present case) leads to reaction channels open also in the harsh conditions of thestellar medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2008.00296v1.title: The Role of State-of-the-Art Quantum-Chemical Calculations in Astrochemistry: Formation Route and Spectroscopy of Ethanimine as a Paradigmatic Case
http://arxiv.org/abs/2008.00296v1.summary: The gas-phase formation and spectroscopic characteristics of ethanimine have been re-investigated as a paradigmatic case illustrating the accuracy of state-of-the-art quantum-chemical methodologies. An accurate characterization of the molecular structure, energetics, andspectroscopic properties of the E and Z isomers of ethAnimine combined withmillimeter-wave measurements up to 300 GHz, allows for predicting therotational spectrum of both isomers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.08232v1.title: The quest for a plausible formation route of formyl cyanide in the interstellar medium: a state-of-the-art quantum-chemical and kinetic approach
http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.08232v1.summary: Interstellar complex organic molecules (iCOMs) are assumed to be mainlyformed on dust-grain surfaces. neutral gas-phase reactions in the interstellar medium (ISM) can play an important role. Owing to accurate quantum-chemicalcomputations followed by rate constant evaluations, we have been able to suggest an effective mechanism for the formation of HCOCN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.07657v1.title: A twist on the reaction of the CN radical with methylamine in the interstellar medium: new hints from a state-of-the-art quantum-chemical study
http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.07657v1.summary: The majority of current models assume that interstellarcomplex organic molecules (iCOMs) are formed on dust-grain surfaces. There is some evidence that neutral gas-phase reactions play an important role. The two major products of the CH$_3$NH$_2$ + CN reaction have not been spectroscopically characterized.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.00663v1.title: Inverse stellar population age gradients of post-starburst galaxies at z=0.8 with LEGA-C
http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.00663v1.summary: We use deep, spatially resolved spectroscopy from the LEGA-C Survey to study the stellar population of 17 spectroscopically-selected post-starburst (PSB) galaxies. We find that, on average, PSB galaxies have radially decreasing $H{\delta}_A$ and increasing $Fe4383$ profiles. In contrast, a control sample of quiescent, non-PSB galaxies in the same mass range shows outwardly increasing $Horka_A $ and decreasing $Fe 4383$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.00720v1.title: Gravitational Potential and Surface Density Drive Stellar Populations -- II. Star-Forming Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.00720v1.summary: Stellar population parameters correlate with a range of galaxy properties, but it is unclear which relations are causal and which are the result of another underlying trend. In Barone et. al. (2018) we found that for early-type galaxies the age-$\Sigma$ and [Z/H]-$\Phi$ relations show the least intrinsic scatter with galaxy size.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2005.12867v1.title: A Systematic Study on the Absorption Features of Interstellar Ices in Presence of Impurities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2005.12867v1.summary: Spectroscopic studies play a key role in the identification and analysis of interstellar ices and their structure. Absorption band features of water ice can significantly change with the presence of different types of impurities. HCOOH was found to have a strong influence on the libration, bending, bulk stretching, and free-OH stretching modes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14990v1.title: Massive Black Hole Binaries as LISA Precursors in the Roman High Latitude Time Domain Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14990v1.summary: Roman is poised to reveal a population of massive black holes during an epoch of vigorous galaxy assembly. By measuring the light curves of a subset of these AGN, Roman can identify several hundred massive black hole binaries with 5-12 day orbital periods. During the last few months of their merger, such binaries are observable with the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07193v1.title: The Complex X-ray Obscuration Environment in the Radio Loud Type 2 Quasar 3C 223
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07193v1.summary: 3C 223 is a radio loud, Type 2 quasar at $z=0.1365$ with an intriguing XMM-Newton spectrum that implicated it as a rare, Compton-thick active galactic nucleus (AGN) The obscuring gas is patchy with both high and low levels of obscuration and clouds with column densities up to an order of magnitude lower.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01694v1.title: Spectroscopic follow-up of a sub-set of the Gaia/IPHAS catalogue of Hα-excess sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01694v1.summary: State-of-the-art techniques to identify H\alpha emission line sources in narrow-band photometric surveys are based on position-based selection. We recently developed a technique to find outliers relative to nearby objects in the colour-magnitude diagram. We built an updatedalogue of H\ alpha-excess candidates in the northern Galactic Plane. 15 of 70 confirmed emitters in our sample were only identified by the CMD-based technique.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.04499v1.title: Rubin Observatory LSST Transients and Variable Stars Roadmap
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.04499v1.summary: The Vera C. Rubin Legacy Survey of Space and Time holds the potential to revolutionaryize time domain astrophysics. The Transient and Variable Stars Science Collaboration, one of the four pillars of Rubin LSSTscience, has identified research areas of interest and requirements. While our roadmap is ever-evolving, this document represents a snapshot of our plans and preparatory work in the final years and months leading up to the survey's first light.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.01627v1.title: XMM-Newton and NuSTAR Observations of an Optically Quiescent Quasar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.01627v1.summary: Optically quiescent quasars (OQQs) represent a recently systematised class of active galactic nuclei. They may represent an interesting, brief phase in the AGN life cycle. Here, we present the first simultaneous X-ray observations of an OQQ, SDSS J075139.06+.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.13140v1.title: Termination Shocks and the Extended X-ray Emission in MRK 78
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.13140v1.summary: Sub-arcsecond imaging of the X-ray emission in the type 2 AGN Mrk 78 with                Chandra shows complex structure with spectral variations on scales from $200 pc to $2 kpc. The Eastern X-rays are mostly in a compact knot, while the Western ones form a loop or shell from the nucleus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.04522v2.title: High-density disc reflection spectroscopy of low-mass active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.04522v2.summary: The standard alpha-disc model predicts an anti-correlation between the inner accretion disc and the black hole mass times square of the accretion rate. We utilize a new high-density reflection model where the density parameter varies from $10^{20}$ cm$^{-3}$ and apply it to the broadband X-ray spectra of the low-mass AGN sample. The results suggest a radiation pressure-dominated disc with an average of 70% of the disc power transferred to the corona.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.10477v1.title: Exploring metallicity-dependent rates of Type Ia supernovae and their impact on galaxy formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.10477v1.summary: Type Ia supernovae play a critical role in stellar feedback and elementalenrichment in galaxies. Recent surveys like the All-Sky Automated AutomatedSurvey for Supernova (ASAS-SN) and the Dark Energy Survey (DES) find that the specific Ia rate at z ~ 0 may be 15-50 times higher in lower-mass galaxies than at Milky Way-mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.13839v2.title: The NuSTAR Extragalactic Survey of the James Webb Space Telescope North Ecliptic Pole Time-Domain Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.13839v2.summary: We present the $NuSTAR$ extragalactic survey of the $James$ $Webb$ $Space$                $Telescope$ ($JWST$) North Ecliptic Pole (NEP) Time-Domain Field. A total of 33 sources were detected above 95% reliability in at least one of the five bands. We present the X-rayproperties (hardness ratio and luminosity) of detected sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2108.13386v2.title: Multi-wavelength Optical and NIR Variability Analysis of the Blazar PKS 0027-426
http://arxiv.org/abs/2108.13386v2.summary: We present multi-wavelength spectral and temporal variability analysis of PKS.0027-426 using optical griz observations from DES (Dark Energy Survey) and VOILETTE. The colour-magnitude relation between each combination of filters was also studied to determine the spectral behaviour.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.06294v2.title: Resolving local and global kinematic signatures of satellite mergers with billion particle simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.06294v2.summary: The new model shows the formation and evolution of structures that have been observed in small, local volumes in the Milky Way. The local $z-v_z$ phase spirals are clearly linked to the global asymmetry across the disc. We find both 2-armed and 1-armed phasespirals, which are related to breathing and bending behaviors respectively.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.00572v1.title: Compton-Thick AGN in the NuSTAR era VII. A joint NuSTAR, Chandra and XMM-Newton analysis of two nearby, heavily obscured sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.00572v1.summary: We present the joint Chandra, XMM-Newton and NuSTAR analysis of two nearby Seymourfert galaxies. NGC 3081 and ESO 565-G019 are the only two having                Chandra data in a larger sample of ten low redshift galaxies. The use of physically-motivated models, combined with the broad energy range covered by the data, allows us to constrain the obscuring material.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.03562v1.title: Snails Across Scales: Local and Global Phase-Mixing Structures as Probes of the Past and Future Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.03562v1.summary: Signatures of vertical disequilibrium have been observed across the Milky Way's disk. These signatures manifest locally as unmixed phase-spirals and globally as nonzero mean $z$ and $v_z$ which wraps around as a physical spiral across the $x$--$y$ plane. We explore the connection through the example of a satellite perturbing a test-particle Milky Way(MW)-like disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.00244v2.title: The Galaxy Activity, Torus and Outflow Survey (GATOS): II. Torus and polar dust emission in nearby Seyfert galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2107.00244v2.summary: We compare mid-IR and ALMA far-IR images of 12 nearby Seyferts. Mid-IR unresolved emission contributes more than 60% of the nuclearEmission in most galaxies. In a few galaxies, the nuclear NH might be too high to uplift large quantities of dusty material along the polar direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2104.10227v2.title: The Galaxy Activity, Torus and Outflow Survey (GATOS) I. ALMA images of dusty molecular tori in Seyfert galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2104.10227v2.summary: The Galaxy Activity, Torus and Outflow Survey is a project aimed at understanding the properties of the dusty molecular tori in nearby Seyfert galaxies. We used ALMA to obtain new images of the emission of molecular gas and dust using the CO(3-2)and HCO(4-3) lines as well as their underlying continuum emission at 870microns.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2105.00749v2.title: Population-based identification of Hα-excess sources in the Gaia DR2 and IPHAS catalogues
http://arxiv.org/abs/2105.00749v2.summary: We present a catalogue of point-like H{\alpha}-excess sources in the Northern                Galactic Plane. Our catalogue is created using a new technique that leveragesastrometric and photomeric information from Gaia. By analysing their intensity in the H{alpha} narrow band, 28,496 objects out of 7,474,835 are identified.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.01310v2.title: The Size and Pervasiveness of Ly$α$-UV Spatial Offsets in Star-Forming Galaxies at $z\sim6$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.01310v2.summary: 40% of galaxies in our sample show significant projected spatial offsets. In our own sample, UV-bright galaxies showed offsets a factor of three greater than their fainter counterparts. We argue that offsets are likely not the result of merging processes, but are rather due to internal anisotropic processes resulting fromstellar feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.12154v1.title: A candidate Optically Quiescent Quasar lacking narrow emission lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.12154v1.summary: Many Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) surveys rely on optical emission line signatures for robust source classification. There are examples of AGN candidates lacking such signatures, including those from the narrow line region. Here, we seek to formalise this subpopulation with a prototypical candidate, SDSS J075139.06+.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.07482v1.title: Resolving the Hot Dust Disk of ESO323-G77
http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.07482v1.summary: Infrared interferometry has fuelled a paradigm shift in our understanding of the dusty structure in the central parsecs of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) The dust is now thought to comprise of a hot ($\sim1000\,$K) equatorial disk, some of which is blown into a cooler ($Â£££) polar dusty wind by radiationpressure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.05666v1.title: The 450 days X-ray monitoring of the changing-look AGN 1ES 1927+654
http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.05666v1.summary: 1ES 1927+654 is a nearby active galactic nucleus (AGN) which underwent achanging-look event in early 2018, developing prominent broad Balmer lines. The source is extremely variable both in spectral shape and flux, and does not show any correlation between X-ray and UV flux on timescales of hours or weeks.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.04620v1.title: How does the Polar Dust affect the Correlation between Dust Covering Factor and Eddington Ratio in Type 1 Quasars Selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 16?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2102.04620v1.summary: We revisit the dependence of covering factor (CF) of dust torus on physicalproperties of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) We select 37,181 type 1 quasars at $z < 0.7$ from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 16 quasar catalog. We find that incorporating the AGN polar dust emission makes those anti-correlations stronger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.08857v2.title: RELICS-DP7: Spectroscopic Confirmation of a Dichromatic Primeval Galaxy at z ~ 7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.08857v2.summary: We report the discovery of a spectroscopically-confirmed strongLyman-$\alpha$ emitter at $z=7.0281\pm0.0003$, observed as part of the Reionization Cluster Lensing Survey (RELICS) This galaxy, dubbed "Dichromatic Primeval Galaxy" (DP7), shows two distinct components. DP7 represents the typical galaxies that are thought to major contribution to the reionization of the Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.07277v1.title: Astrometric excess noise in Gaia DR2 and the search for X-ray emitting binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2009.07277v1.summary: Astrometric noise in excess of parallax and proper motion could be a signature of orbital wobble of individual components in binary star systems. Cross-matching our sample with the Chandra Source Catalogue CSC2.0returns a primary sample of ~1,500 X-ray sources with significant excess noise.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.07275v1.title: The destruction and recreation of the X-ray corona in a changing-look Active Galactic Nucleus
http://arxiv.org/abs/2007.07275v1.summary: We present the drastic transformation of the X-ray properties of the activegalactic nucleus 1ES 1927+654, following a changing-look event. After theoptical/UV outburst the power-law component, produced in theX-ray corona, disappeared, and the spectrum became dominated by a blackbody component. We speculate that our observations could be explained by the interaction between the accretion flow and debris from a tidally disrupted star.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1908.00810v2.title: Kinematic study of the association Cyg OB3 with Gaia DR2
http://arxiv.org/abs/1908.00810v2.summary: Study of stellar kinematic properties and spatial distribution of Cyg OB3 using precise astrometric data from Gaia DR2. Majority of stars are found to be concentrated at a heliocentric distance of 2.0 +/- 0.3 kpc. Results suggest a slowly expanding nature of the association.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.00871v2.title: Orbital period dependent spatial scatter of Galactic Black Hole Transients
http://arxiv.org/abs/2002.00871v2.summary: There remain significant uncertainties in the origin and evolution of black holes in binary systems. The debate has been reinvigorated in the era of gravitational wave detections. Using recent and archival characterisation of Galactic black hole X-ray binaries (BHXBs), we report here an apparent anticorrelation between P{orb} (system orbital periods) and scatter above the Galactic plane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.05959v1.title: Local AGN Survey (LASr): I. Galaxy sample, infrared colour selection and predictions for AGN within 100 Mpc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.05959v1.summary: The Local AGN Survey is four times deeper than the current local galaxy reference, the Two Micron All-Sky Survey RedshiftSurvey (2MRS), which turns out to miss 20% of known luminous AGN. It contains 4.3k already known AGN, and includes 61 new AGN candidates. One third of the AGN within 100 Mpc remain to be identified.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2001.05499v1.title: Probing the circumnuclear absorbing medium of the buried AGN in NGC 1068 through NuSTAR observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2001.05499v1.summary: We present the results of the latest NuSTAR monitoring campaign of the Compton-thick Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 1068. We detect one unveiling and one eclipsing event with timescales less than 27 and 91 days, respectively. We also detected a new flared ULX, at a distance $d\sim$30" (i.e. $d$2 kpc) from the nuclearregion of NGC1068.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1911.05813v1.title: NuSTAR Uncovers an Extremely Local Compton-thick AGN in NGC 4968
http://arxiv.org/abs/1911.05813v1.summary: We present the analysis of Chandra and NuSTAR spectra of NGC 4968. The galaxy is enshrouded within Compton-thick layers of obscuring gas. The line-of-sight column density, from intervening matter between the source and observer that intercepts the intrinsic AGN X-rayemission, is well within the Compton-Thick regime.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1910.00600v1.title: Parsec-scale Dusty Winds in Active Galactic Nuclei: Evidence for Radiation Pressure Driving
http://arxiv.org/abs/1910.00600v1.summary: Infrared interferometry of local AGN has revealed a warm (~300K-400K) polaristicallydust structure. This led to the development of the disk+wind scenario. This scenario consists of a hot (~1000K) compact equatorial dust disk and a polar dust wind.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.08760v1.title: New active galactic nuclei science cases with interferometry: An incomplete preview
http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.08760v1.summary: Infrared (IR) interferometry has made widely recognised contributions to the way we look at the dusty environment of supermassive black holes on parsecscales. New scientific opportunities for AGN have been suggested, and will soon be carried out, focusing on the dynamical aspects of interferometers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04693v1.title: Nine-hour X-ray quasi-periodic eruptions from a low-mass black hole galactic nucleus
http://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04693v1.summary: X-ray emission from the Seyfert 2 galaxy GSN069 (2MASX J01190869-3411305) at redshift z = 0.018 was first detected in 2010. During these eruptions, the X-ray count rate increases by up to two orders of magnitude with event duration of just over 1 hour and recurrence time of about 9 hours.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.09105v3.title: Quantifying Feedback from Narrow Line Region Outflows in Nearby Active Galaxies. II. Spatially Resolved Mass Outflow Rates for the QSO2 Markarian 34
http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.09105v3.summary: Spectra obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope and at ApachePoint Observatory reveal complex kinematics. The mix of rotational and outflowing components suggests that spatially resolved observations are required to determine accurate outflow parameters. The outflows are more energetic than those observed in Mrk 573 and NGC 4151.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1906.06889v1.title: A nuclear molecular outflow in the Seyfert galaxy NGC3227
http://arxiv.org/abs/1906.06889v1.summary: We present ALMA observations of the CO(2-1) and CO(3-2) molecular gastransitions and associated (sub)-mm continua of the nearby Seyfert 1.5 galaxy. The molecular gas in the central region (1" ~73pc) shows several CO clumps with complex kinematics which appears to be dominated by non-circular motions. While we cannot demonstrate conclusively the presence of a warped nuclear disk, we also detected non- Circular motions along the kinematic minor axis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11439v1.title: Resolving the cosmic X-ray background with a next-generation high-energy X-ray observatory
http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11439v1.summary: The cosmic X-ray background (CXB), which peaks at an energy of ~30 keV, is produced primarily by emission from accreting supermassive black holes (SMBHs) This paper gives an overview of recent progress in the synthesis of the CXB and the accretion physics and obscuration in active galactic nuclei (AGNs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.11091v1.title: Cosmic evolution of supermassive black holes: A view into the next two decades
http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.11091v1.summary: The discoveries made over the past 20 years by Chandra and XMM-Newton surveys have significantly changed the view of the supermassive blackhole (SMBH) and galaxy connection. As newobservatories peer into the early Universe, we will begin to understand the physics and demographics of SMBH infancy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.04030v1.title: High- and Low-$α$ Disk Stars Separate Dynamically at all Ages
http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.04030v1.summary: There is a dichotomy in the Milky Way in the $[\alpha/$Fe]-[Fe/H] plane. The origin of this dichotomy is uncertain. We examine if the high- and low-$\alpha$ sequences have distinctorbits at all ages, or if age sets the orbital properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.12433v1.title: The Plane's The Thing: The Case for Wide-Fast-Deep Coverage of the Galactic Plane and Bulge
http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.12433v1.summary: We argue that the exclusion of the Galactic Plane and Bulge from the uniformwide-fast-deep (WFD) LSST survey cadence is fundamentally inconsistent with two of the main science drivers of LSST. We outline the philosophical basis for this claim and describe a number of important science goals that can only be addressed by WFD-like coverage.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.11372v1.title: WISE view of Narrow-Line Seyfert 1 galaxies: mid-infrared color and variability
http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.11372v1.summary: The mean W1 - W2 color of candidate variable NLSy1 galaxies is $0.99 \pm 0.18$ mag. The long-term amplitude of variance shows weak anti-correlation with the Fe II strength, continuum                luminosity and Eddington ratio. A positive correlation between color as well as the amplitude of variability with the radio power at 1.4 GHz was found for the radio-detected galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.02585v1.title: NuSTAR and Keck Observations of Heavily Obscured Quasars Selected by WISE
http://arxiv.org/abs/1811.02585v1.summary: NuSTAR mission is to find and characterize heavily obscured Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs) Three of the four obscured objects are undetected, while the fourth has a marginal detection. The objects have observed hard X-ray (10-40 keV) luminosities at or below 10^43 erg s^-1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.07906v1.title: A study of X-ray emission of galaxies hosting molecular outflows (MOX sample)
http://arxiv.org/abs/1809.07906v1.summary: We have carried out an extensive X-ray spectral analysis of a sample ofgalaxies exhibiting molecular outflows (MOX sample) We find that the central AGN plays an important role in driving these massive outflows. We conclude that both starbursts and AGN play crucialRole in driving the large scale MO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.01863v2.title: New evidence for the dusty wind model: Polar dust and a hot core in the type-1 Seyfert ESO$\,$323-G77
http://arxiv.org/abs/1806.01863v2.summary: Infrared interferometry of Seyfert galaxies has revealed that their dust emission originates primarily from polar regions instead of an equatorial dust torus as predicted by the classic AGN unificationscheme. We interpret this as further evidence that a polar dust component is required even for low-inclination type 1.1 sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.04842v2.title: Resolving the nuclear obscuring disk in the Compton-thick Seyfert galaxy NGC5643 with ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.04842v2.summary: We present ALMA Band 6 $^{12}$CO(2--1) line and rest-frame 232GHz continuum observations of the nearby Compton-thick Seyfert galaxy NGC5643. The CO(2 --1) integrated line map reveals emission from the nuclear and circumnuclear region with a two-arm nuclearspiral extending 10arcsec on each side. There are strong non-circular motions in the central 0.2-0.3 arcsec with velocities of up to 110km/s. In the absence of a nuclear bar, these motions could

http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.01100v2.title: An Iwasawa-Taniguchi Effect for Compton-thick Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.01100v2.summary: We present the first study of an Iwasawa-Taniguchi/X-ray Baldwin effect for Compton-thick active galactic nuclei (AGN) We report a statisticallysignificant anti-correlation between the rest-frame equivalent width (EW) of the narrow core of the neutral Fe K$\alpha$ fluorescence emission line and the continuum luminosity. We discuss the implications this could have if confirmed on larger samples.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.07018v1.title: Determination of the size of the dust torus in H0507+164 through optical and infrared monitoring
http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.07018v1.summary: The time delay between flux variations in different wavelength bands can be used to probe the inner regions of active galactic nuclei (AGN) The measured lags.indicate that the inner edge of dust torus is located at a distance of 0.029 pc from the central UV/optical AGN continuum. This is larger than the radius of the broad line region of this object determined from spectroscopic monitoring.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04938v1.title: New Spectral Model for Constraining Torus Covering Factors from Broadband X-ray Spectra of Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.04938v1.summary: The basic unified model of active galactic nuclei (AGN) invokes a torus to explain AGNobscuration as an angle-dependent effect. We present a new grid of X-rayspectral templates based on radiative transfer calculations in neutral gas in approximately toroidal geometry. The templates are appropriate for CCD-resolution X-rays (FWHM > 130 eV)

http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01881v1.title: The NuSTAR Extragalactic Surveys: source catalog and the Compton-thick fraction in the UDS field
http://arxiv.org/abs/1801.01881v1.summary: We present the results and the source catalog of the NuSTAR survey in the UKIDSS Ultra Deep Survey (UDS) field. The survey covers a $3-24$ keV area of the field for a total observing time of 1.75 Ms. A total of 67 sources are detected in at least one of the three bands, 56 of which have a robust optical redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03989v4.title: BAT AGN Spectroscopic Survey - V. X-ray properties of the Swift/BAT 70-month AGN catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03989v4.summary: Hard X-ray observations of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) can shed light on some of the most obscured episodes of accretion onto supermassive black holes. The 70-month Swift/BAT all-sky survey, which probes the 14-195 keV range, has currently detected 838 AGN. We report here on the broad-band (0.3-150 keV) characteristics of these AGN, obtained by combining observations in the soft X-rays.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.06270v2.title: Joint NuSTAR and Chandra analysis of the obscured quasar in IC 2497 - Hanny's Voorwerp system
http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.06270v2.summary: New Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array (NuSTAR) observations of IC 2497, the galaxy associated with Hanny's Voorwerp. Chandra (0.5-8 keV) and NuSTAR X-ray spectra, together with WISE mid-IR photometry, optical longslit spectroscopy and optical narrow-band imaging, suggest the galaxy hosts a Compton-thick AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.01268v1.title: Embedded AGN and star formation in the central 80 pc of IC 3639
http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.01268v1.summary: We use interferometric observations in the $N$-band with VLTI/MIDI to resolve the mid-IR nucleus of IC 3639. A composite scenario where the star formation component dominatesover the AGN is favoured by the diagnostics based on ratios of IRfine-structure emission lines, the shape of the IR continuum, and the PAH and silicate bands.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.03233v1.title: Investigating the evolution of the dual AGN system ESO~509-IG066
http://arxiv.org/abs/1710.03233v1.summary: We analyze the evolution of the dual AGN in ESO 509-IG066, a galaxy pair with nuclei separated by 11 kpc. One source has dropped in flux by a factor of 10 between 2004 and 2011. This could be explained by either an increase in the absorbingColumn or an intrinsic fading of the central engine. Both of these scenarios are predicted by galaxy merger simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.00429v2.title: Determining the torus covering factors for a sample of type 1 AGN in the local Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.00429v2.summary: In the unified scheme of active galactic nuclei, a dusty torus absorbs and then reprocesses a fraction of the intrinsic luminosity which is emitted at longer wavelengths. The amount of sky covered by the torus as seen from the central source (known as the covering factor $f_c$) can be estimated from the ratio of the infrared to the bolometric luminosities of the source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.06651v2.title: The NuSTAR Serendipitous Survey: Hunting for The Most Extreme Obscured AGN at >10 keV
http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.06651v2.summary: NuSTAR serendipitous survey, to search for the most highly obscured AGNs detected at >10 keV. We identify sources with extremely hard X-ray spectra (i.e., with photon metrics of Gamma<0.6 in the 13 sq. deg. NuSTAR survey. Eight extreme NuSTARsources are identified, and we use the NuSTAR data in combination with lower-energy X-rays.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.05416v1.title: OISTER Optical and Near-Infrared Monitoring Observations of a Peculiar Radio-Loud Active Galactic Nucleus SDSS J110006.07+442144.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.05416v1.summary: A radio-loud active galactic nucleus (AGN) at z=0.840,                SDSS~J110006.07+442144.3 (hereafter, J1100+4421) was identified during a flare-up in late February, 2014. The steepoptical-NIR spectral shape and the large amplitude of variability are consistent with this object being a low jet-dominated AGN. The optical spectrum of a possible faint companion galaxy does not show any emission lines at the same redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.00054v2.title: Search for Thermal X-ray Features from the Crab nebula with Hitomi Soft X-ray Spectrometer
http://arxiv.org/abs/1707.00054v2.summary: The Crab nebula originated from a core-collapse supernova (SN) explosion in 1054 A.D. When viewed as a supernova remnant (SNR), it has anomalously low observed ejecta mass and kinetic energy. Intensive searches were made for a massive shell that solves this discrepancy, but none has been detected.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.04811v1.title: PAH features within few hundred parsecs of active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.04811v1.summary: Spectral features from PAH molecules observed in the mid-IR range are typically used to infer the amount of recent and ongoing star formation. This assumes that the observed PAH features are excited predominantly by SF. With current ground-based telescopes and the upcoming JWST, much smaller spatial scales can now be probed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.10804v1.title: X-ray bolometric corrections for Compton-thick active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/1705.10804v1.summary: We present X-ray bolometric correction factors for Compton-thick (CT) active galactic nuclei (AGN) with the aim of testing AGN torus models, probing orientation effects, and estimating the bolometric output of the most obscured AGN. We adopt bolometric luminosities from literature infrared (IR) torus modeling and compile published 2--10 keV X-rays. We find that our derived $L_X$values are consistent with previously established relationships between $Bol$ and $N_H.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1607.07420v2.title: Hitomi constraints on the 3.5 keV line in the Perseus galaxy cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/1607.07420v2.summary: High-resolution X-ray spectroscopy with Hitomi was expected to resolve the origin of the faint unidentified E=3.5 keV emission line reported in several massive systems. We find no unidentified line at the reported high flux level. We do not find anomalously high fluxes of the nearby faint K line or the Ar satellite line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1701.08768v2.title: Hard X-ray selected AGNs in low-mass galaxies from the NuSTAR serendipitous survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/1701.08768v2.summary: We present a sample of 10 low-mass active galactic nuclei (AGNs) selected from the 40-month NuSTAR serendipitous survey. The sample is selected to have robust NuSTAR detections at $3 - 24$~keV, to be at $z < 0.3$ and to have optical r-band magnitudes at least 0.5~mag fainter than an $L_\star$ galaxy at its redshift. Five objects have detectable broad H$\alpha$ emission in their optical spectra, indicating black-hole masses of $1.1

http://arxiv.org/abs/1612.06389v1.title: The NuSTAR Serendipitous Survey: The 40 month Catalog and the Properties of the Distant High Energy X-ray Source Population
http://arxiv.org/abs/1612.06389v1.summary: We present the first full catalog and science results for the NuSTAR survey. The catalog incorporates data taken during the first 40 months of NuSTAR operation. The sample isprimarily comprised of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) detected over a large                range in redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1612.01996v1.title: Chandra Reveals Heavy Obscuration and Circumnuclear Star Formation in Seyfert 2 Galaxy NGC 4968
http://arxiv.org/abs/1612.01996v1.summary: We present the Chandra imaging and spectral analysis of NGC 4968, a nearby Seyfert 2 galaxy. We discover extended X-ray emissionin the soft band (0.5 - 2 keV) that is neither coincident with the narrow line region nor the extended radio emission. Based on spectral modeling, it is linked to on-going star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.04808v2.title: NuSTAR observations of WISE J1036+0449, a Galaxy at z$\sim1$ obscured by hot dust
http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.04808v2.summary: Hot, Dust-Obscured Galaxies (Hot DOGs) host some of the most powerful Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) known. They might represent an important stage in the evolution of galaxies. WISE J1036+0449 is the first Hot DOG detected by NuSTAR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.08997v1.title: IC 3639 - A new bona fide Compton thick AGN unveiled by NuSTAR
http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.08997v1.summary: We analyse high-quality NuSTAR observations of the local (z = 0.011) Seyfert2 active galactic nucleus (AGN) IC 3639. This provides the first broadband X-ray spectral analysis of the source, spanning nearly two decades in energy (0.5-30 keV) We find the source to be heavily Compton-thick (CTK) with anobscuring column in excess of $3.6\times10^{24}$ cm$^{-2}$, unconstrained at the upper end.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.08517v1.title: Flares, wind and nebulae: the 2015 December mini-outburst of V404 Cygni
http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.08517v1.summary: After more than 26 years in quiescence, the black hole transient V404 Cyg went into a luminous outburst in June 2015. Additional activity was detected in late December of the same year. Here, we present an opticalspectroscopic follow-up of the December mini-outburst, together with X-ray,optical and radio monitoring.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.03529v1.title: Tracing the origin of the AGN fuelling reservoir in MCG--6-30-15
http://arxiv.org/abs/1610.03529v1.summary: The active galaxy MCG--6-30-15 has a 400 pc diameter stellar kinematically distinct core, counter-rotating with respect to the main body of the galaxy. Ionised gas outflows of v ~ 100 km/s are traced by the [Ca VIII] 2.32 {\mu}mcoronal line and extend out to at least a radius of r ~ 140 pc. The molecular gas traces the available gas reservoir for AGN fuelling and is detected as close as r ~ 50 - 100 pc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.09091v1.title: Cosmology with AGN dust time lags -- Simulating the new VEILS survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.09091v1.summary: Time lag between optical and near-infrared continuum emission in activegalactic nuclei shows a tight correlation with luminosity. We explore the use of these AGN hot-dust time lags for cosmological model fitting under constraints of the new VISTA Extragalactic Infrared Legacy Survey VEILS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1606.07818v2.title: Chandra X-ray observations of the hyper-luminous infrared galaxy IRAS F15307+3252
http://arxiv.org/abs/1606.07818v2.summary: Hyper-luminous infrared galaxies (HyLIRGs) lie at the extreme luminosity end of the IR galaxy population. They are thought to be closer counterparts of the more distant sub-mm galaxies. We present deep $Chandra$ observations of IRAS~F15307+3252.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1607.04487v1.title: The Quiescent Intracluster Medium in the Core of the Perseus Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/1607.04487v1.summary: X-rays from the core of the Perseus cluster are emitted by the 50 million K diffuse hot plasma. The Active Galactic Nucleus of the central galaxy NGC1275 is pumping jetted energy into the surrounding surrounding medium. These likely induce motions in the intracluster medium and heat the inner gas preventing runaway radiative cooling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1606.09265v1.title: A growth-rate indicator for Compton-thick active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/1606.09265v1.summary: X-rays undergo reprocessing by Compton scattering and photoelectric absorption when the line-of-sight to the central engine is heavily obscured. A correlation between the Eddington ratio and the X-ray power-law index, {\Gamma, offers an estimate of their growth rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1604.07825v1.title: A New Population of Compton-Thick AGN Identified Using the Spectral Curvature Above 10 keV
http://arxiv.org/abs/1604.07825v1.summary: We present a new metric that uses the spectral curvature (SC) above 10 keV to identify Compton-thick AGN in low-quality Swift BAT X-ray data. We find the SC_bat and SC_nustar measurements are consistent, suggesting this technique can be applied to futuretelescopes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.04852v2.title: Compton-thick Accretion in the local Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.04852v2.summary: Heavily obscured accretion is believed to represent an important stage in the growth of supermassive black holes. Hard X-ray selected samples are less affected by absorption than samples selected at lower energies. We find a significant decrease in the fraction of obscured Compton-thin AGN for increasing luminosity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.02710v1.title: The subarcsecond mid-infrared view of local active galactic nuclei: III. Polar dust emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.02710v1.summary: Bulk of infrared emission originates from the polar region above the putative torus. Out of 149 Seyferts in the MIR atlas of local AGN, 21 show extended MIR emission on single dish images. The James-Webb Space Telescope will enable much deeper MIR studies with comparable angular resolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.03185v1.title: NuSTAR observations of water megamaser AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.03185v1.summary: Study the connection between the masing disk and obscuring torus in Seymourfert 2 galaxies. Most of the sources analyzed are heavily obscured, showing a column-thickness in excess of $79/cm. In this picture, the maser disk is intimately connected to the inner part of the torus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.01524v1.title: Galaxy Infall by Interacting with its Environment: a Comprehensive Study of 340 Galaxy Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.01524v1.summary: We studied the evolution on the angular extents of the galaxy, ICM, and dark matter components in galaxy clusters. When normalizing the radial profile of galaxy number to that of the ICM mass, the relative curve was found to depend significantly on the cluster redshift. The galaxy-to-total mass profile varies in an opposite way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.00702v1.title: IC 751: a new changing-look AGN discovered by NuSTAR
http://arxiv.org/abs/1602.00702v1.summary: We present the results of five NuSTAR observations of the type 2 activegalactic nucleus (AGN) in IC 751. Three of the observations were performed simultaneously with XMM-Newton or Swift/XRT. We find evidence of significant intrinsic X-rayvariability, with the flux varying by a factor of five.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.02021v1.title: The optical-UV emissivity of quasars: dependence on black hole mass and radio loudness
http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.02021v1.summary: We analyzed a large sample of radio-loud and radio-quiet quasar spectra at redshift 1.0 < z < 1.2 to compare the inferred underlying quasar continuum slopes. The latter predict redder alpha_3000 continuum slopes with increasing black hole mass. We find no evidence for these predictions in the data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.00215v1.title: The Origin of UV-optical Variability in AGN and Test of Disc Models: XMM-Newton and ground based observations of NGC4395
http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.00215v1.summary: The origin of short timescale variability of AGN has been a puzzle for many years. XMM-Newton EPIC observations of NGC5548 with Swift have shown that the UV/optical variations lag behind the X-ray variations. The implied size of the accretion disc is 3x greater than expected from a standard thin disc model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1511.00431v2.title: A New Sample of Obscured AGNs Selected from the XMM-Newton and AKARI Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/1511.00431v2.summary: We report a new sample of obscured active galactic nuclei (AGNs) selected from the XMM serendipitous source and AKARI point-source catalogs. We match X-ray sources with infrared (18 and 90 micron) sources located at |b|>10 deg to create a sample of 173 objects. Of the 26 objects, 4are optically classified as an HII nucleus and are new "elusive AGNs" in which star formation activity likely overwhelms AGN emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1510.04453v1.title: A NuSTAR Survey of Nearby Ultraluminous Infrared Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/1510.04453v1.summary: We present a NuSTAR, Chandra, and XMM--Newton survey of nine of the nearestultraluminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) The unprecedented sensitivity of NuSTAR at energies above 10 keV enables spectral modeling with far better precision than was previously possible. We identify IRAS 08572+3915 as another candidate intrinsically X-ray weak source, similar to Mrk 231.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.02661v3.title: The dust sublimation radius as an outer envelope to the bulk of the narrow Fe Kalpha line emission in Type 1 AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.02661v3.summary: Fe Kalpha emission line is the most ubiquitous feature in the X-rayspectra of active galactic nuclei (AGN) The origin of its narrow core                remains uncertain. Here, we investigate the connection between the sizes of the Fe core emission regions and the measured sizes. of the dusty tori in 13 local                Type 1 AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.05065v1.title: The subarcsecond mid-infrared view of local active galactic nuclei: II. The mid-infrared--X-ray correlation
http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.05065v1.summary: MIR--X-ray correlation is nearly linear and within a factor of two independent of the AGN type and the wavebands used. Radio-loud objects show a higher mean MIR-- X-ray ratio at low luminosities, while the ratio is lower than average at high Luminosities. True Seyfert 2 candidates and double AGN do not show any deviation from the general behaviour.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.05120v1.title: NuSTAR Reveals Extreme Absorption in z < 0.5 Type 2 Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.05120v1.summary: The intrinsic column density (NH) distribution of quasars is poorly known. At the high obscuration end of the quasar population and for redshifts z<1, the X-ray spectra can only be characterized using broad-band measurements above 10 keV. Five new NuSTAR observations arereported herein, and four have been previously published. The candidate CTQSO2s have observed [OIII] luminosities in the range 8.4 < 9.6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1505.03524v1.title: Broadband Observations of the Compton-thick Nucleus of NGC 3393
http://arxiv.org/abs/1505.03524v1.summary: NuSTAR and Chandra observations of NGC 3393, a galaxy reported to host the smallest separation dual AGN resolved in the X-rays. Three times deeper Chandraimaging, combined with adaptive optics and radio imaging, suggest a single, heavily obscured, radio-bright AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1410.0791v1.title: Resolving the Clumpy Structure of the Outflow Winds in the Gravitationally Lensed Quasar SDSS J1029+2623
http://arxiv.org/abs/1410.0791v1.summary: Using Subaru/HDS, we performed high-resolution spectroscopic observations of images A and B of the SDSS J1029+2623 quasar. We confirm that the difference inabsorption profiles in the images A. and B discovered by Misawa et. al. (2013) remains unchanged since 2010.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.1309v1.title: Discovery of Dramatic Optical Variability in SDSS J1100+4421: A Peculiar Radio-Loud Narrow-Line Seyfert 1 Galaxy?
http://arxiv.org/abs/1409.1309v1.summary: Spectroscopic observations suggest that this object is likely a narrow-line Seyfert 1 galaxy. The estimated black hole mass of 10^7 Msun implies a nuclear luminosity close to the Eddington limit. The 1.4 GHz radio image of the source shows an extended structure with a linear size of about 100 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5414v1.title: The NuSTAR View of Nearby Compton-thick AGN: The Cases of NGC 424, NGC 1320 and IC 2560
http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5414v1.summary: X-ray spectral analyses for three Seyfert 2 active galacticnuclei. NGC 424, NGC 1320, and IC 2560 were observed by NuSTAR in the 3-79 keVband. All three nuclei are obscured by Compton-thick material. The high quality hard X-ray spectra allow detailed modeling of the Compton reflection component.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5281v1.title: NuSTAR Reveals the Comptonizing Corona of the Broad-Line Radio Galaxy 3C 382
http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5281v1.summary: Broad-line radio galaxies (BLRGs) are active galactic nuclei that produce powerful, large-scale radio jets. BLRGs also appear like Seyfert 1 galaxies, but with flatter spectra and weaker reflection features. One explanation for these properties is that the X-ray continuum is diluted by emission from the jet.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.4453v1.title: A Compton thick AGN in the barred spiral NGC 4785
http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.4453v1.summary: X-ray observations of the active galactic nucleus (AGN) in NGC6764785. The source is a local Seyfert 2 which has not been studied so far in much detail. It was recently detected with high significance in the 15-60 keV band.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.3633v1.title: Weak Hard X-ray Emission from Broad Absorption Line Quasars: Evidence for Intrinsic X-ray Weakness
http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.3633v1.summary: We report NuSTAR observations of a sample of six X-ray weak broad absorption                line (BAL) quasars. Three of the six new targets are weakly detected by NuSTAR with <45Counts in the 3-24 keV band. The other three are not detected. We conclude that the observations have likely discovered a significantpopulation of intrinsically X-rays weak objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.1844v1.title: NuSTAR unveils a Compton-thick Type 2 quasar in Mrk 34
http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.1844v1.summary: We present Nustar 3-40 keV observations of the optically selected Type 2                quasar (QSO2) SDSS J1034+6001 or Mrk 34. The high-quality hard X-ray spectrumand archival XMM-Newton data can be fitted self-consistently with a reflection-dominated continuum and strong Fe Kalpha fluorescence line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1406.3345v1.title: The 2-79 keV X-ray Spectrum of the Circinus Galaxy with NuSTAR, XMM-Newton and Chandra: a Fully Compton-Thick AGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/1406.3345v1.summary: The Circinus galaxy is one of the nearest obscured AGN, making it an ideal target for detailed study. We model the 2-79 keV spectrum to constrain the primary AGN continuum and to derive physical parameters for the obscuring material. We find that the nuclearSpectrum is consistent with Compton-scattering by an optically-thick torus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.7575v1.title: Iron K$α$ emission in type-I and type-II Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.7575v1.summary: The narrow Fe K$\alpha$ line is one of the main signatures of the.reprocessing of X-ray radiation from the material surrounding supermassive.black holes. It has been found to be omnipresent in the X-rays spectra of activelyactive galactic nuclei (AGN)

http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.2645v2.title: The narrow Fe K$α$ line and the molecular torus in active galactic nuclei - an IR/X-ray view
http://arxiv.org/abs/1405.2645v2.summary: The narrow component of the iron K$\alpha$ is an almost ubiquitous feature in X-ray spectra of active galactic nuclei (AGN) and is believed to originate in neutral material, possibly located in the molecular torus. Recent developments in the study of the mid-IR (MIR) spectrum of AGNallow important parameters of the torus to be deduced, such as its coveringfactor.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12138v1.title: The NANOGrav 15-year data set: Search for Transverse Polarization Modes in the Gravitational-Wave Background
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12138v1.summary: Gravitational wave background with quadrupolar Hellings and Downs (HD) and Scalar Transverse (ST) correlations. HD correlations are the best fit to the data, and no significant evidence in favor of ST correlations. Bayes factors show strong evidence for a correlated signal, but data does not strongly prefer either correlation signature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12114v1.title: Dissipationless collapse and the dynamical mass-ellipticity relation of elliptical galaxies in Newtonian gravity and MOND
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12114v1.summary: Deur (2014) and Winters et al. (2023) proposed an empirical relation between the dark to total mass ratio and ellipticity in elliptical galaxies. The larger is the content of dark matter in the galaxy, the more the stellar component would be flattened. The equivalent Newtonian systems of collapse show a similar behaviour.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12108v1.title: New Black Hole Spin Values for Sagittarius A* Obtained with the Outflow Method
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12108v1.summary: Six archival Chandra observations are matched with eight sets of radio data. Three radio and X-ray data sets are identified as preferred for measuring the spin properties of the black hole. The spin function translates into measurements of black hole rotational mass, irreducible mass, and spin mass-energy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15321v2.title: All-sky Kinematics and Chemistry of Monoceros Stellar Overdensity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15321v2.summary: Monoceros is a structure located towards the Galactic anticenter and close to the disk. We identified that its stars have azimuthal velocity in the range of $200 to $250. Our results confirm the similarity to stars found in the thin disk of the Galaxy and suggest an in situ formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12090v1.title: Chemical Analysis of the Brightest Star of the Cetus II Ultra-Faint Dwarf Galaxy Candidate
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12090v1.summary: We present a detailed chemical abundance analysis of the brightest star in the ultra-faint dwarf (UFD) galaxy candidate Cetus II. For this star, DES J011740.53-173053, abundances or upper limits of 18 elements from Carbon to Europium are derived. The star exhibits lower Sc, Ti, and V abundances than Milky Way halo stars with similar metallicity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03063v2.title: $Λ$CDM not dead yet: massive high-z Balmer break galaxies are less common than previously reported
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03063v2.summary: Early JWST observations that targeted so-called double-break sources                (attributed to Lyman and Balmer breaks at $z>7$), reported a previously unknown population of very massive, evolved high-redshift galaxies. This surprising discovery led to a flurry of attempts to explain these objects' unexpectedexistence including invoking alternatives to the standard $Lambda$CDM paradigm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12015v1.title: Implication of the period-magnitude relation for massive AGB stars and its astronomical applications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12015v1.summary: Parallaxes of the three OH/IR stars NSV17351, OH39.7$+$1.5, IRC$-$30363, and the Mira-type variable star AW~Tau were newly obtained. The distribution and kinematics of theircircumstellar matter are also revealed with the VLBI method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00687v2.title: Euclid preparation. XXXII. Evaluating the weak lensing cluster mass biases using the Three Hundred Project hydrodynamical simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00687v2.summary: The photometric catalogue of galaxy clusters extracted from ESA Euclid data is expected to be very competitive for cosmological studies. Using state-of-the-art hydrodynamical simulations, we present analyses of the expected weak lensing profiles from clusters in a variety ofynamic states and at wide range of redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11916v1.title: Evolution to mirror-symmetric galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11916v1.summary: The evolution of a rotating axisymmetric galaxy from an asymmetric state to a state of mirror symmetry with respect to the galactic plane has as basic result that in the asymmetric initial state the perpendicular $z$ normal mode isunstable. Dynamically this results in atransfer of mass and momenta towards the galactic Plane. The timescale of this evolution to symmetric equilibrium will determine the final distribution function describing position and velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v1.title: The JWST Galactic Center Survey -- A White Paper
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v1.summary: JWST has the unique capability to provide us with the necessary, game-changing data. We advocate for a large-area, multi-wavelength NIRCam survey of the inner 100\,pc of the Galaxy. We describe how this survey will derive the physical and kinematic properties of 10,000,000 stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v2.title: The Quasar Feedback Survey: characterising CO excitation in quasar host galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v2.summary: 17 Type 2quasars at $z <$ 0.2 from the Quasar Feedback Survey. We measure the total molecular gas content using the CO(1-0) emission and homogeneously sample the CO spectralline energy distributions (SLEDs) The ionised gas traced by [OIII] exhibit systematically higher velocities than that traced by CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11872v1.title: MUSE observations of the giant low surface brightness galaxy Malin 1: Numerous HII regions, star formation rate, metallicity, and dust attenuation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11872v1.summary: Giant low-surface brightness (GLSB) galaxies are an extreme class of objects with very faint and extended gas-rich disks. Malin 1 is the largest GLSB galaxy known to date, but its formation is still poorly understood. We observe a steep decline in the star formation rate surface density within the inner 20 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13066v2.title: Ram-pressure stripped radio tail and two ULXs in the spiral galaxy HCG 97b
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13066v2.summary: We report LOFAR and VLA detections of extended radio emission in the spiral galaxy HCG 97b, hosted by an X-ray bright galaxy group. The extended radioemission detected at 144 MHz, 1.4 GHz and 4.86 GHz is elongated along theoptical disk and has a tail that extends 27 kpc in projection towards the center of the group at GHz frequencies. The asymmetry observed in both CO emission morphology and kinematics indicates that HCG97b is undergoing ram-pressure stripping.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00602v2.title: Feedback-driven anisotropy in the circumgalactic medium for quenching galaxies in the SIMBA simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00602v2.summary: We use the SIMBA galaxy formation simulation suite to explore anisotropies in circumgalactic gas that result from accretion and feedback processes. We particularly focus on the impact of bipolar active galacticnuclei (AGN) jet feedback as implemented in SIMBA. jets cause lower densities and higher temperatures along the galaxy minor axis (SIMBA jet direction)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15155v2.title: Sulfur isotope ratios in the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.15155v2.summary: Sulfur isotope ratios have emerged as a promising tool for tracing stellar populations. While extensively studied in the Milky Way, in extragalactic environments they remain largely unexplored. We focus on investigating the sulfur isotope. ratios in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11800v1.title: Exploring the Chemistry and Mass Function of the Globular Cluster 47 Tucanae with New Theoretical Color-Magnitude Diagrams
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11800v1.summary: Despite their shared origin, members of globular clusters display star-to-star variations in composition. We developed a stellarmodelling method to obtain precise chemical abundances for stars near the end of the main sequence. The inferred distribution disfavors stellar interactions as the origin of chemical spread. We anticipate thatfuture observations of 47 Tucanae with JWST will extend the mass baseline of analysis into the substellar regime.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11074v2.title: XUE. Molecular inventory in the inner region of an extremely irradiated Protoplanetary Disk
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11074v2.summary: First results of the eXtreme UV Environments (XUE) James WebbSpace Telescope (JWST) program. XUE targets 15 disks in three areas of NGC 6357, which hosts numerous massive OB stars. These regions are likelyrepresentative of the environment in which most planetary systems formed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11717v1.title: Circumgalactic Medium at High Halo Masses -- Signatures of Cold Gas Depletion in Luminous Red Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11717v1.summary: We study ultraviolet HI and metal line transitions in the circumgalacticmedium (CGM) of 15 massive, quenched luminous red galaxies. In the general LRGs population, we detect HI in 4 of 8 LRGs. The CGM of LRGs also shows low and intermediate ionized lines of OVI. While most LRG CGMsystems show weak or non-detectable OVI, a few systems show strong OVI 1031.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15140v2.title: Toward General-Relativistic Magnetohydrodynamics Simulations in Stationary Non-Vacuum Spacetimes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15140v2.summary: Accretion of magnetized gas on compact astrophysical objects such as blackholes has been successfully modeled using general relativistic simulations. These simulations have largely been performed in the Kerr metric, which describes the spacetime of a vacuum andstationary spinning black hole. The simulations have revealed important clues on the physics of accretion and jets near the BH event horizon.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11621v1.title: The Impact of Patchy Reionization on Ultra-faint Dwarf Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11621v1.summary: Patchy reionization affects the star formation history and stellar metallicity of ultra-faint dwarf galaxies (UFDs) UFDs can have different SFHs depending on their position with respect to their host halo during the period of patchyreionization. The average stellariron-to-hydrogen ratio, [Fe/H], of the simulated U FDs with patchy reionsization increases by 0.22-0.42 dex.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11609v1.title: Reflection-Equivariant Diffusion for 3D Structure Determination from Isotopologue Rotational Spectra in Natural Abundance
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11609v1.summary: Structure determination is necessary to identify unknown organic molecules, such as those in natural products, forensic samples, the interstellar medium, and laboratory syntheses. Rotational spectroscopy enables structuredetermination by providing accurate 3D information about small organicmolecules via their moments of inertia. Using these moments, Kraitchmananalysis determines isotopic substitution coordinates, which are the unsigned $|x,|y,|z| coordinates of all atoms with natural isotopic abundance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09404v2.title: When the Well Runs Dry: Modeling Environmental Quenching of High-mass Satellites in Massive Clusters at \boldmath$z \gtrsim 1$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09404v2.summary: We explore models of massive satellitequenching in massive clusters at $z\gtrsim1$ using an MCMC framework. We find that they can be separated between starvation and core quenching scenarios. We conclude that only the starvation pathway is consistent with the projected phase-space distribution and relative abundance of transition galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11544v1.title: Co-Evolution of Stars and Gas: Using Analysis of Synthetic Observations to Investigate the Star-Gas Correlation in STARFORGE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11544v1.summary: We explore the relationship between stellar surface density and gas surface density. We create synthetic observations based on the Spitzer and Herschel telescopes. We extract star-gas properties such as the dense gas mass fraction, the Class II:I ratio, and the S-G correlation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11507v1.title: Why do semi-analytic models predict higher scatter in the stellar mass-halo mass relation than cosmological hydrodynamic simulations?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11507v1.summary: Semi-analytic models (SAMs) systematically predict higher stellar-mass scatter at a given halo mass than hydrodynamical simulations and most empirical models. We investigate the physical origin of this scatter byexploring modifications to the physics in the SAM Dark Sage.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11504v1.title: 2D chemical evolution models II. Effects of multiple spiral arm patterns on O, Eu, Fe and Ba abundance gradients
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11504v1.summary: According to observations and numerical simulations, the Milky Way couldexhibit several spiral arm modes with multiple pattern speeds. Our aim is to quantify the effects of the spiral arms on the azimuthal variations of the metrics for oxygen, iron and for the first time for neutron-capture elements (europium and barium)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11503v1.title: How many stars form in galaxy mergers?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11503v1.summary: Post-coalescence mergers are on average younger than control galaxies. The difference in age from matched controls is up to 1.5 Gyr. The modeled burst fraction is robust to choice of parametric starformation history, as well as differences in burst duration. The result is significantly higher than that found in hydrodynamical simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11502v1.title: Modeling Post-Reionization HI Distributions in Fuzzy Dark Matter Cosmologies Using Conditional Normalizing Flows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11502v1.summary: In this work, we model neutral hydrogen (HI) distributions using high-resolution simulations of both cold dark matter (CDM) and fuzzydark matter (FDM) cosmologies in the post-reionization redshift range of $z=3.42-4.94$. We show that the HI abundance and the HI column density function decrease in FDM-likecosmologies. Upcoming 21 cm intensity mapping experiments like the Square Kilometer Array have significant potential to constrain the properties of dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11495v1.title: Some stars fade quietly: Varied Supernova explosion outcomes and their effects on the multi-phase interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11495v1.summary: We present results from galaxy evolution simulations with a mutiphase interstellar medium. In the default setting, individual supernova (SN) remnants are realized as thermal injections. We find that the variation in the SN-energy, based on the tables of Sukhbold et al. (2016), has only minor effects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11496v1.title: The Peak of the Fallback Rate from Tidal Disruption Events: Dependence on Stellar Type
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11496v1.summary: A star completely destroyed in a tidal disruption event (TDE) ignites a massive flare. The flare is powered by the fallback of tidally stripped debris to a supermassive black hole. We analyze two estimates for the peak fallback rate in a TDE. We conclude that the time to peak illuminate in complete TDEs is almost exclusively determined by SMBH mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11493v1.title: $Σ_{\mathrm{SFR}}$-M* Diagram: A Valuable Galaxy Evolution Diagnostic to Complement (s)SFR-M* Diagrams
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11493v1.summary: The specific star formation rate (sSFR) is commonly used to describe the level of galaxy star formation (SF) and to select quenched galaxies. A small sSFR can be either because of a substantial previous mass build up, or because SF is low. We show that the normalization of SFR by the physicalExtent over which SF is taking place overcomes this ambiguity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11487v1.title: Jets with a Twist: Emergence of FR0 Jets in 3D GRMHD Simulation of Zero Angular Momentum Black Hole Accretion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11487v1.summary: Spinning supermassive black holes (BHs) in active galactic nuclei (AGN) launch relativistic collimated outflows, or jets. Such jets are thought to perish within $3$ orders of magnitude in distance from the BH, well before reaching kpc-scales. We study the survival of such jets at the largest scale separation to date.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11488v1.title: Dark Energy as a Critical Period in Binary Motion: Bounds from Multi-scale Binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11488v1.summary: The suitability of a binary system to constrain dark energy is determined by the ratio between its Keplerian orbital period and the critical period $T_\Lambda$ We show that the ratio emerges from the Kretschmann scalar, which is a quadratic curvature invariant.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11422v1.title: A Full Accounting of the Visible Mass in SDSS MaNGA Disk Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11422v1.summary: We present a study of the ratio of visible mass to total mass in spiral galaxies to better understand the relative amount of dark matter. Using the velocities of the H-alpha emission line measured in spectroscopic observations, we evaluate the rotational velocity of 5522 disk galaxies at their 90% elliptical Petrosian radii, R90.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06470v2.title: Metal enrichment and evolution in four z > 6.5 quasar sightlines observed with JWST/NIRSpec
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06470v2.summary: We present JWST/NIRSpec R~2700 spectra of four high-redshift quasars: VDESJ0020-3653, DELS J0411-0907, UHS J0439+1634 and ULAS J1342+0928. The abundance ratio of [Si/O] in five z>6absorption systems show enrichment signatures produced by low-mass Pop III pair supernovae and possibly Pop III hypernovae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11412v1.title: Stellar mass-metallicity relation throughout the large-scale of the Universe: CAVITY mother sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11412v1.summary: Void galaxies are essential to understand the physical processes that drivegalaxy evolution. They are less affected by external factors than galaxies inenser environments, i.e. filaments, walls, and clusters. Comparing the stellar metallicity of galaxies in various environments can provide valuable insights into how the large-scale environment impacts galaxy evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04529v2.title: JADES: Resolving the Stellar Component and Filamentary Overdense Environment of HST-Dark Submillimeter Galaxy HDF850.1 at $z=5.18$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04529v2.summary: HDF850.1 is the brightest submillimeter galaxy (SMG) in the Hubble DeepField. It is known as a heavily dust-obscured star-forming galaxy embedded in an overdense environment at $z = 5.18$. The galaxy hosts a stellar mass of $10.8 trillion solar masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14881v2.title: Modeling the molecular gas content and CO-to-H2 conversion factors in low-metallicity star-forming dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.14881v2.summary: Low-metallicity dwarf galaxies often show no or little CO emission, despite intense star formation observed in local samples. Constraining the relative importance ofCO-bright versus CO-dark H2 star-forming reservoirs is crucial to understand how star formation proceeds at low metallicity. We find that galaxies with high clumpiness may have CO-to-H2 conversion factor as low as the Galactic value.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11339v1.title: Shocking Sgr B2(N1) with its own outflow: A new perspective on segregation between O- and N-bearing molecules
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11339v1.summary: We want to investigate the influence of the powerful outflow driven by the tumultuous hot core Sgr B2(N1) on the gas molecular inventory of the surrounding medium. Abundances of HCnN (n=3,5) are enhanced in the outflow component pointing to (additional) gas-phase formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16410v2.title: Simulated non-thermal emission from SNR G1.9+0.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16410v2.summary: Supernova remnants are the nebular leftover of defunct stellar environments. They display a large variety of non-spherical morphologies such as ears that shinenon-thermally. We have modelled the structure and the non-thermal emission of G1.9+0.3 through 3D magnetohydrodynamic numerical simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11302v1.title: Gaia FGK Benchmark Stars: fundamental Teff and log g of the third version
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11302v1.summary: We have compiled about 200 candidates which have precise measurements ofangular diameters and parallaxes. We determined their bolometric fluxes byfitting their spectral energy distribution. Masses were determined using twosets of stellar evolution models. In a companion paper we describe thedetermination of metallicities and detailed abundances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12943v1.title: Clustering and physical properties of the star-forming galaxies and AGN: does assembly bias have a role in AGN activity?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12943v1.summary: We compare the spatial clustering and physical properties of the activegalactic nuclei (AGN) and star-forming galaxies (SFG) at fixed stellar mass using a volume limited sample from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. We conclude that AGN are stochastic phenomena owing to an underlying role of the assembly bias.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.09596v2.title: Chemical abundance analysis of symbiotic giants. Metallicity and CNO abundance patterns in 14 northern S-type systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.09596v2.summary: In previous works, we computed abundances for the red giant in nearly four                dozen S-type symbiotic systems (SySt) The abundances provide information about metrics, evolutionary status, and possible memberships in Galactic stellarpopulations. Here, we extend our studies with a northern hemisphere sample of SySt. This northern sample is dominated by Galactic disk/halo objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12895v1.title: Physical properties of circumnuclear ionising clusters. II. NGC 7469
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12895v1.summary: Circumnuclear star forming regions (CNSFR) are massive clusters found close to galactic nuclei. These entities give us an excellent opportunity to study star formation in environments with high metallicity. The inner ring regions which are close to the active galactic nucleus probablyare the only ones that have enough mass to survive the action of the AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12867v1.title: Far-Infrared Luminosity Bursts Trace Mass Accretion onto Protostars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12867v1.summary: Evidence abounds that young stellar objects undergo luminous bursts of accretion that are short compared to the time it takes to form a star. It remains unclear how much these events contribute to the main-sequence massesof the stars. We demonstrate the power of time-series far-infrared (far-IR)photometry to answer this question.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17054v2.title: Impact of orbiting satellites on star formation rate evolution and metallicity variations in Milky Way-like discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17054v2.summary: At least one major merger is currently taking place in the MW. The Sgr dwarf galaxy is being tidally destroyed while orbiting around the MW, whose close passages perturb the MW disc externally. We also found that the close passages of orbiting satellites cause the formation of a substantial amount of low-metallicity stars in the host.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14228v2.title: Optical variability in Quasars: Scaling with black hole mass and Eddington ratio depend on the observed timescales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14228v2.summary: Quasars emission is highly variable, and this variability gives us clues to understand the accretion process onto supermassive black holes. We can expectvariability properties to correlate with the main physical properties of the black hole, i.e., its mass and accretion rate. The behavior can be explained in terms of a universal variability power spectrum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14090v2.title: Physics-informed neural networks in the recreation of hydrodynamic simulations from dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14090v2.summary: Hydrodynamic simulations are a core constituent of modern cosmology. Physics-informed neural networks have emerged as a coherent framework for building predictive models. The underlying notion is to enrich the optimization loss function with known relationships to constrain the space of possible solutions. The results demonstrate improved accuracy of dark matter predictions based on dark matter halo properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07516v4.title: General formulae for the periapsis shift of a quasi-circular orbit in a static spherically symmetric spacetime and the active gravitational mass density
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07516v4.summary: We study the periapsis shift of a quasi-circular orbit in general static spacetimes. We derive two formulae in full order withrespect to the gravitational field. The shift is backward if the gravitational mass density is beyond a critical value. We show that this violation of the strong energy condition provides evidence for dark energy.
