http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12759v1.title: A case study of early galaxy cluster with the Athena X-IFU
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12759v1.summary: Observations of the hot gas in distant clusters of galaxies are key to understand the role of intense galaxy activity, super-massive black hole feedback and chemical enrichment. We assess the feasibility to retrieve, using X-ray hyperspectral data only, the thermodymamical hot gas properties of a $z=2$ galaxy cluster of mass M500=7.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07919v4.title: A model for the infrared-radio correlation of main-sequence galaxies at GHz frequencies and its variation on redshift and stellar mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07919v4.summary: The infrared-radio correlation (IRRC) of star-forming galaxies can be used to estimate their star formation rate. The 1.4 GHz IRRC correlation is nearly z-invariant up to z=4, but depends strongly on stellar mass. For galaxies with lower M (M=10^8.5 M_sun), we find that the IR-to-radiolux ratio increases with increasing redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12704v1.title: CatNorth: An Improved Gaia DR3 Quasar Candidate Catalog with Pan-STARRS1 and CatWISE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12704v1.summary: CatNorth is an improvedGaia DR3 quasar candidate catalog with more than 1.5 million sources in the                3$\pi$ sky built with data from Gaia, Pan-STARRS1, and CatWISE2020. The CatNorth catalog has a high purity of > 90% while maintaining high completeness.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10848v2.title: The star formation, dust, and abundance of galaxies with unWISE-CIB cross-correlations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10848v2.summary: The cosmic infrared background (CIB) is the accumulated infrared (IR)radiation mainly from interstellar dust heated up by early stars. We measure the cross-correlations between galaxies from the unWISE catalog and CIB maps from the Planck satellite to constrain the cosmic star formation rate (SFR)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15983v2.title: Ultrafast modulations in stellar, solar and galactic spectra: Dark Matter and numerical ghosts, stellar flares and SETI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15983v2.summary: We discuss the hypothesis that ultrafast periodic spectral modulations at $f_S \simeq 0.607$ THz found in the spectra of $236$ stars of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) were due to dark matter (DM) cores in their centers. Two additional frequencies in the redshift-corrected SDSS galactic spectra were found [5, 6, 7, 8]. Independent SETI observations of four stars could not confirm with high confidence, but not completely exclude, the presence of $f-S.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12555v1.title: Probing Three-Dimensional Magnetic Fields: II -- An Interpretable Convolutional Neural Network
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12555v1.summary: 3D magnetic fields, including orientation and strength, within the interstellar medium is vital but notoriously difficult. We propose a novel Convolutional Neural Network model to extract this embedded information. The CNN model effectively reconstructs the 3D magnetic field topology and magnetization. We applied this trained CNN model to the L1478 molecular cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12453v1.title: Early Planet Formation in Embedded Disks (eDisk). VIII. A Small Protostellar Disk around the Extremely Low-Mass and Young Class 0 Protostar, IRAS 15398-3359
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12453v1.summary: Protostellar disks are a ubiquitous part of the star formation process and are the future sites of planet formation. We present high-angular resolution dustcontinuum and molecular line observations of the Class 0 protostar, IRAS 15398-3359. The dust continuum is small, compact, and centrally peaked.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06308v2.title: The Spatial and Emission Properties of the Large [O III] Emission Nebula Near M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.06308v2.summary: We discuss SDSO as a possible unrecognized supernova remnant, a large and unusually nearby planetary nebula, or an interaction of M31's outer halo gas with high-velocity circumgalactic gas. We conclude that galactic origins are unlikely and favor instead an extragalactic M31 halo--circumgalactic cloud interaction scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13890v2.title: Massive Dark Matter Halos at High Redshift: Implications for Observations in the JWST Era
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.13890v2.summary: The presence of massive galaxies at high $z$ as recently observed by JWST appears to contradict the current $\Lambda$CDM cosmology. Here we aim to alleviate this tension by incorporating uncertainties from three sources in counting galaxies. cosmic variance, error in stellar mass estimation, and backsplash enhancement significantly increase thecumulative stellar mass density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08972v2.title: A Conditional Abundance Matching Method of Extending Simulated Halo Merger Trees to Resolve Low-Mass Progenitors and Sub-halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08972v2.summary: The algorithm is general and can be applied to data with different resolutions using different target variables. We show that the extended trees are statistically equivalent to the high-resolution trees in the joint distribution of subhalo quantities. The extended trees preserve certain information about individual systems in the target simulation, including properties of resolved satellite subhalos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02352v2.title: The formation channels of multiphase gas in nearby early-type galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02352v2.summary: The processes responsible for the assembly of cold and warm gas in early-typestellargalaxies are not well-understood. We report on the multiwavelengthproperties of 15 non-central, nearby ($z \leq$ 0.00889) ETGs primarily through Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer and Chandra X-ray observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12340v1.title: The JADES Origins Field: A New JWST Deep Field in the JADES Second NIRCam Data Release
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12340v1.summary: The JADES OriginsField (JOF) will soon be the deepest imaging field yet observed with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) This field falls within the GOODS-S region about 8' south-west of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (HUDF) The JOF will be observed for 380 open-shutter hours with NIRCam using 15 imaging filters and 2 grismbandpasses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15824v2.title: LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA's Oldest Black Holes: Probing star formation at cosmic noon with GWTC-3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.15824v2.summary: The LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA gravitational-wave (GW) observatory was sensitive to binary black hole (BBH) mergers out to redshifts. Because GWs are inefficient at shrinking the binaryorbit, some of these BBH systems likely experienced long delay times between formation of their progenitor stars and merger. We use these predicted delay time distributions to determine BBH formation rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12338v1.title: Total mass slopes and enclosed mass constrained by globular cluster system dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12338v1.summary: The goal of this work is to probe the total mass distribution of early-typegalaxies with globular clusters (GCs) as kinematic tracers. We use discrete Jeans anisotropic modelling to determine the velocity moments at the location of GCs in our sample. We find that the orbital properties (anisotropy and rotation of the GC systems) minimally impact the measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12330v1.title: AGN Selection and Demographics: A New Age with JWST/MIRI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12330v1.summary: We report significant progress with JWST towards this goal. We discuss how AGNobscuration, intrinsic SED variations, galaxy contamination, survey depth andselection techniques complicate the construction of a complete AGN sample. We find the obscured AGN fraction gradually increases from $z\sim0$ to $z''sim4'' with most high-$z$ AGNs obscured. Even among the massive galaxies where the previous AGN search is believed to be thorough, 34\% of the MIRI AGN identifications are new.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.07240v4.title: Cold dark matter particle mass and properties and axion-like dark radiation in $Λ$CDM cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2202.07240v4.summary: A theory is presented for the mass, size, lifetime, and other properties of                cold dark matter particles within the $\Lambda$CDM cosmology. Using Illustris simulations, we demonstrate the mass and energy cascade in self-gravitating self-interacting dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11302v2.title: Gaia FGK Benchmark Stars: fundamental Teff and log g of the third version
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11302v2.summary: We have compiled about 200 candidates which have precise measurements ofangular diameters and parallaxes. We determined their bolometric fluxes byfitting their spectral energy distribution. Masses were determined using twosets of stellar evolution models. In a companion paper we describe thedetermination of metallicities and detailed abundances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04423v2.title: J-PLUS: Detecting and studying extragalactic globular clusters -- the case of NGC 1023
http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04423v2.summary: The arrival of wide-field surveys such as the JavalambrePhotometric Local Universe Survey (J-PLUS) offers new possibilities for the study of these systems. We find 523 GC candidates in NGC 1023, of which $\sim$300 are new. We identify subpopulations of GC candidates, where age and metallicity distributions have multiple peaks.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12261v1.title: Mapping Physical Conditions in Neighboring Hot Cores: NOEMA Studies of W3(H$_2$O) and W3(OH)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12261v1.summary: The complex chemistry that occurs in star-forming regions can provide insight into the formation of prebiotic molecules. To study this process, we present millimeter-waveinterferometric observations of the neighboring hot cores. We propose the use of HCOOCH$_3$ as a new temperatureTracer in W3(H$_2$O) and W3 (OH)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12251v1.title: Searching for Mass Concentrations with Precision Pulsar Timing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12251v1.summary: Radio pulse travel times are influenced via gravitational fields along the path from the source to the observer. Transient time delays in transit are a useful measure of the matter distribution. Twelve candidates are reported from this search. The results can be used to sample the massvariation of pulsars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12245v1.title: The three hundred project: thermodynamical properties, shocks and gas dynamics in simulated galaxy cluster filaments and their surroundings
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12245v1.summary: Using cosmological simulations of galaxy cluster regions from The Three Hundred project we study the nature of gas in filaments feeding massive galaxies. We measure average gas properties such as density, temperature,pressure, entropy and Mach number. We also study the distribution of shocked gas around filaments and galaxy clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16127v3.title: Radio Galaxy Zoo: Towards building the first multi-purpose foundation model for radio astronomy with self-supervised learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16127v3.summary: We train a multi-use model which compresses ourunlabelled data into a structured, low dimensional representation. We exceed baseline supervised Fanaroff-Riley classification performance by a statistically significant margin. We show that the learned representation is scientifically useful even if no labels are available by performing a similarity search.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12235v1.title: On the evolutionary history of a simulated disc galaxy as seen by phylogenetic trees
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12235v1.summary: Phylogenetic methods have long been used in biology, and more recently have been extended to other fields - for example, linguistics and technology. Galaxies also have an evolutionary history, and fall within this broad phylogenetic framework. The shape of the trees are strongly affected by the age-metallicity of the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12231v1.title: An almost dark galaxy with the mass of the Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12231v1.summary: Almost Dark Galaxies are objects that have eluded detection by traditionalsurveys such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. Nube is the most massive and extended object of its kind discovered so far. It has an effective radius three times larger than typical ultra-diffusegalaxies with similar stellar masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12228v1.title: Solution to the conflict between the resolved and unresolved galaxy stellar mass estimation from the perspective of JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12228v1.summary: We estimate the resolved and unresolved stellar mass viaspectral energy distribution (SED) fitting to study the discrepancy between them. The SED fitting process tends to overestimate both stellar age and dust attenuation in the absence of rest-frame NIR data. With the inclusion of the JWST NIR photometry, we                find no significant disparity between the resolution and unresolved mass estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12222v1.title: Subaru High-$z$ Exploration of Low-luminosity Quasars (SHELLQs). XVII. Black Hole Mass Distribution at $z \sim 6$ Estimated via Spectral Comparison with Low-$z$ Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12222v1.summary: We report the distribution of black hole (BH) masses and Eddingont ratios for a sample of 131 low luminosity quasars in the early cosmic epoch. Our work is based on Subaru High-$z$ Exploration of                Low-Luminosity Quasars project.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12200v1.title: LATIS: The Stellar Mass-Metallicity Relation of Star-forming Galaxies at $z\sim 2.5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12200v1.summary: We present the stellar mass - stellar metallicity relation for 3491 star-forming galaxies. We find a strong correlation between stellar mass and stellar meetallicity. Our findings may signal the onset of blackhole-driven outflows at $z \sim 2.5$ for galaxies with stellar mass of $M_* $.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12202v1.title: A Population of Short-duration Gamma-ray Bursts with Dwarf Host Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12202v1.summary: We present a population of 11 of the faintest ($> 25.5$ AB mag) short worrisomegamma-ray burst (GRB) host galaxies. We model their sparse availableobservations using the stellar population inference code Prospector-$\beta$ and develop a novel implementation to incorporate the galaxy mass-radius relation. These hosts have dwarf galaxy stellar masses of $7.0-$9.1$. This is striking as only $14\%$ of short GRB hosts with previous inferred stellar masses had this mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12205v1.title: Variations of Interstellar Gas-to-Dust Ratios at High Galactic Latitudes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12205v1.summary: Interstellar dust at high Galactic latitudes can influence astronomical subtraction, produce diffuse scattered light, and result in harder(de-reddened) ultraviolet spectra of quasars. We evaluate the interstellar "gas-to-dust ratio", using hydrogen column densities (H I and H$_2) and estimates of dust reddening.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12206v1.title: Probing the Galactic Diffuse Continuum Emission with COSI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12206v1.summary: Compton Spectrometer and Imager (COSI) had a successful 46-dayflight onboard NASA's Super Pressure Balloon platform. In this work we reportmeasures of the Galactic diffuse continuum emission (GDCE) observed towards the inner Galaxy during the flight. In the COSI energy band (0.2 - 5 MeV) the GDCE is primarily generated from inverse Compton radiation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12197v1.title: Super-early JWST galaxies, outflows and Lyman alpha visibility in the EoR
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.12197v1.summary: The overabundance of super-early (redshift $z>10$) and blue galaxies detected by JWST has been explained as due to negligible dust attenuation in these systems. We show that such a model correctly reproduces the UV luminosity function and the starformation rate (SFR) density evolution. At $z \simeq 10$ the cosmic sSFR crosses the critical value.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11300v1.title: A high fidelity Milky Way simulation with Kraken, Gaia-Enceladus, and Sequoia analogues: clues to their accretion histories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11300v1.summary: The Gaia-Enceladus (GE), Kraken and Sequoia mergers each matches observational results, including in velocity and chemicalabundance space. The Kraken analogue is the earliest merger and has the highest total mass ratio. The GE andSequoia analogue eventsrete at similar times in our simulation, both along filaments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11296v1.title: ALMA gas-dynamical mass measurement of the supermassive black hole in the red nugget relic galaxy PGC 11179
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11296v1.summary: We present observations of CO(2$-$1) emission from the circumnuclear gas disk in the red nugget relic galaxy PGC 11179. The disk shows regular rotation, with projected velocities near the center of 400 km. The supermassive black hole (BH) mass is measured to be $M_\mathrm{BH} = (1.91\pm0.04$ - 10^9)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11268v1.title: The localization of galaxy groups in close proximity to galaxy clusters using cosmic web nodes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11268v1.summary: The large random motions and velocities of galaxies in the regions around clusters complicate the characterisation of substructures through normal group-finding algorithms. We investigate the efficacy of using the cosmic web nodes identified by the DisPerSE topological filament finder to systematically identify galaxy groups around massive clusters. We find that in 3D, 56\% of Dis perse nodes correctly identified as groups (purity) and 68\% as nodes (completeness)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02066v2.title: Combined model for $\rm ^{15}N$, $\rm ^{13}C$, and spin-state chemistry in molecular clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02066v2.summary: We present a new gas-grain chemical model for the combined isotopicfractionation of carbon and nitrogen in molecular clouds. We apply the model to a series of zero-dimensional simulations representing a set of physical conditions across a prototypical prestellar core. We explore the deviations of the isotopic abundance ratios in the various molecules from the elemental isotopic ratios as a function ofphysical conditions and time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05244v2.title: Strong gravitational lensing's `external shear' is not shear
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05244v2.summary: The distribution of mass in galaxy-scale strong gravitational lenses is often.modelled as an elliptical power law plus `external shear', which notionallyaccounts for neighbouring galaxies and cosmic shear. We show that it does not correlate with independent measurements of shear in a handful of rare systems. We conclude that the external shear attached to a power law model is not physically meaningful.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11212v1.title: Probing the structure of the lensed quasar SDSS J1004+4112 through microlensing analysis of spectroscopic data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11212v1.summary: We aim to reveal the sizes of the continuum and broad emission line (BEL) regions in the gravitationally lensed quasar SDSS J1004+4112. We analyzed the outstanding microlensing-induced distortions in the line profiles of various BELs in the quasar image A. The size-wavelength correlation is consistent with that of a geometrically thin and optically thick accretion disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11190v1.title: Jupiter-like planets might be common in a low-density environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11190v1.summary: Jupiter-like planets have a frequency <20% around solar-type stars. However, they may be much more common in one of the closest associations in the solarneighbourhood. Young moving stellar groups are the best targets for direct                imaging of exoplanets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08673v2.title: PyMsOfa: A Python Package for the Standards of Fundamental Astronomy (SOFA) Service
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08673v2.summary: The Standards of Fundamental Astronomy (SOFA) is a service provided by the International Astronomical Union. The python package PyMsOfa has fully implemented 247 functions of the original SOFA subroutines. This package can be suitable to not only the astrometric detection of planets of the Closeby Habitable Exoplanet Survey (CHES) mission (Ji et al.2022)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11008v1.title: Hypernova signatures of the first stars in dwarf galaxies in the Local Group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11008v1.summary: A star recently discovered in the Sculptordwarf galaxy, named AS0039, is considered to show the unique signature of a Pop~III star. The study aims to explore the environmental conditionsrequired for the formation of such a unique star using cosmological simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07750v2.title: Cosmological and idealised simulations of dark matter haloes with velocity-dependent, rare and frequent self-interactions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07750v2.summary: There are a variety of self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) models that lead to varying astrophysical predictions and hence varying success in explaining observations. Studies of dark matter density cores suggest a velocity-dependent scattering cross-section. In this work, we investigate how a velocity dependence alters the evolution of the DMoutheastern distribution for frequent DM scatterings.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10832v1.title: WTP$\,$10aaauow: Discovery of a new FU Ori outburst towards the RCW$\,$49 star-forming region in NEOWISE data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10832v1.summary: Large-amplitude accretion outbursts in young stars are expected to play acentral role in proto-stellar assembly. Most outburst identifications and detailed studies have resulted from searches in optical time domain surveys. Here, we present the discovery of WTP$\,$10aaauow, a large mid-infrared outburst.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10801v1.title: ALMA Observations of the Extraordinary Carina Pillars: A Complementary Sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10801v1.summary: We present a study of six dusty and gaseous pillars and globules localized in the Carina nebula. We report multiple millimeter continuum sources, from where multiple molecular outflows emanate. We reveal that the masses of the disks$+$envelopes are in a range of 0.02 to 0.38 M$_\odot$, which suggests that their exciting sources might be low- or intermediate-mass protostars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13889v2.title: HI in Molecular Clouds: Irradiation by FUV plus Cosmic Rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.13889v2.summary: We extend the analytic theory presented by Sternberg et al. (2014) for the production of atomic hydrogen (HI) via FUVphotodissociation at the boundaries of dense interstellar molecular (H$_2$)clouds. We present computations for a wide range of FUV fieldstrengths, cosmic-ray ionization rates, and dust-to-gas ratios.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10771v1.title: Ray-tracing simulations of the Soft X-ray Scattered Emission in obscured Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10771v1.summary: Most Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) in the local Universe are obscured. In highly obscured AGN this component has lower flux relative to the primary X-raycontinuum. This is measured by the scattering ratio, or fscatt, which is the ratio of the scattered flux to the continuum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10739v1.title: The Astrochemistry Low-energy Electron Cross-Section (ALeCS) database I. Semi-empirical electron-impact ionization cross-section calculations and ionization rates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10739v1.summary: Astrochemistry Low-energy Electron Cross-Section (ALeCS) is a public database for electron interaction cross-sections and ionization rates for molecules of astrochemical interest. The database will be continuously updated for more                molecules and interactions. We show that the ionizationRate scale roughly linearly with the number of constituent atoms in the molecule.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10733v1.title: From Halos to Galaxies. VII. The Connections Between Stellar Mass Growth History, Quenching History and Halo Assembly History for Central Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10733v1.summary: The assembly of galaxies over cosmic time is tightly connected to the assembly of their host dark matter halos. We show that at the same present-day stellar mass, passive central galaxies assembled half of their final stellar mass earlier than star-forming central galaxies. This is because they reside in more massive halos with a higher halo mass increase rate across cosmic time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10730v1.title: Population III star formation: multiple gas phases prevent the use of an equation of state at high densities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10730v1.summary: Advanced primordial chemistry networks have been developed to model the collapse of metal-free baryonic gas within the gravitational well of dark matter halos. Here we explore the feasibility of replacing the chemical network with a barotropic equation of state (EoS) just before the formation of the first protostar. We find a significant reduction in fragmentation when using the EoS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10727v1.title: Resolving the explosion of supernova 2023ixf in Messier 101 within its complex circumstellar environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10727v1.summary: Observing a supernova explosion shortly after it occurs can reveal important information about the physics of stellar explosions. When a star with a well-defined edgeexplodes in vacuum, the first photons to escape from its surface appear as a brief shock-breakout flare. The duration of this flare can extend to at most a few hours even for nonspherical breakouts from supergiant stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10721v1.title: Resolution criteria to avoid artificial clumping in Lagrangian hydrodynamic simulations with a multi-phase interstellar medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10721v1.summary: Large-scale cosmological galaxy formation simulations typically prevent gasin the interstellar medium (ISM) from cooling below 10^4 K. This has been motivated by the inability to resolve the Jeans mass in molecular gas. We show that the classical Jeans criteria derived for Newtonian.gravity are not applicable in the simulated ISM if the spacing of resolution.elements representing the dense ISM is below the gravitational force softeninglength.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10723v1.title: Kinematical coherence between satellite galaxies and host stellar discs for MaNGA & SAMI galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10723v1.summary: The effect of angular momentum on galaxy formation and evolution has beenstudied for several decades. We found the co-rotation pattern between stellar discs and satellites can be concluded with 99.7 percent confidence level ($\sim 3\sigma$) when combining datasets. And the random tests show that the signal can be scarcely drawn from random distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10725v1.title: Very massive stars and Nitrogen emitting galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10725v1.summary: Recent studies of high-redshift galaxies such as GN-z11 at z=10.6 with JWST show significant amounts of nitrogen (N) in their spectra, which is unexpected. We suggest the common ingredient to be very massive stars (VMS) with zero-age main sequence (ZAMS) masses in the range 100-1000 Msun.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10719v1.title: VLT-MUSE spectroscopy of AGNs misclassified by BPT diagnostic or with weak emission lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10719v1.summary: Some X-ray emission lines are known to be 'optically dull' or have lines that fall on the star-forming branch of the BPT diagram ('misclassified' AGNs) Aperture effects have been proposed to explain such atypical spectra. VLT-MUSE IFU spectra allow us to investigate the extent to which the aperture size affects the emission line measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00255v3.title: Revisiting Blueshift Interpretation In Light Of Recent Discovery Of Multiple Systems Of Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00255v3.summary: This study investigates the anomalies associated with redshifts from emission lines in certain quasar candidates and the viability of a blueshiftinterpretation instead. The sample was taken from the Million Quasars Catalog(MILLIQUAS), representing the unidentified class with a redshift greater than 1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13582v1.title: Comprehensive Analysis of the Open Cluster Collinder 74
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13582v1.summary: Collinder 74 is an intermediate-age open cluster. We identified 102 most likely cluster members. Galactic orbit integration shows that the Collinder74 follows a boxy pattern outside the solar circle and is a member of thethin-disc component of the Galaxy. The total mass of the cluster was found to be 365 $M/M_{\odot}$ for the stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13543v1.title: Shedding Light on Low Surface Brightness Galaxies in Dark Energy Survey with Transformers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13543v1.summary: Low surface brightness galaxies (LSBGs) play a crucial role in understanding galaxy evolution and cosmological models. Transformer models have the potential to be on par withconvolutional neural networks as state-of-the-art algorithms in analysing data. We identified 4,083 new LSBGs in DES, adding an additional $\sim17\% $to the L SBGs already known.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13521v1.title: A portrait of the Vast Polar Structure as a young phenomenon: hints from its member satellites
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13521v1.summary: Several Milky Way satellite dwarf galaxies are distributed along a coherent planar distribution known as the Vast Polar Structure (VPOS) Here we investigate whether MW satellites located on the VPOShave different physical and orbital properties from those not associated with them. The on-plane systems tend to have the lowest orbital energies for a given value of angularmomentum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v3.title: The Quasar Feedback Survey: characterising CO excitation in quasar host galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v3.summary: 17 Type 2quasars at $z <$ 0.2 from the Quasar Feedback Survey. We measure the total molecular gas content using the CO(1-0) emission and homogeneously sample the CO spectralline energy distributions (SLEDs) The ionised gas traced by [OIII] exhibit systematically higher velocities than that traced by CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08405v2.title: The X-ray invisible Universe. A look into the halos undetected by eROSITA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08405v2.summary: The paper presents the analysis of optically selected GAMA groups and clusters in the SRG/eROSITA X-ray map of eFEDS. The undetected groups exhibit less than half the surface brightness, dark matter, and galaxy distributions of the detected halos. The low mass concentration and the magnitude of the gap indicate that these systems are young.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13489v1.title: Maser Investigation toward Off-Plane Stars (MIOPS): detection of SiO masers in the Galactic thick disk and halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13489v1.summary: Studying stars that are located off the Galactic plane is important for understanding the formation history of the Milky Way. A total of 102 stars were observed in the SiO $J$=1-0, $v=1$ and 2 transitions with the Effelsberg-100 m and Tianma-65 m telescopes. SiO                ™masers were discovered in eight stars, all first detections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10242v2.title: Bounding the mass of ultralight bosonic Dark Matter particles with the motion of the S2 star around Sgr A*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10242v2.summary: Dark matter is undoubtedly one of the fundamental, albeit unknown, components of the standard cosmological model. The failure to detect WIMPs, the most promising candidate particle for cold dark matter, actually opens the way for the exploration of viable alternatives. Ultralight bosonic particles with masses of $10-21$ eV represent one the most encouraging.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00388v2.title: TODDLERS: A new UV-mm emission library for star-forming regions. 1. Integration with SKIRT and public release
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00388v2.summary: The library generation involves the spherical evolving of a homogeneous gas cloud around a young stellar cluster. It accounts for stellar feedback processes including stellar winds, supernovae, and radiation pressure. The library paves the way for a variety of applications using simulated galaxies at low and high redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13466v1.title: Searching for strong gravitational lenses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13466v1.summary: Strong gravitational lenses provide unique laboratories for cosmological andastrophysical investigations. They must first be discovered - a task that can be met with significant contamination by other astrophysical objects andasterisms. Here we review strong lens searches covering various sources, lenses, datasets, and wavelengths. Search techniques are described based on the main lensing feature that is required for the technique to work.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04024v3.title: The FLAMINGO project: cosmological hydrodynamical simulations for large-scale structure and galaxy cluster surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04024v3.summary: Virgo Consortium's FLAMINGO suite of hydrodynamical simulations for cosmology and galaxy cluster physics. Models are calibrated to the observed low-redshift galaxy stellar mass function and cluster gas fractions. The two most demanding simulations have box sizes of 1.0 and 2.8 Gpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13423v1.title: Reply to Comment on "Dark matter as a Weyl geometric effect"
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13423v1.summary: In a recent Comment on the paper "Dark matter as a Weyl geometric effect", by Burikham et al., posted on arxiv. org aseprint arXiv:2306.11926, it was claimed that the exact solution found in the above mentioned paper "is wrong" In this Reply we present, in a clear and comprehensive way, a step by step derivation of the exact. solution of the vacuum static spherically symmetric field equations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13401v1.title: Cosmic variance suppression in radiation-hydrodynamic modeling of the reionization-era 21-cm signal
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13401v1.summary: The 21-cm line emitted by neutral hydrogen is the most promising probe of the Epoch of Reionization (EoR) Multiple radio interferometric instruments are on the cusp of detecting its power spectrum. The nature of this signal traditionally required the modeling of large volumes. However, the recently-proposed Fixed & Paired (F&P)approach uses carefully-crafted simulation pairs to achieve equal results in smaller volumes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03255v2.title: Wide binaries with white dwarf or neutron star companions discovered from Gaia DR3 and LAMOST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.03255v2.summary: Gaia DR3 mission has identified and provided about 440,000 binary systems with orbital solutions. For two of these sources with a main-sequence companion, no obvious excess is observed in the blue/red band of spectra. The absence of an additional component from spectraldisentangling analysis further suggests the presence of compact objects within these systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v2.title: The JWST Galactic Center Survey -- A White Paper
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v2.summary: JWST has the unique capability to provide us with the necessary, game-changing data. We advocate for a large-area, multi-wavelength NIRCam survey of the inner 100\,pc of the Galaxy. We describe how this survey will derive the physical and kinematic properties of 10,000,000 stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13278v1.title: MaNGA DynPop -- VI. Matter density slopes from dynamical models of 6000 galaxies vs cosmological simulations: the interplay between baryonic and dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13278v1.summary: We use the results from the best Jeans Anisotropic Modelling(JAM) of the integral-field stellar kinematics for near 6000 galaxies. The total and stellar slopes track each other tightly, with the total slope being 0.174$ over the full $R$ range. We find that the central regions of galaxies from TNG50 and TNG100 simulations do not reproduce the observed galaxyMass distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13156v1.title: Enlightening the Universe behind the Milky Way Bulge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13156v1.summary: The location of the Solar System constrains the detection of galaxies beyond the Milky Way(MW) plane. The optical observations are hampered in the so--called Zone of Avoidance (ZOA) where stellar crowdingand Galactic absorption are severe. Observations at longer wavelengths areneeded to discover new background galaxies and complete the census.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13125v1.title: ALMA-IMF IX: Catalog and Physical Properties of 315 SiO Outflow Candidates in 15 Massive Protoclusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13125v1.summary: We present a catalog of 315 protostellar outflow candidates detected in SiO J=5-4 in the ALMA-IMF Large Program. Median outflow lifetimes are 6,000 years. We find correlations between field-aggregated outflow properties and total mass in cores (~3$-$5$\sigma$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13069v1.title: NIHAO-GIZMO: A Comparison of Simulated Disc Galaxies from GASOLINE and GIZMO
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13069v1.summary: We simulate twelve disc galaxies from theNIHAO suite simulated with the GASOLINE code, then compare the correspondinggalaxies in the two simulations. We find that while both codes with the sameinitial conditions and large-scale environments can successfully produce                similar disc galaxies, significant differences are still seen in manyproperties of the galaxies. The differences are mainly due to different feedback models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.07467v2.title: High-z galaxies with JWST and local analogues -- it is not only star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.07467v2.summary: A new analysis of the JWST NIRSpec data of SMACS 0723 released as Early Release Observations. Three new redshifts are provided, bringing the total of reliable redshifting to 14. I also identify a population of possibly shock-dominated galaxies at z<3 whose near-IR emission lines plausibly come nearly all from shocks.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13066v1.title: OGLE-2014-BLG-0221Lb: A Jupiter Mass Ratio Companion Orbiting either a Late-Type Star or a Stellar Remnant
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13066v1.summary: We present the analysis of microlensing event OGLE-2014-BLG-0221, a planetary candidate event discovered in 2014. The photometric light curve is bestdescribed by a binary-lens single-source model. Our light curve modeling finds two degenerate models, with event timescales of $t_\mathrm{E}\sim70$ days and $ t_ \sim110$ days. The two models are similar in their planetary parameters with a Jupiter mass ratio of $q \sim 10^{-3}$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.14317v2.title: COOL-LAMPS. V. Discovery of COOL J0335$-$1927, a Gravitationally Lensed Quasar at $z$=3.27 with an Image Separation of 23.3"
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.14317v2.summary: This is the fifth paper from the COOL-LAMPScollaboration. We report the discovery of COOL J0335$-$1927, a quasar at z = 3.27 lensed into three images. To date this is the highest redshift wide-separation lensed quasar known.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13054v1.title: CAPOS: The bulge Cluster APOgee Survey IV. Elemental Abundances of the bulge globular cluster NGC 6558
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13054v1.summary: This study presents the results concerning six red giant stars members of the grotesqueglobular cluster NGC 6558. The analysis utilized high-resolution near-infraredspectra obtained through the CAPOS initiative. We also found low levels of Nitrogen-Carbon, a typical chemical signature for the presence of multiple stellar populations in virtually all GCs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13055v1.title: The formation of cores in galaxies across cosmic time -- the existence of cores is not in tension with the LCDM paradigm
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13055v1.summary: The core-cusp problem has long been considered a key small scale challenge to the standard LCDM paradigm. In NH, halos that contain galaxies in the upper M* > 10^10.2 MSun end of the stellar mass distribution contain cusps. Cores are created via supernova-driven gas removal from the central regions of halos, which alters the central gravitational potential.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13056v1.title: JWST uncovers helium and water abundance variations in the bulge globular cluster NGC 6440
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13056v1.summary: NGC 6440 is a typicalmassive, obscured and contaminated globular cluster formed and orbiting within the Galactic bulge. We used ultra-deep observations obtained with the NIRCam aboard the James                Webb Space Telescope to explore the stellar population of the cluster. We argue that the presence of a He-enriched stellar population with a helium spread of DeltaY = 0.04 can be attributed to variations in the abundance of oxygen.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13048v1.title: Detection of Accretion Shelves Out to the Virial Radius of a Low-Mass Galaxy with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13048v1.summary: Low-mass galaxy Ark 227 was found in deepJWST NIRCam imaging from the Blue Jay Survey. N-body simulations have predicted that minor mergers create "accretion shelves" in the surface brightness profile at large radius. We observe such a feature in Ark 227 at 10-20 kpc, which, according to models, could be caused by a merger with a spectrum of lower-mass galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13050v1.title: The Three-Phase Evolution of the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13050v1.summary: We illustrate the formation and evolution of the Milky Way over cosmic time. The evolution of angular momentum as a function of metallicity - a rough proxy for stellar age - displays three distinct phases. We interpret these trends using Milky Way analogs from the TNG50 cosmological simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15170v1.title: Oxygen abundance of gamma Vel from [O III] 88um Herschel/PACS spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15170v1.summary: We present Herschel PACS spectroscopy of the [O III] 88.4um fine-structure line in the nearby WC8+O binary system gamma Vel. We obtain higher luminosities for the WR and O components of gamma Vel with respect to De Marco et al, log L/L_sun = 5.31 and 5.56, respectively,primarily as a result of the revised (higher) interferometric distance. The sulphur abundance of X_S = 0.04 +/- 0.01%agrees with the solar abundance, as expected for unprocessed

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15162v1.title: Ionized Gas Extended Over 40 kpc in an Odd Radio Circle Host Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15162v1.summary: Odd Radio Circles (ORCs) are large rings of faint, diffuse radio continuum emission spanning ~1 arcminute on the sky. Galaxies at the center of several ORCs have photometric redshifts of z~0.3-0.6, implying scales of several 100 kiloparsecs in diameter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15158v1.title: Ages and metallicities of stellar clusters using S-PLUS narrow-band integrated photometry: the Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15158v1.summary: The Small Magellanic Clouds are the most massive and closest satellite galaxies of the Milky Way. This makes them important for validating integrated light methods to study stellarpopulations and star-formation processes. We obtained ages and metallicities for all stellar clusters using the Bayesian spectral energy distribution fitting code.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15107v1.title: Assembling a high-precision abundance catalogue of solar twins in GALAH for phylogenetic studies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15107v1.summary: Stellar chemical abundances have proved themselves a key source of information for understanding the evolution of the Milky Way. However, progress is hampered by the level of precision in chemical abundance data. We apply The Cannon algorithm to generate a catalogue of about 40,000 solar twins with high precision abundances which we use to perform a phylogenetic analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v3.title: The JWST Galactic Center Survey -- A White Paper
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v3.summary: JWST has the unique capability to provide us with the necessary, game-changing data. We advocate for a large-area, multi-wavelength NIRCam survey of the inner 100\,pc of the Galaxy. We describe how this survey will derive the physical and kinematic properties of 10,000,000 stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13156v2.title: Enlightening the Universe behind the Milky Way Bulge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13156v2.summary: The location of the Solar System constrains the detection of galaxies beyond the Milky Way(MW) plane. The optical observations are hampered in the so--called Zone of Avoidance (ZOA) where stellar crowdingand Galactic absorption are severe. Observations at longer wavelengths areneeded to discover new background galaxies and complete the census.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.00524v3.title: Studying the internal structures of the central region of prestellar core L1517B in Taurus molecular cloud using ammonia (NH_3 ) (1,1) and (2,2) lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.00524v3.summary: Measurement of internal structures in the prestellar core is essential for understanding the initial conditions prior to star formation. We study the ammonia lines (NH3 ) in the central region of the L1517B prestellarCore with the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array Radio Telescope. Radially averaged kinetic temperature (T_k ) is almost constant inside the core.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15002v1.title: Probing the face-on disc-corona system of the bare AGN Mrk 110 from UV to hard X-rays: a moderate changing-state AGN?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15002v1.summary: The X-ray broadband spectra of the bare AGN Mrk 110 were obtained by XMM-Newton and NuSTAR observations (Nov 2019 and April 2020) They are characterised by the presence of a prominent and absorption-free smooth softX-ray excess, moderately broad OVII and Fe Kalpha emission lines, and a lack of a strong Compton hump. A combination of soft and hard Comptonisation from a warm and a hot coronae, plus mild relativistic disc reflection reproduces the data very well.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12842v2.title: Anisotropic mass segregation: two-component mean-field model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12842v2.summary: Galactic nuclei, the densest stellar environments in the Universe, exhibit acomplex geometrical structure. The stars orbiting the central supermassive black hole follow a mass segregated distribution. The latter distribution may represent the equilibrium state of vector resonant relaxation (VRR) We build simple models to understand the equilibrium distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14841v1.title: Exploring the circumstellar environment of Tycho's supernova remnant--I. The hydrodynamic evolution of the shock
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14841v1.summary: Tycho's SNR has been considered as atypical object from the viewpoints of its spectroscopic, morphological andenvironmental properties. A recent reanalysis of Chandra data shows that its forward shock is experiencing a substantial deceleration since around 2007. Such a non-uniform environment can be linked back to the nature and activities of its progenitor.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14831v1.title: Formation of interstellar complex organic molecules on water-rich ices triggered by atomic carbon freezing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14831v1.summary: The reactivity of interstellar carbon atoms (C) on the water-dominated ices is one of the possible ways to form interstellar complex organic molecules (iCOMs) We found that C spontaneously reacts with the water molecule,resulting in the formation of $^3$C-OH$_2$, a highly reactive species.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16125v2.title: Tides in clouds: control of star formation by long-range gravitational force
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.16125v2.summary: Gravity drives the collapse of molecular clouds through which stars form. The exact role of gravity in cloud collapse remains a complex issue. Tides were first recognized by Newton, yet this is the first time its dominance in cloud evolution has been revealed. We expect this link between cloud density structure and role gravity will be strengthened by future studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02703v2.title: Spatial extent of molecular gas, dust, and stars in massive galaxies at z=2-2.5 determined with ALMA and JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02703v2.summary: We present the results of 0.6"-resolution observations of CO J=3-2 line                emission in 10 massive star-forming galaxies at z=2.2-2.5 with the AtacamaLarge Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) We find a more intense star-formation activity with a higher sSFR and a shorter depletion timescale in the inner region than in the outer region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14617v1.title: Early Planet Formation in Embedded Disks (eDisk) XII: Accretion streamers, protoplanetary disk, and outflow in the Class I source Oph IRS63
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14617v1.summary: We present ALMA observations of the Class I source Oph IRS63 in the context of the Early Planet Formation in Embedded Disks (eDisk) large program. We show a myriad of protostellar features, such as ashell-like bipolar outflow, an extended rotating envelope structure, and several small-scale spiral structures seen towards the edge of the dust continuum. By analyzing the velocity pattern of $^{13}$CO and $C$^{18}$O, we measure a protstellar mass of 0.5 times the dust disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14588v1.title: AESOPUS 2.0: Low-Temperature Opacities with Solid Grains
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14588v1.summary: We compute the equation of state and Rosseland mean opacity from temperatures of T~30000 K down to T~400 K. Atoms, molecules, anddust grains in thermodynamic equilibrium are all included in the equation. To incorporate monochromatic atomic and molecular cross sections, anoptimized opacity sampling technique is used.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14571v1.title: The FLASH pilot survey: an HI absorption search against MRC 1-Jy radio sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14571v1.summary: We report an ASKAP search for associated HI 21-cm absorption against bright                radio sources from the Molonglo Reference Catalogue (MRC) 1-Jy sample. The detected systems comprise two radio galaxies and one quasar. The MRC 0531$-$237 absorption system is the strongest found to date. All three detections have a high 1.4 GHz radio luminosity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14530v1.title: Mock Observations: Formation and Evolution of diffuse light in Galaxy Groups and Clusters in the IllustrisTNG Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14530v1.summary: In this paper, we examine the properties of the diffuse light and compare them to those of central and satellite galaxies. Our findings suggest that the majority of the light originates from satellites. This claim is supported by the similarity between the age and metallicity distributions of the Diffuse Light and those of the satellites.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14488v1.title: Density Functional Theory Calculations on the Interstellar Formation of Biomolecules
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14488v1.summary: Density functional theory (DFT) is the most versatile electronic structure method used in quantum chemical calculations. DFT calculations are used to estimate the potential barriers for chemical reactions in astronomical environments. We survey investigations into the formation of nucleobases in the interstellar medium. We conclude by noting several areas that require more research.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14373v1.title: The Corona Australis star formation complex is accelerating away from the Galactic plane
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14373v1.summary: Kinematics of the recently discovered Corona Australis (CrA)chain of clusters. The expansion along Z exhibits a curved pattern. This is the first time such a nonlinear Velocity-position relation has been observed for stellar clusters. We propose a feedback scenario in which the observed gradient is caused bystellar feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14334v1.title: MOND as manifestation of modified inertia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14334v1.summary: MOND is a term used to refer to theories that modify the Newtonian Poisson action of gravitational potential. Most MOND theories are of the modified-gravity (MG) type. The MI models predict a stronger external-field effect -- e.g. on low acceleration systems in the solar neighborhood.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14299v1.title: Revealing the Chemical Structure of the Magellanic Clouds with APOGEE. III. Abundance Gradients of the Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14299v1.summary: We determine radial- and age-abundance gradients of the Small MagellanicCloud (SMC) using spectra of 2,062 red giant branch (RGB) field stars observed by SDSS-IV / APOGEE-2S. The SMC is found to have an overall metallicity gradient of $-$0.0546 $\pm$ 0.0043 dex/kpc. As a function of age, many gradients show a feature 3.66--5.58 Gyr ago, which is especiallyprominent in the [X/H] grad

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.07368v3.title: SUNRISE: The rich molecular inventory of high-redshift dusty galaxies revealed by broadband spectral line surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.07368v3.summary: Molecular ISM at high-$z$ is commonly studied using only a few species beyond CO. We report the detection of 38 and 25 emission lines in APM and NC. The spectra reveal the chemical richness and the complexity of the ISM. Our astrochemical model suggests that at such high column densities, FUVradiation is less important in regulating the IsM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14253v1.title: Computed Rotational Collision Rate Coefficients for Recently Detected Anionic Cyanopolyynes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14253v1.summary: We report new results from quantum calculations of energy-transfer processes taking place in interstellar environments and involving two newly observed molecular species. These species are part of the anionic molecular chains labeled as cyanopolyynes which have been observed over the years in Circumstellar Envelopes and in molecular clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14193v1.title: Approach of the NGC 1977 star cluster to the TOI-2796 host star
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14193v1.summary: The age of the cluster was determined using the color - absolutemagnitude diagram and the isochron system. The time of themaximum approach 32 pc of the host star with planetary system TOI-2796 with the                NGC 1977 are found. The place of approach in the sky is shown, this point can be considered as the place of appearance of interstellar comets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02490v2.title: Positivity from Cosmological Correlators
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.02490v2.summary: Causality and unitarity are hard to demonstrate in cosmological backgrounds. The expansion of the universe ensures that late-time cosmology correlators are classical. For multi-field inflation, the resulting positivityconstraints have long been known in terms of the Suyama-Yamaguchi inequality. We demonstrate that similar statistical bounds imply nontrivial constraints for massive fields in early universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14106v1.title: The magnetic field of a magnetohydrodynamic disk wind: Water maser observations and simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14106v1.summary: We measure and model the magnetic field distribution in the disk wind of the young stellar object (YSO) IRAS 21078+5211. We measure a weak level of 0.3%-3.2% of linear and circular polarization in 24 and 20 GHz water masers. Our simulations of a jet around a forming massive star reproduce the maser kinematics in the inner jet cavity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14095v1.title: Neutral Hydrogen (HI) 21 cm as a probe: Investigating Spatial Variations in Interstellar Turbulent Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14095v1.summary: Interstellar turbulence shapes the HI distribution in the Milky Way. How this affects large-scale statistical properties of HI column density across theMW remains largely unconstrained. We use approx 13,000 square-degree GALFA-HIsurvey to map statistical fluctuations of HI over the 40 km s-1 velocity range.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14061v1.title: Investigating Protostellar Accretion across the mass spectrum with the JWST: discovery of a collimated jet from the low luminosity protostar IRAS 16253-2429 in a quiescent accretion phase
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14061v1.summary: We report the discovery of a highly collimated atomic jet from the Class 0 protostar IRAS~16253-2429. The jet is clearly detected in multiple [Fe~II] lines, [Ne~II], [Ni~II), and H~I lines, but not in molecular emission. From our analysis, we find that the atomic jet has a velocity of about 169~$\pm$~15~km.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13963v1.title: SDSS J1619 with blue-shifted broad components in H$α$ and in [O~{\sc iii}] having similar line width and velocity shifts: a recoiling SMBH candidate?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13963v1.summary: We report a potential candidate of recoiling supermassive black hole (rSMBH) in SDSS J1619 based on similar velocity shifts and linewidths of the blue-shifted broad components. The virial BH mass derived from the broad H$\alpha$ is consistent with the mass expected from the M_{BH}-\sigma relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17454v2.title: Ghostly galaxies: accretion-dominated stellar systems in low-mass dark matter halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.17454v2.summary: Wide-area deep imaging surveys have discovered large numbers of extremely low surface brightness dwarf galaxies. In this scenario, inefficient radiative cooling prevents starforming in the main branch of the merger tree of a low mass dark matterhalo. Almost all its stellar mass is acquired through mergers with less massive (but nevertheless star-forming) progenitors. Present-day systemsformed in this way would be `ghostly' isolated stellar halos with no central galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13872v1.title: ALMA-IMF VIII -- Combination of Interferometric Continuum Images with Single-Dish Surveys and Structural Analysis of Six Protoclusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13872v1.summary: We present the combination of ALMA-IMF and single-dish continuum images from Mustang-2 Galactic Plane Survey (MGPS90) at 3 millimeters and the Bolocam   BGPS (BGPS) at 1 millimeter. Six and ten out of the fiffteenALMA- IMF fields are combined with MGPS90 and BGPS, respectively. We report the basic physical parameters of the dust-dominated (column densities, masses) and ionized (emission measures) structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13839v1.title: Dark matter distribution in Milky Way-analog galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13839v1.summary: Our current understanding of how dark matter (DM) is distributed within the Milky Way halo is based on either careful studies of the local stellar orbits or model assumptions on the globalshape of the MW halo. In this work, we undertake a study of external galaxies, with the intent of providing insight to the DM distribution in MW-analoggalaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13783v1.title: Study of spectral index of giant radio galaxy from Leahy's Atlas: DA 240
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13783v1.summary: We investigate the giant radio galaxy DA 240, which is a FR II source. We found that thesynchrotron radiation is the dominant radiation mechanism over most of the area of DA 240. The results of this study will be helpful for understanding the evolutionary process of the DA 240radio source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13751v1.title: Nebular C IV 1550 Imaging of the Metal-Poor Starburst Mrk 71: Direct Evidence of Catastrophic Cooling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13751v1.summary: The Hubble Space Telescope ACS camera obtained the first spatially progressivelyresolved, nebular imaging in the light of C IV 1548,1551. These observations of the local starburst Mrk 71 in NGC                2366 show emission apparently originating within the interior cavity around the Knot A super star cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13745v1.title: NGDEEP Epoch 1: Spatially Resolved H$α$ Observations of Disk and Bulge Growth in Star-Forming Galaxies at $z \sim$ 0.6-2.2 from JWST NIRISS Slitless Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13745v1.summary: We study maps of 19 galaxies at redshifts of $0.6 < z < 2.2$ in the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (HUDF) derived from NIRISSslitless spectroscopy as part of the Next Generation Deep Extragalactic Public (NGDEEP) Survey. The majority (84%) of galaxies show positive EW(H$\alpha$) gradients, positive sSFR gradients and negative age progressivelygradients.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13739v1.title: Spikes and accretion of unbound, collisionless matter around black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13739v1.summary: We consider the steady-state density and velocity dispersion profiles of collisionless matter around a Schwarzschild black hole (BH) We treat matter, which could be stars or darkmatter particles, whose orbits are unbound to the BH but still governed by its gravitational field. We consider two opposite spatial geometries for the matter distributions: an infinite, 3D cluster and a 2D razor-thin disk, both with zero net angular momentum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13732v1.title: Directly constraining the spatial coherence of the $z\sim1$ circumgalactic medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13732v1.summary: One of the biggest puzzles regarding the circumgalactic medium (CGM) is the structure of its cool ($T\sim10^4$ K) gas phase. In this work we study the spatial structure of the $z\sim 1$ CGM with unprecedented detail via resolved spectroscopy of giant gravitational arcs. We find that the cool gas tends to cluster in separate structures. We argue that, if this is a universal property of the CGM, it needs to be produced by future theoretical models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16038v1.title: LEM All-Sky Survey: Soft X-ray Sky at Microcalorimeter Resolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16038v1.summary: The LEM-All-Sky Survey (LASS) is expected to follow the success of ROSAT and eROSITA. The Line Emission Mapper (LEM) is an X-ray Probe with with spectralresolution ~2 eV FWHM from 0.2 to 2.5 keV. It will cover a 33 arcmin diameter Field of View with 15 arcsec angularresolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16037v1.title: Star Formation Efficiency in Nearby Galaxies Revealed with a New CO-to-H2 Conversion Factor Prescription
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16037v1.summary: Dynamical effects alter theemissivity properties of CO, leading to variations in the CO-to-H$_2$conversion factor. We propose a new prescription that accounts for CO emissivity variations across galaxies. We find increasing SFE towards high surface density regions like galaxy centers.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16026v1.title: Retrievals of Protoplanetary Disk Parameters using Thermochemical Models: I. Disk Gas Mass from Hydrogen Deuteride Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16026v1.summary: We discuss statistical relationships between the mass of protoplanetary disks and the hydrogen deuteride (HD) line emission and the dust spectral energy distribution. We find that low-mass (optically thin) disks display a tight correlation between the average disk gas temperature andHD line flux. We demonstrate that the central star luminosity, disk size, dust size distribution, and HD flux may be used to determine the disk gas mass to within a factor of three.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15967v1.title: Comparing emission- and absorption-based gas-phase metallicities in GRB host galaxies at $z=2-4$ using JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15967v1.summary: JWST/NIRSpec is providing sensitive spectroscopic observations of distant galaxies. We present the first results from a cycle-1 JWST program to investigate the relation between. the metallicity of neutral gas measured with GRB afterglow absorption lines and NIRSpec. We find a tight relation between absorption and emission line metallicities when using the recent Laseter et al. (2023) $R_3$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v4.title: The JWST Galactic Center Survey -- A White Paper
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11912v4.summary: JWST has the unique capability to provide us with the necessary, game-changing data. We advocate for a large-area, multi-wavelength NIRCam survey of the inner 100\,pc of the Galaxy. We describe how this survey will derive the physical and kinematic properties of 10,000,000 stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15925v1.title: Noema formIng Cluster survEy (NICE): Discovery of a starbursting galaxy group with a radio-luminous core at z=3.95
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15925v1.summary: The study of distant galaxy groups and clusters at the peak epoch of starforming is limited by the lack of a statistically and spectroscopically confirmed sample. Recent discoveries of concentrated starburst activities in cluster cores have opened a new window to hunt for structures based on their integrated IR luminosities. We present the first result from the ongoing NICE survey, a compact group at z=3.95.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15842v1.title: Spatially resolved observations of the peculiar galaxy NGC 232: AGN winds and stellar populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15842v1.summary: We use VLT-MUSE integral field unit data, to study the ionized gas physicalproperties and kinematics, as well as the stellar populations of the Seyfert 2galaxy NGC 232. The data cover a field of view of 60''x60'' at a spatialresolution of ~850 pc. The emission-line profiles have been fitted with twoGaussian components.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12998v2.title: Black-hole mergers in disklike environments could explain the observed $q$-$χ_\mathrm{eff}$ correlation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.12998v2.summary: Current gravitational-wave data from stellar-mass black-hole binary mergers suggest a correlation between the binary mass ratio $q$ and the effective spin. We show that the symmetry of the astrophysical environment is a crucialfeature to shed light on this otherwise puzzling piece of observationalevidence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02380v4.title: The tilt of the velocity ellipsoid of different Galactic disk populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02380v4.summary: The tilt of the velocity ellipsoid is a helpful tracer of the gravitational potential of the Milky Way. We use nearly 140,000 RC starsselected from the LAMOST and Gaia to make a detailed analysis of the tilt. We determine the age and populationependence of various populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15807v1.title: Nobeyama Cygnus-X Survey: Physical Properties of C$^{18}$O clumps in DR-6(W), DR-9 and DR-13S regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15807v1.summary: Cygnus-X is considered a region of interest for high-energy astrophysics. The Cygnus OB2 association has been confirmed as a PeVatron. We discovered 19 new C$^{18}$O clumps associated with the star-forming regions DR-6W, DR-9, and DR13S.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15795v1.title: Temperature profiles of galactic dark matter halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15795v1.summary: We present the temperature profiles of galactic dark matter halos. We conclude that the central temperature of dark matter in all galaxies is the same. The dark matter halo is in a state of Bose-Einstein condensation. By using fittings of observational data, we can put an upper bound on the dark matter particle mass in the order of $13/eV.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12598v2.title: A LOFAR sample of luminous compact sources coincident with nearby dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12598v2.summary: The vast majority of extragalactic compact continuum radio sources are associated with star formation or jets from (super)massive black holes. We search the LOFAR Two-meter Sky Survey (LoTSS) for optically thinsynchrotron emission to date. We identify 29 over-luminous compact radio sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07709v2.title: Dust depletion of of metals from local to distant galaxies II: Cosmic dust-to-metal ratio and dust composition
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07709v2.summary: The chemical enrichment of the Universe can be traced through the evolution of the dust-to-metals ratio (DTM) We find that the DTM and DTG ratios increase with metallicity and with the dust tracer [Zn/Fe]. This suggests that grain growth in the ISM is a dominant process of dust production.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15733v1.title: Supernova Ejecta with Crystalline Silicate Dust in the Supernova Remnant MSH 15-52
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15733v1.summary: IRAS 15099-5856 in the young supernova remnant (SNR) MSH 15-52 is the first SNR-associated object with crystalline silicate dust detected so far. Its nature and the origin of the crystalline Silicate are still unclear.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09284v2.title: Exploring dark matter spike distribution around the Galactic centre with stellar orbits
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09284v2.summary: Precise measurements of the stellar orbits around Sagittarius A* have established the existence of a supermassive black hole (SMBH) at the Galactic center. Due to the interplay between the SMBH and dark matter, the DMdensity profile in the innermost region of the Galaxy is still an open question. We examine the radius and slope of the generalized NFW spike profile, analyze the Einasto spike, and discuss the influence of DM annihilation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15673v1.title: The Tully-Fisher relation and the Bosma effect
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15673v1.summary: The rotation curves of 16 nearby disc galaxies can be described by the NFW halo model and by the Bosma effect at approximately the same level of accuracy. We show that this rescaling allows us to derive a newversion of the Tully-Fisher (TF) relation that nicelyfit the data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15671v1.title: Quality flags for GSP-Phot Gaia DR3 astrophysical parameters with machine learning: Effective temperatures case study
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15671v1.summary: Gaia Data Release 3 (DR3) includes extensive information on the astrophysicalproperties of stars. We develop an approach to distinguish good-quality Gaia DR3 effective temperatures using machine-learning methods such as XGBoost. We test our models on three independent datasets, including PASTEL, a compilation of stellar parameters from different high-resolution studies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07051v2.title: Transition from small-scale to large-scale dynamo in a supernova-driven, multiphase medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07051v2.summary: Magnetic fields are widely recognised as critical at many scales to galacticdynamics and structure. Using imposed magnetic fields cannot reliably model the Interstellar medium's (ISM) structure nor phase interactions. ISM models exist of turbulent magnetic fields using small-scale dynamo (SSD) Others model the large-scale Dynamo (LSD) organising magnetic fields at scale of the disc or spiral arms. Separately, neither can                fully describe the galactic magnetic field dynamics nor topology.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10725v2.title: Very massive stars and Nitrogen emitting galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10725v2.summary: Supermassive stars (VMSs) with zero-age main sequence masses in the range of 100-1000 $M_{\odot}$. The He II in the Sunburst Arc might also be the result of the disproportionally large contribution of VMSs to the total stellar contribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15534v1.title: On the Origin of the Variety of Velocity Dispersion Profiles of Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15534v1.summary: We examine the inner and outer slopes of stellar.velocity dispersion profiles using integral field spectroscopy data and compare.them with cosmological hydrodynamic simulations. The diversity in the outer velocity.dispersion profiles reflects the diverse assembly histories among galaxies. The inner slopes are mainly influenced by the relative radial distribution of the young and old.stars formed in-situ.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14061v2.title: Investigating Protostellar Accretion across the mass spectrum with the JWST: discovery of a collimated jet from the low luminosity protostar IRAS 16253-2429 in a quiescent accretion phase
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.14061v2.summary: We report the discovery of a highly collimated atomic jet from the Class 0 protostar IRAS~16253-2429. The jet is clearly detected in multiple [Fe~II] lines, [Ne~II], [Ni~II), and H~I lines, but not in molecular emission. From our analysis, we find that the atomic jet has a velocity of about 169~$\pm$~15~km.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09777v2.title: A global view on star formation: The GLOSTAR Galactic plane survey. IX. Radio Source Catalog III: 2<l<28, 36<l<40, 56<l<60 and |b|<1, VLA B-configuration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.09777v2.summary: GLOSTAR is currently the highest resolution as well as the most sensitive radio survey of the northern Galactic plane at 4-8GHz. We extracted 13354 sources.above a threshold of 5sigma and 5437 sources above 7sigma that represent the.high-reliability catalog. A significant fraction of HII region and PNe candidates have alpha<-0.1 indicating that these candidates could contain radio jets, winds or outflows from high-mass and low-mass stellarobjects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15408v1.title: Mapping the Galactic disk with the LAMOST and Gaia Red clump sample: VIII: Mapping the kinematics of the Galactic disk using mono-age and mono-abundance stellar populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15408v1.summary: We present a comprehensive study of the kinematic properties of the different Galactic disk populations. The global spatial behaviors of the velocity dispersions clearly show a signal of spiral arms. The disk flaring in the outer region is mostly for young or alpha-poor stellar populations. Young/$\alpha$-poor populations are likely to have been born in the chaotic mergers of gas-rich systems and/or turbulent interstellar medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15374v1.title: Orbital evolution of LIGO/Virgo binaries in stellar clusters driven by cluster tides, stellar encounters and general relativity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15374v1.summary: Origin of LIGO/Virgo gravitational wave events may involve production of binaries with relativistic components in dense stellar systems. Orbitalparameters of these binaries evolve due to both external agents and internal ones. We present a numerical framework that follows the evolution of the binary orbit accounting for all these effects simultaneously.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13311v3.title: Gravitational Lensing of Schwarzschild and Charged Black Holes Immersed in Perfect Fluid Dark Matter Halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13311v3.summary: Dark matter and dark energy dominate the behavior of our universe. Dark matter usually forms halo structures in large number of galaxies. Properties of dark matter halo can be revealed and understood from the gravitational lensingobservations. To effectively model the supermassive black hole in a galaxy center (which is surrounded by dark matter) in a simple way, we investigate the Schwarzschild black hole and Reissner-Nordstr\"om black hole immersed in a perfect fluid dark matterhalo.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15345v1.title: Photometric Binaries in 14 Magellanic Cloud Star Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15345v1.summary: Binary stars play a major role in determining the dynamic evolution of star clusters. We used images collected with the Hubble Space Telescope to study 14 Magellanic Cloud star clusters that span an age interval between $0.6 and $2.1 Gyr. We find that the fraction of binaries with a mass ratio larger than 0.7 ranges from $7% to $20% in NGC2108. There is no evidence for a relation between the fractions of binaries and BSSs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15335v1.title: Photometric candidate selection and spectroscopic confirmation of new PNe and SySts in the Galactic plane
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15335v1.summary: About 3,500 planetary nebulae (PNe) are currently known in the Milky Way. This shows a great discrepancy with the expected number for these objects. The same holds forSymbiotic stars (SySts) as well. This project aims to contribute to the detection of new PNe and SySts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15284v1.title: Efficient survey design for finding high-redshift galaxies with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15284v1.summary: Several large JWST blank field observing programs have not yet discovered the first galaxies expected to form at $15 \leq z. This has motivated the search for more effective survey strategies that will be able to effectivelyprobe this redshift range. Here, we explore the use of gravitationally lensed galaxy cluster fields, that have historically been the most effective discovery tool with HST.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15257v1.title: Chemical Doppelgangers in GALAH DR3: the Distinguishing Power of Neutron-Capture Elements Among Milky Way Disk Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15257v1.summary: The observed chemical diversity of Milky Way stars places importantconstraints on Galactic chemical evolution and the mixing processes that happen within the interstellar medium. Recent works have found that the chemically diversity of disk stars is low. We measure the chemical doppelganger rate in GALAH DR3, with abundances rederived using The Cannon. We find that considering the neutron-capture elements decreases the doppel ganger rate from 2.2% to 0.4%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15248v1.title: Radial acceleration relation of galaxies with joint kinematic and weak-lensing data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15248v1.summary: We combine kinematic and gravitational lensing data to construct the RadialipientAcceleration Relation (RAR) of galaxies over a large dynamic range. We find thatearly- and late-type galaxies lie on the same joint RAR when a sufficiently strict isolation criterion is adopted and their stellar and gas masses are estimated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15244v1.title: Regulating star formation in a magnetized disk galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15244v1.summary: We use high-resolution MHD simulations of isolated disk galaxies to investigate the co-evolution of magnetic fields with a self-regulated, star-forming interstellar medium (ISM) The galaxies reach a quasi-steady state, with slowly declining star formation due to both gas consumption and increases in the field strength at intermediate ISM densities. Strong fields limit feedback bubbles.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15234v1.title: Field-level simulation-based inference with galaxy catalogs: the impact of systematic effects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15234v1.summary: A powerful way to constrain cosmologicalparameters from galaxy redshift surveys is to train graph neural networks to perform field-level likelihood-free inference without imposing cuts on scale. In this paper we train and test our models on galaxy catalogs, created from thousands of state-of-the-art hydrodynamic simulations. We find that, although the presence of these effects degrades the precision and accuracy of the models, and increases the fraction of catalogs where the model breaks down, the fraction that the model performs well is over 90%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15235v1.title: TREVR2: Illuminating fast $N\log_2\,N$ radiative transfer
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15235v1.summary: TREVR2 (Tree-based REVerse Ray Tracing 2) is a fast algorithm for computing the radiation field. It is designed to self-consistently evolve chemistry for zoomed-inastrophysical simulations. Light is propagated until absorbed, with no imposed speed limit other than those due to opacity changes.
