http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15232v1.title: Galaxies Going Bananas: Inferring the 3D Geometry of High-Redshift Galaxies with JWST-CEERS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15232v1.summary: The 3D geometry of high-redshift galaxies remains poorly understood. We build a differentiable Bayesian model and use Hamiltonian Monte Carlo to efficiently infer the 3D shapes of star-forming galaxies in JWST-CEERSobservations. We find high 3D ellipticities for all mass- redshift bins suggesting oblate (disky) or prolate geometries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15230v1.title: A multilevel implementation of the Goldreich-Kylafis effect into the radiative transfer code PyRaTE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15230v1.summary: linear polarization ofspectral lines, referred to in the literature as the Goldreich-Kylafis effect. We implement the GK effect into the non-local thermodynamic equilibrium radiative transfer code PyRaTE. Different modes of polarized radiation are treated individually with separateoptical depths.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15229v1.title: Sensitivity of Polarization to Grain Shape: I. Convex Shapes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15229v1.summary: Aligned interstellar grains produce polarized extinction (observed at wavelengths from the far-ultraviolet to the mid-infrared) and polarizedthermal emission. The grains must be quite nonspherical, but the actual shapes are unknown. The ratio of $10\mu$m polarization to $100\mu $m optical polarization is almost independent of grain shape.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15223v1.title: Fast Forward Modelling of Galaxy Spatial and Statistical Distributions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15223v1.summary: Galaxy clustering needs to be simulated accurately, both for the usage of clustering as its own probe and to control systematics. We use the distribution functions of the galaxyproperties, derived from a forward model adjusted to observations. To simulate the positions of galaxies, we then use a two-parameter relation between galaxies and halos with Subhalo Abundance Matching.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15218v1.title: The impact of binary stars on the dust and metal evolution of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15218v1.summary: We present detailed implementations of (a) binary stellar evolution and (b) dust production and destruction into the cosmologicalsemi-analytic galaxy evolution simulation, L-Galaxies. We find that binaries have a negligible impact on the stellar masses, gas masses, and star formation rates of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15221v1.title: The most stringent upper limit from dynamical models on the mass of a central black hole in 47 Tucanae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15221v1.summary: Globular clusters (GCs) were proposed as promising sites for discovering intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) Previous studies have yielded conflicting results. We present self-consistent dynamical models based on distribution functions (DFs) to assess the presence (or absence) of an IMBH in 47 Tucanae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15859v1.title: A Fermi-LAT Study of Globular Cluster Dynamical Evolution in Milky Way Galaxy: Millisecond Pulsars as the Probe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15859v1.summary: We show that the population of Millisecond Pulsars (MSPs) in Globular Clusters (GlCs) is highly dependent on the cluster dynamical evolution history of the host clusters. Older GlCs with more compact structures are more likely to have larger MSPs. As GlCs evolve into deep core collapse, these trends are found to be reversed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15842v2.title: Spatially resolved observations of the peculiar galaxy NGC 232: AGN winds and stellar populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15842v2.summary: We use VLT-MUSE integral field unit data, to study the ionized gas physicalproperties and kinematics, as well as the stellar populations of the Seyfert 2galaxy NGC 232. The data cover a field of view of 60"x60" at a spatialresolution of ~850 pc. The emission-line profiles have been fitted with twoGaussian components.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10725v3.title: Very massive stars and Nitrogen emitting galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10725v3.summary: Supermassive stars (VMSs) with zero-age main sequence masses in the range of 100-1000 $M_{\odot}$. The He II in the Sunburst Arc might also be the result of the disproportionally large contribution of VMSs to the total stellar contribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16796v1.title: Sky location of Galactic white dwarf binaries in space-based gravitational wave detection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16796v1.summary: Quickly localizing the identified white dwarf (WD) binaries is the basic requirement for the space-based gravitational wave (GW) detection. The intensity of the observed signals is enhanced according to the observation time beyond a year to enhance a high signal to noise ratio (SNR)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.11595v2.title: The impact of supernova feedback on the mass-metallicity relations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.11595v2.summary: Metallicity is a fundamental physical property that strongly constrainsgalaxy formation and evolution. The formation of stars in galaxies is suppressed by the energy released from supernova explosions and can be enhanced by metal production. We compare four different feedback methods, ejecting energy inThermal, kinetic, stochastic and mechanical forms.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00303v2.title: SRG/eROSITA catalogue of X-ray active SDSS dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.00303v2.summary: We present a sample of 99 dwarf galaxies with X-ray activity in their central regions. We find that the fraction of AGN among dwarf galaxies drops with the stellar mass of the host galaxy. We report on a tidal disruption event (TDE) candidate, a massive black hole in a dwarf galaxy and a few other peculiar sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05089v2.title: Broad-line region in active galactic nuclei: Dusty or dustless?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.05089v2.summary: We studied the reprocessing of radiation by the BLR. We calculated a range of models using the CLOUDY photoionisation code. We found the incident radiation to be consistent with the radiation seen by the observer. High ionisation lines such as He II, however, clearly form in the inner dustless region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08640v2.title: The X-ray binaries in M83: will any of them form gravitational wave sources for LIGO/VIRGO/KAGRA?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08640v2.summary: There are 214 X-ray point-sources (XRBs) in the nearby spiral galaxy M83. XRBs are powered by accretion onto a neutron star or a black hole from a companion star. These systems are promising progenitors of merging double-compact objects (DCOs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16228v2.title: The second data release from the European Pulsar Timing Array: VI. Challenging the ultralight dark matter paradigm
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.16228v2.summary: Pulsar Timing Array experiments probe the presence of possible scalar orpseudoscalar ultralight dark matter particles through decade-long timing of galactic millisecond radio pulsars. With the second data release, we focus on the most robust scenario, in which dark matter interacts only gravitationally with ordinary baryonic matter. Our results show that ultralights particles with masses $10^{-24.0}~\text{eV} cannot constitute $100\%$ of the measured local dark matter density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16664v1.title: Mapping Observations of Peptide-like molecules around Sagittarius B2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16664v1.summary: Peptide-like molecule, which has a close connection with the origin of life, has been detected in universe. Mapping observations of HCONH$_2$ and CH$_3$CONH $_2$, two simplest peptide- like molecules, are performed towards Sagittarius B2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16651v1.title: Dwarf galaxies show little ISM evolution from $z\sim1$ to $z\sim0$: a spectroscopic study of metallicity, star formation, and electron density
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16651v1.summary: Metallicity is determined through the measurement of emission lines in very deep ($\sim$7 hr exposure)Keck/DEIMOS spectra taken from the HALO7D survey. We measure the dependence of the metallicity on the stellar mass and star formation properties of the galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16643v1.title: Angular Location of the $n^{th}$ Einstein Ring at large $n$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16643v1.summary: We find an analytic expansion for the angular location of the Einstein Ring (at large $n$) resulting from a star that lies directly behind a black hole. The small parameter for this expansion is $e^{-\pi (2n+1) }$ and our formulae are accurate to third order in this parameter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11412v2.title: Stellar mass-metallicity relation throughout the large-scale of the Universe: CAVITY mother sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11412v2.summary: Void galaxies are essential for understanding the physical processes that drive galaxy evolution. They are less affected by external factors than galaxies in denser environments, that is, in filaments, walls, and clusters. The stellar metallicity of a galaxy traces the accumulated fossil record of the starship formation through the entire life of the galaxy. We find that galaxies in voids have slightly lower stellar metallicities on average than those in filament and walls.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16526v1.title: NIKA2 observations of dust grain evolution from star-forming filament to T-Tauri disk: Preliminary results from NIKA2 observations of the Taurus B211/B213 filament
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16526v1.summary: Using the NIKA2 continuum camera on the IRAM 30~mtelescope, we observed the Taurus B211/B213 filament at 1.2/mm and 2/mm with unprecedented sensitivity. The dust emissivity index $beta$ across the filament exhibits a flat profile. This may imply that dust grain sizes are rather homogeneous in the filament, start to grow significantly in size only after the onset of the gravitational contraction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16480v1.title: Exploring the Formation of Resistive Pseudodisks with the GPU Code Astaroth
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16480v1.summary: Pseudodisks are dense structures formed during the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud core. The formation of pseudodisks is physically and numerically robust and can be achieved with a simple and clean setup. Once suitable physics and problem-specific implementations are realized, the GPU-accelerated code is an efficient option for 3-D magnetized collapse problems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16448v1.title: Growth of Massive Molecular Cloud Filament by Accretion Flows I: Slow Shock Instability v.s. Ambipolar Diffusion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16448v1.summary: The Herschel Gould Belt Survey showed that stars form in dense filaments in molecular clouds. Recent studies suggest that massive filaments are bound by the slow shocks caused by accretion flows. The corrugation instability could convert the accretion flow's rampressure into turbulent pressure that influences the width of the filament.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02078v2.title: EMPRESS. XIII. Chemical Enrichments of Young Galaxies Near and Far at z ~ 0 and 4-10: Fe/O, Ar/O, S/O, and N/O Measurements with Chemical Evolution Model Comparisons
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02078v2.summary: We present gas-phase elemental abundance ratios of 7 local extremely metal-poor galaxies (EMPGs) and 33 JWST $z\sim 4-10$ star-forming galaxies. We find that high Fe/O values of EMPGs can (cannot) be explained by PISN metal enrichments. The high N/O ratio reported in GN-z11 cannot be explained even by rotating PISNe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16296v1.title: A Near Magnetic-to-kinetic Energy Equipartition Flare from the Relativistic Jet in AO 0235+164 during 2013-2019
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16296v1.summary: We present the multiwavelength flaring activity of the blazar AO 0235+164during its recent active period from 2013 to 2019. From a discrete correlationfunction (DCF) analysis, we find a significant (>95%) correlation with flares at longer wavelengths following flares at shorter wavelengths. We identify a new jet component in 43 GHz VLBA data that was ejected from the radio core on MJD during the peak of the 2015 radio flare.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16285v1.title: Removing Dust from CMB Observations with Diffusion Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16285v1.summary: In cosmology, the quest for primordial $B$-modes in cosmic microwavebackground (CMB) observations has highlighted the critical need for a refined model of the Galactic dust foreground. We investigate diffusion-based modeling of the dust foreground and its interest for component separation. We show that common summary statistics of the components are well recovered by this process.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16257v1.title: Variable stars in the field of the Galactic bulge globular cluster NGC 6522
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16257v1.summary: We present a comprehensive analysis of the variable stars projected on the Galactic bulge globular cluster NGC 6522. Using proper motions from Gaia DR3, we aim to distinguish between field stars and true cluster members. We detect and discuss the peculiarities of variable stars of the types RR Lyrae, type II Cepheids, Long Period Variables.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05743v5.title: Compact Binary Formation in Open Star Clusters I: High Formation Efficiency of Gaia BHs and Their Multiplicities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05743v5.summary: Gaia BHs, black hole (BH) binaries discovered from database of an astrometrictelescope Gaia, pose a question to the standard binary evolution model. We have performed gravitational$N$-body simulations of $100$ open clusters with $10^5 M_\odot$ in total for each metallicity $Z=0.02$ and $0.005$. We have discovered one Gaia BH-like binary escaping from an open cluster, and found that the formation efficiency of Gaia Bhs in open clusters is larger than in isolated binaries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07371v3.title: A Global Semi-Analytic Model of the First Stars and Galaxies Including Dark Matter Halo Merger Histories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07371v3.summary: We present a new self-consistent semi-analytic model of the first stars and galaxies. Our model includes the detailed mergerhistory of dark matter halos generated with Monte Carlo merger trees. We find an overall increase in the resulting star formation rate density compared to calibrations based on previous simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16227v1.title: Dynamical aspects of Galactic habitability in N-body simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16227v1.summary: Radial migrations are not negligible, even in a simple axisymmetric model with mild levels of dynamical heating. The net outward diffusion of thestellar component can populate galactic outskirts with habitable systems. The present-day stable population of stars in the Solar neighborhood originates from this radial mixing zone.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16223v1.title: How can the optical variation properties of active galactic nuclei be unbiasedly measured?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16223v1.summary: The variability of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) is ubiquitous but has not yet been understood. Measuring the optical variation properties of AGNs has long served as a critical way of exploring the origin of AGN variability and the associated physics of the accretion process in AGNs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12233v2.title: A Comprehensive Investigation of Metals in the Circumgalactic Medium of Nearby Dwarf Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.12233v2.summary: Dwarf galaxies are found to have lost most of their metals via feedbackprocesses. There still lacks consistent assessment on the retentionRate of metals in their circumgalactic medium (CGM) While H I (Ly$\alpha) is ubiquitously detected, we find low detection rates in C II, C IV, Si II, SiIII, and Si IV, largely consistent with literature values.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16116v1.title: Precise Cosmological Constraints from BOSS Galaxy Clustering with a Simulation-Based Emulator of the Wavelet Scattering Transform
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16116v1.summary: We perform a reanalysis of the BOSS CMASS DR12 galaxy dataset using a simulations-based emulator for the Wavelet Scattering Transform (WST) We find that a joint WST + 2-point correlation function likelihood analysis allows us to obtain tighter errors on the CDM parameters that are tighter by a factor of $2.5-6.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16097v1.title: Beware the recent past: a bias in spectral energy distribution modelling due to bursty star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16097v1.summary: We use the Magphys and Prospectorcodes to fit 6,706 synthetic spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of simulatedmassive galaxies. We identify a previously unknown systematic error due to bursty star formation. We urge caution when using Magphys, or other codes assuming parametric SFHs, to study galaxies where the average SFR may have changed significantly.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16093v1.title: The abundance of dark matter haloes down to Earth mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16093v1.summary: We test the Press-Schechter (PS) and Sheth-Tormen (ST) formulae for the haloabundance over the entire mass range. We find that at $z=0$ ST gives the best prediction for the results of L0. The higher resolution levels (L1-L7) are biased regions at underdensities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16089v1.title: Relight the Candle: What happens to High Redshift Massive Quenched Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16089v1.summary: A population of extremely massive quiescent galaxies at redshifts beyond z=3 has recently been revealed by JWST and ALMA. Some of them withstellar ages that show their quenching times to be as high as z=6. These extremely massive yet quenched galaxies challenge our understanding of galaxy formation at the earliest stages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16085v1.title: Blowing out the Candle: How to Quench Galaxies at High Redshift -- an Ensemble of Rapid Starbursts, AGN Feedback and Environment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16085v1.summary: Recent observations with JWST and ALMA have revealed extremely massive                quiescent galaxies at redshifts of z=3 and higher. Using the cosmological simulation suiteMagneticum Pathfinder we reproduce the observed number densities and stellarmasses. We find that these galaxies are quenched through a rapid burst of                star-formation and subsequent AGN feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16086v1.title: Formation of quenched massive galaxies in FIRE cosmological zoom-in simulations with multi-channel AGN feedback
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16086v1.summary: Feedback from supermassive black holes is believed to be a critical driver of the observed quenching of star formation and color bimodality of galaxies above the Milky Way mass scale. We present the first set of FIRE-3 cosmological zoom-in simulations with AGN feedback evolved to examine a set of galaxies with halos in the mass range.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17604v1.title: Characterization of acetonitrile ice irradiated by X-rays employing the PROCODA code: II. Desorption processes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17604v1.summary: In this work, we focus on the study of radiation induced desorption processes that occurred in acetonitrile ice irradiated by broadband X-rays (6 eV to 2.keV) monitored by FTIR spectroscopy at different radiation fluences. In particular, at chemical equilibrium, at almost 98% of the total, the desorbed columndensity represents almost 98%. The species with larger molecular desorptions percentages at chemical. equilibrium are H, CN and CH$_2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17578v1.title: Gravitational lensing for interstellar power transmission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17578v1.summary: The point-spread function (PSF) is affected by the number of lenses in the system and the distances between them. We show that power transmission via a pair of lenses depends on the initial lens, influenced by both its mass and transmitter's position. The second lens plays an important role by focusing the signal to a much smaller spot.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17575v1.title: Synthetic Detections of Interstellar Objects with The Rubin Observatory Legacy Survey of Space and Time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17575v1.summary: 1I/`Oumuamua and 2I/Borisov, imply that a galactic population exists. The LSST should detect between $0-70 asteroidal interstellar objects every year. The apparent rate of motion on the sky appears to be the largest barrier to detecting interstellar objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17542v1.title: The Blanco DECam Bulge Survey (BDBS) VIII: Chemo-kinematics in the southern Galactic bulge from 2.3 million red clump stars with Gaia DR3 proper motions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17542v1.summary: The Blanco DECam Bulge Survey (BDBS) provides near-ultraviolet tonear-infrared photometry for ~250 million unique stars. By combining BDBSphotometry with the latest Gaia astrometry, we characterize the chemo-dynamics of red clump stars across the BDBS footprint. We find that metal-poor red clumping stars exhibit lower rotation than metal-rich stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17535v1.title: The Atacama Cosmology Telescope: Extragalactic Point Sources in the Southern Surveys at 150, 220 and 280 GHz observed between 2008-2010
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17535v1.summary: We present a multi-frequency, multi-epoch catalog of extragalactic sources. The catalog is based on 150, 220 and 280 GHz observations carried out in 2008, 2009 and 2010 using the Millimeter Bolometric Array Camera on the AtacamaCosmology Telescope. We find 374 synchrotron sources and 321 dusty source candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17503v1.title: A Photometric in-depth look at the core-collapsed globular cluster NGC 6284
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17503v1.summary: High-resolution Hubble Space Telescope (HST) optical observations have been used to perform the deepest photometric study of the poorly studiedGalactic globular cluster NGC 6284. The deep colour-magnitude diagram (CMD) reaches 6 magnitudes below the main sequence turn-off. The density profile shows the presence of a steep central cusp, unambiguouslyindicating that the cluster experienced the core-collapse phase. Updated values of the structural parameters and relaxation times of the system are provided.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17409v1.title: MIGHTEE: multi-wavelength counterparts in the COSMOS field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17409v1.summary: In this paper we combine the Early Science radio continuum data from the MeerKAT International GHz Tiered Extragalactic Exploration (MIGHTEE) Survey, with optical and near-infrared data. The radio data used in this work covers $0.86$ deg$^2$ of the COSMOS field, reaches a thermal noise of $1.7$ $\mu$Jy/beam and contains $6102$ radio components.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17396v1.title: The influence of globular cluster evolution on the specific frequency in dwarf galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17396v1.summary: Dwarf galaxies are known to exhibit an unusual richness in numbers ofglobular clusters (GCs) The amount of mass that GC systems lose scales with the mass (and density) of the host galaxy. The GC mass loss efficiency is lowest in low-mass dwarfs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11412v3.title: Stellar mass-metallicity relation throughout the large-scale structure of the Universe: CAVITY mother sample
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.11412v3.summary: Void galaxies are essential for understanding the physical processes that drive galaxy evolution. They are less affected by external factors than galaxies in denser environments, that is, in filaments, walls, and clusters. The stellar metallicity of a galaxy traces the accumulated fossil record of the starship formation through the entire life of the galaxy. We find that galaxies in voids have slightly lower stellar metallicities on average than those in filament and walls.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17211v1.title: On the origin of V-shaped polarisation spectra in molecular clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17211v1.summary: Polarisation degree spectra of molecular clouds show a so-called V-shape. V-shaped spectra can only be obtained if two dust phases, one dense and cold and one warm and dilute, are present along the line of sight. Reducing the alignment efficiency of silicate grains in the cold and dense phase would further improve the match between data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17204v1.title: Cold molecules in HI 21-cm absorbers across redshifts 0.1-4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17204v1.summary: Absorption lines at high redshift in front of quasars are rare in the mmdomain. Only five associated and five intervening systems are known. These bring very useful information complementary to emission lines, for instance, to distinguish between inflows and outflows. They are also good candidates to study variations of the fundamental constants.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17196v1.title: Age Determination of LAMOST Red Giant Branch stars based on the Gradient Boosting Decision Tree method
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17196v1.summary: In this study we estimate the stellar ages of LAMOST DR5 Red Giant Branch(RGB) stars based on the Gradient Boosting Decision Tree algorithm (GBDT) We used 2088 RGB stars extracted from the APOKASC-2 astero-seismological catalog. The test data-set shows that the medianrelative error is around 0.3 $\%$ for the method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19432v2.title: Observational signatures of forming young massive clusters: continuum emission from dense HII regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19432v2.summary: Young massive clusters (YMCs) are the most massive star clusters forming in galaxies. Understanding the formation process of YMCs leads to looking into very efficient star formation in high-redshift galaxies suggested by recent JWST observations. We investigate possible observational signatures of theirformation stage.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17104v1.title: Using two point correlation functions to understand the assembly histories of Milky Way-like galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17104v1.summary: The two point correlation function (2PCF) is a powerful statistical tool to measure galaxy clustering. Galaxies whichsemble late on average have stronger 2PCF signals. We conclude that it is difficult to use 2PCf alone to precisely predict theformation times or assembly histories of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17095v1.title: Evolution of Fullerenes in Circumstellar Envelopes by Carbon Condensation: Insights from Reactive Molecular Dynamics Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17095v1.summary: Fullerenes, including C60 and C70, have been detected in variousastronomical environments. Understanding how their structures evolve over time is essential for gaining insights into their life cycle and making furtherobservations. To examine the impact of these structural changes on the infrared emission characteristics, we performed quantumchemical calculations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17085v1.title: Testing the Surface Brightness Fluctuation Method on Dwarf Galaxies in the COSMOS Field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17085v1.summary: Dwarf galaxies are important tracer of small-scale cosmological structure. Much of our knowledge about these systems comes from a limited sample of galaxies within the Local Group. To make a comprehensive inventory of dwarf populations in the local Universe, we require effective methods for estimating distance estimates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17048v1.title: Probing 3D magnetic fields using thermal dust polarization and grain alignment theory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17048v1.summary: Magnetic fields are ubiquitous in the universe and are thought to play an important role in various astrophysical processes. Polarization of thermal dust.emission from dust grains aligned with the magnetic field is widely used to measure the. two-dimensional magnetic field projected onto the plane of the sky. The component along the line of sight (LOS) is not yet reliably.constrained with dust polarization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17036v1.title: Fundamental MHD scales -- II: the kinematic phase of the supersonic small-scale dynamo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17036v1.summary: Small-scale dynamo (SSD) amplifies weak magnetic fields exponentially fast via kinetic motions. We develop robust methods for measuring kinetic and magnetic energy dissipation scales. We show that compressible SSDs concentrate magnetic energy in large-scale, over-dense structures. We discuss implications for cosmic-ray transport models in the interstellar medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17024v1.title: SPLUS J142445.34-254247.1: An R-Process Enhanced, Actinide-Boost, Extremely Metal-Poor star observed with GHOST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17024v1.summary: SPLUS J142445.34-254247.1 is an extremely metal-poor halo star. It is enhanced in elements formed by the rapid                neutron-capture process. At [Fe/H]=-3.39, it is one of the lowest                metallicity stars with measured Th and has the highest logeps(Th/Eu) observed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04281v2.title: The impact of the Large Magellanic Cloud on dark matter direct detection signals
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.04281v2.summary: We study the effect of the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) on the dark matter(DM) distribution in the Solar neighborhood. We simulate the signals expected in near future xenon, germanium, and silicon direct detection experiments. We find that the presence of the LMC causes a considerable shift in the expected direct detection exclusion limits towards smaller cross sections and DM masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16943v1.title: Illuminating evaporating protostellar outflows: ERIS/SPIFFIER reveals the dissociation and ionization of HH 900
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16943v1.summary: The HH 900outflow is the first example of an evaporating molecular outflow. The study will help guide theinterpretation of near-IR images of externally irradiated jets and outflows in high-mass star-forming regions where these conditions may be common, the authors say.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02372v2.title: Multiwavelength Study of Dark Globule DC 314.8-5.1: Point Source Identification and Diffuse Emission Characterization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02372v2.summary: We present an analysis of multi-wavelength observations of the dark globule DC\,314.8--5.1. The main goal was to identify possible pre-main sequence stars (PMSs) and young stellar objects (YSOs) associated with the globule. We found no 0.5--10\,keV emission down to a luminosity level typical of a PMS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16923v1.title: JWST NIRCam Photometry: A Study of Globular Clusters Surrounding Bright Elliptical Galaxy VV 191a at z=0.0513
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16923v1.summary: James Webb Space Telescope NIRCam images have revealed 443 globular cluster candidates around the $z=0.0513$ elliptical galaxy VV 191a. Models show that the mass estimate of the GCs detected tends to be more massive, reaching upward of $simeq 10% of the mass of the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16913v1.title: Action Principle for Scale Invariance and Applications (Part I)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16913v1.summary: In a two-body system, orbits very slightly expand, while the orbital velocity keeps constant during expansion. Interestingly enough, Kepler's third law is a remarkable scale-invariant property. From the field and geodesic equations, we derive, in current time units (years, seconds), the Newton-like equation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16902v1.title: Spectral reconstruction for radiation hydrodynamic simulations of galaxy evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16902v1.summary: Radiation from stars and AGN plays an important role in galaxy formation and evolution. On-the-fly RT has started being incorporated in cosmological simulations. But the complex,evolving radiation spectra are often crudely approximated with a small number of broad bands with piece-wise constant intensity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16895v1.title: SPICE: the connection between cosmic reionisation and stellar feedback in the first galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16895v1.summary: SPICE is a new suite of RHD cosmological simulations targeting theepoch of reionisation. The goal of these simulations is to systematically probe a variety of stellar feedback models, including "bursty" and "smooth" forms of supernova energy injection. We also explore poorly-explored scenarios such ashypernova explosions and radiation pressure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16892v1.title: A massive multiphase plume of gas in Abell 2390's brightest cluster galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16892v1.summary: New ALMA observations trace molecular gas in Abell 2390's brightest cluster galaxy. Half of the gas is located in a one-sided plume extending 15 kpc out from the galaxy centre. This molecular gas has a smooth and positive velocity gradient and is receding 250 km/s faster at its farthest point than at the galaxy's centre.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16891v1.title: Detecting Detached Black Hole binaries through Photometric Variability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16891v1.summary: The connection between the properties of black holes (BHs) and their progenitors is interesting in many branches of astrophysics. Discovering BHs in detached orbits with luminous companions (LCs) promises to help create this map. The LC and BH progenitor are expected to have the samemetallicity and formation time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16889v1.title: Resolving Horizon-Scale Dynamics of Sagittarius A*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16889v1.summary: Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*) provides unique opportunities to study black hole accretion, jetformation, and gravitational physics. We find an intriguing dynamic feature on April 6th that propagates in a clock-wisedirection. Geometric modelling with ray-tracing, although not fully conclusive, indicates compatibility with high-inclination configurations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16884v1.title: Atomic Hydrogen Shows its True Colours: Correlations between HI and Galaxy Colour in Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16884v1.summary: We examine the clustering of HI in relation to galaxy colour,stellar mass, and HI mass in IllustrisTNG at $z$ = 0, 0.5, and 1.5. We show that HI clustering increases with galaxy HI mass and depends weakly on detection limits. Blue galaxies in the greatest stellar mass bin cluster more than blue galaxies in other bins.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07277v2.title: On the nature of disks at high redshift seen by JWST/CEERS with contrastive learning and cosmological simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07277v2.summary: The first optical rest-frame images from JWST have shown a surprisingly high fraction of disk galaxies at high redshifts. Here, we apply self-supervised machine learning to explore themorphological diversity at $z \geq 3$ We find that the simulated and observed galaxies do not exactly populate the same manifold in the representation space.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16883v1.title: A Lithium Depletion Age for the Carina Association
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.16883v1.summary: Carina Stellar Association is one of the closest stellar associations to Earth. Measurements of its age have previously ranged from 13 to 45 Myr. Age is consistent within uncertainty across six different models, including those that account for magnetic fields and spots. Age agrees with the older end of previous age measurements and is consistent with the lithium depletion age for neighboring Tucana-Horologium Moving Group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18310v1.title: The physical origins of gas in the circumgalactic medium using observationally-motivated TNG50 mocks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18310v1.summary: The gas in the circumgalactic medium (CGM) of galaxies is being probed byabsorbers in the spectrum of background objects in observations. We use the cosmologicalhydrodynamical simulation TNG50 to statistically trace the origins of HILy-$\alpha$ absorbers around galaxies at $z = 0.5.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04492v2.title: Identifying the possible ex-situ origin of the globular clusters of the Milky Way: A kinematic study
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.04492v2.summary: This is the second paper in a series, which studies the likelihood that someglobular clusters (GCs) of the Milky Way could have originated from a dwarf satellite galaxy. We focus on the Magellanic Clouds and Sagittarius. In total, we find 29 (19%) MW GCs which could be kinematicallyassociated with MW DSGs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18258v1.title: The Milky Way in Context: Building an integral-field spectrograph data cube of the Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18258v1.summary: The Milky Way (MW) is by far the best-studied galaxy and has been regarded as an ideal laboratory for understanding galaxy evolution. We present a novel code GalCraft to address these challenges by generating mock integral-field spectrograph data cubes of the MW. The data products are in the same format as externalgalaxies, allowing for direct comparisons.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06486v2.title: The CO-to-H2 conversion factor of molecular outflows. Rovibrational CO emission in NGC 3256-S resolved by JWST/NIRSpec
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.06486v2.summary: We analyze JWST/NIRSpec observations of the CO rovibrational v=1-0 band at 4.67um around the dust-embedded southern active galactic nucleus (AGN) of the galaxy. We model the ratios between the P(J+2) and R(J) transitions of the band to derive the physical properties of the outflowing gas. We find a temperature gradient in the outflow from >40K in the central 100pc to <15K at 250pc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12725v2.title: Scalable stellar evolution forecasting: Deep learning emulation vs. hierarchical nearest neighbor interpolation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.12725v2.summary: Many astrophysical applications require efficient yet reliable forecasts of stellar evolution tracks. The computational costs of running detailed stellar evolution codes are prohibitive. The feedforward neural network regression model can make millions of predictions, within tens of seconds, on a 4-core CPU. The hierarchical nearest-neighbor interpolation algorithm achieves even higher predictions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18210v1.title: Molecular clouds in M51 from high-resolution extinction mapping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18210v1.summary: Cloud growth is promoted in regions in M51 where shear is minimised. In the spiral arms there is a significant decline of cloud surface densities with increasinggalactocentric radius. We propose that the tidal interaction between M51 and its NGC 5195 might be the main factor behind this.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07219v2.title: Smooth kinematic and metallicity gradients reveal that the Milky Way's nuclear star cluster and disc might be part of the same structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.07219v2.summary: The innermost regions of most galaxies are characterised by the presence of extremely dense nuclear star clusters. The Milky Way's centre, at only 8 kpc, hosts a nuclear star cluster and a nuclear stellar disc, constituting a unique template to understand their relation and formation scenario. We aim to study the kinematics and stellar metallicity of stars from the Milky Way’s nuclear star Cluster and disc to shed light on the relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18177v1.title: Reinterpreting Fundamental Plane Correlations with Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18177v1.summary: This work explores the relationships between galaxy sizes and relatedobservable galaxy properties in a large volume cosmological hydrodynamicalsimulation. The objectives of this work are to both develop a better understanding of the correlations between galaxy properties and the influence of environment on galaxy physics. Using projection pursuit regression, the model successfully predicts intrinsic galaxy sizes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.12334v2.title: Towards Physical Understanding of Galaxy-Halo Alignment
http://arxiv.org/abs/2307.12334v2.summary: We investigate the alignment of galaxy and halo orientations using the TNG300-1 hydrodynamical simulation. We demonstrate that the galaxy-ellipticity (GI) correlations of galaxies can be reproduced byperturbing halo Orientations. Grouping galaxies by $F_{\rm{acc}}$ nearly eliminates the dependence of $M V Vir on the 3D misalignment angle.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18172v1.title: Globular clusters and bar: captured or not captured?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18172v1.summary: Study of the dynamics of globular clusters. The choice of barparameters and the way the bar is converted from the bulge introduce systematics into the orbit classifications. We find that the bar pattern speed is a key factor in orbital classification. With an increase of it, frequencies deviate more and more from the "bar" frequency ratio 2:1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18105v1.title: Observing the launch of an Eddington wind in the luminous Seyfert galaxy PG1211+143
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18105v1.summary: The luminous narrow line Seyfert galaxy PG1211+143 was the first non-BAL AGN to reveal a powerful ionized wind. Subsequent observations, mainly with XMM and the JapaneseSUZAKU Observatory, found such winds to be a common feature of luminous AGN. The wind lasted for at least 3 days and delivered some 10 Earth mass of fresh material into the innermost region of the source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18101v1.title: Radial velocities from Gaia BP/RP spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18101v1.summary: The Gaia mission has provided us full astrometric solutions for over $1.5$B purposefullysources. However, only the brightest 34M of those have radial velocity measurements. This paper aims to close that gap by obtaining radial velocity estimates from the low-resolution BP/RP spectra that Gaia now provides.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13466v2.title: Searching for strong gravitational lenses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13466v2.summary: Strong gravitational lenses provide unique laboratories for cosmological andastrophysical investigations. They must first be discovered - a task that can be met with significant contamination by other astrophysical objects andasterisms. Here we review strong lens searches covering various sources, lenses, datasets, and wavelengths. Search techniques are described based on the main lensing feature that is required for the technique to work.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18081v1.title: A near-UV reconnaissance of metal-poor massive stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18081v1.summary: We use synthetic model spectra to investigate the potential of of near-ultraviolet observations of massive O-type stars. We present performance estimates for observations ofextragalactic massive stars with the Cassegrain U-Band Efficient Spectrograph now in construction for the Very Large Telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v4.title: The Quasar Feedback Survey: characterising CO excitation in quasar host galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.10235v4.summary: 17 Type 2quasars at $z <$ 0.2 from the Quasar Feedback Survey. We measure the total molecular gas content using the CO(1-0) emission and homogeneously sample the CO spectralline energy distributions (SLEDs) The ionised gas traced by [OIII] exhibit systematically higher velocities than that traced by CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11602v2.title: Chemodynamical models of our Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11602v2.summary: The model is defined by action-based distribution functions for dark matter and six stellar components plus a gas disc. The gravitational potential jointly generated by the model's components is used to examine the galaxy's chemical composition. The overwhelming majority of stars have angular momentum J_\phi>0 implying that they were born in the Galactic disc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18002v1.title: Radio outburst from a massive (proto)star. II. A portrait in space and time of the expanding radio jet from S255 NIRS3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18002v1.summary: The accretion process in star formation may occur through accretion outbursts. This phenomenon has also now been detected in a few young massive (proto)stars. The recent outburst at radiowavelengths of S255 NIRS3 has been interpreted as expansion of a thermal jet, fed by infalling material.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18000v1.title: Less is less: photometry alone cannot predict the observed spectral indices of $z\sim1$ galaxies from the LEGA-C spectroscopic survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18000v1.summary: The Large Galaxy Astrophysics Census (LEGA-C) provides high-quality optical spectra of thousands of galaxies. Broad-band photometry of the same galaxies is used to predict the spectral energy distribution. The global bimodality of star-forming and quiescent galaxies in photometric space is recovered with the model spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17970v1.title: The role of turbulence in high-mass star formation: Subsonic and transonic turbulence are ubiquitously found at early stages
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17970v1.summary: Turbulence is considered to be one of the most likely mechanisms to slow down the gravitational collapse in dense clumps, enabling the formation of massive stars. Recent studies have raised differing points of view based on observations carried out with sufficiently high spatial and spectral resolution. Our results suggest that turbulence is a prevalent feature of massive star-forming regions and those cold regions are at early evolutionary stage.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17947v1.title: Time Variation of Fine-Structure Constant Constrained by [O III] Emission-Lines at 1.1<z<3.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17947v1.summary: The spin-orbit doublet is often the strongest narrow emission lines in starburst galaxies and quasi-stellar objects. Previous studies using QSOs optical spectra were limited to $z<1$. Extensive tests indicate that $\alpha$ variation could be better constrained using starburst. galaxies' spectra than QSO spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17939v1.title: JWST Reveals Widespread AGN-Driven Neutral Gas Outflows in Massive z ~ 2 Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17939v1.summary: We use deep JWST/NIRSpec R~1000 slit spectra of 113 galaxies at 1.7 < z < 3.5. Half of the absorption profiles are at least 100 km/s, providing unambiguous evidence for neutral gas outflows. Galaxies with strong Na I D absorption are distinguished byenhanced emission line ratios consistent with AGN ionization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07907v2.title: The Pristine survey -- XXII. A serendipitous discovery of an extremely Li-rich very metal-poor giant and a new method of $^6$Li/$^7$Li isotope measurement
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.07907v2.summary: We report the serendipitous discovery of a very metal-poor (VMP) Li-rich giant star. We analyse the Li I 6103 and 6707 \r{A} lines accounting for departures from local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) and correcting for 3Deffects. We also derive NLTE abundances for 16 elements, most of which show similar abundances to those found in VMP stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17916v1.title: On the existence of a tight planar relation between stellar specific angular momentum, mass and effective surface brightness for ALFALFA galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17916v1.summary: Measurements of the dependence of stellar specific angular momentum ($j_*$) on stellar mass ($M_*) are presented for large samples of ALFALFA galaxies. Accurate estimates of $j*$ are generated using measurements of $I$-band effectiveradius and velocity width of the HI line profile.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17908v1.title: On the Doublet Flux Ratio of Mg II Resonance Lines in and Around Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17908v1.summary: Study explores effects of resonant scattering on the Mg II doublet lines and the stellar continuum in spherical andcylindrical geometries. Under certain circumstances, scattering can cause an increase in the doublet flux ratio. These results may provide a valuable insight regarding the complexity of the shape and orientation of distant, spatially-unresolved galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01782v2.title: J0107a: A Barred Spiral Dusty Star-forming Galaxy at $z=2.467$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.01782v2.summary: Dusty Star-Forming Galaxies (DSFGs) are amongst the most massive and activestar-forming galaxies during the cosmic noon. Theoretical studies have proposed various formation mechanisms of DSFGs, including major merger-driven starbursts and secular star-forming disks. We report J0107a, a bright DSFG at $z=2.467$ that appears to be a gas-rich massive disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06321v3.title: GTC Follow-up Observations of Very Metal-Poor Star Candidates from DESI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06321v3.summary: The observations from the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) will significantly increase the numbers of known extremely metal-poor stars. The analysis of the data using a well-vetted methodology confirms the quality of the DESI spectra and the pipelines developed for the data reduction and analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17866v1.title: Wavelength Dependences of the Optical/UV and X-ray Luminosity Correlations of Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17866v1.summary: Inter-band correlations between optical/UV and X-ray luminosities of active galactic nuclei are important for understanding the disc-coronalconnection. We adopt a well-defined sample of 1169 unobscured quasars in the redshift range 0.13 - 4.51. We find that the luminosity at all UVcontinuum wavelengths correlates with the X-rays similarly to that at rest frame 2500 \AA.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05858v2.title: Loss Cone Shielding
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05858v2.summary: A star wandering close enough to a massive black hole (MBH) can be ripped apart by the tidal forces of the black hole. Classical loss cone theoryocuses on the cumulative effect of many weak scatterings. However, a strong scattering can remove a star from the distribution before it can get tidally disrupted.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17725v1.title: Gaps in the Main-Sequence of Star Cluster Hertzsprung Russell Diagrams
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17725v1.summary: The presence of gaps or regions of small numbers of stars in the mainsequence of the Hertzsprung Russell Diagram (HRD) of star clusters has beenreported in literature. This is interesting and significant as it could berelated to star formation and/or rapid evolution or instabilities. In this paper we explore theHRD of nine open clusters with reported gaps, identify them and assess their importance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17717v1.title: Stored in the archives: Uncovering the CN/CO intensity ratio with ALMA in nearby U/LIRGs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17717v1.summary: We present an archival Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) study of the CN N = 1 - 0 / CO J = 1-0 intensity ratio in nearby (z < 0.05)Ultra Luminous and Luminous Infrared Galaxies (U/LIRGs) We identify sixteen U/LirGs that have been observed in both CN and CO lines at 500 pcresolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17707v1.title: Natal Kicks from the Galactic Center and Implications on their Environment and the Roman Space Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17707v1.summary: Most galaxies, including the Milky Way, harbor a central supermassive blackhole. Neutron stars and possibly black holes receive large natalkicks at birth on the order of hundreds of km. The natal kicks thatoccur in the vicinity of an SMBH may redistribute the orbital configuration of compact objects and alter their underlying density distribution. Different black hole kick prescriptions lead to distinct spatial andkinematic distributions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17701v1.title: Confirmation of a Substantial Discrepancy between Radio and UV--IR Measures of the Star Formation Rate Density at 0.2 < z < 1.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17701v1.summary: We present the initial sample of redshifts for 3,839 galaxies in the MeerKATDEEP2 field -- the deepest $\sim$1.4\,GHz radio field yet observed. The resulting radio luminosity functions between $0.2<z<1.3$ are in remarkable agreement with those inferred from radio source counts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17694v1.title: Where do stars explode in the ISM? -- The distribution of dense gas around massive stars and supernova remnants in M33
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17694v1.summary: Star formation in galaxies is regulated by turbulence, outflows, gas heating and cloud dispersal. This depends sensitively on the properties of the interstellar medium (ISM) into which supernovae (SNe) explode. Direct measurements of ISM environments around SNe remainscarce, as SNe are rare and often distant.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17692v1.title: Unraveling Jet Quenching Criteria Across L* Galaxies and Massive Cluster Ellipticals
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.17692v1.summary: Without additional heating, radiative cooling of the halo gas of massive galaxies produces cold gas or stars exceeding that observed. Heating from AGN jets is likely required, but the jet characteristics remain unclear. We find that scaling the jet energy according to the free-fall energy at the cooling radius can successfully suppress the cooling flows and quench galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03832v2.title: The Evolution of Inclined Binary Black Holes in the Disks of Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.03832v2.summary: Embedded neutron stars and black holes may form binaries and merge, emitting gravitational waves detectable by LIGO/VIRGO. AGN disks are a promising environment for the production of high-mass gravitational wave events involving black holes in the pair instability massgap. However, many orders of magnitude separate the typical length scales of binary formation and those on which gravitational waves can drive binaryinspirals.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11717v2.title: On the Lifetime of Molecular Clouds with the "Tuning-Fork" Analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2308.11717v2.summary: The "tuning-fork" analysis of CO and Halpha emission has been used to estimate the lifetimes of molecular clouds in nearby galaxies. We show that this analysis does not necessarily estimate cloud lifetimes, but instead captures a duration of the cloud evolutionarycycle. We adopt a hypothetical setup in which molecular clouds (e.g., traced in CO) live forever and form stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.19164v1.title: Industrial-Scale Mass Measurements of Isolated Black Holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.19164v1.summary: Mass measurement of isolated black holes (BHs) can be achieved by combining a high-cadence, wide-field microlensing survey and VLTI interferometry. I show that the combination of ground-based and space-based light curves of BH events will automatically exclude the spurious "large parallax" solutions that arise from the standard analysis. The remaining two-fold degeneracy can always bebroken by conducting a second VL TI measurement.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.19107v1.title: Where have all the low-metallicity galaxies gone? Tracing evolution in the mass--metallicity plane since a redshift of 0.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.19107v1.summary: Galaxies have evolved significantly in their location in the mass-metallicity plane, which must be telling us something about the latter stages of galaxy evolution. Galaxies already on the present-day mass--metalicity relation rapidlyform few more stars and their disks fade, so they become smaller and morebulge-like. By contrast, the high-mass low- Metallicity galaxies grow their their disks through late star formation, and evolve rapidly to higher metallicities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11946v3.title: A JWST/NIRSpec First Census of Broad-Line AGNs at z=4-7: Detection of 10 Faint AGNs with M_BH~10^6-10^8 M_sun and Their Host Galaxy Properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11946v3.summary: We present a first statistical sample of faint type-1 AGNs at $z>4$identified by JWST/NIRSpec deep spectroscopy. The AGNs have low-mass black holes with remarkably lower than those of low-luminosity quasars previously identified with ground-based telescopes. Such faint AGNs contribute to cosmicipientreionization, while the total contribution is not large because of their faint nature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03557v3.title: Shape asymmetries and the relation between lopsidedness and radial alignment in simulated galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03557v3.summary: Galaxies are observed to be lopsided, meaning that they are more massive and more extended along one direction than the opposite. We provide aistical analysis of the lopsider morphology of 1780 isolated satellitegalaxies generated by TNG50-1 simulation, incorporating the effect of tidalfields from halo centres. According to our results, the RA is virtually undetectable ininner and intermediate regions, yet it is significantly evident in outer regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18837v1.title: Pair Plasma Cascade in Rotating Black Hole Magnetospheres with Split Monopole Flux Model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18837v1.summary: An electron-positron cascade in the magnetospheres of Kerr Black Holes (BH) is a fundamental ingredient to fueling the relativistic $\gamma$-ray jets seen at the polar regions of galactic supermassive BHs. This leptonic cascadeoccurs in the "spark gap" region of a BH magnetosphere.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18817v1.title: The Low-redshift Lyman Continuum Survey: Radio continuum properties of low-$z$ Lyman continuum emitters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18817v1.summary: The sources that leak Lyman-continuum (LyC) photons are intensely studied using multiple observing facilities. We present KarlG. Jansky Very Large Array RC observations at C (4-8 GHz), S (2-4 GHz) and L (1-2 GHz) bands for a sub-sample of the LzLCS sources. The radio spectral index spans a wide range from being flat (0.1$) to very steep ($\leq -1.0$) We find that the strongest leakers in the sample show flat spectra.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04467v2.title: A search for faint resolved galaxies beyond the Milky Way in DES Year 6: A new faint, diffuse dwarf satellite of NGC 55
http://arxiv.org/abs/2309.04467v2.summary: We report results from a systematic wide-area search for faint dwarf galaxies at heliocentric distances from 0.3 to 2 Mpc. Unlike previous searches over the DES data, this search specifically targeted a field population of faint galaxies located beyond the Milky Way virial radius. We find no new field dwarfs in the DES footprint, but we report the discovery of one high-significance candidate dwarf galaxy. This is the largest, most diffuse galaxy known at this luminosity, suggesting possible tidal interactions with its host.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18597v1.title: Polar-ring galaxies in the Illustris TNG50 simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18597v1.summary: Polar-ring galaxies (PRGs) are galaxies with misaligned kinematics where a typically red central galaxy is surrounded by a disk of stars, gas and dust oriented almost perpendicular to the main body. It is believed that polar structures are formed in asecondary event after the assembly of a central galaxy, but due to their scarcity, their formation paths are not well constrained.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18584v1.title: Investigating scaling relations in X-ray reverberating AGN using symbolic regression
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18584v1.summary: Symbolic regression (SR) is a regression analysis based on genetic algorithms. We use the SR to analyze the relations of the X-ray reverberating Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) where the soft Fe-L lags were observed by XMM-Newton. We find that the SR model supports a non-linear $M BH --$M ast relationship.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18575v1.title: The Milky Way Bulge extra-tidal star survey: BH 261 (AL 3)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18575v1.summary: The Milky Way Bulge extra-tidal star survey (MWBest) is a spectroscopic survey with the goal of identifying stripped globular cluster stars. We observed andanalyzed stars in and around BH 261, an understudied globular Cluster. Stars with 3D velocities and metallicities consistent with BH261 are identified.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18560v1.title: Interpretable machine learning for finding intermediate-mass black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18560v1.summary: Machine learning (ML) models trained on GC simulations can in principle predict IMBH host candidates based on observablefeatures. This approach has two limitations: first, an accurate ML model isexpected to be a black box due to complexity. Second, despite our efforts to simulate GCs, the simulation physics or initial conditions mayfail to fully reflect reality.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18557v1.title: Time-Dependent AGN Disc Winds I -- X-ray Irradiation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18557v1.summary: We study AGN line driven disc winds using time-dependent radiation hydrodynamics. In a pure attenuation model, the disclaunches an episodic wind, as previous studies have shown. Including scatteringor re-emission tends to weaken the wind, lowering the mass flux and outflow velocity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13125v2.title: ALMA-IMF IX: Catalog and Physical Properties of 315 SiO Outflow Candidates in 15 Massive Protoclusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.13125v2.summary: We present a catalog of 315 protostellar outflow candidates detected in SiO J=5-4 in the ALMA-IMF Large Program. Median outflow lifetimes are 6,000 years. We find correlations between field-aggregated outflow properties and total mass in cores (~3$-$5$\sigma$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18478v1.title: Cross-correlation between the thermal Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect and the Integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18478v1.summary: We present a joint cosmological analysis of the power spectra measurement of the Planck Compton parameter and the integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) maps. We find that the ISW-tSZ cross-correlation is capable of probing the properties of the large-scale diffuse gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14312v2.title: Bridging the Gap between Cosmic Dawn and Reionization favors Faint Galaxies-dominated Models
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14312v2.summary: It has been claimed that traditional models struggle to explain the tentativedetection of the 21\,cm absorption trough centered at $z\sim17$ measured by EDGES. On the other hand, it has been shown that the EDGESresults are consistent with an extrapolation of a declining UV luminositydensity, following a simple power-law of deep Hubble Space Telescope observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18464v1.title: JADES: Using NIRCam Photometry to Investigate the Dependence of Stellar Mass Inferences on the IMF in the Early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18464v1.summary: Using local forms of the initial mass function (IMF) toestimate stellar masses of these galaxies from their light output leads to galaxy masses that are at the limit allowed for the state of the LambdaCDMUniverse at their redshift. We demonstrate that models with stellar masses reduced by a factor of three or more do not affect the modeled spectral energy distribution (SED)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18462v1.title: The motivation for flexible star-formation histories from spatially resolved scales within galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18462v1.summary: The estimation of galaxy stellar masses depends on the assumed prior of the star-formation history (SFH) and the spatial scale of the analysis. We connect the prescriptionof the SFH in the Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) fitting to spatially grotesqueresolved scales to shed light on the systematics involved.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18426v1.title: Age-dating the young open cluster UBC 1 with g-mode asteroseismology, gyrochronology, and isochrone fitting
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18426v1.summary: UBC 1 is an open cluster discovered in Gaia data and located near the edge of the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite's (TESS) continuous viewing zone. We provide age constraints for this poorly studied open cluster from thecombination of gravity-mode (g-mode) asteroseismology, gyrochronology, and isochrone fitting.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08636v2.title: Modelling Stochastic Star Formation History of Dwarf Galaxies in GRUMPY
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.08636v2.summary: Bursty star formation increases the scatter in the colour-magnitude distribution for brighter dwarf galaxies. But not for fainter ones, for which scatter remains significantly smaller than observed. This is due to predominant old stellar populations in these faint model galaxies and their declining SFR over the past 10 years.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18407v1.title: Resolved low-J $^{12}$CO excitation at 190 parsec resolution across NGC 2903 and NGC 3627
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18407v1.summary: Low-$J$ rotational transitions are commonly used to trace the distribution of molecular gas in galaxies. Their ratios are sensitive toexcitation and physical conditions in the molecular gas. We measure median line ratios across the disk of two massive, star-forming galaxies NGC2903 and NGC3627 to investigate whether and how local environments drive excitation variations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18406v1.title: An ensemble study of turbulence in extended QSO nebulae at $z\approx0.5$--1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18406v1.summary: Chen et al. (2023b) measured the velocity structure functions (VSFs) of four quasar nebulae. One of these exhibits a spectacular Kolmogorov relation. No discernible differences are observed between radio-loud and radio-quiet QSO fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18405v1.title: Are nonrelativistic ground state $\ell$-boson stars only stable for $\ell=0$ and $\ell=1$?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18405v1.summary: In previous work we analyzed the linear stability of non-relativistic$\ell$-boson stars with respect to radial modes. In this work we extend the analysis to non-spherical linear modeperturbations. By using a combination of analytic and numericalmethods, we show that ground state configurations with $\ell > 1$ possessexponentially in time growing non-radial modes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18395v1.title: Undermassive Host Galaxies of Five z~6 Luminous Quasars Detected with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18395v1.summary: We measure host galaxy stellar masses for a sample of five luminous quasars. Using JWST/NIRCam medium-band images of nearby PSF reference stars, we carefully subtract the contribution from the quasar light to place upper and lower limits on the flux of each host galaxy. We find that the members of our sample of quasar host galaxies have masses of $10.7 - 10.8 M.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18396v1.title: Circumnuclear Multi-phase Gas in the Circinus Galaxy. V. The Origin of the X-Ray Polarization in the Circinus Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18396v1.summary: The Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer (IXPE) detected X-rays in the Circinus galaxy for the first time. The degree of polarization based on two types of radiative hydrodynamic simulations was based on a parsec-scale three-dimensional model and a sub-parsec- scale axisymmetric model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18392v1.title: Shock cooling and breakout emission for optical flares associated with gravitational wave events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2310.18392v1.summary: The astrophysical origin of stellar-mass black hole (BH) mergers discovered through gravitational waves (GWs) is widely debated. Mergers in the disks ofactive galactic nuclei (AGN) represent promising environments for at least a small fraction of these events. An additional clue to unveil AGN merger environments is provided by possibleelectromagnetic emission from post-merger accreting BHs.
